{"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "In the Knavses\u2019 case, Mrs. Trump, who became a citizen in 2006 after obtaining a green card, would have sponsored them.\n\n\u201cIt would be odd if she sponsored her parents and didn\u2019t want to talk about that because it\u2019s a fairly routine thing,\u201d said Hiroshi Motomura, a law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, who specializes in immigration law. \u201cIt only becomes sensitive if her husband is taking a position against this.\u201d\n\nBoth of Mrs. Trump\u2019s parents have been seen at White House events, celebrated Thanksgiving at Mar-a-Lago, Mr. Trump\u2019s Florida estate, and reportedly spend much of their time with the Trump family. Questions about their immigration status were raised in recent months as the administration emphasized stricter immigration reform.\n\nAbout seven million of the 11 million immigrants who obtained green cards between 2007 and 2016 did so through familial relations, according to data from the Department of Homeland Security.\n\n\u201cIn some ways, lawful permanent resident status is the best of all visas,\u201d said Kevin R. Johnson, the dean of the law school at the University of California, Davis, who has taught immigration law. \u201cIt\u2019s the Cadillac of immigrant visas because it allows you a path to citizenship.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Mr. Trump has vilified the program as a way for terrorists to enter the United States and has called for aspects of the program to be eliminated as part of immigration reform.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCHAIN MIGRATION must end now!\u201d he wrote on Twitter in November. \u201cSome people come in, and they bring their whole family with them, who can be truly evil. NOT ACCEPTABLE!\u201d\n\nIt also might have been possible, Mr. Johnson said, for the Knavses, both in their 70s, to obtain residency through an investment visa or a work visa, although the latter would involve employer sponsorship. Mr. Knavs, a former traveling car salesman, and Mrs. Knavs, who used to design patterns for children\u2019s clothes, both appear to be retired.\n\nImmigrants can also apply for asylum or enter the diversity lottery, a path that offers limited numbers of visas. Mr. Trump has also criticized the diversity lottery, which allows admission to immigrants from countries that do not send many people to the United States.\n\n\u201cIf somebody came to me and asked me how to become a citizen, the first question I would ask is \u2018Do you have an American citizen as a relative?\u2019\u201d said Theresa Cardinal Brown, the director of immigration and cross-border policy at the Bipartisan Policy Center in Washington. \u201cThat is the fastest and most direct route to getting a green card.\u201d\n\nIn his State of the Union address, Mr. Trump described a four-pillar immigration plan and continued to criticize the family-based immigration program, eliciting boos from Democrats in the chamber.\n\n\u201cUnder the current broken system, a single immigrant can bring in virtually unlimited numbers of distant relatives,\u201d he said. \u201cThis vital reform is necessary, not just for our economy, but for our security, and our future.\u201d", "title": "Questions Swirl as Melania Trump\u2019s Parents Obtain Green Cards", "authors": ["Emily Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Stretch added that this content was a smidgen of the total content available across Facebook:\n\n\u201cThis equals about four-thousandths of 1 percent (0.004 percent) of content in News Feed, or approximately one out of 23,000 pieces of content.\u201d\n\nAnd on Friday, Rob Goldman, Facebook\u2019s vice president for ads, noted that more than half of the Russian Facebook ads (56 percent) were served after the 2016 election.\n\nQuoting tiny fractions suggests content on Facebook gets drowned out in a torrent of information. But the company\u2019s whole business model is based on giving ads and posts prominence in the feeds of well-targeted users.\n\nQuestions for Facebook:\n\nHas Facebook performed any analyses that looks at smaller groups of people? If so, can Facebook share them? And how did the ads perform before and after the election?\n\nTo what extent did Russia target swing states?\n\nMr. Mueller\u2019s latest indictment says that, after the middle of 2016, Russians often talked about targeting \u201cpurple states,\u201d or those in which the number of Republican and Democratic voters are close. The indictment also describes the Russians as focused on Florida, which Mr. Trump ended up winning.\n\n\u201cOn or about August 4, 2016, Defendants and their co-conspirators created and purchased Facebook advertisements for the \u2018Florida Goes Trump\u2019 rally. The advertisements reached over 59,000 Facebook users in Florida, and over 8,300 Facebook users responded to the advertisements by clicking on it.\u201d\n\nOthers have asserted in the past that Russia did not appear to focus its social media efforts on swing states. As Senator Richard Burr, Republican of North Carolina and chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, noted last year:\n\n\u201cWhat you haven\u2019t heard is that almost five times more ads were targeted at Maryland than Wisconsin. Maryland, which was targeted by 262 ads in comparison to Wisconsin\u2019s 55, wasn\u2019t up for grabs; it was a state the Democratic candidate carried by 26 percent.\u201d\n\nQuestions for Facebook:\n\nDo the company\u2019s records show that Russia-backed ads and posts reached a higher number of people in certain states or regions of the United States? If so, how responsive were Facebook users in those targeted regions to the Russian posts and ads?\n\nThe Russia-backed groups were incredibly successful at gaining followers.\n\nJonathan Albright, research director at the Tow Center for Digital Journalism at Columbia, has done revealing work on Facebook\u2019s Russia-linked pages that is more detailed than anything the company has made public. Mr. Albright\u2019s data, obtained using CrowdTangle, an analytics tool owned by Facebook, shows the speed with which the Russia-backed groups grew.\n\nBlacktivist, a Russia-linked group whose often inflammatory content set it apart from legitimate groups championing African-American rights, had 14,000 followers at the end of 2015. By the time its Facebook page was shut down last year, it had 390,000, according to Mr. Albright\u2019s data \u2014 a hugely successful ramp up that took Blacktivist\u2019s total followers above that for Black Lives Matter. Other Russian-created groups, like Heart of Texas, also showed huge increases in followers.\n\nQuestions for Facebook:\n\nHow exactly were these groups able to scoop up so many members so quickly? Did the speed of the increases wave any red flags internally at Facebook? To what extent did Facebook\u2019s ad targeting tools, which allow advertisers to reach specific groups of people, enable Russia to put incendiary posts in the feeds of certain groups? And one from Mr. Albright: What were the follower totals and other data for any private Facebook pages that were backed by the Russians?\n\nWhy this issue isn\u2019t going away for Facebook.\n\nIt may well be the case that Russian disinformation did not swing the election for Mr. Trump. But it may have had far more of an impact than the public knows. And Facebook is almost certainly sitting on data that could deepen the nation\u2019s understanding of what went on.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t imagine what it would it look like if we had all the data,\u201d Mr. Albright said.", "title": "Questions for Facebook About Russia\u2019s Use of Its Network", "authors": ["Peter Eavis"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201cN.R.A. Chief Denounces \u2018Politicization\u2019 of Tragedy\u201d (news article, Feb. 23), Wayne LaPierre, the head of the National Rifle Association, presented his version of what freedom means.\n\nPresident Franklin D. Roosevelt, in his address to Congress on Jan. 6, 1941, defined his now-famous \u201cFour Freedoms,\u201d one of which was freedom from fear. Though that declamation was used in the context of international relations, anyone of good conscience would say that if a child cannot go to school without fearing for his or her life, then that is not freedom.\n\nMr. LaPierre has to decide whose freedom is more important: the freedom of our schoolchildren and all others who use our public spaces, or the freedom of gun owners who would recklessly invade those spaces.\n\nIf put to a vote, I think that most of our citizens would say that the freedom of our students to study without fear takes priority.", "title": "Opinion | Questions for the N.R.A. and Its Members", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "MADRID \u2014 Enrique Castro Gonz\u00e1lez, a prolific Spanish soccer player known as Quini who was also remembered for being kidnapped at gunpoint in a case that unsettled the nation, died on Tuesday in Gij\u00f3n, on the northern coast of Spain. He was 68.\n\nHis death was confirmed by Sporting de Gij\u00f3n, the club with which he had two stints as a player and for which he continued to work as an official after retiring in 1987.\n\nHe was reported to have had a heart attack while walking along a street near his home in Gij\u00f3n, a port city in the Asturias region. Now it will be showcased in the pop-up store that the house is opening in the Miami Design District for the luxury timepiece event.\n\nAfter all, the Swiss brand is no stranger to pop culture themes, with its Generational Icons line featuring the likes of Pac-Man, Super Mario Bros. and Batman. \u201cWe like the idea of having a dream and iconic characters,\u201d Marco Tedeschi, the company\u2019s new chief executive, said. \u201cI think nostalgia is important in people\u2019s lives.\u201d\n\nThe RJ x Spider-Man model is based on the brand\u2019s Skylab design, which merges a classic round shape with contemporary touches like a steel case with a black PVD (physical vapor deposition) coating and an in-house skeleton movement with three parallel bridges. The balance wheel is visible on the dial side, which features a graphic red lacquer Spider-Man logo with a subtle retro look that also functions as the bridge holding the minute and hour wheels. The sapphire glass caseback is also engraved with a metalized web. Limited to 75 pieces, the 48-millimeter watch is priced at $19,500.\n\nSpider-Man is the house\u2019s first real superhero ambassador, Mr. Tedeschi said, with a hint of millennial-like enthusiasm. (Indeed, the 32-year-old, a former Hublot executive who started his job on S.I.H.H.\u2019s opening day, was nicknamed the \u201cmillennial C.E.O.\u201d during the fair.)\n\nThe partnership with Marvel will allow Romain Jerome, a relatively young house at just 14, to tap into the more than 8,000 characters belonging to Marvel\u2019s parent, the Walt Disney Company.\n\nBut Mr. Tedeschi noted that the RJ x Spider-Man watch isn\u2019t only for the young: Initial owners range from 5- to 60-year-olds. Yet the typical wearer is \u201cdefinitely a trendsetter,\u201d he said. \u201cSomebody who follows design and does not like to buy a watch his father used to buy for himself.\u201d MING LIU", "title": "RJ x Spider-Man: Marvel Moves Into Watches", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "In January, you became the first woman nominated for an Oscar for best cinematography, for your work on \u201cMudbound.\u201d Did you know that it was going to be a male-dominated profession when you first started out? I don\u2019t know that I was entirely conscious of it, because I started in photography, which is closer to 50-50. There\u2019s this idea that there are more female cinematographers now because cameras are lighter, which is the stupidest thing I\u2019ve ever heard. Cinematography speaks to everything that women do inherently well: It\u2019s multitasking, it\u2019s empathy and it\u2019s channeling visuals into human emotion. Little by little, I realized that I was an anomaly, but I tried not to focus on it, or to, at least, see it as a way to stand out in the crowd and bring something to the table that most people don\u2019t.\n\nWhat movies did you first see that made you think about cinematography? I gravitate much more toward realism realism in the work that I do, but magical realism got me hooked on film. I think it was my first time realizing that there was something besides popcorn movies. I caught the Jean-Pierre Jeunet and Marc Caro bug: \u201cDelicatessen,\u201d \u201cThe City of Lost Children.\u201d Wong Kar-wai\u2019s \u201cChungking Express,\u201d \u201cHappy Together\u201d and \u201cFallen Angels.\u201d Emir Kusturica\u2019s \u201cTime of the Gypsies\u201d and \u201cBlack Cat, White Cat.\u201d It was a reflection of the literature I liked: Gabriel Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez and Salman Rushdie.\n\n\u201cMudbound\u201d feels like a very timely movie, with its focus on racism and rural poverty. When I read the script, Obama was president. We didn\u2019t ever think in a million years Trump would get elected. I thought it was timeless, but I didn\u2019t realize it would be as timely as it ultimately proved to be.", "title": "Rachel Morrison Wants More Women Behind the Camera", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The AR-15 that the Kent fire department was raffling off complied with New York State law. Semiautomatic weapons like the AR-15 can still be sold with 10-round magazines in New York as long as they do not include some key features, including a pistol grip, a muzzle flash suppressor and a collapsible stock.\n\nAn employee at Precision Armory, a firearms store in nearby Carmel, said that the stripped-down AR-15 was favored for target practice and also hunting nuisance animals. \u201cIt\u2019s very good for coyotes and stuff like that,\u201d said the employee, who asked that his name be withheld since his shop did not sell the weapons to the fire department.\n\nMs. Bolbrock of the fire department said the meeting on Monday became heated. \u201cThere was shouting,\u201d she said. \u201cThere were people talking over people. There were mothers saying they were worried about their children.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, the fire department had a slight change of heart: It decided to award gift certificates, in the value of the two guns, from a local gun shop, rather than the guns themselves.\n\nThe department\u2019s about-face was so sudden that Andy Irvin, the local schools superintendent, had not heard about it until he was informed by The New York Times.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m thrilled they are changing the prize,\u201d said Mr. Irvin, who oversees the Carmel Central School District, which draws 4,400 students from Kent and neighboring towns. \u201cAnd I would have said that three weeks ago. I\u2019m just angry that it\u2019s only now that these conversations have ramped back up to the level they have. I still don\u2019t understand how it fell off the radar after Newtown.\u201d\n\nHe said he was disappointed that New York State continued to allow the sale of a semiautomatic like the simplified AR-15. \u201cI don\u2019t think there is any room for semiautomatic weapons,\u201d he said. \u201cTo me, whether it\u2019s semiautomatic or assault, nothing that falls into those categories should be legitimate. Once you buy it legally, the modifications can be done by anybody. I guarantee you there are YouTube videos.\u201d", "title": "Raffle Off an AR-15? A N.Y. Fire Department Reconsiders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "For more than a year, Mario Pesantez said, he was told to report to work by climbing over a tall, chain-link fence that separates the streets of Glendale, Queens, from a yard used by his employer, the New York & Atlantic Railway.\n\nOnce inside he joined a group of Mexican, Ecuadorean and Dominican men who said they routinely spent 12- to 14-hour shifts working on sections of the Long Island Rail Road that New York & Atlantic had leased to transport freight. The men said they righted derailed trains, maintained switches and cut thick railroad ties, earning much less than white co-workers while being denied safety equipment and training.\n\nWhenever federal or state rail inspectors showed up, they said, supervisors ordered those who had climbed the fence to hide, sometimes yelling that \u201cfederales\u201d had arrived.\n\n\u201cWe felt embarrassed,\u201d Mr. Pesantez said, speaking through a Spanish-language translator as he sat at a table with a dozen other former New York & Atlantic workers. \u201cWe felt ashamed, we felt humiliated.\u201d", "title": "Railway Workers Sue, Citing Discrimination and Low Pay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Analysts estimate that as many as 5,000 family members of foreign terrorist recruits are now marooned in camps and orphanages in Iraq and Syria. Russia and Georgia are in the forefront of countries helping family members to return, said Liesbeth van der Heide, the co-author of \u201cChildren of the Caliphate,\u201d a study published last summer by the International Center for Counter-Terrorism in The Hague.\n\nAs Mr. Sabsabi acknowledged, many, if not most, of the returning children were exposed to unspeakable acts of macabre violence, including roles in execution videos. Many children were desensitized to violence through ceaseless indoctrination, paramilitary training and participation in various other crimes.\n\nGermany\u2019s domestic intelligence chief, Hans-Georg Maassen, told Reuters the children of the Islamic State were \u201cbrainwashed,\u201d and that \u201cwe have to consider that these children could be living time bombs.\u201d\n\nThat is not an easy view to take of Bilal, 4, a little Russian boy with a mop of sandy blond hair and spindly arms who last summer became the first child returned to Russia from Islamic-State controlled territory.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe makes car noises and pushes a toy around the kitchen table in his grandmother\u2019s apartment in Grozny, the capital of Chechnya. He says little about his time in Iraq, says his grandmother, Rosa Murtazayeva, but it is obvious he remains touchingly attached to his father, Hasan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith American-backed forces closing in, father and son survived like hunted animals in basements in Mosul, which the Islamic State controlled for three years. Bilal recalls little but the boiled potatoes they survived on. \u201cI was with papa,\u201d Bilal said. \u201cThere were no other boys.\u201d\n\nAfter they were captured, his father vanished into Iraqi prisons. Emaciated and filthy when he was found, Bilal is now outwardly fine. Ms. Murtazayeva said he is sociable at kindergarten and has many friends.\n\nThat is not always the case. Even months after returning, some children remain grimly silent, despite various therapies and pampering from their grandparents.\n\nMoscow 50 miles RUSSIA Area of detail Caspian Sea CHECHNYA Grozny Gehki RUSSIA GEORGIA\n\nWhen the Islamic State tide went out, Hadizha, 8, was found like flotsam in a Mosul street. Her grandmother identified her from a photograph posted by an aid group. She was lying in a gutter, her arm and chin bandaged from burns.\n\nWhat became of her mother, two brothers and a sister is unclear, said the grandmother, Zura, identified only by her first name to protect the child\u2019s privacy. She cares for Hadizha in a small village in Chechnya.\n\n\u201cI gently asked her, \u2018What happened?\u2019 but she doesn\u2019t want to say anything,\u201d Zura said. \u201cI want to hope they are alive, to latch onto something. But she is certain. She says they were shot, but that she waved her hands and said in Arabic, \u2018Don\u2019t shoot,\u2019 and saved herself in that way.\u201d\n\nWhile clearly troubled, Hadizha hardly seems to pose any risks. She spends her days curled up on a couch, her eyes distant and angry, watching cartoons on a big-screen television. \u201cShe doesn\u2019t need anything else,\u201d her grandmother said. \u201cShe is silent.\u201d", "title": "Raised by ISIS, Returned to Chechnya: \u2018These Children Saw Terrible Things\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew E. Kramer"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The ad came after a tumultuous year for the N.F.L., which had a national spotlight placed on football players who sat or kneeled during the national anthem, a controversial gesture meant to draw attention to racial oppression and police brutality against black Americans. President Trump sharply criticized the players, which heightened some of the rhetoric surrounding the protests.\n\nAnd while many advertisers release their ads before the game, Ram did not, which added to the social media maelstrom.\n\n\u201cI think it was well intentioned, but they\u2019re going to have a lot of explaining to do,\u201d Mr. Calkins said. \u201cThey did not release this ahead of time, so they went for the surprise. They got that, but at the same time, they now have a big problem with feedback and people being upset.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nAdding to the disconnect, the sermon in question, delivered exactly 50 years ago, touched on the danger of overspending on items like cars and discussed why people \u201care so often taken by advertisers.\u201d That was not lost on the ad\u2019s detractors.\n\nThe King Center said on Twitter that neither the organization nor the Rev. Bernice King, one of Dr. King\u2019s daughters, is responsible for approving his \u201cwords or imagery for use in merchandise, entertainment (movies, music, artwork, etc) or advertisement.\u201d It said that included the Super Bowl commercial.\n\nRam approached Dr. King\u2019s estate about using his voice in the commercial, said Eric D. Tidwell, the managing director of Intellectual Properties Management, the licenser of the estate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOnce the final creative was presented for approval, it was reviewed to ensure it met our standard integrity clearances,\u201d Mr. Tidwell said in a statement. \u201cWe found that the overall message of the ad embodied Dr. King\u2019s philosophy that true greatness is achieved by serving others.\u201d\n\nFiat Chrysler Automobiles U.S., which owns Ram, said in a statement that it was honored to work with the group to celebrate Dr. King\u2019s words about the value of service.\n\n\u201cWe worked closely with the representatives of the Martin Luther King Jr. estate to receive the necessary approvals, and estate representatives were a very important part of the creative process every step of the way,\u201d the company said.\n\nSusan Credle, global chief creative officer of the agency FCB, marveled at the speed of the online backlash around the ad and said it showed the risks of wading into social commentary, especially during an event like the Super Bowl.\n\n\u201cYou get so crucified, so fast,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cWe\u2019re just in a place where we get called out on authenticity and people don\u2019t want to be emotionally manipulated.\u201d\n\nMargaret Johnson, chief creative officer of the agency Goodby Silverstein & Partners, was also surprised at how quickly the negative reaction coalesced online.\n\n\u201cThe intent was right but maybe the timing was wrong,\u201d she said.", "title": "Ram Trucks Commercial With Martin Luther King Jr. Sermon Is Criticized", "authors": ["Sapna Maheshwari"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "The seismic roster shift sent shock waves through the fan base. The Ratelle trade was even on the front page of The New York Times. (By coincidence, the Rangers, who have said they are planning to rebuild, will be honoring Ratelle the day before the trading deadline.)\n\nRatelle, 35 at the time, went on to play six seasons with the Bruins, for whom he wore No. 10. His time in Boston included trips to the Stanley Cup finals in 1977 and 1978 before he retired at 40 in 1981. Ratelle finished his career with 491 goals and continued to work for the Bruins for another two decades, first as an assistant coach, then as a scout. He was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1985.\n\n\u201cI felt loyalty to the Bruins,\u201d he said. \u201cI was with them for 26 years.\u201d\n\nRatelle developed a bond with Jeff Gorton, the Rangers\u2019 general manager, who spent 15 years in the Bruins\u2019 front office before joining the Rangers in 2007.\n\n\u201cI used to go to high school and college games with him,\u201d Gorton said. \u201cI remember those times. You look at his numbers, everything he\u2019s accomplished, and you look up to the rafters knowing Jean Ratelle belongs there.\u201d\n\nRatelle will be the ninth Rangers player to have his number honored, joining Giacomin (1), Gilbert (7), Harry Howell (3), Andy Bathgate (9), Mark Messier (11), Mike Richter (35), Brian Leetch (2) and Adam Graves, whose No. 9 hangs next to Bathgate\u2019s.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just the right time,\u201d Ratelle said.\n\nHe will be joined on Sunday by his wife, Nancy, their three daughters and their families.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMy wife and I were watching a Rangers game last winter, and they were talking about the players with their sweaters retired,\u201d said Ratelle, whose No. 19 was worn most recently by Jesper Fast until he switched to No. 17 this season. \u201cShe said, \u2018The Rangers should really retire your sweater because you had a great career in New York.\u2019 \u2018O.K.,\u2019 I said. \u2018If Glen calls me, I will say yes.\u2019 A month later, he called.\u201d\n\nRatelle will be on the ice with other former teammates, including Park, Giacomin, goaltender Gilles Villemure and forward Pete Stemkowski.\n\n\u201cJean didn\u2019t say much,\u201d said Stemkowski, who played seven seasons with the Rangers. \u201cHe wasn\u2019t a rah-rah guy, and I don\u2019t think I ever heard him swear. He just worked hard at his craft.\u201d\n\nAlso expected to partake in the festivities will be Ratelle\u2019s longtime coach and general manager, Emile Francis. He first coached Ratelle when he was a teenager playing for the Rangers\u2019 junior team in Guelph, Ontario.\n\n\u201cI couldn\u2019t be happier for Jean,\u201d said Francis, 91, who lives in Florida and remains close with his players from the GAG line era. \u201cNo doubt about it, he was one of the best players who ever played for me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThat group is synonymous with a glorious but unfulfilled Rangers era. The chance to stand together again on Garden ice is special.\n\nHadfield, who became the first Ranger to score 50 goals in a season, on the last day of the 1971-72 season, was more enforcer than goal scorer throughout the 1960s, when the Rangers failed to win a single playoff series. Hadfield, who was born one day after Ratelle in October 1940, joined the Rangers in 1961-62 and stayed through the 1973-74 season, after which he was traded to Pittsburgh.\n\nHadfield said what made Rangers teams of that era unique was the players\u2019 closeness, exemplified by the mild-mannered yet intense Ratelle, whose 109 points in 1971-72 are second-most in franchise history (behind Jaromir Jagr\u2019s 123 in 2005-06).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cJean was not only an excellent hockey player, but he was an excellent individual,\u201d Hadfield said. \u201cAs a team, we all hung out together because we all lived on Long Island. We always had five or six guys and our wives together for dinner. That\u2019s how it was. We won as a team and we lost as a team.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGilbert played until 1977, finishing with 406 goals and 1,021 points, still franchise records. He has never left New York, and he works for the Rangers as director of special projects and community relations representative. He marvels at the happenstance that created a lifelong bond with Ratelle, who is from Lac Saint-Jean, Quebec.\n\n\u201cIt was pure luck we were brought together as kids in Montreal,\u201d said Gilbert, a Montreal native. \u201cThen we have this great career together through juniors and with the Rangers. And now we\u2019re both in the Hall of Fame. It\u2019s magical.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Hall of Famer Yvan Cournoyer, who played against Ratelle throughout his career, said there was a parallel between Ratelle and the Montreal Canadiens great Jean Beliveau, Cournoyer\u2019s longtime teammate.\n\n\u201cJean Ratelle had the same elegance and style as Jean Beliveau,\u201d said Cournoyer, a 10-time Stanley Cup winner with the Canadiens. \u201cAnd he was a gentleman off the ice. What is too bad is that Jean Ratelle never won a Stanley Cup. But the Rangers were a team we respected because of Jean and Rod and all their guys.\u201d\n\nIn 1971-72, Ratelle and his linemates were on pace to break all sorts of records and possibly lead the Rangers to their first Stanley Cup since 1940. But in early March, Ratelle\u2019s ankle was fractured by a shot taken by his teammate Dale Rolfe, and he was not a factor in the playoffs. The Rangers beat Montreal in six games, then swept Chicago to set up a showdown against Bobby Orr and the Bruins in the finals.\n\nRatelle had only one assist in six games as the Rangers lost to the Bruins, who lifted the Cup at the Garden that May 11.\n\nRangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist, whose No. 30 will surely take its place above the Garden ice one day, said he had enjoyed visiting with the greats of yesteryear. Ratelle and his linemates attended the team\u2019s preseason golf outing last September.\n\n\u201cThey are all super nice and funny, those guys, and you can see they care for each other,\u201d Lundqvist said. \u201cIt was a different time that\u2019s for sure \u2014 a different game and a different approach. But it looks like they always had fun.\u201d\n\nFor Rangers followers of his era, the chance to honor Ratelle feels like a long-overdue welcome-home party.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTime goes by,\u201d Ratelle said. \u201cIt will be nice to be with the guys. This will be very special for me because we had some great teams in New York. And there\u2019s only one New York.\u201d", "title": "Rangers Greats Reunite to Honor Jean Ratelle", "authors": ["Allan Kreda"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTwo weeks after publicy promising major roster changes amid a season sliding away, the Rangers on Thursday traded their leading goal scorer, Michael Grabner, to the Devils.\n\nGrabner has 25 goals and six assists in 59 games this season, and the trade makes him the 12th player to spend time with the Rangers, the Islanders and the Devils.\n\nThe Rangers received a second-round draft pick in the June draft and defenseman Yegor Rykov, 20, from the Devils, who are currently in playoff position, 11 points ahead of the Rangers in the Metropolitan Division.\n\nIt is the first trade between the Rangers and the Devils since the Colorado Rockies moved to New Jersey and became the Devils in 1982. Miller, Completing Overhaul", "authors": ["Allan Kreda"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "When Anne-Marie Curtis, the editor in chief of Elle U.K., had to go to the Fashion Awards, the British version of the Oscars-meets-the-Met-Gala that was held in December in London, she did not turn to Stella McCartney, Jenny Packham or any number of other local designers famous for their way around an evening dress. Instead she asked Raquel Diniz, an otherwise unknown Brazilian designer working in Milan, to make her a bespoke green velvet gown.\n\nRaquel who?\n\nFor the last year, Ms. Diniz has been the best-kept secret of fashion industry insiders. She is a go-to red carpet favorite for the model Olivia Palermo, and beloved by the blogger Tamu McPherson. The W Magazine fashion director, Rickie De Sole, called Ms. Diniz\u2019s dresses \u201cthe perfect summer wedding outfit.\u201d\n\nBut judging by the line of curious editors and buyers filtering through her recent Milan Fashion Week presentation (her second, on the schedule) her obscurity is about to end.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMy primary concern is that women feel beautiful wearing my clothes,\u201d the 32-year-old said, gesturing at her latest collection. \u201cI am not particularly avant-garde or interested in trends.\u201d The styles included hand-painted floral-print gowns in whisper-thin lam\u00e9 and silk, feather-trimmed halter-neck midi dresses, and velvet jumpsuits and blazers with embroidered silver studding inspired in part by reruns of the 1980s TV show \u201cDynasty.\u201d Straps on some styles are adjustable, and bust fits can be altered by a series of buttons and ties.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA blond, 5-foot 11-inch former swimsuit model, Ms. Diniz studied fashion design at the Istituto Marangoni in Milan from 2008 to 2011, then spent several years working in fashion public relations for brands including Valentino.", "title": "Raquel Diniz, an Insiders\u2019 Best-Kept Secret, Gets Ready for the Spotlight", "authors": ["Elizabeth Paton"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOutside of Russia, Rimsky-Korsakov\u2019s music has remained largely on the periphery of the repertory. But he will be front and center at this year\u2019s Bard SummerScape, which will take place at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., from June 28 to Aug. 19, and includes performances of music, theater and dance.\n\nThe SummerScape centerpiece, the Bard Music Festival, is known for its ambitious programming, taking deep dives into underserved composers (like Carlos Ch\u00e1vez) and resurrecting little-known works \u2014 a favorite practice of its organizer, the conductor (and president of Bard) Leon Botstein. Twelve programs, over Aug. 10-12 and Aug. 17-19, will explore Rimsky-Korsakov\u2019s influences, contemporaries, and his effect on a future generation of Russian composers.\n\nHis one-act opera \u201cMozart and Salieri,\u201d which depicts the infamous relationship between the two composers, will be performed Aug. 18; there will be a semi-staged production of \u201cThe Tsar\u2019s Bride\u201d on Aug. 19. Rimsky-Korsakov\u2019s arrangement of Mussorgsky\u2019s \u201cNight on Bald Mountain\u201d will be heard in a screening of \u201cFantasia,\u201d on July 29, as part of the festival\u2019s film series.\n\nSummerScape\u2019s central opera production will not be by Rimsky-Korsakov, but by his compatriot Anton Rubinstein, who was 15 years his elder. \u201cThe Demon,\u201d which depicts a fallen angel falling in love, will be given a new production with a Russian cast, July 27-Aug. 5; Thaddeus Strassberger directs, and Mr. Botstein will lead the American Symphony Orchestra.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe seemingly endless Leonard Bernstein centennial celebrations roll on at Bard, but in unexpected fashion, with a production of his musical \u201cPeter Pan\u201d (June 28-July 22). Christopher Alden adapted and will direct this adaptation of the J.M. Barrie play, which ran on Broadway in 1950. (It never matched the popularity of another \u201cPeter Pan\u201d musical that opened four years later, with Mary Martin in the title role.)\n\nAnd on July 6-8, T.S. Eliot\u2019s \u201cFour Quartets\u201d will be brought to life in a premiere mixed-media adaptation. Pam Tanowitz is the choreographer, to a new score by Kaija Saariaho and images by the artist Brice Marden; Kathleen Chalfant will read Eliot\u2019s poems.", "title": "Rare Bernstein and Rimsky-Korsakov at the 2018 Bard SummerScape", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Jonathan Larson finished just two full musicals before his death at age 35 in 1996. But he left behind a vast collection of song demos, stray lyrics and unfinished ideas. Some of those rarely heard songs will be brought together in a concert called \u201cThe Jonathan Larson Project,\u201d coming to Feinstein\u2019s/54 Below in October.\n\nThe project will run Oct. 9-14 and feature lightly staged performances of roughly 18 songs from across Mr. Larson\u2019s life, including cut songs from his musicals \u201cRent\u201d and \u201cTick, Tick\u2026Boom!\u201d The five-person cast will include Nick Blaemire and George Salazar, who recently starred together in an Off Broadway production of \u201cTick, Tick\u2026Boom!\u201d\n\nThe project is being directed by Jennifer Ashley Tepper, a theater historian and the creative director at Feinstein\u2019s/54 Below. To select the songs for this performance, she spent hours combing through his tapes, notebooks and floppy disks at the Library of Congress and the New York Public Library. She received permission from the Larson family to stage the songs; she bounced ideas off his sister, Julie, as well as some of Larson\u2019s collaborators, including his former roommate Jonathan Burkhart and the actor Roger Bart.\n\n\u201cHow I\u2019ve been thinking of the project is the song cycle that he never put on but that he would have,\u201d Ms. Tepper said in a phone interview. \u201cThe song cycle is a lot about love and New York and politics.\u201d", "title": "Rarely Heard Jonathan Larson Works Will Be Performed at 54 Below", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAmerican life will be under the microscope at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater during its 2018-19 season.\n\nIn the fall, two plays by Samuel D. Hunter about the struggling descendants of the explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, \u201cLewiston\u201d and \u201cClarkston,\u201d will be performed together for the first time. Set at a fireworks factory in Idaho and a big-box store in Washington, the plays examine life in a country whose frontier has been completely settled. Davis McCallum, a longtime collaborator with Mr. Hunter, will direct.\n\nThe following spring, \u201cLockdown\u201d by Cori Thomas will receive its world premiere in a production directed by Kent Gash. Inspired by Ms. Thomas\u2019s experiences with inmates at San Quentin State Prison in California, the play articulates the effects of long-term incarceration as a grieving writer agrees to draft a statement for an inmate\u2019s parole hearing.\n\n\u201cThese plays are wrestling with what it means to be American today,\u201d Daniella Topol, Rattlestick\u2019s artistic director, said in a statement. \u201cIn what ways has the American dream left certain individuals behind? How do we overcome our emotional, physical and spiritual isolation? How do we relate to our families and how do we make our own communities?\u201d\n\nMs. Topol explained by phone that there is a connection between the themes of the plays and how they will be staged. For \u201cLewiston\u201d and \u201cClarkston,\u201d the theater\u2019s seats and stage will be removed so that the cast and audience occupy a single space. And Rattlestick hopes to bring the production of \u201cLockdown\u201d outside the theater to communities affected by mass incarceration.\n\nThe theater also announced a number of other events in addition to its three main-stage productions. TheaterJam, a one-day theater festival, New Songs Now, a concert series, and previews of works in progress from Rattlestick\u2019s apprentice company, Middle Voice, are all slated for the upcoming season, along with a weeklong festival of staged readings.", "title": "Rattlestick Playwrights Theater Announces Its Upcoming Season", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "What is the most unusual food you have ever eaten?\n\nIf you were to visit another country, would you try the local cuisine \u2014 no matter how strange it might be to you? Why or why not?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out what one reporter ate on his visit to South Korea.", "title": "Raw Octopus", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "As soon as Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods, one of the country\u2019s largest sports retailers, announced on Wednesday that it would no longer sell assault-style rifles, a flood of readers reacted.\n\nMost applauded, including some gun owners. But others saw a public relations stunt on the day that school resumed at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., where 17 people were killed two weeks ago. And some objected that their right to buy firearms was being attacked.\n\nThe company also said it would no longer sell high-capacity magazines and would not sell any gun to anyone younger than 21, regardless of local laws.\n\nDick\u2019s did the right thing\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a gun owner and I commend Dick\u2019s for doing this. I would gladly give up my right to own an assault style weapon if I thought it could save even one child. It really isn\u2019t a hard decision to make.\u201d \u2014 Larry Carino", "title": "Readers React to Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods\u2019 Decision on Assault-Style Rifles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "As the resident millennial among the preview editors \u2014 those of us who select and assign what goes into each Sunday\u2019s issue of The Times Book Review \u2014 I tend to end up with any book remotely related to a \u201cyoung-person\u201d subject. (These might include: the Kardashians; cute dogs; \u201cThe Bachelor\u201d; cute cats; pregnancies, planned or unplanned.) I take pride in having honed my high-low niche; absent the presidential biographies, big-name literary novels and academic histories my peers pore over, my bookshelf feels quirkier, a little irreverent, always stimulating.\n\nSo it came as little surprise when, back in August, a book landed on my desk with the title \u201cBuzz: The Stimulating History of the Sex Toy,\u201d and a cover that made subtle but skillful use of open- and close-parentheses to suggest female genitalia. (I promptly posted it to my Instagram story, dutiful millennial that I am.) Despite my initial skepticism, in the author Hallie Lieberman\u2019s narrative I discovered a wealth of well-researched and thoughtful social context on the development of the self-stimulation device from antiquity to today. I presented it to the higher-ups and recommended a full review.\n\nShortly thereafter, my colleague Gal Beckerman came across another title he wanted to assign, \u201cVibrator Nation: How Feminist Sex-Toy Stores Changed the Business of Pleasure.\u201d The pairing could not have been more obvious, and thus the seeds of what has now resulted in the Sex Issue \u2014 brilliantly christened \u201cPleasure Reading\u201d by our editor, Pamela Paul \u2014 were sown.\n\nYou read that right: We stuffy book nerds have somehow let down our hair enough to put together an entire issue devoted to books about orgasms, porn, kissing, vibrators, bedroom fantasies, extramarital affairs and even teenage hookups. (On the other hand, it\u2019s worth noting that we stuffy book nerds also think that what people are doing on Valentine\u2019s Day weekend is \u2026 reading about sex.)", "title": "Reading in Bed, With The Times Book Review", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Covert propaganda. A plot to destabilize international relations. An assassination attempt on the president of the United States. \u201cHomeland\u201d is bound up in so many complex conspiracies, it can be hard to unravel them all.\n\nBut let\u2019s separate wheat from chaff: You don\u2019t need to remember, for example, all the ins-and-outs of the plot to manipulate the United States into thinking that Iran was violating its nuclear agreement. You need only know that the shadowy Dar Adal (F. Murray Abraham) was behind it. He lurks behind most of the show\u2019s major events lately: the Sekou Bah bombing; the creation of a propaganda machine to undermine the president-elect; the Child Services investigation into Franny\u2019s welfare; some dirty deals with Mossad; the betrayal of a double agent; and the confinement, in a freezer, of a United States senator, who was also in his underwear. (Dar really gets around.)\n\n\u2018Homeland\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Showtime, Amazon, Hulu, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne thing Dar wasn\u2019t responsible for? The assassination attempt on the president-elect, Elizabeth Keane, which has since turned her into a frightening authoritarian. Our heroine Carrie Mathison (Claire Danes) is, of course, troubled, and Carrie being Carrie \u2014 despite also being out of a job, frozen out of the White House and short on allies \u2014 we know that she will take it upon herself to try to fix this mess in Season 7. So before she returns to Showtime on Feb. 11, let\u2019s take a look at where we left off:\n\n#NotMyPresident\n\nMandy Patinkin and Elizabeth Marvel in \u201cHomeland.\u201d Jeff Neumann/Showtime\n\nIt\u2019s a constitutional crisis. In the United States of \u201cHomeland,\u201d 60 million people elected Elizabeth Keane (Elizabeth Marvel) to be president, and she immediately began creating the kind of police state she once decried.\n\n0\n\nWhat happens when a seemingly progressive candidate becomes a fascist-in-chief? Keane has expanded the Patriot Act. She has also arranged for a large number of government officials from the Departments of Defense and State, and from the Central Intelligence Agency (including Saul Berenson, played by Mandy Patinkin), to be arrested \u2014 sorry, detained \u2014 on dubious legal authority. \u201cI wasn\u2019t aware we were about to go full-on Joe Stalin,\u201d Carrie complains. Apparently, we were.\n\nCarrie\u2019s take is that this is political housecleaning run amok. Keane\u2019s new chief of staff, David Wellington (Linus Roache), may or may not be able to talk some sense into an increasingly isolated and paranoid Keane, who feels that the deep state is against her. If it wasn\u2019t before, it is now.\n\nWhy So Many Conspiracies?\n\nF. Murray Abraham, left, and Rupert Friend in \u201cHomeland.\u201d Jeff Neumann/Showtime\n\nDar Adal was part of a cabal to manipulate the presidency, but to what end? Keane was proposing reform and the demilitarization of the C.I.A., but Dar is the ultimate company man. He didn\u2019t want to dismantle the system but to reign over it \u2014 to keep the national security establishment free from interference. So he used false-flag operations, fake intelligence and propaganda in order to change Keane\u2019s policies and undermine Carrie\u2019s influence.\n\nHe also attempted to surround Keane with his puppets and allies (such as his proposed secretary of state candidates, Senator Kevin Westlake, Senator Rachel Mercer and Gov. Glenallen Stewart). At least when Dar discovered that his collaborators were going so far as to stage a coup, he intervened. But we still don\u2019t know who all of his \u201cconstituents\u201d are. Were they all rounded up, or do any of them remain at large?\n\nCoup de McClendon\n\nGoing against Dar\u2019s wishes, Gen. Jamie McClendon (Robert Knepper) orchestrated the assassination attempt \u2014 seemingly because Keane wasn\u2019t a fan of the war effort or big-budget lethal programs. His Delta Force hit squad didn\u2019t get its target, but its casualties include F.B.I. agents, Secret Service agents, the incoming head of the Justice Department and poor, poor Quinn, the framed \u201ctoxic soldier\u201d who sacrificed his life to save Keane.\n\nMcClendon\u2019s sedition is a capital offense, and he will have to face a court-martial or military tribunal of some sort. Keane no doubt expects the maximum punishment, but she should be aware that the last time the military executed one of its own was in 1961, for a case of rape and attempted murder.\n\nAdventures in Babysitting\n\nClaire Danes, left, in \u201cHomeland\u201d; her character\u2019s daughter, right, is played by Claire and McKenna Keane. JoJo Whilden/Showtime\n\nTalk about a difficult childhood. Franny has been taken \u201chostage,\u201d placed in foster care and carted around the world \u2014 all before the age of five. But the show needs Carrie free from taking care of Brody\u2019s love child for a while so that she can attend to sorting out conspiracies.\n\nHer help in this area, however, keeps dwindling. When the billionaire Otto D\u00fcring was paying her a salary, Carrie could afford a nanny. But without a job, she\u2019s going to have to recruit family members to help out again. Her older sister Maggie and Maggie\u2019s husband, Bill, were living in Rome during Season 6. Once they return to Washington, they might be a big help, so long as Carrie doesn\u2019t wear out her welcome. (Take your meds, Carrie!)\n\n0\n\nMiracle Max\n\nCarrie\u2019s loyal and long-suffering tech-support guru, Max (Maury Sterling), is one of her few trusted colleagues, and he is overdue to play a larger part in the plot. When he was applying for the job at the Office of Policy Coordination, he explained away a missing year on his resume by writing \u201cM+M\u201d \u2014 meth and masturbation. Should Carrie decide to self-medicate for any reason, Max might be able to help Carrie procure some street drugs. Does that merit hazard pay?\n\n\u2018Real Truth\u2019 and Fake News\n\nBrett O\u2019Keefe (Jake Weber) is the alt-right mouthpiece of \u201cHomeland,\u201d a pseudo-journalist who claims to channel the voice of the people in his web videos and radio show, \u201cReal Truth.\u201d But he\u2019s actually a part of Dar\u2019s plan to help manipulate public opinion through the Office of Policy Coordination, which operates as a domestic propaganda factory. And O\u2019Keefe\u2019s website traffic (supposedly 15 million visitors a day) is inflated by bots and professional trolls.\n\nO\u2019Keefe criticizes Keane for \u201ctricking\u201d the public about her son\u2019s war record, but he is the trickster, disseminating falsehoods and then self-righteously claiming he is a truth-teller. But what happens when his lies start coming true? He called Keane dangerous before she was, in fact, dangerous. Now that his paranoid conspiracies don\u2019t seem so paranoid, could he end up becoming a legitimate voice of resistance? Or revolution?", "title": "Ready for Season 7 of \u2018Homeland\u2019? Here\u2019s What You Need to Know", "authors": ["Jennifer Vineyard"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Paul Ryan, the House speaker, sees the tax act as a bonanza for the working stiff: He tweeted that a public school secretary would see a whopping $1.50 a week extra in her paycheck. It\u2019s touching that the secretary can now afford an extra McDonald\u2019s coffee every week, but the deficit, thanks partly to the tax cut, is projected after years of decline to explode to a trillion dollars annually.\n\nTax cuts, regardless of the deficit, are an obsession with Republicans and a source of shameless hypocrisy. During the recent shutdown crisis, the House Freedom Caucus balked at a deal to avert an impasse because it contained additional domestic spending, while in the Senate, Rand Paul of Kentucky held up the vote because the spending creates debt that threatens \u201cthe livelihoods of our children.\u201d Yet the senator and every single Freedom Caucus member enthusiastically had voted only a few weeks before for a fiscally irresponsible tax bill.\n\nRepublicans were once the party of conservation and the environment: from Abraham Lincoln, who set aside Yosemite for what later became a national park, to Theodore Roosevelt, preserving 230 million acres of public land, to Richard Nixon, who signed the Clean Air Act and created the Environmental Protection Agency.\n\nNow the E.P.A. is being systematically gutted. Its administrator, Scott Pruitt, has named as chairman of its science advisory board a person who criticizes the E.P.A.\u2019s standards for exposure to mercury (a neurotoxin causing severe brain damage) and believes ozone pollution rules are unnecessary because Americans spend most of their time indoors. Another of the board\u2019s \u201calternative\u201d scientists is a man who has stated that \u201cmodern air is a little too clean for optimum health.\u201d\n\nRepublicans always counted themselves as strong supporters of law and order. Whenever a crime bill was considered in Congress, I used to joke with my colleagues that any minute, a Republican would offer an amendment proposing the death penalty for jaywalking. But the president\u2019s high-decibel smear campaign against the professionals of the F.B.I. destroys the party\u2019s pretense of being a friend of law enforcement, as does the administration\u2019s dismantling of the Consumer Financial Protection Agency and its rules against consumer fraud. The fact that Mr. Trump and his senior appointees are scofflaws regarding conflict-of-interest statutes does not enhance their reputation as straight arrows.\n\nSo what do Republicans have left? The tax cut, the sole important legislation from the Republican Congress, shows that catering to its rich contributors is the party\u2019s only policy. The rest of its agenda is simply tactics and trickery.\n\nAs the party has become unmoored from positive belief, it has grown manipulative, demagogic and contemptuous of truth. This was foreshadowed in 2004 when a senior adviser to George W. Bush boasted that \u201cwe create our own reality.\u201d It has culminated in the president\u2019s counselor Kellyanne Conway\u2019s appealing to \u201calternative facts,\u201d meaning lies, on behalf of her boss, who has made an average of 5.6 false or misleading claims a day since his inauguration.\n\nToday\u2019s Republican Party is incapable of honest and coherent governance, with \u201cright\u201d or \u201cwrong\u201d reduced to a question of whether it helps the party. Its agenda is little more than institutional vandalism and a thumb in the eye.", "title": "Opinion | Reagan\u2019s \u2018Party of Ideas\u2019 Is Down to Just One: Tax Cuts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "What do you think this image is saying? Why or why not?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out the author\u2019s thoughts on friendship.", "title": "Real Friends vs. Facebook Friends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "That assessment is both comforting (all we have to do is change the definition of masculinity) and unnerving (masculinity requires that you do what?).\n\nTwo decades ago, the psychologist William Pollack wrote that boys start out sensitive but through a \u201cshame-hardening process\u201d \u2014 told to stop crying, to be a man \u2014 they learn to hide what they really feel. And if they don\u2019t know or understand their own feelings, how can they care about anyone else\u2019s?\n\nThis has become something of a clich\u00e9. And the truth is, there\u2019s no single culture of boys, but many. In my memories of adolescence, beneath the constant ribbing and occasional pyromania, we had tremendous affection for one another. And we longed to connect with women with an intensity that was difficult to contemplate.\n\nBut what the critique gets right is that early on, we learn to wear masks. As a father, the most obvious way to address this is by example: Take off your mask. Don\u2019t shame your son. Treat women well. From a list by the actress Nicole Stamp come more concrete recommendations: Don\u2019t use gendered insults; don\u2019t call her \u201csweetie\u201d; and when other guys demean women, tell them to knock it off.\n\nBut just modeling a better man is not enough. You also have to talk to your sons (and daughters) about what a healthy relationship looks like. Sarah Edwards, an assistant professor of psychology at Minnesota State University, told me that discussing \u201cgray zones\u201d \u2014 times when explicit consent hasn\u2019t been given \u2014 was important, because that\u2019s often when assaults happen. Her research suggests that men may not even know they\u2019ve done something wrong.\n\nAccording to a survey of 3,000 18- to 25-year-olds by Harvard\u2019s Making Caring Common Project, we are failing horribly at this task. Eighty-seven percent of the young women said they had been sexually harassed. And three-quarters of respondents said they\u2019d never talked with their parents about how to avoid harassing others. Richard Weissbourd, who led the study, said this revealed a \u201cdumbfounding abdication of responsibility.\u201d\n\nLittle data exists on whether kids actually listen to what their parents say, he concedes, but if you don\u2019t talk to your children, he argues, they\u2019re left to absorb norms from, most likely, pornography. And what boys learn from porn is that men must dominate and that women like it that way \u2014 neither of which is necessarily true.", "title": "Opinion | Real Men Get Rejected, Too", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Museums are vital cultural institutions. They provide a glimpse into the past, a record of what once was and an exploration of how the present came to be. They are social cornerstones, shaping public opinion in subtle yet profound ways.\n\nIn a world increasingly dominated by fake news, museums should stand as sanctuaries of truth and science. To do so, a natural-history museum must be accurate, faithful to the facts and trusted by the public. This is why it is so troubling that Rebekah Mercer continues to sit on the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History.\n\nMs. Mercer and her family were important backers of President Trump. She has a stake in Breitbart News, and the family foundation has contributed millions of dollars to climate-change-denying politicians and organizations like the Heartland Institute, which says, \u201cGlobal warming is not a crisis\u201d and \u201cThere is no need to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and no point in attempting to do so.\u201d According to the Mercer Family Foundation\u2019s tax reports, it gave the Heartland Institute nearly $5.9 million from 2008 to 2016, more than the $4 million it donated to the American Museum of Natural History during that period.", "title": "Opinion | Rebekah Mercer Puts a Museum\u2019s Credibility at Risk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "We had to make a decision: Who, exactly, is our Luther? And can we boil him down to three minutes of film? It might have to do with our personal backgrounds in this country that we chose to talk about the Luther who invented freedom. We were able to get at the core of Luther\u2019s concept of spirituality, which was all arranged around his idea of freedom. In the 16th century, God was an angry and punishing God, someone people feared more than anything else \u2014 especially because they were too weak to follow his commandments.\n\nAnd this is where Luther comes in: Studying the Bible, he found something that uncovered the truth of who and what God really is. Luther conceived the idea of grace and concluded: Everybody can be saved! All you need is your own spiritual access to the idea of God and a strong belief. And by translating the Bible so that it could be read by the public, that is what Luther did: He set us free. If people could understand God by themselves without a mediator, they would be free to make up their own minds. Spiritually free. So, inner belief was born, and with it a new way to defy external authorities. Luther demonstrated such defiance himself, challenging the pope and the emperor.", "title": "Opinion | Rebel Monk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "$63/SQ. It is currently the headquarters of Union Square Hospitality Group, founded by the restaurateur Danny Meyer in 1985 at the time he opened Union Square Cafe. How do I take 4K videos on an iPhone?\n\nA. Apple introduced official support for 4K video on its mobile devices in 2015 with the release of its iPhone 6s and iPhone 6s Plus models, so first make sure you are using hardware that can handle the ultra high-definition format. The 4K video option is typically off by default so once you have confirmed your iPhone model is 4K-capable, open the Settings app on the home screen.\n\nOn the main Settings screen, scroll down and select Camera. On the Camera settings screen, tap Record Video.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe next screen displays all the resolutions and frames-per-second rates you can use for recording video. Higher frame rates capture more of the motion in the scene and make the action look smoother. The 24 frames-per-second rate is fairly standard for recording on film and used by movie theaters, while the 30 f.p.s. and 60 f.p.s. rates are often used for high-definition video formats. The most recent iPhone models released last year (the iPhone 8, the iPhone 8 Plus and the iPhone X) can capture 4K video at 60 frames per second.\n\nPhoto\n\nBecause higher resolutions and frame rates mean more video data, they produce larger file sizes. The Record Video setting screen also gives you an idea of how much storage space will be taken up by one minute of video in each format.\n\nThe lowest option for 4K, 24 f.p.s., will take up an estimated 135 megabytes of space for each minute recorded, while the 30 f.p.s. setting takes up 170 megabytes of storage for every 60 seconds of captured video. On iPhones that can record 4K video at 60 f.p.s., plan to fill up about 400 megabytes of storage space for every minute of video.", "title": "Recording 4K Video on an iPhone", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Tina Craig, a high-profile blogger, made a beeline for Norma Kamali on Tuesday night, warmly clasping her hand as she told the designer: \u201cI wanted to show you this dress. I just wore it in Hawaii.\u201d\n\nShe had placed her own stamp on Ms. Kamali\u2019s wrap-and-tie jersey, twisting and tweaking it to suit her shape. \u201cI\u2019ve been buying Kamali since my teens,\u201d Ms. Craig, 47, said.\n\nShe was one in a crowd of Kamali enthusiasts, women of varying ages and shapes, draped from shoulder to shinbone in the designer\u2019s golden oldies. Showing off Ms. Kamali\u2019s much-mythologized sleeping bag coats, ruched parachute dresses or fringed-and-feathered evening clothes, they had gathered at What Goes Around Comes Around, the fancy secondhand shop on West Broadway in SoHo, to commemorate the designer\u2019s half-century in business.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Kamali, 72, took the commotion around her in stride. She is still selling vintage items on her website, but thought she\u2019d exhausted the lot when she stumbled on a cache of some 70 pieces, many dating from the \u201970s, in some long forgotten bins.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe turned them over promptly to Seth Weisser and Gerard Maione, the founders and owners What Goes Around Comes Around, who will be selling the pieces, which they\u2019ve called \u201cvintage for the future,\u201d at nosebleed prices in coming weeks. Prices range from $750 to $7,500, with most falling between $750 and $3,500.", "title": "Rediscovering Norma Kamali, Again", "authors": ["Ruth La Ferla"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Furtive Artists of Power Politics: Mapmakers\u201d (news article, Jan. 30):\n\nNever before have so many states faced court challenges to redistricting plans based on the 2010 census as we have before the courts today this late in the decade. While states will always retain experts to redraw legislative maps, fair, objective and prioritized rules can help limit partisan and racial gerrymandering.\n\nThe New York City Charter provides a strong model for redrawing city council districts by keeping like-minded communities together; avoiding bizarrely shaped districts; and making sure that travel within the district is convenient without having to cross into another district.\n\nNo legal court challenges were brought to plans enacted by the city after the 2003 and 2013 City Council redistricting cycles partly as a result of a methodological process that balanced the law with community concerns. It\u2019s not that difficult a task for others to follow to avoid litigation.\n\nJEFFREY M. WICE, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is a fellow at the Rockefeller Institute of Government. He served as redistricting counsel to two New York City Council redistricting commissions and to both chambers in the New York Legislature.", "title": "Opinion | Redistricting Plans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "He recalled attending a dinner several years ago with Mr. Cathey and other cast members of \u201cThe Wire\u201d at which Mr. Cathey told a hilarious story while impersonating the other actors.\n\n\u201cAnd every voice was perfect,\u201d Mr. Simon said. \u201cBy the end of 25 minutes, nobody could breathe.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe actor Wendell Pierce, who played a detective on \u201cThe Wire,\u201d said Mr. Cathey was not only a great raconteur but also a man who \u201cmade you have a viewpoint\u201d and enjoyed a good debate.\n\n\u201cHe always challenged you and provoked your thoughts,\u201d Mr. Pierce said. \u201cHe was one of those people when you\u2019re speaking with him you felt like you were at the center of the world.\u201d\n\nReginald Eurias Cathey was born on Aug. 18, 1958, in Huntsville, Ala., to a father who was an Army officer and a mother who worked in the Defense Department. Mr. Cathey grew up in Germany and traveled frequently before moving back to Alabama when he was a teenager. He studied at the University of Michigan \u2014 where, reports say, he befriended Madonna and the future comedy star David Alan Grier \u2014 and later at the Yale School of Drama.\n\nOver an acting career that spanned more than 35 years, Mr. Cathey also had a recurring role in the long-running television series \u201cOz\u201d and made appearances in other widely viewed shows like \u201cLaw & Order,\u201d \u201c30 Rock\u201d and \u201cStar Trek: The Next Generation.\u201d\n\nHis many film credits included a role as Dr. Franklin Storm in the 2015 reboot of \u201cFantastic Four\u201d and a part as a homeless man in \u201cAmerican Psycho.\u201d In 2000, Mr. Cathey made his Broadway debut in \u201cThe Green Bird\u201d; he had several other theater credits.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe is survived by his girlfriend, Linda Powell; a sister, Donza Cathey Friende; his stepmother, Maureen Davis Cathey; and two stepbrothers, Jerry Davis and Maurice Davis.\n\nThough some might not know Mr. Cathey by name, his recent roles and commanding voice made him instantly recognizable in the latter part of his career.\n\n\u201cWhen I was on \u2018Oz\u2019 years ago, I did an interview and the guy said, \u2018You\u2019re one of the few actors who can make their living as an actor without being famous,\u2019\u201d he told The Detroit Free Press in 2015. \u201cWe both laughed. And it\u2019s true. There\u2019s a small club of us, actors and actresses, because it\u2019s really difficult just to make a living as an actor without being famous. It used to be easier when I first started, but now it\u2019s really, really difficult.\u201d", "title": "Reg E. Cathey, Actor on \u2018House of Cards\u2019 and \u2018The Wire,\u2019 Dies at 59", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Church was home.\n\nAs a black girl growing up in the Pacific Northwest, I so needed that space. I attended a predominantly white elementary school. My classmates often let me know that they detested the way I talked, the way I wore my hair and the food I brought from home for lunch.\n\nSo when my English teacher introduced her poetry unit, using Langston Hughes as the first poet, my spirit leapt for joy just as it did at church. I recognized the vernacular in his poems. I knew that mother who told her son that life for her had been no crystal stair. I understood the stench of rotting dreams, I knew the longing of a people wanting America to make good on its promise. When Hughes called his people beautiful like the night sky, my grandpa and cousins and neighbors came to mind. I said \u201camen\u201d in that classroom for the first time. The lesson spoke directly to me, about me.\n\nPoetry became my sanctuary.\n\nI grew up in a state where black people make up 2 percent of the population, so I needed a refuge for my blackness. I needed permission to celebrate and critique where I came from. It was validating to know that the struggle of someone like my mother was worthy of a poem, that my dreams were important enough to be recorded. Hughes\u2019s poetry was a witness to my experience, my existence.\n\nThroughout my schooling, there were many more poetry units of study, and almost always there was one black poet on the syllabus: Langston Hughes. But the poems were always the same ones \u2014 the ones about dreams. Every year during Black History Month, my classmates and I recited \u201cHarlem\u201d and \u201cDream Variations.\u201d\n\nIt wasn\u2019t until college that I learned that Hughes wasn\u2019t just a dreamer. The poet who wrote about deferred dreams was the same writer who wrote, \u201cIf the government can set aside some spot for a elk to be a elk without being bothered, or a fish to be a fish without getting hooked, or a buffalo to be a buffalo without being shot down, there ought to be a place in this American country where a Negro can be a Negro without being Jim Crowed.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Remember Langston Hughes\u2019s Anger Alongside His Joy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nI\u2019m occasionally going to use this newsletter to update readers about the situation in Puerto Rico, because I think it\u2019s important to keep the crisis there fresh in our minds. There isn\u2019t nearly enough political pressure on the federal government to help the people of Puerto Rico.\n\nThe basics. Almost five months after Hurricane Maria hit the island, about 25 percent of residents still lack electrical power.\n\nThe official death toll is only 64, but The Times has estimated that the real number may be 1,052.\n\nThousands of Puerto Ricans have left the island for Florida, and experts estimate that as many as 300,000 more could leave if significant rebuilding doesn\u2019t take place. Without wholesale rebuilding, \u201cthe island is likely to find itself back in the same place after the next big storm,\u201d Mekela Panditharatne, an environmental lawyer, wrote in an op-ed this week.", "title": "Opinion | Remember Puerto Rico", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Before volunteering for the war in 1942, Father Washington had last served at St. Stephen\u2019s church in Kearny, N.J., and each year, a Mass is celebrated in honor of him and the other chaplains, attracting veterans from near and far. Among them on Sunday was Gene Swarbrick, 93, who served as an altar boy with Father Washington.\n\n\u201cHe was a beautiful man,\u201d Mr. Swarbrick, who now lives in Daytona Beach, Fla., said. \u201cHe was a prize fighter before he became a priest, and he used to play stick ball with us right behind the church. He loved kids; he just loved them.\u201d\n\nMr. Swarbrick was drafted months before Father Washington died, and remembers hearing the news of the loss. \u201cCan you imagine taking off your life jacket and giving it to someone else?\u201d he said.\n\nJohn Nicaretta, 87, a Korean War veteran from nearby Bayonne, N.J., said he is still moved by the memory that \u201cthese people gave their lives for others.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been coming here so many years, and every year, I\u2019m touched,\u201d Mr. Nicaretta said.\n\nThe Rev. Timothy P. Broglio, archbishop for military services in the United States, celebrated the Mass and was joined by a color guard of veterans and Boy Scouts, in a church filled with hymns and patriotic songs led by a choir, orchestra and bagpipes. This is thought to be among the largest of the several hundred remembrances held each year to mark the chaplains\u2019 sacrifice at veteran\u2019s posts and in churches and temples around the country, said Christine Beady, the executive director of the Four Chaplains Foundation in Philadelphia.", "title": "Remembering the Four Chaplains and Their Ultimate Sacrifice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The White Rose also addressed the atrocities against Jews. Schmorell and Hans wrote in the group\u2019s second leaflet: \u201cHere we see the most frightful crime against human dignity, a crime that is unparalleled in the whole of history. For Jews, too, are human beings.\u201d No punches were pulled even when it came to the F\u00fchrer: \u201cEvery word that comes from Hitler\u2019s mouth is a lie.\u201d Sprinkled with erudite references to Goethe, Aristotle, Schiller, Ecclesiastes, Lao Tzu and others, the leaflets concluded with a plea to support the White Rose by circulating them. \u201cWe will not be silent,\u201d ended the fourth. \u201cWe are your bad conscience. The White Rose will not leave you in peace.\u201d\n\nThe leaflets appeared in mailboxes and phone booths between late June and mid-July 1942 and spread to sympathetic students in Frankfurt, Hamburg, Berlin and Vienna. Then they stopped as Hans, Schmorell, Graf and Probst were shipped east on a day\u2019s notice to the Russian front, where the Germans were bogged down. Yet Hans fought back against the Nazis with acts of simple humanity even as he approached the front. On his train to Russia, he saw a young Jewish girl doing hard labor, wearing the yellow Star of David mandated by the Nazis. Running from his transport, Hans handed her a chocolate bar from his rations \u2014 and a daisy for her hair.\n\nAfter returning from the front, Hans and the others released two more leaflets warning that with the loss at Stalingrad, German defeat was inevitable. Declaring the preciousness of individual rights, the leaflets asked, \u201cAre we forever to be a nation that is hated and rejected by all mankind?\u201d Hans, Schmorell and Graf sneaked out at night and painted signs reading \u201cDown with Hitler,\u201d \u201cFreedom\u201d and other slogans on the main boulevard in Munich.\n\nThen on Feb. 18, 1943, Hans and Sophie decided to distribute leaflets at the university, leaving stacks in corridors. As they started to leave, Sophie noticed that there were more copies in their suitcase and headed to the top of the stairs, which overlooked an atrium. She hurled the remaining leaflets in the air and watched as they drifted down the stairwell.\n\nThe maintenance man, Jakob Schmid, an ardent Nazi, was watching. He immediately locked the doors and notified the authorities. The siblings were hauled to the Wittelsbach Palace, the headquarters of the Gestapo. Soon after, Probst, whose wife had had a third child weeks before, was also arrested. The three were interrogated for several days, but they refused to implicate others.", "title": "Opinion | Remembering the White Rose", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Groping for explanations: Up to that point, commercials had been considered a necessary evil of watching television. Suddenly, they were the show itself. As infomercials, including the unavoidable \u201cPsychic Friends Network\u201d pitches starring Dionne Warwick, crowded out old Bogart movies and \u201cHoneymooners\u201d reruns on late night television, critics were left to wonder why people were suddenly \u201cfeeling powerless to turn off the smiling famous faces and euphoric, satisfied customers who promise a better, younger, prettier, richer, happier, more personally empowered you,\u201d as Rick Marin wrote in 1992. He could only speculate as to the cause. \u201cIn a decade with much talk about dysfunction, the world of the infomercial is mesmerizingly functional, even multifunctional,\u201d he surmised. \u201cEverything works, or seems to. And if it doesn\u2019t? There\u2019s always the money-back guarantee.\u201d\n\nBut seriously, why? Maybe it was the limits of technology. Smartphones and tablets, with their limitless potential for customizing viewing habits, would not become ubiquitous for a decade and a half. TiVo and other DVRs would not emerge to scramble America\u2019s viewing habits for nearly a decade. In those days, families still tended to gather nightly around an actual television set and let whatever was on wash over them, including commercials \u2014 even long ones, apparently. The \u201990s were also the heyday of Prozac, which may have left people open to easy feel-good solutions. As Mark Crispin Miller, a professor of media studies at Johns Hopkins University, conjectured, \u201cwhat people seem to want from the infomercial is an experience that is wholly and brainlessly affirmative. It may be commercial television in its purest state.\u201d", "title": "Remind Me, Why Was It That We Ever Watched Infomercials?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRen\u00e9e Nicole Gray and Andrew Lewis Raff were married Feb. 2 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.Michael McSweeney, a staff member of the New York City clerk\u2019s office, officiated . Tom Price was dismissed as secretary of health and human services over his use of private jets.\n\nWithin hours of the report\u2019s release, a few Republican lawmakers were calling for Dr. Shulkin to resign.
