His name is Harry (Mark Addy, first-rate), who has the complacent, well-fed look of an eater of beef and death-dealing servant of the crown.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the opening scene, set in 1963, Harry, aided by his stuttering assistant, Syd (a creature of Dickensian furtiveness, as played by Reece Shearsmith), secures the noose around the neck of a convicted young murderer who dies protesting his innocence. Played with blazing desperation by Gilles Geary, the doomed man gasps out a last-minute promise to haunt his assassins. (\u201cWell, that\u2019s not a nice thing to say, is it?\u201d says a peeved Syd.)\n\nRemember his name: Hennessy. Harry and Syd certainly will.\n\nTwo years later, Hennessy inevitably comes up in the conversation at the pub that Harry now owns. It is, as Harry puts it \u201ca momentous bloody day,\u201d the date on which capital punishment has been made obsolete.\n\nA young reporter (Owen Campbell) is there, asking for a few commemorative words from Harry, and if Harry is smart (which he ain\u2019t) he\u2019ll say nothing. In the meantime, our Mr. Mooney slithers into the pub, bringing the disharmonious vibe of a swinging, sexed-up London into this frozen outpost of the middle-class 1950s.\n\nThat\u2019s about all you need in the way of setup, though I suppose you should know that Harry has a very bored wife, Alice (Sally Rogers), and a restless, terminally na\u00efve 15-year-old daughter, Shirley (Gaby French). The denizens at Harry\u2019s bar \u2014 a sheeplike herd of enjoyably varied bleats \u2014 include an ineffectual policeman (David Lansbury), and three wilting barflies (Billy Carter, Richard Hollis and John Horton) who are drawn to the place by its owner\u2019s notoriety. Lurking at the plot\u2019s edges is Harry\u2019s archrival from his hanging days, Albert (Maxwell Caulfield).\n\nThe big subject of \u201cHangmen\u201d is the uses and abuses of vengeance, a theme evidently much on Mr. McDonagh\u2019s mind. \u201cThree Billboards\u201d traces the wayward forms taken by the urge to get even in a small American town. Since \u201cThree Billboards\u201d is a Hollywood movie, there is sunlight, real and metaphoric, throughout, including glimmers of that audience-pleasing essential known as Redemption.\n\n\u201cHangmen,\u201d in contrast, is every bit as dark as Mr. McDonagh\u2019s early, bloody plays set in rural Ireland (including \u201cThe Beauty Queen of Leenane\u201d and \u201cThe Lieutenant of Inishmore\u201d). As for redemption, forget about it. People are either foolish or dangerously flawed in the world of \u201cHangmen.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor a writer of Mr. McDonagh\u2019s scalpel-edged gifts, these unadmirable qualities are joyous opportunities, allowing for the sort of conversation in which stupidity and pettiness achieve the sparkle of wit. \u201cHangmen\u201d is often very funny. But as you laugh, you may feel the walls of Anna Fleischle\u2019s clammy pub set closing in on you.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere will be thunder and lightning before the play ends, during a dark and stormy day in which someone goes missing and light thickens, as surely as it does in \u201cMacbeth.\u201d (All credit to Joshua Carr, the lighting designer.)\n\nReplacing the estimable David Morrissey, whom I saw in London two years ago, Mr. Addy brings an extra layer of fatuity and vanity to Harry, which makes you suspect that any comeuppance he receives won\u2019t seriously dent this thick skin. The excellent Ms. Rogers returns as Harry\u2019s frowzy helpmeet, a woman narcotized by monotony, who can still put on the dog for a handsome stranger.\n\nAn affectingly awkward Ms. French, new to the cast, and Mr. Flynn work up a thrilling fly-meets-spider chemistry in their scenes together. And though the play features two simulated deaths (though without the usual McDonagh carnage quotient), its most viscerally disturbing moment finds Mooney slowly, slowly tracing an arc in the air with his hand, to show Shirley he knows what a curve is.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf that doesn\u2019t sound scary to you, then you don\u2019t know Mr. McDonagh, who understands that the most profound shock effects are often rooted in life\u2019s most mundane elements. (Interestingly, he registers as more of a shrewd disciple of Alfred Hitchcock in his plays than he does in his movies.)\n\nThat\u2019s a lesson that\u2019s perfectly grasped by the sensational Mooney of Mr. Flynn, an original cast member whose resume includes Shakespeare with Mark Rylance and his own folk-rock band. Mooney revels in scrambling notions of what\u2019s funny and what\u2019s frightening.\n\nNiggling arguments about words abound in Mr. McDonagh\u2019s world. \u201cHanged\u201d versus \u201chung\u201d as a past tense crops up at the darnedest times here. And Mooney is given to earnestly weighing the adjectives that best suit him, as if they were neckties: creepy (no!), funny (well, not really) and menacing (absolutely).\n\nHe\u2019s wrong, though. Mooney is hilariously menacing, or do I mean menacingly hilarious? In any case, he\u2019s a happy-creepy reminder that Mr. McDonagh can still work his double-edged, sinister magic on a stage, making breathless, alarmed and deeply satisfied dupes of us all.", "title": "Review: A Criminally Enjoyable \u2018Hangmen\u2019 From Martin McDonagh", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI knew that the creative process for \u201cbend the even,\u201d the latest project by the improviser and choreographer Jennifer Monson, involved rehearsals on a prairie at dawn. So when the work, which opened at the Chocolate Factory on Tuesday, began in silence and dim light, I settled in for a meditative experience, a slow reveal. But the first sound came as a shock: a floor-shaking rumble that felt like the start of an earthquake.\n\nI shouldn\u2019t have been surprised. Ms. Monson, who has been a revered figure in experimental dance for decades, has lately been known for researching outdoors and for bringing a sense of nature inside. But while her nature studies incorporate much stasis and quiet, her vision of nature is of forces larger than herself \u2014 wild, powerful forces that can unexpectedly erupt.\n\nThat initial rumble comes from the sound artist Jeff Kolar, who tweaks the dials and levers of his electronics onstage, making visible his technological manipulation of radio waves, storm surges and cricket chirps. The lighting designer Elliott Cennetoglu also works in full view of the audience, brightening and dimming the world, shading it blue and green. The musician Zeena Parkins is sometimes onstage, brushing a microphone against her clothing, connecting sound with touch. She also plays her harp next to viewers\u2019 seats. Her music can be dulcet, as you might expect, though other times it sounds \u2014 and feels \u2014 like heavy metal.\n\nJoining Ms. Monson is the dancer Mauriah Kraker, an effective foil \u2014 younger and more svelte. Although it can be difficult to take your eyes off Ms. Monson, Ms. Kraker is essential. Some of the dance is in unison, all of it interactive. Early on, the two women wrestle, grappling with hooked ankles rather than hands. Near the end, they transfer the activity to their arms, seeming at once to desire entanglement and to push each other out of the way.\n\nIn one strangely captivating section, they stand side by side, as still as figures in a double portrait. Or almost as still, since their faces do move, nearly imperceptibly. Ms. Monson\u2019s face tightens, in concern or anger, following something with her eyes.\n\nSuch subtle change is what is most like the dawn in \u201cbend the even.\u201d Both the music and the dance often work in loops, with large facets repeating while small parts shift until the whole is utterly different. But, again, this nuance doesn\u2019t preclude shocks. Suddenly, the dancers twist, wrench, lunge and leap with a kind of fight-or-flight desperation.\n\nWhen Ms. Monson is in the zone, her performances can seem, without any conventional drama, like an extraordinary event that is happening to her, the emergence of some greater aliveness to which she has opened herself. But if you keep yourself open, suspending impatience (it takes effort), you too can tune into that frequency and feel those vibrations. It\u2019s like adjusting your ears to listen to a butterfly\u2019s wings and being inundated instead with the roar of the ocean.", "title": "Review: A Dance About the Dawn, but Not the Quiet Dawn", "authors": ["Brian Seibert"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Timothy Spall looks so defeated in \u201cThe Party\u201d it\u2019s a wonder he isn\u2019t waving a white flag. His body droops and his face sags, jowls draping under a thatch of beard. He\u2019s playing Bill, who\u2019s somewhat of a mystery man. For a long while, all that you really know about Bill is that he\u2019s married to Janet (Kristin Scott Thomas), the woman cheerfully bustling in the kitchen. Also: He likes vinyl. Every so often, Bill miraculously manages to gather together his flaccid bits so he can put on a record. Then, with a bottle of wine by his side, he collapses back into his chair, resuming his man-of-sorrows pose.\n\nBill\u2019s bearing is matched by his bleak story, which leaks out over the course of this grindingly unhappy affair. Written and directed by Sally Potter, who has made other movies worth seeing \u2014 \u201cThriller,\u201d \u201cOrlando,\u201d \u201cGinger & Rosa\u201d \u2014 \u201cThe Party\u201d is a brittle, unfunny attempt at comedy that features some very fine actors and a lot of empty chatter. It takes place inside a few rooms on the ground-level floor of Bill and Janet\u2019s comfortable London digs. There, they are giving a party to celebrate Janet\u2019s recent appointment as a government functionary of the unnamed opposition party. From the way she furtively coos into her cellphone, it is clear that Janet has some secrets.", "title": "Review: A London Night Goes Wrong in \u2018The Party\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s a small land mine of a scene \u2014 it would be easy to turn against Setsuko right then \u2014 but Ms. Hirayanagi proves distinctly adept at shifting tones. She\u2019s also a fast worker, and she quickly navigates through the story\u2019s trickier, more emotionally precarious moments without seeming to rush through or away from them. The woman\u2019s weeping may be sad, at least given the circumstances, office decorum and social norms. But her galumphing howls also sound funny, too loud, faintly ridiculous, performative and self-flattering. Setsuko may be mean, but in a movie that is very much concerned with identity and the roles that we assume and reject, it\u2019s clear that she isn\u2019t entirely unjustified.\n\nAt first, Ms. Terajima\u2019s subtle performance works like a roadblock to easy sympathy. With her defeated shoulders and practiced deadpan, Setsuko seems to be a passive observer, someone who has become good at watching other people live. She isn\u2019t at all likable and it isn\u2019t clear, at least initially, if she\u2019s even worthy of sustained interest. When she hunkers down smoking in her tiny, uncomfortably cluttered apartment \u2014 a killing field of empty cans, miscellaneous junk and aspirational fashion goods \u2014 it looks as if she\u2019s living in the aftermath of a disaster of her own making. A lot of actors can weep on cue, but it takes one as good as Ms. Terajima to make emptiness feel haunted.\n\nTogether with her director, Ms. Terajima fills up that emptiness with deep, then deeper waves of feeling, and escalating, freewheeling comedy. After some narrative busywork, John disappears and Setsuko \u2014 weighted down with a large suitcase and her comically, aggressively angry sister (Kaho Minami) \u2014 follows him to Southern California. There, amid the sunshine and enveloping shadows, Setsuko finds and then loses herself while cutting loose and engaging in some savage psychological blood sport. She stumbles and she falls, plays at being Lucy and slips back into a radically changed Setsuko in a movie in which the human comedy is by turns tender, plaintive, heartfelt and joyful.", "title": "Review: A Tragic Wig and the Search for Happiness in \u2018Oh Lucy!\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Sometimes at the end of a hard day \u2014 in a hard time, in an unhappy nation \u2014 all you need is the love of a good robot. No, I am not referring to one of those lifelike sex dolls you may have read about. Nor the super-efficient machine that is rumored to be taking over your job next month.\n\nThe robot I\u2019m talking about is the kindly, silver-skinned creature who has descended upon the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn. He is on a mission to bring \u201cpeace, love and dopeness\u201d to this uneasy planet, and he doesn\u2019t have a cynical sprocket in his body.\n\nGive him half a chance, and he\u2019ll wash away your earthly blues for as long as you\u2019re in his company. That\u2019s not much more than an hour, but, hey, it\u2019s an hour devoid of stress, fear, hatred and the other woes that come with belonging to the Divided States of America.\n\nThis beneficent automaton is the creation of Darian Dauchan, the writer and performer of \u201cThe Brobot Johnson Experience,\u201d which runs through March 17. For our entertainment (and for our sins, as well), Mr. Dauchan has assumed the form of an Afrofuturist emissary from the planet of Nubia, who has journeyed here to save both our world and his from destruction.", "title": "Review: An Afrofuturist Mr. Rogers Rules \u2018The Brobot Johnson Experience\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Musical theater history, no less than the regular kind, is told by the winners. Triumphs like \u201cShow Boat,\u201d \u201cWest Side Story\u201d and \u201cHamilton\u201d are the works that give you the shape of their times, both as social documents and as cultural products.\n\nNone of the old musicals sampled in the new Encores! anthology called \u201cHey, Look Me Over!\u201d made or make that kind of history. Added together, the nine shows didn\u2019t run as long as the original production of \u201cMy Fair Lady,\u201d and not one has ever been revived on Broadway. Only one won a Tony Award, and that was for featured actress. If any were to show up on a best-of list, I would suspect family connections.\n\nThat\u2019s never been disqualifying data for the series, which began its 25th season on Wednesday night at City Center with this unusual entry, a revue made up of scenes and songs from shows that opened between 1957 and 1974. The Encores! mandate has always been to present items from Broadway\u2019s trunk that, despite intermittent felicities, were otherwise unlikely to emerge from it again.\n\nSometimes the idea has outwitted itself in the process, as when \u201cChicago\u201d and \u201cWonderful Town\u201d proved surprisingly viable, and moved on to commercial runs. More often, Encores! has honored the lesser work of the form by letting us hear it in full and as close as possible to the way first-nighters did.", "title": "Review: An Anthology of B-List Broadway in \u2018Hey, Look Me Over!\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSuffused with sorcery and silvery light, \u201cNovember,\u201d written and directed by Rainer Sarnet, is a bizarre Estonian love story \u2014 a mishmash of folklore, farm animals and scabrous fun \u2014 in which beauty and ugliness fight to the death.\n\nThe beauty lies in Mart Taniel\u2019s surreal black-and-white cinematography, which turns a freezing lake into liquid mercury and a snow-dusted forest into Christmas-cookie perfection. The stain on this glittering setting, though, is the 19th-century village it shelters. Here, grotesquely impoverished peasants, animated by greed and pagan ritual, thieve and scheme while subsisting largely on bread, tree bark and bats.\n\nVideo\n\nBatty being the operative word in a plot that features a lovelorn young woman (Rea Lest), her dimwitted crush (Jorgen Liik) and the ethereal baroness who has stolen his heart. Around this triangle of unrequited longing, the forest is alive with werewolves and the ghosts of the dead, their antics adding a Monty Python-esque lunacy that amuses and appalls in equal measure.\n\nAdapting Andrus Kivirahk\u2019s 2000 novel \u201cRehepapp,\u201d Mr. Sarnet constructs a cold, cruel world where souls are currency and kisses are usually deadly. Vulgarity and violence abound, not least among the movie\u2019s most entertaining characters: foul-tempered, supernatural slaves known as kratts and assembled from scrap metal and animal bones. When, early in the movie, one of these clanking contraptions steals a cow and carries it into the air, the sight is alarmingly, seductively strange.\n\n\u201cI want to work!\u201d screeches a kratt, voicing the mantra of gadgets that find idleness so intolerable they view it as a reason to kill their makers. And if that\u2019s not a pitch for a sequel, I don\u2019t know what is.", "title": "Review: An Estonian Folk Tale Unfolds in \u2018November\u2019", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Andrus Kivir\u00e4hk", "Novel", "Rainer Sarnet"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "There is no credit for choreography in the Classic Stage Company production of \u201cFire and Air,\u201d which is strange because it\u2019s basically a biography of Sergei Diaghilev.\n\nYou will recall \u2014 and if you don\u2019t, the playwright, Terrence McNally, will repeatedly inform you \u2014 that Diaghilev, working with his prot\u00e9g\u00e9 and lover Nijinsky, was the great impresario of modern ballet as it emerged from the fairy-filled mists of the Romantic era. \u201cI invented the 20th century,\u201d Mr. McNally\u2019s Diaghilev says humbly.\n\nYou witness that process, a little. In one lovely scene, Diaghilev (Douglas Hodge) talks Nijinsky (James Cusati-Moyer) through the opening bars of \u201cThe Afternoon of a Faun,\u201d the groundbreaking Ballets Russes production that caused a scandal at its premiere in Paris in 1912. Nijinsky, who choreographed it and played the title role, brought down the curtain with a bit of improvisation: Instead of deeply inhaling his beloved\u2019s scarf, he basically had sex with it, miming masturbation.\n\nThough we don\u2019t see that \u2014 it is described by shocked onlookers \u2014 a few seconds of the ballet\u2019s prelude are beautifully re-created, from the odd stillness of Nijinsky\u2019s first poses to the pert little tail on his tights. (Ann Hould-Ward designed the terrific costumes.) But the director, John Doyle, never shows us the actual dancing: not from \u201cFaun\u201d or \u201cJeux\u201d or \u201cLe Sacre du Printemps\u201d or the other epochal works that made Diaghilev\u2019s fame, and form the spine of the play.", "title": "Review: An Impresario of \u2018Fire and Air\u2019 (if He Does Say So Himself)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA group of ex-cons in a therapy session introduce themselves, outlining the crimes that landed them in prison.\n\nA bearded guy, Thomas, says he fondled his step-granddaughter for a year and a half before he was stopped. Chris, a fresh-faced 22-year-old, says his girlfriend turned out to be 14. And Chad, a handsome man with haunted eyes, a soft drawl and an aw-shucks charm, says he used to be a teacher. He would rather not go into details, but he molested one of his students.\n\nOn Thursday night, as the actors played this scene in \u201cAmerica Is Hard to See,\u201d a smart and troubling new piece of documentary theater, the room was so pin-drop quiet that you could hear the electric hum of the lights. By then, we had already warmed to some of these characters, already seen them as regular people.\n\nThe makers of this show \u2014 a play with music presented by Life Jacket Theater Company on the intimate main stage at Here \u2014 want us to hold on to that feeling and struggle with it, to try to figure out how to reconcile it with our revulsion. For now, these men are cordoned off from regular society, living in a Florida community for registered sex offenders called Miracle Village. But they won\u2019t stay there forever.\n\nPhoto\n\nWe watch Chad (Ken Barnett), Chris (David Spadora) and Thomas (John Carlin) make progress toward becoming healthier human beings, and we see that the versions of their crimes that they describe to the play\u2019s unseen researchers are not necessarily to be trusted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese people have a real propensity for lying,\u201d a therapist (Joyce Cohen) warns. \u201cThis play of yours, it\u2019s filled with, what do you call it, unreliable narrators?\u201d", "title": "Review: An \u2018Our Town\u2019 With Sex Offenders, in \u2018America Is Hard to See\u2019", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHow much of \u201cThe Music of Silence\u201d is true and how much fiction, only its inspiration, the singer Andrea Bocelli, knows for sure. Adapted from Mr. Bocelli\u2019s 1999 novel of the same name (a story he has described as \u201csimilar to\u201d his own life), this blah trudge from cradle to stage will be catnip to his fans and Ambien to everyone else.\n\nDirected by Michael Radford (no stranger to corny, middle-of-the-road snoozers) with more attention to chronology than creativity, the story dallies so long in its hero\u2019s leafy Tuscan childhood that we\u2019re more than halfway through before anything resembling a singing career materializes. Before then, we learn about the glaucoma that rendered him virtually blind, the soccer accident that exacerbated the condition and the love of music set aside in favor of a law degree.\n\nVideo\n\nAround him, primarily Italian actors gamely wrestle with thickly accented English dialogue, most of it hagiographic and all of it dull. The object of their admiration, meanwhile \u2014 here called Amos Bardi and played as an adult by Toby Sebastian \u2014 is a singularly bland talent, a mopey presence in cardigans and corduroy. Yet my sympathies are all with Mr. Sebastian: It can\u2019t be easy to create a dynamic character when you\u2019re unable to fully open your eyes.\n\nThe filmmakers have no such excuse. Not until Antonio Banderas arrives to play Maestro, the crucial voice coach who knocks Amos into shape, does this metronomic slog to stardom muster a pulse. He\u2019s too late to save the movie, but he\u2019s just in time to stop us from nodding off altogether.", "title": "Review: Andrea Bocelli, From Cradle to Stage in \u2018The Music of Silence\u2019", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Anna Pavignano", "Michael Radford"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The two leading men (Adrian Danchig-Waring, Zachary Catazaro) are seldom parted from their ballerinas (Ashley Laracey, Tiler Peck). The ensemble is led by a pair of determinedly boyish men (Anthony Huxley, Devin Alberda) who dance a chirruping, perky duet together to a pizzicato number. Both chaps then dutifully prove loyal squires to female partners amid a corps where each male-female couple has its little opportunity.\n\nCostumes are colored tights in purples, greens, saffrons, with unobtrusive matching jackets. There is no program acknowledgment for d\u00e9cor, but a curving mauve neon line across the back \u2014 part of Mark Stanley\u2019s lighting \u2014 slowly falls and rises during the ballet. In my quest for \u201codyssey\u201d meaning, I tried seeing this as a coastline, but that got me nowhere.\n\nMr. Walker is a better dancemaker than he wants to let us notice. His steps flow brightly and smoothly; he gives agreeable opportunities to his dancers. But his duets tend to be clingy, his ensemble geometries very neat indeed, and his sense of drama doesn\u2019t get beyond assuring that all\u2019s well with the world.\n\nPart of a program of 21st-century choreography, \u201cdance odyssey\u201d is sandwiched between works made in 2006, Peter Martins\u2019s \u201cThe Red Violin\u201d and Alexei Ratmansky\u2019s \u201cRussian Seasons.\u201d \u201cThe Red Violin\u201d is almost the direct reverse of \u201cdance odyssey\u201d: Its world is dark, its four women and four men find no content with themselves or with each other, and while there are no felicities to its steps, it has a toughness and suspense that keep me watching.\n\nAs for \u201cRussian Seasons,\u201d it at once seizes attention and keeps rewarding it. Two men take double air turns and then do so immediately again, but the second time landing not upright but flat on the floor. The surprise and the rhythm \u2014 bounce, spin, land, bounce, spin, splat! \u2014 make a wonderful introduction. What follows is a mysterious world with its own folk vitality. Dancers keep stepping out into the beyond even while they wrap arms about themselves as if checked by inner forces: they look conflicted, urgent, with marvelously vivid inner and outer lives. At Thursday\u2019s performance, Maria Kowroski, who has been dancing with ever greater finesse and poetry in Balanchine ballets this season, made her debut in the lead role with quietly compelling authority.", "title": "Review: At City Ballet, a Prettily Arcadian \u2018Dance Odyssey\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Every ensemble performing in Carnegie Hall, where audiences and acoustics seem to welcome if not invite blockbuster programs, must be tempted to show off, at least a little. And none have succumbed more readily than the Chicago Symphony Orchestra did in the 1970s and \u201980s, when it was directed by Georg Solti.\n\nIt was a paltry New York season then that did not include a Mahler or Bruckner symphony, or even a Wagner opera, from the City of Broad Shoulders. So all the more remarkable were the modest affairs that the conductor Riccardo Muti and the Chicago Symphony brought to Carnegie over the weekend, with no huge statements, no overarching themes.\n\nThey seemed calculated to demonstrate a malleability and versatility fostered in later years by Daniel Barenboim and honed to a fine touch by Mr. Muti. Especially revealing was Jennifer Higdon\u2019s new Low Brass Concerto, commissioned by the orchestra and heard in its New York premiere on Friday evening.", "title": "Review: Chicago Symphony Displays Out-of-Character Modesty at Carnegie", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Even with a title as seemingly straightforward as \u201cAutobiography,\u201d a dance by the brainy British choreographer Wayne McGregor isn\u2019t likely to be plain memoir. And sure enough, the work, which had its United States debut at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, was partly generated through science. Mr. McGregor had his genome sequenced. Before each performance a computer algorithm based on that biographical data determines the sequencing of the dance\u2019s 23 sections. So each performance is different.\n\nYet for a work to be reordered meaningfully, it must have some comprehensible order to begin with. In \u201cAutobiography,\u201d the title and number of each section are flashed as that section starts, and the titles suggest parts of a life, or ideas about one: Nature, Nurture, Aging, Sleep. Yet if these titles were decoupled from their sections and reshuffled, it would make little difference. The one called \u201cMemories\u201d could just as well be \u201cChoosing.\u201d\n\nThe cause is within, less the ordering of sections than the ordering of steps. Mr. McGregor\u2019s troupe is no longer called Random Dance \u2014 it\u2019s Company Wayne McGregor \u2014 but his sense of sequence is still random in effect, section to section and moment to moment. As ever, his androgynous dancers are a hyper-flexible tribe, able to stretch, splay and bend every which way. Amid this signature elasticity, Mr. McGregor now adds emotional gestures: heads in hands, bodies cradling bodies. But these gestures are just extra bits in the blender, no more or less affecting.\n\nPhoto\n\nInstead of shape or heart, there is impressive surface style. The set by Ben Cullen Williams is a spiky metal grid that hangs above the dancers and sometimes descends upon them like a cage contracting. Lucy Carter\u2019s lighting does even more to slice and dice the stage space. Its sweeping planes of illumination are sculptural and dynamic.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll this technical sophistication, though, seems to be at the service of a fundamentally unsophisticated sensibility, most glaringly exposed by the music. When the piece debuted in Britain, some critics complained about harsh blasts in the electronic score by Jlin. I wanted earplugs for the soft sections, protection from sentimentality and the dull thudding of chic clich\u00e9. Except for a brief respite of Corelli, we might have been in the lounge of a boutique hotel.\n\nThe combination of this music with the preening, aggressive-recessive manner of Mr. McGregor\u2019s choreography is often close to unbearable, and the scrambled structure offers no path through the mire. For all the intellectual effort that his work has long flaunted \u2014 this program credits institutes across Europe as \u201congoing scientific partners\u201d \u2014 it has never been dry movement research. The investigations of corporeal possibilities are electrified, with enough spectacle to make you wonder what it might be masking.", "title": "Review: Dancing the Genome in Wayne McGregor\u2019s \u2018Autobiography\u2019", "authors": ["Brian Seibert"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Working with the production company of the Oscar-winning documentarian Morgan Neville, Mr. Chang and Mr. Meehan dress up \u201cUgly Delicious\u201d with stylistic flourishes that recall Mr. Bourdain\u2019s shows as well as \u201cThe Mind of a Chef,\u201d which Mr. Chang and Mr. Bourdain originated. The restaurant visits and chef interviews are broken up with fake commercials, animations, film clips and parodies of Japanese TV comedies or the \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d Julia-Child-bleeds-out skit. The season finale is structured as a debate between Mr. Chang and the chef Mario Carbone over the relative merits of Italian filled pastas and Asian dumplings.\n\nThese techniques, and a generous Netflix budget, are on display in the pizza episode, which was filmed in Brooklyn, Tokyo, New Haven, Copenhagen, Naples, Los Angeles and Las Vegas. Demonstrating his trademark contrarianism, Mr. Chang praises Domino\u2019s \u2014 even donning the company vest and delivering pies \u2014 and declares New Haven and then Tokyo as the homes of the world\u2019s best pizza.\n\nThe visual curlicues and the attempts to impose a larger thematic structure and narrative \u2014 there\u2019s an awful lot of tired talk about how food tells stories \u2014 don\u2019t hide the reality that there isn\u2019t a whole lot new or surprising about \u201cUgly Delicious.\u201d (The exception: the openness with which it discusses racism as a fundamental force in culinary culture.) Its primary influence, as with other food shows, will probably be to max out reservations at impossibly cool-looking restaurants like the Tokyo pizzeria Seirinkan or the locavorish Salare in Seattle.\n\nWhat the show is really selling is the Chang attitude and mystique, a combination of ego, exactitude, foul-mouthed rebelliousness and self-deprecatory nerdiness. With the opening of Momofuku Noodle Bar 14 years ago, he fortuitously caught the waves of both millennial casualness and fangirl-fanboy-style fetishization (of ingredients, of methods, of chefs) that swept through the restaurant business.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAn important part of Mr. Chang\u2019s persona at the start was his outsider status, casting stones at (or at least making withering remarks about) the bastions of haute cuisine where he had learned his trade. That became problematic as he built an international restaurant empire that recently added the 200-plus-seat Momofuku Las Vegas.\n\nAnd in \u201cUgly Delicious\u201d he moves with a band of insiders that includes Mr. Meehan, the superstar Danish chef Ren\u00e9 Redzepi and Mr. Ansari, Mr. Chang\u2019s fellow Netflix star. It\u2019s also a boy\u2019s club. An episode about home cooking is the only one with an equal representation of women and men among the significant speaking roles. In all the others men outnumber women by 2 or 3 to 1; in the pizza episode it\u2019s 8 to 1. This may reflect the state of affairs in the food industry, but it\u2019s surprising for a series that wants to talk about diversity and representation.\n\n(African-American chefs and commentators are even less present, appearing almost exclusively in an episode about the coded meanings and cultural signifiers of fried chicken.)\n\nThe show often allows Mr. Chang\u2019s rough edges to show, and sometimes its picture of him is unflattering in ways that don\u2019t seem intentional. His jibes can cross over into meanness, and his pontifications can appear oblivious, as when he compares the art of barbecue to the art of jazz in an episode focused entirely on white and Asian cooks.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how the hell it all happened,\u201d Mr. Chang says, contemplating the franchise that he has become. The claim seems unlikely, and one way to see the show, with its focus on pizza and tacos and dumplings, is as a branding exercise \u2014 a pivot away from high-intensity cooking toward the ugly deliciousness of comfort food. The penultimate episode ends with him holding a plate of kimchi and Spam fried rice toward the camera. In the Chang vernacular, it looks bonkers, and you\u2019ll want to crush it.", "title": "Review: David Chang in the Comfort Food Zone on Netflix", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The most stable presence around Eller is her 17-year-old grandson, Jaybo (Reynaldo Piniella). The kid has had to grow up fast, and he cheerily handles the responsibilities of looking after someone with dementia while holding a job at a local steakhouse. The pair\u2019s relationship is easy enough, though the grandmother occasionally reminds her caretaker of the pecking order. \u201cGoddamnit, boy,\u201d Eller snaps at some point, \u201cI am still the boss of me, and the boss of you for that matter.\u201d Ms. O\u2019Connell, who had so far perfectly acted the part of the eccentric little old lady losing her marbles, finds the steely spine that we realize has supported Eller through her tough life.\n\nJaybo is black, and what we learn of his lineage helps fill in the outline of Eller\u2019s tragedy. The partly autobiographical \u201cTerminus,\u201d which is set in 1994, is the second play in a planned cycle set in a small Georgia town, and the region\u2019s history of racial prejudice looms over the show. Mr. Dean and the director Lucie Tiberghien do not always work in issues of race smoothly, though, and the biggest stumble in this production from the Monk Parrots company involves Jaybo\u2019s crush on Finch (Vanessa Butler), a black hobo who takes a break from her travels to observe the weird family she has so improbably stumbled upon. Finch, who is remarkably clean-cut for an unwashed anarcho-punk, represents freedom, sexuality and a comfortable racial identity. But the actors never build a convincing rapport, and an awkward scene involving a kissing lesson makes the show grind to a halt.\n\nMr. Dean is better at atmosphere than plot details so he is best when the ground is shifting and Ms. O\u2019Connell is trying to preserve her shaky balance. We can only thank the gods of theater to have put the play\u2019s harrowing final scene in her hands.", "title": "Review: Deirdre O\u2019Connell Loses Her Grip on Reality in \u2018Terminus\u2019", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Eve Ensler has a word she wants you to get comfortable with.\n\nNo, not that one.\n\nHer remarkably successful play \u201cThe Vagina Monologues,\u201d first seen Off Off Broadway in 1996 and then pretty much all over the world except where it was banned, helped normalize the frank discussion of women\u2019s sexuality (and anatomy) onstage. It also fostered and financed a project called V-Day, which has raised tens of millions of dollars for antiviolence organizations.\n\nBut the new word Ms. Ensler wants you to embrace \u2014 a word that is the subject of her play \u201cIn the Body of the World,\u201d which opened on Tuesday in a Manhattan Theater Club production \u2014 is not so lovable. It\u2019s \u201ctumor.\u201d\n\nIn May 2010, just as she was about to attend the opening of City of Joy, a sanctuary she helped to found for rape victims in Congo, Ms. Ensler received a diagnosis of uterine cancer. \u201cIn the Body of the World,\u201d directed by Diane Paulus, is a troubling record of her attempt to survive that illness, in part by understanding its meaning. Had she somehow poisoned herself, as humans every day poison the earth? (The recent BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was on her mind.) Could the disease growing inside her be an expression of the global disease of violence done to women by men?\n\n\u201cCancer threw me into the center of my body\u2019s crisis,\u201d she says near the beginning of the play. \u201cThe Congo threw me into the crisis of the world, and these two experiences merged as I faced what I felt sure was the beginning of the end.\u201d", "title": "Review: Eve Ensler Goes Deep \u2018In the Body of the World\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Previously on \u201cOne Bruise at a Time\u201d (a.k.a. the first two \u201cFifty Shades\u201d outings): Ana and Christian (Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan), our slap-and-tickle surrogates, bonded through bondage and a shared affection for flattering lighting. Now, with \u201cFifty Shades Freed,\u201d we\u2019ve reached what the publicity notes are pleased to call \u201cthe climactic chapter\u201d of this titillation trilogy based on the heavy-breathing novels of E.L. James. If another sequel shows up, though, I\u2019m going to have to use my safe word.\n\nLayering a damp-squib thriller subplot beneath what appears to be an ad campaign for the one-percent lifestyle, the returning director and screenwriter (James Foley and Niall Leonard) test the newly married couple with an inconvenient pregnancy and an unconvincing car chase. There\u2019s an out-of-left-field abduction and a marital tiff over email addresses; but these narrative fragments, lazily tossed together alongside a neglected supporting cast, are no more than a flimsy causeway connecting bonking sessions.", "title": "Review: Finally, the Audience Is \u2018Fifty Shades Freed\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The sheer volume of existing scholarship on the history of civil rights in the United States poses a formidable challenge to any academic seeking to say something new or unexpected. Adam Winkler, a professor at the law school at the University of California Los Angeles, has nonetheless managed to produce a work that is both engrossing and surprising. Professor Winkler has identified a secret parallel universe of civil rights whose beneficiaries are not the \u201cdiscrete and insular minorities\u201d whose protection were once the focus of the Supreme Court\u2019s jurisprudence.\n\nFrom pre-Revolutionary times to now, \u201cWe the Corporations: How American Businesses Won Their Civil Rights\u201d charts the strategies and philosophical battles that have now earned state-created corporate entities much the same civil rights as individual citizens. Professor Winkler argues that this has occurred because corporate rights \u201chave largely been won in the courts, not in the streets, and have developed largely without much public scrutiny.\u201d\n\nRecent Supreme Court decisions in the Citizens United and Hobby Lobby cases have brought the apparent triumph of corporate rights to the forefront of the national consciousness. But the nature of the role of corporations in United States history is poorly appreciated, often undermining the quality of the resulting debate. We celebrate the persecuted Pilgrims\u2019 landing at Plymouth Rock in 1620 every Thanksgiving, but years earlier \u201cthe Virginia Company of London founded England\u2019s first permanent New World colony in Jamestown.\u201d And few realize that key portions of the earliest state constitutions \u2014 including the recognition of individual rights \u2014 are lifted wholesale from the corporate charters of these early colonies.\n\nThat said, given the absence of any mention in the Constitution of corporations or, with the exception of the First Amendment\u2019s reference to \u201cthe press,\u201d businesses of any kind, the ability of these \u201cartificial persons\u201d to secure many of the same rights as real people is a little shocking. The corporate rights movement achieved this result by following many of the same tactics as the more familiar modern African-American civil rights movement, using test cases and civil disobedience. More broadly, the biggest differences between the corporate and individual civil rights movement is the relentlessness and rate of success of corporate litigants.", "title": "Review: How Corporate America Won Its Civil Rights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe animated shorts nominated for Oscars are rarely the subjects of controversy. But this year, \u201cDear Basketball,\u201d which the retired N.B.A. star Kobe Bryant conceived, executive-produced and narrated, drew some #MeToo movement disapprobation when it was announced as one of the five nominees for the 90th Academy Awards. On social media and elsewhere, a 2003 sexual assault case against Mr. Bryant (which was later dismissed) was cited as a reason not to honor the movie. But the content of this short is unobjectionable on the surface. Directed by Glen Keane, the movie is an autobiographical sketch in which Mr. Bryant thanks basketball \u2014 both the object and the game \u2014 for the life he devoted to it. The animation, rendered in modes of pencils and pastels, has a gorgeous fluency to be sure. The score is by none other than John Williams, American cinema\u2019s king of the Heroic Theme. Ultimately, \u201cDear Basketball\u201d is substance-free, an advertisement for itself. It deserves to not receive an Oscar for that reason alone.\n\nVideo\n\nThree of the other shorts are not without their pleasures. \u201cLou,\u201d a Pixar short directed by Dave Mullins, sees the anthropomorphized contents of a schoolyard lost-and-found box teaching a lesson to a bully. The premise is a stretch, but Pixar\u2019s tech mastery and imaginative chops were made to render such stretches into good cartoons, and this is one. \u201cNegative Space,\u201d directed by Max Porter and Ru Kuwahata, is realized in exquisite stop-motion animation. An adult reminisces about how his father taught him to efficiently pack a suitcase; the childhood memories yield to a chilly present-day and a road trip to a farewell. \u201cRevolting Rhymes\u201d is a BBC adaptation of Roald Dahl\u2019s cheeky revisionist fairy-tale poetry book. A wolf (superbly voiced by Dominic West) regales a baby sitter with the real lowdown on Red Riding Hood and Snow White, with couplets including \u201cThen this is the disgusting part/the Queen sat down and ate the heart.\u201d The computer animation here yields a fun variety of facial caricatures for the beloved figures being deconstructed.\n\nThe really outstanding nominee is \u201cGarden Party,\u201d directed by a French collective of six that calls itself Illogic. It\u2019s a simple narrative in which a few animals, mostly amphibious \u2014 a tree frog and a bullfrog among them \u2014 trudge out of water and down from branches into a mysteriously deserted mansion. The mastery of computer animation here is staggering. The rotting food in the kitchen that the animals snack on is a vivid metaphor for human overconsumption, and the reason for the house\u2019s desolate state is both horror-movie grim and mordantly funny. Watch out for Illogic \u2014 these artists are sure to be heard from more decisively in the future.", "title": "Review: In These Oscar-Nominated Animated Shorts, Riveting Fairy Tales and Kitchen Rot", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "In the first scene of Steph Del Rosso\u2019s hectic comedy \u201cFill Fill Fill Fill Fill Fill Fill\u201d at the Flea Theater, rock god Noah drags his girlfriend Joni onstage in the middle of a concert and tells her that he wants to see other people.\n\n\u201cWhy are we doing this here?\u201d Joni wails.\n\n\u201cBecause I wanted it to feel special,\u201d he says.\n\nA discombobulated Joni (a plucky Sarah Chalfie) leaves the venue and is immediately surrounded by friends and well-meaning strangers. They tell her to take up acupuncture and give up dairy, to put herself out there and take time to heal.\n\nJoni\u2019s body feels full of holes. Urged on by the imperative of the title, she bombards a waiter with existential questions; she invites a couple home for a threesome; she catches up with a college friend; and she appears on a game show designed to empower women.\n\nMaybe she\u2019s trying to find herself, maybe she\u2019s trying to lose herself, maybe\u2019s she\u2019s just trying to shamble from one heart-shattered day to the next.", "title": "Review: In This Play, Her Boyfriend Dumps Her. Should She Find Love, or Herself?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn some years, watching the Oscar-nominated documentary shorts is the easiest way to spot the winner. This year there are plausible rationalizations for all five.\n\nThe front-runner is probably Elaine McMillion Sheldon\u2019s \u201cHeroin(e),\u201d which bears the imprimatur of Netflix, the company that took this statuette last year with \u201cThe White Helmets.\u201d The most visceral of the nominees, it addresses an issue in the news \u2014 the opioid epidemic \u2014 with present-tense reportage and an eye toward putting human faces on the crisis.\n\nThe movie follows three women combating the proliferation of drugs in the heavily affected city of Huntington, W.Va. The filmmakers trail Jan Rader, who becomes the city\u2019s fire chief, on tense overdose calls, and sit in the courtroom of Judge Patricia Keller, who speaks to the recovering addicts before her with the patience of a parent. Necia Freeman hands out food to addicted prostitutes.\n\nVideo\n\nAt 39 minutes, \u201cHeroin(e)\u201d sprawls; each thread could sustain longer-term treatment. In sheer scope, the movie is likely to overshadow Thomas Lennon\u2019s \u201cKnife Skills,\u201d though Mr. Lennon\u2019s film will attract anyone eager to gawk at mouthwatering food. It follows the first class of trainee workers at Edwins, a Cleveland haute cuisine restaurant committed to hiring the formerly incarcerated, with the hope of preventing their returns to prison.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPolice brutality is front and center in Kate Davis\u2019s powerful \u201cTraffic Stop,\u201d which revisits the violent arrest of Breaion King, an African-American teacher in Austin, Tex., flagged by an officer for a traffic violation. The movie combines the dashcam footage of the arrest with Ms. King\u2019s reflections on the incident. The biographical details, meant to warm the heart and stoke outrage, feel superfluous. (A violent arrest would be a violent arrest even if Ms. King weren\u2019t a model citizen.)\n\n\u201cHeaven Is a Traffic Jam on the 405\u201d tells the story of Mindy Alper, who spent her life grappling with mental illness, and emerged as a successful artist. The director, Frank Stiefel, draws on Ms. Alper\u2019s artwork for visual flair, but the film is a bit of a slog.\n\n\u201cEdith+Eddie,\u201d from the Chicago documentary house Kartemquin Films, simply offers a moving portrait. The director Laura Checkoway watches compassionately as the title characters \u2014 a Virginia couple who met when splitting a lottery ticket and married in their mid-90s \u2014 are separated because of squabbling family members and an indifferent bureaucracy. It\u2019s the most intimate movie in the lineup, and all the better for it.", "title": "Review: In the Oscar-Nominated Documentary Shorts, Moving Portraits and Visceral Stories", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nChurning with gun violence, racism, prejudice and religious conflict, four of the five live-action short films nominated for Oscars this year feel so weighty that the lone comedy comes as something of a relief.\n\nThat would be \u201cThe Eleven O\u2019Clock,\u201d Derin Seale\u2019s whip-smart standoff between a psychiatrist and a delusional patient that resembles your worst psychoanalytic nightmare. Hinging on a showdown between objective reality and individual fantasy, this brisk Australian entry is as painfully relevant to our unstable political moment as most of its fellow nominees.\n\nVideo\n\nThree are based on actual incidents, including both American entries, Reed Van Dyk's \u201cDeKalb Elementary\u201d \u2014 a throat-tightening duet between a disturbed school shooter and an empathetic administrator \u2014 and the quietly potent \u201cMy Nephew Emmett.\u201d Unfolding during the hours preceding the 1955 murder of the black teenager Emmett Till, Kevin Wilson, Jr.\u2019s fraught drama, richly photographed in glowing gold and mahogany, coaxes tension from little more than a simple shack and a marvelous performance from L.B. Williams as Till\u2019s uncle, a man who has seen too much and knows what\u2019s coming.\n\nBigotry of a different kind powers the German filmmaker Katja Benrath\u2019s \u201cWatu Wote/All of Us,\u201d as Muslim bus passengers in Kenya rally to protect a terrified Christian woman from an attack by Al-Shabaab terrorists. My personal favorite, though, is \u201cThe Silent Child,\u201d Chris Overton\u2019s heartbreaking story (written by one of its stars, Rachel Shenton) about a profoundly isolated deaf 5-year-old (a wonderful Maisie Sly) and the social worker who tries to help her. Gorgeously shot and perfectly performed, the movie delivers an emotional wallop that many features six times its length never achieve.", "title": "Review: In the Oscar-Nominated Live Action Shorts, Four Dramas and a Comedy", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "A science-fiction fantasy spiked with baroque horror, \u201cAnnihilation\u201d tells an enigmatic tale of love and death and alien invasion. Set in a future that looks pretty much like today, it centers on a biologist, Lena (Natalie Portman), who shortly after the movie opens reunites with her husband, Kane (Oscar Isaac), who she thought was dead. As he sits in their kitchen, the camera slinking about, Lena\u2019s surprise gives way to happiness and then to mounting wariness that, like some kind of contagion, soon slithers under your skin. To understand what has happened and why, Lena sets off on a heroic journey, one that \u2014 like most such adventures \u2014 inevitably leads inward with each searching step.\n\nThe setup turns on one of those alien mysteries (an extraterrestrial or a monolith or floating spaceships) that have come to Earth to wreak havoc or hatch conspiracies and force humans to make bad choices. The foreign body here takes the form of what\u2019s called the shimmer: a glistening, ever-growing force field that has descended on a swath of Florida marshland like an opalescent shower curtain. The shimmer\u2019s whirling pinky purples and blues evoke the rainbow colors you see in oily patches on a road after it rains, which suggests there\u2019s something toxic about its beauty. The rainbow can\u2019t help but also evoke the adventurous Dorothy, another traveler to a strange land.\n\nLena heads off on her own far-out trip soon after arriving at a government bunker at the edge of the shimmer. There, anonymous types scurry around or stare into computers; some carry guns, others clipboards; still others wear Hazmat suits. After a banging start \u2014 an inquisition, a homecoming \u2014 the writer-director Alex Garland fumbles putting these pieces in place. He rolls out the introductions, drops a little mumbo jumbo and some data points (mostly from Dr. Ventress, a shrink played by the perfectly chilled Jennifer Jason Leigh); he also engages in too much narrative throat clearing. Finally, Lena and four other armed women pass into the shimmer, which is where the story gets its weird on.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Annihilation,\u2019 a Heroic Journey into the Alien Shimmer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAthena,\u201d produced by the Hearth, is a much more conventional play than Ms. Gardner\u2019s \u201cP____ Sludge,\u201d a surrealist yowl that won the American Playwriting Foundation\u2019s Relentless Award. (The title is relentless, too.) The structure of \u201cAthena\u201d can feel too pat, the culminating bout predictable.\n\nBut to the director Emma Miller\u2019s credit, that bout is a long, real-time slog up and down the piste, effortful and tough, and a little ugly. (The simple set, with the girls\u2019 foils playing against Jack\u2019s aluminum foil walls is by Emmie Finckel. The costumes, little more than white sneakers and electrified uniforms, are by Dara Affholter.) And the play never diminishes or mocks the importance of a relationship that flourishes and maybe dies over a couple of months during junior year. It treats these girls and their ambitions with the seriousness they deserve.\n\nMs. Awe and Ms. Greer play their roles with humor, grit and team spirit \u2014 palpable even behind those mesh masks. Ms. Awe plays Mary as childlike, but also as the more confident of the pair. Ms. Greer\u2019s Athena is more worldly, but also much needier and more fragile. The twining of these characters and performances makes \u201cAthena\u201d hugely appealing and stealthily moving. Then again, I would say that. They\u2019re the ones holding the swords. They\u2019ve been trained to use them.\n\nThe play is a work of realism. Parts of it cut so close to lived female experience \u2014 the white, urban, middle-class version, anyway \u2014 that they hardly feel like fiction at all. But the play made me think about science fiction and the time machine I\u2019d need to send my teenage self to the show. (She read a lot about the Warhol Factory and would have dug the foil walls.)\n\nWhen I was reading my way through the school library\u2019s theater section, there weren\u2019t many plays by and about young women. There was \u201cA Taste of Honey,\u201d sure, and \u201cRita, Sue and Bob, Too,\u201d and not a lot more. But in the last several years we\u2019ve seen Sarah DeLappe\u2019s \u201cThe Wolves,\u201d Clare Barron\u2019s \u201cI\u2019ll Never Love Again\u201d and Tina Satter\u2019s \u201cIn the Pony Palace/Football,\u201d not to mention Ruby Rae Spiegel\u2019s \u201cDry Land\u201d and Jocelyn Bioh\u2019s \u201cSchool Girls; Or, the African Mean Girls Play.\u201d Will we add the \u201cMean Girls\u201d musical to the canon? We\u2019ll see, babe.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Athena,\u2019 Two Teenage Fencers Parry Ordinary Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "A description of \u201cBecks,\u201d about a lesbian musician who returns to the more conservative environment in which she grew up, makes it sound like an earnest, shopworn indie drama. But the movie exemplifies how small judgments in pace, performance and soundtrack can transcend modest trappings.\n\nMuch of the credit is due to the film\u2019s charismatic, tone-perfect lead, Lena Hall, who won a Tony in 2014 for \u201cHedwig and the Angry Inch.\u201d She plays Becks, a Brooklyn guitarist and singer who follows her girlfriend (Hayley Kiyoko) to Los Angeles \u2014 only to catch her with another woman.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Becks,\u2019 a Guitarist With the Blues Returns Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "When will they ever learn? The aliens, I mean, who can\u2019t seem to resist the impulse to invade Earth and wipe out humanity. \u201cBefore We Vanish,\u201d Kiyoshi Kurosawa\u2019s witty science-fiction chin-scratcher \u2014 less a horror movie than a series of musings on potentially horrifying ideas \u2014 addresses the question literally. It concerns a reconnaissance squad of space travelers sent to do fieldwork in our ways and habits, with particular emphasis on our mental concepts.\n\nThere is a long and rich tradition of debate in philosophy and cognitive science about the nature of those entities, which the three main aliens resolve with impressive practical acumen. For them, to acquire a concept is to steal it from the person who explained it, a theft that is consummated by a brisk tap on the forehead. The victim crumples to the ground (there are some variations on this procedure) and then resumes life missing a key piece of mental furniture.\n\nThe result is not always terrifying. A manipulative, sexually-harassing boss, robbed of \u201cwork,\u201d capers across the desktops of his office, laughing and tossing paper airplanes. A young man who has lived for a long time as an anxious shut-in loses \u201chome\u201d and finds himself free to explore the world and embrace political causes. It almost seems as if the aliens do their unwitting hosts a favor. The catch is that they plan to exterminate us and take over the planet.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Before We Vanish,\u2019 the Aliens Have a Lot of Questions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWould you care to look at me?\u201d Happy to oblige, but then it would be hard not to.\n\nThe statuesque performer Jomama Jones was wearing a sleeveless gold sequined number while she formulated that question, which was also a demand. \u201cI give you all permission to take me in,\u201d she continued with the noblesse oblige of an entertainer fully aware of her glamour.\n\nMind you, that outfit was just one of the five, all equally fabulous, she changed in and out of during her show, \u201cBlack Light,\u201d a Public Theater offering at Joe\u2019s Pub.\n\nMaking her way among the tables, the singer gently teased the audience. To the gentleman who said he was from Mexico, she asked of his country, \u201cDo they have the animal the cougar?\u201d", "title": "Review: In \u2018Black Light,\u2019 an Alter Ego Takes Over, and She Is One Diva", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "What if a group of dancers, mid-performance, just wandered away and didn\u2019t come back? On Thursday at Danspace Project, during the premiere of Mina Nishimura\u2019s \u201cBladder Inn (and X, Y, Z, W),\u201d such a development often seemed imminent. In a loosely knit hourlong show that spilled from the sanctuary of St. Mark\u2019s Church into its back rooms and balconies, Ms. Nishimura, one of eight dancers, created not so much a world as an atmosphere, a web of activity on the brink of dissolving.\n\nAn entrancing performer in her own work and others\u2019 \u2014 like that of her husband, Kota Yamazaki, and the choreographer Dean Moss \u2014 Ms. Nishimura can\u2019t help but be a focal point onstage. (Mr. Moss\u2019s \u201cPetra,\u201d just last week, included a brilliant autobiographical monologue that she wrote and delivered.) She doesn\u2019t demand attention, she just attracts it, in part through her ability to embody multiple qualities at the same time. An action as simple as walking becomes riveting through the illusion of a floating torso supported by weighted, wooden legs. Details as fine as a corner of the mouth, isolated and upturned while the opposite corner rests, spring into view. Often she appears animated, spookily, by forces outside of herself.\n\nLike other dancer-choreographers with distinctive ways of moving, Ms. Nishimura faces the challenge of translating that style onto fellow performers. In \u201cBladder Inn\u201d (what to make of the title?), no one quite matches her strange interiority and specificity. But rather than fighting that difference, she folds it into the format of the work. The piece takes shape as a suite of concurrent solos, each dancer roaming around on his or her own phantomlike terms: crawling backward through open doors, grazing bare walls, staggering out from hallways and stairwells we can\u2019t see.\n\nThe house lights, for the most part, stay up. Distant murmurs and slamming doors mingle with the clacking and oceanic undulations in Masahiro Sugaya\u2019s unobtrusive score. So do the dancers\u2019 vocalizations, like Jonathan Burklund yelling \u201cHey!\u201d in time with the flick of a hand, or Samuel Hanson howling, or Lydia Chrisman singing a few crystal-clear notes.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Bladder Inn,\u2019 Waiting for Dancers to Wander Away", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "An autobiographical meditation on identity and presence, Mashuq Mushtaq Deen\u2019s solo show, \u201cDraw the Circle,\u201d is the story of a suburban girl named Shireen and a Brooklyn man named Deen. They are the same person. And yet they are not.\n\nIn a series of monologues, sometimes gentle and sometimes harrowing, family members, lovers and others tell us about Shireen\u2019s growing unhappiness \u2014 the disorientation, the hospitalizations, the suicide attempts \u2014 and gradual recovery, which culminates in her becoming Deen through a gender transition. Neither Shireen nor Deen ever appears as a character.\n\n\u201cDraw the Circle,\u201d which runs in repertory at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater with Dael Orlandersmith\u2019s \u201cUntil the Flood,\u201d opens with a picture of a smiling girl in a red sweater, an image that fades as Mr. Deen, wearing jeans and a rumpled T-shirt, enters, stepping into the first of a number of lit squares.\n\nA few days before Thanksgiving, Deen\u2019s girlfriend, Molly, is heading to Connecticut with Deen to see his parents, Indian immigrants who struggle to accept them. \u201cWe haven\u2019t seen them in two years,\u201d Molly explains. \u201cIt\u2019s like I\u2019ve got to prove myself all over again. Yes, I\u2019m white. No, I\u2019m not Muslim. Yes, I\u2019m a girl.\u201d Deen has even more to prove.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Draw the Circle,\u2019 a Girl Becomes a Man", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf the filmmaker Charlie Kaufman, best known for scripting metaphysical puzzle films like \u201cBeing John Malkovich\u201d and \u201cEternal Sunshine Of the Spotless Mind\u201d were to try his hand at a Young Adult story, \u201cEvery Day\u201d might be it. The movie\u2019s second lead character, a consciousness or, if you will, soul that refers to itself as \u201cA,\u201d inexplicably wakes up every morning inhabiting a different teenager\u2019s body. \u201cA\u201d has this amazing personality that it supposedly tries not to let impinge overmuch on its host\u2019s own personality. But one morning, A wakes up in the body of the handsome but loutish Justin. He\u2019s the boyfriend of Rhiannon, a bright, beautiful high schooler who deserves better. And thanks to A, she gets it, for one magical day of hooky.\n\nVideo\n\nAfter which A is, well, hooked. It pursues a skeptical-to-the-point-of-freaked-out (wouldn\u2019t you be?) Rhiannon from a variety of bodies, male and female. Midway through the picture, A wakes up in Rhiannon\u2019s body, and the twist, while reminiscent of one in \u201cBeing John Malkovich,\u201d is heartwarmingly benign.\n\nNow would be a good time to point out that Charlie Kaufman did not write this \u2014 the screenplay is by Jesse Andrews, from a novel by David Levithan. (It is perhaps no accident, however, that one of the film\u2019s producers is Anthony Bregman, who also produced three Kaufman-penned movies.) The director is Michael Sucsy, who is not always up to the challenges of the knotty material \u2014 we live in a world of mainstream movies with clumsy edits, but this one has more conspicuously bad cuts than most. The cast does excellent work, particularly Justice Smith, who as Justin gets to play World\u2019s Worst and Best boyfriend and nails both. And as Rhiannon, the appealing Angourie Rice is just the kind of teenager you root for in the finding-true-love department.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Every Day,\u2019 Each 24 Hours Brings Another Boyfriend", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "David Levithan", "Novel"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter his hit series \u201cSix Feet Under\u201d ended in 2005, Alan Ball indulged his inner fanboy, creating the vampire melodrama \u201cTrue Blood\u201d and working on the gothic small-town-crime story \u201cBanshee.\u201d The move suited him \u2014 his aptitudes for dark comedy and unsettling atmosphere were a natural fit for genre entertainment.\n\nBut with \u201cHere and Now,\u201d his new family drama for HBO (beginning Sunday), he\u2019s back to making Big Statements, his mode in his Oscar-winning screenplay for \u201cAmerican Beauty\u201d in 1999. \u201cWe\u2019re living in a new reality\u201d is the tagline on the show\u2019s billboards, and Mr. Ball wants to say something definitive about it.\n\nUnfortunately \u2014 and this was also true of \u201cAmerican Beauty,\u201d despite its multiple Academy Awards \u2014 he doesn\u2019t have anything new or particularly interesting to say. Straight white people are self-loathing and lame. Dads are depressed but redeemable, moms are pretty much a lost cause. We\u2019d all be better off if we put away our cellphones and got outside.\n\nThrough four episodes of its 10-episode season, \u201cHere and Now\u201d works the well-plowed soil of middle-age suburban malaise, the ground of Updike, Cheever and their many imitators. The suburbs have been replaced by Portland, Ore., and the ennui-ridden father, Greg Boatwright (Tim Robbins), is 60, the new middle age. (Kevin Spacey\u2019s Lester Burnham in \u201cAmerican Beauty\u201d was 42.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe biggest update is that Greg and his wife, Audrey Bayer (Holly Hunter), have raised the kind of blended family that exists primarily as a screenwriter\u2019s conceit: Ramon, from Colombia (Daniel Zovatto); Ashley, from Liberia (Jerrika Hinton); and Duc, from Vietnam (Raymond Lee); all adopted and all now adults. The brood is completed by the teenage Kristen (Sosie Bacon, the daughter of Kevin Bacon and Kyra Sedgwick), Audrey and Greg\u2019s biological child, who calls herself \u201cthe boring white chick in the family.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe children constitute a rainbow chorus calling out the pretensions and blind spots of their parents, a philosophy professor (Greg) and professional conflict resolver (Audrey) whose smug \u201960s liberalism is indicated by the scent of patchouli and the sound of Joni Mitchell. Mr. Ball is particularly hard on Audrey, missing no chance to paint her as controlling and narcissistic.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Here and Now,\u2019 Alan Ball Makes America Grim Again", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The two specimens of this type that Ms. Burgess offers in \u201cKings\u201d are not designed to elicit your sympathy. Kate (Gillian Jacobs, late of NBC\u2019s \u201cCommunity\u201d) not only repackages her clients\u2019 grubby schemes as votable policy, but is also rude and double-dealing. Lauren (Aya Cash, a star of \u201cYou\u2019re the Worst\u201d on FXX) is more polished but finds Sydney\u2019s ethical intransigence just as mystifying. If the congresswoman would just go along with that carried interest loophole for private equity fund managers, she could reap millions in donations from that sector alone. So what if it\u2019s hypocritical?\n\nAlas, Sydney is no hypocrite. She is willing to humiliate herself, as the party requires, by dunning donors while on enforced fund-raising retreats in Vail, but she won\u2019t let anyone buy her. \u201cI will take their money,\u201d she tells voters. \u201cI will not do as they say.\u201d\n\nThis paints Sydney, and \u201cKings,\u201d into a self-righteous corner. When McDowell (a wily Zach Grenier) threatens to close off the spigots of cash that Sydney needs for re-election, she makes the only choice she (or the play) has left: to mount an even unlikelier campaign than the one that got her to Washington in the first place.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhenever it focuses on Sydney\u2019s dash through the minefields of democracy, \u201cKings\u201d is entertaining and informative, if not surprising theatrically. Its high point, two-thirds of the way through, is a town-hall-style debate in which she declaims, in perfectly formed phrases, the kinds of things many of us have been rehearsing for months in front of our televisions and on Twitter feeds. The greed of special interests, the mendacity of politicians, the cockroach endurance of lobbyists: If these are familiar, they are also endlessly compelling.\n\nBut with no items on the agenda beyond transparency, the bridge between politics and policy is down. Nothing Ms. Burgess gives Sydney to say connects meaningfully to the daily lives of people outside the Beltway.\n\n\u201cKings,\u201d you eventually realize, is not really about Sydney, anyway; her story \u2014 the only one you care about \u2014 basically dribbles away after the debate. Her entire existence within the play seems designed as a placard to announce one thing: When politics neutralizes the ethically excellent it leaves the field open to everyone else.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSurely, then, the title refers to the lobbyists, the only characters as powerful at the end as they were at the beginning. Kate in particular may be Ms. Burgess\u2019s intended heroine. She does nothing so dramaturgically crude as have a change of heart, but over time her understanding of the world is complicated by Sydney\u2019s. Perhaps she\u2019ll have a change of heart later.\n\nUnfortunately, Kate, too, is a placard, so thinly drawn and acted that we cannot be bothered with her personal journey. In that sense, \u201cKings\u201d \u2014 like Ms. Burgess\u2019s previous play, \u201cDry Powder,\u201d seen at the Public in 2016 \u2014 is a plot in search of an emotion. Kate and Lauren, no less than Sydney and the senator, are improbable exaggerations, caricatures with no human shading. This makes for powerful oppositions and playable scenes but little investment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat fault mattered less in \u201cDry Powder,\u201d about a trio of private equity vultures. We aren\u2019t really meant to care who prevails and who is outwitted in their leveraged buyout schemes; the play\u2019s purpose is simply to expose the system.\n\nThat\u2019s true of \u201cKings,\u201d too, but there is something much larger at stake in a story about public governance than in one about private greed. It\u2019s a telltale problem that the word \u201cDemocrat\u201d goes assiduously unmentioned, though all the characters clearly skew blue. Venality in Washington may be bipartisan, but not strictly so; to obfuscate that feels political in the wrong way.\n\nOf course, it\u2019s Ms. Burgess\u2019s prerogative to write a play demonstrating the thesis that ethical politics is impossible in our broken system. And to the extent that \u201cKings\u201d serves as a brake on expectations for the upcoming midterm elections, it may be a timely corrective for its intended audience.\n\nBut it is too divorced from the real world consequences of its characters\u2019 machinations to support any larger ambition, and in Thomas Kail\u2019s sleek staging \u2014 he directed \u201cDry Powder,\u201d too, and before that \u201cHamilton\u201d \u2014 the gravity of the subject and the sitcom zing of the style make an uncomfortable combo.\n\nWhich renders \u201cKings,\u201d though a more important work than \u201cDry Powder,\u201d also less satisfying. When only political careers are at stake, politics suffers, and plays do too.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Kings,\u2019 Washington Is Where Idealism Goes to Die", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "The lighting often creates a vertical row of four parallel horizontal fields, with dark bars in between them. The drama changes. Now the three dancers \u2014 Elena Demyanenko and Yanan Yu are the others \u2014 stay on those intervening bars. (Sometimes they pace on them slowly as if on tightropes.) Now they keep within the illuminated fields; now one roams in the surrounding shadows. And in some sequences, as if breaking rules, the performers disregard the lighting and instead cross the space diagonally. In some passages, the individual fields are differently lighted. In others, the fields and bars vanish altogether to make the space an even plain: the drastic change of geography \u2014 or of perception \u2014 is disconcerting, but the dancers carry on.\n\nYou might be watching a community of nuns or worker bees. These women, dressed in calf-length culottes with chemises and jackets in dark pastel colors, remain gently purposeful throughout. The movement is entirely flat-footed, often pedestrian, with impulses now rigorous, now mild. Dancers bend from the knee or waist; arms and spines ripple and stretch.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Latitude,\u2019 Dance in Silence Makes Its Own Inner Music", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Lee \u2014 whose credits as a television writer include \u201cLooking,\u201d \u201cGirls\u201d and \u201cHow to Get Away With Murder\u201d \u2014 made an auspicious debut as a playwright several years ago with \u201cLuce\u201d at Lincoln Center Theater. Like that earlier work, about a white couple who adopt a son from a war-torn Congo, \u201cRelevance\u201d shows an admirable willingness to wrestle with uncomfortable subjects.\n\nIt also shares an honorable refusal to provide conclusive answers to the complicated questions it poses, or to tilt its sympathies heavily toward any one of its four prickly characters. (Richard Masur, sporting a man bun, is David, Theresa\u2019s agent and former lover.) Unfortunately, it\u2019s difficult to feel much interest in, let alone liking for, any of them.\n\n\u201cRelevance\u201d might be seen as a latter-day variation on Ibsen\u2019s \u201cThe Master Builder,\u201d in which an aging architect becomes dangerously defensive (and destructive) when he hears the younger generation of his profession \u201cknocking at my door.\u201d Surely the same noise is echoing in Theresa\u2019s head as she watches Msemaji hijack the conference and the attention.\n\nSo the determined older professor, who didn\u2019t rise to the top by being gentle and giving, decides to wage war against Msemaji, and to do so on the younger woman\u2019s unfamiliar turf. That would be the landscape of social media, where reputations can be made and dashed in the twinkling of a tweet.\n\nProjected Twitter feeds and YouTube videos figure prominently in the play\u2019s climactic face-off. (Jeanette Oi-Suk Yew is the projection designer.) And Msemaji is unmasked as something of a charlatan, though she\u2019s so wily in the ways of web culture that she just might be able turn even this to her advantage. Or something like that.\n\n\u201cRelevance\u201d is filled with ideas, many of them promising. But they feel unanchored by anything other than prefab confrontations and mothy lines from a playwriting kit. The cast members still seem to be searching for their characters (and occasionally, their lines).\n\nExacting professionals like Theresa are surely accustomed to more thoroughly thought-through work than what is presented here. \u201cRelevance\u201d feels like an intriguing rough draft prematurely thrown into public view.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Relevance,\u2019 a Titan of Feminism Confronts a New Generation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Who exactly are these guys? They first met as boys in Sacramento, which is where we meet them, played by Cole Eichenberger (Spencer Stone), Paul-Mikel Williams (Anthony Sadler) and Bryce Gheisar (Alek Skarlatos). Alek and Spencer, whose mothers (Judy Greer and Jenna Fischer) are friends, pull their sons out of public school and enroll them in a Christian academy, where they meet Anthony, a regular visitor to the principal\u2019s office.\n\nFrustrated by the educational demands of both church and state, the boys indulge in minor acts of rebellion: toilet-papering a neighbor\u2019s house, swearing in gym class, playing war in the woods. They are separated when Alek moves to Oregon to live with his father and Anthony changes schools, but the three stay in touch as Anthony attends college and Alek and Spencer enlist in the military. Spencer, stationed in Portugal, meets up with Anthony in Rome, and Alek, who is serving in Afghanistan, visits a girlfriend in Germany before joining his pals in Berlin. They go clubbing in Amsterdam, wake up hung over and, after some debate, head for Paris.\n\nImage Ray Corasani as Ayoub El Khazzani. Credit Warner Bros.\n\nTo call what happens before the confrontation with the gunman a plot, in the conventional sense, does not seem quite accurate. Nor do Spencer, Anthony and Alek seem quite like movie characters. But they aren\u2019t documentary subjects, either. Mr. Eastwood, famous for avoiding extensive rehearsals and retakes, doesn\u2019t demand too much acting. Throughout the film, the principal performers behave with the mix of affability and reserve they might display when meeting a group of people for the first time. They are polite, direct and unfailingly good-natured, even when a given scene might call for more emotional intensity. In a normal movie, they would be extras.\n\nAnd on a normal day, they would have been \u2014 part of the mass of tourists, commuters and other travelers taking a quick ride from one European capital to another.
