At times, Spencer, the most restless of the three and the one whose life choices receive the most attention, talks about the feeling of being \u201ccatapulted\u201d toward some obscure destiny. But \u201cThe 15:17 to Paris\u201d isn\u2019t a meditation on fate any more than it is an exploration of the politics of global terrorism. Rather, it is concerned with locating the precise boundary between the banal and the extraordinary, between routine and violence, between complacency and courage.\n\nThe personalities of the main characters remain opaque, their inner lives the subject of speculation. You can wonder about the sorrow in Alek\u2019s eyes, about the hint of a temper underneath Spencer\u2019s jovial energy, about Anthony\u2019s skeptical detachment. But at the end of the movie, you don\u2019t really know them all that well. (You barely know Chris, a British passenger who helped subdue Mr. Khazzani, at all. He is seen but not named.)", "title": "Review: In \u2018The 15:17 to Paris,\u2019 Real Heroes Portray Their Heroism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mixing a lathered-up love triangle with a ghostly murder-mystery, Derek Nguyen\u2019s \u201cThe Housemaid\u201d wraps a painful chapter in Vietnamese history in Gothic-melodrama trappings. The result is a good-looking but overstuffed genre pileup that confuses as often as it compels.\n\nSet in 1953 when Vietnam was under French colonial rule, the story \u2014 inspired by the recollections of Mr. Nguyen\u2019s grandmother, a former housemaid \u2014 takes place on a sprawling rubber plantation belonging to Sebastien (Jean-Michel Richaud), a handsome French officer. When an orphan named Linh (Nhung Kate) joins his small house staff, she enters a terrifying world where creaks and whispers and vibrating strings follow her from room to room. Everyone, it seems, harbors shameful secrets, not least the house itself, where Sebastien\u2019s wife and baby died and a wraithlike apparition flits and hovers.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Housemaid,\u2019 Twisted Love and Angry Ghosts in Vietnam", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe inhabitants of the derelict mansion in \u201cThe Lodgers\u201d don\u2019t get out much. It\u2019s some time around World War I in rural Ireland and the orphaned Rachel (Charlotte Vega) and her twin brother, Edward (an effective Bill Milner), are struggling in the family manor, an art-directed ruin cloaked in shadows and mystery. Edward stays inside, turning paler and weirder, but Rachel sometimes ventures out, occasionally putting on a black riding hood (the better to scare you) to visit a nearby village. She sweeps in and out to stock up on provisions, breezing past locals with rude manners and wagging tongues.\n\nThe twins have an unfortunate history to go with their exceedingly troublesome tenants, who scuttle into a movie that takes entirely too long to spill its dark secrets. Working from David Turpin\u2019s script, the director Brian O\u2019Malley drapes the house in cobwebs and pours on the dust (the look is Miss Havisham without the cake), and sets the camera loose while he tries to rustle up the scares. These come intermittently and generally when you expect them, whether Rachel is dashing through the darkening forest or taking one of those candlelit soaks in the tub that women in storybook peril indulge in.\n\nVideo\n\nThings steadily go from eerie to worse with the approach of the twins\u2019 birthday, an occasion that Rachel seems to fear far more than Edward does. (Something wicked this way trundles.) And, as Edward sulks and lurks in the house, his pale face flickering in the gloom like a guttering candle, Rachel brings a little life and a few people into the proceedings. During one of her outings, she catches the eye of Sean (Eugene Smith), newly returned home from the war, who unwisely maintains faith in pretty women and his own heroism.\n\nWorking with an uneven cast and an undercooked story, Mr. O\u2019Malley hits the horror beats just fine (slam, creak, squeak) without putting a sinister spin on the assorted strange doings. For all the genre exertions, none of this feels the least bit spooky, including the digital ghouls that float in and the cobwebs that look as if they originated in a spray can.\n\nIn time, the monsters come out to play, but it\u2019s a measure of this movie\u2019s insistently fright-free storytelling that they\u2019re nowhere as disturbing as Mr. Milner\u2019s Edward. He\u2019s one feral twitch away from Renfield in the 1931 \u201cDracula,\u201d as the family\u2019s lawyer (David Bradley, a welcome, wry presence) discovers during a very unwise visit.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Lodgers,\u2019 Something Wicked This Way Trundles", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "David Turpin"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPadraig O\u2019Malley is a scholar and what one might call an amateur diplomat. He is the peacemaker of this film\u2019s title. The documentary, directed by James Demo, is not a portrait of an idealist. The Irish-born Mr. O\u2019Malley is an often dour man, and when he speaks of his work, there are no stars in his eyes. One of his recent books, about Israel and Palestine, is called \u201cThe Two State Delusion.\u201d In negotiation, as the movie shows, he is pragmatic, focused and often steely.\n\nVideo\n\nHis story is an unusual one, which the director unspools by showing Mr. O\u2019Malley first in a war-torn Iraq, then in the streets of Cambridge, Mass., where he teaches. (He travels so frequently he calls no place \u201chome\u201d). He enters a church, and we soon understand he\u2019s in an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. Filming an A.A. meeting isn\u2019t exactly kosher, but Mr. Demo doesn\u2019t show the faces of the other attendees. (It\u2019s not quite clear that this session hasn\u2019t been staged specifically for the movie.)\n\nA good part of the picture relies on Mr. O\u2019Malley\u2019s account of his life with and without the bottle \u2014 members call it a \u201cqualification\u201d \u2014 during this A.A. gathering. He tells how he started in conflict mediation when, in the early \u201970s, he bought a Cambridge bar and funneled its revenue into hosting a negotiation between warring factions of Northern Ireland \u2014 a first for these groups.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t love anybody,\u201d the lanky, white-haired Mr. O\u2019Malley admits during one interview segment. It\u2019s his peculiar detachment, perhaps, that makes him good at what he does, even when the summits he hosts \u2014 he spent years in Iraq and in South Africa \u2014 yield nothing more than agreements on bilingual street signs. The movie is a fascinating portrait that is if anything too brief.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Peacemaker,\u2019 a Negotiator Who Is No Idealist", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "James Demo"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Until his partnership with Engels is solidified \u2014 and access to some of the Engels\u2019s family wealth is secured \u2014 Marx struggles with deadlines, antagonizes editors and lives in bohemian penury with his wife, Jenny (Vicky Krieps), and their infant daughter. The family is harassed by bill collectors and also by the police, bouncing from Cologne to Paris to Brussels as Marx\u2019s political agitation brands him a dangerous subversive.\n\nHe is also embroiled in a series of volatile alliances with eminent figures of the European left, notably Wilhelm Weitling (Alexander Scheer), a bombastic orator whose ideas sound vaporous at best, and Pierre-Joseph Proudhon (the marvelous Olivier Gourmet), a good-natured philosopher who seems to be the hardest-working anarchist in show business. Those names are fairly obscure today, while Marx\u2019s is still attached to an -ism, however battered. (Does that count as a spoiler?) He and Engels stage both a theoretical and an organizational coup, replacing utopian nostrums about the brotherhood of man with a doctrine of conflict between the proletarian and the bourgeoisie. The rest is history, bloody and contentious and not yet finished.\n\nMarx and Engels\u2019s takeover of a stodgy workers\u2019-rights group called the League of the Just is a premonition of the tactical ruthlessness that would become characteristic of Communist parties in the 20th century. To put it in the language of 21st-century capitalism, the founders of Communism are disrupters and innovators, in possession of the entrepreneurial doggedness and the self-righteous zeal required to bend the world to their will.\n\n\u201cThe Young Karl Marx\u201d is a highly individualized picture of the authors of a doctrine of collective struggle. This contradiction (to revert to Marxist vocabulary) is precisely what energizes the film and rescues it from the twin dangers of tedium and sentimentality. There are other knots of irony and dialectical difficulty, notably with respect to the status of women within the global program of emancipation the two dudes so grandly envision.\n\nJenny Marx is a rebellious Prussian aristocrat; Engels\u2019s wife, Mary Burns (Hannah Steele), is a rebellious Irish factory worker. The two women provide a degree of centrifugal energy, pulling the story away from politics toward matters of the heart and hearth. But they also, for exactly that reason, expose gaps in their husbands\u2019 emerging theory of inequality and exploitation. Jenny and Mary support Karl and Friedrich\u2019s work wholeheartedly, but also within the parameters of a division of labor that seems beyond the reach of their politics. They clear the dishes, tend the children, hand out fliers and hang banners \u2014 part of the history but also at its margins.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Young Karl Marx,\u2019 a Scruffy Specter Haunts Europe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "A tone of stark austerity seems to have become the default mode of contemporary films about drug addiction (Josh and Bennie Safdie\u2019s excellent 2015 film \u201cHeaven Knows What\u201d being a notable exception). This holds for \u201cWerewolf,\u201d a Canadian film written and directed by Ashley McKenzie. But the particulars of Ms. McKenzie\u2019s approach, and the excellent work of her lead actors, bring new value to the mode.\n\nAndrew Gillis and Bhreagh MacNeil play Blaise and Vanessa, two addicts on a methadone program. Young, dirt-poor and without any significant options for moving their lives forward, they trudge around the small town they\u2019re stuck in, dragging a lawn mower with them. Entrepreneurship, such as it is, subsists in their offering to cut neighborhood lawns for money. And of course, eventually the lawn mower breaks.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Werewolf,\u2019 a Drug-Addicted Couple Struggle to Stay Clean", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Everything about \u201cWestern\u201d may be knottier and more contradictory than it initially appears, but it also might be simpler. The friendship between Meinhard and Adrian (Syuleyman Alilov Lefitov), a local landowner and businessman, is direct and affectionate, and the actors show how intimacy can develop without a common language. Meinhard, nicknamed the \u201clegionnaire,\u201d is jokingly described as Adrian\u2019s bodyguard, and events will test the extent and intensity of his loyalty.\n\nGeopolitics and global economics are elements in the atmosphere, less themes of the movie than part of the air its inhabitants breathe. It\u2019s worth noting that Maren Ade, whose \u201cToni Erdmann\u201d is also about a German expatriate in a Balkan country, is credited as a producer of \u201cWestern.\u201d (Ms. Grisebach was a script consultant on \u201cToni Erdmann.\u201d) Both films combine highly specific individual narratives with sharp, critical scrutiny of the way the world is organized now \u2014 the imbalances of power and autonomy that inevitably, though not always predictably, influence the ways people behave toward one another.\n\n\u201cAnything can happen in a village,\u201d Adrian says ruefully, as matters seem to be coming to a head. It\u2019s something of a rebuttal to Meinhard\u2019s earlier observation that the one consistent truth of the human condition is the domination of the weak by the strong. But there are different kinds of strength, and there are also other factors at work, including laziness, whim, habit and random chance. The western as a genre, like Meinhard, believes in determinism, in a history governed by laws and patterns. \u201cWestern\u201d has its doubts.\n\nThere is no doubting Ms. Grisebach\u2019s filmmaking. Her eye for faces and for nuances of gesture and posture is matched by her ability to capture the beauty and strangeness of the landscape, and to make sense of its intricate geography. \u201cWestern\u201d is as precise as a dropped pin on a GPS map, which makes its sense of mystery all the more powerful.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Western,\u2019 German Workers Fan Tensions in a Bulgarian Town", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Was there ever a more terrifying opening line, in a play or in life, than \u201cWe should talk\u201d?\n\nWell, maybe. For those who recognize it, \u201cI\u2019ve been to the zoo\u201d is at least as ominous.\n\nThey are the words with which Edward Albee greeted the world in his first play, \u201cThe Zoo Story,\u201d back in 1959. Actually, the words were originally heard in translation, because \u201cThe Zoo Story\u201d had its premiere in Berlin. When I once asked Albee whether he understood German, he said, \u201cI understand that it is a language.\u201d\n\nHe would. \u201cThe Zoo Story,\u201d a one-act about a successful, domesticated man accosted in a park by a man who is neither, introduced not only Albee\u2019s despairing vision of life as an unwinnable war for dominance but also the verbal exuberance that made that vision bearable. All of Albee\u2019s subsequent plays \u2014 some three dozen over the course of 50 years, from \u201cWho\u2019s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?\u201d to \u201cThree Tall Women\u201d and beyond \u2014 proceed from those perpendicular impulses, creating a body of serio-comic emotional linguistic thrillers unmatched in modern theater.\n\nWhich brings us to \u201cWe should talk,\u201d the first words of \u201cHomelife,\u201d a one-act Albee wrote as a companion and prequel to \u201cThe Zoo Story.\u201d First performed on a double bill with the earlier play at Second Stage in 2007, \u201cHomelife\u201d now emerges, in a revival that opened on Wednesday night at the Signature Theater, as more than just the other half of an eggshell, jaggedly interlocking. Lila Neugebauer\u2019s terrific production proves it to be an indispensably excellent work in its own right, and a suitable tribute to the playwright, who died in 2016.", "title": "Review: Is Edward Albee \u2018At Home at the Zoo\u2019? You Bet He Is", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "The Scarlatti \u201cErminia\u201d \u2014 a tale of love, jealousy and disguise, with shepherds real and counterfeit \u2014 was a very different kettle of fish. The orchestra here was larger, with a more striking assortment of color, but much of the music\u2019s power was concentrated in its four solo voices: mezzo-sopranos Erminia (Julia Dawson) and Tancredi (Allegra De Vita), bass Pastore (Andr\u00e9 Courville), and tenor Polidoro (Asitha Tennekoon). In arias, the coloratura writing is often intense, so that \u2014 as in some Handel operas, only more so \u2014 each character plunges at once into a vortex of emotion conveyed by the knots and chains of the rapid-moving vocal line.\n\nThanks to the conductor Ryan Brown and the four singers, the recitatives between the set pieces stayed suspenseful; the act took us through quite a spectrum. At moments, admittedly, the immediate flare-ups of temperament in the succession of arias become formulaic. Virtuoso emotional display seems more crucial than character or narrative tension. But it\u2019s also possible that Scarlatti wanted a yet greater range of tone (absurdity, humor) than Lafayette gave us.\n\nThe emotionalism became more (or less) three-dimensional according to who was singing. Ms. Dawson, beautiful in face and voice, was commanding, conflicted, touching as Erminia. Ms. De Vita, in the smaller male role of Tancredi, proved yet more remarkable, with incisive diction: Her vocalism burns like a dark flame. It was a pleasure to hear the accomplishment of Mr. Courville and Mr. Tennekoon; but their vocal characters remained far sketchier and less engrossing.\n\nHow often does New York hear music by either Alessandro Scarlatti (father of Domenico) or Geminiani? I cherish the Lafayette impulse to fill a gap in our knowledge. Notwithstanding more than 40 years of attending both opera and dance, this was the first theatrical performance I had heard of music by either composer. Now I\u2019ll seek out more of both.", "title": "Review: Lafayette\u2019s Double Bill of Baroque Opera and Dance Drama", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "A few years ago, when the Whitney Museum\u2019s airy home in the meatpacking district was brand new, the Abstract Expressionists Jackson Pollock and Lee Krasner were part of a group exhibition there \u2014 my favorite part, though had less to do with their art than its arresting display. Huge and colorful, Krasner\u2019s canvas got a magnificently conspicuous spot, while a smaller, dimmer work by Pollock, her celebrated husband, hung opposite on a more crowded wall.\n\nIt felt like a face-off between them \u2014 one that the Great Man was losing to the Little Woman, who at last got to outshine him publicly.\n\nSomething similar occurs in the French playwright Fabrice Melquiot\u2019s \u201cPollock,\u201d a two-hander that (its title notwithstanding) is as much about Krasner as it is about Pollock, and above all about their volatile pairing. Directed by Paul Desveaux for Compagnie de la Vall\u00e9e-l\u2019H\u00e9liotrope, it\u2019s a duet, a double act, a surreal sparring match steeped in alcohol and dripping with paint.\n\nAs embodied by the experimental theater veteran Jim Fletcher in the modernist Underground Theater at Abrons Arts Center, Jackson Pollock can be fascinating to watch \u2014 a brooding, dry-humored malcontent in the 20th-century American-genius mold. But Lee Krasner is the riveting one, rare and defiant and glowing with life in a beautifully modulated, remarkably understated performance by Birgit Huppuch. Together these barefoot ghosts are really something.", "title": "Review: Lee Krasner Gets the Upper Hand in \u2018Pollock\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "If you have an iPhone and want to hear a computer evade a question, ask Siri to identify her race. She won\u2019t do it. But even as she equivocates, her accent and intonation give you clues to answer the question yourself.\n\nI was led to this curious exercise by David Thomson\u2019s \u201che his own mythical beast,\u201d a thoughtful and subtly provocative dance performance that had its premiere on Wednesday at Performance Space New York as part of the Coil Festival. Among the many disparate anecdotes related by the four dancers is an amusing story about trying to get Apple to create a black Siri.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Thomson is black, as are Paul Hamilton and Katrina Reid, two other members of the excellent cast. As Mr. Thomson proudly points out in the show, he has a beautiful speaking voice. For decades, he has been known as a dancer of extreme elegance. Here, he recalls an unnamed choreographer in the 1990s telling him with dissatisfaction, \u201cI see you.\u201d She wanted him to disappear into her work, he says.\n\nYou can guess who that choreographer might have been. Mr. Thomson was in the company of Trisha Brown from 1979 to 1993, and in \u201cmythical beast\u201d he quotes (with attribution in the program notes) from her 1975 work \u201cLocus.\u201d But identifying that source isn\u2019t the point, really. The particular history of Mr. Thomson as a minority in the largely white field of postmodern dance is allowed to resonate with larger questions of identity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen the fourth cast member, Jodi Bender, first speaks, her face is covered by a veil. Elsewhere in \u201cmythical beast,\u201d the whiteness of her skin is sometimes impossible to ignore, as in a sequence when she repeatedly shoves Mr. Hamilton to the floor, puts him in a chokehold and drags him around, once by the ear.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet even in this most on-the-nose part, it\u2019s equally important (and complicating) that Ms. Bender is much smaller than Mr. Hamilton, and female. Often, the dancers are divided by gender, with the two women speaking while the two men move, or vice versa.", "title": "Review: On Siri, Bodies and Masks in \u2018he his own mythical beast\u2019", "authors": ["Brian Seibert"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOver the last decade, Carnegie Hall\u2019s composer in residence position has tended to go to veteran iconoclasts whose innovations have taken root in the broader classical scene. Meredith Monk, Louis Andriessen and Kaija Saariaho, for example, have all been celebrated with the concert series that come with the Carnegie post, the Debs Composer\u2019s Chair.\n\nI\u2019ve noticed, listening to a range of these series, that programs devoted exclusively to the chosen composer\u2019s works are often impressive. Less satisfying, on the whole, have been the concerts in which the composer is tucked \u2014 or, more to the point, jammed \u2014 into a broader concept or next to other works.\n\nThis year Philip Glass holds the chair. And Tuesday evening was his turn with that latter format. In its Carnegie debut, the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra and its music director, Carlos Miguel Prieto, played two of his lesser-known orchestral pieces \u2014 \u201cDays and Nights in Rocinha\u201d (1997) and the Concerto Fantasy for Two Timpanists and Orchestra (2000) \u2014 on a program that also included Silvestre Revueltas\u2019s \u201cLa Noche de los Mayas.\u201d\n\nYou don\u2019t need to squint to identify the connecting thread here. The incandescent Revueltas suite, derived from one of his film scores, is a touchstone of the Mexican repertoire; pairing it with Mr. Glass\u2019s tribute to Rocinha, a Rio de Janeiro favela, gives the program a vaguely Latin American theme. The Concerto Fantasy doesn\u2019t share that theme, even vaguely. But it does spotlight percussionists, which puts it in a stylistic neighborhood adjacent to some of Revueltas\u2019s higher-octane passages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s neat enough on paper. But the problem is that these two Glass pieces aren\u2019t close to his most interesting.\n\nThe Concerto Fantasy\u2019s beginning, with its uncanny similarity to the stomping opening of the \u201cMission: Impossible\u201d theme, is, at best, distracting. (Mr. Glass has denied plagiarizing, saying that he doesn\u2019t watch television.) More disappointing is how nothing else in the work manages to be as melodically memorable. During the Louisiana Philharmonic\u2019s performance, the strings were frequently swamped by the timpanists (Jim Atwood and Paul Yancich, stationed at the front of Carnegie\u2019s stage).", "title": "Review: Philip Glass Is Celebrated, but Not With His Best", "authors": ["Seth Colter Walls"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Jaap van Zweden, the music director designate of the New York Philharmonic, built up good will with the orchestra\u2019s extended audience on Tuesday evening when he announced the details of his first season, which begins in September. He enthusiastically discussed his plans and programming, including five premieres he will conduct, the introduction of two new-music series tied to themes the season will explore, and much more. It was an auspicious occasion for the Philharmonic.\n\nLess auspicious was Mr. van Zweden\u2019s conducting on Wednesday night at David Geffen Hall. The concert, a program pairing the New York premiere of a short, recent work by John Luther Adams with a concert performance of Act I from Wagner\u2019s \u201cDie Walk\u00fcre,\u201d was an opportunity to find out more about what he might bring to the Philharmonic, and to New York audiences. If anything, Mr. van Zweden can be too feisty and forceful in his performances of the standard repertory. So I was surprised that his account of this 70-minute Wagner act often lacked tension and urgency.\n\nThe performance started strongly. In the dark, pulsing orchestra music of the opening scene, Wagner simultaneously depicts the stormy weather that pummels a wounded young Siegmund as he is pursued through a dense forest, and the internal despair that never leaves him. Mr. van Zweden conducted this music with lean textures and crisp attacks.\n\nBut once Siegmund (here the veteran tenor Simon O\u2019Neill), seeking shelter in a hut, chances upon the fearful young Sieglinde (the radiant soprano Heidi Melton), Wagner\u2019s music turns mysterious and quietly suspenseful. The isolated Siegmund and beaten-down Sieglinde, who is trapped in a marriage to the bullying Hunding, look at each other longingly. In fact, they are twins, separated since their early childhood. And during these passages Mr. van Zweden\u2019s performance often went slack.", "title": "Review: Restrained Wagner at the New York Philharmonic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Indie romantic comedies are swarming with aimless, emotionally damaged men seeking meaning in the arms of confident young women. Sometimes, like Ben (Thomas Middleditch) in \u201cEntanglement,\u201d these sad specimens are permitted clinical passes for their weird behavior; but whether in need of restraints, medication or simply a decent barber, they are almost always presented as desirable romantic partners.\n\nLet\u2019s go with that, then. \u201cHe\u2019s not good in a crisis,\u201d Ben\u2019s father informs us, though a montage of botched suicide attempts has already established Ben\u2019s misery bona fides and general ineptness. His wife has skedaddled, but his nosy neighbor (the delightful Diana Bang) is eager to clean his house and enable his quest to track down the woman who was once almost his adoptive sister. Like the wiring in Ben\u2019s brain, it\u2019s complicated.", "title": "Review: Suicidal Man Seeks Mystery Woman for \u2018Entanglement\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The New Sydney Hotel in the Tasmanian capital, Hobart, has found an immensely lovable middle path. Opened in 1835, the building spent a few years as a private residence, and also had a short stint as a brothel around the end of the 19th century. But for most of its history it has been one of the central business district\u2019s most popular pubs.\n\nThe last renovation happened a decade ago, leaving the interior with wood-paneled walls covered in various memorabilia: old photos, vintage advertisements, license plates, taxidermied animals (a kookaburra, a raven, a ringtail possum). In the winter, bartenders pull double duty slinging drinks and stoking the leaping flames in the huge brick fireplace.\n\nAlistair Derham, the owner, has been proactive in balancing tradition with the needs of a modern urban clientele. There are no televisions, but there are USB outlets under the bar to charge your phone. There are cheap beers, and there are craft beers. The back bar holds some truly exciting local whiskeys and gins. And in terms of food, the pub classics are all available, done very well with little to no gourmet pretensions.\n\nYou can also order a tasting menu. Part of that menu will be cooked at your table by a waiter brandishing a blowtorch. A large portion of the New Sydney\u2019s food offerings can be credited to the creative impulses of the chef, Klee Clemens. Mr. Clemens was born and raised in Tasmania, but he spent time in the kitchens of Melbourne, most notably that of Vue De Monde, one of the country\u2019s most established fine-dining restaurants. Mr. Clemens has been at the New Sydney for a decade now, and his kitchen manages to achieve remarkably varied aims.\n\nHere is a chicken Parma, the classic Australian pub meal that puts a breaded, fried chicken cutlet under a slice of ham, a layer of red sauce and melted cheese, and over a pile of fries. The sauce is house-made, with a hint of smokiness; the cheese is blistered perfectly. There\u2019s no tinkering with the form, no cleverness. It is just a very good Parma.", "title": "Review: The New Sydney Hotel in Hobart, Tasmania", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nImages become cinema in \u201c24 Frames,\u201d the last movie from the Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami (1940-2016). \u201cI always wonder to what extent the artist aims to depict the reality of a scene,\u201d he reveals in the opening text. \u201cPainters capture only one frame of reality and nothing before or after it.\u201d This wondering led him to digitally transform 24 still images into short, visually and thematically linked sequences that make up this alternately charming and frustrating labor of love, which he worked on during the final three years of his life. (It was completed under the supervision of one of his sons.)\n\nIt opens on the painting \u201cHunters in the Snow,\u201d one in a series of seasonal landscapes by Pieter Bruegel the Elder dating from 1565. On the left side of the canvas, a group of men and dogs can be seen walking near people clustered close to a fire and a line of buildings; the right side of the painting shows a smattering of structures in the near distance and, beyond these, still more distant people skating and milling about on lakes of dark ice. Over the next few minutes, the painting begins to stir as smoke streams from a chimney, snow falls, a dog urinates against a tree and crows caw and fly.\n\nThe addition of these modest sounds and movements is intriguing but adds no insight and certainly no beauty to the Bruegel, which needs no such interventions. The rest of \u201c24 Frames\u201d is more appealing. It consists of 23 segments that turn Kiarostami\u2019s own photographs, many in starkly beautiful black and white, into animations of about four and a half minutes. Filled with desolate vistas, a feathered and furred menagerie, and multiple aperture-like windows, these fragments quickly establish a moody tone and over time become dolorous refrains. Each section is divided by fades to black and individual titles (Frame 2, Frame 15) that create a kind of countdown effect.\n\nA fine-art photographer as well as a filmmaker, Kiarostami could set your heart to leaping with cinematic landscapes that sometimes linger longer than his stories: a rough, dusty hill delineated by a zigzagging path in \u201cWhere Is My Friend\u2019s House?\u201d; two travelers motoring through a swaying field in \u201cThe Wind Will Carry Us.\u201d It\u2019s no surprise then that the images in \u201c24 Frames\u201d are consistently pretty and at times striking, harmoniously composed and filled with visual tension that make the shots vibrate even before something \u2014 birds, horses, an unfortunate deer or an opportunistically placed cat \u2014 starts moving in them. Many of the views are organized around an obvious center point, a leafless tree or bush, for instance, roughly set in a brilliantly white wintry expanse.\n\nAt other times, Kiarostami flattens the picture, turning it into a stack of horizontal wedges. In one frame, a slab of darkly brooding sky seems to loom down on a skeletal railing that runs across the shot, cleaving it in half. Beyond the railing, water (ocean, sea or lake) surges and, with a bird, gives the image a frisson of drama. Repeatedly, a movement \u2014 a bird raising its head, a horse its hooves \u2014 turns an image into a tidy narrative fragment. Every so often (a watery panorama with a balustrade, tall poles and complaining gulls), the compositions seem to nod at Yasujiro Ozu, the Japanese filmmaker to whom Kiarostami dedicated \u201cFive\u201d (2003), another experimental work.\n\n\u201c24 Frames\u201d can\u2019t help but be affecting because it is Kiarostami\u2019s final movie. But it\u2019s intellectually uninvolving, and its technical limitations prove frustrating. In a few shots, snow or rain falls, for instance, on the same left-to-right diagonal, creating a distracting pattern that suggests the software wasn\u2019t altered for each photograph. This synthetic quality may be an intentional imitation of life; certainly it\u2019s obvious that Kiarostami was thinking a great deal about cinema. Intriguingly, while winter and all it implies loom large here, they are gently offset by a glimpse of the film \u201cThe Best Years of Our Lives\u201d playing on a computer as the sounds of a deeply unexpected love song fill a lonely room.", "title": "Review: The Persistence of Abbas Kiarostami\u2019s Vision in \u201824 Frames\u2019", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Unay often shoots Mr. Carman in wide screen at close range, emphasizing the physical strain of his routines, whether he\u2019s running, training or doing mechanical work for a ferry system. Part of the secret of the movie\u2019s interest is that Mr. Carman is not invincible or a former superstar. We\u2019re told that he doesn\u2019t even make money off cage matches.\n\nYet the damage they do to his home life is real. \u201cIt\u2019s the only time in my life when I feel proud of myself,\u201d he tells dismayed family members who have just learned that he is fighting again, despite having promised his ill wife never to get back in the ring. Fighting, he says, allows him to feel that he likes himself. Mr. Carman is shown throughout the film as a loving parent (we see him dancing with his daughters and making them pancakes), but he can\u2019t check his pride. Fighting means being in a cage in more than one sense.", "title": "Review: The Ring Is a Cage in Every Sense in \u2018The Cage Fighter\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "A dimply new star has joined the cast of \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d and he\u2019s delightful \u2014 oh wait.\n\nPerhaps you weren\u2019t asking about Charlie Stemp, the replacement Barnaby Tucker in the hit musical revival that introduced four fresh principals on Thursday evening.\n\nO.K., then: A dimply new star has joined the cast of \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d and she\u2019s delightful.\n\nAnd something more, too.\n\nBernadette Peters, who turns 70 next week, doesn\u2019t need to step into anyone\u2019s shoes at this point in her 60-year Broadway career. That she would take over the role of Dolly Levi from Bette Midler (and her alternate, Donna Murphy) means she was interested in the challenge, not the provenance. I imagine she understood that there was something she could bring to the part that no one else could.\n\nThat something is not a stage personality filled with gregarious high spirits. Ms. Peters is neither the hoyden type nor the winking type, at least not since her days as a self-parodying chorine. Where Ms. Midler wrung laughs from a line like \u201cI\u2019m tired, Ephraim, tired of living from hand to mouth\u201d \u2014 sometimes even pretending to collapse in decrepitude \u2014 Ms. Peters doesn\u2019t even go for a giggle. She makes it clear that Dolly is talking about real hardships: the anxiety of work and the loneliness of a widow.", "title": "Review: The \u2018Dolly\u2019 Parade Marches On, Now With a New Star", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Indeed, despite the fact that the film\u2019s director is Will Gluck (an American whose prior film was the 2014 \u201cAnnie\u201d remake), the mode of cheeky humor here is reasonably British. There are at least a handful of inflections of Aardman, the renowned British stop-motion animation studio, in this picture. The scene in which Peter, his sisters Flopsy, Mopsy and Cottontail, and his neurotic sidekick Benjamin Bunny travel to London on a mission to find a crucial human character recalls Aardman\u2019s \u201cShaun the Sheep Movie,\u201d from 2015. Let me be clear, though: \u201cShaun the Sheep Movie\u201d is an animation masterpiece, while this film is \u2026 not. For one thing, it leans pretty heavily on the convention of \u201ccomedic scenes scored to jumpy \u2018classic\u2019 rock songs.\u201d But its story line is clean; the live-action actors, particularly Rose Byrne (as Bea, an artist who paints portraits of the bunnies), bring their onscreen-appeal A game; and the computer-generated animals are charming, albeit lacking in the particular gentle winsomeness of Potter\u2019s originals.\n\nWith movies such as these, the most pertinent immediate question is, \u201cWill the kids like it?\u201d I don\u2019t have any myself, but for the press screening I was able (with an actual parent, mind you) to host three, between the ages of 5 and 7. These were pretty sophisticated kids, as you tend to find in the tristate area. One of the 7-year-olds, on learning that I had a fear of heights, asked me if I\u2019d ever seen \u201cVertigo.\u201d They enjoyed the movie pretty quietly, and over pizza afterward, enthusiastically compared notes on their favorite scenes. Your results may vary.", "title": "Review: This \u2018Peter Rabbit\u2019 Is No Beatrix Potter, but It\u2019s Not All Bad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The burly veteran German baritone Matthias Goerne, a commanding vocalist if a sometimes intrusive physical presence onstage, and the brilliant yet retiring young Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov may seem an odd couple as recitalists. And their program at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening was decidedly eccentric, yet utterly winning. Mr. Trifonov conceived the event as part of his Carnegie Perspectives series this season, and the respect and affinity he showed toward Mr. Goerne were clearly mutual.\n\nTheir program somewhat typically placed romantic love and loss at its core, with Schumann\u2019s great song cycle \u201cDichterliebe\u201d (\u201cA Poet\u2019s Love\u201d); then it took a wide turn to Christian charity as its endpoint, in Brahms\u2019s late, biblical \u201cFour Serious Songs.\u201d Otherwise it worked the fringes of the repertory with a subtext of death, in Berg\u2019s early Four Songs (Op. 2); three songs to poems of Michelangelo by Wolf; and three more by Shostakovich.\n\nBut it was the manner of presentation that really set this intermissionless evening apart. By going immediately from one song to the next \u2014 and from one composer to the next \u2014 Mr. Goerne and Mr. Trifonov created an overall intensity that proved captivating. Though you would have thought the game had become obvious after the four songs by Berg and the 16 by Schumann, a sprinkling of listeners started to applaud after \u201cDichterliebe,\u201d only to be squelched by an arresting gesture from Mr. Goerne and an immediate leap into the Wolf by Mr. Trifonov.\n\nStill more striking, this unified fabric created new contexts for the various sets, placing each in a different light and revealing subtexts usually hidden. \u201cDichterliebe,\u201d in fact, perhaps should have come with a spoiler alert. Its lovely opening song, \u201cIm Wundersch\u00f6nen Monat Mai\u201d (\u201cIn the Wondrous Month of May\u201d), is usually rendered in blithe fashion, giving little hint of the heartbreak ahead. But coming directly out of Berg\u2019s death-haunted \u201cWarm die L\u00fcfte\u201d (\u201cWarm Are the Breezes\u201d), Schumann\u2019s opening took on a subdued, pensive air that made clear from the outset that this romance would come to no good end.", "title": "Review: Unlikely Pairing Turns to Intense Affinity at Carnegie", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "This Friday the world turns its eyes to the mountains of South Korea, where the Winter Olympics are getting underway in the town of Pyeongchang: small, bustling and by all accounts, bitterly cold.\n\nThe skiing events take place in the Taebaek Mountains, and for centuries before Alpine sports came to this country, pilgrims, artists and tourists trekked to these thickly forested peaks that span the eastern crest of the Korean Peninsula. No mountain in the Taebaek range is more august than Mount Kumgang, also called the \u201cDiamond Mountains\u201d: a stunning expanse of jagged granite peaks and coursing waterfalls, praised by poets and painters, Koreans and foreigners, Buddhists and neo-Confucianists, for more than a millennium.\n\n\u201cI wish that I had been born in Korea,\u201d the 11th-century Chinese poet Su Shi is said to have wept, \u201cso that I could see the Diamond Mountains in person!\u201d\n\nThis month\u2019s visitors to Pyeongchang will not be able to see them either. Mount Kumgang, just 90 miles as the crow flies from the Olympic Stadium, lies in North Korea \u2014 and, except during the years of Kim Dae-jung\u2019s Sunshine Policy, it has been impossible to travel there from the South (or, indeed, from almost anywhere). The mountains, central to the cultural history of both countries, have become a misty mirage in the South Korean imagination.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDiamond Mountains: Travel and Nostalgia in Korean Art,\u201d a melancholy beauty of a show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, reveals the indelible influence of this mountain range on Korean painting from the 18th century to today. Even before the division of the peninsula, Mount Kumgang inspired not just awe but also longing, wistfulness, regret. For artists of the late Joseon dynasty, for those living under Japanese occupation, and now for contemporary South Korean painters, the mountains have always constituted a thick tangle of natural beauty, historical legend and political symbolism.", "title": "Review: When a Landscape (and Memory) Is All You Have", "authors": ["Jason Farago"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Yet somehow, seeing those theories brought to dramatized life \u2014 seven episodes were provided for review \u2014 gives them more power.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cUnsolved\u201d is equal parts appealingly pulpy and workmanlike, sometimes paced like a procedural and sometimes like a prestige drama. It weaves together three story lines \u2014 the friendship between Tupac (Marcc Rose) and Biggie (Wavyy Jonez), which soured and ultimately collapsed; the original L.A.P.D. investigation into Biggie\u2019s murder, steered maniacally by the detective Russell Poole (Jimmi Simpson); and the task force convened a decade after the killings, helmed by Mr. Kading (Josh Duhamel).\n\nThe love story here isn\u2019t between Biggie and Tupac, though ample screentime is given over to their early friendship. It\u2019s between the two detectives who never meet: Poole and Kading, who both begin to unravel in the face of a complex investigation, institutional pressure and family problems.\n\nIn this telling, Poole is the true detective, wholly and distractingly absorbed by the case. Mr. Simpson plays him as an impatient savant, forever sternly exhaling and chafing against his superiors. (It should be noted, though, that in the \u201cMurder Rap\u201d documentary, Mr. Kading makes short work of Mr. Poole\u2019s theories about the murders.) By contrast, Mr. Duhamel\u2019s Kading is blank. Better is his extended team, which includes Daryn Dupree (a grounded Bokeem Woodbine) and Lee Tucker (Wendell Pierce, testy as ever).\n\nMr. Jonez captures the gentle grandeur of Biggie (born Christopher Wallace), and Mr. Rose has Tupac\u2019s familiar seductive glint in his eye. But this show about murdered rappers is really a cop show. What\u2019s more, \u201cUnsolved\u201d did not secure licensing rights for either rapper\u2019s music \u2014 though some lyrics are sprinkled into conversation \u2014 making them feel even more distant as subjects.\n\nIn capturing the two investigations, though, \u201cUnsolved\u201d is effective in an unglamorous, no-frills way. And yet, as the episodes toggle between the ostentation of the hip-hop world and the grayness of police headquarters, it\u2019s hard to overlook that a story of this historical significance is rendered in such proletarian fashion.\n\nAdd to that the fact that Mr. Kading\u2019s book and documentary were self-released, and that \u201cUnsolved\u201d isn\u2019t on a vanity platform like HBO or Netflix, or delivered with the luxe production values of the \u201cAmerican Crime Story\u201d series, but rather on USA, a basic cable staple.\n\nYou would think that a show that advertises a convincing theory about these killings would be lavished with funding, be loudly publicized not just as art, but also as news. But instead, \u201cUnsolved\u201d remains in the shadows. Myth has a way of enduring.", "title": "Review: Who Killed Biggie and Tupac? \u2018Unsolved\u2019 Might Know", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn rural Georgia, 100 years ago this spring, Mary Turner, eight months pregnant, made what a newspaper called \u201cunwise remarks\u201d about the lynching of her husband. So a mob came for her, too. They tied her by the ankles. They hung her upside down from a tree. They doused her dress with gasoline and lit a match. That wasn\u2019t the worst.\n\nAs a reporter for The Crisis, a magazine published by the NAACP, wrote, while Turner writhed, a man took a hog-butchering knife and cut the baby out of her belly. \u201cThe infant, prematurely born, gave two feeble cries and then its head was crushed by a member of the mob with his heel,\u201d the article says.\n\nI didn\u2019t know this particular story before I saw \u201cA Small Oak Tree Runs Red,\u201d written by Lekethia Dalcoe and directed by Harry Lennix at the Billie Holiday Theater. And there\u2019s a part of me that wishes I still didn\u2019t know it. But \u201cA Small Oak Tree,\u201d flawed and devastating, won\u2019t support that. It argues that in remaining ignorant of our history we risk remaining mired in its violence.\n\nThe three-character play takes place in two times and two places \u2014 or a time and a non-time, a place and a non-place if you want to be precise about it. Half of the play is set in Brooks County, Ga., in May 1918; the other half is set in a sepulchral space that might be purgatory, where the characters must wander until they face the trauma of their deaths. Christian and psychoanalytic, it\u2019s a \u201cNo Exit\u201d with the promise of salvation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnstage we see a table, some chairs and the skeletons of trees, constructed by the set designer Diggle with branches made of rope and rustling paper scraps. Here we meet Mary Turner (Kyra Riley), her husband Hayes Turner (R.J. Foster) and Sidney Johnson (Yusef Miller), a friend who seeks shelter after murdering the brutal white man whose land he worked.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
