View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen the lights change and Mary\u2019s pregnant belly is flattened, the Turner home slides into some dismal corner of the afterlife, where Mary hears the sound of a crying child and Sidney is charged with helping her remember that child\u2019s murder. Hayes, already on his way to heaven, looks in occasionally.", "title": "Review: \u2018A Small Oak Tree Runs Red\u2019 Unties a Century-Old Noose", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe famed violinist Jascha Heifetz has gone for a walk with a stranger in the hills of Palestine. Now that they\u2019re up there, he isn\u2019t quite sure what the point is.\n\nIt is 1926, and Heifetz has just given a concert. Is that three-piece suit what he wore onstage? He\u2019s dour, in any case, and the garrulous exuberance of his companion \u2014 a kibbutz choirmaster named Yehuda Sharett \u2014 does nothing to alleviate his mood.\n\n\u201cWhy did you bring me here, Mr. Sharett?\u201d Heifetz asks, his patience thinning.\n\nThrough much of the first act of \u201cA Walk With Mr. Heifetz,\u201d a world-premiere play by the cultural journalist James Inverne, the audience may be puzzling, too, wondering why the bored and irritated Heifetz (Adam Green) doesn\u2019t simply leave.\n\nThe answer, alas, is that the author is keeping him there to force a conversation. Directed by Andrew Leynse for Primary Stages at the Cherry Lane Theater, \u201cA Walk With Mr. Heifetz\u201d is a play constructed for the sake of an argument. Inspired by real people and events in the decades leading up to the foundation of Israel, Mr. Inverne wants to make a point about the vital role of music in establishing a culture and knitting together a new nation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Theater Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest news, interviews and reviews from Broadway and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThus the buttonholing of the comparatively decadent Heifetz by the idealistic Yehuda (Yuval Boim), who is determined to use his own music for social good. Way off in the future, Yehuda will become an important Israeli composer. His more formal elder brother, Moshe (Erik Lochtefeld, dependably fun to watch), an alpha politician, will serve as the nation\u2019s second prime minister.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut for all the biography in it, this play is an awkward amalgam of hastily sketched history, which will read clearly only to those who already know it, and stories told in detail to characters who would surely not be hearing them for the first time.", "title": "Review: \u2018A Walk With Mr. Heifetz\u2019 Stumbles Through History", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMilitary drones have had an interesting effect on storytelling: They have forced writers to rethink how they portray warfare. For how do you represent invisible weapons? How do you tell of battles where combatants never face each other and death comes out of nowhere in seconds? Movies such as \u201cEye in the Sky\u201d and \u201cGood Kill\u201d have looked at the price exacted by drones on those who remote-control them, an approach also adopted by the 2015 solo play \u201cGrounded,\u201d in which Anne Hathaway portrayed a pilot now dropping hellfire while sitting thousands of miles away from her targets.\n\nSylvia Khoury\u2019s earnest new drama, \u201cAgainst the Hillside,\u201d looks at the effect of drones both on those who guide them and those who endure them. The show toggles between Pakistan, where the married Sayid (Babak Tafti) and Reem (Mahira Kakkar, \u201cWhen January Feels Like Summer\u201d) are constantly \u201clistening to the sky,\u201d and America, where one Capt. Matt Walker (Jack Mikesell) is doing the watching. Both parties live in anxiety, though of course the stakes are quite different \u2014 it\u2019s in Pakistan that a corpse\u2019s limbs, torn by a sudden strike, have to be recovered for a proper burial.\n\nMatt, a pilot who took the drone job when he and his wife, Erin (Caroline Hewitt), decided to start a family, is becoming way too \u201cinvested,\u201d as he puts it, in the Pakistani couple\u2019s life. He is particularly fascinated by Reem, and feels as if he knows her. That\u2019s a mistake, of course. First, he doesn\u2019t have access to her inner life, and second, there\u2019s a reason farmers don\u2019t name the animals they\u2019re raising for slaughter \u2014 being invested in your victims is a bad idea.\n\nThis setup is an intriguing one, and we should be grateful a young playwright has at least chosen to engage with it. But \u201cAgainst the Hillside,\u201d which just opened at Ensemble Studio Theater under William Carden\u2019s direction, does not live up to its potential. It is somehow too descriptive and too elusive, at once over-explaining and vague.\n\nInitially, Ms. Khoury seems most interested in Reem, who pleads with her husband to move to a big city, where the anonymity of crowds will protect them from those unseen threats. He won\u2019t budge, so one night she takes their baby and leaves. On the other side of the world, Matt unravels. Plot strands wither on the vine: Why this obsession with Reem? Why does Sayid abandon his store and start teaching math after Reem\u2019s departure?\n\nPhoto\n\nTime moves on. Major characters drop out of the story, never to come back; uninteresting peripheral ones are gifted unnecessary scenes.\n\nAnd then the unexpected happens: Ms. Khoury pulls a nifty epilogue out of her hat.\n\nTime has moved on again, and we are now seeing the long-term aftermath of drone warfare. The narrative and stylistic jump is jarring, yes, but somehow it works \u2014 we are left wanting more \u2014 and makes for a satisfying coda to a frustrating show.", "title": "Review: \u2018Against the Hillside\u2019 Is an Eye on Drone Warfare", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cAltered Carbon\u201d is a lesson in the importance of context.\n\nIf it were on the Syfy channel, where it belongs, it would look above average. You\u2019d think, yeah, not bad. On Netflix, where its 10 episodes have been released, it still looks like an above-average Syfy series, which just makes you think, what the heck is this doing here?\n\nTo give Netflix the benefit of the doubt, it\u2019s probably there for the cord cutters. If attracting them means recreating the entire ecosystem of television, then there\u2019s room for a low-rent \u201cBlade Runner\u201d knockoff with basic-cable production values and premium-cable nudity. Not everything can or needs to be \u201cBlack Mirror.\u201d\n\nBut if you\u2019re concerned with maintaining your reputation as a leading purveyor of prestige TV, you might want to think harder about what you slap the \u201cNetflix Original\u201d label on.\n\nBased on a cyberpunk novel by Richard K. Morgan and created by the \u201cTerminator Genisys\u201d executive producer Laeta Kalogridis, \u201cAltered Carbon\u201d takes place in a future when technology has brought about a qualified form of immortality.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA person\u2019s essence \u2014 personality, intelligence, memories \u2014 can be loaded onto a metal disc called a stack and, in the event of death or boredom, inserted into a new body. The rich, called Meths (for Methuselahs), can repeatedly clone themselves and live out an unchanging prime of life. The poor make do with any body they can get their hands on, whose age, race and even gender may be different from theirs.", "title": "Review: \u2018Altered Carbon,\u2019 Netflix\u2019s \u2018Blade Runner\u2019 Replicant", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The conflict between husband and wife, pressurized by their daily encounters with Islamophobia, is set within a larger family and historical context. Azeem and Saima live with Azeem\u2019s parents, Akeel and Malika, who in their own way have played out the drama of deracination.\n\nAkeel (Ranjit Chowdhry) is old enough to have lived through two major emigrations, from India to Pakistan after the 1947 partition and from Pakistan to England in the 1950s. The first move cost his family its land and money, the second its status as part of the majority culture. During the decades of dead-end manual labor in London, Akeel often vented his accumulated frustration on Malika (Rita Wolf) and she in turn vented hers on their daughter, Javeria (Angel Desai).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSet in 2011, \u201cAn Ordinary Muslim\u201d considers the double bind facing those who wish to enjoy the opportunities of assimilation while also maintaining a connection to their traditions. Each path looks suspicious to those who favor the other. Azeem lurches back and forth, letting his frustrations at work infect his family life and vice versa. He ends up alienating white colleagues like his pal David (Andrew Hovelson) by telling them that their professed liberality is in fact more treacherous than bigotry.\n\nThis is already a great deal for one play to shoulder, and I haven\u2019t even mentioned the thread of the plot that considers the pressures on Azeem that come from within the Muslim community. (No single way of practicing his faith will please everyone.) As those pressures start to drag him down, his behavior becomes even more erratic \u2014 \u201cYou\u2019ve gone from no Islam to Nation of Islam in five seconds,\u201d Saima says \u2014 and the play\u2019s point of view blurs. By the time it tries to connect Azeem\u2019s personal crisis to the rise of Muslim extremist violence in the West, it has lost its ability to sustain an argument.\n\nThe high-thread-count plot, the theme of moral confusion and the politico-economic framework that looms over the family drama are all hallmarks of the work of Tony Kushner, who mentored Mr. Chaudry as he worked on \u201cAn Ordinary Muslim.\u201d And New York Theater Workshop, which produced Mr. Kushner\u2019s \u201cHomebody/Kabul\u201d in 2001, has put its considerable expertise \u2014 and the strong director Jo Bonney \u2014 at the production\u2019s disposal. Few first-time playwrights receive such support.\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t enough. \u201cAn Ordinary Muslim\u201d is an important work still struggling to emerge from a text filled with freshman problems. The argumentative plot (Mr. Chaudry was studying to be a lawyer when the theater bug bit him) makes sense only for short stretches, after each of which the character logic seems to reset. Because the key conflicts are mostly described by unreliable narrators instead of enacted directly for us, they feel imposed or even doubtful. So even though everything about the play\u2019s take on assimilation and racism is convincing in the abstract, nothing about the people experiencing it is.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat isn\u2019t the cast\u2019s fault. No one could steer smoothly through all of Azeem\u2019s hairpin turns, but Mr. De Silva is charismatic while trying. All of the others (including Sathya Sridharan and Harsh Nayyar as representatives of the local Muslim community) have strong moments too, and Ms. Wolf, as a mother who is somehow both amusing and terrifying, has nothing but.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe production doesn\u2019t help those strong moments hang together. Visually it seems to be caught between genres, unable to settle on domestic realism or Kushnerian poetics. (The set is by Neil Patel.) Ms. Bonney, who has staged thrilling productions of several recent plays by Suzan-Lori Parks, can do little but help this one move swiftly, though it seems to me it should have been shorter or longer than its two and a half hours.\n\nPlays are mysterious machines; even veteran playwrights find them hard to operate. The most promising thing about \u201cAn Ordinary Muslim\u201d is the way its best moments seem to creep delicately out from under the rock of the author\u2019s determination to make heavier points.\n\nIn my favorite of these, Akeel, just when he seems ready to apologize to Malika for his lifetime of failures as a husband and father, suddenly switches from English to Urdu. Here Mr. Chaudry is using an inherently theatrical gesture to force an understanding, among the non-Urdu speakers in the audience anyway, that not everything true is universally comprehensible. And that, small as it is, is an earthshaking insight.", "title": "Review: \u2018An Ordinary Muslim\u2019 Gets Caught Between Cultures and Genres", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Eli takes a gig trucking an engine upstate, and in the desolate winter setting, takes to chugging antifreeze (or some such horrific liquid) with a local resident, who takes him to a place the end credits call Sludge Club. That\u2019s accurate. There he meets Anya (Chelsea Lopez), who has a purple pageboy wig and a devotion to vintage soul music that\u2019s compelled her to create a Rube Goldbergesque light show machine to accompany her tunes. When she removes her wig, she has a head of stringy hair that rather resembles that of the Crypt Keeper on that old horror anthology TV show \u201cTales From the Crypt.\u201d\n\nSo that\u2019s different. Written and directed by Xander Robin, the movie continues in this peculiar vein, taking in Anya\u2019s hair-eating fetish/compulsion and depicting its consequences. The picture climaxes with a grisly hairball-removal scene accompanied on the soundtrack by Timmy Thomas\u2019s catchy classic \u201cWhy Can\u2019t We Live Together.\u201d You have to wonder what the music supervisor\u2019s pitch was in seeking permission for its use. \u201cAre We Not Cats\u201d is a well-put-together film with a lot of striking imagery, but, as you may have already inferred, something of a specialty item.", "title": "Review: \u2018Are We Not Cats\u2019 Offers Hair Balls of a Different Order", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "But where does robbin\u2019 season stop and regular life begin? Especially for the struggling creatives in \u201cAtlanta\u201d (Alfred\u2019s hit single won him more fame than cash), it can be hard to tell.\n\nEach of the first three episodes either involves or mentions robbery, sometimes scary, sometimes ludicrous, as with the armed man who sticks up an old friend out of nowhere, apologizing profusely throughout it: \u201cHey, my fault, bro.\u201d\n\nBut there are also scams and hustles and the everyday pickpocketing of dignity. When Earn goes out with Van (Zazie Beetz), his friend, his sometime lover and the mother of his child, the movie theater refuses to accept a $100 bill from him but takes one from the middle-aged white man behind him in line.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get expert TV and movie recommendations from the Watching newsletter The best of what to watch and where to watch it, delivered to your inbox twice a week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis focus puts a finer point on what was an intermittent theme in the first season: the larcenous nature of everyday life. Money in \u201cAtlanta\u201d is like an occult force, flowing through everything but accessible only through arcane arts and invocations.\n\nYou can feel its presence in the loft-like office of a streaming music company that Earn and Alfred visit. After a disappointing meeting \u2014 the audio system glitches trying to play Alfred\u2019s music \u2014 they wander around and see another artist inside a conference room, performing for rapt staffers. Success seems so close, but it\u2019s behind impenetrable, soundproof glass.\n\nThe season also introduces Clark County (RJ Walker), a more successful rapper whose manager \u2014 a white guy \u2014 has connections to secure the rich advertising deals that elude Alfred. (Though he\u2019s laid-back offstage, he\u2019s been typecast into a bad-boy role by the industry; the only endorsement he\u2019s offered is for \u201ccocaine white cheddar\u201d snack chips.)\n\nWhen the characters in \u201cAtlanta\u201d do get money, it\u2019s like a silent alarm goes off somewhere; the entire world becomes focused on separating the newfound cash from its holder. A windfall attracts new temporary friends; nightclubs transform into hungry money-extraction vortices.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlong with its new title, \u201cAtlanta Robbin\u2019 Season\u201d has a different, more serial structure from the impressionistic first season. What\u2019s blessedly the same: the dry sense of humor, the luscious visual style established by the frequent director Hiro Murai and the writers\u2019 effortless fluency with social media\u2019s language and quirks. (A brilliant early bit involves the popularity of white-girl acoustic covers of rap songs on YouTube.)\n\nThe storytelling in \u201cAtlanta\u201d is dreamlike, which is another way of saying that it\u2019s unusually realistic. As in life, weird or comical developments don\u2019t announce themselves before they happen: They just start happening, and your consciousness has to catch up. The off-balance feeling this creates is the buzz of watching \u201cAtlanta.\u201d\n\nThat buzz kicks in during the first episode, where Earn finds himself moderating a dispute at the house of his uncle Willy (a crackling guest spot by the comedian Katt Williams). Willy casually mentions that he has an alligator in the bathroom. You don\u2019t see an alligator, just a closed door. Is he kidding? Maybe. But now you are in a world where an alligator might be in the next room.\n\nThis is what \u201cAtlanta\u201d is so good at: dropping you into scenes blind, trusting that getting oriented will be half the pleasure.\n\nThe approach requires close attention, and the episodes reward a second watching. But they\u2019re hardly homework. Mr. Glover and his creative team (including his brother, Stephen) are in enough control of their material to produce meticulously crafted episodes that play like offhanded shaggy-dog (or -alligator) stories. \u201cRobbin\u2019 Season\u201d is so good, it\u2019s almost criminal.", "title": "Review: \u2018Atlanta\u2019 and the Surreal Larceny of Life", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "A jolt of a movie, \u201cBlack Panther\u201d creates wonder with great flair and feeling partly through something Hollywood rarely dreams of anymore: myth. Most big studio fantasies take you out for a joy ride only to hit the same exhausted story and franchise-expanding beats. Not this one. Its axis point is the fantastical nation of Wakanda, an African Eden where verdant-green landscapes meet blue-sky science fiction. There, spaceships with undercarriages resembling tribal masks soar over majestic waterfalls, touching down in a story that has far more going for it than branding.\n\nWakanda is home to Black Panther, a.k.a. T\u2019Challa (Chadwick Boseman), the latest Marvel hero to leap off the comic-book page and into his own movie. Created in 1966 by Stan Lee (script) and Jack Kirby (art), the original Black Panther \u2014 a hepcat in a slinky suit with claws and ears \u2014 debuted alongside the Fantastic Four in an adventure in Wakanda, which is powered by a mystery metal, vibranium. It was a splashy, timely entrance (the revolutionary group that shares his name officially formed that same year), and by the end of his first escapade, the Four had assured T\u2019Challa \u201cthere\u2019s no reason for the Black Panther\u2019s career to come to an end!\u201d\n\nIn the decades since, Black Panther has undergone a variety of costume alterations and adventures in the comics, some under the direction of the filmmaker Reginald Hudlin and, more recently, the author Ta-Nehisi Coates. To direct the first Panther movie, Marvel tapped Ryan Coogler, who with his last outing, \u201cCreed,\u201d shook the dust off the Rocky series by giving it an African-American champion played by Michael B. Jordan. For \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d Mr. Coogler brought back both Mr. Jordan and some former crew members \u2014 including Rachel Morrison, the director of photography on his first feature \u201cFruitvale Station\u201d \u2014 continuity that may help account for this movie\u2019s intimacy and fluidity.", "title": "Review: \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Shakes Up the Marvel Universe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn \u201cThe Fire Next Time,\u201d James Baldwin wrote that \u201cto accept one\u2019s past \u2014 one\u2019s history \u2014 is not the same thing as drowning in it.\u201d He knew that the superstitious fear of being swallowed up, the dread of giving up a fantasy of innocence, is precisely what keeps so many white Americans from confronting the uglier aspects of the nation\u2019s legacy.\n\nTravis Wilkerson, a documentary filmmaker whose roots are in small-town Alabama, attempts just such a reckoning in \u201cDid You Wonder Who Fired the Gun?\u201d The movie, a scorching and rigorous essay on memory and accountability, is neither a profession of guilt nor a performance of virtue. Though his inquiry is intensely, at times painfully personal, Mr. Wilkerson is above all concerned with unpacking the mechanisms of racial domination. The procedure is akin to performing surgery on a half-conscious subject, or digging up a buried land mine that has lost little of its explosive power.\n\nVideo\n\nThe focus of his excavation is a killing that took place in Dothan, Ala., in 1946, when S.E. Branch, a white shopkeeper, shot Bill Spann, a black man who was in his store. Branch, Mr. Wilkerson\u2019s great-grandfather, was charged with first-degree murder, but no trial was ever held, and the crime faded from memory. Or rather, the memory of it was quietly and systematically suppressed. All that remains are a short newspaper article and a few photographs and home movies of the killer.\n\n\u201cDid You Wonder Who Fired the Gun?\u201d proceeds on several parallel tracks. Mr. Wilkerson returns to Alabama and tries to discover both how Bill Spann died and how he was forgotten. His investigation, accompanied by haunting images of Southern back roads and quiet houses, is punctuated by reminders that Bill Spann\u2019s death is hardly a unique or anomalous event. The names of Trayvon Martin, Eric Garner and other recent victims of racist violence appear onscreen, and two songs of protest loop into the soundtrack: Janelle Mon\u00e1e\u2019s \u201cHell You Talmbout\u201d and Phil Ochs\u2019s \u201cWilliam Moore.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat song, about a white postal worker and civil rights activist murdered on an Alabama highway in 1963, is the source of the film\u2019s title and a part of its wider cultural context. \u201cDid You Wonder Who Fired the Gun?\u201d is a passionately political film, aflame with rage in spite of its director\u2019s measured, ruminative tone of voice. It is also a horror movie, full of specters and silences and a terror that is pervasive, intimate and elusive.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Wilkerson, whose previous films include \u201cAn Injury to One\u201d and \u201cFar From Afghanistan,\u201d dispenses with many of the usual techniques of historical documentary. There are a few on-camera interviews, with neighbors and relatives, but more frequently Mr. Wilkerson narrates encounters that took place off camera. And his sleuthing often leads not to moments of revelation but to dead ends and deeper mysteries. The insertion of clips from \u201cTo Kill a Mockingbird\u201d provides a chilling and ironic counterpoint to the grim story this movie is telling. S.E. Branch is the opposite of Gregory Peck\u2019s brave and decent Atticus Finch, and the truth about what happened to Bill Spann resists the kind of redemptive, healing conclusion that remains a cornerstone of American racial fantasy.\n\nInstead of consolation, Mr. Wilkerson offers commitment. Instead of idealism, honesty. He doesn\u2019t suppose that his film will solve anything, but there is nonetheless something profoundly useful about the way he confronts past and present manifestations of white supremacy. He links his great-grandfather\u2019s crime to the contemporaneous gang rape of Recy Taylor (the subject of an excellent recent documentary by Nancy Buirski), and uncovers patterns of abuse within his family. He corresponds with a relative who is part of a white nationalist, \u201cSouthern secessionist\u201d group. He notes the way racial injustice dwells in apparently mundane facts. The killer is immortalized in pictures and a well-kept tombstone. His victim has been almost entirely erased from memory, a kind of second death beyond the reach of redress or revenge.", "title": "Review: \u2018Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun?\u2019 Reckons With White Supremacy", "authors": ["A. O. Scott"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn the opening scene of \u201cDouble Lover,\u201d its protagonist, Chlo\u00e9 (Marine Vacth), is seen getting her hair cut. Her wet hair, pale face and the gray background impart a simple elegance to the sequence. The following scene takes place in the bleaker confines of a gynecologist\u2019s office. In one shot, the screen fills with the colors pink and silver. Viewers may wonder exactly what they are seeing at first, but as the camera zooms out it becomes clear: a speculum seen from the point of view of a doctor conducting a vaginal examination. The shot dissolves into a geometrically corresponding close-up of Chlo\u00e9\u2019s eye.\n\nThe straightforward explicitness of the imagery is a hallmark of Fran\u00e7ois Ozon, the film\u2019s director (his best known films include the thrillers \u201cSee the Sea\u201d and \u201cSwimming Pool\u201d); the juxtaposition is very Georges Bataille (he wrote a piece of outr\u00e9 eroticism titled \u201cStory of the Eye\u201d). Some might say it\u2019s all very French, and perhaps it is. But it does make one sit up and take notice. The clever thing about it is that it\u2019s not until the movie is almost over that the viewer can fully understand this imagery as something more than an effective, but perhaps idle provocation.\n\nVideo\n\nChlo\u00e9, looking underweight, has complained about chronic stomach pains to her gynecologist. And on that doctor\u2019s advice, she starts seeing a psychoanalyst, Paul (J\u00e9r\u00e9mie Renier). He\u2019s handsome, gentle, compassionate. He \u201ccures\u201d her, they confess romantic feelings for each other, and they move in together. One small glitch is that he does not much care for her cat Milo. A bigger glitch comes soon after that: Chlo\u00e9 meets another psychoanalyst, Paul\u2019s double, who claims to be his twin brother. He\u2019s a rougher character who likes his own cat, a specimen of a rare breed. He thinks he can cure Chlo\u00e9 of a new complaint, and there\u2019s lots of athletic sex involved in the treatment.\n\nWhat\u2019s going on here? The doubling imagery, the recurring spiral staircases, and so much else engulfing Chlo\u00e9 make this thriller unusually engrossing. \u201cDouble Lover\u201d nods a bit to David Cronenberg\u2019s \u201cDead Ringers\u201d (1988) and Roman Polanski\u2019s \u201cThe Tenant\u201d (1976), two arguably classic thrillers on doppelg\u00e4ngers and madness, and Mr. Ozon\u2019s stylistic gymnastics sometimes bring to mind Brian De Palma, who made a film about good/bad twins early in his career. But \u201cDouble Lover,\u201d which Mr. Ozon \u201cfreely adapted\u201d from the Joyce Carol Oates book \u201cLives of the Twins,\u201d spins its influences into a frenzy that ultimately reveals the story to be very much its own thing. And a crazy, and eventually strangely moving, thing it is. As elaborate as its visuals are, the movie is also intimate. There aren\u2019t many characters besides Chlo\u00e9 and the twins, which adds to the frisson late in the movie when the great Jacqueline Bisset makes her entrance.\n\nMr. Renier is clearly having a blast as the twins, but Ms. Vacth, who worked with Mr. Ozon on the 2014 film \u201cYoung and Beautiful,\u201d does more than hold her own opposite him. She modulates Chlo\u00e9\u2019s mood from slumping vulnerability to hip-swinging confidence, from a whirlpool of self-doubt and near despair to defiance. \u201cDouble Lover\u201d is as much, if not more, Ms. Vacth\u2019s movie as it is the director\u2019s.", "title": "Review: \u2018Double Lover\u2019 Is a Knotty Delight of a Thriller", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Fran\u00e7ois Ozon"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMy feelings about \u201cEarly Man\u201d can be summed up as better late than never. I\u2019m a little sorry that this utterly silly feature from Nick Park and Aardman Animations was not around when I was 7 or 8 years old, or when my children were wearing out the Wallace and Gromit videocassettes that someone had given them for Christmas. Not that anyone could outgrow this kind of movie, which manages to be fresh and delightful even as some of its jokes are so old \u2014 how old? So old that the last time I heard them, I fell off my dinosaur I was laughing so hard.\n\nAbout that: In prehistoric times, according to Mr. Park and the screenwriters (Mark Burton and James Higginson), cave men and giant lizards shared the planet for a while. A bit later, descendants of those same cave-dwellers \u2014 a band of genial, not-too-bright hunter-gatherers in a verdant valley near what is now Manchester, England \u2014 coexisted uneasily with a more aggressive and arrogant breed of humans, who mastered metallurgy, stadium-building and sports commentary. \u201cThe age of stone is over. The age of bronze is here,\u201d they proclaim as they drive the Stone Agers into the wasteland.\n\nIt would be pedantic in the extreme to fault this movie for its inaccurate rendering of the past. Did mammoths\u2019 feet in ancient times walk upon England\u2019s green and pleasant land? Does the fossil record contain evidence of a mallard the size of a 727? You might as well ask if there are La Brea Tar Pits in Scotland. As Bugs Bunny will tell you, there are no La Brea Tar Pits in Scotland.\n\nVideo\n\nBut I would not go so far as to say that \u201cEarly Man\u201d is entirely devoid of historical interest. Its structuring myth is the loss of Arcadia. A peaceful and authentic way of life is threatened with destruction by the forces of modernity, and the threat is resisted in a stirring and potentially tragic show of courage. The encounter between the simple, primitive folk and their more sophisticated would-be conquerors may remind you of the films of Mel Gibson. Mr. Park has essentially remade \u201cApocalypto\u201d but with soccer instead of human sacrifice, \u201cBraveheart\u201d with a giant stop-motion duck.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother way to look at this movie might be as an artisanal cartoon exploration of the story told by the Yale political scientist James Scott in his recent book \u201cAgainst the Grain.\u201d According to Mr. Scott (no relation to the present writer), the rise of states \u2014 of political authority, organized violence, accumulated wealth and everything else we associate with the advance of civilization \u2014 was a disaster for our species: a blow to our autonomy, our solidarity, our moral and physical health. Or, to put the argument in \u201cEarly Man\u201d terms, we were happier when we were chasing rabbits instead of building monuments, fighting wars and paying taxes. The rabbits, all things considered, were probably happier, too.", "title": "Review: \u2018Early Man\u2019 Is a Very Funny Trip to the Past", "authors": ["A.O. Scott", "Mark Burton", "James Higginson"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The antidote to that sensationalist exercise is the fascinating experimental documentary \u201cEl Mar La Mar,\u201d which also concerns migration in the Sonoran Desert and screens at MoMA from Friday through March 1. But instead of offering a short burst of terror followed by the prospect of a quick escape, this immersive, sensorially complex movie evokes the terrifying disorientation and loneliness of migration: the eerie sounds of sand crunching underfoot; the surreal sights of jugs of water left by well-wishers; fragments of voices heard over radio transmissions.\n\nTold in three movements, the second being the longest and least cryptic, the film is the work of J.P. Sniadecki (a veteran of Harvard\u2019s Sensory Ethnography Lab) and Joshua Bonnetta, who are as concerned with the possibilities of the film medium as they are with this particular subject. The human presence is largely limited to voice-over testimonies. A resident talks about taking in a shivering young man. We hear of migrants\u2019 experiences with getting lost. A woman recalls discovering a body.\n\nThe result is simultaneously elusive and concrete: abstract cinema that packs a punch.", "title": "Review: \u2018El Mar La Mar,\u2019 an Abstract Look at Desert Border Crossings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNEW HAVEN \u2014 Have you ever wanted to see a towering novel of moral anguish reduced to an 80-minute romp? Oh, good: me, too.\n\nSo it pains me to report that \u201cField Guide,\u201d a semi-goofball, semi-searching distillation of Dostoyevsky\u2019s \u201cThe Brothers Karamazov,\u201d isn\u2019t much fun. Created by Rude Mechs and produced by Yale Repertory Theater, which commissioned it, \u201cField Guide\u201d distills 800 pages of text into alt-comedy riffs, surrealist digressions and several scenes in which cardboard set pieces whiz around the stage more or less by themselves.\n\n\u201cThe Grand Inquisitor\u201d section? It\u2019s here. And it\u2019s set in a hot tub.\n\nTo see the show among Dostoyevsky fans was to watch an audience move from excited to perplexed to annoyed. A couple of spectators used that gift of freedom with which they were born and left midway.\n\nRude Mechs, an Austin, Tex., company, has concocted some superb pieces, like a cooler-than-cool adaptation of Greil Marcus\u2019s \u201cLipstick Traces\u201d and an ultradry staging of the David Rees comic strip \u201cGet Your War On.\u201d When they\u2019re good, they\u2019re very, very good \u2014 hip and brash and welcoming.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut when they\u2019re bad, as in the Tennessee Williams riff \u201cThe Method Gun,\u201d they\u2019re smug and in-jokey, like a table full of popular kids who won\u2019t let you put your tray down. (There are plays in the middle, too, like the half-formed \u201cStop Hitting Yourself,\u201d which played at LCT3 a few years ago and is fondly remembered for its queso fountain.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cField Guide,\u201d directed by Shawn Sides, isn\u2019t one of the great ones. It begins well enough, with an anhedonic standup set by Hannah Kenah, a pileup of nonjokes like \u201cSo I ran into my hairdresser at a coffee shop the other day. I think she was pretty disappointed.\u201d They land with the bounce of a punctured beach ball.", "title": "Review: \u2018Field Guide\u2019 Brings Standup to a Dostoyevsky Downer", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe wood-paneled elevator that ferries guests up to \u201cFlight\u201d at the McKittrick Hotel rises at a languid pace, and the tinny, piped-in music sounds like something out of a speakeasy. Atmospherically, it seems an awkward match with the show you\u2019ve come to see, about a pair of Afghan child refugees crossing Europe in search of sanctuary.\n\nSo does the McKittrick, not a hotel at all but the sprawling Chelsea complex that is the longtime home of the immersive-theater behemoth \u201cSleep No More,\u201d where spectators roam dimly lit halls on multiple floors, traipsing through rooms that are essentially art installations in which performances periodically break out.\n\nCreated by the Scottish company Vox Motus, and a hit at the Edinburgh International Festival, \u201cFlight\u201d is 180 degrees different from that vast and ambulatory production \u2014 still, intimate, visceral, rendered on a Lilliputian scale and requiring you to do nothing but watch and listen. Intricately designed yet with no live performers, it is arguably not even theater. But it is pulse-pounding, immersive storytelling, strange and exquisite and intensely affecting.\n\nAs you\u2019re led to it in the dark, your seat looks like a library carrel, partitioned off like all of the others. You sit, you don a pair of headphones and in a few moments the show will appear, tableaus inside a succession of little windows, lit up one by one and slowly revolving on a carousel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe refugees are orphans. Darling round-faced Kabir is 7 or 8, and his big brother Aryan is on the cusp of adolescence, the two of them crossing perilously from Turkey into Greece. The landscape is rocky and they are tiny against it, but bound, they are sure, for England, where they want to go to school.\n\nPhoto\n\nAryan (voiced by Farshid Rokey) has taught Kabir (voiced by Nalini Chetty) their route, drilling it into him so thoroughly that the boy speaks it like one long, exultant word:\n\n\u201cKabulTehranIstanbulAthensRomeParisLondon!\u201d\n\nAs soon as their story begins, you are whooshed into it with an immediacy that would be impossible in any other form. On screen or in print or even with live actors, physical and emotional distance would form a barrier. But the directors, Jamie Harrison (whose big upcoming Broadway credit is for the illusions in \u201cHarry Potter and the Cursed Child\u201d) and Candice Edmunds, have created a world in miniature inches from our own eyes that allows us, somehow, a straight line into all of its fear and danger and battered resilience.", "title": "Review: \u2018Flight\u2019 Has No Live Actors. But Its Story of Two Afghan Boys Feels So Real.", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Only the kidnapping is real, or seems to be. The gun Brooks leaves behind is very much real and loaded, as Max learns when one of its rounds goes through his arm. It\u2019s at junctures like this when the movie becomes less conventional, although it never soars. The dialogue leans so heavily on pop culture references you have to wonder whether the film\u2019s screenwriter, Mark Perez, is as insecure as his creation Max.\n\nThe directors, John Francis Daley and Jonathan Goldstein, who were behind the repellent 2015 film \u201cVacation,\u201d show relative restraint here, in spite of a set piece that involves an adorable little dog getting its immaculate white coat doused with blood. And all the cast members \u2014 particularly the friends and neighbors played by Chelsea Peretti, Billy Magnussen, Sharon Horgan, Lamorne Morris and Jesse Plemons (who, as an uptight cop, delivers a deliberately robotic idea of a Matt Damon impersonation) \u2014 are very funny when they get the opportunity to be. And the movie is a pointed reminder that Ms. McAdams is one of cinema\u2019s most accomplished and appealing comic actresses. It\u2019s almost heartbreaking to contemplate how amazing she would be in a new comedy that was more than intermittently O.K.", "title": "Review: \u2018Game Night\u2019 Has a Winning Rachel McAdams and Charades With a Twist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "The director of \u201cGeorge,\u201d Jeffrey Perkins, an artist who is described in his own biography as a Fluxus associate, emphasizes the contradictions of the enigmatic ringleader. Was Mr. Maciunas a significant artist himself or more of an organizer? Was Fluxus an original idea or did it simply seize on a post-Dada spirit that was already fueling conceptual and performance art across the globe in the 1960s? Fluxus may have been a way for the domineering Mr. Maciunas, an admirer of military history, to try to conquer and monopolize the avant-garde \u2014 though at times he had some difficulty bending artists to his will. And the Fluxus philosophy had democratic and even utopian underpinnings.\n\nMr. Perkins livens up what could have been a dull talking-heads presentation with vortex-like editing, often dividing the screen into multiple panels and making inventive use of sound design. There is no shortage of vintage Fluxus footage or arcana to draw on; the interviews, old and new, with Maciunas associates like Yoko Ono, Nam June Paik and Henry Flynt are informative and often fascinatingly contradictory.", "title": "Review: \u2018George,\u2019 Like Its Fluxus Subject, Is Playful and Prankish", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cGood Girls,\u201d which begins Monday on NBC, has an empowerment theme that\u2019s timely in the #MeToo era. But it also speaks to antihero dramas\u2019 long history of giving men \u2014 generally only men \u2014 license to be bad.\n\nFor Walter White and his many TV cousins, crime has often been about self-worth, even virility. (Tony Soprano\u2019s big boat is named \u201cThe Stugots,\u201d after an Italian male-anatomical slang term.)\n\nFor Beth, Annie and Ruby, the money is more about self-determination: freedom from reliance on lousy men or the whims of the economy. When Ruby, flush with cash, sees an expensive doctor who offers her cucumber water, she cries a little bit at the upgrade in attention that money can buy.\n\nThe series, created by Jenna Bans, is tartly funny, less heavy than its cable kin and more concerned with righteous payback than ethical angst.\n\nBut it\u2019s not entirely light, either. There\u2019s some blood \u2014 more than a tablespoon, less than a gallon \u2014 and an attempted rape early on. This material feels like it should carry more weight than \u201cGood Girls\u201d often gives it.\n\n\u201cGood Girls\u201d certainly works as a caper, especially given the rapport among its three leads. You can\u2019t not want to spend an hour watching Ms. Hendricks, Ms. Whitman and Retta rob stuff. The show gets plenty of mileage from its surburbanites-gone-wild conceit, as when Ruby chooses the location for a rendezvous: \u201cThey always do the drop-off at a park on \u2018Law & Order.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe problem is that it\u2019s also very much a drama, and the needs of the one mode often conflict with those of the other. (Throw in the scenes between Ms. Whitman and Mr. Gilford, formerly of \u201cFriday Night Lights,\u201d and the show occasionally shades into a third genre, a more-realistic family dramedy along the lines of Ms. Whitman\u2019s former show, \u201cParenthood.\u201d)\n\nTo work as a walk-on-the-wild-side drama, the series needs a sense of stakes, that bad things can happen and that characters can come to bad ends. To deliver on the ironies of that \u201cGood\u201d in the title, there needs to be moral conflict \u2014 the possibility that these protagonists, however much we like them, might make a wrong choice that will get somebody hurt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut because \u201cGood Girls\u201d has an offbeat tone \u2014 and airs on a broadcast network \u2014 you get the feeling that the guardrails are up. Most of the threatening situations resolve comically, and we\u2019re reminded that the robbery is a victimless crime. \u201cWe\u2019re normal people,\u201d Beth says. \u201cWe pay our taxes, and we take our kids to P.F. Chang\u2019s, and we take orange slices to soccer games.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s a valid choice, but one more consistent with an escapist comedy, and at times the show seems to have other intentions.\n\nI\u2019ve only seen three episodes of \u201cGood Girls,\u201d however, and it\u2019s possible that the uneven tone reflects the characters\u2019 situations. Just as the women have to decide if they\u2019re actual criminals or just dabblers, so, too, may \u201cGood Girls\u201d land on a better sense of what kind of series it is.\n\nThere\u2019s a sign of its long-term direction in the third episode, when Beth considers whether she\u2019s breaking the law simply for the money or because she likes it. This might also address the question of how you make an extended series about three characters trying to get out of the crime business, rather than into it.\n\nBut maybe the pleasures of \u201cGood Girls\u201d so far are like the proceeds from a heist. You\u2019ve just got to enjoy them while they last.", "title": "Review: \u2018Good Girls\u2019 Offers Equal Time for Antiheroines", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe hip-hop entrepreneur Damon Dash has been producing and directing motion pictures since the late 1990s. You\u2019d never know it from looking at \u201cHonor Up,\u201d a new movie he directed from a script he wrote with Kevin Bennett.\n\nVideo\n\nThe filmmaking is point-and-shoot rudimentary (when it wants to get fancy, it resorts to split-screen effects that bring to mind the 1980s production software called Video Toaster). The acting is awkward (Mr. Dash himself has a leading role), and the characters themselves indifferently delineated. Clich\u00e9s are rife, both in dialogue (\u201cSometimes good guys have to do bad things\u201d) and construction (shootout scenes are frequently scored to arias and fake-arias sung by Radmila Lolly).\n\nAnd yet this anecdotal movie about drug dealers and their internecine troubles, and their further troubles with the justice system, can be oddly persuasive. Narrated by Mr. Dash\u2019s character, named O.G., the movie begins by laying out the meaning of the title phrase. Which is pretty much what you\u2019d infer: that you don\u2019t rat out your partners in the criminal enterprise that players call \u201cthe game.\u201d The movie then shows various gang members and rivals facing each other down, wiping each other out, and eventually giving each other up.\n\nNicholas Turturro as a relentless and racist cop, and Eishia Brightwell as the ostensibly \u201coff limits\u201d sister of a dealer who tries to get herself a piece of gang action, make particularly vivid impressions. For all of its failings, the movie sometimes manages to bring a scary whiff of the street into its sounds and images.", "title": "Review: \u2018Honor Up\u2019 Offers a Raw View of Gangster Life", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Kevin Bennett", "Damon Dash"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "The play wears its learning lightly, though. Its masterstroke is newly contextualizing ages-old themes and motifs into a thoroughly contemporary, divided African-American landscape. That every character is black doesn\u2019t mean that there\u2019s solidarity between the play\u2019s haves and have-nots or, for that matter, within a single family.\n\nResentment festers so deeply in the people portrayed here that they\u2019re all going to wind up alone. That may even include the symbiotic sisters at the play\u2019s center.\n\nRacine and Anaia open the play downstage center, in glaring light, positioned in a way that invites \u2014 no, dares \u2014 us to stare at them. They bear hideous scars, which, in Anaia\u2019s case, cover much of her face.\n\nThe sisters, in turns out, are survivors of a fire, which was set by their mysterious father and which they believe killed their mother. They grew up in a series of foster homes. As Racine describes their upbringing, \u201cWe been kilt. Again and again. More than one way to die. How we still alive after all the times we been passed around? How we still alive after all the times we got hit?\u201d\n\nThe infernal plot machinery is set in motion when they receive a letter. Their mother is alive, in a rest home in the \u201cDirty South,\u201d and she wants to see them before she dies. What follows unfolds in a series of chapters signaled by titles (including \u201cBefore God,\u201d \u201cThe Weapon,\u201d \u201cIn the Valley\u201d) that pop up \u2014 against hokey cinematic backdrops \u2014 on that battered television above the stage.\n\nThe twins wind up in the hills of California, where they encounter a fat-cat lawyer (Michael Genet) and a well-heeled but uneasy suburban family, which includes a perfectly groomed, miserable mother (Nehassaiu deGannes) and her teenage boys (Caleb Eberhardt and Anthony Cason). What do you know? They\u2019re twins, too!\n\nYou don\u2019t need to ask, \u201cWho is the father?\u201d Identified only as the Man (a perfect, laconic Teagle F. Bougere), this unholy father shows up late, whistling, his face concealed by a black cowboy hat. And so the reckoning is at hand.", "title": "Review: \u2018Is God Is\u2019 Reinvents the Good, the Bad and the Ugly", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "But until \u201cDonald Trump \u2014 The Opera\u201d comes along (shudder), \u201cJerry Springer\u201d may be the richest theatrical means we have for channeling the heaving American Id that put Mr. Trump in the White House. And there\u2019s the nifty dividend that \u201cJerry Springer\u201d also sings volumes about the enduring appeal of the musical as a popular art form.\n\nBut first a trigger warning, in deference to those who protested at Carnegie Hall: This show has what is surely the highest ratio of obscenities of any mainstream musical ever. Make that any mainstream theater production period. (Sorry about that, David Mamet.)\n\nWhat\u2019s more, Anglo-Saxon words that are still regularly bleeped on radio and television have been set to melodies that recall Baroque choral prayer song as well as soulful Broadway ballads. Those uttering these curse words include Jesus and his heavenly father.\n\nThe juxtaposition of holy music and unholy lyrics might seem too facile by half; it\u2019s a treatment long applied by giggly school children to church hymns. But this show uses the disparity between words and music to suggest how inadequate most people\u2019s vocabularies are in conveying their most ardent longings.\n\nMusic is what captures the skyward-reaching, ineffable yearnings of the characters \u2014 the triple-timing bisexual lug, the man with the diaper fetish, the housewife who wants to be a pole dancer. The pure, pulsing beauty of Mr. Thomas\u2019s score (he and Mr. Lee collaborated on the book and lyrics) hooks us subliminally, while reminding us how classic American musicals are so often all about aspiration.\n\nThe aspirations in \u201cJerry Springer\u201d are a little less classic than finding love or triumphing over adversity. What drives the denizens of the Springer universe is, quite simply, the desire to exercise their constitutional right to be famous.\n\nThe show\u2019s first half takes place in a studio (created by the set designer Derek McLane as a space that embraces us all), where a live audience responds with vim and vitriol to the procession of \u201closers\u201d who are Jerry\u2019s featured guests. The second half takes us to the furnace room known as hell, where Jerry is asked to do \u201cconflict resolution\u201d (which was never in his contract) for special, otherworldly guests who are way over his pay grade.", "title": "Review: \u2018Jerry Springer,\u2019 Sacred and Profane, Triumphantly Sings Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "A magical mystery marathon, King Hu\u2019s \u201cLegend of the Mountain\u201d takes place (maybe, as the narrator waggishly says) in the 11th century during the Song dynasty. It tells of a cheerful, underemployed scholar, Ho Yunqing (Shih Chun), who makes a meager living as a copyist. Soon after the movie opens, he is entrusted to copy a Buddhist sutra (a dialogue or sermon) that can liberate souls stuck in limbo. Ho isn\u2019t a believer, but he needs the money and so enthusiastically heads out on a seemingly simple mission, one that eventually leads to an isolated outpost where curious and curiouser things occur.\n\nFilled with lovely natural landscapes that have been meticulously framed and photographed, \u201cLegend of the Mountain\u201d is often a visual ravishment. (It was shot in the South Korean countryside.) There\u2019s a mesmerizing appeal to many of its panoramas, with their variegated colors, dense vegetation and drifting, swirling white mist. And while King Hu certainly likes to move the camera \u2014 it sweeps, swoops and sometime breaks into a near-run \u2014 he also likes to linger on images as if encouraging you to admire their compositional harmony. You can get lost in these pictorial reveries as you trace the rays of light piercing the trees, brightening the dark waters and the reality-softening haze.\n\nDespite being warned away by a stranger, Ho at last makes it to the outpost, where a story of sorts emerges, along with allies and other figures who prove more sinister. Mysterious women (the equally charismatic Hsu Feng and Sylvia Chang) come and go, as does an enigmatic lama (Ng Ming-choi) with an open, cherubic face and splendid yellow vestments. There are digressions and some wonderful visual fillips \u2014 beautifully curved trees and noble stone statues lined up like soldiers. All these attractions are a necessary balm given that Ho turns out to be a deeply uninvolving character (Mr. Shih mostly smiles, grimaces or looks amazed), a wan placeholder for a character in a narratively thin film that runs over three very leisurely hours.\n\nA giant of Chinese cinema, King Hu (1932-1997) is best known for his wuxia films (\u201cA Touch of Zen\u201d), martial arts stories involving heroic deeds, quests, swordplay and the supernatural. \u201cLegend of the Mountain,\u201d a 1979 film that has been restored to the director\u2019s cut, is more wuxia-adjacent though it does feature some fight sequences in which characters go fantastically airborne, defying gravity with bounce and somersaults. Amusingly, the main choice of weapons isn\u2019t swords but drums that opponents beat \u2014 with insistent, galloping fingers \u2014 to create a powerful, mystical sonic force. The drumming is wonderful and suitably hypnotic even if it doesn\u2019t necessarily pull you under the film\u2019s own spell.", "title": "Review: \u2018Legend of the Mountain,\u2019 a Magical Mystery Marathon in Ancient China", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "King Hu"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMark Pellington\u2019s \u201cNostalgia\u201d is the kind of heartfelt wallow that you feel like a heel for attacking. A soggy string of Hallmark moments designed to interrogate the value of the objects we cherish, the movie is front-loaded with major stars and squelching with sentiment. To say it\u2019s depressing, then, is to state the obvious; less evident is why Mr. Pellington, previously known for suspenseful thrillers like \u201cArlington Road\u201d and \u201cThe Mothman Prophecies,\u201d would dive down this rabbit hole at all.\n\nVideo\n\nBeset by a moony piano and maudlin musings about the stuff we carry (\u201cCan what we hold in our hands be the same as what we hold in our hearts?\u201d), the film follows for a time an eye-rollingly empathetic insurance assessor (John Ortiz) as he helps bereaved clients answer that question. A lonely octogenarian (Bruce Dern) prepares for death by taking inventory of his possessions; a distraught widow (Ellen Burstyn) salvages keepsakes from her burned-out home.\n\nPicking up the narrative baton, Jon Hamm takes over as the most softhearted collectibles expert ever. But it\u2019s here, in the movie\u2019s longest section, that this repetitive dirge \u2014 inspired by a 2013 article in The New York Times \u2014 gains thematic heft from exceptionally strong performances. Catherine Keener and James LeGros excel as a grieving couple, and Mikey Madison (riveting as the eldest daughter in FX\u2019s \u201cBetter Things,\u201d) is so moving as Kathleen, a mourning teenager, that we want to give her her own movie.\n\nFascinated by the Portuguese word \u201csaudade,\u201d Kathleen defines it as \u201ca pleasure you suffer, a pain you enjoy.\u201d If that\u2019s what Mr. Pellington was going for, he was half successful.", "title": "Review: \u2018Nostalgia\u2019 Asks Why We Keep Things", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Alex Ross Perry"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "In the second episode of Showtime\u2019s \u201cOur Cartoon President,\u201d Donald Trump (Jeff Bergman) hatches a scheme to get out of disaster-relief appearances: He hires an army of impersonators. He gets the idea while flipping channels on TV and seeing one comedian after another imitate him. His wife, Melania (Cody Lindquist), marvels, \u201cIt\u2019s like everyone is you!\u201d\n\nAnd therein lies a problem. Who, at this point, does not have a Donald Trump? \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d does, and Comedy Central does, and talk shows do, and Johnny Depp does. There are more Trump-branded spoofs, parodies and sendups than there are Trump-branded hotels.\n\nIf you\u2019re going to enter this hall of mirrors, you\u2019d better have a distinct, original idea about your subject. \u201cOur Cartoon President,\u201d an animated sitcom, seems to have none besides being a cartoon about the president.", "title": "Review: \u2018Our Cartoon President\u2019 Misses a Huuuge Target", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Important safety tip: While drinking, do not propose a drastic relationship overhaul to your friends, especially if your advice sounds suspiciously like a screenplay pitch. In \u201cPermission,\u201d a birthday celebration turns awkward when Reece (Morgan Spector) mentions an elephant in the room: Anna (Rebecca Hall), who is turning 30, and Will (Dan Stevens) have only ever gone out with each other. They\u2019re likely to marry, and they\u2019re clearly a perfect, consistent couple \u2014 but aren\u2019t they the least bit curious about what sex with other people is like?\n\nDespite Reece\u2019s apology the next day, the idea sticks, and once agreed to, the swinging experiment pays off with astonishing speed. The roulette wheel of New York City dating is no problem for Will and Anna, even with a lack of practice. On the couple\u2019s first night out, Anna, a music historian whose thesis draft has the mind-melting title \u201cFemale Composers + Feminism \u2013 Matriarchal Pedagogy = Feminist Composers\u201d meets the composer-rocker of her dreams, Dane (Fran\u00e7ois Arnaud). But the series\u2019 revival finds a new one while visiting Cory, a NASCAR-loving Georgia police officer: a Make America Great Again cap.\n\nKaramo Brown, the show\u2019s culture expert, playfully puts the hat on as Bobby Berk, the interior designer, watches slack-jawed. \u201cWe\u2019re all going to make America great again,\u201d Cory says.\n\nThe scene captures how the new \u201cQueer Eye,\u201d now on Netflix, deals with the baggage America has accumulated in its closets since 2003. It doesn\u2019t look away from the new culture clashes. But for the most part, it wears them lightly.\n\nThe original \u201cQueer Eye\u201d was like a stealth mission to straight America\u2019s vanity cabinets, built on the idea of gay men as arbiters of cool. It had its own political context. The fall after its premiere, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled same-sex marriage legal. In the next year\u2019s midterm election, a host of ballot initiatives banning such marriages passed.", "title": "Review: \u2018Queer Eye\u2019 Aims to Make America Gay(-Friendly) Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s not theater.\u201d\n\nSo says the director to the actress. Spoken with jokey reassurance, this disclaimer is delivered in the opening moments of \u201cReturning to Reims,\u201d an all-too timely rumination on working-class disaffection and nationalist politics from the German director Thomas Ostermeier, which opened on Sunday at St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse in Brooklyn.\n\nWhat Paul (Bush Moukarzel), the director, means is that the performer, Katy (Nina Hoss), needn\u2019t worry about fluffing lines. After all, they\u2019re in a studio where she\u2019ll be recording the voice-over for a film by Paul, and mistakes can be erased with the flick of a dial.\n\nBut audiences familiar with the work of Mr. Ostermeier, and his Schaub\u00fchne Berlin company, may hear a different, more confrontational meaning in Paul\u2019s words. Mr. Ostermeier, whose productions of classics like \u201cRichard III\u201d (seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last fall) seemed not so much to push envelopes as to rip them apart, is celebrated for redefining how theater should behave.\n\nBut even his longtime fans are unlikely to be prepared for the seeming noneventfulness of the first half of \u201cReturning to Reims,\u201d adapted from a 2009 memoir by the French philosopher Didier Eribon. Most of what happens during that hour seems to be willfully, even numbingly anti-dramatic.", "title": "Review: \u2018Returning to Reims\u2019 and Those European Working-Class Blues", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe angry art of protest is flourishing these days, and its forms are as myriad as the grievances it gives voice to: marches, rallies, occupations, boycotts, black evening wear for televised awards ceremonies. Then there is the popular retro-disco-circus protest, featuring family-friendly nudity.\n\nWhat? Never heard of that last one?\n\nWell, if it sounds like a communal activity you might want to be involved in (and be warned, it involves pastel spandex and the music of a-ha), then boogie on down to the N.Y.U. Skirball Center in Greenwich Village. There, through Saturday night, a group of acrobats, poets, dancers and one tall drag queen are asking their audience to make love, not war, in an exceedingly cheery revue with the rowdy name \u201cRiot.\u201d\n\nThis rose-colored response to a mean, gray world is the work of Thisispopbaby, a Dublin-based performance troupe that specializes in what might be called agitpop, and is a presentation with the Irish Arts Center. This Hibernian import inflects familiar staples of contemporary entertainment with an Irish accent.\n\nSo dance, whether of the balletic or break varieties, tends to slip, as if by conditioned reflex, into the knee-raising style Americans know from \u201cRiverdance\u201d; a penny whistle is sounded; rap is recited as a Joycean stream-of-consciousness; and a Roman Catholic priest (who would appear to be naked under his robes) shows up, as does his personal savior, Jesus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow if this sounds more impudent than insurrectionist, you should know that the show \u2014 created and directed by Jennifer Jennings and Phillip McMahon \u2014 has grave matters on its mind. Our Gaelic rapper-in-chief, Emmet Kirwan, reels off tongue-tripping spiels that speak of bleak times \u201cthat crave the drop of artistic resistance.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Theater Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest news, interviews and reviews from Broadway and beyond.
