Enjoy yourselves!\u201d", "title": "Review: \u2018Riot\u2019 and the Art of Kitsch as Protest", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The issues arising from the departure of Peter Martins as ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet keep multiplying. What value do Mr. Martins\u2019s own ballets have? For decades his choreography has been an easy punching bag. There were always worse dance makers, but he was singularly prestigious (thanks to his job at City Ballet) while his ballets were seldom interesting.\n\nIf most of his one-acts fell out of repertory, they would not be missed. In an era when the ballet audience needs lures, however, he has given City Ballet three full-length productions that have drawn the throng. In the case of his \u201cSleeping Beauty\u201d and \u201cSwan Lake,\u201d he drew on the work of previous masters.\n\nBut \u201cRomeo + Juliet,\u201d which returned to repertory on Tuesday, is all Martins. (That \u201c+\u201d comes from the 1996 Baz Luhrmann movie.) There are worse versions of \u201cRomeo,\u201d but few so perfunctory or thin. Originally choreographed in 2007, Mr. Martins\u2019s featured an immediately notorious moment \u2014 Lord Capulet audibly slapped his daughter Juliet \u2014 that has now been excised. Instead of the slap, Lord Capulet now merely swipes the air in anger. Amid his several showily blustering gestures, this one is scarcely noticeable.\n\nWhat remains, however, is the gruesome way Romeo kills Tybalt. What on earth impelled Mr. Martins to make Romeo suddenly wrap Tybalt\u2019s head in his cloak and stab him repeatedly in the back? Any \u201cRomeo\u201d abounds in fights and deaths, but this incident remains among the most gratuitously unpleasant. It also robs Romeo of audience sympathy.", "title": "Review: \u2018Romeo + Juliet,\u2019 a Movielike Ballet in Need of Better Direction", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "If you haven\u2019t seen the lawyer Gloria Allred on television \u2014 a distinct impossibility \u2014 she now appears on movie screens in \u201cSeeing Allred,\u201d a documentary that\u2019s remarkably engaging despite treating its rough-and-tumble hero with kid gloves.\n\nMs. Allred, who specializes in women\u2019s rights cases, has represented many of those who have accused influential men (including Bill Cosby, Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski) of sexual assault, discrimination or other crimes. Though she also handles lower-profile cases, she\u2019s best known for sitting with clients behind banks of microphones, or standing in front of cameras at protests and marches.\n\nSuch images have given her a reputation as a grandstander and media manipulator. She counters that her methods hold powerful figures accountable and provide their often-silenced victims with a voice, \u201ceven if they can\u2019t have justice in the conventional setting of a court of law.\u201d", "title": "Review: \u2018Seeing Allred\u2019 Watches a Pit-Bull Lawyer at Work", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere is a quiet, noble experiment going on with the Metropolitan Opera\u2019s first revival in 25 years of Rossini\u2019s \u201cSemiramide,\u201d which opened on Monday and runs through March 17.\n\nThe Met has lately embraced bel canto works it long ignored \u2014 \u201cAnna Bolena,\u201d \u201cLa Sonnambula,\u201d \u201cLa Donna del Lago,\u201d \u201cArmida,\u201d \u201cGuillaume Tell,\u201d \u201cLe Comte Ory\u201d \u2014 and has even made hits out of them. But it has done so almost invariably with stars to anchor the productions. Ren\u00e9e Fleming, Anna Netrebko, Natalie Dessay, Joyce DiDonato, Juan Diego Fl\u00f3rez, Diana Damrau: These are the kind of names who have tended to bring operas by Rossini, Donizetti and Bellini to the Met.\n\nThere\u2019s no one on that level of renown in this \u201cSemiramide.\u201d So the question is: Can one of the grand, stylized ocean liners of early-19th-century opera flourish \u2014 can the Met, with 4,000 seats to fill and an audience raised with a great-performers fetish, survive \u2014 with a cast that isn\u2019t particularly glamorous but is, merely, excellent?\n\nThe ticket sales are not, so far, inspiring, but the performance often is.\n\nBased on a Voltaire tragedy of ancient Babylon with nods to \u201cHamlet\u201d and \u201cOedipus,\u201d the plot is a heady mixture of romantic intrigue and jockeying for power that unfolds in a sprawling pageant of arias and duets. In the title role of the queen who murders her husband and unwittingly tries to marry her son, the soprano Angela Meade gives her gutsiest Met performance since \u201cNorma\u201d in 2013, her coloratura fireworks amplifying her pride, guilt and fear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven with 45 minutes cut from the score, this is a long opera \u2014 the conductor Maurizio Benini led a crisp, clear rendition that nevertheless struggled to find variety in the 105-minute first act \u2014 and a long part. But if Semiramide seems to tire Ms. Meade no more than it did when she coolly dazzled in it at Caramoor in 2009, her tone has shed the overly pearled sheen it had then; its silver is now warmer.\n\nAs Arsace, the Assyrian commander whom Semiramide chooses to marry before learning she is his mother, the mezzo-soprano Elizabeth DeShong has her first really major turn at the Met, which hasn\u2019t seemed to know what to do with her talent. Her voice is more clarinet than trumpet, but it\u2019s agile, even and velvety.\n\nJavier Camarena continues a brilliant run of bel canto performances in New York. Rossini tenors have often been caricatured as pinched and nasal \u2014 you try to hit those high notes! \u2014 but Mr. Camarena is melting and nuanced, clarion in coloratura, his sound sunny and earnest. There\u2019s no one better.", "title": "Review: \u2018Semiramide\u2019 Returns to the Met, Unglamorous but Excellent", "authors": ["Zachary Woolfe"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSeven Seconds\u201d is a crime story in which you know immediately who did it. Pete Jablonski (Beau Knapp), a Jersey City police officer, is driving through a park on the way to the hospital to meet his pregnant wife, when he hits something. Or someone, it turns out: There\u2019s a bicycle in the snow, and a trail of blood.\n\nIn shock, Pete calls Michael DiAngelo (David Lyons), his sergeant in his narcotics unit, who finds the victim: an African-American teenage boy. They have to cover it up, DiAngelo says. Otherwise, he adds, Pete will be crucified, payback for \u201cFerguson, Chicago, Baltimore \u2014 every white cop who ever killed a black kid.\u201d\n\nThe boy is in a deep coma. We never hear him speak, see only a few glimpses of him taking his last bike ride. But we hear his name again and again: Brenton Butler, which hangs over the story like others \u2014 Tamir Rice, Freddie Gray \u2014 that have become totems and rallying cries.\n\nThe cover-up leads inexorably to further crimes. But the true mystery in \u201cSeven Seconds\u201d is, Will Brenton get justice? What would justice look like? And how many other lives will be destroyed in the wake of Brenton\u2019s?", "title": "Review: \u2018Seven Seconds,\u2019 a Grim Account of Whose Lives Matter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "What happens next is tawdry, predictable, queasy-making and also frequently funny, though not for the Swensons. Mr. Tucci is the most unflappable of actors, which makes Ted\u2019s inevitable and dramatic flapping all the more terrible and amusing to witness. He is a charming guy, to be sure, but also smug and self-pitying. Whether or not he entirely deserves what he eventually gets, his complacency and passivity set him up for a fall.\n\nBut \u201cSubmission\u201d isn\u2019t just his story. Angela is in many ways more interesting, even though, at the end, her motives are flattened in the interest of a narrative payoff. Ted is taken with her writing, and also with her na\u00efve, admiring eagerness for his approval. She writes about sex with older men, in her novel and in an earlier book of poems, in a way that seems calculated to trigger inappropriate fantasies in the mind of a creatively frustrated, self-consciously aging teacher marooned in academia.\n\nTed is an easy mark, and hardly an unwilling participant in his own ruin. He is less pathetic than the professor played by Emil Jannings in Josef von Sternberg\u2019s \u201cThe Blue Angel\u201d (which serves as both a model for \u201cSubmission\u201d and point of reference within it), and Angela is hardly a siren in the mold of Marlene Dietrich\u2019s cabaret singer. But Angela does turn out to be amoral, manipulative and dishonest, traits that make her both a caricature of feminine guile and a promising fiction writer \u2014 perhaps more fully committed to the art than her vain, bumbling teacher.\n\nUnfortunately, Mr. Levine, directing his second feature after working mainly in television (on \u201cMasters of Sex\u201d and \u201cNip/Tuck,\u201d among other series), is a lesser artist than Ms. Prose. \u201cSubmission\u201d feels more like an act of devotion, or perhaps of submission, than a free-standing adaptation. The satire is cautious and the emotions restrained, so that what should be a swirl of lust, ambition, recrimination and bureaucratic absurdity rises only to genteel, nervous laughter and mild discomfort. The actors all do their best \u2014 Ms. Timlin manages the difficult trick of switching back and forth between innocence and its opposite \u2014 but a crucial element of intensity is missing. By the end, the stakes seem trivial, even though families and livelihoods are in play and big ideas hover in the background.\n\nCan a movie be provocatively timid? Clumsy and coy at the same time? The more you think about \u201cSubmission,\u201d the less relevant it looks. Which may represent a pyrrhic kind of vindication. There\u2019s nothing here that\u2019s really worth arguing about.", "title": "Review: \u2018Submission\u2019 Plunges Into a Campus Sex Scandal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTehran Taboo\u201d gains much of its power from its use of rotoscoping, a form of animation (familiar to viewers of \u201cWaking Life\u201d and \u201cTower\u201d) in which the drawing is done over filmed actors. What is provocative about the technique here is that it\u2019s a sort of workaround \u2014 a way for the director, Ali Soozandeh, who grew up in Iran and now lives in Germany, to tell a story that he says would have been impossible to film in Tehran.\n\nAn ensemble piece (and European production, despite the Persian dialogue), the movie lays bare the double standards that surround sex in Iran. Its confrontational quality is established in the opening scene: A driver picks up a prostitute who is turning tricks with her young son in tow \u2014 and moments later expresses horror when he spots a man holding hands with his daughter.", "title": "Review: \u2018Tehran Taboo\u2019 Exposes Double Standards About Sex in Iran", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "This is only in part so that Mr. Harrison, who now appears as a character onstage, can connect the dots between the Black Death and AIDS. The detour also allows him to delay the return trip down the mountain of plot he has spent the first half of the play climbing. What Mr. Harrison, the character, says he is avoiding is the very object of that trek: the play\u2019s catharsis, which he doubts he can earn. In a world of endless suffering, a catharsis is \u201cinnately complacent,\u201d he concludes.\n\nLike the rest of \u201cThe Amateurs,\u201d this despairing contemporary interlude is frantically funny, even when it veers into an art history lecture. Playing Mr. Harrison, Michael Cyril Creighton, who in the medieval scenes is handy Gregory, paints a witty, affectionate portrait of a neurotic playwright afraid of his own tools. It can\u2019t be a realistic portrait; Mr. Harrison could hardly wield those tools so expertly if his hands were shaking. As in his 2015 play \u201cMarjorie Prime\u201d \u2014 a superbly controlled exercise in speculative fiction that elicits profound feeling without appearing to solicit it \u2014 \u201cThe Amateurs\u201d works by a kind of indirection. The magic happens, by design, wherever the playwright isn\u2019t pointing.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo the postmodern gewgaws are a bit of a decoy. They might work even better if there were fewer of them, as Mr. Harrison seems to know. (\u201cHopefully you aren\u2019t allergic to these sorts of shenanigans,\u201d his stand-in says.) When Ms. Bernstine interrupts his interruption with her own take on Hollis\u2019s story, you begin to wonder whether the material has gone a bit too deep into the theatrical weeds, too far for civilians to follow. But just as she did in Anne Washburn\u2019s heady backstager \u201c10 out of 12,\u201d Ms. Bernstine, so legible and relatable and seemingly guileless, grounds even the most meta material with quiet feeling.\n\nStill, I kept thinking that a fully cooked play shouldn\u2019t need so much exegesis and counterpoint. It didn\u2019t seem likely that Mr. Harrison\u2019s self-parodying seminar, however amusing, could deepen the play\u2019s action when it returned to medieval Italy. Eventually, though, I understood that deepening wasn\u2019t the point; distancing was. \u201cThe Amateurs\u201d wants to be seen with a form of double vision in which the past and the present are both present. We are meant to be vigilant about the \u201cluxury of fiction,\u201d with its false sense of endings.\n\nWhich is why these medieval actors all have names you might expect to find on a teen soap opera. At every turn, Oliver Butler\u2019s gutsy production supports rather than tries to disguise such anachronisms. The singsong verse of the morality plays is countered by ribald cross talk delivered with naturalistic verve. And whenever the troupe\u2019s pageant wagon \u2014 a cabinet of curiosities filled with handmade surprises \u2014 sits in the middle of the Vineyard\u2019s modern stage (both designed by David Zinn) you see in one image the continuity of human creativity in the face of disaster.\n\nThe cast, which also includes Greg Keller as a newcomer to the troupe, is a cabinet of curiosities in itself, a collection of Off Broadway treasures. Of course, all actors love to re-enact theatrical disaster stories, and Mr. Harrison loads \u201cThe Amateurs\u201d with plenty of gags. But Ms. Bernstine and the others are seriously funny, by which I mean funny in a serious way: a good thing in a play that has so much on its mind. Among the themes that light up like fireflies here and there are the nature of sin, the purpose of art, the low status of actors and the low status of humans in general. If history has been a drama, it has consigned almost everyone throughout time to the chorus.\n\nAnd so it really is a thrilling, expansive, world-changing moment in a very sneaky play when Hollis, contemplating Mrs. Noah, first asks, What\u2019s my motivation? Which is a question you can only begin to contemplate after asking, What is God\u2019s?\n\nThe Amateurs NYT Critic\u2019s Pick Vineyard Theater 108 E. 15th St. Flatiron/U. Sq. 212-353-0303 vineyardtheatre.org Category Off Broadway, Play, Comedy/Drama Runtime 1 hr. and 30 min. Credits Written by Jordan Harrison; Directed by Oliver Butler Cast Kyle Beltran, Quincy Tyler Bernstine, Michael Cyril Creighton, Greg Keller, Jennifer Kim and Thomas Jay Ryan Preview February 8, 2018 Opened February 27, 2018 Closing Date March 29, 2018 This information was last updated: March 29, 2018", "title": "Review: \u2018The Amateurs\u2019 Takes On God, Noah\u2019s Ark and the Plague. For Laughs.", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "In \u201cThe Boy Downstairs,\u201d a debut feature from the writer and director Sophie Brooks, not only do Diana and Ben live in the same brownstone, but Ben is also dating Meg, the real estate agent who showed Diana the apartment. Meg (Sarah Ramos) is a former good friend of Diana\u2019s bestie, Gabby (Diana Irvine). And Brooklyn has a fourth resident, Amy (Deirdre O\u2019Connell), a kind landlord who is always there to provide wise counsel to Diana \u2014 an aspiring writer, of course.\n\nHow, and in whose apartment, Diana and Ben will confess their emotions is the subject of Ms. Brooks\u2019s pallid dramedy, which leaves its actors looking somewhat stranded, as if waiting for Neil Simon zingers that were never written. It doesn\u2019t matter that there\u2019s little suspense to the central romance (Ben and Diana still obviously have feelings for each other); people don\u2019t always resolve their confusion in real time. That\u2019s roughly the speed, however, at which \u201cThe Boy Downstairs\u201d seems to play.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Boy Downstairs\u2019 Provides a Twist of Fate for Zosia Mamet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The mission, which she of course joins, involves firing up a particle collider, to solve a global food and power crisis. One scene shows a worried author (Donal Logue) warning that the collider could open up alternate realities that in turn could unleash giant beasts of unknown origin on our world. Hmm.\n\nAfter multiple failures, the mission succeeds. But not in a good way. Earth disappears from the station\u2019s view, providing a novel existential crisis for the space dwellers. Horrific human screams come from behind a space station wall; inside, inexplicably, is a woman with wires and cables running through her bleeding body. (This imagery brought to mind the 1989 movie \u201cTetsuo: The Iron Man\u201d \u2014 like the other \u201cCloverfield\u201d movies, this one makes multiple nods to sci-fi and horror forebears.) Once healed, the character, Jensen (Elizabeth Debicki), reveals herself as the kind of Enigmatic Pale Person filmgoers tend to associate with Tilda Swinton. She informs Ava that they are best friends, although Ava doesn\u2019t know her at all. It becomes clear that the collider has indeed caused reality to jump perhaps several dimensional tracks.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Cloverfield Paradox,\u2019 Netflix\u2019s Surprise Release, Unleashes Chaos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The western is still dead, but zombie movies are anything but. The last 15 years have given us \u201c28 Days Later\u201d and its sequel; a remake of \u201cDawn of the Dead\u201d; the parodies \u201cShaun of the Dead\u201d and \u201cZombieland\u201d; three genre entries from the \u201cNight of the Living Dead\u201d auteur George A. Romero, who has since gone to the grave himself; the TV series \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d and \u201cFear the Walking Dead\u201d; and the zombie-adjacent \u201cMaze Runner\u201d movies.\n\nAnyone digging through the cemetery soil again had better have fresh ideas. \u201cThe Cured,\u201d the debut feature from David Freyne, has roughly two.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Cured,\u2019 in Which Former Zombies Turn to New Terrorism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRomantic comedy conventions get a brain scan in this new movie directed by the comedian Whitney Cummings. Ms. Cummings also stars as Dr. Julia Brizendine, a newly divorced neuroscientist who observes brain activity as a way to study gender. While Julia uses work to dodge dating, her long-married study subjects, Lisa (Sof\u00eda Vergara) and Steven (Deon Cole) have become more platonic than romantic. In Julia\u2019s other case studies, Lexi (Lucy Punch) can\u2019t stop nit-picking her boyfriend, Adam (James Marsden), and Zoe (Cecily Strong) has let professional stress seep into her marriage to a basketball player, Greg ( Blake Griffin of the Detroit Pistons.)\n\nVideo\n\nAs the couples stumble through their daily frustrations, the film occasionally pauses to overlay a brain chart on the action, lighting up the glands and lobes Julia deems responsible for their behaviors. According to Julia\u2019s funny phrenology, Lexi criticizes Adam\u2019s hair and skin because her pituitary gland releases endorphins when she grooms, and Lisa adjusts a dangling bedroom mirror because her amygdala registers fear faster than Steven\u2019s.\n\n\u201cThe Female Brain\u201d is a fictionalized adaptation of a nonfiction book of the same title by the neuropsychiatrist Louann Brizendine. Armed with scientific conviction, the movie pits men\u2019s minds against women\u2019s with no room for overlap, and no room for those identities that exist outside the male and female categories. With tender performances and dubious conclusions, this story is best appreciated as an explanation for why people seek out the false comfort of gendered pseudoscience. But by fitting characters into formulas, \u201cThe Female Brain\u201d fails to observe the flexibility of human experience.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Female Brain\u2019 Flattens the Female Experience", "authors": ["Teo Bugbee", "Neal Brennan", "Louann Brizendine", "Whitney Cummings"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Based on the first three episodes of \u201cThe Looming Tower\u201d (which begin streaming on Wednesday), Mr. Wright, working with the writer Dan Futterman and the director Alex Gibney, has reduced the story to that other 20 percent.\n\nThe result is a crisp, quickly paced and essentially ordinary crime procedural, with a surprising amount of fictionalization for dramatic effect and narrative convenience. The show reverses the balance of perspective from the book: A pair of F.B.I. agents, John O\u2019Neill (Jeff Daniels) and Ali Soufan (Tahar Rahim), replace bin Laden and Zawahri as the central characters, and the point of view is firmly American.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe series opens with a standard espionage thriller scene, the clandestine daisy-chain transport of a computer hard drive, that doesn\u2019t appear in the book, where Mr. Wright is matter-of-fact in his descriptions of spycraft. Other inventions are more problematic. A hookup between an F.B.I. agent and an American diplomat (both fictitious) is thrown in just to squeeze some tears. And a heroic act that in real life was performed by a dying Kenyan, during the 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi, is shifted to a dying American.\n\nCutting out 50 years of the story and most of the cast of characters (the book begins in the 1940s with the Egyptian writer Sayyid Qutb; the show skips decades of Arab history and opens in 1998) allows more time for fiction-friendly details. In the book, Mr. Wright gives a few pages to the Mr. O\u2019Neill\u2019s byzantine romantic life, as a counterpoint to Islamist attitudes toward women and sex. This gets a fuller, but (so far) less relevant treatment on screen.\n\n\u201cThe Looming Tower\u201d is not alone in favoring a detective story over ideas and import. \u201cManhunt: Unabomber,\u201d \u201cUnsolved: The Murders of Tupac and the Notorious B.I.G.\u201d and \u201cWaco,\u201d to cite current or recent examples, all do it to some degree. (Though Paramount Network\u2019s \u201cWaco\u201d has gained depth in its later episodes, with the Branch Davidians captive inside their compound.)\n\n\u201cThe Looming Tower\u201d does benefit from good performances, including those of Mr. Rahim, Peter Sarsgaard as a querulous C.I.A. agent (seemingly based on the real-life Michael Scheuer) and Bill Camp as an F.B.I. gumshoe (a composite of New York-based agents). Mr. Daniels is fun to watch, but his Midwestern affability and natural courtliness don\u2019t match up at all with the book\u2019s description of O\u2019Neill. (He\u2019s also 15-plus years older than O\u2019Neill was at the time.)\n\nIn 2018, \u201cThe Looming Tower\u201d sits in an odd place. So much has happened since the events it depicts that it feels like ancient history. But so much has happened \u2014 and continues to happen \u2014 precisely because of the events it depicts, that the book now feels unequal to its task. Perhaps turning it into a sentimental cop show was the only sensible approach.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Looming Tower\u2019 Looks at 9/11, but Misses the Big Picture", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt isn\u2019t easy to stand out these days in the ranks of half-hour personal dramedies, where shows like \u201cBetter Things,\u201d \u201cInsecure\u201d and \u201cAtlanta\u201d are among the best and most challenging series on television.\n\n\u201cThis Close,\u201d streaming on Sundance Now beginning Wednesday, isn\u2019t at those shows\u2019 level \u2014 it\u2019s more conventional, with familiar relationship and family situations, and it doesn\u2019t really have a distinct sensibility. But it\u2019s funny and poignant in ways we haven\u2019t seen before, and more deftly directed and impressively cast than you\u2019d expect for an original series on a small streaming service. It\u2019s also, at six episodes totaling about 150 minutes, an easy binge.\n\nThe deaf actors Josh Feldman and Shoshannah Stern created and wrote \u201cThis Close,\u201d expanding on an earlier no-budget online series called \u201cFridays.\u201d They also star in it as Michael and Kate, best friends living in Los Angeles. Michael is a gay artist in a downward spiral after a breakup, blocked on his graphic novel and often drunk; Kate is a snarkily funny spitfire who works at a public-relations firm and is engaged to a hearing man, Danny (Zach Gilford), who hasn\u2019t told her that he lost his job.\n\nMichael and Kate are also deaf, a fact that is both secondary and central to the show. The questions are universal: Will Kate and Danny find a way to trust each other? Will Michael and his ex, Ryan (Colt Prattes), get back together? Will Michael meet his deadline? But deafness is the inescapable context of each story line, amplifying and complicating the characters\u2019 pain. Being shut out and lied to, as Kate is by Danny, is an even greater betrayal when communicating with the world is your daily struggle.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Feldman and Ms. Stern get their points across in mostly low-key and cleverly comic ways, with an occasional slide into heavy-handedness, usually involving Danny, who\u2019s awfully clueless even by the low standards contemporary dramedies tend to set for straight white boyfriends.", "title": "Review: \u2018This Close,\u2019 a Serious Comedy About Life and Deafness", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Set in 1906 and inspired by actual events (liberally sauced with myth and legend), the story centers on the eccentric Sarah Winchester (Ms. Mirren, grimly determined), heiress to the rifle fortune and eager dabbler in architecture and spiritualism. Believing that she has flourished on the deaths caused by her late husband\u2019s invention, Sarah atones by constructing a vast and ever-changing mansion, whose hundreds of rooms are intended to imprison evil spirits or encourage benign ones to move on.\n\nEnter Dr. Price (Jason Clarke), a psychologist hired by the Winchester company\u2019s board to count Sarah\u2019s marbles and report back. Conveniently addicted to laudanum, Dr. Price is soon staggering around the labyrinthine structure, besieged by generic scares: a creepy butler, a rattling armoire, a child in the grip of milky-eyed possession. The Hogwarts-like domicile might be swarming with staff and construction workers, but not until Price arrives do the spirits hit the fan.\n\nWritten by the Spierigs and Tom Vaughan, the script is as batty and clich\u00e9d as its heroine. The house (you can take a tour of the real one in San Jose, Calif.) never feels like a single space, as ho-hum apparitions appear and disappear without a trace. Ms. Mirren and her representatives are probably hoping the movie will do likewise.", "title": "Review: \u2018Winchester\u2019 Has a Grim Helen Mirren. And a Silly Script.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nPHILADELPHIA \u2014 \u201cWritten on Skin,\u201d an opera about the creation of an illuminated manuscript, isn\u2019t an open book. At my first live encounter with this 2012 work at the Academy of Music here on Friday, for the premiere of a new staging by Opera Philadelphia that runs through Feb. 18, I was struck by how reserved George Benjamin\u2019s score is.\n\nNot that there aren\u2019t passages of loud density or idiosyncratic instrumentation \u2014 a typewriter, pebbles, sets of small tablas and glass harmonica augment the traditional orchestra \u2014 but on the whole the music gives the sense of being artfully curbed. It\u2019s as though \u201cPell\u00e9as et M\u00e9lisande\u201d or \u201cWozzeck\u201d had been partly quieted, even half-vaporized, their roiling energies kept \u2014 and sometimes not \u2014 at bay.\n\nWill Kerley\u2019s stage direction in Philadelphia amplifies this impression of reticence concealing glinting, surging colors. The set, designed by Tom Rogers, is a giant gray box that rotates on a turntable and reveals, as doors open and walls push aside, a labyrinth of shifting spaces: raw wood incompletely painted a radiant blue and studded with panels with the jewel tones of stained glass.\n\nThis is the home of a married couple in medieval times. The wife (referred to sometimes as the Woman, sometimes as Agn\u00e8s) is restive; the husband (the Protector), controlling. Commenting on and guiding the action from our own moment, and dressed in this staging in futuristic, Sprockets-style black, is a trio of angels, vaguely sinister in its affectlessness. One of them doubles as the Boy, who enters the household under commission to depict the Protector\u2019s dominion in images and letters.\n\nPhoto\n\nRepresenting the world in art is portrayed by Mr. Benjamin and the librettist, the playwright Martin Crimp, as a complex, empowering, exposing, explosive, inevitably destructive enterprise. (Their next opera, \u201cLessons in Love and Violence,\u201d has its premiere in London in May.) Her mind fired with new possibilities, Agn\u00e8s begins an affair with the Boy. When they\u2019re discovered \u2014 the Protector, of course, reads about it in the book \u2014 he is murdered and she, after a cannibalistic climax that suggests \u201cSalome\u201d and \u201cTitus Andronicus,\u201d kills herself. A coda reflects on the angels\u2019 \u201ccold fascination with human disaster.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA story about a woman\u2019s defiant emergence into selfhood and her repression by a brutal husband obviously resonates differently now than it did just a year ago. But the detached, enigmatic text keeps our sympathies distant, and implicates our own fascination with disaster as much as it does the patriarchy it shows in action. We perceive onstage not personalities but vivid puppets, drawn to their doom by forces outside themselves.", "title": "Review: \u2018Written on Skin,\u2019 an Opera of Love, Betrayal and a Little Cannibalism", "authors": ["Zachary Woolfe"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "MICHAEL HOFACRE\n\nWEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF.\n\nThe writer is a film editor.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cComing to Terms With Woody Allen\u201d (Arts pages, Feb. 1):\n\nI\u2019m a great admirer of A. O. Scott\u2019s film reviews and commentary, but his argument for reappraising Woody Allen in light of renewed allegations of abuse by his adopted daughter strikes me as weak and somewhat pandering.\n\nMr. Allen may or may not deserve his latest brush with notoriety. But dogged investigation into the accusations against him by child sexual abuse experts \u2014 along with the refusal of the Connecticut state prosecutor to pursue the case \u2014 suggests that the filmmaker isn\u2019t ever likely to be tried, except in the court of public opinion, which is already happening.\n\nLet the actors who no longer want to work with him not do so. Let the moviegoers who no longer want to see his pictures \u2014 or never wanted to in the first place \u2014 stay home. But the notion that we should now rethink his entire body of work \u2014 one that contains its share of clunkers as well as more than a few genuine masterpieces \u2014 is the worst form of historical revisionism.\n\nWhile we\u2019re at it, why not revisit Alfred Hitchcock or Elia Kazan, both of whom had something in their histories that is troubling? Just as bad art is sometimes made by good people, good art can be and often is the product of imperfect people. We throw out all the alleged rascals at our peril.\n\nWAYNE J. GUGLIELMO, MAHWAH, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWoody Allen Takes a Hit in the Wrath of #MeToo\u201d (Arts pages, Jan. 29):\n\nThe #MeToo movement is all about listening to women\u2019s voices rather than ignoring or invalidating victims of sexual misconduct. That is a change worth fighting for. But Dylan Farrow was listened to 25 years ago. In fact, she has had the singularly exceptional attention of two separate teams of experts on child abuse from two states who devoted months to investigating Woody Allen on her behalf. They found no reason to charge Mr. Allen.", "title": "Opinion | Reviewing the Case of Woody Allen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere is a truism that a great novel cannot provide the basis for a great \u2014 or even a very good \u2014 movie. If so, the 1999 Ra\u00fal Ruiz film, \u201cTime Regained,\u201d adapted from the last volume of Proust\u2019s \u201cIn Search of Lost Time,\u201d is an exception that proves the rule.\n\nShowing for a week in a new digital restoration as part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center\u2019s second Ruiz retrospective, \u201cTime Regained\u201d is as close as Ruiz, the Chilean-born filmmaker who died in 2011, came to making the kind of entertainment that used to be called a \u201cmovie movie.\u201d\n\nAs omnipresent as Proust\u2019s narrator, the camera insinuates itself among the glamorous cast. Catherine Deneuve plays the former courtesan Odette de Crecy, with Emmanuelle B\u00e9art as her daughter Gilberte. Ms. Deneuve\u2019s actual daughter, Chiara Mastroianni, has a cameo as the elusive Albertine. Marie-France Pisier trills her way through the film as the social climbing Madame Verdurin. Pascal Greggory and John Malkovich also have juicy roles, as Gilberte\u2019s unfaithful husband and the cheerfully depraved Baron de Charlus.\n\nPhoto\n\nStanding in for the book\u2019s unnamed narrator is the little-known Italian actor Marcello Mazzarella, made up here with a dapper mustache and kohl-rimmed eyes to resemble Proust. He is referred to as \u201cMarcel\u201d and, in his outsize hat and overly large coat, cuts an almost Chaplinesque figure \u2014 an obvious outsider in this ostentatiously glittering ensemble.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRuiz\u2019s film has no particular plot. Or, rather, there are many. Proust\u2019s \u201cTime Regained\u201d postscripts the action of his novel\u2019s six preceding volumes. The narrator revisits past events and, in effect, explains how the entire work came into being. The movie opens with Marcel on his deathbed, imagining his novel. His recent return to Paris is much on his mind. World War I is raging as he re-encounters his old social circle, attends their soirees and observes their affairs. People are recalled at various ages; the writer is watched in memories by his childhood self.", "title": "Revived and Still Luxurious: Ra\u00fal Ruiz\u2019s Search for Proust", "authors": ["J. Hoberman"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "European diplomats said there was scope for an agreement on missiles and inspections, but not yet on the length of the deal. They argue that rewriting those terms would break the bargain they struck, not only with Iran but also with Russia and China, two other signatories. And breaching the deal, they say, would free Iran to pursue nuclear weapons again.\n\nThe upcoming talks are being led by Brian H. Hook, a low-key Republican lawyer who is the State Department\u2019s director of policy planning, who has said he would bring the European request for a guarantee back to Washington. European diplomats said they worry that Mr. Trump\u2019s scorn for the deal runs so deep that he would find other reasons to pull out. Last month, he warned that the accord \u201cis under continuous review, and our participation can be canceled by me as president at any time.\u201d\n\nEven if Mr. Trump did pledge to abide by the deal, it is far from clear that a successor deal would be endorsed by Russia or China, let alone the Iranians, who signaled in recent weeks that they are planning a new project \u2014 a fleet of nuclear-powered ships, fueled by Iranian-made reactors \u2014 that they say would justify resuming the production of nuclear fuel as the limits imposed by the deal expire over the next dozen years.\n\nStill, the mere fact that the United States and Europe are trying to work out a compromise attests to the desire, on both sides, to find a solution that would satisfy Mr. Trump while not unraveling the deal.\n\nThe president\u2019s national security team \u2014 Mr. Tillerson, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, and the national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster \u2014 has on three occasions talked him out of ripping up the deal. With each deadline to reimpose sanctions on Iran, that task gets harder.\n\nThere is an element of diplomatic legerdemain to the exercise, European diplomats acknowledge: How do you convince Mr. Trump that you have changed the deal without actually changing it?\n\n\u201cThe supplemental deal is a diplomatic device that is being used to allow the Europeans to declare victory,\u201d said Mark Dubowitz, a leading critic of the Iran deal who is nevertheless open to the idea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey can say they were able to keep the deal, remain steadfast to their commitment not to renegotiate it, but also to satisfy the U.S. and their own concerns that the length of the deal was too short,\u201d said Mr. Dubowitz, the chief executive of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies.\n\nBy law, Mr. Trump must decide every 120 days whether to continue suspending longstanding American economic sanctions against Tehran, which the United States committed to lift as part of the deal. If he were to reimpose them, as he has threatened, that would effectively scuttle the deal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIran complains that Mr. Trump\u2019s threats have already kept European banks from investing in major projects in Iran, denying it the benefits that were promised for giving up its enrichment program.\n\n\u201cIf the same policy of confusion and uncertainties over the future of the deal continue,\u201d Iran\u2019s deputy foreign minister, Abbas Araqchi, who was a member of the negotiating team, said last week, \u201cif companies and banks are not working with Iran, we cannot remain in a deal that has no benefit for us.\u201d\n\nThe International Atomic Energy Agency said last week that it had received formal notice from Tehran about a \u201cdecision that has been taken to construct naval nuclear propulsion in future.\u201d\n\nNothing in the 2015 agreement prohibits the construction of nuclear reactors to power ships and submarines, and those reactors would almost certainly not use nuclear-weapons-grade fuel. But they could provide a pretext for Iran to resume uranium enrichment.\n\nThe Europeans are most comfortable with enforcing new limits on Iran\u2019s intercontinental ballistic missile development and testing. Missiles are not covered by the nuclear accord, but rather by a United Nations resolution, whose wording was negotiated by then-Secretary of State John Kerry just as the nuclear accord was coming together in Vienna in July 2015.\n\nThe State Department\u2019s talking points said the United States viewed the nuclear and missile programs as \u201cinseparable,\u201d and said that \u201cIran\u2019s development and testing of missiles should be subject to severe sanctions.\u201d The Europeans have not gone that far, at least yet.\n\nInspections are potentially more problematic, given the administration\u2019s rejection of arguments by the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps that all military-related sites are off limits to international inspectors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut this has not been an issue yet: The inspections have been limited to declared nuclear sites, and the United Nations nuclear agency affirmed last week that it had been given all the access it sought. Inspectors have said they would try to inspect military sites only if they had intelligence suggesting that surreptitious nuclear activity was underway.\n\nOnce a deal is struck with the Europeans, administration officials intend to seek approval from Russia, China and Iran. But concerns that such a deal could not possibly pass muster with Iran will not deter them, a senior official said. Russia and China\u2019s lack of participation would also matter little, given the stark consequences for Iran\u2019s economy if Europe and the United States reimpose sanctions, this person said.\n\nWhile American and European negotiators are working feverishly on a deal to preserve the 2015 accord, there are also preliminary discussions about what will happen if they fall short.\n\nReimposing sanctions, such as blacklisting the Central Bank of Iran, would cause serious problems for European companies, potentially precipitating a split in the trans-Atlantic alliance. But the president, Mr. Dubowitz noted, has the authority to phase in sanctions, which he could use as leverage to give negotiators more time to work out an agreement.\n\nHe could, for example, impose sanctions on the central bank for its support of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, which is accused of supporting terrorism, but waive the imposition of so-called secondary sanctions on foreign companies that do business with the bank until the next deadline in July.\n\nFor the Europeans, who are mostly satisfied with the deal and face no domestic political pressure to pull out, there is little joy in this exercise. But they feel they have no choice but to go along with it. One diplomat compared it to humoring an angry relative who controlled a family vacation estate, and periodically threatened to burn it down.", "title": "Rewrite Iran Deal? Europeans Offer a Different Solution: A New Chapter", "authors": ["Mark Landler", "David E. Sanger", "Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 For the first time in the 116-year history of the Rhodes scholarship, students from anywhere in the world \u2014 even Britain \u2014 can now qualify for the award to study at Oxford University, the Rhodes Trust announced on Monday.\n\nThe news culminates a multiyear push by the trust to raise money from philanthropists, expand the number of scholarships and broaden the program \u2014 which until recently was limited to a fairly short list of countries \u2014 into something global. The result is far removed from the legacy of Cecil Rhodes, a South African diamond magnate and devoted British imperialist who saw the scholarships he endowed as very much an Anglo-Saxon and male privilege.\n\n\u201cIf we believe in our mission to find incredibly talented people who will change the world for the better, they\u2019re just as likely to be found in Indonesia as in Ohio,\u201d said Charles R. Conn, the chief executive of the trust and warden of Rhodes House at Oxford. \u201cWe don\u2019t feel constrained by who Rhodes was as a person, but perhaps each Rhodes scholar needs to reflect on that when they accept the money.\u201d\n\nWhen Rhodes died in 1902, he left instructions and money in his will for more than 50 students from a few current or former British possessions to study at Oxford, and five scholarships were soon allocated for German students. From the start, some scholarships were set aside for students from southern Africa, but for decades all of the recipients from those countries were white.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor generations, as the scholarships became among the most prestigious in the world, countries were added to the list gradually \u2014 British possessions, or former ones, in Africa and Asia, though some were later removed. Women were not eligible until the 1970s, students from some countries that were never part of the empire were first included in the 1990s, and British students have never qualified.", "title": "Rhodes Scholarships Go Global as Students From Anywhere Now Qualify", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Hamantaschen, the triangular pastries for Purim (which starts next Wednesday), are usually filled with prune, apricot or poppy seeds. This year, they are getting the chocolate treatment at By the Way Bakery, a small chain that makes gluten-free, dairy-free pastries, cakes and breads. By the Way\u2019s hamantaschen have a creamy dark chocolate center enclosed in rich chocolate pastry. They\u2019re available, along with the traditional jam-filled pastries, now through March 4 for pick up at the shops: Chocolate hamantaschen, $3 each, $15 for a bag of six, By the Way Bakery with locations on the Upper East and Upper West Sides of Manhattan, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Greenwich, Conn., btwbakery.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. In Syria, government-allied militias swept into the northwestern town of Afrin, above, in support of Kurdish forces. It\u2019s a setback for Turkey, which is trying to clear the Kurdish groups from the area.\n\nAnd at the U.N. Security Council this week, Russia stalled plans for a cease-fire that would have allowed humanitarian aid to reach a besieged rebel-held enclave near Damascus.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Anbang Insurance Group burst onto the global scene in 2014, when it announced a nearly $2 billion deal to purchase the famed Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York, above, an Art Deco symbol of Champagne-soaked excess.\n\nFew had ever heard of the company, which was founded a decade earlier in Ningbo, China, and skyrocketed to success selling insurance and wealth management products.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Friday, it all came crashing down. The Chinese government seized Anbang, saying it broke regulations and jeopardized its ability to pay claims. Its former chairman, Wu Xiaohui, now faces criminal charges in a Shanghai court. Here\u2019s the story of its fall.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. At the Olympics, we look at the remarkable dietary habits of cross-country skiers, like Martin Moeller of Denmark, above.\n\nThey eat more than any other type of athlete \u2014 by a lot. Men in the category need up to 8,000 calories a day. That\u2019s more than three times the normal recommendation.\n\nThe long-distance men and women\u2019s skiing competitions will be held this weekend. The closing ceremony is on Sunday. Here\u2019s the full medal count and schedule.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. How are you going to achieve anything if you can\u2019t even do the splits?\n\nThat\u2019s the question Eiko, above center, asks in her new book, \u201cEven the Stiffest People Can Do the Splits: A Four-Week Stretching Plan to Achieve Amazing Health.\u201d\n\nThe book is a smash hit in Japan, where Eiko says women in their 30s and 40s \u2014 and lots of senior citizens \u2014 are taking her tough-love message seriously. It was recently released in the U.S., and it left our author wondering if Eiko is the next Marie Kondo.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, Trevor Noah riffed on the CNN town hall event with survivors of the Florida school shooting. He was impressed that Senator Marco Rubio said he would reconsider his position on high-capacity magazines, which allow weapons to fire many bullets quickly.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not going to lie, I\u2019m surprised that these heckling teenagers got Rubio to change his mind,\u201d Mr. Noah said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMaybe bullying isn\u2019t that bad after all. In fact, maybe that\u2019s how you get the rest of America\u2019s lawmakers to do anything: Move the floor of Congress to the middle of a coliseum.\u201d\n\nHave a great weekend.\n\n____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Rick Gates, Florida, Justin Trudeau: Your Friday Evening Briefing", "authors": ["Karen Zraick", "Sandra Stevenson"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Besides the agreement with Mr. Gates, the special counsel\u2019s team has already secured guilty pleas from two of Mr. Trump\u2019s advisers. Michael T. Flynn, the president\u2019s first national security adviser, and George Papadopoulos, a foreign policy aide during the campaign, have both pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. and agreed to cooperate with the inquiry.\n\nMr. Gates\u2019s plea deal came together over the past few days, according to people familiar with the process. In a letter to friends and family, Mr. Gates said there had been false news stories about an impending plea deal over the past two weeks.\n\nBut, he added, \u201cDespite my initial desire to vigorously defend myself, I have had a change of heart. The reality of how long this legal process will likely take, the cost, and the circuslike atmosphere of an anticipated trial are too much. I will better serve my family moving forward by exiting this process.\u201d\n\n[Read our 2017 profile of Rick Gates \u00bb]\n\nTestimony from Mr. Gates could give Mr. Mueller\u2019s team a first-person account of the criminal conduct that is claimed in the indictments \u2014 a potential blow to Mr. Manafort\u2019s defense strategy. On Friday, Mr. Manafort pledged to continue the fight.\n\n\u201cNotwithstanding that Rick Gates pleaded today, I continue to maintain my innocence,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cI had hoped and expected my business colleague would have had the strength to continue the battle to prove our innocence. For reasons yet to surface he chose to do otherwise. This does not alter my commitment to defend myself against the untrue piled up charges contained in the indictments against me.\u201d\n\nAfter Mr. Gates\u2019s plea hearing, prosecutors filed a new indictment against Mr. Manafort. That indictment did not allege new charges against him, but was done for procedural purposes as prosecutors pursue separate cases in Washington and Northern Virginia.\n\nThe court papers give few specifics about how Mr. Gates came to be charged with lying to the F.B.I. On Feb. 1, as he was negotiating with prosecutors about a possible deal, Mr. Gates misled investigators about a conversation he had with Mr. Manafort in March 2013, after Mr. Manafort had met with the congressman to discuss the situation in Ukraine. The documents do not name the lawmaker, but news accounts have identified him as Representative Dana Rohrabacher of California, a Republican long known for his pro-Russia views.", "title": "Rick Gates, Trump Campaign Aide, Pleads Guilty in Mueller Inquiry and Will Cooperate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. McKay told the podcast \u201cBehind the Curtain: Broadway\u2019s Living Legends\u201d in 2016 that Ms. Arthur was dismayed when he told her that he planned to conduct the interview while handling the camera, sound and lighting by himself. But the interview went well, and she connected him to some of her famous friends. He used her connections and those of his own friends in show business as entree to an ever-wider circle of celebrities.\n\nMr. McKay was persistent in his pursuit of different actors, and once he got them on camera he was a convivial, sympathetic interviewer.\n\nThe secret to getting stars to open up about their lives was easy, he said on the podcast: Do extensive research and \u201cmake it about them, constantly about them.\u201d\n\nJulie Harris, Stephen Sondheim, Ben Gazzara, Elaine Stritch, Carol Burnett, Diahann Carroll, Alec Baldwin and Shirley MacLaine were among the luminaries he interviewed.\n\n\u201cMost people will never work with a cast like this,\u201d Mr. McKay told The Los Angeles Times in 2004.\n\nIn \u201cBroadway,\u201d which Mr. McKay produced, directed and edited, Ms. MacLaine reminisced about making lemonade for herself out of free lemons, water and sugar at a Manhattan automat. Mr. Gazzara recalled skipping school for more than a month to see every play on Broadway. And Ms. Burnett remembered sharing an audition dress with three other aspiring actresses.\n\nMr. McKay also tracked down rare archival footage, including an audio recording of Marlon Brando in \u201cA Streetcar Named Desire\u201d during the play\u2019s original Broadway run in the late 1940s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe documentary was shown at art-house cinemas and won more than a dozen awards at film festivals. Critics were mostly enthusiastic.\n\n\u201c \u2018Broadway: The Golden Age\u2019 is all chatter all the time, but that\u2019s a good thing,\u201d Desson Thomson wrote in The Washington Post.\n\n\u201cThe chatterers, you see, are actors of a certain vintage,\u201d he continued. \u201cA Broadway vintage, that is. And the stories they tell in this warm, evocative documentary crackle with humor and glow with reverence.\u201d\n\nMr. McKay\u2019s brother said he was not sure when the two subsequent parts of the documentary would be released.\n\nRichard Charles McKay was born on Aug. 30, 1955, in a suburb of Boston. His mother, the former Alyce Monroe, was a homemaker and theater buff, and his father, James McKay, was an engineer.\n\nWhen Rick was still young the family moved to Beech Grove, Ind., near Indianapolis, where he was active in musical theater and graduated from high school. He taught at the Indiana School for the Deaf, moved to Boston in the early 1970s, then lived in Japan, where he was an English teacher and nightclub singer.\n\nAfter moving to New York, he kept singing in clubs and on cruises and later turned to broadcast and print journalism.\n\nAt his death Mr. McKay was also working on a documentary about the actress Fay Wray, a friend of his for years.\n\nIn addition to his brother, he is survived by four sisters, Stacie Stevenson and Sandy, Hope and Linda McKay.", "title": "Rick McKay, Who Documented Memories of Broadway, Dies at 62", "authors": ["Daniel E. Slotnik"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The meeting that nearly led to Mr. Sessions\u2019s resignation came last May shortly after the president fired James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director who was heading an investigation into Russia\u2019s interference in the 2016 presidential election and any cooperation with Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign. The dismissal of Mr. Comey, which Mr. Trump in an interview with NBC News linked to his unhappiness with the Russia investigation, triggered the appointment of a special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, to the ire of the president.\n\nMr. Trump was furious with Mr. Sessions for recusing himself from the Russia investigation and therefore losing control over it. Mr. Priebus\u2019s account confirms and adds more detail to a New York Times report that the president berated Mr. Sessions in a meeting in the Oval Office, leading him to offer his resignation. Vice President Mike Pence and the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, were in the meeting, but Mr. Priebus was not.\n\n\u201cDon McGahn came in my office pretty hot, red, out of breath and said, \u2018We\u2019ve got a problem,\u2019\u201d Mr. Priebus recalled. \u201cI responded, \u2018What?\u2019 And he said, \u2018Well, we just got a special counsel and Sessions just resigned.\u2019 I said, \u2018What? What the hell are you talking about?\u2019 And I said, \u2018That can\u2019t happen.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Priebus bolted down the back stairway of the West Wing and out the door to the parking lot and found Mr. Sessions in the back of a black sedan with the engine running and about to leave. \u201cI knocked on the door of the car and Jeff was sitting there and I just jumped in and shut the door and I said, \u2018Jeff, what\u2019s going on?\u2019\u201d Mr. Priebus said. \u201cAnd then he told me that he was going to resign.\u201d\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018You cannot resign. It\u2019s not possible. We are going to talk about this right now,\u2019\u201d Mr. Priebus continued. \u201cSo I dragged him back up to my office from the car. Pence and Bannon came in,\u201d he added, referring to Stephen K. Bannon, the president\u2019s chief strategist, \u201cand we started talking to him to the point where he decided that he would not resign right then and he would instead think about it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the end, Mr. Sessions still drafted a resignation letter later that night and sent it to the White House. Mr. Priebus then went to work on Mr. Trump, arguing that he should not accept it. The president reluctantly agreed and Mr. Sessions stayed.\n\nBut that did not end the danger to the attorney general. A couple months later, Mr. Trump took his anger with Mr. Sessions public by telling The New York Times in an interview that he would not have appointed him attorney general had he known that he would recuse himself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBehind the scenes, Mr. Trump once again demanded Mr. Sessions\u2019s resignation. Citing a White House insider, Mr. Whipple\u2019s book says the president told Mr. Priebus to act on his order. \u201cDon\u2019t try to slow me down like you always do,\u201d Mr. Trump told him. \u201cGet the resignation of Jeff Sessions.\u201d\n\nMr. Priebus, however, did try to slow him down and argued that pushing out Mr. Sessions would result in the resignations of the second- and third-ranking Justice Department officials too. \u201cIf I get this resignation, you are in for a spiral of calamity that makes Comey look like a picnic,\u201d Mr. Priebus warned him. Again, Mr. Trump backed down.\n\nBut in other ways he did not. Mr. Priebus said he and other aides \u2014 including Ivanka Trump, the president\u2019s daughter; Jared Kushner, his son-in-law; and Hope Hicks, his communications director \u2014 regularly tried to convince Mr. Trump that his random, often incendiary Twitter messages were self-destructive.\n\n\u201cI told him, \u2018Some of it\u2019s not helpful, it causes distraction. We can get thrown off our message by tweeting things that aren\u2019t the issues of the day,\u2019\u201d he said. But he did not get through. \u201cEverybody tried at different times to cool down the Twitter habit \u2014 but no one could do it. Not me, Jared, Ivanka, Hope.\u201d\n\nEven the first lady weighed in when her husband addressed Congress. \u201cAfter the joint session, we all talked to him and Melania said, \u2018No tweeting,\u2019\u201d Mr. Priebus said. \u201cAnd he said, \u2018OK \u2014 for the next few days.\u2019 We had many discussions involving this issue. We had meetings in the residence. I couldn\u2019t stop it.\u201d\n\nThe challenge was clear from the very start when Mr. Trump called him the morning after he was sworn in ranting about news coverage comparing the size of his inaugural crowd with that of his predecessor. Mr. Priebus tried to calm the new president, but ultimately had to go along. \u201cAm I going to go to war over this with the president of the United States?\u201d he asked himself.\n\nMr. Priebus\u2019s inability to control Mr. Trump or even control who could wander in and out of the Oval Office caused consternation. Mr. Bannon told Mr. Whipple that John F. Kelly, then the secretary of homeland security, complained to him about it. \u201cHe said to me, \u2018It really upsets me that I walk in the Oval Office and it\u2019s like Grand Central Station,\u2019\u201d said Mr. Bannon.\n\nUltimately, Mr. Trump would pick Mr. Kelly to replace Mr. Priebus. But Mr. Kelly, who initially earned plaudits for imposing more order on the West Wing, lately has come under fire for his management of the White House, particularly his handling of spousal abuse allegations that resulted in the resignation of the staff secretary, Rob Porter.\n\nMr. Priebus said that Mr. Trump has spent his whole life resisting the sort of organization that others would like to impose on him. \u201cThe idea that he was suddenly going to accept an immediate and elaborate staff structure regulating every minute of his life was never in the cards,\u201d Mr. Priebus said. \u201cAt least not on Day 1.\u201d", "title": "Riding an Untamed Horse: Priebus Opens Up on Serving Trump", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Which, he writes, makes the attacks on the agency by Mr. Trump and congressional Republicans all the more strange and alarming. He points out that during the presidential campaign, news of the investigation into Hillary Clinton leaked to the news media while the Trump investigation was kept quiet. \u201cThis hardly suggests an F.B.I. bias.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nJohn Nichols in The Nation:\n\n\n\n\u201cThe speaker\u2019s embrace of Nunes and his memo has dishonored the chamber that he, above all others, is duty bound to defend.\u201d\n\nMr. Nichols takes aim at Speaker Paul D. Ryan, writing that the Republican congressional leader abandoned his duty to steer the legislative branch as a check on the \u201clawless\u201d executive branch of the Trump administration. \u201cPaul Ryan is not supporting the Constitution,\u201d Mr. Nichols writes. \u201cHe is shredding it.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nFinally, From the Center\n\nJohn Sipher in Politico Magazine:\n\n\n\n\u201cWhy would anyone be willing to put themselves into harm\u2019s way to work with the U.S. government again?\u201d\n\nMr. Sipher, a former C.I.A. agent, argues that the Nunes memo, and its treatment of Christopher Steele, the author of the Trump dossier and a former MI-6 agent, may scare off other foreign tipsters willing to share vital information with American agencies. Moreover, he argues that even if Mr. Steele had a personal bias against Mr. Trump, it should not disqualify his information as unreliable. \u201cBeing biased is hardly a disqualifier,\u201d Mr. Sipher writes. \u201cIf it were, we would have a tough time finding sources in most countries around the world.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nDouglas M. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com.\n\nFor an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks.\n\nFrom the Right\n\nPhoto\n\nDavid French in National Review:\n\n\n\n\u201cWhen policies fail, people can and should rise to the occasion.\u201d\n\nMr. French says he does not believe that new guns laws work to prevent the type of violence that happened on Wednesday at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. But that does not mean that nothing can be done to prevent tragedies of this nature. Mr. French suggests that Americans are \u201cstill the first line of defense in our own communities,\u201d and should feel empowered to step in when they see the warning signs. Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nSteve Deace in USA Today:\n\n\u201cIf you want gun owners to listen to what you believe are reasonable ideas and you\u2019re not just a gun grabber, be informed and reasonable.\u201d\n\nMr. Deace, a \u201cstaunch advocate of the God-given right to self-defense\u201d and a conservative radio host, laments the fact that, so often, the conversation around gun control has partisans retreating to their rigid ideological corners without really listening to the other side. He poses a number of \u201clegitimate\u201d questions that he says would move the conversation forward, including \u201cShould our schools be secured like our airports?\u201d and \u201cHow come stories of private gun ownership actually saving lives rarely get sustained national attention?\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That\u2019s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.\n\nHas this series exposed you to new ideas? Tell us how. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com.\n\nFor an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks.\n\nFrom the Right\n\nPhoto\n\nMary Katharine Ham in The Federalist:\n\n\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been trying for a year to separate correct from wrong and responsible from irresponsible, and there has been plenty of wrong and irresponsible reporting. This memo offers additional context, even if it\u2019s as selective, incomplete, and politically motivated as its harshest critics suggest.\u201d\n\nMs. Ham draws parallels between the Nunes memo and much of the reporting around potential collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign team. Both, she writes, rely on selectively released information with partisan or biased sources at their origin. She advises readers of both the memo and news media accounts to take these caveats into consideration before drawing conclusions from either. Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nJim Geraghty in National Review:\n\n\u201cWhatever you think of President Trump, Carter Page, or any of these other figures, it\u2019s bad when the F.B.I. withholds information while applying for FISA warrants.\u201d\n\nFor Mr. Geraghty, the key piece of wrongdoing revealed by the Nunes memo is how the F.B.I. handled its application to monitor Carter Page, a foreign policy adviser to the Trump campaign. He asks his readers to imagine that the roles were reversed and that \u201cHillary Clinton\u2019s campaign officials because of research by\u2026 oh, America Rising, or Jerome Corsi, and then withheld the source of that information from the FISA judge when they sought permission.\u201d Democrats, he writes, would justifiably be enraged by a law enforcement agency using its power to accomplish \u201cpartisan objectives.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n_____\n\nFrom the Left\n\nPhoto\n\nEric Levitz in New York Magazine:\n\n\n\n\u201cEven if we stipulate that all of the memo\u2019s factual assertions are true, the document does nothing to discredit the validity of the Mueller investigation \u2014 but does quite a bit to discredit the GOP\u2019s own attacks on that probe.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s possible, Mr. Levitz concedes, that Mr. Page was improperly surveilled by the government. However, in his estimation, the memo doesn\u2019t do many of the things Trump allies may have been hoping for and speculating about. Notably, it does not prove the Steele dossier was the basis for the investigation into collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign. Moreover the memo does little to impugn the behavior of current F.B.I. and Justice Department leadership, like Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, who some believe is in the president\u2019s cross hairs. Read more \u00bb\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nMatthew Miller in The Washington Post:\n\n\u201cWhat makes the president\u2019s involvement so fundamentally inappropriate is the fact that the Nunes memo cannot be disentwined from the active, ongoing investigation into the president and his 2016 campaign.\u201d\n\nMr. Miller worked in the Justice Department under Eric Holder, the former attorney general, from 2009 to 2011. He suggests that, in addition to firing James Comey, President Trump\u2019s decision to release the Nunes memo may play a big part in the obstruction of justice investigation against him. Read more \u00bb", "title": "Right and Left React to the Release of Nunes Memo", "authors": ["Anna Dubenko"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Jordan Weissmann in Slate:\n\n\u201cThe White House released its official budget proposal today. I\u2019m not going to waste my time reading it, and neither should you.\u201d\n\nMr. Weissmann suggests that his readers ignore the budget proposed by the Trump administration. After all, he writes, the president already signed a spending bill that raised the government\u2019s budget by $300 billion. This means that the White House\u2019s budget revealed on Monday is \u201ccompletely irrelevant to any real-world decision making.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nMatthew Rozsa in Salon:\n\n\u201cDuring the Obama years, deficit was a four-letter word to the Republican Party.\u201d\n\nThe Republicans used to be deficit averse, Mr. Rozsa reminds his readers. So what gave rise to the party\u2019s seemingly newfound tolerance for ballooning debt? Perhaps, he speculates, the party\u2019s fiscal conservatives have been sidelined by Mr. Trump\u2019s ideology. Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nFinally, From the Center\n\nRobert J. Samuelson in The Washington Post:\n\n\n\n\u201cNeither party will make the unpopular choices necessary to pay for an aging society and essential government. Ever-larger budget deficits have become their means of making policy and practicing politics.\u201d\n\n\u201cMost politicians are can kickers,\u201d declares Mr. Samuelson. Politicians of both parties are loath to eliminate popular entitlement programs and military spending, and so far, perhaps they\u2019ve been right. As he points out, this strategy has so far yielded \u201cfew economic or political costs.\u201d But, he argues, even though there have been few negative consequences to a soaring national debt in the past, we should still care about the deficit. The reason we should care? In one word, writes Mr. Samuelson, \u201cprudence.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\n_____\n\nJonathan Bernstein in Bloomberg:\n\n\u201cThe plan the O.M.B. sent to Congress is not, in any real way, the president\u2019s budget proposal.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s nothing new about Congress not taking the president\u2019s budget seriously. However, Mr. Bernstein notes, in the past, \u201cthe annual document is still normally regarded as a statement of the president\u2019s preferences and priorities.\u201d This time, however, the budget may mean even less to lawmakers in Washington. It contains proposals and policy ideas, Mr. Bernstein argues, \u201cthat Trump has little interest in supporting or fighting for.\u201d Moreover, because the document so clearly reflects the worldview of Mick Mulvaney, the president\u2019s budget director, and not Mr. Trump, it reveals a rift within the executive branch that we don\u2019t often see. It\u2019s unusual, Mr. Bernstein writes, \u201cfor a president to be so apparently indifferent to whether the executive branch follows where he leads.\u201d Read more \u00bb\n\nWant the Partisan Writing Roundup in your inbox? Sign up for the Morning Briefing Newsletter or the What We\u2019re Reading Newsletter.", "title": "Right and Left React to the Soaring Budget Deficit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe teenagers of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., who a week ago lost 17 of their classmates and school staff members in a mass shooting, have emerged as passionate advocates for reform, speaking openly of their anger in the hope of forcing a reckoning on guns.\n\nBut in certain right-wing corners of the web \u2014 and, increasingly, from more mainstream voices like Rush Limbaugh and a commentator on CNN \u2014 the students are being portrayed not as grief-ridden survivors but as pawns and conspiracists intent on exploiting a tragedy to undermine the nation\u2019s laws.\n\nIn these baseless accounts, which by Tuesday had spread rapidly on social media, the students are described as \u201ccrisis actors,\u201d who travel to the sites of shootings to instigate fury against guns. Or they are called F.B.I. plants, defending the bureau for its failure to catch the shooter. They have been portrayed as puppets being coached and manipulated by the Democratic Party, gun control activists, the so-called antifa movement and the left-wing billionaire George Soros.\n\nThe theories are far-fetched. But they are finding a broad and prominent audience online. On Tuesday, the president\u2019s son Donald J.
