The data also reflected cases that were resolved during the Trump administration but had been initiated and largely handled under President Obama.\n\nThe New York Times in December did its own analysis of the E.P.A.\u2019s civil enforcement action initiated in the first nine months under Scott Pruitt, the administrator appointed by President Trump. During that time frame, the agency sought civil penalties of about $50.4 million from polluters, which, adjusted for inflation, was about 39 percent of what the Obama administration sought in the same time period under its first E.P.A. director and about 70 percent of what the Bush administration sought in the same period.", "title": "Rise in E.P.A. Penalties Against Polluters Comes With an Asterisk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "That set off a supply crunch, at one point pushing prices for vanilla pods, which were about $30 a kilogram, or $13.60 a pound, in 2012, to more than $700 a kilogram in 2017. Those prices, coupled with poor crops, were too high for some retailers. Oddono\u2019s, an ice cream chain in London, stopped selling vanilla ice cream for several months.\n\n\u25a0 A drought in California drove almond prices sharply higher in 2014 and 2015. That came just as demand for a broad range of nuts was surging, pushed in particular by increased consumption in China.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u25a0 In 2015, the combination of rising demand for chocolate in Asian countries, unusual weather in major cocoa-producing countries of West Africa and attacks of fungus resulted in higher prices for chocolate. The factors just happened to coincide with Valentine\u2019s Day.\n\nBritain is particularly vulnerable to shifts in the international food system: It imports almost a third of its food, and a weaker currency, driven in part by uncertainty over the country\u2019s exit from the European Union next year, could make groceries even more expensive.\n\nThe unexpectedly severe drought in India of the past few years has affected hundreds of millions of people in the country. It has also had consequences for global markets, including for chickpeas, as India typically produces 10 times the amount of the legume as the next-biggest producer, according to data from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Britain, hummus has quickly gone from being a niche snack, introduced to supermarkets in the 1990s, to being a staple. The dish, a specialty of the Middle East and the Mediterranean, was voted one of the products most likely to be found in Britons\u2019 fridges in a 2013 survey of European food habits. Annual sales of hummus in the country total more than 100 million pounds, or about $140 million, up about 50 percent from four years ago, according to the research firm Kantar Worldpanel.\n\nIndeed, worldwide demand for hummus has driven up interest in chickpea production, and analysts expect a shift toward healthier eating will continue to bolster the dish\u2019s popularity. Farmers in the United States, for example, were forecast to drastically raise their chickpea harvests last year, according to official data, after what was already a record year in 2016. And scientists from Scotland and Ethiopia are jointly exploring the development of drought-resistant chickpeas.\n\nFor now, some manufacturers in Britain are trying to absorb the higher costs.\n\nRamona Hazan\u2019s London-based business, Ramona\u2019s Kitchen, makes about 75 tons of hummus a month, both for supermarkets and for sale directly to customers. Each 250-gram tub costs about \u00a31.60, but tighter margins resulting from higher chickpea prices mean she is now looking at diversifying.\n\n\u201cWe might look at pea and mint dips, extend our range to things not as chickpea-based,\u201d Ms. Hazan said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOthers have taken to searching for options elsewhere. AGT Poortman, which supplies chickpeas to companies that make hummus for British supermarkets, said its prices had increased around 40 percent from 2015 to 2017. To supply clients, it has asked them to allow it to buy chickpeas from a wider variety of places.", "title": "Rising Hummus Prices? Blame a Drought Half a World Away", "authors": ["Amie Tsang"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Willets Point is dead. Long live Willets Point.\n\nThe $3 billion Bloomberg-era project to transform a neighborhood of broken streets and ramshackle auto repair shops across from Citi Field in Queens appeared dead in 2015, when a state court ruled that the city could not take a piece of Flushing Meadows Corona Park for a gigantic shopping mall and garage as it had planned.\n\nStill, bulldozers plowed over dozens of shops as the city used eminent domain to take some of the land and hundreds of immigrant workers lost their jobs.\n\nBut on Monday, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio struck a deal with the original developers for a new version of the plan, which will include 1,100 apartments for low- and moderate-income New Yorkers, a 450-seat school, open space and retail on six acres at Willets Point Boulevard and Roosevelt Avenue.\n\nNotably not part of the plan: the mall. Instead of pursuing remnants of the old plan, the de Blasio administration will convene a task force with Melinda Katz, the Queens borough president, and Francisco Moya, the local City Council member, to fashion a framework for developing the remaining 17 acres at the site, which is also known as the Iron Triangle.", "title": "Rising from the Ashes, Willets Point Redevelopment Will Go Forward, City Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Ukrainian Night,\u201d the Yale historian Marci Shore\u2019s compact book (its large-font chapters typically range from two to seven pages), seeks to portray the ideals that animated the protesters. Shore succeeds admirably, particularly because she tells the story through their words. Her sympathy for their courage and her support for a democratic Ukraine aligned with the West are evident, her depictions of the sights, sounds and smells on the Maidan superb. In lucid, if occasionally overwrought, prose she draws evocative portraits of people who braved the bitter cold \u2014 and truncheons and bullets \u2014 to create a \u201cparallel polis\u201d with barricades, soup kitchens, libraries, rock concerts, fiery speakers and solidarity among Ukrainians of disparate backgrounds.\n\nImage\n\nThis is not a work of historical scholarship, nor is it comparable to the detailed eyewitness reportage of writers like Keith Gessen or Sophie Pinkham. Shore strides through centuries of Ukraine\u2019s past, but the result verges on potted history: It offers little to readers familiar with Ukraine and not nearly enough for novices seeking to understand the stark cultural and political variations within the country or the complex forces that produced the Maidan revolution. Shore wishes to give the movement a human face, but she devotes so much space to people\u2019s appearances, professions, families, ruminations and inner thoughts that her account resembles a collage of personalities.\n\nShore does not dispute that Yanukovych was elected fairly in 2010 yet fails to explain how a crook and a thug (\u201choodlum\u201d is her apt description), who betrayed even the inhabitants of the Donbass, his political bastion, prevailed, or why he suddenly shelved the association agreement. Given her overwhelming focus on Kiev and parts west, she says little about those Ukrainians in Crimea and the Donbass who opposed the Maidan revolt. Generally, they are voiceless \u2014 spoken for by Shore herself, or by her pro-Maidan interlocutors (who tend to characterize them as troglodytes). The internal political differences produced by Ukraine\u2019s history are obscured, or dismissed as backward when they do not align with the ideals of the Maidan.\n\n\u201cThe Ukrainian Night\u201d vividly depicts life on the Maidan. It is less effective in uncovering Ukraine\u2019s complexities and the roots of a still-unfinished revolution.", "title": "Risking Everything for Democracy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Several prominent free agents are clients of the agent Scott Boras, including Eric Hosmer, J.D. Martinez, Jake Arrieta, Mike Moustakas, Greg Holland, Carlos Gomez, Carlos Gonzalez and Tony Watson. Manfred did not mention Boras by name on Thursday, but the target of his comments seemed obvious.\n\n\u201cDrawing lines in the sand based on a perception that your market value is something different than what the market is telling you your value is, that doesn\u2019t make a lot of sense,\u201d Manfred said. \u201cIt is a fact that markets dictate value. Values are not dictated by big, thick, three-ring binders and rhetoric about who\u2019s better than whom. They\u2019re dictated by markets. That\u2019s the system we negotiated.\u201d\n\nBoras, who often presents teams with exhaustive research on the value of his clients, has excoriated teams for failing to field competitive rosters this off-season.\n\n\u201cThis is not about the ability to pay,\u201d Boras said last month. \u201cIt\u2019s about choices.\u201d\n\nMany players and agents are suspicious of the industry\u2019s seemingly abrupt choice to show restraint in free agency. Owners were found guilty of collusion three times in the 1980s, a strategy that effectively robbed players of nearly $300 million and helped create a labor environment so poisonous that a work stoppage canceled the 1994 World Series.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nManfred insisted on Thursday that teams had acted appropriately this off-season.\n\n\u201cWe believe that players who are major league players will eventually get signed, whatever that timetable turns out to be, and we wish them the best of luck in that regard,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I can tell you one thing for certain: Clubs have conducted themselves in a manner that\u2019s completely consistent with the agreement we made with the M.L.B.P.A.\u201d\n\nManfred said that teams had always gone through rebuilding cycles, and even if they were not splurging for veteran free agents, \u201cthey\u2019re in a process that is directed at winning.\u201d He disputed the notion that players were now getting a smaller portion of revenue in the sport, which generated around $10 billion last year.\n\n\u201cWe have been at a very stable \u2014 approximately 50 percent of revenue going to player salaries \u2014 for five, six, seven years,\u201d Manfred said. \u201cThe math of that means that salaries are growing in line with revenues.\u201d\n\nPlayers have noticed the absence of some of their peers from training camps. Two everyday players for the Mets in recent seasons, first baseman Lucas Duda and second baseman Neil Walker, are among the unsigned. Others still seeking jobs include catcher Jonathan Lucroy, first baseman Logan Morrison and starters Alex Cobb, Lance Lynn and Jason Vargas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s crazy,\u201d said outfielder Jay Bruce, who returned to the Mets with a three-year, $39 million deal after seeking much more in free agency. \u201cI\u2019ve never seen anything like it. I just hope everyone will get to where they want to get and find a job.\u201d\n\nThe Yankees brought back pitcher C. C. Sabathia for one year and $10 million \u2014 a significant cut from the $25 million he earned last season, when he was 14-5 with a 3.69 earned run average. Sabathia, 37, understands why the market has changed.\n\n\u201cWhen I was a free agent, you got paid for what you did,\u201d Sabathia said. \u201cNow, guys are getting paid for what they can do throughout their contract. So it\u2019s just a different landscape in baseball the way teams are changing. G.M.s are getting younger and smarter, and want to get more value out of a player.\u201d\n\nValuable players remain unsigned, and the game goes on without them.", "title": "Rob Manfred Defends Changing Paces, of Free Agency and of the Game", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "On Wednesday, we learned that during a 2017 background check for the former White House staff secretary Rob Porter, his two ex-wives both told the F.B.I. that he had abused them. His first wife, Colbie Holderness, gave the F.B.I. a photo of her with a black eye, a result, she said, of Porter punching her in the face during a vacation in 2005. Porter\u2019s second wife, Jennifer Willoughby, shared a 2010 emergency protective order she\u2019d received after he punched in the glass on her door while they were separated.\n\nThe White House chief of staff John Kelly reportedly knew about these allegations, which are said to be the reason the F.B.I. never gave Porter a full security clearance, ordinarily a prerequisite for his job. Nevertheless, Porter\u2019s past was apparently not considered a problem inside the White House until it became public. This tells us quite a bit about how seriously this administration takes violence against women.\n\nEven after The Daily Mail broke the story, Kelly reportedly urged Porter not to resign, though he did anyway. In the White House briefing room Wednesday, President Trump\u2019s press secretary Sarah Sanders read a statement from Porter calling his ex-wives\u2019 accounts \u201csimply false\u201d and part of a \u201ccoordinated smear campaign.\u201d In what was perhaps a rare outbreak of candor by omission, she didn\u2019t bother with a pro forma statement that the White House condemns domestic violence.\n\nEven if you put aside questions of morality \u2014 which most people working for Donald Trump have already done \u2014 a staff secretary who can\u2019t qualify for a security clearance because of his personal life is a serious security risk. Among other things, such a person could be subject to blackmail.", "title": "Opinion | Rob Porter Is Donald Trump\u2019s Kind of Guy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The White House\u2019s initial response was consistent with the way both Mr. Trump and his aides have handled allegations of harassment or abuse against the president or his allies and advisers since the 2016 presidential campaign. Mr. Trump vigorously defended Roy S. Moore, the failed Alabama Republican Senate candidate, against allegations that included child molestation, and Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, has said that multiple women who have accused the president of sexual misconduct were lying.\n\nIn the White House, Mr. Porter, 40, had been widely regarded as a rising star. A Harvard graduate, Rhodes scholar and former Senate aide, Mr. Porter was an ally of Mr. Kelly\u2019s and a steady force in a West Wing populated by aides vying for face time with \u2014 and influence over \u2014 the president. But, a year into his job, Mr. Porter did not have the permanent security clearance that aides of his rank always have.\n\nMs. Willoughby, Mr. Porter\u2019s second wife, said in an interview on Wednesday that when the F.B.I. was conducting research for Mr. Porter\u2019s security clearance, he asked her whether she had told investigators about their marriage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe believed that that was holding up his clearance,\u201d Ms. Willoughby said. \u201cI did describe my marriage in detail.\u201d\n\nMs. Willoughby, who said that she divorced Mr. Porter in November 2013, decided to go public about the allegations after facing pressure from Mr. Porter to issue a statement that she felt \u201cminimized\u201d her experiences in their marriage.\n\nIn addition to asking her about what she said to F.B.I. officials, Mr. Porter, she said, had been in touch several times over the past year to urge her to take down a blog post in which she detailed abuse in their marriage without naming him.\n\nAccording to an emergency protective order she filed in June 2010 against him in an Arlington, Va., court, Ms. Willoughby accused Mr. Porter of growing angry when she said he had violated a private separation agreement. A day later, her complaint said, Mr. Porter entered her apartment with a key he had not given back.\n\nAccording to her complaint, Mr. Porter left only after Ms. Willoughby had asked him to leave several times. He returned minutes later and \u201cpunched in the glass on the door,\u201d trying to get into the apartment. He left the property after she read her name and address aloud to a 911 dispatcher.\n\n\u201cWhen he heard me on the phone with the police,\u201d Ms. Willoughby wrote in the complaint, \u201che apologized and begged me not to involve them.\u201d\n\nMs. Holderness, Mr. Porter\u2019s first wife, described their relationship as \u201cverbally, emotionally and physically abusive\u201d in an interview with The Daily Mail. In photographs she gave to The Intercept, Ms. Holderness has a blackened right eye and a swollen cheekbone.\n\nIn his statement, Mr. Porter said the pictures of Ms. Holderness were misleading.\n\n\u201cI took the photos given to the media nearly 15 years ago, and the reality behind them is nowhere close to what is being described,\u201d he said. \u201cI have been transparent and truthful about these vile claims, but I will not further engage publicly with a coordinated smear campaign.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe White House sent several statements to The Mail on Tuesday evening in support of Mr. Porter. In one, Mr. Kelly, who in recent months has leaned heavily on Mr. Porter in his efforts to bring order to a once chaotic West Wing, called Mr. Porter \u201ca man of true integrity\u201d whom he could not say \u201cenough good things\u201d about.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe is a friend, a confidant and a trusted professional,\u201d Mr. Kelly said. \u201cI am proud to serve alongside him.\u201d\n\nBut by Wednesday evening, after reports that Mr. Kelly had known since the fall about the nature of the allegations against Mr. Porter, Mr. Kelly issued a statement indicating that was not the case.\n\n\u201cI was shocked by the new allegations released today against Rob Porter,\u201d Mr. Kelly said in the statement. \u201cThere is no place for domestic violence in our society. I stand by my previous comments of the Rob Porter that I have come to know since becoming chief of staff, and believe every individual deserves the right to defend their reputation. I accepted his resignation earlier today, and will ensure a swift and orderly transition.\u201d\n\nTwo White House officials, who asked not to be identified because they were not authorized to speak about the internal deliberations, insisted that Mr. Porter had misled Mr. Kelly and several other aides about the severity of the allegations. He had portrayed the women as making up stories to cause trouble, and few, if any, aides in the White House considered conducting their own investigations to discover what might have taken place, the officials said.\n\nAfter initially saying that Mr. Porter would remain on for a period of time, one of the White House officials said that he would be gone by the end of the week, as the West Wing faced blowback for standing by him.\n\nAsked in her daily briefing what the president thought of the photographs of Mr. Porter\u2019s bruised former wife, Ms. Sanders said she had not discussed them with him, and she declined to discuss specifics about Mr. Porter\u2019s security clearance.\n\nCongressional Democrats have been trying for months to get the White House to provide information about its security clearance process, including how many White House aides have been granted interim clearances because of issues that arose during their F.B.I. background checks.\n\nMr. Porter\u2019s former boss, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, sent his own statement to The Mail, saying that the article contained \u201cvile\u201d smears and vouching for Mr. Porter\u2019s character.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in a new statement on Wednesday, Mr. Hatch said that he was \u201cheartbroken\u201d by the allegations against Mr. Porter, who he said had been a beloved staff member and trusted adviser.\n\n\u201cI do not know the details of Rob\u2019s personal life,\u201d he said. \u201cDomestic violence in any form is abhorrent and unacceptable.\u201d\n\nAware of Mr. Hatch\u2019s comments, Ms. Willoughby said she would let her story speak for itself. Ms. Willoughby, who works as a writer and public speaker, said \u201cthis discourse that we\u2019re in in terms of women\u2019s rights and the \u2018Me Too\u2019 movement\u201d was a reason for stepping forward, and a reason she agreed with Mr. Porter\u2019s decision to resign.\n\n\u201cRob is in fact charming and intelligent and diligent and extremely good at his job,\u201d Ms. Willoughby said. \u201cAnd, in capital letters, abusive and manipulative and toxic in his personal relationships.\u201d", "title": "Rob Porter, White House Aide, Resigns After Accusations of Abuse", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Katie Rogers"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 People who crossed paths with Rob Porter in Harvard classrooms or the hallways of Capitol Hill describe him in glowing terms: He was articulate enough to be secretary of state. Intelligent enough to be a Supreme Court justice. Driven enough to be president.\n\nUntil Mr. Porter resigned as a White House aide amid domestic abuse accusations, plunging the Trump administration into a scandal over the vetting of West Wing hires, most were certain he would have his pick of positions.\n\nDescribed as charismatic, intense and privileged, Mr. Porter, the son of Roger B. Porter, a Harvard professor and a former domestic policy adviser to President George Bush, spent years building on his pedigree. He grew up Mormon in a family with close ties to the elite Mormon enclave of Belmont, Mass., collected degrees from Harvard and Oxford University and amassed prestigious job titles.\n\nThough many described him as composed and calm, others in his ultracompetitive workplaces described him as tightly wound, revealing occasional glimpses of how angry he could become, particularly if anyone got in his way. A former White House official said the temper flare-ups left him with the sense that Mr. Porter was more volatile and troubled than his clean-cut image let on.", "title": "Rob Porter\u2019s Charisma and Ambition Disguised Flare-ups of Anger", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Robert Alfred Pincus was born on April 5, 1935, in Manhattan and grew up in the Bronx. His father, Samuel, an immigrant from Poland, was a tailor. His mother, the former Charlotte Wittenberg, who had immigrated from Germany, worked at RCA, specializing in Morse code.\n\nAt some point Robert adapted his mother\u2019s last name and began going by Pincus-Witten \u2014 perhaps, Mr. Hecht speculated, to separate himself in the professional sphere. \u201cI think he wanted to be distinctively different,\u201d Mr. Hecht said.\n\nMr. Pincus-Witten also had a distinctively different speaking voice with a hard-to-define timbre that suggested erudition. Some who heard him lecture mistook it for an accent or an affectation, but Mr. Hecht, who had known him since early childhood, said those impressions were mistaken.\n\n\u201cAs a little boy in school, he spoke the same way,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd, of course, the teachers loved him, he was so witty and bright.\u201d\n\nMr. Pincus-Witten received a degree from the Cooper Union in Manhattan in 1956 and a master of arts from the University of Chicago in 1962, adding a doctorate from that institution in 1968. He joined the CUNY faculty in 1964, retiring in 1990.\n\nMr. Pincus-Witten began writing for Artforum in the mid-1960s. (He also held editing titles at times during his long association with the magazine.) About the same time, various artists began expanding beyond Minimalism; a 1966 show at the Fischbach Gallery in Manhattan called \u201cEccentric Abstraction\u201d was one important indicator of change.\n\nBut it was not until 1971 that Mr. Pincus-Witten came up with the label for these efforts that stuck, when he used Post-Minimalism in an Artforum article about the sculptor Eva Hesse, who had died the year before.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was also tangentially involved in one of Artforum\u2019s most incendiary moments from the 1970s: a 1974 issue of the magazine that featured a color photograph of the artist Lynda Benglis nude and holding a dildo between her thighs.\n\nThe photograph ran as an advertisement \u2014 it carried the name of the Paula Cooper Gallery, her dealer \u2014 but Ms. Benglis had initially hoped that it would appear with an article about her, written by Mr. Pincus-Witten, in the same the issue. The magazine\u2019s editor, John Coplans, would not allow that.\n\nMr. Pincus-Witten may have been a vital voice in the Post-Minimal moment, but he also knew that the art world would move on to new trends and ideas, at it always did.\n\n\u201cThe taste for the successful and celebrated is fickle,\u201d he noted in 2008 in Artforum. \u201cWhat waxes, wanes.\u201d\n\n\u201cTalk to a displaced middle-aged abstractionist today and listen to what is said,\u201d he added. \u201cWalk the display floors of the contemporary day sales \u2014 not the uncontested important lots of the evening sale \u2014 of the reigning auction houses and have a revelation: What was passionately acquired ten or twenty years earlier forms the bulk of lot upon lot of discredited art.\u201d\n\nHe thus remained ever curious.\n\nThe curator Scott Rothkopf wrote of him in Artforum in 2003, \u201cAfter fifteen years on the front lines of new art \u2014 an interval that could spawn almost as many generations of artists as fruit flies \u2014 Pincus-Witten wasn\u2019t about to desert the new recruits.\u201d\n\nMr. Rothkopf was writing in praise of the diarylike pieces that Mr. Pincus-Witten wrote for Arts magazine from 1976 to 1990. A mixture of feature article and critical assessment, they recounted his visits to shows and artists\u2019 lofts.\n\n\u201cHis reportage often illuminates the personal and commercial machinations that inevitably inform art\u2019s checkered past and present,\u201d Mr. Rothkopf wrote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Pincus-Witten was the author of several books, including \u201cPostminimalism\u201d (1977), \u201cEye to Eye: Twenty Years of Art Criticism\u201d (1984) and \u201cPostminimalism Into Maximalism: American Art, 1966-1986\u201d (1987). He worked at the Gagosian gallery from 1990 to 1996 and continued to contribute essays to its publications thereafter. Later that year he joined C&M Arts (now the Mnuchin Gallery) as director of exhibitions, a post he held for 11 years.\n\nMr. Hecht is his only immediate survivor.\n\nMr. Pincus-Witten thought that collectors of contemporary art enjoyed a special privilege not shared by those who focus on established artists: the chance to help determine what is ultimately viewed as significant.\n\n\u201cThe collector of contemporary art actually participates in the discourse of the day,\u201d he wrote, \u201cadding through acquisition his or her particular inflection to this tumultuous conversation. Hence, the collecting of contemporary art \u2014 whatever other benefits it may provide or deficits it may incur \u2014 confers a voice upon the collector with regard to the formation of the larger culture.\u201d\n\nAnd what of the critic\u2019s role? \u201cI see the critical task as being essentially that of pointing to the new,\u201d he wrote.", "title": "Robert Pincus-Witten, Art Critic and Historian, Is Dead at 82", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cThe Secret Life of Scissors,\u201d an exhibition at London\u2019s Fashion and Textile Museum I wrote up for the Thursday Styles section, was always advertised as a small display. The main event at the museum this season is a terrific show on T-shirts, which I could see was likely to be a crowd-puller, but the idea of this little show on scissors fascinated me. I pitched a short feature to Vanessa Friedman, the fashion director at The Times, under an honest subject line: \u201cOdd story \u2026 but I\u2019m a little obsessed with it.\u201d\n\nIt was my milliner friend Gabrielle Djanogly \u2014 a font of good stories and folklore \u2014 who first told me of the connection between sewing scissors and midwifery, the same instrument cutting both embroidery thread and umbilical cord. It was revelatory: I\u2019d grown up using the little stork scissors in my own mother\u2019s sewing box, and it had never occurred to me that such a story might have lurked behind their design. Of course, once you make that connection, you see immediately that the spindly metal bird with its snipping bill is a sibling to the stork on the spoon handle that records details of a baby\u2019s birth.\n\nThe stork scissors in my own mother\u2019s sewing box were part of an orderly feminine realm populated by objects designed for delicate hands and sharp eyes \u2014 little silver thimbles, slim needles, fine thread \u2014 to be called upon for acts of maintenance and repair. They occupied quite a different technical vocabulary from the medieval-looking shears she later used in her sheep shed to trim rank wool. And yet technically, the only difference was one of scale: Dagging shears and tiny stork alike were both fitted to the mechanism of the human hand.\n\nThey threatened human hands, too: I was haunted as a child by the long-legged scissor man in Heinrich Hoffmann\u2019s \u201cStruwwelpeter,\u201d who \u201calways comes to boys and girls who suck their thumbs.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite all the above, I don\u2019t feel I have a distinct personal history with scissors \u2014 I think my experiences are quite universal. After all, these are some of the most basic and ancient of human tools. I sensed that \u201cThe Secret Life of Scissors\u201d and its curator would yield some wonderful stories, and I wasn\u2019t wrong. The exhibition is actually based on the curator Teresa Collenette\u2019s personal collection, and I think she would forgive me for suggesting she has something of an obsession. Toward the end of the installation period, we met for tea at a hipster cafe in Bermondsey. Ms. Collenette heaved a laden cotton bag \u2014 printed with the scissored crest of the Craftivist Collective \u2014 onto the wooden countertop and drew out a procession of highlights from her collection for me to examine.", "title": "Rock and Paper Had No Idea", "authors": ["Hettie Judah"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe No. 1 tax is very low in this case,\u201d Courier said.\n\nTo scale the summit for the first time since Nov. 4, 2012, Federer need only reach the semifinals in Rotterdam. That means winning three matches, the first against the Belgian qualifier Ruben Bemelmans on Wednesday night in what will be their first meeting.\n\nWin that and Federer\u2019s second-round opponent will be the 36th-ranked Philipp Kohlschreiber, whom Federer has beaten in all 12 of their singles matches. Make it 13-0 and Federer is guaranteed to face a Dutchman ranked no higher than 42 \u2014 perhaps Robin Haase \u2014 in the quarterfinals with the top ranking at stake.\n\n\u201cIt would be absolutely incredible,\u201d Federer said of reaching No. 1, in an interview with Tennis TV. \u201cI can\u2019t believe I\u2019m this close, but No. 1 has never been simple, never been easy to get there. So I know it\u2019s going to be a lot of hard work for me this week mentally just to cope with everything, just also not thinking too far ahead.\u201d\n\nStill, the odds appear to be heavily in his favor, all the more so now that Stan Wawrinka, still working his way back from knee surgery but the only other major winner in Federer\u2019s quarter of the draw, was upset on Tuesday by the Dutch wild-card Tallon Griekspoor.\n\nFederer even gets the chance to keep playing indoors, which is where he played his last two matches at the Australian Open.\n\nHis semifinal with Hyeon Chung was contested under a closed roof in Melbourne because of rain. The final against Marin Cilic was played under a closed roof because of heat and humidity, a decision that caught the finalists and many others by surprise because the match was played in the evening.\n\nThat\u2019s why it is time for the Australian Open to revisit its extreme heat policy and not leave quite so much to the tournament referee\u2019s discretion. The sentiment in some sectors of the tennis community that the Australians may have been protecting Federer from the elements this year does no one any favors and distracts from a remarkable achievement that Federer was perfectly capable of managing without caveats.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fact that Tennis Australia and Federer are now in business together does not help.\n\nTennis Australia, like the United States Tennis Association, is a partner in the Laver Cup, the team event Federer\u2019s management group started in 2017. The Laver Cup advertisements that were visible in Melbourne Park raised some eyebrows in the player lounge (there were also signs on site for Rafael Nadal\u2019s academy in Majorca).\n\nGiven all that, the Australian Open should be bending over backward to eliminate any impression that the tournament is favoring Federer (or Nadal). So should the United States Open come August.\n\nBut then tennis runs on conflict of interest like few sports. It also runs on breaking records, which has long been Federer\u2019s forte.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe shouldn\u2019t lose sight of how amazing it is that Roger is playing at this level at 36,\u201d Courier said. \u201cThat he can make another run at the No. 1 ranking this week is a testament to his immense talent, diligent work habits and intelligent scheduling over the course of his career.\u201d\n\nIf he gets to No. 1, he will be the oldest player to do so in ATP ranking history. He is more than three years older than top-ranked Andre Agassi in 2003; Serena Williams, the oldest No. 1 singles player in WTA history, was 35 when she last held the top spot in 2017.\n\nThat Federer is this close even after skipping the clay-court season last year is a big surprise and also an indicator of how much his younger rivals \u2014 Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, both 30 \u2014 have struggled with injuries. Even though Federer won last year\u2019s Wimbledon and this year\u2019s Australian Open without facing any of the so-called Big Five, he has been an inspiration, picking his spots and proving that less can lead to more.\n\n\u201cThe thing that is amazing is Roger having the ability to play less and yet not lose confidence due to lack of reps,\u201d said Paul Annacone, his former coach. \u201cThat is a tough balance for anyone.\u201d\n\nConsidering the unlikely confluence of circumstances that have led to this moment, it is tempting to think it may never be matched.\n\n\u201cI do think Novak could make a similar run to the top at 36 if he is able to regain full health,\u201d Courier said. \u201cI could see his professionalism and talent taking him back to the pinnacle in his mid-30s.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAgassi was 33 when he last was No. 1. He was in the midst of a late-career surge animated by regret over missed opportunities in his less-committed youth and by the desire to play for a higher cause: the school he had opened in Las Vegas.\n\nHe was also racing the clock and a degenerative back problem that already was requiring cortisone injections.\n\nFederer, who has had back problems of his own, seems to be feeling no such pain at this stage and is even talking about playing the tournament in Dubai this month, too. He then intends to defend his hardcourt titles at Indian Wells (all but certain) and Miami (we\u2019ll see). After that, he presumably will play as little clay-court tennis as possible, perhaps none at all, which was his winning formula last year.\n\nThat is not because he has no chance at the French Open. He needs to pace himself and avoid too much risk to his postoperative knee, as Pierre Paganini, his longtime fitness trainer, explained to me late last year.\n\n\u201cThe advantage when you play on clay for the joints is there is less shock because there is the slide, and the disadvantage on hard courts is there is that shock,\u201d he said. \u201cBut the advantage on hard courts is that the shock is brief. It\u2019s bang and the foot leaves the ground and a player who is as coordinated and a dancer like Federer, he crushes his joints a bit less at that bad moment.\n\n\u201cIn contrast, the disadvantage with the slide on clay is that in the joints there is a lot of vibration. We don\u2019t see it from the outside, but to control this slide there is instability in the knee, the foot, the ankle. And that in some cases can be bad for the knee or joint in question.\u201d\n\nHowever logical, skipping the French Open again would still be a sacrifice. Federer has been the third-best clay-courter of this era, behind Nadal and Djokovic. He won the French Open in 2009, securing his spot in the greatest-ever debate.\n\nBecoming the oldest No. 1 in ATP history could turn that debate into a filibuster, and here he is, tantalizingly close without having been single-minded about the chase.", "title": "Roger Federer Pursues the No. 1 Ranking Again. Why Not?", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Federer will leapfrog Rafael Nadal, 31, when the rankings are updated on Monday.\n\nAlso a record will be the five-years-plus that have elapsed since Federer was last No. 1, and the 14 years since he first reached the top spot.\n\n\u201cThis one, because I\u2019m a little bit older, is a little bit more special maybe, because there\u2019s just so much that has to go into it, so much has to be right for it to work out, and it did so. It\u2019s a very deep satisfaction,\u201d Federer said.\n\nOn Monday, he will extend his record of 302 weeks at No. 1 since the rankings began in 1973. Pete Sampras is a distant second with 286 weeks at the top. Novak Djokovic is the closest currently active player, with 223 weeks at No. 1.\n\n\u201cReaching No. 1 is one of, if not the ultimate, achievement in our sport,\u201d Federer said.\n\n\u201cSometimes at the beginning you get there just because you play so well. Later, you sometimes try to fight it back and you wrest it back from somebody else who deserved to be there, and when you\u2019re older, you feel like you have to put maybe double the work in. So this one maybe means the most to me throughout my career.\u201d\n\nFederer, the 2005 and 2012 ABN AMRO champion, plays Andreas Seppi of Italy in the semifinals on Saturday. He beat qualifier Daniil Medvedev of Russia, 7-6 (4), 4-6, 6-3.", "title": "Roger Federer Secures No. 1 Ranking at Age 36", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "With the support of many N.F.L. owners, Commissioner Roger Goodell is prepared to escalate his public feud with Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys and long one of the most influential people in the league, by ordering him to pay millions of dollars for his efforts to derail negotiations to renew Goodell\u2019s contract and for his outspoken defense of a star player who was suspended, according to five league officials with direct knowledge of the situation.\n\nThe punishment will be issued in the coming weeks by Goodell, who will declare that Jones\u2019s actions were detrimental to the league, which rarely shows such acute signs of acrimony among owners and the commissioner\u2019s office. Goodell has been reluctant to be seen as exacting retribution for the way Jones tried to sabotage his contract talks, but he was urged to bring the penalties by several owners who believed that Jones had crossed an unspoken boundary by threatening his colleagues.\n\nIn November, Jones hired the high-profile lawyer David Boies and said he was prepared to sue the six owners on the league\u2019s compensation committee, which had been working for months on extending Goodell\u2019s contract. Jones also lobbied loudly for running back Ezekiel Elliott not to be penalized, and reportedly tried to influence league officials deciding his case. Elliott had been suspended by the league for six games before the season after the N.F.L. investigated domestic-assault allegations.\n\nJones will be ordered to pay the legal fees that the committee incurred defending itself, as well as the legal expenses the N.F.L. spent defending its decision to suspend Elliott.", "title": "Roger Goodell Expected to Demand Millions of Dollars From Jerry Jones", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Though Ms. Acosta Ba\u00f1uelos was an Arizonan by birth, when she was 7, during the Depression, she and her mother and stepfather were deported to Mexico as part of an anti-immigrant backlash.\n\nOnce in Mexico, Romana was raised by her mother and her stepfather, a miner, in the states of Sonora and Chihuahua. \u201cMy grandmother, being a very savvy businesswoman, set up a kitchen wherever the miners would go,\u201d said her daughter, Ms. Ba\u00f1uelos. \u201cShe was paid in gold dust.\u201d\n\nMs. Acosta Ba\u00f1uelos married Nepunoceno Torres, a firefighter, when she was 14 or 15, her daughter said. She had two sons with him, Martin and Carlos, and by 17 was divorced.\n\nShe dreamed of a life across the border. \u201cShe told her mother, \u2018I think that my future lies in L.A.,\u2019 \u201d Ms. Ba\u00f1uelos said.\n\nAfter arriving in California in her late teens (the immigration authorities confirmed her American citizenship), she found work as a dishwasher and waitress and sold homemade tortillas to neighbors.\n\nOnce she had saved about $500, she and her second husband, Alejandro Ba\u00f1uelos Tapia, a tool and die maker, invested it. \u201cTwo Mexican brothers were looking for money to open up a tortilla business,\u201d Ms. Ba\u00f1uelos recalled. Ms. Acosta Ba\u00f1uelos eventually bought out her partners and ran the business, Ramona\u2019s Mexican Food, herself.\n\nAs a business owner in the late 1940s, she would awaken at 2 a.m. and bring her toddler sons to work with her. While they slept on sacks of corn and flour, Ms. Ba\u00f1uelos said, she would grind the corn and make the dough to prepare for packing and delivery later. She would then head home for a shower and drop her children off at day care before boarding a public bus to make her deliveries.", "title": "Romana Acosta Ba\u00f1uelos, U.S. Treasurer Under Nixon, Dies at 92", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "In the lexicon of single New Yorkers, the term \u201cgeographically undesirable\u201d usually refers to those who live too many subway stops or bus rides away, or are a (Brooklyn) Bridge too far for serious relationship consideration. (Apps including JDate, OkCupid, Tinder and Match let members set a distance profile for just how far they are willing to go for love.)\n\nBut for some, \u201cgeographically undesirable\u201d means something else entirely: It is a synonym for \u201ctoo close for comfort.\u201d To such people, a bridge or tunnel is no bother at all; it is a buffer and a blessing.\n\nSo much for all those songs and books and movies about the irresistible charms of the boy, or girl, next door.\n\n\u201cManhattan is full of little pockets, and it\u2019s hard to stay in that pocket and try to date someone without it blowing up in your face and disrupting your daily life,\u201d Mr. Gurfein said. \u201cYou go out with that person and she knows someone else you dated, and they both know your friends, and all of a sudden it becomes high drama.\u201d\n\nHe dated someone in the neighborhood last summer only to learn that \u201cwe had hundreds of mutual friends,\u201d he said. \u201cThe amount of gossip it generated, the potential discomfort \u2014 it was not something you need when you\u2019re 48 years old.\u201d\n\nAnonymity is one of the benefits New York City provides its residents, \u201cand it\u2019s hard when that filter of anonymity is pierced,\u201d said Kathy Braddock, a managing director at William Raveis New York City. \u201cBut that\u2019s what can happen when you date too locally.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe added: \u201cYou go pick up something at the liquor store, and you find out that your former significant other was just there and bought the scotch you used to buy him. You go down the street and you see your old boyfriend with his new girlfriend. And suddenly, your home, your neighborhood is no longer what it should be: a sanctuary.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs Nicole Beauchamp, a sales agent at Engel & Volkers put it, \u201cWe all think New York is a big city, but at the end of the day, it\u2019s a small town.\u201d\n\nAnd for some single people, Ms. Beauchamp said, there comes a point when they get set in their ways and want their neighborhood space to stay their space. For them, having to travel for a relationship is actually a plus.\n\nSometimes it takes a while to come around to that way of thinking. Amy Wilcox once thought it would be really handy to date someone who lived just a few blocks away. That was before she started dating someone who lived just a few blocks away.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t that things ended badly. It was simply that things ended, and \u201cthen I saw him in line waiting for the bathroom at a local bar,\u201d said Ms. Wilcox, 27, a nanny who shares a Williamsburg rental with two roommates.\n\nIt was a bit uncomfortable, but it wasn\u2019t as uncomfortable as a subsequent encounter with another man who \u2014 well, let\u2019s simply say that Ms. Wilcox just wasn\u2019t that into him.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019d gone on a few dates, and I told him nicely that I wasn\u2019t interested in pursuing things,\u201d she said. \u201cSome people, when you tell them that, just accept it, and some people want to know why. And he was in the category of wanting to know why.\u201d\n\nWho can explain such things? Certainly not Ms. Wilcox.\n\nSome weeks later, she ordered an Uber pool. She was in the middle of a phone call when the car showed up, which is probably why she didn\u2019t take immediate notice of the man in the back seat, the one with his head turned away as far as anatomically possible, the one who hadn\u2019t been able to get his head around why Ms. Wilcox was disinclined to pursue a relationship. He maintained that posture until arriving at his stop.\n\n\u201cIt was very awkward,\u201d Ms. Wilcox said. \u201cI should have learned my lesson in college when I dated someone across the hall in my dorm.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe and others talk about the pressure of keeping up appearances both while a romance is in full flower and after the bloom has departed the rose\n\n\u201cWhen I\u2019ve gone out with someone in my neighborhood, or even when I\u2019ve broken up with someone, it makes me think twice about running outside in sweatpants and yesterday\u2019s mascara,\u201d Ms. Wilcox said. \u201cThe truth is, I really don\u2019t want to see anyone I\u2019m not expecting to see. And when it\u2019s someone I used to have feelings for, it\u2019s left me flustered and trying to come up with the right thing to say. It\u2019s nice to have peace of mind and walk around and not worry you\u2019ll end up in an awkward, forced conversation.\u201d\n\nAnd you take on extra responsibilities, she believes, when you date locally. \u201cBecause you\u2019re likely to run into the person, you have to be thoughtful about how you end the relationship,\u201d Ms. Wilcox said. \u201cYou\u2019re going to be more accountable for the way you left things.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKayley Oshan understands about accountability. She wishes a former boyfriend, someone she met in her neighborhood, Two Bridges, understood it as well.\n\n\u201cWe went out for six months, and all of a sudden he disappeared,\u201d said Ms. Oshan, 32, an account manager at a risk management firm. \u201cThere was no argument. He just stopped calling.\u201d\n\nA few months later, the two bumped into each other. They spoke briefly, but not about the ghosting, and went their separate ways. Some time later, their paths crossed again, \u201cand I confronted him,\u201d Ms. Oshan recalled. \u201cHe explained, but it was just a bunch of excuses.\u201d\n\nNow, when she spots him \u2014 a fairly frequent occurrence \u2014 \u201cI walk in the other direction or cross the street to avoid him. I won\u2019t make eye contact,\u201d she said. \u201cOne time when we ran into each other, my face was bright red because I had just had a facial. The timing couldn\u2019t have been worse.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen you dated someone and you don\u2019t anymore, you want to look your best when you see him,\u201d added Ms. Oshan, who now has a live-in boyfriend, someone she met on Long Island.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAshlie Roberson used to be one of those people who didn\u2019t want to travel far for a date. No more than three stops on the subway \u2014 that was her rule.\n\nThen she met someone on OkCupid, a \u201clovely guy\u201d who \u201cchecked all the boxes,\u201d said Ms. Roberson, now 29, a real estate salesperson at Triplemint. The two had many phone chats and exchanged numerous texts over the course of a month, learning, among other things, that they both lived in Hell\u2019s Kitchen. \u201cBut that was fine,\u201d she thought. \u201cIt\u2019s a big neighborhood.\u201d\n\nFinally, they agreed the time had come to meet, and the man suggested a restaurant two avenues west and several blocks north of Ms. Roberson\u2019s studio apartment in a high-rise rental.\n\n\u201cI assumed it was close to where he lived, but I was fine walking that distance,\u201d Ms. Roberson said. All the more so because it was a truly great first date. The couple talked for hours, later adjourning to the jazz club next door. At the end of the evening, the man offered to walk Ms. Roberson home, and she gladly accepted.\n\nThey ambled across 10th Avenue, across 9th and over to 8th Avenue. \u201cWe started getting closer to my building, and when we got in front of it he said, \u2018You live here? I live here.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Roberson mutely pointed up at her apartment on the 43rd floor; her date\u2019s was on the exact same line, two floors below.\n\n\u201cAfter I got home,\u201d she said, \u201cI got a text from him that said, \u2018Great to finally meet you. It\u2019s hilarious that we live in the same building.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut it wasn\u2019t hilarious to Ms. Roberson, who didn\u2019t respond. \u201cIt gave me the creeps,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was like I\u2019d moved in with him. I saw him in the elevator. I saw him in the gym. I ran into him in the residents\u2019 lounge, and he asked why I hadn\u2019t answered his text. I was mortified.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Roberson has since moved to another building in Hell\u2019s Kitchen (but not because of the unsuitable suitor) and has a boyfriend who lives well out of the neighborhood.\n\nShawn Kennedy can\u2019t use ignorance as an excuse for dating a woman who lived in his building. He knew her address before they began keeping company.\n\n\u201cThe whole thing created a problem for me and for anyone who came to visit me,\u201d said Mr. Kennedy, 39, a cabdriver and entrepreneur who lives in a rental in the Bronx. \u201cIf she saw me with other women, she would jump in their faces and say, \u2018Who are you?\u2019 And it could have been a family member.\u201d\n\nTo be entirely fair, Mr. Kennedy would get similarly jealous when he saw another man show up at his girlfriend\u2019s door. \u201cYou can\u2019t help seeing who\u2019s visiting if you\u2019re in the same building.\u201d\n\nIt didn\u2019t help that the two of them traveled in the same circles, \u201cso people would carry news about one of us to the other one,\u201d he said. \u201cThere was just no breathing room. My friends and I would be hanging out in front of the building, and someone would ask my girlfriend to join us. And if we\u2019d be having a fight, it meant one of us had to leave.\u201d\n\nEver since, Mr. Kennedy said, \u201cmy first question before I\u2019d consider going out with someone was \u2018Where do you live?\u2019 It had to be a different borough. If the answer was \u2018the Bronx,\u2019 I wouldn\u2019t be interested.\u201d\n\nHe is now married. His wife lives in Brooklyn. \u201cYou know,\u201d Mr. Kennedy said, \u201cit works out perfectly.\u201d\n\nStephanie Sica isn\u2019t quite that territorially rigid. It is true that when she was a renter in NoLIta, she did her best to dampen the ardor of two men in the building who asked her out. One got the message; the other did not.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe was very persistent, and he would text me and ask about hanging out, or he would try to join me in a walk when I was out with my dog,\u201d said Ms. Sica, the founder and chief executive of Orchard and Broome, a boutique public relations company. \u201cI think I ended up ignoring a lot of his texts. I hate being put in that position.\u201d\n\nShe now lives in a one-bedroom co-op in the West Village, and she loves the neighborhood so much that she might even be willing to consider dating someone hyper-local.\n\n\u201cIf the connection is right, it\u2019s right,\u201d she said. \u201cYou just hope if they live in the building that they\u2019re right next door, so you can combine the apartments.\u201d", "title": "Romance? Not in My Backyard", "authors": ["Joanne Kaufman"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "In The New York Times Book Review, Michelle Goldberg reviews Rose McGowan\u2019s \u201cBrave.\u201d Goldberg writes:\n\nImage\n\nIf I had read Rose McGowan\u2019s new memoir, \u201cBrave,\u201d in a vacuum, absent the feats of investigative reporting that took down the former Miramax head Harvey Weinstein, I would have thought it overwrought and paranoid. McGowan describes a life of almost ceaseless abuse, of falling into the clutches of one sadistic ogre after another as powerful forces conspired to crush her rogue spirit. \u201cMy life was infiltrated by Israeli spies and harassing lawyers, some of the most formidable on earth,\u201d she writes on the first page. \u201cThese evil people hounded me at every turn while I went about resurrecting the ghosts that have made up my time on earth.\u201d Come on \u2014 Israeli spies? Of course, we now know: Yes, Israeli spies.\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, McGowan talks about \u201cBrave\u201d; Katie Kitamura discusses Tom Malmquist\u2019s new novel, \u201cIn Every Moment We Are Still Alive\u201d; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; and in a new segment, Critical Mass, The Times\u2019s staff book critics, Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai, talk about books they\u2019ve recently reviewed. Pamela Paul is the host.\n\nWe would love to hear your thoughts about this episode, and about the Book Review\u2019s podcast in general. You can send them to books@nytimes.com.\n\nHow do I listen? If you think you\u2019re having trouble finding a mate, just try being Jeremy, the lefty brown garden snail whose unusual shell made it nearly impossible for him to find a suitable partner.\n\n\u2022 For every warm and fuzzy love story, there\u2019s a crushing tale of heartbreak. We even compiled proof. Here are a few tales of breakups and bad dates that are sure to make you happy to be alone.\n\n\u2022 And, even if you think you\u2019re in love, there\u2019s a pretty good chance you will marry the wrong person. Awesome, right?\n\nBut if you insist on falling in love \u2026\n\nVideo\n\nIt\u2019s easy! As this now-famous Modern Love essay tells us, just ask the person you wish to fall for this series of 36 increasingly personal questions. (If, however, you find that those questions worked entirely too well and you\u2019ve made a terrible mistake \u2014 i.e. \u201cmarried the wrong person\u201d \u2014 you can extricate yourself with these 13 questions that lead to divorce.)\n\nOr take an example from someone else.\n\nThe Times often writes about how couples go from dating to \u201cI Do.\u201d One of the most memorable recent stories of this kind came from C.J. Chivers, who won a Pulitzer Prize for a 2016 article about an Afghan war veteran suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder.\n\nLast year, he wrote again about the veteran, the woman who had loved the veteran since elementary school, and the long, weary road to their wedding day.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Here Is Your Guide to Valentine\u2019s Day.", "authors": ["Matt Stevens"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "MAL\u00c9, Maldives \u2014 Political opponents of the Maldives government clashed with the police on the streets of the capital early Friday after the Supreme Court overturned the conviction of a former president living in exile in Britain and ordered the release of several other imprisoned politicians.\n\nHundreds of people celebrated in Mal\u00e9, the capital, by waving the country\u2019s flag after the court overturned verdicts against former President Mohamed Nasheed and a former vice president that were the result of trials that were internationally condemned. The court said in its ruling late Thursday that the guilty verdicts had been influenced by the government.\n\nThe police dispersed the crowds from the streets using pepper spray and batons. Rocks were thrown at police officers, and at least one injured officer was seen being carried to a hospital.\n\nThe ruling could allow Mr. Nasheed, the country\u2019s first democratically elected president, to challenge President Abdulla Yameen when he seeks re-election later this year. Mr. Yameen, also known as Yameen Abdul Gayoom, is the half brother of former President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn Indian Ocean nation known for its luxury tourist resorts, Maldives became a multiparty democracy 10 years ago after decades of autocratic rule. But it lost much of its democratic gains after Mr. Yameen was elected in 2013. He has maintained a tight grip on power, controlling institutions like the judiciary, the police and the bureaucracy.", "title": "Ruling by Court in Maldives Breathes New Life Into Political Opposition", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "CAPE TOWN \u2014 This city celebrated for its natural beauty on South Africa\u2019s southwest coast is about to run out of water.\n\nStarting Thursday, we\u2019re being asked to curb our use of municipal water to 13.2 gallons a day. If water levels keep falling as expected, this will be reduced to 6.6 gallons on April 16, referred to here as Day Zero, when most taps are expected to be shut off and residents will have to line up at 200 distribution points for their daily allotment. In the lead-up to Day Zero, those who don\u2019t abide by the restrictions will face fines and may have water-monitoring devices placed on their properties.\n\nYes, this is actually happening in South Africa\u2019s second-most populous city, a sprawling metropolis with nearly four million people.\n\nAlready, we have buckets under every faucet to capture water from hand washing, teeth brushing and food washing. This becomes the gray water we use to flush our toilets once or twice a day. Cafes and restaurants have signs asking customers to flush only when necessary. Showering has become a special (and rare) ritual; radio stations have put out playlists of songs lasting two minutes to help bathers keep it quick. Clothes are worn multiple times before washing; people try to keep their sheets clean longer by washing their feet before getting into bed. Some restaurants and gyms have replaced sinks with hand-sanitizing stations.", "title": "Opinion | Running Dry in Cape Town", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Brandon Huffman, the national recruiting editor for 24/7 Sports, recalled how fast and fluid Stanton looked. \u201cIt was like he glided downfield,\u201d Huffman said. \u201cIt didn\u2019t look like he was that fast, but he had long strides. It was like watching a center fielder who knows how much ground he has to cover.\u201d\n\nJudge, like Stanton, was a three-sport standout, playing football, basketball and baseball in Linden, Calif., a Central Valley farming community just east of Stockton.\n\nWhile Judge received recruiting interest from Notre Dame, Washington and U.C.L.A., he made it clear to most schools that he was interested in playing only baseball. A few, such as Eastern Michigan and Portland State, offered to let him play both, but Judge thought playing two sports \u2014 along with the academic challenges of college \u2014 would be too much, so he focused on baseball at Fresno State.\n\n\u201cI thought if I could find a place where I could just play baseball, that would be great,\u201d he said.\n\nFurther dampening the idea of playing football was the fact that he might not have played receiver. Judge, who was a Cal fan \u2014 in part because his older brother John went to school there \u2014 attended a football camp in Berkeley before his senior season.\n\n\u201cThey knew I enjoyed football, but that I had baseball on the mind,\u201d Judge said. \u201cThe receiver coach said, \u2018I like you, but we\u2019ll bulk you up and put you at tight end, to be honest.\u2019\u201d\n\nIf that idea did not appeal to Judge at the time, he did not seem put off that Wilson viewed him as a tight end, figuring that Wilson would make him look good with a few passes.\n\nWilson did not have a football with him, but said he would by the end of the week. Just as he is showing off what he might do with a baseball bat in his hands, Judge and Stanton might be able to show what they can do with a football in theirs.\n\n\u201cYou might catch us out on a backfield running some routes,\u201d Judge said with a smile.\n\nINSIDE PITCH\n\nOutfielder Clint Frazier was found to have a concussion.
