Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Schumer, North Korea, Los Angeles Times: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing", "authors": ["Karen Zraick", "Sandra Stevenson"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "A researcher seeking instruction in the sophisticated use of such techniques may want to consult OBSERVATION AND EXPERIMENT: An Introduction to Causal Inference (Harvard University, $35), by the statistician Paul R. Rosenbaum. The methodology of statistical significance, along with that of randomized experimentation, was developed by the statistician R. A. Fisher in the 1920s and \u201930s. Fisher was aware that statistical significance was not a measure of the likelihood that, say, a certain drug was effective, given the data. He knew it revealed the likelihood of the data, assuming the null hypothesis that there was no treatment effect from the drug. But as Rosenbaum\u2019s book demonstrates, this was by no means an admission of inadequacy. Fisher\u2019s aim was to show, through proper experimental design and analysis, how the investigation of the null hypothesis speaks \u201cdirectly and plainly\u201d to a question we want to answer: Namely, is there good evidence that the drug had any treatment effect? That many researchers are careless with this technique is not the fault of the methodology.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDiaconis and Skyrms declare themselves to be \u201cthorough Bayesians,\u201d unwavering followers of the 18th-century thinker Thomas Bayes, who laid down the basic mathematics for the coveted \u201cinverse\u201d inference \u2014 straight from the data to the degree of confidence in your hypothesis. (This is Diaconis and Skyrms\u2019s sixth \u201cgreat idea\u201d about chance.) Bayesian statistics purports to show how to rationally update your beliefs over time, in the face of new evidence. It does so by mathematically unifying three factors: your initial confidence in your hypothesis (\u201cI\u2019m pretty sure this coin is weighted\u201d); your confidence in the accuracy of the data, given your hypothesis (\u201cI\u2019d fully expect to see a weighted coin come up heads five times in a row\u201d); and your confidence in the accuracy of the data, setting aside your hypothesis (\u201cI\u2019d be quite surprised, but not shocked, to see a fair coin come up heads five times in a row\u201d). In this way, Diaconis and Skyrms argue, the Bayesian approach reckons with the \u201ctotality of evidence,\u201d and thus offers researchers valuable guidance as they address the replication crisis.\n\nThough psychological and biomedical research have received the most attention, neuroscientific experiments involving brain-scanning machines have also been criticized for generating hard-to-reproduce results. For the psychologist Jerome Kagan, brain-scanning technology holds out the exciting prospect of learning the relationship between brain states and mental phenomena. But as he notes in FIVE CONSTRAINTS ON PREDICTING BEHAVIOR (M.I.T., $30), most of the psychological conclusions drawn from brain-scanning data are \u201ctentative\u201d and others \u201care simply wrong.\u201d The reason for this, he argues, is a group of five obstacles, often overlooked, that prevent making \u201cconfident inferences\u201d from what our brains are doing to what our minds are doing.\n\nOne obstacle is the potentially disruptive effect of the laboratory context. A research subject lying horizontal in the tight confines of a brain-scanning machine is \u201cin an unusual psychological and bodily state.\u201d This can influence what is going on in the brain. Feeling hemmed in, mindful of being evaluated, asked to hold physically still, the subject may exhibit a brain reaction in response to an image of a deadly snake that is different than he would have, had he seen a deadly snake in the course of a pleasant mountain hike. Or consider the distorting effect of expectation. Kagan notes that unexpected events activate \u201cmany brain sites.\u201d Police detectives studying a gruesome crime scene may experience fear or disgust, but they are seldom startled by what they see. On the other hand, volunteers for an fMRI study may not \u201cexpect the examiner to show them pictures of violence, sex, blood or diseased bodies.\u201d If those pictures, say, activate the amygdala, how do we know we are detecting fear or disgust as opposed to surprise?\n\nPerhaps the most difficult challenge Kagan describes is the mismatching of the respective concepts and terminologies of brain science and psychology. Because neuroscientists lack a \u201crich biological vocabulary\u201d for the variety of brain states, they can be tempted to borrow correlates from psychology before they have shown there is in fact a correlation. On the psychology side, many concepts can be faddish or otherwise short-lived, which should make you skeptical that today\u2019s psychological terms will \u201cmap neatly\u201d onto information about the brain. If fMRI machines had been available a century ago, Kagan points out, we would have been searching for the neurological basis of Pavlov\u2019s \u201cfreedom reflex\u201d or Freud\u2019s \u201coral stage\u201d of development, no doubt in vain. Why should we be any more confident that today\u2019s psychological concepts will prove any better at cutting nature at the joints?", "title": "Science\u2019s Inference Problem: When Data Doesn\u2019t Mean What We Think It Does", "authors": ["James Ryerson", "Ivory Tower"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The hub of this region is La Macarena, a small town perched on the broad, silty Guayabero River. For decades, the government\u2019s war with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, a guerrilla army known as FARC, made this a risky place to visit.\n\nAfter the Colombian military established a stronger presence in the area about 12 years ago, a trickle of tourists began arriving. With Colombia\u2019s civil conflict winding down \u2014 a peace accord was signed in 2016 \u2014 the trickle became a flood.\n\nPhoto\n\nMore than 15,000 tourists visited the rainbow river last year, and Ms. D\u00edaz is one of more than 130 local guides. On busy days, hundreds of tourists disperse among seven designated sites managed by Cormacarena, a regional government agency focused on sustainable development. Several of the sites, including Ca\u00f1o Cristales, are part of Sierra de La Macarena National Park.\n\nIn 2009, Hupecol, a Colombian subsidiary of the Dan A. Hughes Company of Beeville, Tex., began seismic studies to look for oil on land it had leased near the small town of San Vicente del Cagu\u00e1n, west of here.\n\nThe Colombian government revoked the lease in 2016, and President Juan Manuel Santos wrote on Twitter that the decision would protect Ca\u00f1o Cristales and the surrounding area.\n\nThe revocation was popular in La Macarena, where Mayor Ismael Medellin Due\u00f1as, whose desk sits beneath a painting of Ca\u00f1o Cristales, said residents are very concerned about possible environmental impacts of oil development. The region\u2019s economic future rests on dairy farming and ecotourism, he said.\n\nPosters and murals against oil drilling emblazon the walls and windows of the town. \u201cOnce it was a FARC war,\u201d said Miguel Ortiz, an English teacher and interpreter who has lived here for 13 years. \u201cNow it\u2019s the fracking war.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nScientists are trying to learn more about the diverse and unique environment, where jaguars and margays roam the savannah and jungles, and river dolphins swim in the Guayabero River.\n\nCarlos Lasso, a senior investigator at the Humboldt Institute, a nonprofit dedicated to studying Colombia\u2019s biodiversity, has co-authored a 180-page guide to the fauna of Ca\u00f1o Cristales, part of a four-year regional study.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn late January, he led a two-week expedition in large dugout canoes to survey the Duda, Guayabero and Losada rivers. The team identified more than 50 species of aquatic birds, four species of aquatic snakes, and more than 150 species of fish, including three that may be new to science.\n\nThey also found Orinoco crocodiles, a critically endangered species that can grow to seven meters in length.\n\nThe humble M. clavigera plays a key role, not least because it attracts the tourists that drive the economy. The plant is endemic to the clear, acidic, nutrient-poor waters rivers flowing from the Serrania de la Macarena, an isolated mountain range east of the Andes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a unique ecosystem,\u201d Dr. Lasso said. \u201cAnd it\u2019s very fragile.\u201d\n\n\u00c1ngela Mar\u00eda Rodr\u00edguez, the integral sustainability manager at Hupecol, said there is a lot of misinformation about the oil project. To start, she said, Hupecol\u2019s oil lease was far from Ca\u00f1o Cristales.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no possibility of any impact, because it\u2019s 68 kilometers away,\u201d Ms. Rodr\u00edguez said. (That\u2019s about 42 miles.) Further, she said, the company had no interest in fracking, as some feared, only in conventional oil drilling.\n\nMs. Rodr\u00edguez described the decision to revoke Hupecol\u2019s permit as political, an opportunity for government officials to burnish their environmental credentials by protecting a popular tourist site.\n\nMs. Rodr\u00edguez said the seismic studies were promising, and Hupecol had hoped to drill an exploratory well. The company is seeking $21 million in damages in a court case against the government.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut now there is a new complication. A group of FARC dissidents, who did not disarm in the recent peace deal, is active in the area. \u201cRight now, we don\u2019t know if it\u2019s possible to drill a well in that area if the licenses comes back to us,\u201d Ms. Rodr\u00edguez said, citing the instability.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJavier Francisco Parra, the regional coordinator at Cormacarena, acknowledged that the Hupecol lease is not very close to Ca\u00f1o Cristales, but said it is hard to know whether it would pose a direct threat to the river.\n\nAnd oil drilling is incompatible with a regional management plan Cormacarena developed with the input of local residents, he said.\n\nMr. Parra sees another emerging threat: In recent years, there have been dry periods during the rainy season, and rain during the dry season.\n\nDr. Lasso said there is no long-term water flow data for Ca\u00f1o Cristales, but agreed that things appear to be changing. The river is closed to tourists during the dry season, and over the past decade, he said, the season has seemed to arrive earlier each year.\n\nThe timing could be part of a natural cycle, Dr. Lasso said, or related to local forest clearing. But it could also be linked to broader patterns of climate change.\n\nBack on Ca\u00f1o Piedras, Ms. Diaz, who works as a firefighter during the off-season, stood on the ancient rocks between M. clavigera and an oil seep, and said she is looking forward to May. The tourists will return, and the rivers will again run red.\n\nAnd Ms. D\u00edaz was clear about where she and her co-workers stand on the local controversy. \u201cThe guides,\u201d she said, \u201cwe don\u2019t want the oil drilling.\u201d", "title": "Scientists Fear for Colombia\u2019s \u2018Melted Rainbow\u2019", "authors": ["Murray Carpenter"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Both senators from Colorado, Senator Michael Bennet, a Democrat, and Senator Cory Gardner, a Republican \u2014 said through their representatives that anyone who knew about the Nassar accusations and did nothing must step down. The U.S.O.C. is based in Colorado.\n\nProbst said on Friday that Blackmun had acted just as he was supposed to after learning of the accusations against Nassar.\n\nBut the call for Blackmun\u2019s ouster shouldn\u2019t be just about the U.S.O.C.\u2019s role in the Nassar matter. Because it\u2019s certainly not the only sexual abuse scandal that has unfolded under Blackmun\u2019s watch.\n\nTo his credit, Blackmun spearheaded the efforts to create the Denver-based U.S. Center for SafeSport, a national nonprofit organization providing education and resources, including a hotline, to promote respect and prevent abuse in sport. It took seven years.\n\nOther sports, like swimming, taekwondo and judo, have had major abuse problems, and Blackmun was introduced to some of them soon after he took over as chief executive in 2010. Right away, he should have recognized that the U.S.O.C. needed to oversee the federations with a sharper eye and make it a priority to address abuse. He should have seen that it was the U.S.O.C.\u2019s duty to keep all athletes safe.\n\nIn 2010, three months after Blackmun was hired, U.S.A. Swimming came under fire for mishandling dozens of sexual abuse cases. That year, the swimming organization set up a program to investigate sexual abuse accusations within its own sport. But letting a federation investigate itself is never a good idea, and the abuse continued.\n\nIn 2016, U.S.A. Taekwondo told the U.S.O.C. that it had been investigating sexual assault accusations involving two of its biggest Olympic stars. But after consulting with the U.S.O.C., the taekwondo federation put the investigation on hold for the Rio Olympics, and those athletes competed at the Games, according to USA Today.", "title": "Scott Blackmun Gets to Keep His Job? Really?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Blackmun did not attend the recent Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea. But Larry Probst, the chairman of the Olympic committee\u2019s board, said at a news conference before the Games that Mr. Blackmun would keep his job \u2014 for which he was paid $1 million in 2016 \u2014 until the organization had completed an independent investigation of its actions in the Nassar matter.\n\nIn a phone interview on Wednesday, Mr. Probst attributed Mr. Blackmun\u2019s resignation to his health, but the organization acknowledged the urgency of the scandal and outlined multiple reforms alongside the change in leadership. Those included increased funding for Dr. Nassar\u2019s victims and a plan to re-examine the basic governance structure of American Olympic sports.\n\nMr. Probst said Mr. Blackmun and the board agreed that the organization \u201cneeded a C.E.O. who can work 24-7 as we navigate through this situation.\u201d\n\nAsked whether he felt it was appropriate for him to remain as chairman of the Olympic committee, Mr. Probst said, \u201cI serve at the discretion of the board, so that is really a question for them to answer.\u201d He added that he was confident that he and the current board members were \u201cthe appropriate group of people to lead the organization through these difficult times.\u201d\n\nSusanne Lyons, a former executive at Visa who has belonged to the committee\u2019s board since 2010, will serve as acting chief executive until a permanent replacement is found, the organization said.\n\nMs. Lyons said she wanted the committee to re-evaluate its relationship with the national governing bodies of each sport and make sure it has \u201cclear-cut authorization to intercede\u201d when appropriate.\n\n\u201cI understand that may involve opening up the Amateur Sports Act,\u201d she said in a phone interview, referring to the four-decade-old legislation that puts the U.S.O.C. in charge of amateur sports in the United States but also limits its power to interfere with the business of national sports federations.", "title": "Scott Blackmun Steps Down as Head of U.S.O.C. Under Pressure From Nassar Case", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Hamilton laughed off my assumptions.\n\nIn the past 21 years, he has faced Stage 4 testicular cancer, followed by three brain tumors \u2014 one every six years since 2004. He\u2019s living with a brain tumor right now.\n\nSo in the fall of 2014, when Hamilton reached out to Jim Bell, NBC\u2019s president of Olympics production and programming, to find out if he would be working on Skate America that October, Bell called him back to break the news. NBC valued him and adored him, Hamilton recalled Bell saying, and the network appreciated all his years at the top. But it was time for a change.\n\n\u201cThere was a sadness for about 10 minutes,\u201d Hamilton said last week at the Olympic figure skating arena. \u201cI lamented it being over. I thought, \u2018Oh, man, that was such a beautiful part of my life and now it\u2019s over.\u2019 But change happens to everyone \u2014 even me.\u201d\n\nHamilton gets it. Something like this happens to even the best of us \u2014 eventually \u2014 right? Corporate America decided that his shelf life had expired. There was nothing he could do about it.\n\nBesides, after he had spent so many years just trying to stay healthy \u2014 and alive \u2014 how could being replaced by the next big thing really matter? In his heart, Hamilton knew it did not. He would bounce back, almost out of habit.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI calculated once how many times I fell during my skating career \u2014 41,600 times,\u201d he said. \u201cBut here\u2019s the funny thing: I got up 41,600 times. That\u2019s the muscle you have to build in your psyche \u2014 the one that reminds you to just get up.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLooking ahead, Hamilton knew there was so much more to worry about and, in the end, so much he decided not to worry about.\n\nAfter overcoming testicular cancer in 1997, he learned that he had a pituitary tumor in 2004, one that had wrapped itself around his optic nerve. The tumor was benign, but it threatened to grow in ways that dangerously crowded his brain.\n\nHamilton said he had prayed about 12 times a day for it to go away. Doctors treated him with radiation, and the tumor did go away.\n\nIn 2010, it reappeared. Surgery caused an aneurysm that temporarily blinded him in one eye.\n\nHamilton said he would never forget what his wife, Tracie, said to him during a pep talk: \u201cJoy is not the lack of suffering or fear, it\u2019s how you choose to handle the suffering and fear.\u201d It finally hit him that it was true.\n\nSo when the tumor returned for an encore in 2016, Hamilton decided to react differently. There was no \u201cwhy me?\u201d anymore.\n\n\u201cI figured I needed to go through this with joy,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was just a muscle I needed to build, like the muscles I built skating.\u201d\n\nWhen one of his four children asked about the tumor, Hamilton said: \u201cYep, it\u2019s back. It\u2019s fine, it\u2019s fine, it\u2019s really fine.\u201d\n\nFine \u2014 but also time to fight back in a new way. There was no chance to undergo radiation treatment again. It would only have fried his brain, he said. The tumor was still relatively small, so Hamilton didn\u2019t need to rush into surgery. He tried to tackle the problem differently: He stopped eating sugar, red meat and other things he considered bad for his body. He started eating organic food and drinking only coffee or water with high pH. He hit the treadmill and the weight room.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Hamilton went back to the doctor several months later, he learned that his tumor hadn\u2019t grown. During his next checkup, he heard even better news.\n\nThe tumor had shrunk, by about half. Hamilton choked up when describing what happened next.\n\n\u201cHave you ever had one shrink without treatment before?\u201d he said he asked the doctor. \u201cAnd the doctor said, \u2018Nope, never.\u2019\u201d\n\nHamilton asked, \u201cSo how can you explain this?\u201d\n\nThe doctor said, \u201cGod.\u201d\n\nIt floored him. He was in the process of losing three friends to colon cancer, yet he, somehow, someway, was given this miracle? At his latest doctor\u2019s visit, in December, the tumor was even smaller.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAt some point, this tumor is going to start growing again, and it\u2019s going to start causing its mischief, and I\u2019m going to have to deal with it,\u201d he said. \u201cBut for now there must be a reason I\u2019ve gotten this pass. There\u2019s something that I need to be doing. I just have to figure out what that is.\u201d\n\nDuring the figure skating events last week, Hamilton stood on a riser just above Lipinski, Weir and Terry Gannon, the third member of the main broadcasting team. Hamilton couldn\u2019t miss them when the lights came on and they were on center stage, just as he used to be. He looked on, often peeking at them over his reading glasses. But he said the change hadn\u2019t been awkward, and Lipinski echoed that.\n\n\u201cWhen I first started as a commentator, I listened to all of Scott\u2019s tapes and learned so much because he was so incredible,\u201d said Lipinski, who won the Olympic gold medal in 1998. \u201cHe called my Olympics and was like a big brother to me when we toured together. He\u2019s been a mentor and, of course, he was at my wedding last summer. I think this whole thing is just a natural progression for us.\u201d\n\nShe said he was still involved in the broadcast \u201cin a big way\u201d because he brings something unique \u2014 and that\u2019s Scott Hamilton being Scott Hamilton.\n\n\u201cHe has such enthusiasm for the sport,\u201d she said.\n\nHe\u2019s a legend in skating arenas. So much so that Maxim Trankov, half of the Russian pairs team that won gold in 2014, stopped Hamilton on Wednesday and asked him to pose for a selfie.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOh, wow, thank you so much,\u201d Trankov said. \u201cI watched you skate all the time when I was a kid. You\u2019re amazing.\u201d\n\nHamilton returned the compliment and told Trankov they should grab coffee sometime. He was gracious, as always.\n\n\u201cThere was a little apprehension coming to these Olympics because nobody likes change,\u201d he told me. \u201cBut I\u2019ve decided to make this fun because I\u2019m doing things joyfully. And, turns out, it is fun.\u201d", "title": "Scott Hamilton Was Demoted as an Olympic Broadcaster. Don\u2019t Feel Sorry for Him.", "authors": ["Juliet Macur", "Sports Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "The political dispute within the Washington-backed government deepened on Sunday when another governor and ally of Mr. Noor in the north, Abdul Karim Khadam, refused an order from Mr. Ghani that he resign as governor of Samangan Province.\n\n\u201cThe government\u2019s decision is unjust and unfair,\u201d Mr. Khadam said in a telephone interview, adding that it goes against a power-sharing agreement reached last spring between the Jamiat party and the president.\n\nMr. Khadam took pains to emphasize that his refusal to obey the order did not amount to an armed rebellion. \u201cOur opposition to the government does not mean we are rebelling,\u201d he said.\n\nStill, the growing standoff spells trouble for the Kabul government. Mr. Dostum retains the title of vice president.\n\nMr. Ghani appointed as the new leader of Samangan an associate of a onetime insurgent leader and Taliban ally, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, who reconciled with the government last year. Last season, six children in the city died of flu-related illness.\n\nOn Monday, officials reiterated the need for residents to take precautions.\n\n\u201cThe influenza season is far from over, and it is not too late to get the flu shot,\u201d the health department said in a statement. \u201cWe urge parents to protect themselves and their families by getting this potentially life-saving vaccine today. In addition to health care settings, flu vaccines are also available at pharmacies for children as young as two years old.", "title": "Second Child in New York City Dies of Flu-Related Illness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "The immigration lawyers who brought the case nonetheless hailed his ruling as a victory.\n\n\u201cDuring a week when the Senate is having a battle over immigration, we now have two judges saying that what happened on Sept. 5 was not justified,\u201d said Marisol Orihuela, a lawyer from the Jerome N. Frank Legal Services Organization at Yale Law School. \u201cThis sends a clear message to lawmakers to act and pass something.\u201d\n\nAfter the decision, Mr. Schneiderman said in a statement that the judge had affirmed the states\u2019 position. \u201cFederal courts from coast to coast have now reviewed the record and reached the same conclusion,\u201d Mr. Schneiderman said. \u201cPresident Trump\u2019s decision to rescind DACA was illegal.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, Devin O\u2019Malley, a spokesman for the Justice Department, reiterated arguments that the government had made before Judge Garaufis, saying that DACA was \u201can unlawful circumvention of Congress\u201d and that the Department of Homeland Security had \u201cacted within its lawful authority.\u201d\n\n\u201cPromoting and enforcing the rule of law is vital to protecting a nation, its borders, and its citizens,\u201d Mr. O\u2019Malley added. \u201cThe Justice Department will continue to vigorously defend this position, and looks forward to vindicating its position in further litigation.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSince the Trump administration\u2019s decision to end the program, Judge Garaufis wrote, more than 100 DACA recipients a day have been losing their protected status \u2014 a number, he noted, that could rise to as many as 1,400 a day once the program officially ends on March 5. All of them could face deportation, he said; some may face the loss of health care, imposing burdens not only on the immigrants themselves, but also on public hospitals. Employers will be hurt as DACA recipients lose their jobs, Judge Garaufis added, \u201cresulting in staggering adverse economic impacts\u201d that could include up to $800 million in lost tax revenue.\n\nEnding DACA would also have \u201cprofound and irreversible\u201d social costs, Judge Garaufis said, as hundreds of thousands of recipients are separated from their families. \u201cIt is impossible to understand the full consequences of a decision of this magnitude,\u201d he wrote.\n\nThough he has repeatedly said that he would prefer Congress, not the courts, fix DACA, Judge Garaufis has from the start of the case had tough words for the government in general and for Mr. Trump specifically. At a hearing in January, he slammed Mr. Trump for his \u201crecurring redundant drumbeat of anti-Latino commentary.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t ordinary,\u201d Judge Garaufis said. \u201cIn this country, in over 250 years, it\u2019s extreme, it\u2019s recurrent and it\u2019s vicious.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the same hearing, Judge Garaufis also took a shot at Mr. Sessions, who had rebuked him at a speech in October for an earlier remark the judge had made calling the repeal of DACA \u201cheartless.\u201d Citing the speech, Judge Garaufis said in open court that Mr. Sessions \u201cseems to think that courts don\u2019t get to have their own opinions.\u201d\n\nIn his ruling on Tuesday, Judge Garaufis based his decision to keep DACA in place for now on the Administrative Procedure Act, which forbids the government from acting arbitrarily or capriciously in changing federal policy. He noted that lawyers for the government had initially claimed that DACA was ended out a fear that the program would be struck down as illegal, much as a federal court in Texas had done in 2015 with a similar program known as DAPA, which protected the parents of young immigrants.\n\nBut, Judge Garaufis wrote, \u201cthe administrative record does not support defendants\u2019 contention that they decided to end DACA for this reason.\u201d In fact, he added, the government had showed \u201ca failure to explain their decision\u201d at all.", "title": "Second Federal Judge Issues Injunction to Keep DACA in Place", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "For Cairo, the Israeli intervention has helped the Egyptian military regain its footing in its nearly five-year battle against the militants. For Israel, the strikes have bolstered the security of its borders and the stability of its neighbor.\n\nTheir collaboration in the North Sinai is the most dramatic evidence yet of a quiet reconfiguration of the politics of the region. Shared enemies like ISIS, Iran and political Islam have quietly brought the leaders of several Arab states into growing alignment with Israel \u2014 even as their officials and news media continue to vilify the Jewish state in public.\n\nAmerican officials say Israel\u2019s air campaign has played a decisive role in enabling the Egyptian armed forces to gain an upper hand against the militants. But the Israeli role is having some unexpected consequences for the region, including on Middle East peace negotiations, in part by convincing senior Israeli officials that Egypt is now dependent on them even to control its own territory.\n\nSeven current or former British and American officials involved in Middle East policy described the Israeli attacks inside Egypt, all speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss classified information.\n\nSpokesmen for the Israeli and Egyptian militaries declined to comment, and so did a spokesman for the Egyptian foreign ministry.", "title": "Secret Alliance: Israel Carries Out Airstrikes in Egypt, With Cairo\u2019s O.K.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Separately, White House officials left the details of the president\u2019s $1.5 trillion infrastructure plan to Congress. (The origin of the name is a subject of dispute.)\n\nOver the next decade, Mr. Wilcox and his wife, Daeida, conjured out of the desert a strict Christian community of orchards and Victorian cottages, connected to Los Angeles by a lone streetcar line.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere were just a few hundred residents, and the hamlet banned alcohol, bowling alleys and even, briefly, movie theaters. But in 1910, Hollywood voted to merge with Los Angeles.\n\nSoon, movie studios fled the enforcement of Thomas Edison\u2019s monopoly on film patents and started setting up in the ideal Southern California light.\n\nIn 1923, the Hollywoodland sign went up (it was truncated to Hollywood in 1949). The original sign was an illuminated billboard for a segregated housing development that called itself a fortress against \u201cmetropolitanism\u201d; one ad urged, \u201cProtect your family.\u201d\n\nThe sign was left up as the so-called Golden Age of Hollywood arrived, a noirish era embodied by the starlet Peg Entwistle, who jumped to her death from the H in 1932.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPenn Bullock contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. Just as quickly, gun rights supporters have criticized the companies for their stance.", "title": "Security Clearance, N.R.A., Ben Carson: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "A security guard at the National September 11 Memorial and Museum and a Florida man face firearms trafficking charges after selling more than 25 guns \u2014 including a MAC-10 machine pistol \u2014 to an undercover officer, the authorities said on Friday.\n\nThe security guard, Maquan Moore, 29, of Manhattan, allegedly conspired with Morris Wilson, 32, of Orlando, to sell the guns. Prosecutors say Mr. Moore sold several guns to an undercover officer in Lower Manhattan, and that Mr. Wilson brought some of the weapons to New York from Florida.\n\nEach faces multiple counts related to the movement, transportation and receipt of firearms. If convicted of all counts, Mr. Moore would face a maximum penalty of 30 years in prison; Mr. Wilson would face 15 years.\n\nLawyers for the two men could not immediately be reached on Friday.\n\nThe men \u201care responsible for illegally introducing into Manhattan scores of illegal firearms \u2014 including assault-style weapons capable of inflicting mass casualties \u2014 and knowingly doing so in the neighborhood of a nearby school,\u201d Geoffrey S. Berman, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said in a statement on Friday. \u201cTheir alleged disregard for public safety could have had catastrophic consequences. The danger of selling unlicensed firearms cannot be overstated.\u201d", "title": "Security Guard at 9/11 Memorial Charged With Trafficking Firearms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The researchers trapped pea plants in glass chambers with ether, soaked roots of the sensitive plant and seedlings of garden cress in lidocaine and even measured the electrical activity of a Venus fly trap\u2019s cells. An hour or so later the plants became unresponsive. The seedlings stayed dormant. And the Venus fly trap didn\u2019t react to a stimulus similar to a bug crawling across its maw. Its cells stopped firing.\n\nWhen the dope wore off, the plants returned to life, as if something had hit pause \u2014 almost like they were regaining consciousness, something we typically don\u2019t think they possess. It\u2019s all so animal-like.\n\n\u201cHow organisms are perceiving the environment or responding or adapting are based on some very similar principles,\u201d Dr. Baluska said.\n\nResearchers already knew that anesthetics with different chemical structures or elements all seem to halt pain, consciousness or activity in plants and animals \u2014 even bacteria. But how they render us unconscious or how so many different kinds physically act on the human nervous system still elude us after more than a century of use. Some bind to receptors to turn off activity. But this can\u2019t explain them all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnder anesthetics, the physical properties of cell membranes change, becoming more flexible. Apply pressure to the cells, this effect is reversed and the anesthetic wears off. This suggests that something simple, like what is physically happening to a cell\u2019s membrane, may be the common denominator explaining anesthetics\u2019 effects across the plant and animal kingdoms, Dr. Baluska and colleagues suggest.\n\nMore Reporting on Plant Science\n\nIn some plant root cells under anesthesia, Dr. Baluska and his colleagues found that membranes were having trouble doing what they normally do, recycling bits of cellular material by transporting it in and out of cells.\n\nDr. Baluska can\u2019t say what was altering membrane function in the plants, but membranes are important for transferring messages via electricity from one cell to another, messages that would lead to action or movement.\n\nThe electrical activity that moves across neurons is thought by some scientists to contribute to human consciousness. If electrical activity is being disrupted by anesthetic in plants, too, causing them to \u201close consciousness,\u201d does that mean, in some way, that they are conscious?\n\n\u201cNo one can answer this because you cannot ask them,\u201d said Dr. Baluska.\n\nEven so, perhaps we\u2019re more alike, us and plants, than we think.", "title": "Sedate a Plant, and It Seems to Lose Consciousness. Is It Conscious?", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "At this point, I\u2019d opened the puzzle up a little bit but hadn\u2019t quite cracked it open. I didn\u2019t yet see the commonality between ART and ERICA. Third time\u2019s a charm, though; I got 77A, PRIM COLORS, and 78D, MARY: (across) PRI \u2014 (down) MARY \u2014 (across) COLORS, and recognized that all of the corresponding down answers, that created the punch lines for each them clue, were names.\n\nSo, looping around to that theme entry, 68A? If you\u2019re \u201csupercilious,\u201d you might be a NAME DROPPER.\n\nThe word supercilious derives from the Latin word for \u201ceyebrow,\u201d and one can very easily see how someone \u201cputting on airs\u201d would be depicted with their eyebrows raised as they literally looked down on anyone they felt better than. Before I had solved the titular theme clue, I enjoyed the cleverness of Ms. Long\u2019s making us figuratively look down on others to completely get this puzzle.\n\nPhoto\n\nSmall spoiler ahead: If you\u2019re still finding that the only names that come to mind are epithets, the three that are left are BILL, ANNE and FRANK.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nI think the theme was tougher to get than the fill this week, but your mileage may vary.\n\n5A: There are a lot of different prayer books among the religions. On a weekday, the additional hint of \u201cCatholic\u201d might help narrow the choices down for \u201cPrayer books\u201d and help you solve with MISSALS; I had \u201chymnals\u201d for a while, myself.\n\n21A: It\u2019s fair to say that there\u2019s probably nothing sweet or nice being used as a \u201cpesticide ingredient\u201d; I garden as a hobby, chemical-free, and I have often experienced the heartbreak of a nearly ripe crop being overrun with some insane alien invasion. I wasn\u2019t expecting URETHANE here; I\u2019ve always thought of this as a plastic used in bowling balls and roller skate wheels. As they say, plastics do it all.\n\n64: I was 100 percent sure there was a typo in this clue, \u201cOpposite of ennemies.\u201d I\u2019ve taken French in school more than once and tried to learn it conversationally several times, and I bandy about terms like \u201cmes AMIES favories\u201d when I\u2019m trying to get more than one person to do something for me. The word for enemy in French is simply \u201cennemi,\u201d but I simply don\u2019t recall ever seeing it before. This summer, I will attack mes ennemies, les aphides et les beetles japonais, tous les jours! Bonne chance \u00e0 moi et vous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n5D: I was looking for a more abstruse entry to this Sunday clue, like aurora borealis I guess, and it didn\u2019t help that for some time I had an H for the M in MOONSET since I had incorrectly entered 5A. For some reason, I didn\u2019t think of the moon and the sun \u201cswapping places,\u201d but now that I\u2019ve got it (I think) it\u2019s a pretty cool phenomenon.\n\n72D: By far my favorite clue in this well-clued puzzle, I thought of a few different references to LOTUS EATERS, from the Odyssey itself to \u201cUlysses,\u201d in which a fabulous episode concerns escapism and our natural tendency to do whatever it takes to avoid, at least in our minds, the struggle existence can be.\n\n91D: This is one of those crossword chestnuts, ONEOCAT, that comes up here and there, probably because of the arrangement of vowels. I\u2019ve never given it much thought but because of the kitty up top today I figured I\u2019d check it out, and I think the \u201cOld Cat\u201d games might be one of the few historical phenomena I\u2019ve found that seem quite under-researched.\n\nIs there some awful skeleton in the closet of early baseball history? I could find hardly any information on \u201cone o\u2019cat\u201d, \u201ctwo o\u2019cat\u201d or \u201cthree o\u2019cat\u201d, the last essentially being the progenitor of baseball, if I understand correctly. Basically, in the game of one o\u2019cat it seems that the pitcher\u2019s mound is the only base, or \u201ccat,\u201d and you stand at home plate, hit a ball, and run frantically back and forth between your home plate and your pitcher until someone pegs you and you\u2019re out. Take me out to the cat game!\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "See 68-Across", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Plenty of companies, small and large, work with university plant breeders to distribute new seed varieties. But Row 7 aims to give breeders the chance to reach a big market with their most esoteric and groundbreaking work \u2014 by connecting them with chefs.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs they develop new varieties, plant breeders will kick around ideas with chefs across the country, using feedback from the kitchen to guide their research. While Row 7 will consider the needs of regional growers, its founders say that flavor will always come first.\n\n\u201cPart of the goal of the company is not only to increase the flavor of vegetables: It\u2019s to look at how we, as chefs, can change the culture of eating,\u201d said Mr. Barber, who started Row 7 with the seedsman Matthew Goldfarb and the plant breeder Michael Mazourek.\n\nStarting Tuesday, Row 7 will sell organic seeds, developed in the United States, on its website, row7seeds.com. At first, it will sell seeds for the Badger Flame; three varieties of squash (including one that announces its ripeness on the vine by changing from dark green to a rusty orange); a small, creamy potato; a pleasingly bitter cucumber; and a floral-tasting habanero pepper without even a pinprick of heat.\n\nRow 7\u2019s founders are betting that as plant breeders and chefs conspire to grow what\u2019s most delicious, they will grab the attention of home gardeners and small- to mid-scale farmers, who can order the seed in bulk. Their new varieties may then pop up at farmers\u2019 markets and high-end grocery stores, and, if demand is high enough, in national supermarket chains and manufactured foods.\n\nIt sounds ambitious for a new company with such a small selection, not to mention one whose prices are high, from $3.50 for 100 seeds to $4.95 for just 12. But the founders have seen what happens when high-profile chefs flex their marketing muscles.\n\nEIGHT YEARS AGO, Mr. Barber asked Mr. Mazourek, an associate professor of plant breeding and genetics at Cornell University, if he could develop a better butternut squash. Mr. Mazourek had been working on what he calls \u201csquash innovation\u201d for many years, and came back to Mr. Barber with the Honeynut.\n\nPhoto\n\nLike all breeders, Mr. Mazourek had reached plenty of dead ends throughout his career. He didn\u2019t see why this miniature squash should be any different, even if it was notably cute and tasty.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Barber pitched the new variety, calling it out by name at food conferences and cooking with it at his restaurants, where the servers tell diners detailed stories about ingredients. The squash elbowed its way beyond an elite dining scene, through more and more restaurant kitchens, from social media and articles in Vogue and Cooking Light, right into the aisles of national grocery chains and onto dinner tables across the country.\n\nIn about five years, the Honeynut had risen from academic obscurity. (That\u2019s fast for a squash.)\n\n\u201cThe Honeynut could not have happened without chefs,\u201d Mr. Barber said. \u201cThey Instagrammed it, they talked about it, it was on their menus, and it went from zero to 60.\u201d\n\nMr. Barber, Mr. Mazourek and Mr. Goldfarb all wondered what might happen if more chefs had a say in which new seeds went to market \u2014 if they played a part in shaping their own food supply.\n\nWas it a freakish anomaly, or could the Honeynut effect be repeated over and over again? Could chefs create a demand for new varieties that were more experimental and interesting and diverse, more nutrient-dense and more thoroughly delicious, from root to stem to leaf?\n\nMr. Mazourek\u2019s colleagues \u2014 plant breeders with creative streaks, experts on the substance of cauliflower, corn and carrots \u2014 found all of these questions exciting. When Mr. Barber spoke to chefs, they were just as enthusiastic. Row 7\u2019s partners brought in investors, including Walter Robb, a former chief executive of Whole Foods Market, and Adam Neumann, the chief executive of WeWork.\n\nPhoto\n\nRow 7\u2019s seeds are not patented; the company\u2019s founders say they don\u2019t believe in patenting life, and want researchers to have access to information. \u201cAs the climate changes and pests and disease evolve, we have to keep up,\u201d Mr. Mazourek said.\n\nFor now, all profits from the seed sales will be used to support each plant breeder\u2019s research. (Later, the model could look more like that of other seed companies, which pass only a portion of profits to breeders, or license out particular seeds for royalty fees.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMichael Sligh, the director of a sustainable agriculture program at Rural Advancement Foundation International, said that as the seed market has become more consolidated in the last two decades, there has been an alarming decline in the number of public plant-breeding programs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cSo part of what we\u2019re dealing with is, how do we reinvent this pipeline from seed development all the way into the marketplace and to the point of consumption?\u201d he said.\n\nHe has seen a flurry of what he calls participatory plant breeding, in which plant breeders, farmers and others collaborate to build new supply chains and address their own regional needs, such as the Bread Lab at Washington State University.\n\nMr. Sligh said that a seed business with chefs in the picture had potential. \u201cIt\u2019s a new and exciting linkage that would be cutting edge,\u201d he said. \u201cChefs have great public access, which plant breeders and farmers don\u2019t have so much.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWHEN MR. MAZOUREK FIRST ASKED the Boston chef Ana Sortun to imagine editing a vegetable, any vegetable she liked, Ms. Sortun was stumped.\n\n\u201cWhy would I want to change something in nature?\u201d she said. \u201cNature is perfect.\u201d\n\nBut tasting some of Mr. Mazourek\u2019s squash trials gave her a sense of the possibilities. \u201cIt had just never dawned on me that I could talk to a seed breeder and have a conversation like this,\u201d said Ms. Sortun, who has served the Honeynut at her restaurants for years.\n\nShe is one of dozens of chefs who plan to cook with Row 7\u2019s new varieties as they\u2019re available. They include Mashama Bailey, of the Grey in Savannah, Ga. Ms. Bailey was drawn to Mr. Mazourek\u2019s work with another variety of squash, bred to have stems that taste too good to throw away.\n\n\u201cI like the focus on utilizing the entire plant,\u201d she said, \u201cand on reducing waste.\u201d\n\nHeirlooms, which are older varieties of open-pollinated plants, are prized for their origin stories and their flavors \u2014 though they can be risky for growers. The newer seeds that plant breeders produce, whether open-pollinated or hybrid, are manipulated to thrive, and aren\u2019t idealized in the same way, except by the breeders.\n\nIn interviews, some described the work as beautiful, as both an art and a science, practiced in the lab and the field. Mr. Goldman said that like many of his peers, he considered every plant to be imperfect and unfinished \u2014 a work-in-progress on a continuum that stretched all the way back to each plant\u2019s domestication.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Mazourek kept working on the Honeynut, even after its initial success, selecting for higher yields on the vine and longer storage. The palm-sized 898 squash is his latest version, and among Row 7\u2019s first group of trial seeds.\n\nEvery year or so, the company plans to release more seed varieties, and newer versions of previously sold seeds. But that\u2019s not the only reason Mr. Goldman, who worked for more than a decade on his sunset-colored beet, continues to tinker on a new generation of the Badger Flame, even as the seed goes on sale.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like a raising a kid,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019re really never done.\u201d\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Seeds Only a Plant Breeder Could Love, Until Now", "authors": ["Tejal Rao"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "More broadly, analysts and officials wonder if engaging with the outside world could have a political effect back home.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose scuffling for information find only scraps. The North Korean figure skaters seemed to enjoy a variety of global food in the athletes\u2019 cafeteria, said Kam Alex Kang Chan, a South Korean skater who also trained with Mr. Marcotte.\n\nMegan Duhamel, who with her skating partner, Eric Radford, won a bronze medal in pairs figure skating and is married to Mr. Marcotte, said that the North Korean skaters became fans of protein bars made by a friend of hers in Montreal, and that she gave them several to take home.\n\nIn the locker room before a game between the unified Korean women\u2019s ice hockey team and Sweden, some of the South Koreans taught their teammates from the North how to dance to K-pop music, said Sarah Murray, the Korean women\u2019s hockey coach.\n\nThe subtext of some of the curiosity is whether the North Koreans, exposed to glimpses of popular culture or the higher standard of living in the South, might be tempted to defect, as athletes from other Communist countries have done at previous Olympic Games. No North Korean athletes have defected during an Olympics, although one defected in 1991 during a world judo championship in Spain.\n\nSome analysts theorize that exposure to the outside world could eventually drive change back home.\n\n\u201cIt might be better to think that an information inflow will slowly alter the preferences of North Koreans by inevitably poking holes in the ideology,\u201d said Robert E. Kelly, a professor of political science at Pusan National University in South Korea. \u201cOver time, this should change the regime and make it easier to deal. That\u2019s the hope anyway.\u201d\n\nSome American officials espouse a version of this view. \u201cOur sense is the more North Koreans that come here and can see how successful the South has been, the better,\u201d Marc Knapper, the deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in Seoul, said during a news conference before the Games.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMaybe they\u2019ll discover what good things accrue when they decide to rejoin the international community and make the right decisions,\u201d Mr. Knapper added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet even North Korea watchers who support greater athletic and cultural exchanges say none of it will slow down the country\u2019s nuclear ambitions.\n\n\u201cOf course they will proceed with their nuclear program,\u201d said Andrei Lankov, a North Korea expert at Kookmin University in Seoul. \u201cNothing can be done, short of a military invasion, to reverse it. The best we can hope for is to achieve some kind of freeze.\u201d\n\nAny North Korean who might try to steer the government in a new direction risks severe punishment. Dissidents are thrown into prison camps, and Kim Jong-un has had hundreds of people killed, including his own uncle, and, it is widely believed, his half brother.\n\nCritics say countries hosting North Koreans become susceptible to propaganda designed to soften the North\u2019s image. They point to the regime\u2019s charm offensive at the Olympics, including a visit by Kim Yo-jong, Kim Jong-un\u2019s sister.\n\n\u201cWhile North Korea, the target of engagement, remains a menacing nuclear state, the outsiders have become beholden to the enchanting possibility of their efforts bearing fruit one day,\u201d said Lee Sung-yoon, a professor of Korean studies at the Fletcher School at Tufts University.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose who promote more engagement with the North say change will be evolutionary, not revolutionary. \u201cNorth Koreans, including North Korean officials, will see they are lagging very behind the world,\u201d Mr. Lankov said. \u201cSome of them will say, \u2018Let\u2019s overthrow the government,\u2019 but many more will say, \u2018Let\u2019s change our policy a bit.\u2019\u201d\n\nIt is not even clear how much the North\u2019s athletes and supporters have seen or heard while at the Games. The dozen female players on the joint ice hockey team sleep in separate dorms and ride a separate bus from their South Korean teammates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe North Korean cheerleaders and journalists are staying in a remote resort in Inje County, at least a 90-minute drive from many of the Olympic venues.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe cheerleaders are not even allowed to slip to the bathroom on their own, and minders from the North Korean delegation, as well as South Korean police officers, are constantly monitoring them, the athletes and performers.\n\n\u201cLeaving North Korea is even harder than leaving the mafia,\u201d said Sue Mi Terry, Korea chairwoman at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. Would-be defectors \u201cknow their entire family, extended relatives, friends will get executed or rounded up and sent to labor camps,\u201d she said.\n\nWhat\u2019s more, she said, the athletes and cheerleaders at the Olympics are \u201ccarefully handpicked and vetted North Koreans, children of the elite ruling class\u201d who have decent living standards. \u201cWhy risk bringing serious harm to your loved ones when you are living a pretty good life?\u201d Ms. Terry said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnalysts say it is also presumptuous to assume any North Korean who goes abroad would immediately want to move.\n\n\u201cIf you use the analogy of someone coming from the Midwest or a small town and you go to New York for a weekend, and there\u2019s all of a sudden all of this stuff \u2014 a lot of people that I know from quieter cities tend to get very overwhelmed,\u201d said Jenny Town, assistant director of the US-Korea Institute at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.\n\nDefectors say those who have been abroad are likely to receive some kind of ideological \u201cre-education\u201d session upon returning home.\n\nStill, some experts say exposure to the outside world may ultimately undermine the regime\u2019s efforts to keep citizens in line.\n\nIdeological education \u201ccan\u2019t take away people\u2019s thoughts after they experience what it\u2019s like in a democratic society,\u201d said Kang Dong-wan, professor of North Korean culture and politics at Dong-A University in Busan, South Korea. \u201cWouldn\u2019t the cheerleaders and the athletes wonder why they are being controlled while other South Koreans in the crowd sitting right next to them are cheering naturally and moving about freely?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe North\u2019s athletes at the Olympics have said little in public, but have generally conveyed their loyalty to their nation. Ms. Duhamel, who drove the North Korean skating pair to daily practice in Montreal last summer, said they told her Canada was \u201clike our country, very nice, very peaceful.\u201d\n\nAnd at a news conference after an ice hockey match, Jong Su-hyon, a North Korean player, said, \u201cNothing made me uncomfortable, and nothing really surprised me here.\u201d\n\nSome spectators riveted by the North\u2019s synchronized cheerleaders acknowledged it was likely some actually wanted to go back.\n\n\u201cMany South Koreans worked abroad after the Korean War, when things were tough for South Korea,\u201d said Kim Myo-jong, 34, an orthopedic surgeon in the stands for the pairs skating short program. \u201cBut instead of staying abroad because it was easier to make money there, they decided to return to help South Korea\u2019s development. Maybe the North Korean elites who have outside exposure might feel the same.\u201d", "title": "Seeing Bounty Abroad, Will North Koreans Change Their Homeland?", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE BOAT PEOPLE\n\nBy Sharon Bala\n\n352 pp. Doubleday. $26.95.\n\nTwo pieces of Canadian history lie behind Sharon Bala\u2019s debut novel, \u201cThe Boat People.\u201d The first involves the arrival \u2014 in August 2010 \u2014 of the merchant vessel Sun Sea at Equimalt naval base in British Columbia, carrying hundreds of Sri Lankan asylum seekers. The second involves the internment of almost 24,000 Canadian citizens of Japanese origin in the Slocan Valley by the British Columbia Security Commission between 1941 and 1949.\n\n\n\nThe arrival of the refugees is fictionalized through the voices of the widower Mahindan, a resourceful father rendered unscrupulous by the circumstances of a terrible war, who has arrived with his 6-year-old son, Sellian, and Priya Rajasekaran, a law student assigned to represent the refugees. Grace Nakamura, an adjudicator for the Immigration and Refugee Board, provides the connection to 1941 through her mother, Kumi. The latter, her mind laced with dementia, sallies forth like a Greek chorus to insist that subjecting foreign asylum seekers to the processes established by rule of law is the same as the forced removal and incarceration of law-abiding citizens. It\u2019s a false equivalence that blights a novel already struggling under the weight of political opinion: Bala vilifies the Canadian Border Services Agency and the draconian immigration laws and penalties that can be traced to the prime minister at the time, Stephen Harper, and sings the praises of the Canadian Tamil Congress, which appears here as the Tamil Alliance.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe \u201ccompassionate\u201d lens promised on the jacket copy proves elusive. The novel is burdened by a heavy-handed use of emotive prose. Bala is particularly fond of the diminutive, the \u201csmall\u201d of things, hands, wounded children \u2014 all designed to elicit sympathy. Stock characters crowd the narrative. One of them, Grace\u2019s world-weary colleague Mitchell Hurst, shows up no fewer than four times to make declarative statements about what a neophyte she is at this business of adjudicating asylum. Bala also labors to explain things that do not require explanation, from immigration law (\u201cthere can be a gap between policy and practice\u201d) to Border Services (\u201cthe agency responsible for patrolling the perimeter, the country\u2019s official boundaries\u201d).\n\nLess than 10 pages into this novel, a lawyer says: \u201cThe truth is immaterial. \u2026 Do the claimants appear to be telling the truth? That is what matters.\u201d His words are echoed by Mahindan toward the end of the book: \u201cWhat is important is not what is true or false. The important thing is what these people, the Canadian authorities, believe is true and false.\u201d It\u2019s an interesting premise that, if allowed to float, might have permitted the novel to reach safe harbor. Instead, Bala frog-marches readers toward a foregone conclusion: The government is vindictive; the refugees, innocent.\n\nThe author plays with time through flashbacks told in the present tense, an innovative approach well suited to capturing the upside-down nature of refugee narratives. With a treasure trove of material \u2014 what can\u2019t a writer do with a boatload of refugees? \u2014 it is mystifying that Bala has chosen to ignore the obvious: letting us see the refugees as perfect in their imperfections rather than rendered as pawns in this political narrative, just as they were trapped in a war not of their choosing. There is one character, Mahindan\u2019s champion bargainer of a wife, Chithra, who in flashbacks lights up the page with her presence and prescience, the energy she brings to her marriage, her friendships and her pregnancy. One is left wishing Chithra had made it to Canada. Her youthful vitality and fierce personality would have helped the author dispense with a multitude of middling characters and political invective and given us a heroine worth cheering for.", "title": "Seeking Asylum but Finding Heartbreak", "authors": ["Ru Freeman", "Sharon Bala"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "There are more than two million incarcerated people in the United States. We, the public, have seen countless images of them: Arms laced between rusted metal bars; gloomy faces staring at us, backs against a white wall; bodies shrouded in orange jumpsuits. These images pop up over and over in our cultural lexicon, but do little to make us consider the individuals portrayed.\n\n\u201cWhen we think of the word mass incarceration we think of the word mass,\u201d said Nicole Fleetwood, an associate professor of A merican studies at Rutgers University and scholar on incarceration. \u201cBut every person has a story.\u201d\n\nMs. Fleetwood has now collaborated with Aperture magazine on its latest issue, \u201cPrison Nation,\u201d which features the work of more than a dozen photographers and writers. The issue addresses the role photography can play in creating a visual record of mass incarceration that focuses less on prisons and more on the human beings inside.", "title": "Seeking Humanity in a Prison Passion Play", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Does every terrible employee in America work for the Trump White House?\n\nO.K., probably not. Donald Trump didn\u2019t hire the guy who told Hawaiians they were about to be hit by a ballistic missile. Or the airline representative who was accused of pressing a passenger to flush her hamster down the toilet.\n\nBut for overall ineptitude and ability to create crises at the highest level, you have to go with the presidential team. Just this week we had a top aide with multiple domestic abuse allegations, plus a chief of staff who never seemed to bother to pursue the matter. And a communications director \u2014 third one in a little over a year \u2014 who helped write the statement defending said aide, whom she happened to also be dating.\n\nObviously, the real blame falls on Trump, whose only comment on domestic abuse Friday was to say the departed aide \u201cdid a very good job.\u201d But about the underlings \u2014 which one do you think is worst?\n\nBesides Omarosa. Let\u2019s think about major officials who are still standing, more or less. And while voting for John Kelly is all right, it\u2019d be interesting to talk about somebody else for a while.", "title": "Opinion | Select the Worst Trump Minion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "About 700,000 young immigrants who were brought to the United States illegally as children are shielded from deportation under an Obama-era initiative known as the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA. Another 1.1 million young immigrants are eligible for DACA but did not apply. But Mr. Trump suspended the initiative in September and gave lawmakers until March 5 to come up with a replacement that would protect the young immigrants, known as Dreamers, after proposed legislation called the Development, Relief and Education for Alien Minors, or DREAM Act.\n\nLiberal interest groups and immigration rights activists have mobilized to insist on legal status for the Dreamers without the concessions demanded by the president and immigration hard-liners: billions for a wall on the Mexican border, an even more aggressive crackdown on illegal immigrants and dramatic changes to the legal immigration system that would favor skilled immigrants over the family members of citizens and green-card holders.\n\n\u201cAs the Senate is poised to start debate on the humanitarian crisis Donald Trump caused when he cruelly ended DACA, here\u2019s what every sitting Senator should remember: Americans want the Dream Act \u2014 not cruel deals that go against basic American values,\u201d said Corinne Ball, campaign director for MoveOn.org, a liberal activist group.\n\nConservatives and anti-immigration groups are just as vociferous.\n\n\u201cIt was President Obama who created a cruel situation by making promises to a group of illegal aliens who he had no authority to promise what he gave them,\u201d said Rosemary Jenks, the director of government relations for NumbersUSA, a group that advocates limiting immigration. \u201cPresident Trump had a duty to rescind that policy, because the Constitution makes very clear that Congress, not the White House, sets the laws in this land.\u201d\n\nIn such a polarized environment, there is a significant chance that the Senate will pass nothing by the end of the week \u2014 or that whatever measure the Senate does adopt will be thwarted by the House.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to have something in the Senate that we haven\u2019t had in a while,\u201d Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona, said Sunday on the NBC program \u201cMeet the Press.\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s a real debate on an issue where we really don\u2019t know what the outcome is going to be.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nImmigration is one of the most emotional, contentious issues in Washington. The last time Congress seriously considered immigration legislation was in 2013, when the Senate passed a comprehensive immigration overhaul with 68 votes. But that measure, which offered a path to citizenship for about 11 million immigrants in the United States illegally \u2014 including the Dreamers \u2014 was never taken up by the House.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s election, on a wave of anti-immigrant fervor, has made the current negotiations even more difficult, senators say. The negotiations are complicated by Republicans\u2019 demands to pair any protection for DACA recipients with an increase in border security, and limits on legal immigration, and by conflicting pronouncements from Mr. Trump.\n\nAfter telling lawmakers last month that he would sign whatever they sent him, Mr. Trump now insists that any proposal address what the White House is calling \u201cfour pillars\u201d: protection for DACA recipients; an end to what Mr. Trump calls \u201cchain migration,\u201d in which legal immigrants can sponsor their family members; an end to the diversity visa lottery, which is aimed at bringing in immigrants from underrepresented countries; and full funding for the proposed border wall, estimated to cost $25 billion over 10 years.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe White House recently put forth its own proposal that meets those conditions; it would offer 1.8 million Dreamers a path to citizenship, in exchange for strict limits on legal immigration and the full $25 billion for the border wall. A number of Republican senators, led by Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, have drafted legislation that mirrors the White House plan, which will almost certainly be introduced as an amendment. Mr. McConnell said on Monday that he supported it.\n\nThe American people have \u201cheard many of my colleagues across the aisle insist this issue requires swift action,\u201d Mr. McConnell said. \u201cNow is the time to back up the talk with the hard work of finding a workable solution. That means finding an agreement that can pass the Senate, pass the House and which the president will sign \u2014 not just making a point.\u201d\n\nSeveral other proposals are floating around Capitol Hill, but so far none has garnered the backing of the White House. A bipartisan group calling itself the Common Sense Coalition, led by Senators Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, and Joe Manchin, Democrat of West Virginia, has been working on its own measure but has not released a plan.\n\nThat group is focused on a narrower bill than the president would like, one that would pair a path to citizenship for the Dreamers with funding for the border wall.\n\n\u201cThe only way to achieve a solution to the DACA crisis is to keep it simple,\u201d Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida and a member of the coalition, said on the Senate floor Monday.\n\nBut Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Republican, said he could not support a bill that addresses only DACA and border security. \u201cThe president\u2019s indicated he would not sign such a bill, so that really doesn\u2019t meet my definition of success,\u201d he said.\n\nAt the same time, the idea of an open-ended debate is so novel that many newer senators say they have never experienced one, and are scurrying to learn the rules.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFor a lot of us, we\u2019re going to have to learn this process,\u201d said Senator Mike Rounds, Republican of South Dakota, who was elected in 2014.\n\nSenator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, marveled, \u201cBeen here seven years \u2014 I\u2019ve never seen anything like it.\u201d\n\nImmigrant rights groups are nervous, and do not know quite what to expect. Frank Sharry, the executive director of America\u2019s Voice, an immigrant rights group, put it this way: \u201cThis is going to be an uncertain, wild week.\u201d", "title": "Senate Begins \u2018Wild\u2019 Week of Debate on Immigration, Outcome Unknown", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "But in the Capitol, Mr. McConnell and his Democratic counterpart, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, were unable to come to terms on an agreement that would get the debate underway in earnest.\n\nMr. McConnell sought to open with a vote on legislation to punish so-called sanctuary cities, which refuse to cooperate with federal immigration officials. But Mr. Schumer objected, on the grounds that such a measure is unrelated to DACA. Without the Democratic leader\u2019s consent, debate cannot begin until midnight Tuesday, or very early Wednesday morning. Republicans were left fuming in frustration.\n\n\u201cThis is the debate they said they wanted,\u201d Mr. McConnell, sounding irked, told reporters Tuesday. \u201cI said we\u2019d have an open and fair process. We\u2019re trying to do that, and the sooner we get started, the better because we need to wrap up this week.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhether senators can stick to that schedule remains an open question. The chamber is scheduled to be in recess next week, but some lawmakers are urging that the immigration debate be continued after the recess if no resolution is reached by Friday.\n\n\u201cThe preference obviously is to finish,\u201d said Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona. \u201cYou never want to have a break right in the middle of a debate. That\u2019s not optimal. But it\u2019s better than letting it die.\u201d\n\nImmigration is one of the most difficult and contentious issues to come before Congress. The last time the Senate debated immigration, in 2013, the matter was on the floor for weeks. It culminated in Senate passage of a comprehensive immigration overhaul with 68 votes, but the measure never got a vote in the House.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
