An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m thinking what does this mean?\u201d White said. \u201cWe were on such a great path, and it was that true question of, like: Do I really want this? Stepping out on the snow again means that I\u2019m willing to let this happen to myself again. And that\u2019s a big decision.\u201d\n\nHe came back. Few were sure how good he could be, given his age, injury and relatively few competitions. Then he won an event to qualify for the team (with a 100-point score). He won the qualifiers on Tuesday in what might now be the second-best halfpipe contest in history, behind the one the next day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhite thought he might have won it in the first of three rounds, when judges awarded him 94.25 points. He watched Hirano, the silver medalist in Sochi and long considered an heir apparent to White, take the lead in the second round with a run that included back-to-back 1440s.\n\nWhite knew he had to do it, too, even though he never had, he said.\n\n\u201cYou could come up on any other day, when all these people aren\u2019t here, and ask me to do that, and I\u2019d be terrified,\u201d he said, a rare admission of fear. \u201cBecause there\u2019s no motivation. But when you\u2019ve got the Olympics, and you\u2019ve got the dye on the pipe and the world watching, there was no doubt in my mind I was going to do the trick. I just had to land it.\u201d", "title": "Shaun White\u2019s Bumpy Ride Back to the Top", "authors": ["John Branch"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "In December 1995, they saw each other at the Wee Burn Country Club, where both their parents were members. \u201cChris was so warm and I felt completely comfortable. Our rapport was so natural,\u201d she said. \u201cI was charmed by him, and thought, \u2018What an interesting person.\u2019 That night I went home and broke up with the person I\u2019d been dating for six months.\u201d\n\nThat week she sent him a Christmas card. He wrote her back, stating that if she was going to be in Connecticut, they could go to a movie. She came for a visit. They talked all night. A month later they started dating again, this time for real. Eight months later, Mr. Van Munching proposed at Smith\u2019s Point, a beach on Nantucket. Five months later they were married.\n\nWhat They\u2019ve Learned\n\nMrs. Van Munching: Chris is the perfect combination of funny and together. I grew up in an insane family where we flew by the seats of our pants. Chris always has it together. He knows where everything is, and that\u2019s incredibly comforting. I could be 100 percent myself with him. I couldn\u2019t do that with others in the past. I\u2019ve learned that sometimes, somebody can bring incredible love out of you.\n\nWe have short hand because we had known each other, and where we came from. He knows my crazy and I know his, and we\u2019re still O.K. with that. He\u2019s the most thoughtful, warm and sensitive person. We complement each other. I\u2019m introverted; he\u2019s extroverted. He keeps charge of the calendar. He makes the social plans with the wives in town because he knows that overwhelms me. He tells me when to show up and the appropriate ensemble. He anticipates things. He reads my signals without me having to say it. He knows when I\u2019m hungry or guilty, when I haven\u2019t seen my parents enough.\n\nMarriage taught me it\u2019s the small kindness that you do for each other that makes a huge difference. They accumulate. You might think they\u2019re insignificant, but they add up and make this big thing. He sets the table. He knows my favorite sandwich and sometimes just shows up with it. He draws a bath for me.", "title": "She Knows His Crazy, and He Knows Hers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRecently, New York museums have presented retrospectives of all three of the most influential artists of Brazil\u2019s postwar avant-garde. Lygia Clark, with her hinged-metal sculptures you can fiddle with at will, filled the top floor of the Museum of Modern Art. Lygia Pape, known for bold, participative performances and sculptures of iridescent gold filaments, appeared at the Met Breuer. And H\u00e9lio Oiticica was the man of the hour this summer at the Whitney, live birds and all.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe generation that set the stage for them, however \u2014 the one that established Modern art in Brazil in the early 1920s \u2014 has received less attention here. You\u2019ll have to go back to the Guggenheim\u2019s 2001 blockbuster \u201cBrazil: Body and Soul\u201d for the last big-ticket appearance of Modernist painters like Emiliano di Cavalcanti, C\u00e2ndido Portinari and, above all, Tarsila do Amaral (1886-1973): the most popular artist of the last century in her home country, but still little known in the United States. Her mature paintings, featuring oversize bodies in flowing, stylized landscapes, provoked the modern Brazilian penchant for antropofagia, or \u201ccannibalism,\u201d that Clark, Oiticica and Pape would all draw from. In the art of Tarsila (like a Brazilian soccer star, she is always called by her first name), Brazil found a new cultural confidence that said goodbye to European envy and consumed Western, African and indigenous influences with equal relish.\n\n\u201cTarsila do Amaral: Inventing Modern Art in Brazil,\u201d a belated but very welcome exhibition at the Modern, at last introduces New York audiences to the painter who, more than any of her contemporaries, forged a Modernist vocabulary for the country\u2019s art. Trained in Paris, enamored of rural Brazil, Tarsila moved quickly from folksy, idealized depictions of the New World to a brawny, confident biomorphism. Her three most important paintings have all been united in this show: \u201cA Negra\u201d and \u201cAntropofagia,\u201d on loan from museums in S\u00e3o Paulo, and \u201cAbaporu,\u201d which has traveled from Buenos Aires. (This show appeared last year at the Art Institute of Chicago; it was organized by Luis P\u00e9rez-Oramas, who recently stepped down as MoMA\u2019s curator of Latin American art, and Stephanie D\u2019Alessandro, now at the Met but previously at the Art Institute.)\n\nPhoto\n\nTarsila was born into a family of wealthy landowners on a coffee plantation outside S\u00e3o Paulo in 1886 \u2014 two years before the end of slavery in Brazil, the last country in the Americas to abolish it. She received an art education in S\u00e3o Paulo, but she found the instruction traditionalist, so she left for Paris in 1920. There she learned from Fernand L\u00e9ger, whose bold colors and rounded figures would be decisive for her mature art. There is much of L\u00e9ger in a 1923 academy (or nude figure study) of Tarsila\u2019s, in which the sitter\u2019s contoured flesh pops against a backdrop of blue, green and beige.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nParis had left her \u201ccontaminated by revolutionary ideas,\u201d Tarsila later wrote, and, while still abroad, she would soon redeploy her French lessons in the service of a new Brazilian art. Her 1923 breakthrough, \u201cA Negra\u201d \u2014 \u201cThe Black Woman,\u201d in English, though Brazilian racial taxonomies are quite different from American ones \u2014 pictures its nude subject sitting cross-legged, and her oversize feet, complete with toes of childlike chubbiness, take up much of the bottom of the composition. Her body is flattened; her right breast droops over her crossed arm; and her lips are so large that they run right off her face. Her flesh is a rusty orange, which darkens at the edges, as in L\u00e9ger\u2019s paintings. And note the background: an abstract arrangement of cool-colored stripes, indebted to Brazilian textiles but also to new European painting.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor contemporary audiences in New York, now hyper-attuned to white artists\u2019 use and misuse of black bodies, \u201cA Negra\u201d will pose the toughest challenge in this exhibition. But context is critical here. In 1923, for a trained artist to imagine a black woman as the embodiment of a new national spirit would have constituted a direct attack on the old, wannabe-European establishment of Rio and S\u00e3o Paulo. (We might add that Modern artists in 1920s Paris were besotted with African and Native American art, precisely what the Brazilian bourgeoisie disdained.) The Modernist tropes of \u201cA Negra,\u201d with its scrambling of scales and its simplified graphics, were to be the building blocks for the art of a multiracial society.", "title": "She Led Latin American Art in a Bold New Direction", "authors": ["Jason Farago"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "We didn\u2019t have a lot of money, but Terry would do trades with friends. It was organic. He loved his students [at the University of Pennsylvania] and collected their work. Jamal Cyrus was one of his students and Demetrius Oliver. Wilmer Wilson was in Terry\u2019s last class.\n\nWould he do trades even for the African art?\n\nWhatever it was he wanted, it was like a barter system. He knew a lot about African art, what was good and what wasn\u2019t good. He started collecting musical instruments in Zurich in 1987. He found this kora [lute] through an African art dealer. That was one of the things he loved the most. There\u2019s a photograph of him before I knew him playing it in the Alps. For two years after he passed away, we couldn\u2019t find it. I sent photographs out to all the people who had moved his things from Penn. Then somehow it showed up. It was him bringing it back to me so I could rest easily.\n\nHave you continued to collect on your own?\n\nI go to benefits and I will buy things. My eye is not like Terry\u2019s, but I think I\u2019m pretty good at it.\n\nPhoto\n\nThese little thumb pianos seem to crop up on every shelf and mantel.\n\nThere are a million thumb pianos around the house. They are wood and metal and he would play them. They make really cool tonal sounds. You\u2019ll also see tons of bells, which he bought on eBay and at flea markets, like this heap on the floor that have rabbit\u2019s feet on them \u2014 he being superstitious. When people come in, inevitably somebody kicks them and it\u2019s like he\u2019s still here. When Terry was alive, there was always music blaring, whether it was Beethoven or Bessie Smith or Mahalia Jackson.\n\nPhoto\n\nWho made these large X-ray photographs?\n\nThose are Terry\u2019s, taken of memory jugs, which are African-American funerary objects. Sharecroppers in the South would collect small trinkets they found. When they died, the trinkets were put in plaster and this would be their tombstone. Terry collected over 120 of these. He was friends with the people at Penn in the radiology department at the hospital who helped make these photographs.\n\nDo you have any favorites among Terry\u2019s sculptures here?\n\nI\u2019m never getting rid of this one named \u201cFirmament RHA\u201d that was shown at the Whitney at Philip Morris in 1995. It\u2019s all found metal and usually hangs up very high. It was an ode to his father who had passed away right before that show. It kind of looks like a plane and kind of looks like a box. Terry would probably have described it as a box filled with memories of his father.\n\nAnd what\u2019s the significance of hanging it high?\n\nBecause it\u2019s closer to the angels.", "title": "She Married an Artist, and Now Finds Comfort in His Work", "authors": ["Hilarie M. Sheets", "Show Us Your Wall"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Over 28 years at the giant computer chip maker Intel, Ren\u00e9e James climbed to its No. 2 position, becoming one of Silicon Valley\u2019s prominent female leaders.\n\nNow she is taking aim at Intel\u2019s most lucrative business, one that she helped build.\n\nMs. James, who announced in 2015 that she would resign from Intel, on Monday revealed a start-up backed by the private equity firm Carlyle Group to sell chips to handle calculations in servers. Those computers run most internet services and corporate back-office operations.\n\nIntel dominates that market, accounting for 98 percent of the microprocessor chips sold for the most popular variety of server, the research firm IDC estimates. The group that sells such chips generated about $19 billion in revenue last year and nearly half of Intel\u2019s operating profit.\n\nMs. James emphasized her respect for her former employer and played down potential competition. She said her new company, Ampere, was designing chips for new, specialized jobs at cloud services that aren\u2019t Intel\u2019s primary focus.", "title": "She Was No. 2 at Intel. Now She\u2019s Taking Aim at the Chip Maker.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "In recent public opinion polls, her approval ratings have reached as high as 43 percent, second only to the prime minister, Paolo Gentiloni, and she is often mentioned as a candidate for Italy\u2019s presidency. The country\u2019s mostly male Parliament \u2014 which chooses the president \u2014 has repeatedly bypassed her for men.\n\nYet that general aura of popularity around Ms. Bonino has not always translated into votes. Her Radical Party has traditionally hovered around what she calls \u201cour beloved 2 percent\u201d in election results, short of the 3 percent of the total vote now needed to merit a seat in Parliament.\n\nThat has prompted her to adopt a new slogan: \u201cLove Me Less, Vote Me More.\u201d\n\nWhen asked why her vote totals have always lagged behind her popularity, Ms. Bonino sighed.\n\n\u201cYou need to ask an expert,\u201d she said somewhat dispiritedly, during an interview in her cheery, book-filled attic apartment in central Rome.\n\nSome suggest it has something to do with the unpopular causes she has taken up.\n\n\u201cThat is my destiny, and the destiny of the Radicals,\u201d Ms. Bonino said. \u201cIt\u2019s to be unpopular at the beginning, become popular during the struggle and then be shoved aside at the end.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlongside Marco Pannella, the charismatic Radical Party founder and leader who died in 2016, Ms. Bonino helped to change Italian society.\n\nThrough referendums, acts of civil disobedience, hunger strikes and campaigns, the party has swayed public opinion in this overwhelmingly Catholic country on several sensitive issues, among them divorce, abortion, conscientious objection and family law. In December, Parliament passed a measure that allows living wills and the right to refuse medical treatment, another Radical Party battle that had lasted decades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur ambition is not to promise things that people like most to the most people,\u201d she told supporters at the Rome rally, a reference to what she believes are the unrealistic electoral promises of her competitors. \u201cOur ambition is to carry out what we promise, even saying things that don\u2019t appear to be too popular.\u201d\n\nIt is hard at this point to say whether Ms. Bonino\u2019s pro-Europe policy is popular or not. Support for the European Union has been wobbling throughout the Continent and especially in Italy, where polls suggest 34 percent of the population is disgruntled enough to want to leave, the second-highest level after Greece.\n\nStill, President Emmanuel Macron of France has done well with his strongly pro-European stance.\n\nMs. Bonino, who turns 70 next month, characteristically sees the issue in black and white terms, and does not particularly care whether it is popular or not. She sees an embrace of Europe as the only hope for this aging and economically struggling country, and her electoral target is Italy\u2019s disenchanted youth. \u201cVote, and vote for us. You are the Erasmus generation,\u201d she said, referring to a European Union program that, broadly speaking, funds student exchanges.\n\n\u201cWhen I was a young girl, a weekend in Turin was the height of exoticism,\u201d she said, referring to the Piedmont capital, about 40 miles from where she was born.\n\n\u201cWhat is interesting is that she is a great supporter of European integration without being Eurocentric,\u201d said Marta Dass\u00f9, the senior director of European affairs at the Aspen Institute, who has worked alongside Ms. Bonino on women\u2019s issues. \u201cShe believes in a strong affirmation of Europe, along with an outreach in particular to Mediterranean and African countries.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Bonino was born in 1948 into a \u201cmodest farming family\u201d in a small town in the Piedmont countryside.\n\nWhile she loves her family very much, she said, marriage to a local boy and everything that usually followed in small town life 50 years ago was never going to satisfy her.\n\nMuch to her father\u2019s consternation, she went off to Bocconi University in Milan, where she studied foreign languages. Like many Italian men of that era, her father \u201cdidn\u2019t understand\u201d why she needed to pursue an education. Instead, she said, her mother secretly helped her out.\n\nShe traveled, \u201cbut I always learned languages in the wrong place,\u201d picking up Spanish from a boyfriend at a school in Ireland, and English from a boyfriend she met during a course in France. Still, she said, it was a \u201cpleasant\u201d way to learn languages.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Bonino did not embark on a political career by design. \u201cPolitics found me,\u201d she said.\n\nThe political upheaval that swept Western societies in the late 1960s breezed past her, she said. She cannot even remember voting in the referendum to legalize divorce, which the Radical Party spearheaded. But in 1974 she had an abortion, which was illegal at the time, and she discovered something to fight for.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the way it goes with civil rights \u2014 people act when they discover them, or when they are denied,\u201d she said.\n\nShe met Adele Faccio, a women\u2019s rights advocate and abortion rights campaigner, \u201cwho spoke to me about civil disobedience, which I\u2019d never heard of, about the Radical Party,\u201d and she began accompanying women to a Florentine abortion clinic.\n\nThis was illegal, too, and in 1975 she turned herself in and was arrested. But a law legalizing abortion took effect in 1978, and the Radical Party successfully fended off efforts to repeal it three years later.\n\nIn 1976 the Radical Party ran in national elections for the first time, and Ms. Bonino was one of four members to be elected to Parliament. Three years later she was elected to the European Parliament, and she has remained in the political arena \u2014 in one form or another \u2014 ever since.\n\nShe spent nearly 30 years in the Italian parliament and 14 years in the European Parliament, holding both seats when that was still possible. She was also a member of the European Commission, where she was in charge of fisheries, consumer policy and the European Community humanitarian office. In that capacity, she oversaw management of several crises, including the one million refugees from the war in Kosovo in 1998.\n\nShe has constructed a web of international connections through her advocacy for women\u2019s rights, refugees, humanitarian aid and other causes.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s a sponge. She reads all day, she\u2019s always learning, so she can talk about things knowledgeably,\u201d said Cristina Tagliabue, one of her biographers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Bonino\u2019s current platform includes another unpopular position: the integration of the thousands of undocumented migrants who have arrived in Italy in recent years.\n\nHer campaign last year to change immigration laws in Italy \u2014 \u201cI Was a Foreigner\u201d \u2014 was supported by humanitarian organizations and 150 mayors, and attracted 90,000 petition signatures, enough to present a bill to Parliament. That was another battle, Ms. Dass\u00f9 said, that ran \u201ccounter current to the mood of the country, but she sees migration as a long-term and structural problem that must be addressed.\u201d\n\nShe is winning one fight in which she has enjoyed widespread support. In January 2015, Ms. Bonino announced that she had lung cancer. Treatment took many months, but in October 2016 she said that she was free of cancer. The turbans she now wears are the only vestiges of that episode. True to form, she continues to smoke, unrepentant.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s a real fighter on her ideas and her life,\u201d Ms. Dass\u00f9 said.", "title": "She Won Italians\u2019 Hearts. But Can She Win Their Votes?", "authors": ["Elisabetta Povoledo", "The Saturday Profile"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Peterson should have \u201cwent in, addressed the killer, killed the killer,\u201d Sheriff Israel said.\n\n\u201cLet there be no mistake, Mr. Peterson wishes that he could have prevented the untimely passing of the seventeen victims on that day, and his heart goes out to the families of the victims in their time of need,\u201d Mr. DiRuzzo said in a statement. \u201cHowever, the allegations that Mr. Peterson was a coward and that his performance, under the circumstances, failed to meet the standards of police officers are patently untrue.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear why Mr. Peterson nevertheless chose to retire on Thursday after Sheriff Israel placed him under internal investigation. Sheriff Israel has said the investigation will continue despite the deputy\u2019s departure. The sheriff\u2019s office is under intense scrutiny over its response to the Feb. 14 shooting.\n\nThe office\u2019s active shooter protocol says that on-scene deputies, without approval from a supervisor, \u201cmay\u201d engage the gunman. That appears to give deputies discretion, but only to a point: They \u201cmay\u201d choose not to go in if they know a door is armed with a large explosive device, for example, or if they know the only way into a building has a dangerous suspect immediately on the other side ready to shoot the deputy, Col. Jim Polan explained in written responses to questions.\n\nOtherwise, deputies are expected to prioritize the lives of victims by trying to confront the gunman as quickly as possible.\n\nSheriff Israel said on the day of the massacre that it appeared the shooting had begun and then continued outside the building, and that three people had died outside the school. But on Monday, his office said, \u201cThe shooting occurred inside.\u201d", "title": "Sheriff\u2019s Deputy Defends Actions in Florida Shooting, Denying He Was a \u2018Coward\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Vonn, one of the most fearless and accomplished downhillers in history, flung herself down the course and would have posted the day\u2019s fastest time had she not stood up, relaxed and raised her arms to shoulder level 75 yards from the finish line.\n\nVonn was not just showing some style. The favorite in a downhill sometimes purposely slows down in the final seconds of training to keep the competition guessing about just how fast a time might have been possible. Vonn finished third in the field Monday. She won the first training run on Sunday.\n\nShiffrin, on the other hand, was still showing signs of her inexperience on a high-level downhill course. Her body language and the amount of forward pressure she was exerting on her skis made it clear that she was thinking her way through her run. She was graceful, efficient and smoothly glided across the icy track of snow, but she also was not entirely certain where to seek more speed and where to be wary. She finished a respectable 16th on Monday, which was seven spots higher than she did in the first training run. The final training runs will be Tuesday, but now only Vonn will be there.\n\nThe apparent differences between Vonn and Shiffrin continued after they had left the snow on Monday. Shortly after her run, Shiffrin did a brief interview with NBC but otherwise did not speak with reporters. She was on her way to slalom training Monday afternoon to get ready for the Alpine combined.\n\nVonn, who will enter Wednesday\u2019s race as a co-favorite with Italy\u2019s Sofia Goggia, watched the entire training session from a spot near the finish area, laughing and joking with her rivals. She later did more than 30 minutes of interviews.\n\n\u201cJust trying to enjoy every moment of this while I\u2019m still here,\u201d she said.\n\nAsked if she realized that Wednesday would be her last Olympic downhill race, Vonn smiled and said: \u201cI\u2019m trying not to think about that. But I am soaking everything in.\u201d", "title": "Shiffrin Pulls Out of Downhill, Leaving Only One Chance to Face Vonn", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Pita Taufatofua, the taekwondo athlete from Tonga who achieved Olympic immortality as his country\u2019s flag bearer at the opening ceremony of the 2016 Rio Games by slathering his sculpted upper body with oil and not covering it with a shirt, delivered an encore performance at the opening ceremony of the Winter Games in South Korea on Friday, elevating himself beyond Olympic immortality and into the realm of unbridled internet glory because it was very cold in Pyeongchang and he apparently defied all odds to compete in cross-country skiing at the Olympics, since he is from a country where cross-country skiing has to be extremely difficult.\n\nTaufatofua competed in the 15-kilometer cross country race on Friday; he placed 114th out of 119 entrants.\n\n\u201cThe 15 kilometer never worked so well for me,\u201d he confessed. \u201cI\u2019m always gassed out by about the second kilometer.\u201d\n\nAs for his future plans he said: \u201cThree Olympics, three different sports, let\u2019s see if it can be done, huh?\u201d", "title": "Shirtless Tongan, Part Ua", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Schneemann had little use for Abstract Expressionism\u2019s culture of angst. What interested her was the physical action in \u201caction painting.\u201d She took it seriously enough to slice into her canvases and layer them with collage material, and then move into assemblage (at one point she forged a mutually beneficial friendship with Joseph Cornell). For a while she used fire as a mark-making medium.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy the early 1960s, after she had converted a Manhattan commercial loft into a studio, her assemblages grew to the size of environments, in which she performed, her nude body smeared and streaked with paint, for a series of photographs titled \u201cEye Body: 36 Transformative Actions for Camera.\u201d The performances, which included live snakes, shattered mirrors, and cow skulls as props, suggested archaic rituals, violence-tinged but executed with surrealist wit.\n\nIt was a short, logical step from the studio into a theater. Ms. Schneemann made the transition as a founding member, along with dancer-choreographers like Deborah Hay and Yvonne Rainer, of Judson Dance Theater, a company that was changing American dance. In the Judson aesthetic, everyday actions \u2013 walking, running, lovemaking \u2013 assumed expressive dimensions. In 1964, Ms. Schneemann, using a pop-song score composed by Mr. Tenney, directed nine performers in an epochal event she called \u201cMeat Joy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nStaged first in Paris and then in New York, it had at least the appearance of being an erotic free-for all with men and women in bikini briefs rolling around among piles of newspapers, slathering each other with blood-red paint, and clutching the bodies of dead fish and raw chickens. Seen in blurry film montage, the work is a landmark, but also a period artifact. It again confirms the painterly impulse behind the artist\u2019s work: here she turns bodies into brushes. But of far more interest, with its mingling of creaturely flesh, living and dead, is the work\u2019s deep investment in ideas of transience and mortality.\n\nIf \u201cMeat Joy,\u201d which she termed \u201ckinetic theater,\u201d reflected the liberationist spirit of the proto-feminist early-60s, other work tapped into darker political realities, namely the war in Vietnam. In a flickering 1965 film called \u201cViet-Flakes,\u201d the artist\u2019s camera scans newspaper clips of battlefield atrocities as if from a fighter-plane perspective. Two years later, she incorporated this film into a performance piece called \u201cSnows,\u201d in which the audience had a role in dictating which live photo-derived tableaus would be staged.\n\nMost of her theater work, documented in photographs or on film, exists only as ghost traces in the show, organized by Sabine Breitwieser, of the Museum der Moderne Salzburg, and Branden W. Joseph, a professor at Columbia University, along with Erica Papernik-Shimizu and Oliver Shultz of MoMA PS1. Yet some images, such as shots of the solo piece \u201cInterior Scroll,\u201d still startle. For the 1975 performance, the artist stood alone on a table, nude, posing like a studio model, and reading aloud from a book of her collected writings, \u201cCezanne, She Was A Great Painter,\u201d which includes a litany of misogynistic reactions a female artist could expect to encounter in her career:\n\n\u201cBE PREPARED:\n\nto have your brain picked\n\nto have the pickings misunderstood\n\nto be mistreated whether your success\n\nincreases or decreases\n\nif you are a woman (and things are not utterly changed)\n\nthey will almost never believe you really did it\n\n(what you did do)\n\nthey will patronize you humor you\n\ntry to sleep with you want you to transform them\n\nwith your energy\u201d\n\nShe then put the book down and slowly extracted a narrow strip of folded typewritten paper from her vagina, reading the text on the scroll as it emerged. It included, among other things, a direct appeal to a film historian \u2014 female, as it happened \u2014 who had been dismissive of her work, as a sizeable swath of the art world was at that time.\n\nMs. Schneemann has consistently run into resistance, often from conflicting directions. Some feminists have viewed her body-positive art as exploitive in an old, essentializing way, failing to see the claim to power implicit in her erotic self-portraiture. Yet in 1969 at Cannes, when she screened her film \u201cFuses,\u201d with its images of the artist and Mr. Tenney having sex, male critics were furious: the film wasn\u2019t pornographic enough for their taste.", "title": "Shock of the Nude", "authors": ["Holland Cotter"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "FORT MEADE, Md. \u2014 Three men were in custody Wednesday after they tried to drive onto the National Security Agency\u2019s campus at Fort Meade, in Maryland. Baltimore division. Weapons were fired in the course of the episode, but preliminary reports did not suggest that anyone had been shot, and the car crashed.\n\nThe driver was injured in the crash and was taken to an area hospital, while the other two men were being interviewed by the F.B.I. A police officer and onlooker also were injured, officials said, but the injuries were not serious.\n\nMr. Johnson and Tommy Groves, an N.S.A. spokesman, said that terrorism was ruled out as a motive during preliminary investigations. They declined to rule out any other potential cause \u2014 including whether the driver entered the campus by mistake. The military\u2019s Cyber Command is also located at the base.", "title": "Shooting at N.S.A. Headquarters Leaves Several Injured", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "With the right blend of aesthetics and practicality, children\u2019s chairs can be just as pleasing to parents. For many grown-ups, they offer a chance to play with colors and shapes that might normally seem too bold or risky.\n\nAfter all, \u201cwhen you\u2019re designing for the main part of the home, it\u2019s serious,\u201d said Susana Simonpietri, creative director of the Brooklyn-based interior design firm Chango & Co. \u201cWith kids\u2019 rooms, you can just let loose and have fun.\u201d\n\nEmbracing this philosophy, Ms. Simonpietri creates spaces for her youngest clients with features like rope swings, watermelon wallpaper and, of course, plenty of pint-size statement-making chairs.\n\n\u201cYou can find miniature bentwood chairs in bright colors,\u201d she said, as well as scaled-down modern classics by the likes of Norman Cherner, Verner Panton and Harry Bertoia. \u201cHow cute is that?\u201d", "title": "Shopping for Children\u2019s Chairs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "When you need a little extra storage or display space, a weighty bookcase can sometimes be overkill. A wall-mounted shelf might do just as well, if all you want is a place to show off small accessories or stash a few novels \u2014 and it won\u2019t hog floor space or overwhelm a room.\n\n\u201cWall-mounted shelves give the impression of lightness and floating in space,\u201d said the New York-based interior designer Amy Lau. \u201cThey take up less visual space, because they don\u2019t have backs.\u201d\n\nWhere do shelves like this work best? In the bedroom or a home office, to display personal collections, she suggested, or in the kitchen, to hold decorative dishes. In a powder room, you might use them as a place to put candles and perfume.\n\n\u201cYou can even use one as a desk,\u201d Ms. Lau said, if the shelf is the right size and mounted at the proper height.", "title": "Shopping for Wall-Mounted Shelves", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Not every motion in every sport is symmetrical \u2014 think of the swings of a golfer or a baseball batter, or the torque of someone like a pole-vaulter \u2014 but those unbalanced actions are not performed continuously throughout practice and competition.\n\nShort-track speedskaters, racing against others on an oval inside a hockey rink, spend most of the competition turning.\n\nAlthough techniques vary, and are dependent on the race and other competitors, skaters often perform three crossovers to get around the 180-degree corners (meaning six strides, three with each leg) and only one on the straightaway before the next corner. That means three-quarters of all their strides are done with a hard lean to the left. And all of them are done with the skater bent over at the waist. (Sore backs are a common malady.)\n\n\u201cWe try to skate as low as possible, so it sometimes hurts in the bottom of our back,\u201d Pascal Dion, a member of the Canadian team, said. \u201cOur back is not that strong compared to our lower body and legs.\u201d\n\nIt is different from long-track speedskating, where most of the action takes place on straightaways. Long track tends to attract taller athletes who race a clock with metronomic steadiness.\n\nShort track, which prizes agility and quick bursts, along with speed, tends to attract smaller athletes, bottom-heavy ones, their centers of gravity pulled low by thick, powerful thighs.\n\nNot all strokes are the same, as competitors skate against one another in a race to the finish line, rather than against the clock \u2014 long track has added one \u201cmass start\u201d race to its schedule for these Olympics \u2014 requiring an ability to dart in and out of traffic and burst past competitors.", "title": "Short-Track Speedskaters Are Lopsided", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Lepsche had a more concise reason to do away with the old Sunday restriction.\n\n\u201cIt was a ridiculous law,\u201d he said.\n\nThirty miles east of Minneapolis on Interstate 94, just across the St. Croix River, which separates Minnesota and Wisconsin, you\u2019ll find the town of Hudson. It has a quaint downtown along the river, but it was well known to Minnesotans, before the new law, as the best source for Sunday beers.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you take the first exit off Interstate 94 in Hudson and make a right at the Dairy Queen, you\u2019ll end up at Historic Casanova Liquor, a liquor store known for craft beer, specialty wine and, according to its owner, Tyrrell Gaffer, being the \u201cfirst one off the interstate.\u201d\n\nGaffer estimated that 60 percent of his Sunday sales before passage of the new law were from Minnesotans crossing the border to buy alcohol. \u201cA lot of it was: \u2018Hey, I forgot. People are at my house and I need something,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cEveryone in Minnesota knows this area pretty well.\u201d\n\nCompared with the owners of other border liquor stores, Gaffer is fortunate. His store is filled with high-margin niche beers and wines, and Minnesotans still come to buy products like Spotted Cow, the farmhouse ale from New Glarus Brewing, which doesn\u2019t distribute to Minnesota.\n\nWhat he now sells fewer of are name brand spirits and cases of low-margin beers from macro breweries, like 24-packs of Bud Light. \u201cWe haven\u2019t gotten hit as bad as some of the other stores and other places around here,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTom Salewski owns Valley Spirits, just across the Wisconsin border in Osceola, about an hour northeast of Minneapolis. There is no town directly across the river in Minnesota, but he would still see plenty of Vikings fans who forgot to buy beer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt blew me away sometimes when people would come in, trying to leave their place at halftime and drive 20 or 30 miles and try to get back for the fourth quarter because they ran out of beer for the game,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019d really notice it if the Vikings played a later game.\u201d\n\nHe said his Sunday sales were down a third since the new law, and he now schedules one fewer employee to work on Sundays.\n\nSalewski is resigned to the fact that he will simply make less money. Without a town directly across the river, he cannot run promotions or otherwise attract Minnesotans to his store. \u201cThere is only so much you can do with pricing where you can make somebody drive 30 or 40 miles,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAbout 110 miles south of Osceola is Fountain City, Wis., over the river from Winona, Minn., and the 8,400 students at Winona State University. \u201cBefore they changed the law, we were pretty busy, and it\u2019s not like it used to be,\u201d said Bridget Johnson, a clerk at Wine House in Fountain City.\n\nWhile the law is just seven months old, its effect is beginning to be quantified. During the first five months after it took effect, Wisconsin state sales tax collected from liquor stores in counties that do not border Minnesota grew by 3.4 percent compared with the same months in 2016, according to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue.\n\nBut in Wisconsin counties bordering Minnesota, state sales taxes collected from liquor stores fell 5.5 percent over the same period. A Department of Revenue spokeswoman cautioned that the data did not include alcohol sold at places like grocery stores and gas stations \u2014 which is allowed in Wisconsin \u2014 and that monthly sales tax data was volatile.\n\nIt isn\u2019t clear yet whether Minnesota liquor stores are seeing an appreciable rise in sales. The Minnesota Department of Revenue has not completed its 2017 data, and it also lumps together taxes on all alcohol products, including those in bars and restaurants. Minnesota\u2019s border counties also tend to be much more populous than Wisconsin\u2019s, making small changes less noticeable.\n\nIt\u2019s not all bad news for Wisconsin\u2019s liquor stores. Unlike Minnesota\u2019s, they are still allowed to be open on Thanksgiving and Christmas, and some stores still anticipate brisk sales to Minnesotans after their stores close on Sunday nights before holidays like Memorial Day and Labor Day.\n\nPlus, as a patron drinking Wednesday afternoon at the newly opened Hop & Barrel Brewing in Hudson noted, without the hordes of Minnesotans running in to buy their cases of beer, on Sundays locals \u201ccan finally go to Casanova again.\u201d", "title": "Shorter Beer Runs in Minnesota, Just in Time for the Super Bowl", "authors": ["Kevin Draper"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "TAMPA, Fla. \u2014 Thairo Estrada, a top Yankees infield prospect, was shot in the hip during a robbery attempt last month in his native Venezuela, the Yankees announced on Friday.\n\nEstrada, 21, who had hoped to compete for the starting second base job, is expected to make a full recovery and could begin working out on a stationary bike next week. But he will be doing so with a small-caliber bullet lodged in the area around his right hip; doctors decided during surgery to leave the bullet in place.\n\nManager Aaron Boone announced the injury nearly three weeks after the incident occurred, on Jan. 28. Afterward Estrada described ordering dinner at a restaurant with his wife in his hometown, Bejuma, when two teenagers demanded his phone and money at gunpoint.\n\nEstrada said he did not have his phone with him and was not carrying cash \u2014 a precaution he said many people take in the violence-stricken country. After the assailants checked Estrada\u2019s pockets, they shot him, he said.", "title": "Shot in a Robbery Attempt, Yankees Prospect Recovers at Spring Training", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Clayton highlighted the risks posed by cryptocurrency trading platforms that call themselves \u201cexchanges,\u201d which gives the impression that they are regulated like the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq. But investors using such platforms \u201cdo not receive many of the market protections that they would when transacting through broker-dealers on registered exchanges,\u201d Mr. Clayton said. Instead, the cryptocurrency exchanges are considered \u201cmoney transmission\u201d businesses, subject to a hodgepodge of state and federal rules that provide little protection to those who use their services.\n\nThere are distinctions between cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, which are not tied to a single company but instead operate more like regular money, and tokens issued by firms to help raise money in initial coin offerings, or I.C.O.s. Mr. Clayton announced a much tougher stand on that second form of virtual assets. \u201cThe structures of I.C.O.s that I have seen involve the offer and sale of securities and directly implicate the securities registration requirements,\u201d he said. The S.E.C. has filed cases against companies making coin offerings for selling unregistered securities, and more are certainly on the way.\n\nMr. Giancarlo explained that his agency does regulate futures contracts that are tied to cryptocurrencies, and it can police firms executing transactions involving the contracts. But he pointed out that the C.F.T.C. \u201cdoes not have regulatory jurisdiction over markets or platforms conducting cash or \u2018spot\u2019 transactions in virtual currencies, or over participants on those platforms.\u201d To reach actual trading in cryptocurrencies, Congress would have to extend its authority to cover a cash commodity market, something lawmakers have not done.\n\nInvestors need protection. Virtual currency firms have seen a rash of large-scale thefts from customer accounts. An Italian cryptocurrency exchange called BitGrail reported on Saturday that tokens called Nano worth approximately $170 million had gone missing in unauthorized transactions. An exchange in Japan called Coincheck disclosed in late January that hackers had stolen $530 million from the accounts of cryptocurrency investors.\n\nAny theft can be prosecuted under a range of federal laws, including the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act and the wire fraud statute because cryptocurrencies are a form of property, even though they are intangible. But criminal prosecution is not a particularly effective weapon for battling hackers who plunder cryptocurrency wallets. Many of the exchanges are outside the United States, so finding those responsible is a challenge.", "title": "Should Congress Create a Crypto-Cop?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Some people, I realize, think that self-directed considerations don\u2019t belong in the moral calculus. You can assess the consequence of your actions on others and on the world, in their view, but you\u2019re not supposed to take your own concerns into account. They identify morality with the triumph over self-interest. This austerely demanding view is tempting but misguided. Morality should not be turned into something like the good china, which you take down from the high shelf only for special occasions. Ethics, in its classical sense, was about being a good person \u2014 and living a good life. (The first thing being part of the second.) It was meant for everyday use. The point is that you\u2019re a participant in the situation you describe; your own prospects have to be considered, too.\n\nAnd suppose that by turning in these cheaters, you became a pariah; would you have helped or hurt the social norm of honesty? Still, there may be things you can do. You might write to the head of your school board and say that cheating is happening and not being detected. (Consult your parents first, of course.) In an ideal world, students could be trusted to refrain from cheating because, like you, they value honesty. But we\u2019re probably headed toward a world that\u2019s simply less dependent on trust: no unsupervised tests, regular use of plagiarism checkers and statistical methods for detecting cheaters; stiff penalties for those who are caught. Given this reality, you might suggest some simple measures that could be taken. For starters, it\u2019s not too much to ask that teachers stay in the room when an exam is being given.\n\nI used to play rugby in college. Two of my old teammates are now assistant coaches for the team. Recently, one of the players got wasted and then fell and hit her head getting out of her friend\u2019s car. She hit it hard enough to cause bleeding. Her friends called an ambulance.\n\nI heard about this from one of the assistant coaches. The team is going to championships soon, and so everyone is practicing even more than before. I told my friend, one of the assistant coaches, that she should have the woman take the concussion test again, even though the injury wasn\u2019t rugby-related. My best friend blew it off. I also texted the head coach, who also brushed it off.\n\nI find this deeply troubling, because it involves head trauma. I believe that the young woman should be looked at for her own health and recovery. It\u2019s the safest bet in my view.\n\nBecause I am no longer part of the team, do I have a right to speak up? If so, what should the next steps be? Name Withheld\n\nYou\u2019ve been told that this young woman hit her head and went in an ambulance to the hospital. Given the nature of the accident, she was presumably checked for a concussion. Your view is that she should be checked again. I\u2019m no physician, but because she was treated in an emergency room, we should assume that the doctor there would have told her if she needed to return for another examination. If the doctor didn\u2019t tell her that, I can\u2019t see why she has more reason to check than anyone else on her team.\n\nIt has been a great many years since I\u2019ve played rugby, but I know that given the nature of the sport, there will be a risk of concussion during practice and, especially, during play. So the coaches should be keeping an eye out for head impacts and for the symptoms of concussion. Still, you have no reason to think that the professionals involved here \u2014 in the hospital or on the field \u2014 haven\u2019t been doing their job. Especially given that you have no professional responsibilities in relation to the team, you\u2019re in no position to substitute your judgment for theirs.", "title": "Should I Tell on My Cheating Classmates?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Rauch and Wittes argue that these reasons are nonetheless insufficient for conservatives to abandon the party. Only the Trumpian attack on democratic norms is. I think they\u2019re wrong about that \u2014 and therefore end up with an unnecessarily narrow argument, against which Douthat scores some points.\n\nTrump is an outgrowth of today\u2019s radical, norm-shattering Republican Party. In some ways, he took its ideas to their logical extreme without hiding them behind the more polished behavior of, say, Paul Ryan.\n\nThere is little reason to believe that would-be Republican reformers \u2014 like my friend Ross Douthat \u2014 are going to succeed in stopping the craziness until the party loses power. Winning parties don\u2019t tend to reform themselves. Which makes the ultimate Wittes-Rauch conclusion persuasive: \u201cThe most-important tasks in U.S. politics right now are to change the Republicans\u2019 trajectory and to deprive them of power in the meantime.\u201d\n\nI recognize that voting against Republicans is as easy for a progressive to suggest as it is hard for a conservative to execute. But here\u2019s my case to conservatives who do believe in facts and democratic norms (and would rather that Miami stay above water): You are politically homeless right now. Your party has become a destructive force. Its victories \u2014 which you may understandably celebrate, like a lower corporate tax rate \u2014 don\u2019t make up for the damage the party is doing. And the other party obviously remains too left-wing for you.\n\nYour best hope is a sane conservative party. And the only route to a sane conservative party is a string of losses for the current Republican Party.\n\nConservatives aren\u2019t the only ones who would benefit from a better Republican Party, either. Democrats, and the country, would, too.\n\nThere\u2019s a very long list of issues on which conservative ideas have something important to say: about whether government regulations are the best way to fight climate change; about the benefits of competition and accountability for public schools; about the breakdown in family structure; about the tensions between abortion and eugenics; about avoiding the economic sclerosis of Europe; and on and on.", "title": "Opinion | Should Republicans Vote Democratic?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHave you learned about climate change in your science classes? If so, what have you been taught about it? What have class discussions about climate change been like?\n\nIf not, have you learned about it anywhere else, such as from another organization, club, your family or friends, or on your own? What do you know about it?\n\nIn \u201cIdaho Stripped Climate Change From School Guidelines. Now, It\u2019s a Battle,\u201d Livia Albeck-Ripka writes:\n\nThe political fight over global warming has extended to science education in recent years as several states have attempted to weaken or block new teaching standards that included information about climate science. But only in Idaho has the state legislature stripped all mentions of human-caused climate change from statewide science guidelines while leaving the rest of the standards intact. Now teachers, parents and students are pushing back, hoping to convince the Republican-controlled Idaho Legislature to approve revised standards, which science proponents say are watered down but would still represent a victory for climate-change education in the state. The Idaho House education committee could vote as soon as Wednesday on whether to allow the revised language into the state\u2019s curriculum. \u201cWe\u2019re hopeful that we can put a final bow on this,\u201d said Scott Cook, the director of academics at the Idaho State Department of Education, who helps lead a committee of teachers, parents and scientists urging that climate change be included in the standards. The battle started in early 2016, when Idaho was working to update its decade-old science standards for kindergarten through 12th grade, which outside education groups said were out of date. Lawmakers rejected a new set of standards, which were closely modeled after national guidelines developed by a consortium of states and science organizations and included information on climate change, saying more input from the public was needed.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do you think schools should teach about climate change? What did you like about it?\n\nIn \u201cYale\u2019s Most Popular Class Ever: Happiness,\u201d David Shimer writes:\n\nOn Jan. 12, a few days after registration opened at Yale for Psyc 157, Psychology and the Good Life, roughly 300 people had signed up. Within three days, the figure had more than doubled. After three more days, about 1,200 students, or nearly one-fourth of Yale undergraduates, were enrolled. The course, taught by Laurie Santos, 42, a psychology professor and the head of one of Yale\u2019s residential colleges, tries to teach students how to lead a happier, more satisfying life in twice-weekly lectures. \u201cStudents want to change, to be happier themselves, and to change the culture here on campus,\u201d Dr. Santos said in an interview. \u201cWith one in four students at Yale taking it, if we see good habits, things like students showing more gratitude, procrastinating less, increasing social connections, we\u2019re actually seeding change in the school\u2019s culture.\u201d Dr. Santos speculated that Yale students are interested in the class because, in high school, they had to deprioritize their happiness to gain admission to the school, adopting harmful life habits that have led to what she called \u201cthe mental health crises we\u2019re seeing at places like Yale.\u201d A 2013 report by the Yale College Council found that more than half of undergraduates sought mental health care from the university during their time there. \u201cIn reality, a lot of us are anxious, stressed, unhappy, numb,\u201d said Alannah Maynez, 19, a freshman taking the course. \u201cThe fact that a class like this has such large interest speaks to how tired students are of numbing their emotions \u2014 both positive and negative \u2014 so they can focus on their work, the next step, the next accomplishment.\u201d\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do you think schools should teach students how to be happy? Teachers who were qualified to handle a weapon \u2014 Mr. Trump estimated between 10 percent and 40 percent \u2014 would receive \u201ca little bit of a bonus,\u201d he said, adding that he would devote federal money to training them. \u201cI want my schools protected just like I want my banks protected,\u201d the president said. \u2026 Mr. Trump said he was not in favor of one measure that schools around the nation have increasingly taken to defend themselves and their students against school shooters: holding drills to practice what to do. \u201cActive shooter drills is a very negative thing,\u201d Mr. Trump said after Pam Stewart, the Florida Department of Education commissioner, mentioned such preparations. \u201cI don\u2019t like it. That effort has gained momentum in recent days. Legislators have moved to permit concealed weapons in schools. Sheriffs\u2019 offices have offered to train school staff members in armed response. But one assistant high school principal who survived a school shooting \u2014 after loading his Colt .45 pistol, then chasing and detaining the suspect at gunpoint \u2014 says the idea is misguided. \u201cTeachers have to teach, and that\u2019s what they should be doing,\u201d said Joel Myrick, the former assistant principal at a high school in Mississippi. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter what a pistolero you are, or think you are. Why?\n\n\u2014 What other solutions would you propose to make schools safer?", "title": "Should Teachers Be Armed With Guns?", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "The point of a lockdown drill is to know what to do automatically, without having to think.\n\n\u201cWhen something\u2019s going down, you will not respond from your head, you will respond from your stomach,\u201d Ms. Rush said. \u201cYou need to get that in your stomach. You need to know what instinctively you will do. That\u2019s got to be part of your psyche. So it requires constant training.\u201d\n\nDifferent schools or districts may have different protocols. The important thing is that everyone, from teachers to students to parents, know what they are. \u201cIt has to be something that goes like clockwork,\u201d said Dr. Irwin Redlener, a professor of pediatrics and public health and the director of the National Center for Disaster Preparedness at Columbia University.\n\nIf someone knocks on a locked door, should they be allowed in?\n\nIt may be heart-wrenching, but don\u2019t open the door, experts say. A teacher has to think of the lives of the many who have moved to a safe place over the one person outside in the hallway who may bring danger in.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t open that door until you know the police are on the other side,\u201d Ms. Rush said, adding, \u201cYou\u2019re doing it for the masses of kids.\u201d\n\nWhat should students be told?\n\nIt depends on their age. \u201cWe don\u2019t have to scare the heck out of these kids,\u201d Mr. Connors said. \u201cIn a kindergarten through third-grade building, you might tell the kids, come over here and sit down next to the wall.
