That also expanded the list of potential ad buyers to medium-sized firms.", "title": "Snap Reverses Slide as User Growth and Revenue Jump", "authors": ["David Streitfeld"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "When you feel a sneeze or a cough coming on, covering your mouth prevents the spread of infectious germs. You probably knew that.\n\nBut the way you cover up also matters, and there are plenty of people who haven\u2019t yet heard the consensus guidance of health officials: If no tissue is available, you should aim into your elbow, not your hand. Even if that means breaking a long-held habit.\n\n\u201cIf somebody sneezes into their hands, that creates an opportunity for those germs to be passed on to other people, or contaminate other objects that people touch,\u201d said Dr. Vincent Hill, chief of the waterborne disease prevention branch of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nGerms are most commonly spread by the respiratory droplets emitted from sneezing and coughing. When they land on your hands, they\u2019re transmitted to things like door knobs, elevator buttons and other surfaces the people around you are likely to also touch.", "title": "Sneeze Into Your Elbow, Not Your Hand. Please.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "People tobogganed in Rome\u2019s public parks on makeshift sleds \u2014 garbage bags appeared to be a preferred, if potentially painful, material \u2014 and a few hardy individuals strapped on skis to slalom in the Circus Maximus, once the site of chariot races.\n\nIngrid Nutty and Anthony Awy, who were visiting from London, were bemused that a snowy day would make the news. \u201cWe\u2019re used to it,\u201d Ms. Nutty said. Mr. Awy noted that the forecast had predicted the cold weather. \u201cWe came prepared,\u201d he said, clapping his gloved hands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA Siberian weather front nicknamed the Beast from the East sent temperatures plunging and brought snow and icy conditions to many European countries in recent days. In Italy, the weather front was dubbed Burian, a play on the name for a gelid wind from the Siberian steppe, and temperatures have dropped well below their seasonal average.\n\nSnow in Rome is rare. It last really fell here in 2012, after a hiatus of nearly 30 years. On Monday, the city awakened under a layer of snow 1.5 to six inches (four to 15 centimeters) deep, depending on the neighborhood.", "title": "Snow Falls in Rome, and the Eternal City Takes a Holiday", "authors": ["Elisabetta Povoledo"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cShe could never put it all together,\u201d Italy\u2019s Sofia Goggia, who finished 11th Saturday, said of Ledecka. \u201cBut today she did.\u201d\n\nLedecka cruised across the finish line, and a giant No. 1 flashed next to her name. A dumbfounded crowd at first seemed stunned silent.\n\nVeith said, \u201cMy first reaction was, \u2018Is this possible?\u2019\u201d\n\nThe crowd began to cheer, growing louder every few seconds. Ledecka remained still and did not react, waiting for the scoreboard correction.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNothing was happening, and everybody was screaming,\u201d Ledecka said afterward.\n\nHer time did not change, and she remained at the top of the leaderboard. Slowly, she skied toward an area adjacent to the finish, where she was feted as the race winner.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nSoon, her unforeseen victory lit up the internet, and a report circulated that she was using a used pair of skis borrowed from the Olympic giant slalom champion Mikaela Shiffrin\u2019s supply.\n\nEileen Shiffrin, Mikaela\u2019s mother and coach, disputed this. She said Ledecka had most likely chosen her skis from a batch the manufacturer Atomic provided to a number of racers. Ledecka said she always chose skis that had been used by other racers.\n\nWhisked to a news conference, Ledecka kept her ski goggles on her face as she answered questions from the news media. Asked why she did not remove her goggles, she giggled and answered, \u201cBecause I was not as prepared as the other girls that would be at the ceremony.\u201d Then she explained that she did not have on any makeup.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLedecka, who has both an Alpine coach and a snowboarding coach, was scheduled to compete in the snowboarding parallel giant slalom next week. But after her victory Saturday, she said she might change her plans. \u201cMaybe my skiing coach will be a little bit pushy after today,\u201d she said.\n\nLedecka could also enter Wednesday\u2019s Alpine downhill. Last December, she finished seventh at a World Cup downhill at the Lake Louise resort in Alberta, Canada.\n\nThroughout her news conference, Ledecka seemed less astounded that a ski racer who splits her time on the snowboarding pro circuit could win an Olympic Alpine gold medal than her inquisitors. Asked to explain how she could be good at both, Ledecka responded:\n\n\u201cWell, it\u2019s down a hill, both of them, right? That\u2019s the basics.\u201d\n\nWhen the room broke out in laughter, she yelped, \u201cWell, it\u2019s true.\u201d\n\nVonn was clearly impressed by Ledecka.\n\n\u201cI wish I had as much athleticism as her,\u201d she said. \u201cTo be a snowboarder and win is pretty darn impressive.\u201d", "title": "Snowboarder Ester Ledecka Shocks Lindsey Vonn and the Super-G Field", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Even before the first snowflake had fallen, alarm bells were sounding across Britain.\n\n\u201cBeware Beast From the East: It Will Kill,\u201d one tabloid warned.\n\n\u201cArmy on standby as heavy snow to cripple Britain in \u201315C weather hell,\u201d another said.\n\nBold red signs went up in shop windows, prompting panicked Brits to empty supermarket shelves: \u201cSNOWMAGGEDON! Stock up on essentials now.\u201d\n\nThey were describing a storm known as the Beast From the East, a polar vortex that brought freezing temperatures and snowstorms to parts of Europe this week, including to cities like Rome and London that rarely see snow.\n\nSome noted that as the cold descended on Europe, the Arctic was witnessing one of its warmest winters ever. Last Sunday, as the temperature in Britain fell to 23 degrees Fahrenheit (minus 5 Celsius), northern Greenland was at 43 degrees.", "title": "Snowstorm Called \u2018Beast From the East\u2019 Sends Britons Scrambling", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The small overall decline in the stock market over the past few days pales in comparison with the large gains over the past few years. So hopefully you\u2019re still on schedule to meet your goals, absent any big health or job changes.\n\nThis moment of checking your gut, however, is as good a time as any to consider whether you have the right proportion of your money in stocks versus other options like cash, bonds or real estate that don\u2019t experience this kind of volatility or may not rise or fall in tandem with stocks. In other words, are you taking too much risk? Or too little? If so, buy or sell some stocks accordingly \u2014 not because of what the stock market will or will not do next but because you are or are not on track to pay for the things you want to buy someday.\n\nCan You Predict What the Market Will Do Next?\n\nLet me answer that one for you: No. Perhaps you got lucky with some individual stocks as a teenager or used what you learned in finance class to buy just the right mutual fund at exactly the right time.\n\nCongratulations! But you\u2019re almost certainly more lucky than you are smart. Professionals rarely do so well over 50 years that their decisions about when to get in and out of a stock lead to better performance than they might have achieved by just putting money into an index fund that buys every stock in a particular category. And you can\u2019t know ahead of time whether you are that rare breed of market genius.\n\nStill tempted to sell and wait out this latest market hiccup? Plenty of studies warn against this, including one that shows that missing out on just 10 of the best days in the stock market over 160,000 daily returns in 15 markets around the world can cause you to end up with about half of what you would have earned if you had stuck with an index fund over time.\n\nHow Much Does This Affect Your Net Worth?\n\nAny decline hurts, even if it\u2019s only on paper and you don\u2019t plan on selling for decades. But consider everything else that might happen over that many years.\n\nYou will (hopefully) pay down your student loan debt. You will (hopefully) get promotions and raises or start a company that will increase your income. You will buy a home, and its value will probably go up over time, or at least match inflation. Or you\u2019ll rent and draw dividends from the freedom and flexibility that brings you.\n\nIn other words, you are not the stock market. There is so much more to your net worth (and, hopefully, self worth) than a bouncing S.&P. 500 chart. Check in with your life, and if it\u2019s better than it was a year or five years ago, think about that if the stock market keeps falling.", "title": "So It\u2019s Your First Market Hiccup. What Should You Do Now?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The big decisions are made on the couch around 5 a.m.\n\nWhen it looks like snow, the sanitation commissioner gathers her top chiefs and directors in a cozy office on the eighth floor of an old building on Worth Street near the federal courthouse for their \u201ccouch meeting.\u201d They squeeze onto a dark brown leather sofa and, without fail, talk about the weather.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ve got to be able to rock \u2019n\u2019 roll when the shift starts at 7 a.m.,\u201d said Commissioner Kathryn Garcia, who oversees a $1.6 billion budget \u2014 $84 million of which typically goes to snow removal. From this couch, the plan for thousands of sanitation workers is put in place. Ms. Garcia also gives her recommendation to the mayor on whether to close schools.\n\nSince 2014, when Ms. Garcia took over the department, major changes have taken place to clear the streets after anything from a dusting to a bomb cyclone. For decades, snow was dealt with in a convoluted system depending on how trafficked an area was. But all that changed in 2010 when a catastrophic blizzard left people in parts of the boroughs stranded for days and shook the department to its core.", "title": "So Let It Snow: The Strongest Are Ready", "authors": ["Helene Stapinski"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "So the play (is it one or two plays?) just continues where the books and movies left off?\n\nIt\u2019s one play, performed in two separate parts \u2014 like \u201cAngels in America,\u201d but with spells. It picks up where the epilogue to the seventh novel does: 19 years after Hogwarts, when Harry is a father of three, married to Ginny, Ron\u2019s little sister. (Cover your eyes if you don\u2019t want any spoilers.) Harry is doing well in his wizarding career \u2014 if not as well as Hermione, who\u2019s Minister for Magic \u2014 yet he fumbles at parenthood. Several characters fit the description of the title\u2019s \u201ccursed child,\u201d and one of them is Harry\u2019s younger son, Albus Severus, who struggles under the weight of his father\u2019s enduring fame. The story is partly about their troubled relationship.\n\nPhoto\n\nEesh. Why would anyone name his child Albus Severus?\n\nAlbus is in honor of Albus Dumbledore, a great wizard and the kindly, enigmatic (though when it came to student safety, appallingly lax) headmaster of Hogwarts in Harry\u2019s day. Severus is for Severus Snape, the acerbic potions professor Harry spent years loathing before he discovered that Snape was a brave and decent guy, just deep undercover. Snape was also the head of Slytherin House.\n\nAnd Slytherin House is what?\n\nBased on inner qualities divined by a hat (yes, a hat), each student at Hogwarts is assigned to live in one of four houses. The two that matter are Gryffindor, which was Harry\u2019s, and Slytherin, which might have a less ominous reputation if Tom Riddle hadn\u2019t belonged to it. Harry\u2019s son Albus, much to his initial dismay, is a Slytherin. So is his best friend, Scorpius Malfoy, whose family goes way back with the Dark Lord.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBad egg, this Scorpius?\n\nHarry assumes so, because he\u2019s hated Scorpius\u2019s dad, Draco, since they were children on opposing sides in the war between good and evil. But when Albus steals a forbidden instrument, intending to travel back in time and save Cedric Diggory \u2014 a Hogwarts student killed in front of teenage Harry at Voldemort\u2019s command \u2014 Scorpius is right by his side.\n\nSeriously, this is a lot of back story. Is it possible to enjoy the show if you\u2019re not already a Potterite?\n\nWould it help if you knew that it\u2019s an allegory with enormous resonance in our politically stormy age? Sure, you\u2019ll miss details, but the vivid and intricate world Ms. Rowling invented is beloved for a reason. She\u2019s no slouch at character or plot, either. Part 1 of the play ends with a deep, dark cliffhanger, and Part 2 is all about resolving that.\n\nSo it\u2019s best to see the two parts in order?\n\nDefinitely. You can do it all in one marathon or on separate days. Don\u2019t count on getting discounted tickets to such a highly anticipated show (at present, they\u2019re not even an option for groups or schools), and remember that you will need a separate ticket to each part. But there are 150 $20 tickets for each performance, and another 150 for $40 or less. Once previews start, those will include a small batch of $20 tickets for some of the best seats, released online every Friday for the following week. Otherwise, though, you may be paying from $70 to $199 for a single nonpremium seat. Resist the temptation to buy from anywhere other than harrypottertheplay.com or Ticketmaster. (The Lyric Theater box office is not yet open for in-person sales.) Demand is voracious. As in London, counterfeiters will try to take advantage of that.\n\nO.K., then. But is the play too scary for young children?\n\nThree words: soul-sucking dementors. In terms of inspiring terror in little kids, the dementors \u2014 black-cloaked figures that are exactly what they sound like \u2014 are probably in the same league as the flying monkeys in \u201cThe Wizard of Oz.\u201d The producers of \u201cThe Cursed Child\u201d say it\u2019s for ages 10 and up. Children 4 and older are allowed, but bear in mind that each part clocks in at more than two and a half hours.\n\nHarry means well when he promises Albus that there\u2019s nothing to be frightened of at Hogwarts. But the magical world can be a very scary place.", "title": "So You Know Nothing About \u2018Harry Potter\u2019? Let\u2019s Catch You Up", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "If you\u2019ve ever harbored the desire to do the splits, this desire probably left you around age 13, eclipsed by equally brutal preoccupations like romance or acne. But the breakout success in Japan of \u201cEven the Stiffest People Can Do the Splits: A Four-Week Stretching Plan to Achieve Amazing Health,\u201d a book published last spring by cluttering guru Marie Kondo\u2019s publisher, Sunmark Publishing, and recently out in the United States, suggests that some people never give up the dream.\n\nWritten by Eiko, a yoga teacher based in Osaka, the book has you do several minutes of yoga and gentle bouncing every day for a month, at which point you\u2019ll be able to do the splits while seated on the floor. If hygge made you drowsy, and Marie Kondo saddled you with empty cupboards and regret, \u201cshake yoga\u201d is a way to masochistically jiggle these bad memories away with your thighs.\n\nThe book has sold more than a million copies; Eiko\u2019s instructional videos on YouTube have been viewed 6.7 million times. On the streets of Osaka now, schoolboys point their fingers at the so-called Queen of Splits and scream \u201cHey, it\u2019s the Queen!\u201d Meanwhile, The Times of London has heaped upon the new monarch a notably un-British encomium: Eiko is \u201cwatchably bendy.\u201d\n\nTwo factors would seem to be fueling the book\u2019s success. First, Gumby-like bendiness is not the book\u2019s sole mandate \u2014 Eiko contends that the ancillary benefits of being able to do the splits include weight loss, improved balance, injury prevention and peace of mind. \u201cIf your body is stiff, it becomes harder and harder to do things like walk, step over things, pick things up, sleep or even sit,\u201d Eiko said in an email, adding that, outside of women in their 30s and 40s, the book has also been very popular with senior citizens. To back up its claims, the book cites studies from an array of sources ranging from the Journal of Applied Physiology and the Neuropsychoeconomics Conference Proceedings to The Sunday Tasmanian and Joe Weider\u2019s Muscle & Fitness magazine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe second component of the book\u2019s power is less wholesome. It only takes several pages for Eiko to lay out her regimen \u2014 you do two minute-long exercises a day, one wherein you lie on your back and pull your outstretched leg backward with a towel and then bounce, and another where you do a legs-spread sumo stretch and then bounce. A third minute-long yoga position or exercise changes each week. Eiko recommends that, with any move, you push yourself to 70 percent of your capacity.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the bulk of the book consists of a slightly strange short story \u2014 \u201cHow Are You Going to Achieve Anything If You Can\u2019t Even Do the Splits?\u201d \u2014 about two shame-ridden employees of a corporation in Japan who discover the joys and benisons of shake yoga. The gentle Oba is being outworked and outplayed by his younger colleagues, and harried Umemoto fears her work has deteriorated because of poor time management skills and a lack of self-restraint. But Oba and Umemoto\u2019s lives change dramatically when their new boss Hori encourages them to start meeting in the conference room at 7:30 a.m., where they cover the floor with some \u201cpicnic sheets for cherry-blossom parties\u201d and then stretch and bounce their way to a new life \u2014 the kind of life that\u2019s led by people who can do the splits. \u201cThat sparkle you feel, that sense of respect,\u201d as Hori puts it, \u201c \u2026 is something you reserve for the kind of people who keep on trying to accomplish something that most people can\u2019t.\u201d", "title": "So, You Say You Want to Do the Splits?", "authors": ["Henry Alford"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Love is no paradise in the songs of Sophie Allison, 20, who records as Soccer Mommy. It\u2019s a realm of misunderstandings, disappointments, unfulfilled longings and everyday betrayals, and Soccer Mommy\u2019s songs recount them in a haze of acceptance and resentment. \u201cIn the summer you said you loved me like an animal/Stayed beside me just enough to keep your belly full,\u201d Ms. Allison sings in \u201cSo Clean\u201d; then she devotes the remaining verses to missing him, predatory as he is, through the fall, winter and spring.\n\nSoccer Mommy joins a wavelet of young women \u2014 along with Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers, Mitski and many others \u2014 who are using gentle voices, pristine melodies and the expressive imperfections of indie rock for songs that probe vulnerability and trauma, self-sabotage and self-preservation. They are continuing a longstanding role of female singer-songwriters as pop\u2019s bearers of emotional sensitivity and catharsis. But in the era of SoundCloud and Bandcamp, they need no one\u2019s help or permission to go public. Whether anyone will listen is another question, but Soccer Mommy got through.\n\nMs. Allison began posting home-recorded songs to Bandcamp as Soccer Mommy in 2015, during the summer when she was about to leave her hometown, Nashville, for college at New York University. (She has since dropped out and returned to Nashville to pursue her music career.) As Soccer Mommy, she wrote about leaving behind her first love, about new independence and infatuations, about dodging the gaze of parents, about having to suddenly feel \u201cgrown.\u201d At first, with just a guitar, she was lonely and forlorn above all; her early digital EPs were titled \u201cSongs for the Recently Sad\u201d and \u201cSongs From My Bedroom.\u201d\n\nBut she soon gathered additional instruments and confidence, turning Soccer Mommy into an indie-rock band and getting signed to Fat Possum. She reworked six Bandcamp songs and added two newer, more assertive ones for \u201cCollection,\u201d released last year.", "title": "Soccer Mommy Confronts All the Disappointments of Love on \u2018Clean\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "What memorable project have you worked on?\n\nOur product allows customers to connect to their bank and automatically import expenses, such as debit card transactions, into the software so they can easily track them. I designed a friendly, animated squirrel that appears the first time you try to connect. It does a breakdance move with a little wave when the connection is successful. Rather than have a standard message or figure, the squirrel adds some humor to the procedure.\n\nWhere does your inspiration come from?\n\nI like a lot of things people consider old-timey: old illustrations, music and movies, nondigital art materials and methods like life drawing and silk screening.\n\nMy co-workers get a kick out of seeing what\u2019s on my computer screen when they walk by. I look at everything from 1940s animated videos explaining science or predicting the future, to after-school specials from the \u201970s and \u201980s. A lot of my influences are from before the 1990s, so I\u2019m a strange fit for a modern technology company.\n\nWhat challenges are you facing?\n\nI\u2019m the only artist here, and we\u2019re growing, so I try to convince my boss I should put my energy where it will have the most impact. I can\u2019t plan a project that will take a week to complete when there\u2019s a lot of work to be done. Also, I try to stick to one style. At home I\u2019m much looser.\n\nHow do accounting software customers respond to your art?\n\nWe serve small business owners who are pursuing their passions, so adding quirkiness and passion to our material rather than using stock images shows we know where they\u2019re coming from.", "title": "Software that Crunches Numbers Needs Personality, Too", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "When the deadliest fire in New York City in more than 25 years ripped through the apartment building where Pfc. The charges include possession of illegal weapons and attempted murder in a terrorist context.\n\nThe trial in Brussels is the first time the public will be given a sense of how prosecutors are piecing together the parts of what they say was a larger conspiracy, and Mr. Abdeslam used his first opportunity to speak at the trial to suggest that he had been prejudged by both the public and the court because he is a Muslim.\n\nMr. Abdeslam had refused to break his silence after his arrest, and the trial provides the authorities with a first opportunity to bring someone to account for the attacks, which focused attention on the threat of European fighters for the Islamic State who filtered back to their home countries with the intent of committing acts of terrorism.", "title": "Sole Surviving Suspect in Paris Attacks Stands Trial in Belgium", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe biggest difference between male and female brains of the same species is found in songbirds,\u201d said Sarah Woolley, a neuroscientist who studies finches at Columbia University\u2019s Zuckerman Institute.\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Woolley\u2019s lab has been looking into the acoustic systems of zebra, bengalese and long-tailed finches to see how their brains take in and process sounds \u2014 learning, performing and analyzing different parts of them to make sense of songs.\n\nA male\u2019s system is designed to recognize the songs of other males and copy his father\u2019s. If he doesn\u2019t learn, perfect and memorize his father\u2019s song within the first 90 days of life, when his brain is especially malleable, he never will. He still sings, but \u201che sings a disaster,\u201d said Dr. Woolley. \u201cAnd the females want nothing to do with him.\u201d\n\nWhen a female\u2019s brain is young and malleable, she tunes into her father\u2019s song, memorizes it and then stores it as a template for evaluating a mate\u2019s song later. This example reminds her that she didn\u2019t die, and her father helped ensure that. Perhaps something similar will work for her offspring.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFemales tend to prefer elaborate songs with more syllables.\n\nHow well the birds learn depends on a genetic predisposition to tune into sounds specific to their species. But experience is important too. Because social relationships are so powerful, a baby bird reared by the wrong species, Dr. Woolley has found, can learn the wrong species\u2019 song even if its biological father\u2019s song is audible.\n\n\u201cThe magic of the songbird is that vocal learning is incredibly rare to find in animals,\u201d said Dr. Woolley. \u201cNo ape can do it (except the human), no monkey can do it, and no rodent can do it.\u201d And she believes that by understanding more about how songbirds use their brains to make sense of sound, she can learn more about how humans use theirs to develop a spoken language early to communicate later in life.\n\nFor songbirds that form bonds with members of the same sex for life, songs, though still important message bearers, may be less important for finding a match.\n\nAnd although some humans may be less interested in words than other aspects like looks, scent, youth, money, power or whatever we find attractive in a partner, birdsongs remind us that good communication, in any pair, makes love possible. \u201cThe way that people fall in love, is talking to each other,\u201d Dr. Woolley said.", "title": "Some Songbirds Have Brains Specially Designed to Find Mates for Life", "authors": ["Joanna Klein"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "KILIS, Turkey \u2014 Turkey is relying on a newly reconfigured, 20,000-member American-trained force with three army corps as it tries to carve out a buffer zone within Syria. The force has already taken 16 casualties in two weeks of fighting on the front lines.\n\nBut the soldiers are not Turks. Rather they are the mostly Arab fighters of the Free Syrian Army, once trained and assembled by the C.I.A. and Western allies to oust President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.\n\nSince the routing of the Islamic State, alliances in Syria have been scrambled. The latest round of the conflict, in fact, features two American-trained forces fighting each other.\n\nThe Free Syrian Army, out of favor with the United States and badly depleted after seven years of fighting on multiple fronts, has long had common cause with Turkey, whose incursion has angered the Americans.", "title": "Some Syrian Refugees Are Going Back to War Alongside Turkey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "OSLO \u2014 The protocol for nominating and choosing recipients of the Nobel Peace Prize is one of the world\u2019s most scrutinized and secretive.\n\nA total of 329 candidates \u2014 217 individuals and 112 organizations \u2014 are being considered for this year\u2019s prize, which will be announced in October. The identities of the candidates are kept secret, and indeed, the Norwegian Nobel Committee, which awards the prizes, is forbidden from divulging any information about its deliberations for 50 years, and even then, only for scholarship purposes and at its discretion.\n\nBut a wrinkle in this time-honored process \u2014 the peace prize was first awarded in 1901 \u2014 emerged on Tuesday, when the committee announced that it had uncovered what appeared to be a forged nomination of President Trump for the prize. The matter has been referred to the Oslo police for investigation.\n\nMoreover, the forgery appears to have occurred twice: Olav Njolstad, the secretary of the five-member committee, said it appeared that a forged nomination of Mr. Trump for the prize was also submitted last year \u2014 and was also referred to the police. (The earlier forgery was not disclosed to the public at the time.)", "title": "Trump\u2019s Nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize Was Apparently Forged. Twice.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Sonia Gechtoff, a prominent Abstract Expressionist on the West Coast early in her career and later a mainstay of the New York art scene, died on Feb. 1 at a hospice center in the Bronx. She was 91.\n\nHer daughter, Susannah Kelly, confirmed the death.\n\nMs. Gechtoff made a quick and substantial impression in San Francisco, where she had arrived in 1951, a time when the Bay Area art scene was bubbling. An early oil, \u201cSelf Portrait,\u201d made in 1954 when she was still in her 20s, is now in the collection of the Smithsonian Institution. That same year she was represented in a group show of young painters at the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan.\n\nShe was also becoming well known in the California art world, with solo exhibitions at outlets like the de Young Museum in San Francisco and the Ferus Gallery in Los Angeles, both in 1957.", "title": "Sonia Gechtoff, Acclaimed Abstract Expressionist, Dies at 91", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "In an emailed statement on Sunday, the filmmakers and Sony Pictures apologized: \u201cFood allergies are a serious issue. Our film should not have made light of Peter Rabbit\u2019s archnemesis, Mr. McGregor, being allergic to blackberries, even in a cartoonish, slapstick way.\u201d\n\nThe statement, which was attributed in part to the film\u2019s director, writers and producers, added, \u201cWe sincerely regret not being more aware and sensitive to this issue, and we truly apologize.\u201d\n\nKenneth Mendez, the president and chief executive of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, saw the movie on Saturday.\n\nWhen the rabbits fire a blackberry into Mr. McGregor\u2019s mouth, Mr. Mendez said, \u201cthere\u2019s a close-up of his face, and it\u2019s him holding his neck like he\u2019s choking.\u201d When Mr. McGregor collapses and appears to be dead for a moment, the rabbits cheer.\n\nMr. Mendez said in an open letter to the moviemakers that they should not mock food allergies, which are often life-threatening.\n\n\u201cMaking light of this condition hurts our members because it encourages the public not to take the risk of allergic reactions seriously, and this cavalier attitude may make them act in ways that could put an allergic person in danger,\u201d it said.\n\nMr. McGregor, played by Domhnall Gleeson, is made out to be the villain for most of the movie. He is determined to keep rabbits off his property using whatever he needs, from garden tools to an electric fence.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPeter Rabbit is rascally too, and he seems to delight in mocking and hurting Mr. McGregor as the two battle for dominion over the garden.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe movie fits an old trope of children\u2019s shows in which two nemeses (like Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner, Elmer Fudd and Bugs Bunny, or Tom and Jerry) face off, often with slapstick violence in the form of explosions, high-speed crashes or falling anvils.\n\nThe reaction to the blackberry attack in \u201cPeter Rabbit,\u201d which is rated PG for rude humor and action, was mixed on social media. Some objected to what they saw as an insensitive disregard for allergies, and groups from as far away as Australia called for an apology. Others said it was only a movie and suggested that parents use it to start a conversation with their children about allergies.\n\nDr. Andrew Adesman, the chief of developmental and behavioral pediatrics at the Cohen Children\u2019s Medical Center of New York in Queens, said he remembered watching Wile E. Coyote cartoons as a child. He said the blackberry attack in \u201cPeter Rabbit\u201d is a little different because it purposely exploits a person\u2019s health condition.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s some research out there suggesting that what is depicted in this movie is a real-world experience for some children with life-threatening food allergies,\u201d Dr. Adesman said in an interview on Sunday. \u201cI can understand the outrage.\u201d\n\nNicole Drey of Merrick, N.Y., said her son Brayden, 7, has such severe allergies that she takes him to movie theaters early in the day, when the air and the seats are as clean as possible.\n\nThey went to see \u201cPeter Rabbit\u201d on Friday morning, Ms. Drey said in a phone interview. And when Mr. McGregor collapsed onscreen, she tried to reassure her son. \u201cI just kept explaining to him that it\u2019s make believe, it\u2019s not real, and people don\u2019t act that way,\u201d she said.\n\nBrayden did not like it.\n\n\u201cI was really afraid about the one part where they shot the blackberries,\u201d he said. \u201cI was upset because he had to use his EpiPen.\u201d\n\nIn real life, he added, using the EpiPen is \u201cscary.\u201d\n\nMs. Drey said that she knew it was just a children\u2019s film, but that \u201cpeople that don\u2019t deal with this don\u2019t understand.\u201d She has spent years helping Brayden deal with bullying, isolation, medical appointments and the everyday logistical challenges of finding safe food.\n\n\u201cI think there should have been a trigger warning, and we should have been notified somehow,\u201d she said of the movie. \u201cPut it out there, so we can at least talk to our kids about the contents and then make an informed decision.\u201d", "title": "Sony Apologizes for \u2018Peter Rabbit\u2019 Movie\u2019s Allergy Scene", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 It was a gray, drizzly day in Paris, but Laurence Nicolas had only the sunniest of thoughts on her mind. She was soon to move to New York, where \u201cI know it will be cold, but the sky will be blue,\u201d she said with a grin.\n\nBut more important than the weather, Ms. Nicolas, 53, is now the executive vice president, global managing director of jewelry and watches at Sotheby\u2019s. The position was created for her, an indication of the auction house\u2019s enhanced focus on watch and jewelry sales.\n\nWhile Sotheby\u2019s performance in the art market has been strong \u2014 the auction house\u2019s Masters Week Sales series this month brought in $82.5 million, nearly twice as much as last year\u2019s \u2014 Phillips has been stealing its thunder when it comes to watches.\n\n\u201cSotheby\u2019s has been suffering the most among auctioneers since the entrance of Phillips in the watch auction business,\u201d William Rohr, former chief operating officer of Antiquorum auctioneers, said. \u201cThey are the one that lost the most market share in 2017, especially in Geneva. To judge from furious street protests that have swept the nation, the party devolved in the eyes of many into a patronage network enriching a well-connected few.\n\nNow the A.N.C. is gaining a new opportunity after the resignation of President Jacob Zuma in the face of rampant accusations of corruption. The newly installed president, Cyril Ramaphosa, inherits the historic challenge that has evaded post-apartheid leaders \u2014 how to transform and reinvigorate an economy that long funneled most of the spoils to a narrow, predominantly white slice of the populace into a source of progress for the masses, elevating the country\u2019s overwhelmingly black population. And how to eliminate protections for South African conglomerates forged during apartheid.\n\nIt will not be easy.\n\nOverall economic growth is slow. By the end of 2016, South Africa\u2019s economy was still roughly the same size it was in 2009, according to the World Bank, which anticipates growth of about 1.1 percent this year. That makes the country one of the weakest economies on earth in a time of global expansion.", "title": "South Africa Sees Fresh Start for Economy, With the Same Challenges", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRamaphosa wouldn\u2019t have been elected without Mabuza,\u201d Mr. Friedman said.\n\nBut Mr. Mabuza, he said, was known for ruling with \u201can iron fist\u201d and for \u201cconsistent allegations of corruption.\u201d His province was also for many years the \u201cepicenter of political killings,\u201d Mr. Friedman said.\n\nThe appointment of Mr. Mabuza to the second-highest position in the government \u2014 one that has served as a springboard to the presidency in South Africa\u2019s post-apartheid history \u2014 could undermine Mr. Ramaphosa\u2019s pledge to root out corruption, experts said.\n\n\u201cHow can Ramaphosa claim to be anti-corruption when he is standing next to such a morally compromised figure as David Mabuza?\u201d said Ralph Mathekga, a political analyst and author. \u201cWhen he talks about being anti-corruption, he\u2019ll just have to sing to the birds, because no one else will listen.\u201d\n\nIn his state of the nation address a day after being sworn in as president this month, Mr. Ramaphosa said that \u201ca new dawn is upon us.\u201d He promised to rejuvenate the economy, create jobs and fight corruption.\n\nEarlier this month, Mr. Ramaphosa pushed Mr. Zuma to resign as the nation\u2019s leader, though his term did not expire until mid-2019. Mr. Ramaphosa persuaded the party\u2019s top leaders that getting rid of the unpopular, scandal-plagued Mr. Zuma as soon as possible would help the party rebuild itself before national elections next year.\n\nIn December, Mr. Ramaphosa, who had served as Mr. Zuma\u2019s deputy for nearly four years, was elected leader of the A.N.C., defeating Mr. Zuma\u2019s preferred candidate. In a country where the president is chosen by Parliament, the A.N.C.\u2019s top leaders effectively select the nation\u2019s leader.", "title": "South Africa\u2019s New President Names Allies and Rivals to Cabinet", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Jacob Zuma finally succumbed to growing pressure from the African National Congress and resigned as South Africa\u2019s president on Wednesday. Once a hero of the resistance to apartheid, Mr. Zuma became increasingly embroiled in sordid corruption scandals, prompting the A.N.C. to elect another leader and to effectively force Mr. Zuma out of office.\n\nThat done, the question now is whether the A.N.C., the party of Nelson Mandela, which has had a near-monopoly on South African politics since the end of minority rule, can cleanse and revive itself under Cyril Ramaphosa, its new leader, who is now all but certain of being elected the nation\u2019s president by Parliament.\n\nMr. Ramaphosa, a onetime labor leader and prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Mr. Mandela who made a fortune in business and leads the party\u2019s reformist wing, was elected president of the A.N.C. in a hotly contested election in December. Since Parliament chooses the president in South Africa and the A.N.C. controls Parliament, the expectation was that Mr. Zuma would step down. But he refused, until the party this week threatened a vote of no confidence to force him out.\n\nThere is nothing to regret in Mr. Zuma\u2019s fall. Though he spent time in prison with Mr. Mandela and in exile, on coming to power he succumbed to the sordid lure of power\u2019s perks and now faces multiple accusations of corruption and other unethical behavior. He also came to be identified with a nation economically adrift and unable to achieve the economic equality promised at the end of white rule. But the A.N.C. continued to prop up Mr. Zuma, at least until the party itself began losing its once unassailable popularity and Mr. Zuma became a liability ahead of national elections in 2019.", "title": "Opinion | South Africa\u2019s Zuma Leaves Behind a Broken Democracy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\n\nBut experts who monitor development in the South China Sea say the photos show the islands in dispute and are consistent with satellite imagery of the development that they have been monitoring for years.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nConor Cronin, a research associate at the Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said the buildings in the new images were at the same scale as the structures in the photographs his group regularly assesses from the region. The initiative monitors development in an area long shrouded in secrecy.\n\nWhat\u2019s striking about these images, he said, is that for the first time, significant surface-level details can be seen.\n\n\u201cThese are kind of rare shots to see publicly,\u201d Mr. Cronin said, noting that the detailed views of the island, seen from a much closer angle than the satellite level, were insightful. \u201cIt\u2019s another indication of how well established these facilities are and kind of the capabilities they are going to have.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nThe development of the Spratly Islands has ignited outrage from neighbors that also lay claim to this portion of the South China Sea. To varying degrees, the Philippines, Taiwan, Vietnam and Malaysia all stake claim to parts of the area.\n\nWhile tensions have eased somewhat as China negotiates an agreement with other players on a code of conduct for the region \u2014 which seems to allow economic development without resolving the underlying sovereignty disputes \u2014 the unabated pace of construction could stir fresh tensions.\n\nBonnie S. Glaser, a senior adviser for Asia at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the photos provided a unique perspective. She said she believed, particularly given the annotations on the images, that they were most likely taken by a military aircraft.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat is really quite stunning is how clear you can see in these aerial photos how much has been built,\u201d Ms. Glaser said. \u201cIt\u2019s really up close and personal.\u201d\n\nA recent assessment from the Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative of satellite imagery revealed that China had developed 72 acres, both above and below ground, in the South China Sea in 2017 alone. Since the construction first began in 2013, China has developed more than 3,200 acres across the area.\n\nMore recently, the Chinese have turned their attention from dredging and reclaiming land to building airstrips, radar and communications facilities and hangars.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Mischief Reef, which was once largely underwater, 1,379 acres have been developed by China. It was a bit like playing baseball in Boston or soccer in Rio de Janeiro. The people get it.\n\nOne big difference was the presence of the North Korean cheering section, consisting of more than 100 young women in matching red warm-up suits and ceaseless smiles. They performed a choreographed song from their seats in the upper bowl, moving in perfect formation, swaying their bodies and swirling their hands. Sometimes they waved small flags, first the North Korean one (long banned in South Korea, but increasingly routine at these Olympics) and then the one being used as a unified flag between the two nations. South Koreans clapped with them or aimed their smartphones at the spectacle. Eventually, predictably, they started a wave.\n\nBut not before the South Korean president, Moon Jae-in, was ushered to his seat at mid-ice, next to Vice President Mike Pence of the United States. Or before two Korean singers performed \u201cUptown Funk\u201d and were later joined by a horn section, a house band like a Korean version of the Roots. There was a kiss cam.\n\nBy the end of the night, after the political dignitaries were gone, after the superstar Choi Min-jeong set an Olympic record in the 500-meter qualifying, and after the South Korean women\u2019s relay team set another Olympic record despite a midrace tumble, a quiet 21-year-old named Lim Hyo-jun was on the top step of a podium, winner of South Korea\u2019s first gold medal of these Olympics, soaking in the adulation of the crowd and a nation.", "title": "South Korea Goes Wild for Short-Track Speedskating (and Its First Gold)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Germany dominates luge the way the University of Connecticut dominates women\u2019s college basketball. The country has four luge tracks, and nearly a quarter of the world\u2019s courses for elite competitions. The success is a remnant of the country\u2019s Cold War divide. Of the 129 Olympic medals awarded in luge since 1964, 75 have been won by East or West Germans or athletes from the unified team.\n\nAt the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, German lugers won all four available gold medals. Frisch failed to make that sliding team. Competition and pressure are immense to make the country\u2019s Olympic squad. Discouraged, she retired in 2015 at age 22.\n\n\u201cIt was frustrating,\u201d Frisch, now 25, said. \u201cI didn\u2019t have much fun anymore.\u201d\n\nThen came an unexpected call.\n\nSouth Korea\u2019s luge federation hired a German, Steffen Sartor, to be its national coach in preparation for the Olympics. And Sartor contacted Frisch in late 2015 to gauge her interest in competing for South Korea in the Games. Her first response was no.\n\nIn early 2016, a second entreaty came. This time Frisch reconsidered. She missed traveling and competing. And she was drawn to South Korea\u2019s history of existing on a divided peninsula. In some ways, it resembled Germany\u2019s own rived past.\n\n\u201cI liked the idea of becoming Korean,\u201d Frisch said.\n\nShe took 40 hours of language, history and cultural lessons from a teacher in Germany, then moved to South Korea and immersed herself in the language and the culture. At first, some South Korean lugers were wary of her presence, Frisch said.\n\n\u201cI got the feeling that some of my teammates thought I should have not come to Korea,\u201d she said. \u201cThey thought I\u2019m just a foreigner and were afraid I would take their place. They did not see that I could also help them to become better.\u201d", "title": "South Korea Got the Winter Games. Then It Needed More Olympians.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "The scandal began in 2016, when students at a prestigious Seoul university alleged that Ms. Choi had used her influence with Ms. Park to force the school to admit her daughter, despite a lack of qualifications. (It would later emerge that some of the money Ms. Choi secured from South Korean businesses went to finance her daughter\u2019s equestrian career.)\n\nLocal news media began digging, and former associates of Ms. Choi turned into whistle-blowers. Soon, South Korea had its biggest corruption scandal in decades. Huge crowds of demonstrators filled central Seoul every weekend for months on end, and Parliament impeached Ms. Park in December 2016. The Constitutional Court formally ousted her last March.\n\nThe scandal rekindled longstanding public anger over the extensive ties between government and corporations in South Korea. Ms. Park tearfully apologized to the public, cutting ties with Ms. Choi and insisting that she was not aware of her activities.\n\nMs. Choi has remained loyal to Ms. Park, insisting that both were innocent. Both have also argued that they were victims of a politically motivated investigation. But prosecutors called them criminal conspirators, an argument that the court endorsed on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cWe are speechless,\u201d Lee Kyung-jae, Ms. Choi\u2019s lawyer, said, adding that she would appeal.\n\nMs. Park, who has been in custody since March, is being tried separately on 18 criminal charges, including bribery, coercion and abuse of office. She still has loyal followers, who rally in central Seoul calling for her release. On her 66th birthday this month, they placed a large cake in front of the prison where she is being held.\n\nThe ruling on Tuesday could have ramifications for the trial of Mr. Lee, the Samsung leader. Last August, he was sentenced to five years in prison for offering $6.7 million in bribes to Ms. Choi and Ms. Park. But the appeals court that freed Mr. Lee this month said the bribes had totaled just $3.3 million, and accordingly reduced his prison term by half (and suspended the sentence).\n\nThe judges handling Ms. Choi\u2019s case on Tuesday, however, said that Mr. Lee had indeed paid $6.7 million in bribes. That information is likely to come before the Supreme Court, which now has Mr. Lee\u2019s case.\n\nMr. Lee, the vice chairman of Samsung Electronics and the third-generation scion of the family that runs the Samsung conglomerate, has denied the charges against him, saying that Samsung was coerced into contributing to support Ms. Choi\u2019s foundations and her daughter.", "title": "South Korean Court Sentences Ex-President\u2019s Confidante to 20 Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, urged the United States and North Korea on Monday to soften their uncompromising stances so that talks could start on defusing the crisis prompted by the North\u2019s nuclear program and Washington\u2019s threats to stop it with military force.\n\nDuring a meeting with China\u2019s vice premier, Liu Yandong, Mr. Moon said both North Korea and the United States had begun showing a willingness for talks. But Mr. Moon said both sides still needed to step back from their uncompromising stances to make talks possible, according to a statement from his office.\n\n\u201cThe United States needs to lower the threshold for dialogue, and North Korea should express a willingness to denuclearize,\u201d Mr. Moon was quoted as saying, summarizing the obstacles he faced in trying to get the two countries to sit down for talks.\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s remarks came a day after he met Kim Yong-chol, a senior North Korean official who attended the closing ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, on Sunday. Given the deep mistrust between both sides, though, that is far from an assurance that negotiations will occur.", "title": "South Korean Leader Urges U.S. and North Korea to Make Talks Possible", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 In the highest-level contact between the two Koreas in years, President Moon Jae-in of South Korea plans to meet Saturday with the sister of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, and the North\u2019s nominal head of state, officials said on Thursday.\n\nMr. Moon\u2019s luncheon meeting with the North Koreans was announced on Thursday, as Vice President Mike Pence arrived in South Korea carrying a message from Washington: not to waver from strong sanctions against North Korea.\n\nThe high-level North Korean delegation, headed by Kim Yong-nam, the North\u2019s ceremonial head of state, will arrive in South Korea on Friday on a special plane to attend the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics later in the day. The trip\u2019s significance was underscored by the revelation on Wednesday that the delegation would include Kim Yo-jong, the only sister and a trusted aide of Kim Jong-un, the supreme leader.\n\nIn North Korea\u2019s dynastic system, which upholds the Kim family\u2019s \u201cbloodline\u201d as a sacred leadership qualification, Ms. Kim wields a singular clout that cannot be matched by any nonrelative members of the elite, regardless of their official titles, according to North Korea analysts.", "title": "South Korean Leader to Meet Kim Jong-un\u2019s Sister in Highest-Level Contact in Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "When the whirlwind of the Winter Olympics spins to a close this weekend, the host city, Pyeongchang, South Korea, will settle down to a life beyond aerial flips, halfpipe pretzels and metronomic North Korean cheerleaders. The place will become, once again, a quiet spot where very few children live \u2014 its population a disproportionately elderly one, dependent on an imperiled social-security system. Pyeongchang played a happy Olympic host, but its everyday economic reality highlights an existential threat shadowing South Korea. It\u2019s not (or not only) the North Korean missiles and nuclear weapons arrayed across the border just 50 miles away. The more intractable danger is a demographic time bomb already starting to detonate across South Korea and all over East Asia.\n\nJapan, with its shrinking population, has long been the region\u2019s pace setter for demographic doom. But South Korea\u2019s fertility rate has plummeted to one of the lowest in the world, barely more than one child per woman. Throw in rising life expectancy, and South Korea is now aging faster than any other advanced economy on Earth. Between 1975 and 2015, its median age soared to 41.2 from just 19.6. In Gangwon, the potato-growing province that encompasses Pyeongchang, the median age is expected to pass 60 by 2045. (The median age in the United States, now 37.9, is predicted to creep up to 42 by 2045.) Thousands of South Korean schools have already been abandoned for lack of students.\n\nThe economic fallout of this demographic shift could be devastating. After transforming itself from a poor, war-ravaged agricultural society into a manufacturing giant in just a few decades, South Korea now faces one peril of prosperity: a labor shortage that will be a drag on both the economy and the pension system for its aging residents. Like the rest of East Asia, Seoul has tried to increase birthrates, offering child care bonuses, fertility treatments, even gifts of beef for families with newborns. Some of its efforts, though, come across as little more than pressuring women to marry and reproduce. In one instance, the government published (and then retracted) an online \u201cbirth map\u201d that showed, in shades of pink, the number of women of childbearing age by city and region.\n\nFailing in its push, South Korea opted to pull. It has brought in \u2014 cautiously, but still much more actively than China or Japan \u2014 a growing number of foreign migrants. Back in 1990, the country was so insular that it had fewer than 50,000 foreign nationals. Today there are more than two million, a 40-fold increase, most from China, Vietnam and other parts of Southeast Asia. \u201cWhat other options are there?\u201d says Mihyung Park, the head of the South Korea office of the International Organization for Migration. \u201cThe South Korean economy cannot function without foreign workers.\u201d", "title": "South Korea\u2019s Most Dangerous Enemy: Demographics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Asked to elaborate, she said through an interpreter that the country really only got behind curling in 2014, and because it remains less popular than other sports, it has been difficult to obtain the resources to properly develop athletes. As the words rushed out of Kim Min-jung, the curlers sat next to her on the podium, stone-faced.\n\nThe news conference, which began with the moderator announcing that the curlers would not answer \u201cpolitical or sensitive questions,\u201d contained a few lighthearted moments. Kim Eun-jung, 27, the team skip, essentially a captain on the ice, explained that \u201cEun\u201d means silver in Korean. So maybe, she said with a laugh, she should change her name to \u201cGeum-Jung because geum means gold.\u201d\n\nBut then her tone changed. She said the team went through \u201ca lot in order to be successful.\u201d\n\nThe curlers\u2019 somber expressions throughout most of the news conference gave the impression the silver medals hung heavy around their necks. Their expressions brightened when they left the interview tent and were greeted by men in police bibs and volunteers who clapped and took photographs.\n\n\u201cIt was our first time ever to really curl in front of a big audience,\u201d said Kim Seon-Yeong. \u201cAll I can say is \u2018Thank you so much.\u2019\u201d", "title": "South Korea\u2019s \u2018Garlic Girls\u2019 Fall to Sweden in Olympic Curling", "authors": ["Karen Crouse"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. After Hurricane Maria, a one-woman company was awarded a huge contract by FEMA to provide 30 million meals. Only 50,000 were delivered.\n\nDemocrats on the House Oversight Committee are investigating. Lawmakers fear the agency is not lining up potential contractors in advance, leading to frantic searches when disasters strike \u2014 and predictably messy results.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. A 35-year-old Saudi man who had been living in Oklahoma for years was arrested on a charge of visa fraud.\n\nThe reason? The F.B.I. says it recently discovered his fingerprints on a document recovered in Afghanistan, an application from nearly two decades ago for an Al Qaeda training camp. Above, a video from the camp, which was destroyed in 2001.\n\nThe government has a huge backlog of materials and data that were collected in nearly two decades of war, but have yet to be processed.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. The president of Poland, Andrzej Duda, above, said he would sign a bill making it illegal to accuse his country of complicity in the Holocaust, including referring to \u201cPolish death camps.\u201d\n\nThe measure has roiled relations with Israel and the U.S., and spurred claims that the nationalist government is trying to whitewash one of the bloodiest chapters in Poland\u2019s history.\n\nOpponents say it would stifle free speech and put questions of historical accuracy into the hands of judges and prosecutors.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. A mutant is taking over Europe. The marbled crayfish didn\u2019t exist until about 25 years ago. A drastic mutation in a single crayfish produced the species in an instant \u2014 and gave the creature the ability to clone itself. In fact, they produce nothing but fertile offspring, so populations are exploding.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Quentin Tarantino responded to Uma Thurman\u2019s accusation that he had put her life at risk while making the \u201cKill Bill\u201d films.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an interview with Maureen Dowd that we published over the weekend (and that is still drawing large numbers of readers), Ms. Thurman detailed how she was injured during filming. She had requested that a stunt driver handle a refitted car, but was forced to take the wheel and crashed. \u201cDehumanization to the point of death,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Tarantino called his decision to make her do the driving one of the biggest regrets of his life. Above, the two in 2004.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, our critic gave a hearty thumbs up to the new \u201cBlack Panther\u201d movie from Marvel.\n\n\u201cIt wouldn\u2019t be a Marvel production without manly skirmishes and digital avatars,\u201d she writes. \u201cYet in its emphasis on black imagination, creation and liberation, the movie becomes an emblem of a past that was denied and a future that feels very present. And in doing so opens up its world, and yours, beautifully.\u201d\n\nThe film opens widely late next week.\n\nHave a great night.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday.
