[The New York Times]", "title": "SpaceX, Wall Street, Poland: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "MADRID \u2014 Whether by law or intimidation, Spain has become a country where the risks of free expression have quietly mounted in recent years.\n\nPuppeteers have been prosecuted for inciting terrorism. So have a 21-year-old Twitter user, a poet and some musicians, including the 12 members of a band. A much criticized law has made it illegal to film the faces of police officers on the streets, and sharply restricts public gatherings.\n\nOn Wednesday, the chill entered the realm of contemporary art, when Madrid\u2019s main exhibition center ordered that a work labeling Catalonia\u2019s separatist leaders as political prisoners be removed from an international arts fair.\n\nThe exhibition center, known as Ifema, is controlled by the regional and local governments of Madrid, though it remains unclear who exactly decided to order the removal of the work, \u201cContemporary Spanish Political Prisoners,\u201d by the artist Santiago Sierra.", "title": "Spanish Artwork Denounced Political \u2018Persecution.\u2019 It Was Ordered Removed.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nEvery spring and fall for 32 years, my sister and I would meet in New York City for a two-night rendezvous. She left her husband and children at home in Rochester; I left my husband and children at home in Newton, Mass.\n\nWe would go to the theater, museums, the latest \u201chot\u201d restaurants and shopping at Bergdorf Goodman and Saks. At night, we would talk into the wee hours about our children, marriages, careers and, eventually, grandchildren. We would laugh the kind of laughter that starts deep in the belly and rises until tears start to flow.\n\nOn one trip, in spring 2002, I was checking in at the Park Lane Hotel. As I finished registering, I heard a familiar voice from the other end of the counter say, \u201cHi, I\u2019m Arlene Davidson. I\u2019d like to check in.\u201d\n\nI turned and saw my sister.\n\n\u201cArlene!\u201d I called.\n\nWe ran toward each other, hugging and kissing and laughing at our perfect timing.", "title": "Special Sister Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s such a pleasure to be making my themeless debut today, since I always look forward to the themeless puzzles each week. I chose this grid in part for its pleasing symmetry, but also for its versatility. While it\u2019s true that there are no entries in the grid longer than seven letters, the fact that there are 36 of these slots meant that I had a good amount of flexibility in placing my marquee answers. This 72-word grid also allowed me to incorporate some Scrabbly letters into lively entries without too much difficulty, and to maintain a nice grid flow throughout the puzzle while still being able to work on sections one at a time.\n\nI started in the lower-left with CAPTCHA, which I found yielded promising letter combinations when paired with AM I RITE. The discovery that CTHULHU, another entry on my 7-letter seed list, could fit at 61-Across ended up being the key to finishing the corner, despite its delightfully odd combination of letters (not that I ever doubted the power of the Great Old One, mind you).\n\nI did the upper-left next, as ST. JOHNS was one of my few choices for 24-Down. I was glad to be able to fit in DAD JOKE and NOXZEMA, as well as DNA LABS, which I think makes for a nice 1-Across, what with the interesting DN- start and Will and Joel\u2019s fantastic clue. Among other entries in the upper-right, I thought it would be cool to incorporate B.J. NOVAK, in order to highlight both his great performance in \u201cThe Office\u201d and the unusual opening letter sequence of BJN- (see a pattern here yet?) As it was the last to go in, filling the lower-right took the most time, but I\u2019m pleased with how it turned out, especially with the unexpected intersection of CAKE MIX and XS AND OS at the X.\n\nAS I SAID, it\u2019s a joy to see this puzzle in The Times \u2014 while I\u2019ve constructed several other themeless puzzles since then, this one might still be my favorite. Hope you enjoy solving it as much as I enjoyed creating it.\n\nP.S. Here\u2019s a bonus puzzle: purely by happenstance, one entry ended up in a particularly appropriate location \u2014 which one?", "title": "Speed of Sound", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 At least nine children were killed and 20 others injured on Saturday after a speeding vehicle rammed a crowd outside a government school in northern India.\n\nThe crash occurred around 1:30 p.m., as children were leaving school for the day, near Muzaffarpur, in Bihar State.\n\n\u201cThe accident happened on the road while the children were trying to cross,\u201d Dharmendra Singh, a local official, said in an interview with Zee Hindustan, a Hindi language news channel.\n\nMithilesh Yadav, who saw the crash, told The Hindustan Times newspaper that the vehicle, a Bolero, had swerved to avoid another accident and hit the children. Gaurav Pandey, the deputy police superintendent for the area, told the newspaper that the Bolero\u2019s driver had abandoned the vehicle and fled.", "title": "Speeding Car Plows Into Students in India, Killing at Least 9", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 The night train to Silchar was moving fast \u2014 too fast, the authorities say.\n\nAs it chugged into a forested area of northeastern India on Saturday night, a group of villagers waved their flashlights frantically, urging the driver to slow down. He didn\u2019t know why, but he soon found out.\n\nAhead in the darkness, a large herd of elephants was ambling across the railway tracks. When the train driver finally saw what was in front of him, he hit the emergency brake, railway officials said, but it was too late.\n\nThe 14-car passenger train plowed right into the herd. Two calves and two adult elephants were killed instantly, and an adult elephant that was badly injured died on Monday. Some local news reports said that several baby elephants had not even moved as the train approached, and that adult elephants had sought to protect them by surrounding them.\n\nIndian forestry officials said the warnings had been ignored for a simple reason: The train was running 10 minutes late.", "title": "Speeding Train Plows Into Elephants in India, Killing 5 Animals", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Similar to today\u2019s black widows and huntsman spiders, C. yingi had silk-producing spinnerets near its rear end. The males of this species also had two modified appendages called pedipalps near their heads that were used like syringes to deliver sperm to females. But unlike today\u2019s spiders, C. yingi had a long tail, like those seen in whip-scorpions or vinegarroons.\n\n\u201cTake the front of a spider, the end of a vinegarroon and then you put spinnerets on it and that\u2019s our fossil,\u201d said Gonzalo Giribet, an invertebrate biologist from Harvard University and an author on one of the papers.\n\nThough the arachnid was quite small, only about 2.5 millimeters long, it had a tail nearly twice its body size. The tail, or telson, was most likely a sensory organ rather than an acid-flinging weapon as seen in whip scorpions.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like an antenna on the back end,\u201d said Paul Selden, a paleontologist at the University of Kansas and an author of the second study.\n\n[READ: That Thing With Feathers Trapped in Amber? It Was a Dinosaur Tail]\n\nThe creature\u2019s peculiar mix of features presented a puzzle for the teams led by Dr. Giribet and Dr. Selden. How do they classify it?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDr. Giribet and his team suggest that C. yingi belonged to a group of extinct spider relatives called Uraraneida, which had tails. Unlike today\u2019s spiders, uraraneids had plates on their bellies rather than squishy abdomens. They also had their silk-producing organs, or spigots, on the edges of their plates, and not on rear end spinnerets like modern spiders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough Dr. Selden and his colleagues agree it\u2019s possible C. yingi may have been a part of the Uraraneida group, they also suggest that it could earn its own branch on the evolutionary tree right between spiders and Uraraneida.\n\nDr. Edgecombe said the two groups of researchers agreed that uraraneids were the closest relatives of spiders. But he added that the classification of whether C. yingi was more closely related to uraraneids or to modern spiders isn\u2019t yet resolved.\n\nOnly by finding more arachnids in amber can scientists weave together the rest of the spider\u2019s evolutionary history.", "title": "Spiderlike Creature With a Scorpion\u2019s Tail Is Found Trapped in Amber", "authors": ["Nicholas St. Fleur"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019re interested in your feedback on this page. Tell us what you think.", "title": "Sportswear That\u2019s Subtle \u2014 and Revolutionary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The company, showing no shortage of ambition, said that its mission was \u201cto unlock the potential of human creativity by giving a million creative artists the opportunity to live off their art and billions of fans the opportunity to enjoy and be inspired by these creators.\u201d\n\nFor the music industry, Spotify \u2014 and the streaming model it has championed \u2014 has been a powerful engine. After more than a decade of decline, the global music market began to turn around in about 2015, just as streaming began to take hold.\n\nIn the United States, for example, streaming now accounts for about two-thirds of recorded music revenues, according to the Recording Industry Association of America, and streaming platforms like Spotify, Apple Music, YouTube and SoundCloud have become the new outlets where stars develop and hits are minted.\n\nEven so, many artists remain skeptical of the streaming economy, which heavily rewards mainstream hits but has drawn complaints from other songwriters and musicians, particularly those outside the sphere of pop, who feel they are not being adequately compensated for their work.\n\nSpotify\u2019s prospectus is the most detailed disclosure the company has given about its business.\n\nAccording to the filing, Spotify, which began its streaming service in Sweden in 2008 and came to the United States three years later, had nearly $5 billion in revenue in 2017, up 38.6 percent from the year before. In 2016, it had grown by 52 percent.\n\nBy the end of 2017, Spotify, whose full name is Spotify Technology, had 159 million active users, including 71 million who pay for subscriptions; the rest, using the \u201cfreemium\u201d model that has become Spotify\u2019s marketing hallmark, get free access to music but are subjected to advertisements.\n\nAs quickly as Spotify has grown, though, so have its losses. Last year, it had a net loss of $1.5 billion, up from about $650 million the year before. Its largest expense, by far, is the cost of licenses from record companies and music publishers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe prospectus also highlights Spotify\u2019s successes, and its value to the music industry. Through the end of last year, the company had paid more than $10 billion in music royalties since its inception, and its \u201cchurn\u201d \u2014 a measure of how many paying users cancel each month \u2014 has been steadily declining, to 5.5 percent in 2017 from 7.7 percent in 2015.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe largest stakes are owned by its two founders: Daniel Ek, the chief executive and the company\u2019s public face, and Martin Lorentzon, who holds no executive position. In addition to their shares, they also have \u201cbeneficiary certificates\u201d granting them extra voting rights. In total, Mr. Ek has 37.3 percent voting power over the company, and Mr. Lorentzon 43.1 percent, according to the prospectus.\n\nThe major record labels also own minority stakes in the company, as a result of licensing deals struck over the years. Sony has the largest, with 5.7 percent; the others were not disclosed.\n\nSpotify\u2019s major competitor is Apple, whose co-founder Steve Jobs had long disdained music subscriptions. Apple finally entered the streaming subscription business in 2015 with Apple Music, and recently said that it had 36 million paying users. But according to a recent report in The Wall Street Journal, Apple Music has been outpacing Spotify in its growth in paid subscribers in the United States.\n\nThe market for public offerings has been robust so far this year. Through late February, 30 companies listed their shares publicly on markets in the United States, raising $11.4 billion from investors. That was the strongest annual start for the market since 2000, according to data from Thomson Reuters.\n\nAt least some of the highly valued, privately held technology companies, known as unicorns, could move quickly to capitalize on the opportunity and sell shares publicly.\n\nLast week, for instance, the online file storage company Dropbox, valued by the private markets at about $10 billion, filed paperwork to raise up to $500 million in an initial public offering.\n\nBut to convert that paper wealth into actual cash at top dollar, early-stage investors, company founders and employees with stock options need receptive public markets to buy their shares.\n\nIf the public investors do not think the companies are worth as much as the small number of deep-pocketed investors who dominate the private markets, it could mean the large amounts of paper wealth could be vaporized once the company\u2019s shares start trading.\n\nThat\u2019s effectively what happened last year, when some prominent public offerings fizzled once the shares were trading publicly. Shares of Snap, the start-up behind the popular Snapchat app, surged when it went public last March, but it has since had difficulty staying above its offering price of $17 a share. And the meal-delivery start-up Blue Apron, which went public at $10 a share last June, is now trading at less than $3 a share.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGiven that it involves a direct listing, Spotify\u2019s debut on the public markets has the potential to be even more volatile.", "title": "Spotify Files to Go Public on the New York Stock Exchange", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The filing says Spotify had \u20ac3.67 billion of premium streaming revenue last year. The cost of that revenue last year was \u20ac2.87 billion. The difference between those numbers, the gross profit on streaming revenue, was equivalent to 22 percent of that revenue. That is well up from 16 percent in 2016 and 15 percent in 2015. And how did Spotify bolster its margins? A big factor: It signed more advantageous licensing agreements with music companies. \u201cThis decrease in cost of revenue as a percentage of premium revenue was driven largely by a reduction in content costs pursuant to new licensing agreements,\u201d the filing said.\n\nBut can Spotify keep turning the screw? The music companies might be willing to compromise on price because the overall amount of dollars they receive is going up, making life easier for the first time in years. But, with Apple, Amazon and others adding subscribers, competition is intensifying. The music industry might be able to exploit that.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nSpotify\u2019s cash flow mystery\n\nAccounting nerds delving into Spotify\u2019s filing will have stumbled on an odd discrepancy.\n\nTwo metrics that attempt to capture how much cash a company is taking in had very different totals for 2017. Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, was negative to the tune of \u20ac324 million last year. But net cash flows from operations totaled \u20ac179 million in 2017. Both totals benefited from adding back large noncash financing costs. So what items bolstered operating cash flows but not Ebitda?\n\nIt looks like operating cash flows did better in part because Spotify waited to pay some of its bills. Such items make up what is often called working capital. Spotify wrung \u20ac439 million of cash out of working capital in 2017. The question for investors is whether the company can do that every year.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nSpotify files to go public.\n\nThe streaming music service filed its prospectus for a direct listing on the New York Stock Exchange, an unusual route that bypasses the traditional initial public offering process.\n\nDirect listings essentially move trading in a company\u2019s stock from private markets to public ones, with new investors buying shares on the open market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWall Street and Silicon Valley will watch Spotify\u2019s listing closely. If it goes well, it could spur other high profile start-ups to pursue a direct listing. Wall Street bankers are unlikely to cheer such a development. Direct listings generate lower fees than the typical I.P.O.\n\nSpotify won\u2019t embark on its roadshow, a series of meetings with investor ahead of the listing, for at least 15 days.\n\nHere\u2019s a look at the details:\n\nTicker symbol: SPOT\n\nPrice range for private shares in 2017: $37.50-$125.00\n\nPrice range for private shares this year: $90.00-$132.50\n\nValuation range in 2017: $6.3 billion to $20.9 billion\n\nValuation range this year: $15.9 billion to $23.4 billion\n\nValuation based on the midpoint of its 2018 price range: $19.7 billion\n\nLoss: \u20ac1.2 billion in 2017, up from \u20ac225 million in 2015\n\nOperating loss: \u20ac378 million, compared with \u20ac235 million in 2015.\n\nRevenue: \u20ac4.1 billion last year, up from \u20ac1.9 billion in 2015.\n\nFree cash flow: \u20ac109 million in 2017\n\nEbitda: -\u20ac324 million in 2017\n\nMonthly average users: 159 million last year, up from 91 million in 2015\n\nPremium subscribers: 71 million, up from 28 million in 2015\n\nShare of global streaming music market: 42 percent\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe amount Spotify has paid in royalties to record labels since its inception: More than $8 billion\n\nPercent of total voting power controlled by co-founder and chief executive, Daniel Ek: 37.3 percent\n\nPercent of total voting power controlled by co-founder, Martin Lorentzon: 43.1 percent\n\nRisks of a direct listing: \u201cOur ability to sell your ordinary shares at or above the price you bought them for due to (i) our listing not having the same safeguards as an underwritten initial public offering, which may result in the public price of our ordinary shares being volatile and declining significantly upon listing, or (ii) the failure of an active, liquid, and orderly market for our ordinary shares to develop or be sustained.\u201d\n\nBig year for I.P.O.s so far.\n\nDespite a sharp selloff in financial markets in early February, the market for public offerings started 2018 with a bang.\n\nThrough late February, 30 companies publicly listed their shares on markets in the United States, raising $11.4 billion from investors. That was the strongest annual start for the market since 2000, according to data from Thomson Reuters.\n\nThe pipeline of listings to come is also strong. On top of Spotify\u2019s listing, which should come in the next few weeks, Dropbox filed paperwork last week to go public.\n\nPhoto\n\nDick\u2019s takes a big step to limit gun sales\n\nOne of the U.S.\u2019s biggest gun sellers, Dick\u2019s Sporting Goods, said that it would stop selling assault-style rifles and high-capacity magazines, as well as limit sales of any gun to those 21 and older.\n\nIn doing so, the retailer is steering directly into the controversy that has embroiled companies that have taken on the American gun lobby.\n\nDick\u2019s C.E.O., Edward Stack, told the NYT:\n\n\u201cWhen we saw what happened in Parkland, we were so disturbed and upset. We love these kids and their rallying cry, \u2018enough is enough.\u2019 It got to us.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s next: Mr. Stack wants what he calls \u201ccommon sense\u201d changes to gun laws, like the steps his company is taking and broader universal background checks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhy it\u2019s remarkable: Other companies, big and small, continue to sever ties to the National Rifle Association. Delta has been openly dressed down \u2014 and potentially punished \u2014 by Republicans in Georgia after eliminating discounts for N.R.A. members. (Gun control is certainly a hot topic in the midterm election campaign.)\n\nAnd then there\u2019s this: FedEx and UPS are feuding over ties to the N.R.A.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe end of an era for Ackman; the start for another one?\n\nOver five years ago, Bill Ackman boldly announced that he was shorting Herbalife, declaring the company a pyramid scheme and vowing to see its stock price down to zero.\n\nToday, Mr. Ackman finally gave up on that quest.\n\nThe Pershing Square Capital Management chief told CNBC that his firm had finally exited the short bet. That\u2019s after:\n\n\u2022 Mr. Ackman\u2019s frenemy, Dan Loeb, took the other side of that bet.\n\n\u2022 So did Carl Icahn, in one of the most prominent public spats in recent Wall Street history, before the two men made up. (That didn\u2019t stop Mr. Icahn from continuing to bet on Herbalife.)\n\nHow did Herbalife investors respond Wednesday? They pushed shares in the company up 8.5 percent to $94.04, an all-time high.\n\nBut Mr. Ackman has found a new investment: United Technologies.\n\nWhy? The hedge fund mogul told CNBC that he liked the company \u2014 which happens to be considering spinning off parts of itself as a way to get more value for the conglomerate\u2019s shareholders.\n\nShares in United Technologies were up 2.1 percent this afternoon, at $136.73.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nIs the family business a liability for Jared Kushner?\n\nFor months, the former real estate investor\u2019s inability to get a permanent top-secret security clearance has been a lightning rod for criticism. Now his interim credentials have been docked to secret and his West Wing portfolio clipped \u2014 and people are asking what happened.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne thing that has come up, per the WaPo, citing unidentified U.S. officials: Officials in China, Israel, Mexico and the United Arab Emirates have discussed how to manipulate him by taking advantage of his business dealings and complicated finances.\n\nSpeaking of the Kushner business: It\u2019s is in talks to buy Vornado out of 666 Fifth Ave., the troubled Manhattan skyscraper that the two own, according to the WSJ. Critics will ask, where would the money come from?\n\nUsers don\u2019t like the Snapchat redesign but\u2026\n\nIs it scaring off users? So far the answer seems to be no.\n\nCNBC reports Snap\u2019s download rates have remained strong, according to App Annie. And Snap\u2019s shares are up 5 percent.\n\nBackground\n\nSnap\u2019s redesign, which has been rolling out over the past few months, has faced growing criticism from users and weighed on the stock. Last week a tweet from Kylie Jenner, saying she did not open Snapchat, sent the stock tumbling 6 percent. Wall Street has picked up on the customer backlash and a couple of analysts have downgraded the stock.\n\nThe criticism has also overshadowed Snap\u2019s positive fourth-quarter results earlier this month that pushed its shares up nearly 50 percent.\n\nA lot of people are worried about E.T.F.s.\n\nBlackRock thinks that could be a risk to its business. From the risk factors in BlackRock\u2019s annual report:\n\nAs a leader in the index investing and asset management industry, BlackRock has been the subject of third-party commentary citing concerns about the growth of index investing, as well as perceived competition issues associated with asset managers managing stakes in multiple companies within certain industries, known as \u201ccommon ownership\u201d. The commentators argue that index funds have the potential to distort investment flows, create stock price bubbles, or conversely, exacerbate a decline in market prices.\n\nThe filing goes on to say:\n\nIf the conclusions advanced by such commentators were to gain traction or result in the enactment of policy measures that place limits on asset managers, BlackRock\u2019s business operations, reputation or financial condition may be adversely affected.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018Congratulations, Mr. Powell! You just hit America with a wake-up call!\u2019\n\nThat is how John D. Herrmann, an analyst who covers the bond markets for MUFG Securities Americas, reacted to the testimony in Congress of Jerome Powell. In a note to clients yesterday, Mr. Herrmann cataloged upbeat remarks that Mr. Powell made, and observed that Mr. Powell seemed optimistic not just about the current economic environment, but also the outlook for the next three to four years.\n\nWhat to make of Wall Street\u2019s response to Mr. Powell?\n\nOne interpretation is that Mr. Powell wants investors and others to be more prepared for higher interest rates. Wall Street seems to have settled on a scenario in which the Fed raises interest rates steadily over the next two years. Any sign that rates may rise much more quickly than expected could cause a panicky pullback in the financial markets, which could ultimately harm the economy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo help prevent that, Fed officials can say things aimed at prompting investors to give more consideration to certain outcomes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIs it working?\n\nArguably, if investors were more concerned, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note would be higher than the 2.88 percent it traded at on Wednesday morning. Bank of America Merrill Lynch is forecasting the 10-year Treasury yield will be 3.25 percent at the end of this year.\n\nAnyone surprised that the yield gets there far more quickly should not be after Mr. Powell\u2019s testimony.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nThe policy flyaround\n\n\u2022 Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has floated the idea of rejoining the Trans-Pacific Partnership, more than a year after President Trump walked away. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Washington and Beijing are bracing for a new cold war, as President Xi Jinping prepares to stay in power indefinitely.\n\n\u2022 Hope Hicks, the White House communications director, said that she hasn\u2019t lied about issues relevant to investigations into Russia\u2019s election interference. And the head of the N.S.A., Adm. Michael Rogers, said that the U.S. hasn\u2019t done enough to deter Russia from future meddling.\n\n\u2022 Facebook said that the Trump campaign spent slightly more per ad on its site than Hillary Clinton\u2019s. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Josh Raffel, who was brought to the White House as a spokesman for Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, is leaving. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Mick Mulvaney is focused on cutting financial firms\u2019 cost of complying with regulations by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Ben Carson, the Housing and Urban Development secretary, is under scrutiny for spending $31,000 for furniture for his office as the department looks to cut programs for the homeless, elderly and poor. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy Brian Roberts is butting heads with Rupert Murdoch\n\nIt\u2019s because the British satellite broadcaster Sky \u2014 which Comcast and 21st Century Fox are poised to fight over \u2014 is a smaller example of what U.S. telecom giants want to become. More from Stu Woo of the WSJ:\n\nSky is both a telecom operator \u2014 selling TV, internet and phone services \u2014 and a media company with its own original news, sports and entertainment programming. And Sky has reach beyond the U.K. market. It is a Pan-European operation, with businesses in Britain, Ireland, Germany, Austria, Italy, Spain and Switzerland.\n\nIt\u2019s also probably because everyone is worried about Netflix.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner: Investors are right to expect a bidding war, according to Chris Hughes of Gadfly.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Geely built up its stake in Daimler through complex derivative trades that allowed it to build up its holdings while limiting risk, unidentified sources said. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Toshiba\u2019s sale of its memory chip business has opened the door to other Japanese companies selling long-cherished businesses. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Talks about a merger between Walgreens Boots Alliance and AmerisourceBergen have ended without an agreement, unidentified sources said. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 Toys \u201cR\u201d Us is in talks to sell its Asian business to Fung Group, its local partner, for at least $1 billion, unnamed sources said. And its British arm has filed for administration and will begin winding down.\n\n\u2022 Baidu\u2019s streaming service, iQiyi, filed for an I.P.O. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Nomad Health, an online marketplace for health care jobs, has raised $12 million in new financing. (BusinessWire)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy Wall Street has been quiet on #MeToo\n\nWomen in finance aren\u2019t coming forward in huge numbers, in part because the movement has made the work environment more difficult to navigate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s what Brande Stellings, who runs advisory services at the women\u2019s advocacy group Catalyst, told Bethany McLean of Vanity Fair:\n\n\u201cWe have heard anecdotally that there is a chilling effect and that men are pulling back from sponsoring women,\u201d says Stellings. She heard that one company made a rule that men and women could not meet behind closed doors in the office.\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 A woman told police that she had a child with Steve Wynn after he raped her. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Spotify Is Getting Paid to Save the Music Industry: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Advocates are hoping that the more information they can bring to the surface, the more they can bend companies\u2019 or voters\u2019 behavior with it.\n\n\u201cWhat we want to create is sort of a living thing that puts companies on notice,\u201d said Martin Whittaker, chief executive of Just Capital, a nonpartisan group that has compiled data on how 90 public corporations plan to spend their tax savings, and which will send letters to 875 companies on Wednesday seeking more information on those plans. Its initial release includes breakdowns of how individual companies will allocate their tax savings, based on their public statements and disclosures.\n\nPaul Tudor Jones, a hedge fund titan who is a co-founder of Just Capital, said he hoped publication of that data would lead to a dialogue among executives and the general public \u201cabout what\u2019s the most equitable way to distribute this windfall we just received.\u201d By the middle of the year, he added, the group should have enough information from public disclosures and survey responses to get a fuller understanding of where the money is actually headed. \u201cWe\u2019ll learn a lot,\u201d he said.\n\nThe group\u2019s initial findings suggest shareholders of 90 large corporations \u2014 including Home Depot, Pfizer and Capital One \u2014 are reaping far more of the benefits of the law than workers or consumers. Pay or benefit increases for workers account for 6 percent of the savings those companies report from the law, the group calculates, while job creation accounts for 22 percent. More than half of the money going directly to workers takes the form of one-time bonuses, as opposed to permanent raises or benefits.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThose bonus announcements have dominated headlines, though, in part because of the tireless compilation work of Mr. Kartch, the vice president for communications at Americans for Tax Reform. \u201cNobody was expecting those announcements,\u201d Mr. Kartch said; Republicans had largely argued that corporate rate cuts would unleash business investment, which would raise productivity and, with it, worker pay.\n\nWhen companies began announcing them in late December, after the bill had passed but before Mr. Trump had signed it, Mr. Kartch sent an email to staff members and affiliates of his organization, asking them to flag \u201cany statements you see from companies raising wages/paying bonuses/hiring due to the tax bill.\u201d He said he would keep a running list and include smaller businesses that \u201cwould otherwise be overlooked by national media.\u201d\n\nOther conservatives, including Republican leaders in Congress, followed suit, but Mr. Kartch\u2019s crowdsourced list seemed to catch the most fire. Mr. Trump tweeted an article about it after it reached 100 companies. The influential Drudge Report linked to it for a day on its home page. Tips poured in, about bosses passing out bonus checks in break rooms or posting about them on company bulletin boards. A 19-year-old fan of the law emails Mr. Kartch frequently with any bonus news he can find. Conservatives credit the stream of bonus news, in part, for the bill\u2019s improving poll numbers.\n\n\u201cIt will get more detailed with time,\u201d Mr. Kartch said, \u201cbut for now, it\u2019s all the raw material up there for anybody who wants it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBonus and wage announcements are only one slice of the law\u2019s impact. In early December, researchers in the office of Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, began tracking another slice: the surge in stock buybacks that has accompanied the law. The team scours earnings calls, Google and social media for buyback announcements, and frequently blasts the results out to reporters. Mr. Schumer has taken to denouncing the buyback increases regularly on the Senate floor.\n\nOutside groups are compiling a much broader array of data on what companies plan to do with their savings. Morgan Stanley has surveyed its stock analysts over their expectations of how companies they cover will spend their tax savings. Last week, its researchers released a 23-page report, counting appendixes, that contends stock traders may be overvaluing some companies by underestimating how much of their tax savings they will invest in workers and operations, as opposed to passing on to shareholders.\n\nJust Capital is hoping to round out the picture further, by pushing companies that have not disclosed their tax windfall plans to answer 11 questions \u2014 including spelling out how much of the savings they will put toward raising workers\u2019 compensation, lowering consumer prices and minimizing environmental impact. Mr. Jones said the group would follow up weekly, as necessary, with phone calls and other attempts to collect the information.\n\n\u201cMy attitude is,\u201d he said, \u201cwe\u2019re going to get the data one way or another.\u201d", "title": "Spreadsheets at Dawn: The New Tax Battle Is All About Data", "authors": ["Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Calvin Klein 205W39NYC blanket, price on request, and coat, $1,900, calvinklein.com. But now the city had a new public safety director and police chief, both of whom are black, and it was looking to turn a page.\n\nSo on Sunday night, Chief John Hayden announced on Twitter that his officers would give out candy to children from their patrol cars as a way to build relationships. \u201cIt\u2019s the little things that often do the most good,\u201d he wrote.\n\nThe announcement did not go over well.\n\nOne Twitter user, @wbuchek, offered two questions: \u201cWhat kind of candy will it be?\u201d And: \u201cAny plans for cops to stop killing black people?\u201d", "title": "St. Louis Police Offer Candy to Build Trust. Residents Say No Thanks.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Gordon Snow, the managing editor of The Daily Herald, an English-language newspaper on the island, said that many buildings, including several large hotels, saw significant damage because of Hurricane Irma and still need to be reconstructed. \u201cThis is my home, and I love it here, but there is a lot of rebuilding to do, and some of it hasn\u2019t even begun yet,\u201d he said. \u201cBut this island recovered from Hurricane Luis in 1995, and we will do so again.\u201d\n\nThe Dutch government is helping with the recovery by providing the island with 550 million euros (about $634 million) in aid.\n\nMr. Snow said that the debris from the storm that littered the roads and beaches has been cleaned up. Kate Richardson, general manager of St. Martin\u2019s tourism office, said that the beaches are as she remembers them as a child. \u201cThe beaches are back to their magnificent state, and the roads are litter free,\u201d she said.\n\nBoth airports are fully operational and run around 60 flights a week from 12 airlines. Princess Juliana, which reopened in October with the one runway it had before the storm, has daily nonstop service to and from the United States including a JetBlue flight to and from John F. Kennedy International Airport and an American Airlines flight to and from Miami International Airport. However, the terminal that sustained structural damage during Irma is still not open; passengers are temporarily being accommodated in tent-like structures.\n\nThe island\u2019s other airport, Grand Case International Airport, reopened to commercial flights in September; the airport offers daily flights to and from Guadeloupe, Martinique and St. Bart\u2019s and to and from destinations in Europe, Canada and the United States.", "title": "St. Martin Starts a Comeback", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The actress Stacey Dash, best known for starring in the 1995 movie \u201cClueless,\u201d is now aiming for Congress.\n\nIn paperwork filed with the Federal Election Commission on Monday, Ms. Dash declared her candidacy for the House of Representatives in California\u2019s 44th District, a Democratic stronghold in the southern suburbs of Los Angeles.\n\nAs a Republican, Ms. Dash is likely to face an uphill battle in the district, which is currently represented by Nanette Barrag\u00e1n, a Democrat. Hillary Clinton received 83 percent of the vote there in the 2016 presidential election, and Barack Obama won similar shares in 2008 and 2012.\n\nMs. Dash, 51, did not immediately respond to a request for comment Monday evening and has not announced her candidacy publicly, beyond the F.E.C. filing. She hinted at it in a series of tweets, however, writing: \u201cFormal statements coming. For those mocking for the district I live in...open your minds. It\u2019s time to for me to put up or shut up and I want to serve great people.\u201d", "title": "Stacey Dash, Actress From \u2018Clueless,\u2019 Is Running for Congress in California", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Researchers calculate that standing instead of sitting for six hours would use an extra 54 calories a day.\n\nThat calorie expenditure would theoretically translate to a weight loss of five and a half pounds in a year, assuming you didn\u2019t find other ways to make up for the calorie deficit. But studies suggest we often stealthily do make up for those lost calories, either by eating more or moving less.\n\nFor the study, published in the European Journal of Preventive Cardiology, researchers pooled data from 46 studies involving 1,184 people. Ten of the studies were randomized trials. The average age of participants was 33, and 60 percent were men.\n\nAll the studies calculated energy expenditure by measuring quantities of oxygen and carbon dioxide as they are breathed in and out. The mean difference between sitting and standing was 0.15 calories a minute, and it was larger in men than in women, probably because of men\u2019s greater muscle mass.", "title": "Standing for 6 Hours Burns an Extra 54 Calories", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "So, while Stanley sneered at authority and sauntered about town going to magazine parties, Gil lived in dread. Our most precious secret was Bing\u2019s anonymity, which assured the continued well-being of both of us.\n\nAnd then it all began to unravel. Colleagues in the white hot center of the magazine\u2019s demographic started to route me my own column through the corporate mail. On the top of the page would be a Post-it: \u201cHey!\u201d it would say, \u201cI think you\u2019ll find this funny!\u201d\n\n\u201cGee,\u201d I\u2019d scrawl on the top. \u201cI really don\u2019t get this.\u201d And send it back.\n\nOf course it couldn\u2019t last. In a column, I made the mistake of referring to something I called \u201cthe company Acura.\u201d This was a bit too precise. On a fine Monday morning, my pal Graves stalked into my office and slammed the door behind him. He plopped the magazine down on my desk, open to the proper page. \u201cYou!\u201d he cried. \u201cYou are Stanley Bing!\u201d\n\n\u201cYeah,\u201d I said, \u201cI guess I am.\u201d It felt great.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t worry, dude,\u201d Graves whispered conspiratorially. \u201cYour secret is safe with me.\u201d By the Friday of that week, everybody on both floors knew about it. I trembled, of course. But something strange was happening. People who never gave me the time of day were asking me to lunch. I could feel that most precious jewel of corporate life \u2014 status \u2014 slowly engorging.\n\nWhen Bing\u2019s first book came out, I had been trying to become a vice president for quite some time but was assured that they simply didn\u2019t make any more of them, like Studebakers. So I was frustrated. The book put forth the theory that mental illness is actually an asset in business and government, not a liability \u2014 a hypothesis that has since been proved spectacularly true. I was invited to go on a national morning show to talk about the book. I had a choice: Decline, or go on the air with a blue dot over my face. Neither seemed strategic.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI went to see my new boss, who had succeeded Bill in the top slot. \u201cBurt,\u201d I said, heart pounding. \u201cI have a book coming out. Here it is.\u201d I pushed the hardcover across the desk, its title screaming in gold and blue \u2014 \u201cCrazy Bosses.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cYou didn\u2019t write this,\u201d Burt said. \u201cStanley Bing wrote this.\u201d\n\n\u201cYes. Well. The thing is, Burt \u2026 I am Stanley Bing.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou S.O.B.!\u201d he exclaimed. But he smiled when he said it. \u201c\u2018Crazy Bosses,\u2019 huh?\u201d The smile faded.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re in the introduction.\u201d\n\nHe looked, then read the passage. \u201cThink about the people who boss you,\u201d it said. \u201cHow many could you say, while in full pursuit of their duties, are \u2026 sane? I\u2019ll give you my answer. One. My chairman is sane. But then, he\u2019s only been chairman for a couple of years. Give him time.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou know, Gil,\u201d Burt said, \u201cthat is one of the finest pieces of sucking up I have ever seen.\u201d\n\nTwo weeks later, I was promoted to vice president.\n\nWhat was left of my anonymity was pretty much destroyed by this very newspaper. Toward the end of the last century, my company acquired one of the giants of our business and I got a pretty big new job. At the same time, Bing\u2019s column moved to what was then an important financial publication. So a fatuous fellow I knew from Esquire marketed that tidbit over a drink. \u201cDid you know,\u201d he told a Times reporter then on the business beat, \u201cthat the new head of communications for CBS is Stanley Bing of Fortune magazine?\u201d\n\nThe hammer fell. In spite of my piteous beseeching, the reporter called the chairman of CBS, who showed the first spark of humor I had ever seen from him and referred the call back to the company\u2019s spokesman \u2014 i.e., me. The reporter also called my boss at Fortune and rattled his cage. During this ordeal, I reached an exquisite level of trepidation known to those waiting to hear if the governor has canceled their appointment with Old Sparky.\n\nIn the end, the piece came out during a January blizzard. It was fine. My mom liked it. I was sure I was ruined.\n\nAnd a month later I was promoted again.\n\nSo what can we say, Bing and I? It\u2019s certainly been a long, scary ride for us both. Perhaps it would not be inappropriate, however, when considering this matter, for each of us to take this opportunity to thank the other for all the good he, uh, we, I mean, they have done for my, um, that is, our lives over the years. I might also add that Stanley Bing has a new novel out. I\u2019m eager to see what it\u2019s going to do for us both. We\u2019re scared, of course. But hopeful.", "title": "Stanley Bing\u2019s Real Identity Was a Closely Guarded Secret. Until It Wasn\u2019t.", "authors": ["Gil Schwartz"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Starboard Value, the activist hedge fund, is taking up a new line of attack as it pushes for change at Mellanox.\n\nIt is accusing the chip maker\u2019s top executives and board members of not having enough faith in their company.\n\nStarboard Value sent a letter to Mellanox on Monday morning arguing that company insiders have consistently sold shares since its initial public offering in 2007 \u2014 while having bought stock on the open market only just once, and not since 2013.\n\nIt is an unusual line of attack as Starboard seeks to unseat Mellanox\u2019s nine-member board. Last month, the hedge fund began its proxy fight after arguing that the company, which makes computer networking chips, has not done enough to improve its operations.", "title": "Starboard Value Criticizes Mellanox for Stock Sales", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Look at a starfish in a tidal pool and you may think: ah, there\u2019s one of those pretty, multi-armed sea worms that crawl around and don\u2019t do much. But look deeper and your views might change.\n\nHundreds of feet below the ocean\u2019s surface, some starfish make their own light. And they can look right back at you too, with a teeny eye on the tip of each bendy starfish arm.\n\nScientists, who didn\u2019t even know if deep sea starfish had eyes, did not expect to find this.\n\nThey collected starfish from Arctic waters off Greenland\u2019s coast to determine which species had eyes, and for those who did, how well they could see. The researchers found that some starfish are far more biologically complex than previously thought, after looking at the structures of their eyes, their behavior in a simulated environment, whether they glowed in the dark and what tasks in the wild would make eyesight useful.\n\n\u201cEven in places where the sun don\u2019t shine, it\u2019s far from dark,\u201d said Anders Garm, a marine biologist at the University of Copenhagen who led the study published Wednesday in Proceedings of the Royal Society B. \u201cThere are animals there making their own lanterns and finding their way.\u201d", "title": "Starfish See Pretty Well in the Deep Ocean. By the Way, Starfish Have Eyes.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "When Coach John Beilein led Richmond to the N.C.A.A. men\u2019s basketball tournament in 1998, he had so much time to fill between the Colonial Athletic Association Tournament and Selection Sunday that he took his players fishing.\n\nSuch is life for midmajor programs, which sometimes punch their tickets to the N.C.A.A. tournament a week \u2014 or more \u2014 before the major conferences have even gathered to crown their league champions. In that waiting period, keeping a team sharp can require coaching methods that have nothing to do with basketball. So there are fishing trips. And whiffle ball games. And intrasquad scrimmages.\n\n\u201cJust anything to change things up,\u201d Beilein said this week.\n\nBeilein coaches Michigan now, in the undeniably major Big Ten Conference. But the league will hold its tournament a week early this year, squeezing into the schedule for Madison Square Garden, which the Big East had already booked for the prime week.\n\nWith Rutgers and Maryland now in the traditionally Midwestern Big Ten, the conference\u2019s commissioner, Jim Delany, pressed for the schedule shift to give the league a chance to promote itself in the New York market.", "title": "Starting Its Postseason Early, Big Ten Wonders if It Made the Right Call", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Still, 300 years is a significant milestone for a city that often seems to be at risk of sinking into the sea. That it was so very nearly lost 12 years ago during Hurricane Katrina \u2014 or that there\u2019s another one coming \u2014 is not lost on residents, who defend their home turf with fierce pride. I experienced that pride a bit when I wrote something offhand on Twitter about how locals were ending conversations by telling me to \u201cbe safe,\u201d and that I got the impression that no one walked around after dark. It was a badly worded tweet, though not entirely off base. People were indeed telling me to be safe. New Orleans has a notorious violent crime rate, one that predominantly affects black men, but that sometimes spills over to tourists and residents. (Solo women travelers, as always, should exercise extra caution , no matter the outcry of locals. )\n\nBut the city also has, I\u2019ve learned, a very forgiving spirit. The same people who sent me angry messages had turned warm within minutes. One woman I met at the Pinettes show, Renee Lapeyrolerie, wrote me, \u201cBadly worded, not a crime, just a sin lol enjoy the rest of your stay,\u201d and then advised me to put my phone in a zip-lock bag in case it rained.\n\nThe city is certainly in the midst of a post-Katrina upswing, with plenty of new dining and drinking spots (the St. Roch food market, Latitude 29, for instance ), but there are still boarded-up houses in many neighborhoods and a kind of lingering sadness about the hurricane\u2019s most lasting impact, which was a loss of community. Almost every New Orleans native I met told me about friends and family who fled flooded homes and have yet to be able to return.\n\nAmong residents\u2019 other regular complaints are the roads, which often seem to be more pothole than concrete, and the water quality, which had much of the city on a \u201cboil water\u201d advisory ( including for bathing) due to frozen pipes just days before I arrived. At the satirical Krewe du Vieux, the first major parade of Mardi Gras season, most floats were rebukes of the Sewerage & Water Board, whose failure to maintain drainage pumps resulted in damaging floods this summer. (Other targets were President Trump and the celebrity chef John Besh, who stepped down from his local restaurant empire in the wake of sexual misconduct accusations.)\n\nWhat is thriving is the arts scene. There are, of course, world-class art museums, the slavery-themed Whitney Plantation Museum, and the international arts fair Prospect 4 (which ends on Feb. 25), not to mention the wig artists at Fifi Mahony\u2019s in the Quarter. But it\u2019s school-level performing arts where the most exciting work is taking place. I got a chance to visit ReNEW Cultural Arts Academy, a public arts magnet middle school in Irish Channel, as their marching band got ready for Mardi Gras. They were as impressive as any professional musicians you\u2019ll find on Frenchmen Street. \u201cA lot of these kids, their parents weren\u2019t in a band because of the migration to other states,\u201d said Tenell Moore, the band director. \u201cSo we\u2019re building new \u2018bandheads,\u2019 what we refer to them in New Orleans. We\u2019re pushing hard to get it back.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s working. Out in the Seventh Ward at a booming local spot called Bullet\u2019s Sports Bar , with no other businesses in sight, the Pinettes played to a packed Friday night house that included the New Orleans funk legend Mac Rebennack, better known as Dr. John. \u201cMy friend said, \u2018Come out and hang out with some sisters,\u2019 and I couldn\u2019t believe how many white people are here. I was like, \u2018I\u2019m going home!\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cForget it, the Pinettes are the real deal. Overlooked way too long in New Orleans, maybe because they\u2019re women.\u201d\n\nThe group was formed at St. Mary\u2019s Academy, an all-female high school, and in 2013 won the Street Kings brass band competition. (Event organizers had to take a marker and cross out \u201cKings\u201d and write in \u201cQueens.\u201d) Natasha Harris, the saxophonist, told me that none of them are full-time musicians: \u201cWe all have families, we all have jobs, we\u2019re college-educated women, but we do this because it\u2019s our passion.\u201d They often have to perform without their full roster because there aren\u2019t enough women instrumentalists around to act as substitutes for members who can\u2019t make certain gigs. \u201cOur hope,\u201d Ms. Harris said, \u201cis that middle school girls will come up and continue their passion, or that women will see us and realize it\u2019s never too late. Pick that horn back up, keep it going.\u201d", "title": "Place 1 of 52: Starting an Intimidating World Tour in the Big Easy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Then, in January 2017, the Homeland Security Department declared the states\u2019 election apparatus to be \u201ccritical national infrastructure,\u201d raising suspicion among state officials that their authority was being usurped.\n\nIn fact, the declaration was meant to be the basis for a voluntary effort to cooperate with the states in thwarting attacks on election systems. That effort is now overseen by a council of 24 state and local election officials and three federal liaisons.\n\nMost state officials praise the security measures that Homeland Security experts have offered them so far, including what are called cyberhygiene checks of computer systems; sensors that watch for suspicious network traffic; and a national election-security analysis center.\n\nConnie Lawson, the Republican secretary of state in Indiana and the president of the National Association of Secretaries of State, joked on Saturday that the state secretaries\u2019 relationship with Homeland Security \u201cis going about as well as any arranged marriage can go.\u201d\n\nDespite communications gaps and complications in dealing with the huge federal bureaucracy, she said, cooperation had vastly improved and \u201cit\u2019s going to continue to improve.\u201d\n\nBut others said they were far from pleased with the flow of information about the threats and, as a result, have made major investments in voting equipment and cybersecurity.\n\nSome state officials say the Russian attacks that made news in 2016 were misconstrued, and perhaps exaggerated, because federal officials failed to say quickly and clearly what was going on. Of the 21 states that were targeted by the Russians then, only one \u2014 Illinois \u2014 suffered a known breach of an election-related database, and that breach was contained. Most of the other states appear to have experienced little more than digital probing for weak spots in their computer defenses, a routine occurrence.", "title": "State Officials Say They Are Told Too Little About Election Threats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The New York State Education Department said Thursday that it would not take control of Hempstead School District on Long Island, which has been troubled for decades by abysmal graduation rates, crumbling school buildings, violence and corruption. The state education commissioner, MaryEllen Elia, had given the district a Feb. 2 deadline to come up with an improvement plan, and on Thursday she said she had accepted it.\n\nStill, in a letter to the acting district superintendent, Ms. Elia was critical of the plan, which was supposed to propose solutions for how the district deals with issues including school safety, special education and high school instruction. She said that \u201ccritical issues\u201d were \u201cnot adequately addressed\u201d and admonished the district to make changes.\n\nMs. Elia instructed the district to submit monthly progress reports to the education department.\n\nNew York has only taken over one school district in the past, the Roosevelt School District, also on Long Island. Like Hempstead, Roosevelt is a poor district in Nassau County that serves almost entirely black and Hispanic students. Among Hempstead\u2019s students, about 70 percent are Hispanic and another 27 percent are black. But state control in Roosevelt is not widely regarded as a success.\n\n\u201cIt was an expensive disaster,\u201d said Alan J. Singer, a professor of education at Hofstra University. \u201cThey put a lot of money into it and the progress was very incremental.\u201d", "title": "State Will Not Take Over Long-Struggling Hempstead Schools", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "A study in 2016 led by researchers at Duke University concluded that Connecticut\u2019s red flag law appeared to have prevented some suicides.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s fair to say that everyone, law enforcement included, is learning how this law might work \u2014 in the process of using it,\u201d said Garen Wintemute, a professor of emergency medicine and director of the Violence Prevention Research Program at the Sacramento campus of the University of California, Davis.\n\nWe Want to Hear From You Will arming and training more teachers make schools safer? Why or why not? * Continue Are you a teacher? * yes no Are you armed and trained to carry a gun in school? * yes no Where do you live? * What is your full name? * What is your phone number? * We will not publish your contact information. It will only be used by our journalists to contact you. What is your email address? * By submitting to us, you are promising that the content is original, does not plagiarize from anyone or infringe a copyright or trademark, does not violate anyone\u2019s rights and is not libelous or otherwise unlawful or misleading. You are agreeing that we can use your submission in all manner and media of The New York Times and that we shall have the right to authorize third parties to do so. And you agree to our Terms of Service. Thank you for your submission.\n\nConnecticut was the first state in the nation to pass such a statute in 1999, in response to a mass shooting at a state lottery office. What followed surprised some officials there: Almost no one used the law. For years, it was relegated to the back shelf of law enforcement, with only a few cases a year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe pace of cases began to quicken, Connecticut statistics show, after high-profile shootings occurred elsewhere, starting in 2007 with the deaths of 33 people on the campus of Virginia Tech. Advocates of red flag laws said they provided important protections, particularly as people became increasingly aware of the risks of mass shootings.\n\nStill, even states with the laws have not avoided such shootings. The gunman who killed 26 people at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., in December 2012 had access to guns, though people who knew him said he had shown troubling signs before the attack.\n\n\u201cThis is a country with hundreds of millions of guns in circulation, and that fact imposes real constraints on what policy can achieve and on what kind of policy makes sense,\u201d said Ramesh Ponnuru, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group.\n\nNo one, Mr. Ponnuru added, should expect any one law to fix everything. \u201cRealism is the right attitude,\u201d he said.\n\nMany Republicans oppose red flag laws, and the National Rifle Association has argued that a judge\u2019s order to seize a person\u2019s weapon may violate Second Amendment rights when no crime has been committed.\n\nBut law enforcement officials who have embraced red flag laws say that they allow the authorities to step in before something catastrophic occurs. The removals are temporary, these officials stress, meaning that guns are returned to people no longer deemed dangerous.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe laws allow weapons to be seized for a brief time \u2014 typically two or three weeks \u2014 after which a petitioner, usually a police agency, must go back to court to let a judge decide whether the gun owner\u2019s behavior amounts to a threat to himself or others and whether the weapons should be held longer.\n\nSome states, including New York and Texas, already allow guns to be taken from mental health patients deemed dangerous, but red flag laws hinge on outward behavior \u2014 a person\u2019s statements and actions regardless of medical diagnosis.\n\n\u201cThe reason I like gun violence restraining orders as an option is that we can use them even if the person hasn\u2019t been convicted of a crime,\u201d said Mara W. Elliott, the San Diego city attorney. California\u2019s measure, patterned after Connecticut\u2019s, took effect in 2016, and late last year, Ms. Elliott assigned an assistant city attorney to pursue gun seizure cases full time, one of the first cities in the nation to take such aggressive action.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo far, the office has pursued 10 cases, Ms. Elliott said, and officials there have seen circumstances involving more intimate situations than they had expected.\n\nPrompted by calls to the police, who then asked the city attorney to intervene under the new law, the authorities removed guns from Alzheimer\u2019s patients, alcoholics and people accused of domestic abuse.\n\nSince Connecticut passed its law, the state has seen 1,519 cases, about two-thirds of them since 2012. California\u2019s far newer law resulted in 86 cases in its first year. And Washington\u2019s superior courts have held about 65 hearings under the law since it was approved by voters in 2016.\n\nRed flag laws have evolved, too. Connecticut and Indiana, which passed its law in 2005 after the murder of an Indianapolis police officer, allow only law enforcement agencies to bring petitions for temporary gun removal. Newer measures, in California, Oregon and Washington, allow family members to bring such petitions to judges as well.\n\nThe effectiveness of the statutes has depended on the level of communication between the public and law enforcement agencies, according to social and health policy researchers who have studied the laws.\n\nIn some places, they said, residents have been far more willing to report troubling behavior than in others. And in some communities, law enforcement agencies are more familiar with the technical intricacies of applying the red flag laws than they are in others.\n\nEven in the states that have had the laws longer, like Indiana, state officials have said that many residents and police officers are unaware of the tools they have.\n\nCurtis T. Hill Jr., the Republican attorney general of Indiana, on Wednesday took the unusual step of reminding his colleagues around the state that the provision exists.\n\n\u201cIndiana\u2019s \u2018Red Flag Law\u2019 is a common-sense measure that in no way inhibits the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding citizens,\u201d Mr. Hill said in a statement. \u201cThis useful provision is not as well-known, even among law enforcement, as one might expect. That\u2019s why this week we are distributing a public safety advisory raising awareness of the law and urging police and prosecutors to make full use of it as we work together to protect all Hoosiers.\u201d", "title": "States Mull \u2018Red Flag\u2019 Gun Seizures from People Deemed Dangerous", "authors": ["Kirk Johnson"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 There are hundreds of athletes at the Winter Olympics who can soar and flip and twist in the air in a manner that appears to defy gravity.\n\nNo one, however, can fly the way Stefan Kraft can.\n\nKraft, a 24-year-old Austrian, may not win a medal here this week. He finished 13th in the normal hill competition last weekend. In the large hill qualifications on Friday, he finished in 11th place. The final is Saturday.\n\nGenerally, the larger the hill, the better Kraft is. He holds the world record in ski flying, an offshoot of ski jumping, where the hills are larger than those used in the Olympics and where the landing zone is set more than 200 meters away from the takeoff point. He set the world record at a sky flying hill in Norway last year, soaring 253.5 meters (just over 831 feet) and then sticking the landing.\n\nAt 5-foot-5 and 123 pounds, Kraft has a slight build and strong legs that are tailor-made for flight. He isn\u2019t great at pushing off the jump, which is more important on the smaller normal hills, but once in the air, his technique is immaculate, and he appears to float on the wind.\n\n\u201cI am a flier,\u201d he said in an interview this week.\n\nSo what does it feel like to fly more than two and a half football fields down a mountain?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really great,\u201d Kraft said.\n\nBefore his world-record flight, he said, the anticipation built as he sat on the bar, waiting for the starter to give him the green light. When he felt the wind blowing up the hill, optimal conditions for keeping a jumper and his extra wide skis aloft, he could sense the moment was right for a big jump.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Kraft won the large hill competition here last year. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\n\u2018We Already Know How You React to Combat Situations\u2019\n\nPresident Trump said on Monday that he believed he would have run into the Florida high school where a gunman opened fire this month, even if he\u2019d been unarmed. The only way you would run inside is if a reporter asked you a question outside.\u201d \u2014 SETH MEYERS\n\nAbandoning the N.R.A.\n\nMany companies have decided to cut ties with the National Rifle Association after the shooting in Parkland, Fla., provoked a public outcry over gun violence.\n\n\u201cSeveral businesses have canceled their partnership with the N.R.A. over the past week, including United Airlines. You know you messed up when the company that dragged the guy off the plane is like, \u2018You\u2019re making us look bad.\u2019\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON \u201cWith the Olympics over, 90 countries have departed South Korea. Yep, 90 groups waving goodbye \u2014 or as the N.R.A. calls those, sponsors.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON\n\nTrevor Noah thought carrying a gun sounded like a pretty smart way to get yourself a discount.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m less surprised that corporations are canceling N.R.A. discounts than I am that corporations were giving them discounts in the first place. Like, how does the N.R.A. even get discounts? Were all the N.R.A. members just there like, [brandishes weapon] \u2018We\u2019d like a discount.\u2019\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH\n\nThe Punchiest Punchlines (CPAC Edition)\n\n\u201cA new CNN poll has found that Democrats have a 16-point lead over Republicans in a generic congressional ballot. Yeah, this is the third time this has happened to Melania.\u201d \u2014 CONAN O\u2019BRIEN\n\nThe Bits Worth Watching\n\nIn his first broadcast since the shooting in Florida, Jimmy Fallon expressed solidarity with the students pushing for gun control legislation and said he would join them at the March for Our Lives, a protest in Washington scheduled for March 24.\n\nSteve Harvey thinks he could maybe do James Corden\u2019s job for him.\n\nWhat We\u2019re Excited About on Tuesday Night\n\nBruce Willis, whose latest film, \u201cDeath Wish,\u201d is in theaters, appears on \u201cThe Tonight Show\u201d on Tuesday.\n\nAlso, Check This Out\n\nPhoto\n\nA new TV series dramatizes the still-unsolved murders of Biggie Smalls and Tupac Shakur, the rappers who were famously gunned down in the 1990s.
