And he lashed out at politicians who oppose these measures.", "title": "Stephen Colbert Stands With Florida Students Fighting for Gun Control", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "As part of the process of granting Mr. Wynn a license to operate a casino, the Massachusetts commission conducted an extensive review of Mr. Wynn and his corporate empire. Investigators, who usually focus on an individual\u2019s criminal history and potential ties to organized crime, did not report that Mr. Wynn had been the subject of any sexual misconduct allegations and determined that he met the state\u2019s \u201csuitability\u201d standard.\n\nThe chief question before the commission on Wednesday was how its investigators could have overlooked the allegations against Mr. Wynn, which had been confirmed to The Journal by dozens of people. Wynn Resorts told The Journal in a statement that the application process did not ask for disclosure of that type of information.\n\nThe director of the commission\u2019s investigations and enforcement bureau, Karen Wells, told the commissioners that lawyers for Wynn Resorts had confirmed to her the existence of the $7.5 million settlement reported by The Journal and that it had not been disclosed to anyone or mentioned in court documents.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis was a private agreement and steps were taken to keep it from the public domain,\u201d Ms. Wells said.\n\nShe said her team would conduct a further review \u2014 including a look at Mr. Wynn\u2019s suitability and who knew what, when, and what they did about it. Ms. Wells said she could not speculate about how long her investigation might take, but the commissioners urged her to conduct it quickly while maintaining fairness and transparency.\n\nNo representatives from Wynn Resorts spoke at the meeting. In a statement, the company said it would fully cooperate with the commission\u2019s investigation. \u201cOur construction is on schedule for a 2019 opening and continues to create more than 4,000 local union trade jobs,\u201d the company said.\n\nSteve Crosby, the commission chairman, told reporters that the commission had already begun a review of its investigative procedure, but added that he had \u201cenormous confidence\u201d in the commission\u2019s investigators.\n\nHe said the purpose of the meeting on Wednesday, which lasted less than an hour, was to determine the significance \u201cof these appalling accusations on the suitability status of Mr. Wynn\u201d and other principals in the Wynn organization, and to \u201censure public confidence in the integrity of the gaming licensing process.\u201d\n\nPressed by reporters as to whether the commission might revoke Mr. Wynn\u2019s license or shut down the project just north of Boston in Everett, Mr. Crosby said: \u201cWe have unlimited authority to do virtually anything that we want, once we know what the facts are.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said he did not want to speculate about what might happen. \u201cBut for the time being, everybody who\u2019s got jobs in Everett should go about their business and feel fine,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is not the first time that there have been allegations of misconduct against major players in the casino business.\u201d", "title": "Stephen Wynn to Be Investigated by Massachusetts Casino Regulators", "authors": ["Katharine Q. Seelye"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA woman told the police that she had a child with the casino mogul Steve Wynn after he raped her, while another reported that she was forced to resign from a Las Vegas job after she refused to have sex with him.\n\nThe Associated Press on Tuesday obtained copies of police reports recently filed by the two women about allegations dating to the 1970s. The police in Las Vegas said this month that they had taken the statements after a news report in January revealed sexual misconduct allegations against the billionaire.\n\nThe allegations are the latest leveled against Mr. Wynn. He resigned as chairman and chief executive of Wynn Resorts on Feb. 6, less than two weeks after The Wall Street Journal reported in an in-depth investigation that a number of women said he harassed or assaulted them and that one case led to a $7.5 million settlement.\n\nMr. Wynn has vehemently denied the misconduct accusations the newspaper reported, and he attributed them to a campaign led by his ex-wife, Elaine Wynn, whose lawyer has denied that she instigated the news article.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fallout for Mr. Wynn and his empire has been swift since the first allegations were disclosed. He resigned as finance chairman of the Republican National Committee, and his name was stripped from buildings and programs at various universities.", "title": "Steve Wynn Is Accused of Rape and Coercion in Police Reports", "authors": ["Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wynn has denied all the allegations, calling them \u201cpreposterous.\u201d\n\nWithin a day of the article\u2019s publication, Mr. Wynn, a major Republican donor, stepped down as finance chairman of the Republican National Committee. A few days later, the University of Pennsylvania revoked his honorary degree and removed his name from a campus plaza and scholarship. And the Massachusetts Gaming Commission promised an investigation, as Wynn Resorts is building a multibillion-dollar casino outside Boston.\n\nAfter Mr. Wynn announced his resignation on Tuesday, the commission said it would \u201cneed to assess the overall impact and implications of this significant development.\u201d\n\nMr. Wynn also stepped down as chairman of Wynn Macau, the arm of the company that focuses on Macau, the Chinese gambling enclave. Shares of Wynn Macau, which are traded in Hong Kong, had been halted pending the release of the announcement, but the company said it would seek to resume trading on Thursday. Wynn Resorts\u2019 stock price had already tumbled in response to the misconduct allegations, from $200.60 on Jan. 25 to $163.22 on Tuesday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a statement, the company\u2019s board said it had accepted Mr. Wynn\u2019s resignation \u201creluctantly.\u201d\n\n\u201cSteve Wynn is an industry giant,\u201d Boone Wayson, nonexecutive director of the board, said in the statement. \u201cHe is a philanthropist and a beloved leader and visionary. He played the pivotal role in transforming Las Vegas into the entertainment destination it is today.\u201d\n\nMr. Wynn\u2019s mark on Las Vegas is indelible. From the Mirage, which he opened in 1989, to the Bellagio and the soaring Wynn Hotel and Encore towers, he introduced the idea that visitors to the Strip were not there just to gamble. He also offered them top-of-the-line staterooms, fine dining and Rodeo Drive-level shopping.\n\nHe first arrived in Las Vegas as a young boy with his father, Mike Wynn, an East Coast bingo parlor operator. After his father died, Mr. Wynn and his wife at the time, Elaine Pascal, took over the business. He called out the numbers while she counted the cash.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1967, he bought a small stake in the Frontier casino. More deals would follow, including the takeover of the publicly traded Golden Nugget, which operated a run-down casino in downtown Las Vegas. Mr. Wynn started an ambitious renovation and expansion project that would ultimately lead him back east to oversee the construction of the Golden Nugget in Atlantic City.\n\nBut his rising stature in Las Vegas in the 1980s resulted in frequent regulatory inquiries and investigations into possible ties to organized crime. Mr. Wynn was always quick to point out that the various examinations found no wrongdoing.\n\nHis relationship with his ex-wife, a force of her own in Las Vegas, has been tumultuous. Married when they were teenagers \u2014 she was 18 and he was 19 \u2014 they divorced, remarried and divorced again in 2010. Ms. Wynn sat on Wynn Resorts\u2019 board for years before she was removed in 2015.\n\nSince 2012, the two have been locked in a legal battle over control of Ms. Wynn\u2019s stake, valued recently at $1.6 billion, in Wynn Resorts. An agreement she signed with Mr. Wynn gives him the right to vote her stake in the company and limits her ability to sell her shares. A spokeswoman for Ms. Wynn declined to comment Tuesday evening.\n\nHis resignation may help stanch the bleeding for Wynn Resorts, which has a number of ambitious projects in the works. Besides the huge resort set to open next year in Boston Harbor, it is clearing land behind its Wynn and Encore hotels in Las Vegas for \u201cParadise Park,\u201d a sandy waterfront around a 38-acre lagoon that is to include a casino, a hotel and restaurants. And in January, the company began laying out its vision for another 38-acre property it acquired late last year, a resort and casino called Wynn West.\n\nMr. Wynn is the latest in a growing series of prominent men, from actors to politicians to journalists, who have been accused of sexual harassment or assault since The New York Times published an expos\u00e9 on the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein in October. Many have resigned or been fired as a result.", "title": "Steve Wynn Resigns From Company Amid Sexual Misconduct Allegations", "authors": ["Maggie Astor", "Julie Creswell"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "In general, when companies wrap a brand around a personality, whether the founder or a celebrity, there\u2019s a risk, Mr. Friederichsen said. When that person does something that draws negative attention, he added, the brand needs to address it quickly and directly, offer up a remedy and communicate it to shareholders and consumers.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t push it off, put it to the side or wait to address it,\u201d Mr. Friederichsen said. \u201cYou\u2019re in damage control so you have to address it immediately, be specific about it and offer up a remedy.\u201d\n\nIt is a predicament that companies connected with well-known figures as varied as Martha Stewart and Harvey Weinstein have faced. When the celebrity chef Paula Deen became embroiled in controversy over racial comments she had made, she stumbled, he said.\n\n\u201cShe initially tried to deny it at first, then diminish it, and didn\u2019t show up for critical interviews like the \u2018Today\u2019 show, and that cast suspicion on her and her brand,\u201d Mr. Friederichsen said. \u201cAnd she had a very difficult time recovering from that.\u201d\n\nMs. Deen wound up losing endorsements and TV show contracts.\n\nThe repercussions for the Wynn brand could cut far deeper and last far longer than they have for other companies that have faced harassment allegations in recent months, such as NBC, which fired Matt Lauer, and Fox, which let Bill O\u2019Reilly go.", "title": "Steve Wynn\u2019s Tarnished Name and Now a Tainted Brand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cohen\u2019s former firm, SAC Capital Advisors, shut down in early 2014 after it pleaded guilty in an insider trading investigation.\n\nMr. Cohen wasn\u2019t charged by the authorities. But he agreed to a two-year ban from the securities industry for failing to properly supervise some of his staff. He created Point72, which currently has more than 1,000 employees, to manage his personal fortune.\n\nThe ban from the securities industry expired at the end of last year. Mr. Cohen, 61, is preparing to relaunch Point72 as a hedge fund that will manage money for outside investors.\n\nWhile traditional Wall Street firms have overhauled their cultures in recent years and elevated women to positions of authority, the $3 trillion hedge fund industry has been far slower in breaking away from its male-dominated roots.\n\nAt Point72, women make up fewer than 3 percent of the managing directors, according to the discrimination lawsuit, which was brought on behalf of Lauren Bonner, an associate director. Of the firm\u2019s 125 portfolio managers \u2014 top traders who decide which stocks to buy and sell \u2014 one is a woman. There are no women on the firm\u2019s hiring or executive committee.\n\nFor several weeks last year, a whiteboard in the office of a top executive had the word \u201cpussy\u201d written on it, leaving the firm\u2019s few senior women feeling uneasy, according to the lawsuit. A person who worked at the firm confirmed the incident.\n\nMany of the allegations in the complaint could not be independently verified. But four people who worked at the firm, and who declined to be identified for fear of retribution, said Point72 could be a difficult work environment for women. They said, for example, that male colleagues regularly made comments on women\u2019s physical appearances.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Bonner, who did not comment for this article, is represented by lawyers with Wigdor L.L.P., which has represented women in a number of notable sexual harassment lawsuits, including several against Fox News and 21st Century Fox. Two years ago, the firm represented a male employee in a sexual harassment complaint against Bridgewater Associates, the world\u2019s biggest hedge fund.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis lawsuit proves that #MeToo is just getting started, and Wall Street will not be spared,\u201d one of Ms. Bonner\u2019s lawyers, Jeanne M. Christensen, said.\n\nSuch lawsuits are rare on Wall Street because, women say, there is little to gain by challenging employers and they risk tarnishing their reputations and upending their careers.\n\nIt is even more uncommon for a current employee of a firm to file such a complaint.\n\nMs. Bonner is part of a recruitment analytics team at Point72 and supervises 14 people. She previously worked at Bridgewater.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHer suit contends that she was passed over for several promotions, with jobs going to less experienced men who joined Point72 after she began working there in July 2016. This year, she is slated to earn a base salary of $300,000 with a potential bonus of $225,000. The lawsuit alleges that similarly situated men earn at least twice as much.\n\nThe lawsuit seeks unspecified monetary damages and an injunction against Point72\u2019s violating state anti-discrimination laws.\n\nAs Point72 prepares to start trading as a hedge fund, the firm has raised between $2 billion and $4 billion from outside investors, although some institutional investors have balked at its high fees, people familiar with the matter previously told The New York Times.\n\nMr. Cohen has emphasized Point72\u2019s commitment to the highest ethical standards, which the firm boasts about in its mission statement. He brought in former federal prosecutors to oversee compliance at the firm.\n\nKevin O\u2019Connor, a former United States attorney for Connecticut, was hired as general counsel. Douglas Haynes, once a top executive at the consulting firm McKinsey, was brought in as Point72\u2019s president.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth men are responsible for overseeing the firm\u2019s cultural cleanup \u2014 and both figure in Ms. Bonner\u2019s lawsuit.\n\nMr. Haynes is named as a defendant. The lawsuit said he had once ridiculed a female executive as a \u201cdumb blond.\u201d The whiteboard mentioned in the suit was in Mr. Haynes\u2019s office.\n\nAnd the suit quoted Mr. O\u2019Connor as having said to colleagues that \u201cthe reality is that this is just a really tough place for women, and that\u2019s not going to change.\u201d\n\nMr. Haynes and Mr. O\u2019Connor didn\u2019t immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nMs. Bonner also said that a supervisor belittled her and that she had complained to the head of human resources. Nothing happened: The supervisor remained on a powerful internal committee that decides which employees get promotions, the suit said.\n\nThe lawsuit also accused Mark Herr, the firm\u2019s head of corporate communications, of making degrading comments about women. He didn\u2019t immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nIn one example of the firm\u2019s allegedly inhospitable culture, the lawsuit described a women\u2019s leadership forum that Mr. Cohen hosted in October 2016 at his 35,000-square-foot mansion in Greenwich, Conn. One of the main speakers was a psychiatrist and Fox News contributor who, according to the lawsuit, described Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential nominee, as \u201can accomplished man\u2019s wife.\u201d\n\nA person who attended the event confirmed that account.\n\nThe lawsuit said Ms. Bonner intended to file discrimination complaints against Point72 with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and New York City\u2019s Commission on Human Rights.", "title": "Steven Cohen\u2019s Investment Firm Accused of Hostility to Women", "authors": ["Jessica Silver-Greenberg", "Matthew Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Steven Pinker doesn\u2019t just want you to be happy; he wants you to be grateful too. His new book, \u201cEnlightenment Now,\u201d is a spirited and exasperated rebuke to anyone who refuses to concede that the world is becoming a better place. \u201cNone of us are as happy as we ought to be, given how amazing our world has become,\u201d he writes. \u201cPeople seem to bitch, moan, whine, carp and kvetch as much as ever.\u201d\n\nIn the United States, this spectacular ingratitude is lamentably bipartisan, he says, shared by anti-establishmentarians on both sides who refuse to see the light: \u201cLeft-wing and right-wing political ideologies have themselves become secular religions, providing people with a community of like-minded brethren, a catechism of sacred beliefs, a well-populated demonology and a beatific confidence in the righteousness of their cause.\u201d Of course, Pinker\u2019s confidence in the righteousness of his own cause may come across as similarly beatific (he\u2019s an atheist who\u2019s confident enough to use the word \u201cblessed\u201d without a hint of irony), but as he repeatedly tells us, the evidence is on his side. Scientific discovery and technological developments have ensured that \u201ceverything is amazing.\u201d He\u2019s merely expounding the obvious.\n\nNot so obvious, though, that he didn\u2019t need to write a 550-page book to make his case. Pinker is a scientist \u2014 a psychologist, to be exact \u2014 and he prides himself on being thorough, valiantly fighting \u201cprogressophobia\u201d with his voluble sentences and a fusillade of data. When he published \u201cThe Better Angels of Our Nature\u201d in 2011, he believed he unequivocally showed that modernity and liberal Enlightenment values had made people less violent, and so he was taken aback by skeptical reviews that had the temerity to question his research methods or his conclusions.\n\n\u201cI had thought that a parade of graphs with time on the horizontal axis, body counts or other measures of violence on the vertical, and a line that meandered from the top left to the bottom right would cure audiences\u201d of their delusions and \u201cpersuade them that at least in this sphere of well-being the world has made progress,\u201d he recalls near the beginning of \u201cEnlightenment Now.\u201d But Pinker\u2019s inability to \u201ccure audiences\u201d and \u201cpersuade them\u201d doesn\u2019t mean he has reconsidered his rhetorical approach; 300 pages after bemoaning those poor souls who read \u201cBetter Angels\u201d and weren\u2019t bowled over by his panoply of statistics, Pinker doubles down with still more data. \u201cWe have seen six dozen graphs that have vindicated the hope for progress by charting the ways in which the world has been getting better,\u201d he writes.", "title": "Steven Pinker Wants You to Know Humanity Is Doing Fine. Just Don\u2019t Ask About Individual Humans.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "OXON HILL, Md. \u2014 Conservatives have committed to memory the Trump achievements that they can recite when that inevitable, needling question comes up: Are you still glad you voted for him?\n\nA $1.5 trillion tax cut. Sweeping deregulation. Increased military spending. Conservative judges.\n\nAt the Conservative Political Action Conference this week, a lot of activists and elected officials were quick to rattle off that list as they assessed President Trump one year in and defended the man many of them initially believed was not conservative enough to be their president.\n\n\u201cEverybody knows that list,\u201d said Ben Domenech, the publisher of The Federalist and a speaker at the conference.\n\nSure, there was another \u2014 and far longer \u2014 list that left many shaking their heads. The tweeting. The West Wing\u2019s high turnover and constant turmoil. The hush money paid to a pornographic-film actress. The indictments. But all that seemed quite incidental because, as Mr. Domenech added, conservatives have been pleasantly surprised by the president\u2019s policies, if not by him.", "title": "Still Glad You Voted Trump? At CPAC, Conservatives Had an Answer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Mrs. Bratescu was working on abstract collages made of geometric shapes drawn with chunky marker pens and pieces of paper or found materials glued on top. One of her most recent collages included candy wrappers from some chocolates she had eaten a few days before.\n\n\u201cI think of drawing as a dance,\u201d Mrs. Bratescu said. \u201cAnd a dance is a drawing in space. If you don\u2019t appreciate dancing, these things aren\u2019t possible to create.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMrs. Bratescu\u2019s studio has long played an essential role in her creative process. In 1978, she made an experimental black-and-white film titled \u201cThe Studio,\u201d and last year an exhibition in London explored how critical the space has been for her.\n\n\u201cMy family and friends, everyone, understood that the studio was a necessity,\u201d Mrs. Bratescu said. \u201cBut it\u2019s not very complicated; like for many artists, it\u2019s a place of my own.\u201d\n\nMagda Radu, a Bucharest-based curator and art historian, said in a telephone interview, \u201cIt\u2019s space of freedom, delineated from the outside world, but very fertile and productive.\u201d Ms. Radu has worked closely with Mrs. Bratescu for a number of years and curated both the Venice exhibition and the show in Los Angeles. \u201cFor artists in Eastern Europe, the studio represents a space of autonomy.\u201d\n\nInterest in Mrs. Bratescu\u2019s work centers on a paradox she is reticent to talk about: She worked freely as an artist in a period of political repression.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDuring communism it was almost mandatory to make political art, so the avant-garde had to be political in an unpolitical way,\u201d Sebestyen Gyorgy Szekely, an art historian who specializes in female Eastern European artists, said in a telephone interview. \u201cOne of Geta Bratescu\u2019s escape routes to make unpolitical art was to use mythology, and the other way she did it was in her handling of the process of art, using the act of drawing as a way to discover the world.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBorn in 1926 in Ploiesti, a town 50 miles north Bucharest, Mrs. Bratescu started drawing in her early childhood. Her father owned a drugstore and she said her parents encouraged her artistic ambitions: \u201cMy parents never forced me to become a pharmacist; they saw that I liked to draw and they left me to take my own course.\u201d\n\nIn 1945 she enrolled concurrently at the University of Bucharest, in the Faculty of Letters and Philosophy, and also at the Bucharest School of Belle Arte, an art college. Her studies were interrupted in 1949 when she was expelled from university in a purge of the bourgeoisie: Her father was a landowner, and therefore unpalatable to the Communist regime.\n\nIn 1951, Mrs. Bratescu married Mihai Bratescu, an engineer and photographer with whom she sometimes collaborated, and they had a son, Tudor, in 1954. During the 1950s, Mrs. Bratescu worked as a children\u2019s book illustrator; by 1957 the regime had softened somewhat and Mrs. Bratescu became affiliated with the Union of Artists, a state entity that approved exhibitions and granted studios to its artists.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a book of sketches in her studio, Mrs. Bratescu has drawings from when she was sent by the union to draw peasants at weddings and in factories on the Danube Delta. It was through this affiliation that she had the rare occasion to exhibit in Romania and to travel a little, although she only left the country for the first time when she was 40.\n\nMs. Radu said that while being overtly political was never an interest for Mrs. Bratescu, an underlying current in her work deals with the freedom of artists and their role in the wider world. \u201cHer work functions on conceptual, literary and Aesopian levels,\u201d she said.\n\nAs such, the Los Angeles show, centered around Mrs. Bratescu\u2019s longstanding interest in Aesop, is perhaps the best way to read any sort of political statement into Mrs. Bratescu\u2019s work. Her interest the Greek author has less to do with his fables and instead is focused on the character of Aesop himself. \u201cFor her, Aesop is a disrupter, someone that is a fool but plays tricks on authoritarian figures,\u201d Ms. Radu said. \u201cHe creates mayhem.\u201d\n\nGiven that Mrs. Bratescu\u2019s oeuvre combines playfulness and dark humor, it is little surprise that she named her other major influences as Marcel Duchamp, Samuel Beckett and Charlie Chaplin. Clowns, chocolate-wrapper collages and childlike drawings are all Mrs. Bratescu\u2019s little jokes, but the punch lines remain hazy. \u201cIt\u2019s a game,\u201d Mrs. Bratescu said of her most recent collage. \u201cI like to draw and to work freely, like any other game.\u201d", "title": "Still Making Art, and Sly Jokes, at Age 91", "authors": ["Anna Codrea-Rado"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThis week, in light of Justin Timberlake\u2019s coming Super Bowl halftime appearance, we revisit his infamous 2004 \u201cwardrobe malfunction\u201d performance with Janet Jackson. We dissect the public reaction to \u201cnipplegate,\u201d why Jackson (and not Timberlake) took the fall and how the controversy changed the course of both artists\u2019 careers. We consider Timberlake\u2019s new musical direction in the context of his history of appropriating other cultures. And we offer Jackson the forgiveness she deserves, revisiting how her sexual experimentation led to some of our favorite moments in music history.\n\nHow do I listen? Two ways\n\nStill Processing Listen to \u2018Still Processing\u2019 We dissect the public reaction to \u201cnipplegate\u201d and offer Janet Jackson the forgiveness she deserves. Audio\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.\n\nOn your iPhone or iPad:\n\n1. Open your podcast app. It\u2019s a pre-loaded app called \u201cPodcasts\u201d with a purple icon. (This link may help.)\n\n2. Search for the series. Subscribe. Once on the series page, tap on the \u201csubscribe\u201d button to have new episodes sent to your phone free. You may want to adjust your notifications to be alerted when a new episode arrives.", "title": "Still Processing: We\u2019re Still Here For Janet", "authors": ["Wesley Morris", "Jenna Wortham", "Still Processing"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Freud is still dead, but psychoanalysis may be experiencing a rebirth.\n\nThis week, Maddie Freeman, 25, a candidate for a master\u2019s degree in social work at Smith College, was in town not only to see \u201cWaitress\u201d on Broadway but also for the American Psychoanalytic Association\u2019s annual conference at the New York Hilton Midtown, along with 1,600 or so other analysts, analysts-in-training and those who love them. (On Valentine\u2019s Day, little bags of Necco Conversation Hearts were given out, swag from an insurance company.)\n\nThe four day psyche-fest was a bonanza of seminars, from the doctrinaire to the esoteric, the practical to the political. You could bone up on telepathic dreams and the quantum hologram, which has something to do with parapsychological phenomena and was way, way over this reporter\u2019s head. Another seminar examined \u201cA Streetcar Named Desire\u201d from a structural and relational psychoanalytic perspective.\n\nThere were talks on collaborative care in low-income communities; working with technologies like video conferencing; and how to influence health care and other public policies. A session on the ethics of mental health professionals commenting on public figures had drawn nearly 300 sign-ups at last count.\n\nThere didn\u2019t seem to be a lot of unreconstructed Freudians hanging around \u2014 or Lacanians, for that matter \u2014 though you could imbibe the canon at a seminar on the Wolf Man, or at another on the correspondence between Freud and his prot\u00e9g\u00e9, Sandor Ferenczi, and their falling out, which turned into a lively conversation about boundary violations and how ideas about them have evolved.", "title": "Still Talking After All These Years", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The final score could have easily gone to Wilkins, but Jordan was performing in front of a hometown Chicago crowd, which \u201csurely had some influence on the slam dunk judges, and galvanized his All-Star teammates, to say nothing of their considerable effect on The Flying Machine himself,\u201d The Times reported. Above, another famous Jordan dunk from the competition.\n\nThe next day, Jordan would go on to score 40 points in the All-Star Game.\n\n\u201cThis was,\u201d Jordan said, \u201ca picture-perfect weekend.\u201d\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nAs markets drop, take the long view\n\n\u2022 That\u2019s the advice of Neil Irwin, one of our economics correspondents, after the Dow fell 1,175 points on Monday, its largest single-day point decline ever. Here are four takeaways from the sell-off.\n\nHe reports that the slump returned the market roughly to its level in mid-December, less than two months ago, and that it seems more worrisome than it is.\n\nStill.\n\nStock markets in Asia and Europe fell today, and Wall Street opened lower but then recovered.\n\nOur DealBook columnist, Andrew Ross Sorkin, attributes the turmoil to investors\u2019 belief that President Trump\u2019s policies to stoke growth are going to work, but so much so that they\u2019ll overheat the economy.\n\nMr. Trump took credit for rising stocks at least 25 times in January alone, even though most presidents scrupulously avoid talking about short-term market trends. The past few days demonstrate why. He didn\u2019t mention the recent decline during a speech about the economy on Monday. (Indexes remain well above where they were when he was elected.)", "title": "Stock Markets, Donald Trump, SpaceX: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was standing in the checkout line at Trader Joe\u2019s, mindlessly looking at a bag of Belgian endive that someone had left in the organic hot cocoa bin and listening to the Smashing Pumpkins on my iPhone.\n\nAn older woman with close-cropped gray hair and a black Nikon camera hanging around her neck tapped my shoulder with great urgency, startling me. I took off my headphones.\n\n\u201cCan you hand me the blue card?\u201d the woman asked, pointing to the rows of greeting cards lined up along the wall.\n\nI reached toward a light blue birthday card, and then noticed that it was resting next to a dark blue condolence card.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith my right arm extended, I turned my head toward the woman and sought guidance.\n\n\u201cThe sympathy card,\u201d she said.\n\nI moved my hand to the left and pinched the top of the first card there.\n\n\u201cTwo,\u201d the woman said.\n\nI plucked out two cards and handed them to her.", "title": "Stockpiling Sympathy", "authors": ["Aaron Kaplowitz", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The Dow plunged more than 1,000 points Thursday, its second decline of more than 1,000 points this week. The S. & P. 500 dropped 100 points, its third decline of more than 100 points in its history.\n\nOn a percentage basis, the Dow fell 4.15 percent, the S. & P. 500 dropped 3.75 percent and the Nasdaq slid 3.9 percent.\n\nThe bigger picture\n\nAnxieties about inflation have driven the much of decline over the past week and a half. The yield on the benchmark Treasury note climbed above 2.85 percent \u2014 its highest level since 2014 \u2014 for the second time this week. Higher yields can crimp economic activity by raising borrowing costs, while also making riskier assets like stocks less appealing to bonds.\n\nMany market watchers say that investors should not worry about the recent spate of volatility in the stock market. Such swings, they say, are normal. They point to strong corporate earnings and a strengthening economy both in the United States and abroad as reasons to be optimistic about stocks.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m definitely in the camp that says this is a healthy correction,\u201d said Joe Brusuelas, chief economist at RSM US LLP, told the WSJ.\n\n\u2022 Greg Ip of the WSJ notes how much the markets now depend on low interest rates.\n\n\u2022 Neil Irwin of the Upshot asks: How much inflation can we tolerate? The answer isn\u2019t simple.\n\n\n\nInvestor sentiment reverses.\n\nInvestor sentiment has reversed in recent weeks as the sell-off in stocks gained momentum.\n\nAccording to the American Association of Individual Investors\u2019 weekly survey, bullish sentiment, or the percentage of respondents that say stocks will rise over the next six months, declined to 37 percent. The drop ended a streak of eight straight weeks with bullish sentiment above its historical average of 38.5 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt began the year at nearly 60 percent, its highest level since 2010.\n\nThe context\n\nThe survey has proved to be a good contrarian indicator. That means overly bullish sentiment often signals that the stock market is ripe for a pullback, while overly bearish sentiment often indicates that market may soon rally.\n\nPhoto\n\nQualcomm rejects Broadcom\u2019s revised offer.\n\nThe chip maker said its board had rejected Broadcom\u2019s revised $121 billion offer.\n\nThe reasons\n\n\u2022 \u201cThe Broadcom proposal materially undervalues Qualcomm.\u201d \u2022 The offer \u201cfalls well short of the firm regulatory commitment the board would demand given the significant downside risk of a failed transaction.\u201d\n\nQualcomm said that it was willing to meet with Broadcom to see if its issues with the offer could be addressed.\n\nThe context\n\nOn Monday, Broadcom raised its takeover bid for Qualcomm to $82 per share from $70 per share, a month before Qualcomm\u2019s annual shareholder meeting where it hopes to unseat company\u2019s entire board. The improved offer was designed to entice shareholders to demand that Qualcomm\u2019s executives begin negotiations.\n\nQualcomm\u2019s management team and board have consistently argued that Broadcom\u2019s takeover approach is opportunistic since it is unfolding during Qualcomm\u2019s bruising legal fight with Apple, as well as priced too low.\n\nPhoto\n\nFrom also-rans to worthy contenders?\n\nTill this week, many investors wondered whether Snap and Twitter had much of a future at a time when Google and Facebook are sucking up such a large share of digital advertising dollars. But after Snap and Twitter reported earnings this week, the view now seems to be that there is space for the two firms to make good money, even as they remain in the shadow of Facebook and Google.\n\nBig stock moves. Twitter is up 16 percent in trading on Thursday after reporting fourth-quarter earnings. Snap, though down 8 percent on Thursday, is up over 30 percent since reporting its results earlier this week.\n\nTwitter and Snap are at very different stages of development. Though Snap added new users at a nice clip in the fourth quarter, the company still needs to prove that Snapchat is an effective and convenient place for big companies to advertise. In that sense, it is like Facebook in its early days as a public company. Twitter, however, needs to show that it can wring more revenue out of a slower-growing collection of users.\n\nThe bright spots shone out. Snap\u2019s strong user growth, up 18 percent in the fourth quarter, is a sign that it remains a draw to younger users that advertisers are keen to reach. While Twitter\u2019s user growth and advertising revenue for the United States was unimpressive in the fourth quarter, the company showed solid gains in both in the rest of the world. And there was evidence that Twitter is getting better at squeezing advertising revenue out of its users. Twitter\u2019s executives, without providing much numerical evidence, said that users are engaging more with ads, even while the costs of those ads fell for advertisers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nValuable breathing room. The fourth-quarter results bought both companies more time to prove themselves. And the financial pressure has lessened at Twitter. It is now churning out roughly half a billion dollars a year in cash flow, even including outlays for new plant and equipment.\n\nBut it will be a slog. The fourth quarter is generally bumper period for companies that rely on digital advertising, so the next couple of quarters could feel like a let down for Snap and Twitter. And if the companies disappoint, the stocks, far more highly valued than Facebook, could plunge. Twitter trades at 26 times the earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization that analysts surveyed by Bloomberg expect for the company in 2018. Facebook trades at 15 times forecast 2018 Ebitda. Analysts expect Snap\u2019s Ebitda to be negative this year.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nDoes Larry Fink want to be Buffett (or his old boss)?\n\nBlackRock is already the $6 trillion gorilla of the investing world. But its effort to raise more than $10 billion to buy and hold direct stakes in companies (as reported by the WSJ, citing unnamed sources) could put it more directly in competition with Mr. Fink\u2019s old firm, the Blackstone Group.\n\nBlackRock itself raises a different comparison, according to Sarah Krouse of the WSJ \u2014 to Warren Buffett:\n\nThe \u201cbest known\u201d example of BlackRock\u2019s approach with this new vehicle is Berkshire Hathaway, according to a fund-raising document reviewed by The Wall Street Journal. The Omaha conglomerate run by Mr. Buffett is well known for its long-term ownership of companies.\n\nBlackRock\u2019s Long-Term Private Capital fund would be a tenth of Berkshire\u2019s $101 billion in cash. But it too would look to buy and hold positions for more than 10 years. Over all, though, this seems more akin to private equity.\n\nThe bigger picture: BlackRock is competing against Blackstone and other asset managers for higher-fee investing products. (Mr. Fink\u2019s firm, of course, helped spearhead the rise of low-cost funds.)\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: There\u2019s an old rule. \u201cBeware of money managers saying that they will be like Buffett.\u201d\n\nA top WSJ editor heads to Lazard\n\nDennis Berman, the WSJ\u2019s financial editor, will join the investment bank\u2019s shareholder advisory practice, which helps defend companies against activist investors.\n\nThe practice has grown on Wall Street with the rise of activist investors, with investment banks touting their defense capabilities to corporate clients.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBefore becoming finance editor at the Journal, Mr. Berman oversaw the paper\u2019s business coverage and was its M.&A. reporter prior to that.\n\nMr. Berman, who will join as a managing director and be based in New York, will start on Feb. 26.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nAndrew, with a bit of context\n\nDennis follows in the footsteps of Steven Rattner, who worked as a reporter at the NYT in the 1980s before going to work as a banker at Lazard and becoming an influential financier. (Today, Mr. Rattner overseas Michael Bloomberg\u2019s fortune.) Dennis was my fiercest reporting competitor over the last decade and is one of the most talented financial journalists in recent memory.\n\nPhoto\n\nBrunswick Group names a new C.E.O.\n\nIt\u2019s Neal Wolin, a former deputy secretary for the Treasury Department in the Obama administration who has been a senior counselor to the communications firm for the past three years.\n\nMr. Wolin, who will remain based in Washington, will take over from the London-based Susan Gilchrist, who will become chairwoman of Brunswick\u2019s global clients operations and focus on client work full time.\n\nAlan Parker, Brunswick\u2019s founder, said in a telephone interview of the move, \u201cIt reflects the growth of the business and the business opportunity in America.\u201d\n\nThe context\n\nMany financial P.R. firms has been expanding beyond advising on mergers and on activist shareholder situations into work that touches on government relations and more. (Brunswick last week announced that it was forming a geopolitical consultancy group whose members include Bob Zoellick, the former Bush administration official.)\n\nIn some ways, the appointment of Mr. Wolin reflects that trend. Beyond his time at the Treasury Department, he previously worked as a senior executive at The Hartford, an insurer. And he was previously a Treasury Department official in the Clinton administration.\n\n\u201cIncreasingly, I think senior executives and boards of directors have come to understand that a lot of their challenges and opportunitiess sit at the intersection of business and governments and society and so forth,\u201d Mr. Wolin said in a phone interview.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOr as Mr. Parker put it, \u201cMore and more we hear ourselves described as a critical issues business.\u201d\n\nOther moves at Brunswick\n\n\u2022 Rob Pinker, who was the firm\u2019s C.O.O., will become the chairman of its emerging markets business.\n\n\u2022 Helen James, a partner, was named to the firm\u2019s C.O.O.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nTwitter\u2019s earnings, by the numbers\n\nFrom the company\u2019s earnings announcement:\n\n\u2022 Fourth-quarter revenue was $732 million, up 2 percent year over year.\n\n\u2022 Ad revenue hit $644 million, barely up from the same time last year.\n\n\u2022 Ad engagement was up 75 percent year over year.\n\n\u2022 Fourth-quarter profit \u2014 Twitter\u2019s first as a public company \u2014 was $91 million.\n\n\u2022 Monthly active users hit 330 million, up 4 percent year over year but flat quarter over quarter. (Twitter says that it purged some fake user accounts, which limited user growth numbers.)\n\n\u2022 Daily active users ... wasn\u2019t actually disclosed, only that it was up 12 percent year over year. Make of that as you will.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Shares in Twitter were up 23 percent in early-morning trading today/\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nThe dollar weakened and bond yields popped on the Bank of England.\n\nThe recent stock market freak-out may have abated, but the dynamics that drove the sell-off \u2014 worries that faster global growth and hotter inflation will trigger faster-than-expected rate hikes \u2014 are alive and well in the currency markets.\n\nOn Thursday, the Bank of England raised its growth forecasts for the United Kingdom, and Mark Carney, the bank\u2019s governor, said rates would likely have to be increased faster than previously expected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe British pound promptly popped by more than 1 percent against the dollar, and yields on British government bonds rose. Treasury bonds yields in the United States also rose, with the 10-year note offering yields of nearing 2.90 percent.\n\nThe sight of bond yields nearing 3 percent should keep stock investors on edge amid the growing conviction we\u2019re moving out of the era of low-interest rates, which were such a key ingredient for the near-decade-long bull market in stocks.\n\n\u2014 Matt Phillips\n\nPhoto\n\nStock markets are still jittery.\n\nThe bigger picture\n\nAs President Trump tweeted, \u201cWe have so much good (great) news about the economy!\u201d (It was the first time he had weighed in on the stock market moves, our colleagues Michael Shear and Alan Rappeport noted yesterday.) And indeed, analysts and economists said most economic indicators showed the U.S. doing well.\n\nBut Greg Ip of the WSJ notes how much the markets now depend on low interest rates.\n\nMeanwhile, Neil Irwin of the Upshot asks, How much inflation can we tolerate? The answer isn\u2019t simple.\n\nA bonus: How millennials coped with the market gyrations.\n\nPhoto\n\nWill we see a budget deal?\n\nIf the Senate has its way, yes. But critics in the House \u2014 where both Nancy Pelosi and hard-line conservatives denounced the proposal \u2014 may yet stop it.\n\nWhat business cares about in the proposal:\n\n\u2022 Nearly $300 billion in additional spending over the next two years\n\n\u2022 $20 billion for infrastructure spending\n\n\u2022 A lifting of the debt ceiling until March 2019\n\nThe bigger picture, from Thomas Kaplan of the NYT:\n\nThe agreement will cause federal budget deficits to grow even larger, on top of the effects of the sweeping tax overhaul that lawmakers approved in December. But because the deal gives long-sought victories to both parties, the deficit effect appears to be of little concern.\n\nIt\u2019s a complete reversal by Republicans on deficit spending.\n\nElsewhere in Washington: The White House\u2019s staff secretary, Rob Porter, resigned amid allegations of domestic abuse.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWynn Resorts\u2019 troubles aren\u2019t over yet\n\nSteve Wynn is gone. And Wynn\u2019s shares leapt nearly 9 percent on that news.\n\nBut the Massachusetts gaming commission is still investigating the company after sexual misconduct allegations going back decades emerged against the casino mogul. So is Macau, the home of its most profitable business.\n\nThe spotlight on Wynn\u2019s board: Our colleague Peter Eavis raised questions about the board\u2019s independence, like why it didn\u2019t suspend Mr. Wynn while it investigated the allegations. The Massachusetts commission also had concerns. Elizabeth Winkler of Heard on the Street thinks the board should go.\n\nPhoto\n\nCan Tronc stay together after selling the L.A. Times?\n\nWithout that crown jewel, the media company may find its digital strategy harder to achieve. (Tronc\u2019s chairman, Michael Ferro, wanted 100 million monthly unique visitors. This sale makes that virtually impossible. And while the deal will let Tronc repay all its debt, it\u2019s also parting with the source of a third of its operating profit, as Lex points out.)\n\nSo would someone like Gannett want what remains of Tronc, such as the Chicago Tribune and the Baltimore Sun?\n\nMore on the LAT\u2019s new owner: Patrick Soon-Shiong made his billions in the generic drug business, but has stayed relatively low-profile. (Other than being sued for stock fraud by Cher, and being the subject of news reports that he donates to hospitals that then do business with his companies.)\n\nMore on local news: Farhad Manjoo thinks it can be funded by \u2014 get this \u2014 readers paying for it.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat does SoftBank want with an insurer?\n\nBuying the chip maker ARM: We get that. But what does Masa Son\u2019s Japanese conglomerate want with Swiss Re, one of the world\u2019s biggest reinsurers?\n\nMaybe it\u2019s cash: $6 billion a year from operations, which could shore up SoftBank\u2019s debt-heavy balance sheet. Or maybe it\u2019s risk diversification.\n\nThe details: SoftBank is in talks to buy up to a third of Swiss Re at a premium to its Wednesday closing price.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 AT&T plans to spin out the Latin American operations of DirecTV, potentially raising billions of dollars. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nTesla forces Elon Musk back down to earth\n\nHere are some of Peter Eavis\u2019s takeaways from the carmaker\u2019s fourth-quarter results:\n\nWhat was OK: Tesla lost $3.04 per share, less than analysts forecast. Its $3.29 billion of revenue in the fourth quarter was roughly in line with expectations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat disappointed: Tesla\u2019s gross margin in its auto business, which reveals the profitability of actually producing its cars, came in at 13.8 percent, below the \u201cabout 15 percent\u201d it forecast when reporting third-quarter results.\n\nThe culprit: The Model 3.\n\nNaspers and Meituan make another big bet on food delivery\n\nNaspers, the South African tech conglomerate, and Meituan, the Chinese e-commerce company, said on Thursday that they were investing $100 million in Swiggy, an Indian food delivery app. (Naspers has done so before.)\n\nThe money will help the nearly four-year-old Swiggy build out its tech platform, expand its network and cut its delivery times.\n\nBehind the deal\n\nFood delivery is taking off in emerging markets just as it is in developed ones \u2014 but is focused even more on restaurants that make food explicitly for these services.\n\nNaspers Ventures\u2019s chief, Larry Illg, told Michael that lessons from Swiggy\u2019s rise could help it with other investments, like Delivery Hero. \u201cThe players tend not to cross borders, but consumer behavior is the same everywhere,\u201d he said.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 How Uber and Alphabet went from brothers to bitter enemies. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 YouTube\u2019s algorithmic recommendations can lead users to conspiracy theories and misleading videos. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nJeff Immelt adds \u2018Athenahealth chairman\u2019 to his post-G.E. r\u00e9sum\u00e9\n\nThe fast-growing medical records company can use a veteran corporate chieftain, particularly as it seeks to prove it can mature.\n\n\u201cI literally feel like I just scored a decade\u2019s worth of guitar lessons from Elvis,\u201d Jonathan Bush, the company\u2019s founder and C.E.O., told Michael.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe big questions\n\n\u2022 Is Mr. Immelt, whose successor at G.E. is trying to turn the company around after years of stagnation, the right man to chair Athenahealth?\n\n\u2022 Can a company founder take direction from an outsider?\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Lyft has hired Jon McNeill, most recently Tesla\u2019s president of global sales and service, as its C.O.O. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Scott Garrett, the former Republican lawmaker rejected as a nominee to lead the U.S.\u2019s Export-Import Bank, will join the S.E.C. as an adviser. He is Allen Shim, not Allen Shin.\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 The Justice Department charged 36 people after taking down a credit card crime website responsible for more than $530 million in losses. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Stocks Enter Correction Territory: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Given the strength of the global economy, central banks, led by the United States Federal Reserve, have started to remove some of the supports that helped supercharge stock and bond prices over the last decade. The Fed started raising rates two years ago. And with the robust jobs report on Friday showing the fastest wage growth in years, some think the pace of rate increases could quicken.\n\nAverage hourly earnings for United States workers were 2.9 percent higher in January than the previous year, the fastest annual increase in years. Although a welcome development for workers, economists often view rising wages as an early indication of inflationary pressure. If faster price increases do begin to emerge, the Fed could try to head them off with more aggressive rate action.\n\nJanet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve\u2019s departing chairwoman who had her last working day on Friday, was viewed by some as being more concerned about measures of weakness in the job market than by the risk of rising inflation, and therefore more willing to keep rates low. Her successor, Jerome H. Powell, will face different challenges as the Fed charts a new course in raising interest rates.\n\nInterest rates that are set every day in the global bond markets are already leaping higher, in anticipation of central bank rate increases later this year. On Friday, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note \u2014 a widely used gauge for overall interest rates \u2014 rose to more than 2.8 percent, the highest level since early 2014.\n\nRising rates have myriad consequences, including making it more expensive for companies and individuals to borrow money, like for buying a home or a car. The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate is around 4.2 percent, up from less than 4 percent at the end of 2017.\n\nUncertainty about how the economy will react to rising borrowing costs has raised the blood pressure of investors. In one sign of a shift underway, a measure of expected market turbulence, the CBOE Volatility Index, jumped by more than 25 percent on Friday. The so-called VIX has spent months at historically low levels, reflecting a placid market mood that seems to have evaporated over the last week.\n\nThe stock markets this week have reflected the jitters.\n\nThe energy sector was especially hard hit, with energy giants ExxonMobil dropping 5.1 percent and Chevron falling 5.6 percent on Friday after reporting lackluster earnings. The energy sector of the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index fell 6.4 percent during the week, the biggest drop of all industrial sectors in the benchmark.", "title": "Stocks Fall to End a Bad Week, and a Boom Begins to Look Shaky", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "After watching stocks march higher for nearly nine years, investors are suddenly confronting a new reality: The long, smooth ride is over. And it doesn\u2019t feel good.\n\nMajor stock indexes suffered a steep drop in late trading on Thursday, the second-straight day that stocks dived shortly before the markets closed. The 3.75 percent decline pushed the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index down more than 10 percent from its peak in late January. That means the market is technically in correction territory \u2014 a term used to indicate that a downward trend is more severe than simply a few days of bearish trading.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been trained that the market does nothing but go up,\u201d Bruce McCain, chief investment strategist at Key Private Bank, said of investors. \u201cAnd then suddenly, they\u2019re anxious, they\u2019re sitting nervously on the sidelines, and then they can\u2019t take it anymore.\u201d\n\nTrying to pinpoint the exact reasons for the last week\u2019s tumble is a fool\u2019s errand. But the most likely culprit appears to be fear that central banks will increase interest rates in an effort to fend off inflation and ensure that fast-growing economies don\u2019t overheat. Those fears were stoked Thursday when the Bank of England warned that it might raise interest rates faster than investors had expected.", "title": "Stocks Plunge as Market Enters \u2018Correction\u2019 Territory", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "For the week, the S.&P. 500 and the Dow tumbled 5.2 percent, their steepest weekly declines since January 2016.\n\nAt its lows on Friday, the Dow had given back nearly 40 percent of its gains since election day in 2016 and more than 45 percent of the gains since President Trump was inaugurated.\n\nHow volatile were stocks this week?\n\nThe Dow moved more than 1,000 points between its intraday high and low on Friday. For the week, the Dow swung at least 500 points from its session high to its low on five consecutive trading days\u2014something that last happened in October 2008, points out the WSJ\u2019s Akane Otani.\n\nBloomberg reports that a gauge on S.&P. 500 price moves had its biggest swing over the past two weeks on record. Of the move, Cameron Crise, a macro strategist at Bloomberg, said:\n\n\u201cThe journey from ecstasy to agony is entirely unprecedented, in the United States at least. That\u2019s the largest momentum swing in history \u2014 and it\u2019s not particularly close.\u201d\n\nThe C.B.O.E Volatility Index, known as the market\u2019s so-called fear gauge, moved from contango to backwardation. What does that mean? Here\u2019s an explanation.\n\nThe bigger picture\n\nThe cause of one of the most turbulent weeks in recent memory appeared to be widespread expectations that the global economy is improving and that growth would accelerate in the near future.\n\nThat has led to fears that interest rate increases could cheapen the value of certain kinds of investments.\n\nMore on the markets and economy\n\n\u2022 Steep sell-offs in the stock market can be the result of superficial worries that soon pass. But sometimes, falling stock prices reflect concerns about deeper problems. After a years-long borrowing binge, cracks may start to appear in the credit markets. Peter Eavis takes a look at where the big debt loads are and asks if they are sustainable.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmid market turmoil, earnings remain a bright spot.\n\nNearly 70 percent of S.&P. 500 companies have reported results so far, and profits are on pace to grow 14 percent, according to FactSet. Analysts expected earnings to rise 11 percent at the end of the fourth quarter.\n\n\u2022 If that growth rate holds up, it would mark the third quarter of double-digit earnings growth in the past four.\n\n\u2022 All 11 of the S.&P. 500\u2019s sectors are reporting higher profits, and five sectors have reported double-digit gains.\n\n\u2022 74 percent of companies are announcing earnings above Wall Street estimates.\n\n\u2022 79 percent are reporting sales above forecasts.\n\n\u2022 S.&P. 500 companies that generate more than 50 percent of their sales abroad are on pace to report a 17.4 percent increase in their bottom lines. For those that get the majority of their revenue from within the United States, earnings are set to rise 12 percent.\n\nPhoto\n\nWaymo and Uber settle their legal fight.\n\nNearly a year after Waymo first accused the ride-hailing company of plotting to steal important self-driving car technology, the two companies have settled their courtroom fight.\n\nAfter four days of arguments in Federal District Court here, Uber agreed to provide Waymo with 0.34 percent of its stock. Uber is now valued at about $72 billion, which works out to about $240 million, according to Waymo.\n\nWaymo, the self-driving car unit spun out of Google\u2019s parent company, Alphabet, argued that Uber had colluded with a former Google engineer to steal technology related to laser-based sensors, a key component in self-driving cars. Uber said it had developed its technology on its own.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nWho cares about deficits? Not Congress, it seems\n\nOne of the shortest shutdowns in U.S. government history is over, and Congress has reached a budget deal. The price is hundreds of billions in new spending.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRand Paul, who temporarily halted the Senate\u2019s vote on the deal, said this:\n\n\u201cI want people to feel uncomfortable. I want them to have to answer people at home who said, \u2018How come you were against President Obama\u2019s deficits and then how come you\u2019re for Republican deficits?\u2019 \u201d\n\nConservative House Republicans like the Freedom Caucus opposed the bill on similar grounds.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe critical take on deficit spending, from the lead editorial of this week\u2019s Economist:\n\nDemocrats are to get more funds for child care and other goodies; hawks in both parties have won more money for the defense budget. Mr. Trump, meanwhile, still wants his border wall and an infrastructure plan. The mood of fiscal insouciance in Washington, D.C., is troubling.\n\nWhat\u2019s in the bill\n\nThe NYT has a rundown of some hard-to-spot items in the bill, including:\n\n\u2022 The killing of the Independent Payment Advisory Board, which was meant to cap Medicare spending\n\n\u2022 The extension of tax breaks for renewable and nuclear energy and a tax credit for carbon dioxide capture\n\n\u2022 Special tax rates for timber sales\n\nThe immigration issue\n\nNancy Pelosi both praised the budget deal and said that she wouldn\u2019t vote for it because it didn\u2019t protect Dreamers. Some Democrats called on her to force her colleagues to block the deal, but others pointed to its funding for domestic programs.\n\nHow will the market rout impact the Federal Reserve\u2019s March decision?\n\nThe S.&P. 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average both fell into correction territory on Thursday. Fed officials, though, have remained upbeat on their outlook for the United States economy and sanguine about the market\u2019s tumble.\n\nThis week Robert Kaplan, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said:\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s healthy that there is some correction, a little more volatility in markets\u2026can be a healthy thing.\u201d\n\nWilliam Dudley, the New York Fed President, said:\n\n\u201cIf the stock market were to go down precipitously and stay down, then that would actually feed into the economic outlook, and that would affect my view in terms of the implications for monetary policy.\u201d\n\nBut expectations for a March rate increase have begun to come down, reported Chelsey Dulaney of MoneyBeat. Traders are betting there is a 72 percent chance that the Fed will raise rates at its March meeting, down from 79 percent a week ago, according to CME Group data. For the year, investors now see only a 17.5 percent chance of four rate increases this year, compared to 24 percent a week ago, Ms. Dulaney wrote.\n\nThe big question remains: Is the underlying economy holding up? So far, probably yes.\n\nMore in markets\n\n\u2022 The LJM Preservation and Growth Fund, an options mutual fund, essentially collapsed amid the turmoil. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Most Americans have limited exposure to the stock market. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Amazon effect is coming for UPS and FedEx\n\nShares in the two big names in package delivery were down in premarket trading today. Why?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom Laura Stevens of the WSJ:\n\nAmazon.com preparing to launch a delivery service for businesses, positioning it to directly compete with United Parcel Service Inc. and FedEx Corp. Dubbed \u201cShipping with Amazon,\u201d or SWA, the new service will entail the tech giant picking up packages from businesses and shipping them to consumers, according to people familiar with the matter. Amazon expects to roll out the new delivery service in Los Angeles in coming weeks with third-party merchants that sell goods via its website, according to the people. Amazon then aims to expand the service to more cities as soon as this year, some of the people say.\n\nWhere else have investors felt fear about what Amazon might do to an industry?\n\n\u2022 Healthcare\n\n\u2022 Groceries\n\n\u2022 Media\n\n\u2022 And retail, of course\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 White House officials knew as early as last fall that Rob Porter, the former White House staff secretary, faced domestic abuse allegations. The scandal has cast unflattering light on Mr. Porter\u2019s boss, John Kelly. And some White House officials say it was all orchestrated by the former Trump aide Corey Lewandowski.\n\n\u2022 Rand Paul is opposing the nomination of Marvin Goodfriend to the Fed, endangering the economist\u2019s chances. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump formally nominated Charles Rettig, a tax lawyer who fought the I.R.S., as its next leader. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 CVS is raising its base hourly pay rate and improving employees\u2019 health benefits because of the tax overhaul. (It also happens to be trying to buy Aetna for $69 billion.) (Axios)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. (NYT)\n\nWill Broadcom and Qualcomm reach a deal?\n\nQualcomm rejected Broadcom\u2019s revised $121 billion bid, saying it was an undervaluation and didn\u2019t offer enough commitment if regulators pushed back. But it opened the door to negotiations.\n\nBroadcom\u2019s C.E.O., Hock Tan, responded by asking to meet this weekend.\n\nBut there\u2019s still a lot they disagree on:\n\n\u2022 Qualcomm wants more than $82 a share. Broadcom says its bid is \u201cbest and final.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Qualcomm says it needs a firmer commitment to completing a deal, even if antitrust regulators object. Broadcom has offered an $8 billion breakup fee in that case, as well as a 6 percent \u201cticking fee\u201d if the deal takes more than 12 months to close.\n\nWhat one shareholder wants: Steven R\u00e9 of Fairbanks Capital Management told the WSJ, \u201cIn a peaceful deal, they can probably talk Hock Tan up another $5, maybe $7.\u201d\n\nAlso remember: Qualcomm\u2019s shareholder meeting is scheduled for March 6. Broadcom is looking to unseat the entire board.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 L\u2019Or\u00e9al says that it\u2019s ready to buy out Nestl\u00e9\u2019s 23 percent stake in it and hinted that it would sell its own stake in Sanofi, if necessary. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Walmart is willing to invest up to $4 billion in Flipkart, valuing the Indian ecommerce giant at as much as $20 billion, an unnamed source says. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Is Boeing in talks to buy Woodward, an airplane parts maker? Woodward says no, but unnamed sources told the WSJ yes. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Starboard Value will seek to unseat the entire board of Newell Brands, unnamed sources said. (Tilray)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Winter Olympics, brought to you by Samsung\n\nFollow the NYT\u2019s coverage of the games at Pyeonchang.\n\nBehind the scenes, the games reflect cozy ties between South Korea\u2019s government and Samsung \u2014 ones that continue to attract criticism.\n\nMore from Raymond Zhong and Park Jeong-eun of the NYT:\n\nThe company\u2019s chairman, Lee Kun-hee, is a longtime member of the International Olympic Committee and lobbied for years behind the scenes to bring the Winter Games to South Korea. The government saw Mr. Lee as so pivotal to its Olympic dreams that after he was convicted of tax evasion in 2008, the country\u2019s president then pardoned him expressly so he could resume lobbying for Pyeongchang.\n\nAnd from Timothy Martin of the WSJ:\n\nSo extraordinary is the overlap between Samsung, South Korea and the Pyeongchang Games it is unlikely to be repeated, say IOC members and Olympics experts. Mr. Lee\u2019s lobbying and Samsung\u2019s close involvement are now considered inappropriate by some Olympics experts and voters.\n\nPhoto\n\nAre Twitter and Snap contenders again?\n\nAfter Snap and Twitter reported earnings this week, the view now seems to be that there is space for the two firms to make good money, even in the shadow of Facebook and Google, Peter Eavis writes:\n\nBright spots: Snap\u2019s strong user growth, up 18 percent in the fourth quarter, is a sign that it remains a draw to younger users. And while Twitter\u2019s U.S. user growth and advertising revenue were unimpressive in the fourth quarter, both looked solid in the rest of the world.\n\nBreathing room: The fourth-quarter results bought both companies more time to prove themselves. And the financial pressure has lessened at Twitter. It is now churning out roughly half a billion dollars a year in cash flow.\n\nBut it will be a slog: The fourth quarter is generally a bumper period for companies that rely on digital advertising, so the next couple of quarters could feel like a let down for Snap and Twitter. And if they disappoint, their stocks \u2014 far more highly valued than Facebook \u2014 could plunge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Eleven British lawmakers testily questioned executives from Google, Facebook and Twitter about fake news during recent elections. (TechCrunch)\n\n\u2022 Didi and SoftBank are teaming up for ride-hailing services in Japan, giving Uber another headache. (WSJ)\n\nPhoto\n\nYour Bitcoin update\n\nIt\u2019s down to about $8,251 this morning, according to CoinMarketCap. Meanwhile, investors are more willing to bet against the virtual currency.\n\n\u2022 Elite U.S. universities are rushing to offer classes about Bitcoin and blockchain. One board member boasted that it\u2019s better than blockchain. Bill Griffin will be interim C.E.O. and Mike Johnson interim C.F.O. (Bloomberg)\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 The Trump administration has published data showing a large increase in penalties against polluters, as well as $20 billion in commitments from companies to correct problems that have cause environmental damage. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Addiction Policy Forum\u2019s acceptance of money from the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America has raised questions about whether it can really hold the drug industry to account over the opioid crisis.
