Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Stocks Post Worst Week in Two Years: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The Nasdaq Composite rose 1.8 percent and turned positive for the year.\n\nCorrection factoids\n\n\u2022 How many corrections have there been since 1980? 36, Ryan Detrick of LPL Financial writes. That comes to a little less than one a year.\n\n\u2022 What made this correction unique? It was the first time the S.&.P. 500 crossed into a correction nine days after hitting an all-time high, Mr. Detrick wrote.\n\n\u2022 The S.&P. 500 has moved at least 1 percent in eight sessions, matching last year\u2019s number of 1 percent moves.\n\n\u2022 One trader made nearly $200 million on a bet that volatility would surge, according to Pravit Chintawongvanich, the head of derivatives strategy at Macro Risk Advisors, via Bloomberg.\n\n\u2022 Bloomberg also reports that E*Trade added 64,581 gross new brokerage accounts in January, the most in a month since September 2016.\n\nHas the 30-year bond bull market reached a top?\n\nRay Dalio thinks so.\n\nIn a LinkedIn post, the billionaire hedge fund manager said: \u201cWe don\u2019t know exactly how far we are from the top in the stock market and then the economy, though it is clear that we are past the top in the bond market.\u201d\n\nYet Jeff Rosenberg, the chief fixed-income strategist at BlackRock, said that it is a \u201cfool\u2019s errand\u201d to call the end of the bond bull market. Mr. Rosenberg told CNBC that while he expects higher bond yields to persist for a period, he is not ready to call the end of the bond bull market.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat could be sold off in the Trump infrastructure plan\n\nIf the White House had its way, here\u2019s some of the government-run assets that could be sold to private financiers as part of the $1.5 trillion infrastructure investment program:\n\n\u2022 Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport\n\n\u2022 Dulles International Airport\n\n\u2022 The George Washington and Baltimore Washington parkways\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The Washington Aqueduct\n\nHere\u2019s what the plan says:\n\nThe vast majority of the Nation\u2019s electricity needs are met through for-profit investor-owned utilities. Federal ownership of these assets can result in sub-optimal investment decisions and create risk for taxpayers.\n\nSome context: Only one U.S. airport \u2014 Puerto Rico\u2019s \u2014 has successfully been privatized. (Chicago\u2019s bid to privatize Midway failed four years ago.) Thus far, St. Louis is the only mainland U.S. city that is exploring privatizing its airport, but the effort has drawn criticism.\n\nAn interesting point about infrastructure investing raised by Dan Primack of Axios:\n\nThe average level of return that infrastructure investment funds have sought was about 10.6 percent in 2016, down from 14 percent in 2004, according to a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers and the Global Infrastructure Investor Association. Infrastructure in general is regarded as a lower-return asset class with fairly consistent cash flows.\n\nWhile the Blackstone Group is raising $40 billion for its own infrastructure fund (half of which is coming from Saudi Arabia), it\u2019s hard to see private investors filling in the $1.3 trillion required to fulfill the Trump administration\u2019s vision.\n\nTo break it down numerically:\n\n\u2022 PwC and the G.I.A.A. note that roughly $200 billion had been raised by infrastructure investors since 2006.\n\n\u2022 Roughly $1.7 trillion was invested worldwide between January 2010 and September 2016.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nWhat investors are watching to guess the markets\u2019 direction\n\nThe recent, complacency-shaking declines in stock prices will have forced investors to take more seriously the yardsticks used to assess whether stocks are worth buying. None of the metrics on their own reliably can predict the direction of stocks, but when markets are freaking out and much is a blur, well-chosen indicators can steady the nerves and clarify the mind.\n\nThe most important indicator right now\n\nIt\u2019s the 10-year Treasury note\u2019s yield, which moves in the opposite direction to its price. A higher yield reflects greater inflation fears among investors \u2014 and a higher likelihood of that interest rates are going up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStock investors fear higher interest rates for two main reasons:\n\n\u2022 Most immediately, they make stock valuations look less attractive\n\n\u2022 In the longer term, they can eventually slow economic growth.\n\nThe yield on the 10-year Treasury note has retreated to 2.83 percent Monday, while United States stocks are trading higher. The Dow Jones industrial average, the S.&P. 500 and the Nasdaq Composite are all up more than 0.5 percent.\n\nAdding to the fun\n\nThe government inflation figures come out on Wednesday.\n\nThe valuation question\n\nThe recent volatility in the stock market has stirred up the valuation debate. Put more directly, did the declines take stock prices down to level where they no longer look expensive?\n\nThere are many ways to tackle that question. But for no particular reason, let\u2019s look at the Rule of 20 today. This yardstick subtracts the inflation rate from the number 20 and compares that answer with the price-to-earnings ratio of the S.&P. 500. Stocks are theoretically overvalued if the price-to-earnings ratio is higher.\n\nRight now, the S.&P. 500 price-to-earnings ratio is 21.1 times, 3.2 above the 17.9 that you get from subtracting the inflation rate from 20. That suggests stocks could have further to fall.\n\nStill, history shows why that might not be the case. In 1997, the rule of 20 gave roughly the same answer as we have now, but stocks kept zooming higher. (Of course, that bull run did not end well. By 2001, the stock market was down below 1997 levels.)\n\nIf you find the debate over valuation unsatisfactory ...\n\nThere are also technical indicators, which look at how traders react to a wide selection of market measurements. One of the most interesting right now is the 200-day moving average on the S.&P. 500.\n\nJohn Kimelman at Barron\u2019s gave a good run down on why it matters:\n\nBut at one point Friday, it looked like that was where things were heading. Shortly before 1 p.m., the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 briefly broke below its 200-day moving average, or 2539, before recovering and closing the week above 2619, up 1.5% on the day. The 200-day moving average\u2014the continually updated average price of the past 200 days\u2014is considered a strong measure of investor sentiment. If the S&P 500 had continued to fall below the average, it would have conveyed real bearishness. The S&P 500 hasn\u2019t closed below that moving average in 408 trading sessions, going back to around the U.S. presidential election in November 2016, according to LPL Financial.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nIcahn and Deason urge shareholders not to \u201clet Fuji steal\u201d Xerox.\n\nCarl Icahn and Darwin Deason, two of Xerox\u2019s biggest investors, sent a letter to shareholders criticizing the printer and copier maker\u2019s deal with Fujifilm Holdings of Japan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrom the letter:\n\nIt really is a remarkable achievement by Fuji. Without putting up any cash, they will acquire majority control and ownership of a venerable American icon. In exchange, we \u2013 the existing Xerox shareholders \u2013 will receive (1) an additional, indirect 25% interest in a Fuji subsidiary that just last year disclosed a $360 million accounting scandal caused by a \u201cculture of concealment\u201d and Fuji\u2019s failure to have adequate management systems and (2) a one-time special dividend financed with our own assets.\n\nThe backstory\n\nXerox said on Jan. 31 that it would combine operations with Fujifilm Holdings in a $6.1 billion deal.\n\nThe complicated transaction will fold Xerox into an existing 55-year-old joint venture. Xerox shareholders will receive a special cash dividend of $9.80 a share and will own 49.9 percent of the combined business, which will be publicly traded. The move is expected to save at least $1.7 billion in costs, though Fujifilm will cut 10,000 jobs.\n\nAt the end of last year, Mr. Icahn launched a campaign to unseat the Xerox\u2019s board, and late last month, he and Mr. Deason pressured the company to explore a deal \u2014 including revising or ending the Fujifilm joint venture.\n\nXerox\u2019s statement, via Reuters:\n\nXerox said it \u201cconsidered several other options in detail and concluded that the combination with Fuji Xerox is the \u2018best path to create value\u2019 for the company.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nBroadcom will walk if it doesn\u2019t get control of Qualcomm\u2019s board.\n\nBroadcom\u2019s chief executive, Hock Tan, appeared on CNBC to discuss his company\u2019s $121 billion bid for Qualcomm. The appearance comes just days before the two companies are scheduled to meet to discuss the deal and less than a month before Qualcomm\u2019s annual shareholder meeting on March 6. Broadcom proposed a slate of 11 directors to replace the entire board of Qualcomm in December.\n\nHere are some of Mr. Tan\u2019s comments:\n\nOn concerns the deal won\u2019t win regulatory approval and Broadcom\u2019s offer of an $8 billion breakup fee if it doesn\u2019t:\n\n\u201cYou know, I\u2019m kind of a frugal guy. You think I would sign up to pay $8 billion if there\u2019s even a second thought?\u201d\n\nOn if Qualcomm\u2019s shareholders don\u2019t vote for a majority of Broadcom\u2019s slate on March 6:\n\n\u201cThis is a binary proposal. If at least a majority of our slate does not get in on March 6, then I guess we will get the message that this deal is not going to happen. We will walk.\u201d\n\nOn Qualcomm\u2019s $110 a share offer for NXP Semiconductors, which has gotten pushback from NXP investors:\n\n\u201cNXPI will not solve Qualcomm\u2019s problems.\u201d\n\nOn the possibility that Qualcomm increases its bid for NXP Semiconductors:\n\n\u201cIf Qualcomm raises the price on NXPI, we have made it very clear, it\u2019s a clear transfer of value from Qualcomm shareholders to NXPI shareholders.\u201d \u201c$110 is a full and fair price for NXPI.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWho wants to buy which Time Inc. titles from Meredith?\n\nMeredith has closed its deal to buy Time Inc. Now the media industry is buzzing about which publications Meredith\u2014 a predominantly women-focused, non-newsy publisher \u2014 is likely to sell.\n\nHere\u2019s what the media banker Reed Phillips told Joe Pompeo of Vanity Fair:\n\nTime, Fortune, Sports Illustrated, and Entertainment Weekly are the hot properties, he said, noting that suitors are most likely to be rich trophy buyers, former media executives, and possibly other publishers. Private equity, not so much, \u201cexcept maybe for some firms that would do distress deals,\u201d Phillips said. \u201cStrategic buyers or wealthy individuals are gonna win out.\u201c\n\nWho could be a buyer? Some of the names that Mr. Pompeo identified:\n\n\u2022 Jimmy Finkelstein, who owns The Hill\n\n\u2022 David Pecker, who owns the National Enquirer\n\n\u2022 Wang Jianlin of Dalian Wanda\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nIs Facebook losing younger users?\n\nThe answer is yes, according to new figures from the market research firm eMarketer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe numbers\n\n\u2022 \u201cFor the first time, less than half of United States internet users ages 12 to 17 will use Facebook via any device at least once per month.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cThe number of users ages 12 to 17 and 18 to 24 will decrease by 5.6 percent and 5.8 percent.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cIn 2018, the number of United States Facebook users ages 11 and younger will decline by 9.3 percent.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cFacebook will lose 2 million users ages 24 and younger this year, eMarketer estimates. Not all of those users are migrating to Instagram.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cSnapchat, meanwhile, will add 1.9 million users in that age group.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cSnapchat will continue to have more users ages 12 to 24 compared with that of Instagram.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nPhoto\n\nGeneral Dynamics\u2019s deal and the new era of military spending\n\nWhat\u2019s happening: The company agreed to buy CSRA, a provider of information technology to the federal government, for $6.8 billion.\n\nGeneral Dynamics will pay $40.75 a share in cash, up 32 percent from CSRA\u2019s Friday closing price.\n\nPhebe Novakovic, General Dynamics\u2019 chairman and C.E.O., said of the deal:\n\nCSRA\u2019s management team has created an outstanding provider of innovative, next-generation IT solutions with industry-leading margins. We see substantial opportunities to provide cost-effective IT solutions and services to the Department of Defense, the intelligence community and federal civilian agencies.\n\nThe context\n\nThe deal came as President Trump has pushed for higher defense spending since taking office. Last week\u2019s budget deal added billions for military programs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRemember Mr. Trump\u2019s tweet on Friday:\n\nThe advisers\n\n\u2022 For General Dynamics: Stone Key Group and the law firm Jenner & Block\n\n\u2022 For CSRA: Evercore, Macquarie Capital and the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison\n\n\u2014 Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nDina Powell is headed to Harvard\n\nAfter leaving the White House as deputy national security adviser for strategy, Ms. Powell is going to academia. She will become a non-resident senior fellow for the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at the Harvard Kennedy School.\n\nNicholas Burns, the faculty director of the Belfer Center\u2019s Future of Diplomacy Project, said in a statement:\n\n\u201cDina Powell is one of our country\u2019s finest public servants. ... Combined with her deep private sector background, Dina will be a source of ideas and inspiration for our students.\u201d\n\nMany had been wondering where Ms. Powell would go after her tenure in the Trump administration. Before joining the White House, she had been a fast-rising executive at Goldman Sachs, where she oversaw the firm\u2019s impact investment business.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Bush administration.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nThe deeper issues in the markets\n\nWas Friday too volatile for you? Let\u2019s see how today goes. S. & P. 500 futures were up this morning, suggesting a rise today. But some savvy market players warn that more pain may be in store.\n\nThe head of Goldman Sachs\u2019s equities trading sent a pessimistic note to clients on Friday, according to Robin Wigglesworth of the FT. The message: We haven\u2019t hit a market bottom yet, and the era of \u201cbuy the dip\u201d is over.\n\nAnd Bob Prince, a co-chief investment officer at Bridgewater Associates, told the FT, \u201cThere had been a lot of complacency built up in markets over a long time, so we don\u2019t think this shakeout will be over in a matter of days.\u201d\n\nFrom Andrew: Something to think about. How much of the economy\u2019s recent success has been a function of the wealth effect in the stock market? If even some of it is, how would more volatility affect consumer spending \u2014 and cycle back through the markets?\n\nThe markets flyaround\n\n\u2022 Peter Eavis breaks down potential debt problems. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Did insurers trigger the market volatility? (FT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The clash between bonds and stocks is heating up. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nUnilever\u2019s threat to Facebook and Google\n\nOne of the biggest advertisers around says it will stop buying ads on their platforms if they don\u2019t do more to combat hate speech, fake news and other divisive content.\n\nFor context: Unilever spent more than $9 billion on marketing last year, for products from Dove soap to Lipton iced tea.\n\nWhat Keith Weed, its chief marketing officer, plans to say at the Interactive Advertising Bureau conference today:\n\n\u201cWe cannot continue to prop up a digital supply chain \u2014 one that delivers over a quarter of our advertising to our consumers \u2014 which at times is little better than a swamp in terms of its transparency.\u201d\n\nRemember: Unilever was already outspoken about the need to clean up the digital ad industry. And shareholders like BlackRock have called upon public companies to do more social good, or risk a backlash.\n\nPhoto\n\nAre the infrastructure and budget plans \u2018science fiction\u2019?\n\nThat\u2019s what Axios reckons, since neither White House proposal is likely to go anywhere.\n\nOn infrastructure\n\nDon\u2019t look for more specifics from the Trump administration, including on how its initiative will be funded. Republican lawmakers are wary of more spending: The government funding bill that Mr. Trump signed last week will push the budget deficit toward $1 trillion.\n\nRepresentative Daniel Lipinski, Democrat of Illinois, told the WaPo of the plan, \u201cI think it\u2019s just dead on arrival.\u201d And the National Resource Defense Council attacked it as an \u201cunacceptable corporate giveaway.\u201d\n\nPolitico points out that the proposal would shift many project decisions to state governments.\n\nOn the budget proposal\n\nLast week\u2019s bill made it irrelevant. Still, Mick Mulvaney of the Office of Management and Budget warned yesterday that the growing budget deficit could lead to a \u201cspike\u201d in interest rates. (His caveat: sustained economic growth could make up for that.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, the White House wants $23 billion for more immigration enforcement, including for Mr. Trump\u2019s border wall.\n\nThe policy flyaround\n\n\u2022 The fallout from the resignation of Rob Porter, the former White House staff secretary, continues. He added that the office reviewed the proposed terms of the sale and that they did not include a victims compensation fund.\n\nHarvey Weinstein said of the lawsuit in a statement that if it was designed to scapegoat him, \u201che will vigorously defend himself.\u201d\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump appeared to dismiss the #MeToo campaign, making Republicans uneasy. And its latest valuation is $72 billion. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Stocks Record Their Biggest Two-Day Rally Since 2016: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "All along, they took steps to cover their tracks by stealing the identities of real Americans, opening accounts on American-based servers and lying about what their money was being used for. Last September, after Facebook turned over information about Russian ad purchases to the special counsel, a specialist named Irina Kaverzina emailed a family member: \u201cWe had a slight crisis here at work: the FBI busted our activity (not a joke). So, I got preoccupied with covering tracks together with the colleagues.\u201d Ms. Kaverzina continued, \u201cI created all these pictures and posts, and the Americans believed that it was written by their people.\u201d\n\nFake news, indeed.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s defenders, desperate to exculpate him, seized on a single word \u2014 \u201cunwitting\u201d \u2014 that the indictment used to describe certain \u201cmembers, volunteers and supporters of the Trump campaign involved in local community outreach\u201d who had interacted with the Russians.\n\nIn other words, as the White House subtly put it in a statement on Friday, \u201cNO COLLUSION.\u201d The president repeated the claim himself in a tweet, grudgingly acknowledging Russia\u2019s \u201canti-US campaign,\u201d but emphasizing that it had started \u201clong before I announced that I would run for President. The results of the election were not impacted. The Trump campaign did nothing wrong \u2014 no collusion!\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s true that, as Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein said in an announcement, these particular indictments do not allege that any American knew about the influence campaign, nor that the campaign had changed the outcome of the election. But that\u2019s quite different from saying that there was no collusion or impact on the election. As Mr. Rosenstein also said, the special counsel\u2019s investigation is continuing, and there are many strands the public still knows little or nothing about.\n\nRemember, Mr. Mueller has already secured two guilty pleas, one from Mr. Trump\u2019s former national security adviser and another from a former campaign adviser, for lying to federal authorities about their connections to Russian government officials. He has also charged Mr. Trump\u2019s former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, and his top aide, Rick Gates, with crimes including money laundering. Mr. Gates appears to be nearing a plea deal himself.\n\nThen there were Russian cyberattacks on the elections systems of at least 39 states. And the hacking of emails sent among members of the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton campaign \u2014 which Mr. Trump openly encouraged.\n\nThis is all going to happen again. Intelligence and law enforcement authorities have made that clear. The question is whether Mr. Trump will at last accept the fact of Russian interference and take aggressive measures to protect American democracy. For starters, he could impose the sanctions on Russia that Congress overwhelmingly passed, and that he signed into law, last summer. Of course, this would require him to overcome his mysterious resistance to acting against Russia and to focus on protecting his own country.", "title": "Opinion | Stop Letting the Russians Get Away With It, Mr. Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "If headlines about an \u201cInstant Pot recall\u201d or an \u201cInstant Pot meltdown\u201d have been making you anxious, there\u2019s reason for relief. Your beloved pressure cooker is probably fine.\n\nInstant Pot, the Canadian company whose electric multifunction pressure cookers became a must-have gift for many over the holiday season, said last week that it had received a small number of reports about overheating in the Gem 65 8-in-1 Multicooker. The company said it would replace the affected models of the device, which is not a pressure cooker.\n\nInstant Pot said that the only models of the Gem affected were those from five batches, marked with the batchcodes 1728, 1730, 1731, 1734 and 1746. Customers can check to see whether their Gems were included in those batches by finding a silver label on the bottom of the cooker. The batchcode is on the bottom right of the label.\n\nThat said, if you do have a Gem in one of those batches, you should stop using it. Instant Pot has assured affected customers that they will be sent instructions on how to receive a free replacement.", "title": "Stop Worrying! Your Instant Pot Is Safe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFrom Black Gold to Golden Rays\u201d (Business Day, Feb. 6) and \u201cClean Power Becomes Cheap Power,\u201d by Justin Gillis and Hal Harvey (Op-Ed, Feb. 7):\n\nWhile the falling cost of solar power and wind power is welcome news, let\u2019s not overlook the fact that these forms of generation are intermittent. Storage that can meet the demanding performance requirements of the electricity grid is the missing piece. Such batteries would allow us to draw electricity from the sun even when the sun doesn\u2019t shine.\n\nBut those batteries, unlike anything on the market today, must be long-lived (say 20 years), safe, operationally flexible and inexpensive. Without investment in the requisite research and commercialization, we cannot expect radical innovation in this sector. We have a technological problem; it demands a technological solution.\n\nDONALD R. SADOWAY\n\nCAMBRIDGE, MASS.\n\nThe writer is a professor of materials chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and co-founder of the battery company Ambri.", "title": "Opinion | Storing Solar Energy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Last fall, Mr. Darbi was sentenced to 13 years in prison. In a document jointly prepared by prosecutors and the defense, the government agreed that he had fulfilled his end of the deal, including providing testimony against two other detainees that was \u201cunprecedented in similar counterterrorism prosecutions to date.\u201d\n\nBut on the date by which he was to have left \u2014 Feb. 20 \u2014 the Pentagon announced that he would remain at Guant\u00e1namo for the time being. In a statement at the time, Cmdr. Sarah Higgins, a Defense Department spokeswoman, said the United States government was still waiting for the Saudi government to provide assurances permitting the departure to move forward, but hoped that would happen soon.\n\nWhen he learned he would not be going home on Feb. 20, Mr. Darbi said: \u201cI felt like I got hit by a truck. I felt destroyed, physically and morally.\u201d And, referring to his detainee number, he added, \u201cInstead of being called by my first or last name in my own country, I\u2019m still being called \u2019768,\u2019 still here in this place.\u201d\n\nThe unexpected limbo in which Mr. Darbi finds himself may have larger consequences for the military commissions system. His fate could encourage \u2014 or discourage \u2014 other detainees who may consider cooperating and serving as witnesses in exchange for a deal to eventually leave Guant\u00e1namo.\n\nOn Wednesday, Commander Higgins said that nothing had changed since Feb. 20 and that the United States was still awaiting word from the Saudis.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRamzi Kassem, a law professor at the City University of New York who has been Mr. Darbi\u2019s lead defense counsel since 2008, appealed to Saudi officials to focus on his client.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI understand that senior Saudi officials are preoccupied with other matters,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s still disappointing to read statements by U.S. spokespeople indicating that the cause of delay is the Saudi government. This arrangement has been a long time coming. We expected smooth and timely implementation and hope that both countries are working hard to fulfill the agreement soon.\u201d\n\nAt the time of Mr. Darbi\u2019s plea deal, Saudi Arabia and the United States exchanged diplomatic notes agreeing to the transfer. Under those terms, the process was to begin with him submitting a request to prosecutors, which the United States would then send through diplomatic channels to the kingdom.\n\nIf Saudi Arabia concurred, the notes said, the kingdom would inform the United States \u201cand initiate procedures\u201d to carry out the transfer at Saudi expense. Or, if it did not concur, the kingdom would \u201cpromptly\u201d say so.\n\nMr. Kassem said Mr. Darbi submitted his transfer request to commissions prosecutors in August. The lawyer also suggested that there was little left to negotiate in terms of the specifics of diplomatic assurances.\n\n\u201cThe diplomatic notes that the United States and Saudi Arabia exchanged in 2014 reflect the full framework we negotiated for Mr. Darbi\u2019s transfer to Saudi custody,\u201d he said. \u201cAny additional terms or assurances deemed applicable should be familiar from the many repatriations of Saudis from Guant\u00e1namo.\u201d\n\nIt remains unclear how long it took for the Pentagon to pass Mr. Darbi\u2019s request to the State Department, and when the United States Embassy in Riyadh in turn presented it to the Saudi government.\n\nA State Department spokeswoman declined to discuss the matter beyond expressing its support for the Pentagon in trying to carry out the transfer under the plea deal, saying the government would not \u201cdetail private, diplomatic conversations.\u201d", "title": "Stranded at Guant\u00e1namo, a Cooperative Detainee Criticizes Saudi Arabia", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "As neither is in a hurry to leave town, it\u2019s fortunate that the High-Ho is hiring, and soon the new waitress and the new short-order cook \u2014 wouldn\u2019t you know it, Adam has formidable kitchen skills \u2014 are passing order slips and plates of steak to each other, building up to something that isn\u2019t exactly \u201cFrankie and Johnny.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nLaura Lippman\u2019s \u201cSunburn\u201d may be set in 1995, before Google searches made it a whole lot harder to vanish and start afresh elsewhere, but it takes its inspiration (as Polly does, explicitly), from \u201940s noir: \u201cDouble Indemnity,\u201d \u201cMildred Pierce,\u201d \u201cThe Postman Always Rings Twice.\u201d Polly and Adam\u2019s relationship observes the conventions. It\u2019s ill advised, passionate and doomed. How could it be otherwise? The reader knows from the start that Polly has done something unforgivable: She has walked away from her husband and 3-year-old daughter at the beach, left a note in their holiday rental and hitched a ride into an unknown future, jumping out at Belleville when the driver tried to put a hand on her knee. We know her husband is a heel, we can forgive her for running away from him \u2014 but a child? Really? And if Adam is able to overlook this, how do we feel about that?\n\nPolly yearns for a quiet life (\u201cAll she has ever wanted is a home, a place with things that bring comfort. Thick towels, deep chairs, soft rugs. That doesn\u2019t necessarily mean having money, but it means having more money than she\u2019s ever had. So far\u201d) but she won\u2019t find one in Belleville. All the shadows she hoped to leave behind \u2014 police corruption, arson, insurance scams, confidence tricks and, inevitably, murder \u2014 are catching up with her. If these elements of the plot drag a little, perhaps that\u2019s because Lippman wants us to examine our assumptions. Why are these crimes somehow less compelling, less appalling, than Polly\u2019s act of maternal desertion? Unpicking this, the reader is shown something unexpected. The last scenes may belong in a different, more sentimental novel, but by this point you will want difficult, damaged Polly to find her happy ending.\n\nSo \u201cSunburn,\u201d though cool and twisty, has more heart than expected. It\u2019s generous in other ways, too. The particular atmosphere of unlovely Belleville is deftly conveyed: its motel and trailer park, its emptied-out Main Street and, of course, the High-Ho, where regulars gather to watch \u201cthe inevitable Orioles game on the inevitable TV with the inevitable shimmy in its reception.\u201d Yet there is beauty here too. You see the huge red sun sinking into the cornfields; you feel the dew underfoot.\n\nNow and then a tangential character who in another novel might only merit a line or two is given a vivid chapter of his or her own. Here\u2019s a recently dumped gay P.I. who\u2019s fussy about chef\u2019s salads; a video-store clerk who prides himself on his staff picks; a housewife who has a marble-topped kitchen island and white roses in a milk-bottle vase; and her sister, who has none of those things.\n\nPeople move in and out of the narrative with their own baggage and preoccupations. What they choose to tell us is very subjective and not always directly relevant, and this clamor of voices gives the novel satisfying depth and texture. There\u2019s a sense here that we\u2019re brushing up against many lives, many versions of the truth. \u201cStories are like dough,\u201d Polly thinks, reflecting on the slippery business of family myth. \u201cPut your hands in your stories, work them, but don\u2019t overwork them.\u201d", "title": "Strangers in the Night, Exchanging Genre Conventions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCinephiles, like other mammals, need love. As such, we also need movies about love, and yes, in this category we often expect somewhat higher standards than those reflected in works like \u201cFailure to Launch\u201d or \u201cFriends With Benefits.\u201d\n\nAs Valentine\u2019s Day looms, I\u2019ve compiled my list of outstanding romantic films available on streaming video services. I begin with offerings on FilmStruck and its attendant Criterion Channel. A real find there is the \u201cHistory Is Made at Night,\u201d a still-underseen film from 1937 that\u2019s never been on a presentable DVD. It\u2019s one of the most romantic Hollywood movies ever, also one of the warmest and in some respects the funniest. Any attempts to sum up the plot of this film will sound daft. Story elements include a jealous husband, cheesy ventriloquism used for flirtation, two men who take over a restaurant for the sole purpose of attracting a single client, and an ocean liner forced to plow into an iceberg. But the chemistry between its stars, the ultra-Gallic Charles Boyer and Jean Arthur, playing up her cornfed American quality (early on Boyer\u2019s character nicknames her \u201cKansas\u201d), remains remarkable to this day. And Frank Borzage\u2019s direction of Gene Towne and C. Graham Baker\u2019s far-fetched screenplay is a model of seamless conviction.\n\nThe Michael Powell-Emeric Pressburger picture \u201cI Know Where I\u2019m Going!\u201d from 1947, is a strong contender for the most romantic British picture ever made. Wendy Hiller\u2019s lead character thinks she knows where she\u2019s going \u2014 off to the Scottish Hebrides to marry for money. A detour in the company of a near-penniless laird (Roger Livesey) changes her plans. The raw beauty of the Scottish locations sets off the tumultuous love story in inimitable cinematic style. Other greats in FilmStruck\u2019s catalog include Fran\u00e7ois Truffaut\u2019s sweet and graceful \u201cStolen Kisses,\u201d a 1969 picture in which Jean-Pierre L\u00e9aud, as the Truffaut alter-ego Antoine Doinel, tentatively pursues the lovely Claude Jade, but is intrigued by an older woman, Delphine Seyrig, and Howard Hawks\u2019s \u201cHis Girl Friday\u201d (1940), starring Cary Grant as a newspaper editor who pursues his ex-wife and former star reporter, Rosalind Russell, in frantic, eccentric screwball-comedy style.\n\nFilmStruck also offers two first-rate stories of gay love. \u201cWeekend,\u201d the 2011 film written and directed by Andrew Haigh, in which a late-night bar pickup turns into something deeper and more intimate. (This is not to be confused with the 1968 \u201cWeekend\u201d on the Criterion Channel, a ragefest directed by Jean-Luc Godard that begins with a mutually adulterous husband and wife contemplating homicide.) Donna Deitch\u2019s 1985 \u201cDesert Hearts,\u201d about two women falling in love in the wide open spaces of 1950s Nevada, is a groundbreaking movie that continues to play beautifully today.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd while I wouldn\u2019t call \u201cMy Beautiful Laundrette\u201d (1986), directed by Stephen Frears from a script by Hanif Kureishi, a direct precursor to Mr. Haigh\u2019s \u201cWeekend,\u201d the films do have an affinity. \u201cLaundrette\u201d is a story not just of cultural difference (the main character is a second-generation immigrant of Pakistani origins, trying to make good in Thatcher\u2019s England) but of gay love and friendship in a working-class milieu. It also features a young Daniel Day-Lewis at his most boyishly adorable in the role of Johnny, a former skinhead who\u2019s the lead character\u2019s love interest. The movie streams on Fandor.", "title": "Streaming Your Valentine\u2019s Day", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Thursday\u2019s Air France strike involving the carrier\u2019s pilots, cabin crew and ground staff has ended, and as of today, the carrier\u2019s operations are slowly returning back to normal, according to a statement on its website.\n\nThe one-day strike disrupted the travel schedules of thousands of Air France passengers all over the world and will likely continue to do so for the next day or two, according to Michael Holtz, the owner of SmartFlyer, a global travel consultancy specializing in airlines.\n\n\u201cIt usually takes an airline 24 to 48 hours to get back on track after a strike,\u201d he said.\n\nIn the case of Air France, since the carrier anticipated the strike because workers had made clear that they would take action, Mr. Holtz said that the it likely held most of its planes in Paris, its home base. \u201cSince the planes are sitting in Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports, outbound flights from Paris should be up and running today or within the next day,\u201d he said.\n\nIn-bound flights to Paris from long-haul destinations, however, could still be delayed for 48 hours, Mr. Holtz said, because the planes need to fly from Paris to reach those destinations in order to operate the routes. \u201cAir France has a flight from Bangkok to Paris,\u201d he said. \u201cThe plane needs to reach Bangkok from Paris, which takes more than ten hours, before it can fly the scheduled route.\u201d", "title": "Strike Over, Air France Resumes Flights", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "There is no escaping it: The rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. One-quarter of American workers make less than $10 per hour, a wage well below the current poverty level. The top 1 percent have an average net worth of $26.4 million, and on top of that, they take home $1.5 million annually. The wealthiest 1 percent own 40 percent of the income of our entire country, and that number is growing. Most low-wage workers do not receive any benefits from their employers \u2014 no health insurance, no retirement plans, no guaranteed sick days, nothing to protect them from the unforeseen forces of fate, whether it be a bad fall or an unexpected death or illness in the family. Ignoring these facts, the Trump administration\u2019s major legislative accomplishment has been a huge tax cut for the wealthy, widening the wage gap even further.\n\nNow comes a court case that could increase our nation\u2019s income inequality even more. On Monday the Supreme Court heard Janus vs. Afscme, a historic case that challenges a four-decade-old precedent that stipulates union members must pay the union in exchange for the union fulfilling its legal responsibility to represent every member, negotiate a contract and fight for pay increases for everyone. The potential consequences of the court\u2019s decision will be real and immediate. If the court rules against Afscme \u2014 the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees \u2014 then union members across the country could receive all the benefits of being in a union without having to pay for it.\n\nThis could be perceived as a win for union members, who would reap the assistance of a union without having to pay dues. But the impact of an anti-union decision would be financially disastrous for public-sector employees. It would give people an option that might seem appealing (getting something for nothing) but that would actually ensure that unions do not have the resources they need to negotiate good contracts, fight for higher wages, defend members and protect pensions.\n\nThe plaintiff in this case is Mark Janus, a child-support specialist for the state of Illinois. But the real perpetrators of the broader assault on workers are the billionaires and corporations who have spent fortunes over many years to defund unions and consequently make it harder for working people to receive fair wages. The lie at the heart of this effort is the idea of \u201cright to work,\u201d policies that allow workers to avoid paying fees to unions that bargain for them.", "title": "Opinion | Striking a Blow for the Big Guys", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Weather delays have plagued Alpine races at the Winter Olympics for more than 50 years. It is a natural consequence of the typical Winter Games setting, where altitude and a seasonable climate can lead to excessive snow and high winds. Either one can make a ski course unsafe.\n\nAlthough the Alpine courses at the Pyeongchang Olympics are not at an especially high elevation for an Olympics (less than 4,000 feet), strong, gusty winds of 40 to 60 miles per hour this week have whipped through the valleys and mountain passes.\n\nThe conditions caused the postponement of the men\u2019s downhill here on Sunday. On Monday, the women\u2019s giant slalom was called off as well, despite bright sun. The swirling winds were so harsh it was hard to keep the cloth panels used to mark the gates affixed to the gate poles. Expecting the racers, even the best in the world, to negotiate down the course was asking too much.\n\nThe Olympic Alpine calendar included days built into the schedule in case of weather delays when it was formed months ago. But with the weather not expected to improve until Wednesday, Olympic officials on Monday did something uncharacteristic: In essence, they threw up their hands and gave in to the weather.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficials had been hoping to avoid running two Alpine races on the same day since it diminishes the profile of each event. Over the years, they have been especially protective of the men\u2019s downhill, the most daredevil Alpine event and a signature race of any Winter Olympics.", "title": "Strong Winds Bring More Skiing Delays, and Good News for Shiffrin", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump delivered a brief, uncharacteristically subdued message of faith and American values to religious leaders as a fresh crisis swirled in his White House, declaring on Thursday morning \u201cwe praise God for how truly blessed we are to be American.\u201d\n\n\u201cFaith is central to American life and to liberty,\u201d Mr. Trump said at the annual National Prayer Breakfast, a gathering of religious leaders who have become a keystone of his political base. \u201cOur founders invoked the creator four times in the Declaration of Independence. Our currency declares, \u2018In God we trust.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s remarks came amid growing questions about how the White House handled allegations of domestic violence against one of the president\u2019s closest aides.\n\nThe White House chief of staff, John F. Kelly, steadfastly defended the aide, Rob Porter, right up until Mr. Porter resigned on Wednesday. Officials now say the White House was aware of the charges against Mr. Porter, which contributed to a delay in granting him a security clearance for his post as staff secretary.", "title": "Subdued Prayer Breakfast Message by Trump Amid White House Turbulence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIf Subway Is Nearby, Should You Pay More Taxes?\u201d (front page, Jan. 29):\n\nIf New York City\u2019s assessments are up to date, you already pay more in taxes. If there is any public amenity nearby that causes the property to be worth more than similar properties without the amenity, then that higher value is in the assessment and you pay higher taxes because of it.\n\nIt also works the other way: If your property is near something that reduces the value, the assessment should be less and you pay less in taxes. The only real question is whether or not the city is current in keeping its assessments up to date.\n\nNATHAN L. JASCHIK, ROCHESTER\n\nThe writer is a retired regional planner.", "title": "Opinion | Subways and Taxes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt just seems if we are investing a billion in station upgrades we think that some of those stations should get elevators,\u201d said Polly Trottenberg, the commissioner of the city\u2019s Department of Transportation. \u201cI don\u2019t understand nonetheless how they reached the decision, picking some of these stations.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Cuomo and transit officials have argued that improving the appearance of stations is part of improving the experience for riders and that the system is already undergoing a major face-lift as part of the subway emergency plan that was begun last summer.\n\nAt Thursday\u2019s meeting, Andy Byford, the president of New York City Transit, the M.T.A.\u2019s subway division, offered a full-throated endorsement of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s plan, arguing that some of the work addressed structural issues that could no longer be ignored. \u201cIf they were purely cosmetic then I would have a problem with it,\u201d Mr. Byford said.\n\nMr. Byford said he had spent weeks analyzing the stations slated to be enhanced and had come to understand why things like elevators were not part of the plan, explaining that some of the stations were close to accessible stations, while in other cases figuring out how to make a station compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act would drag out the necessary work.\n\n\u201cTo wait for perfection at every station?\u2019\u2019 he said.\u201cSome will fall into a dangerous state of disrepair, and you will fall into my scenario of, \u2018yes it\u2019s ADA-compliant but oops\u2019\u201d \u2014 the station would be inaccessible because it had fallen apart.", "title": "Subways to Get Station Upgrades, and Governor Gets His Way", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "That reluctance, Mr. Kelly said, is partly \u201con account of the struggle for land in the past, the hard times we came from, the British Empire running the country,\u201d when landlords, who were predominantly Protestant, rented to tenant farmers, who were mainly Roman Catholic.\n\nThis passion for land is deeply engraved in the Irish mentality, as evidenced in literary works like Patrick Kavanagh\u2019s epic poem \u201cThe Great Hunger\u201d and John B. Keane\u2019s play \u201cThe Field,\u201d said Terence Dooley, a historian of land reform who is a professor at Maynooth University. \u201cAnd rights of way on Irish land are probably the most contentious and controversial issue you can deal with.\u201d\n\nBut the timing of the Greenway development was propitious.\n\nThe local council had long been interested in using the old railway as a walking and cycling route based on similar initiatives elsewhere in Europe. And when Padraig Philbin, the senior county engineer who pioneered the Greenway, got started on the project nine years ago, the global financial crisis had left Ireland in need of ideas that would bring in revenue.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe were in a bad place back in 2009,\u201d Mr. Philbin said. \u201cThe recession had just begun, and this area was hurt worse than most. Most people knew it was for the well-being of the entire area, and there would be jobs and other benefits.\u201d\n\nThere were still many obstacles. Landowners had to be assured that they would not face lawsuits by anyone injured on the trail, and that they would retain full ownership of their land and be able to withdraw permission to cross it at any time. In some places, diversions had to be made where the old line passed too close to newly built houses, or where landowners could not be persuaded to come on board.\n\nBut the response to the Greenway\u2019s opening has been highly positive.\n\nThe local council reckons that the trail had already generated enough new tourism to make up for most of its cost of 7.5 million euros, or about $9.3 million, only a year after it officially opened in 2010. At least 200 new jobs were created in pubs, hotels, bicycle rental and other tourism-related businesses, the council said, and over a quarter-million people now use the trail each year.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Greenway concept, already proven abroad, has been emulated in other parts of Ireland, too. Walking and tourism groups like Mountaineering Ireland are relying on the same principle of \u201cpermissive access\u201d to develop new foot trails and improve existing ones in other scenic but privately owned shore and mountain areas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Kelly, the farmer, likes the Greenway concept so much that he lets one section follow part of his house\u2019s driveway. There, he built a wooden shelter for tired passers-by, with water on tap for humans and dogs.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve met people from all over the world right on my doorstep,\u201d he said.\n\nDermot Madigan, the general manager of the Mulranny Park Hotel, said it was a no-brainer to let the Greenway pass through the hotel grounds. Built in 1897 as a seaside resort that depended on the railway, the hotel now sees its old branch line delivering customers once again. \u201cOur bar business alone went up 13 percent in the first year, which is a big jump,\u201d Mr. Madigan said.", "title": "Success of Irish Trail Shows That Maybe You Can Eat the Scenery", "authors": ["Ed O Loughlin"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 The figure skater Evgenia Medvedeva of Russia was already a two-time world champion and a consensus favorite to win gold at the 2018 Winter Olympics weeks before her 18th birthday last autumn.\n\nAt a competition in Moscow in October, she laughed easily. Months earlier, she had skated as the anime character Sailor Moon, dressed as a Japanese schoolgirl turned superhero. Now she performed as Tolstoy\u2019s tragic Anna Karenina, joking, \u201cI\u2019m skating to show that I won\u2019t be an old maid.\u201d\n\nShe carried a toy cat like a security blanket but also became the assertive face of Russia\u2019s Olympic athletes. She argued forcefully \u2014 and successfully \u2014 at a December meeting of the International Olympic Committee that all Russian athletes should not be barred from the 2018 Games because of a state-sponsored system of doping at the 2014 Games in Sochi, Russia.\n\nMedvedeva and her training partner, Alina Zagitova, 15, are widely expected to win two of the three available medals in women\u2019s singles skating at the Winter Games and are expected to make Russia a gold medal favorite in the team competition. But no longer does Medvedeva appear invincible. Will this stoke their passion or quell it?\n\n\u201cI think the Philadelphia fans will always be the same passionate (sometimes obnoxious) fans they always were, win or lose,\u201d Anne Clark, the matriarch of a family of ardent Eagles fans, said in an email during the game.\n\n\u201cPerhaps it should\u201d change the fans\u2019 mind-set, Jack Long, 69, a retired Philadelphia firefighter and paramedic, said at the gym. \u201cYou\u2019re no longer the underdog. You\u2019re just another team that needs to show up and spend the money to win.\u201d", "title": "Suddenly, Philadelphia Has a Major Identity Crisis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "ISLAMABAD, Pakistan \u2014 At least 11 soldiers, including an army captain, were killed and 13 others were injured Saturday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives at a highly guarded army base in northern Pakistan, officials said.\n\nThe Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack, one of the deadliest against the military in recent years. The powerful explosion, which rocked the surrounding area, occurred in the Kabal region of Swat, a picturesque valley in the northern part of the country.\n\nThis was the first major terrorist attack in Swat, once a Taliban stronghold, in the past five years, local residents said. The Pakistani military wrested the region from the Taliban in 2009 and has maintained a heavy presence.\n\nThe suicide bomber struck Saturday evening while the soldiers were playing volleyball after duty. Officials said they imposed a curfew, cordoned off most local roads and searched for accomplices in the aftermath.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe most recent suicide bombing in Swat took place in 2013, when 22 people were killed at a religious congregation.\n\nThe Pakistani Taliban are led by Maulana Fazlullah, who comes from Swat and led militants in the region before assuming leadership of the group. Mr. Fazlullah escaped to Afghanistan after the 2009 military operation, and Pakistani military officials say he is hiding in Kunar Province of Afghanistan. Pakistan has made several requests to the Afghan government to track down and arrest Mr. Fazlullah.", "title": "Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 11 at Pakistani Army Base", "authors": ["Salman Masood"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSunroofs are getting bigger, and so that raises questions that perhaps those numbers are larger,\u201d Mr. Levine said.\n\nMs. Hankins is among those whose lives were forever changed.\n\nThe sunroof in her 2000 Ford Expedition was fun when she first got the vehicle, but the novelty wore off and she usually kept it closed \u2014 just as it was when she crashed on the way to work in Yazoo City, Miss., in 2005.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t think I would ever be thrown out of it,\u201d she said in a telephone interview.\n\nMs. Hankins has no memory of the crash, but the evidence showed that the truck rolled over, the glass panel of the sunroof popped out and she was thrown through the opening.\n\n\u201cIt put me in a wheelchair,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cIt scarred my face really badly.\u201d\n\nIn the suit against Ford, Ms. Hankins\u2019s lawyers argued that the automaker should have used laminated safety glass, the kind used in windshields, and more securely anchored the panel. The lawyers said Ford had known for decades that laminated glass \u2014 which uses a layer of plastic film between two layers of glass \u2014 was safer, but used less-expensive tempered glass.\n\nThe automaker acknowledged that tempered glass, which is used in side windows, was less expensive. However, it said serious brain and neck injuries could occur when heads hit laminated glass, a danger it concluded was a greater threat to belted occupants than ejection. (Ford asserted that Ms. Hankins had not been wearing a seatbelt \u2014 a suggestion she denied.)\n\nThe N.H.T.S.A. considered regulating sunroof safety in 2011 when it established rules to prevent side-window ejections but ultimately opted against doing so. (To comply with the side-window rules, carmakers usually rely on curtain airbags that cover the windows.)\n\nThe agency noted that only 3 percent of the 10,000 ejection deaths each year from 1997 to 2008 involved sunroofs. That contrasted with 62 percent through side windows.", "title": "Sunroofs Are Growing in Size and Popularity. Rules Haven\u2019t Kept Up.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Are you planning to watch Super Bowl LII? If so, what are you most looking forward to \u2014 the game, the commercials, the parties or the halftime show? If not, why not?\n\nIf you\u2019re a football fan, what do you think of the matchup between the Philadelphia Eagles and the New England Patriots? Who are you rooting for? Who do you think will win? Which players do you think will stand out and why?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to see what the numbers say about who will win this year.", "title": "Super Bowl LII", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "When New England Has the Ball\n\nPhoto\n\nAnyone who watched an Eagles game this season should be familiar with the havoc that Fletcher Cox and Brandon Graham, Philadelphia\u2019s star defensive linemen, can wreak. They may not have been among the league leaders in sacks, but they were the key cogs in a defense that led the N.F.L. with 112 quarterback hits.\n\nThere is little relief behind the defensive line, as the Eagles have standout defenders on all three levels, especially the secondary, where Ronald Darby and Malcolm Jenkins are the stars but Jalen Mills and Rodney McLeod more than hold their own.\n\nOne of the things Philadelphia did best this season, according to statistics provided by Sportradar, was limit the effectiveness of throwing into coverage. Brady was one of the most aggressive quarterbacks in the N.F.L. this season at attempting passes to covered receivers, and that could be a serious problem against a team that allowed a 16.6 passer rating on passes in which a defender was within a yard of the receiver.\n\nBrady is Brady, so he can be relied upon to find a way to move the ball, but tight end Rob Gronkowski\u2019s health and effectiveness are in question after he sustained a concussion in the A.F.C. championship game. If Gronkowski is limited, Brady will try to move the ball downfield with Brandin Cooks, but will probably have to rely on running backs James White and Dion Lewis to provide a lot of his passing yardage on catch-and-runs.\n\nIt is unlikely that the Patriots will get much out of their running game. The Eagles had the top-ranked run defense in the N.F.L., giving up an average of 79.2 yards a game. Part of that is a function of the opposition often trying to overcome a deficit, but the Eagles were sixth in the N.F.L. in yards allowed per carry and allowed only seven rushing touchdowns. It is hard to see Mike Gillislee, Rex Burkhead and Lewis getting much traction.\n\nWhen Philadelphia Has the Ball\n\nPhoto\n\nPhiladelphia\u2019s status as underdog rests almost entirely on which version of Foles shows up. If he is the tentative passer who struggled in the regular season and his team\u2019s win over the Atlanta Falcons in the divisional round, the Eagles are in trouble. If he is the confident, 2013 vintage Foles who tore apart the Minnesota Vikings in the N.F.C. championship game, the game is at worst a tossup for Philadelphia and at most a shocking upset.\n\nTo put so much pressure on Foles, who stepped into the starting role after a season-ending injury to Carson Wentz, is, of course, unfair. But there is an argument to be made that if Wentz were active, it would be Patriots fans raiding Amazon.com in hopes of finding dog masks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFoles will want to build on his recent success against a terrific Minnesota secondary. He spread the ball around and appeared to have shaken off the rust that limited him severely in the previous few games. He got receptions of 35 yards or more from four different receivers and was especially good on third down; Philadelphia converted 10 of 14 opportunities.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNew England\u2019s pass defense was ranked 30th in the N.F.L., but that was skewed by the team\u2019s struggles in the first six weeks of the season. The Patriots\u2019 secondary could struggle against receiver Alshon Jeffery and tight end Zach Ertz, but will probably not have much trouble containing Torrey Smith and the erratic Nelson Agholor.\n\nWhen looking to run, the Eagles have one of the most diversified and effective attacks in the N.F.L. Losing the mobile Wentz was a serious blow, but a group of backs that includes Jay Ajayi, LeGarrette Blount and Corey Clement can run against any defense. The only thing that would slow them down is the Patriots getting off to a big early lead, which would force the Eagles to abandon the run.\n\nSumming Up\n\nIf you remove the quarterbacks from the equation, the Eagles are at least the Patriots\u2019 equal, if not their superior. They were a juggernaut under Wentz and still have a loaded roster. The Patriots, for all of their recent success, are relying far more on experience and execution than overall talent. At one point, Las Vegas had the Eagles as 6-point underdogs, but that has been lowered to 4 points, which seems closer to reality. Just don\u2019t tell Brady.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not buying any underdogs,\u201d he said of the Eagles. \u201cYou\u2019re not fooling me with that.\u201d\n\nThe Eagles will fight hard, and certainly have a chance at pulling off an upset, but Brady\u2019s experience and Foles\u2019s volatility give New England a slight advantage. The Patriots won three Super Bowls in a four-season period from 2001 to 2004, and they appear poised to repeat that accomplishment.
