[BBC]\n\n\u2022 Two Reuters journalists arrested after investigating the existence of a mass grave of Rohingya Muslims, are due in court in Myanmar today. [Reuters]\n\n\u2022 In Japan, a military helicopter crashed on the southern island of Okinawa. One crew member was killed and one was missing, but no civilian deaths were reported. [Associated Press]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 A machete-wielding man wearing the white robe of a Shiite martyr was shot and wounded as he tried to enter the central offices of the Iranian president. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 As Iranian women protest compulsory veiling, the president\u2019s office released a 2014 report showing that nearly half of Iranians consider the veil a private matter that should not be regulated. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The Philadelphia Eagles won their first Super Bowl by beating the New England Patriots. But celebrations in the team\u2019s hometown turned unruly. [The New York Times]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Celebrate Mardi Gras with these classic recipes, like crawfish \u00e9touff\u00e9e, above.\n\n\u2022 This customizable quinoa and white bean soup doesn\u2019t need meat to taste good.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Polar bears are fat-burning machines, but global warming forces them to venture farther onto Arctic sea ice to catch seals. Researchers attached video cameras to nine of them, revealing fascinating footage of their increasingly urgent quest for food.\n\n\u2022 For Asia Shiva Keshavan, an Indian luge pilot, is the reigning Asian champion of a sport dominated by athletes from Austria, Germany and Italy. The Winter Olympics in South Korea will be his sixth, and probably last.\n\n\u2022 And some romance and heartbreak: Our \u201cModern Love\u201d podcast is 100 episodes old. To mark the occasion, we asked listeners to weigh in.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cOh, what a flight.\u201d\n\nThe Times\u2019s headline about the 1988 N.B.A. All-Star festivities said it all. The weekend belonged to Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, widely considered the greatest basketball player of all time. He cemented his place in slam dunk history 30 years ago today.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the final round of the slam dunk contest, in which judges award competitors\u2019 creativity, Jordan faced Dominique Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks.\n\nIn one of his final dunks, Jordan dribbled from the far end of the court and leapt from the foul line, 15 feet from the basket. Back arched, legs trailing behind him, Jordan sailed through the air with one hand pushing the ball toward the basket. The judges awarded him a perfect score.\n\nThe final score could have easily gone to Wilkins, but Jordan was performing in front of a hometown Chicago crowd, which \u201csurely had some influence on the slam dunk judges, and galvanized his All-Star teammates, to say nothing of their considerable effect on The Flying Machine himself,\u201d The Times reported. Above, another famous Jordan dunk from the competition.\n\nThe next day, Jordan would go on to score 40 points in the All-Star Game.\n\n\u201cThis was,\u201d Jordan said, \u201ca picture-perfect weekend.\u201d\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Browse past briefings here.\n\n\n\nWe have briefings timed for the Australian, Asian, European and American mornings. And our Australia bureau chief offers a weekly letter adding analysis and conversations with readers. You can sign up for these and other Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Super Bowl, Samsung, Maldives: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": ["Mike Ives", "Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Supreme Court partly granted on Tuesday a request from North Carolina Republicans to block a voting map drawn by a federal court there. That court had interceded after finding that a map drawn by state lawmakers for the General Assembly had relied too heavily on race and had violated state laws.\n\nThe Supreme Court\u2019s order, which was brief and gave no reasons, partly blocked that decision while the justices consider whether to hear an appeal in the case.\n\nThe justices seemed to split into three camps: Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel A. Alito Jr. said they would have granted the entire request; Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Sonia Sotomayor said they would have granted none of it; and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Stephen G. Breyer, Elena Kagan and Neil M. Gorsuch appeared to take the middle position.\n\nLast month, the Supreme Court blocked a decision from a different federal court in North Carolina that had ordered state lawmakers to redraw the state\u2019s congressional maps. That ruling concerned partisan gerrymandering, while the new one was based on a finding of racial gerrymandering and violations of state law.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Supreme Court has occasionally struck down voting districts as racial gerrymanders. But it has never ruled that a partisan gerrymander crossed a constitutional line. The court is considering two cases, from Wisconsin and Maryland, that will give it a new chance to determine whether extreme partisan gerrymandering is constitutional.", "title": "Supreme Court Issues Partial Stay in North Carolina Voting Case", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "But the brief argued that the exceptions in the immunities law did not apply. \u201cThe property at issue here consists of ancient Persian artifacts, documenting a unique aspect of Iran\u2019s cultural heritage, that were lent to a U.S. institution in the 1930s for academic study,\u201d the administration\u2019s brief said. \u201cExecution against such unique cultural artifacts could cause affront and reciprocity problems.\u201d\n\nJustice Elena Kagan was recused in the case, Rubin v. Islamic Republic of Iran, No. 16-534, but the court did not say why.\n\nWhistle-Blowers\n\nThe court unanimously ruled that a federal law protecting whistle-blowers in securities cases must be read narrowly to bar many retaliation suits from people who say they were fired for reporting wrongdoing. The plain words of the law, part of the Dodd-Frank Act, required that conclusion, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg wrote.\n\nThe law defined \u201cwhistle-blower\u201d to mean \u201can individual who provides information relating to a violation of the securities laws\u201d to the Securities and Exchange Commission. That language excluded people who merely reported wrongdoing to their employers, Justice Ginsburg wrote.\n\nThe case, Digital Realty Trust v. Somers, No. 16-1276, started when Paul Somers, then an executive at a real estate investment trust, told his superiors \u2014 but not the S.E.C. \u2014 about what he said were securities law violations. Mr. Somers was fired, and he sued under the Dodd-Frank Act.\n\nA divided three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, allowed the case to proceed, saying that a literal application of the law \u201cwould make little practical sense and undercut congressional intent.\u201d\n\nThe Supreme Court reversed that decision. \u201cCourts are not at liberty to dispense with the condition \u2014 tell the S.E.C. \u2014 Congress imposed,\u201d Justice Ginsburg wrote.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo sets of justices filed concurring opinions, disagreeing over whether the majority should have taken account of a Senate report in addition to words of the statute. \u201cI do not think it wise for judges to close their eyes to reliable legislative history,\u201d wrote Justice Sotomayor, joined by Justice Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Clarence Thomas, joined by Justices Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Neil M. Gorsuch, disagreed, saying that only the text of the statute should be considered.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPrisoners\u2019 Lawsuits\n\nBy a 5-to-4 vote that divided the justices along ideological lines, the court ruled that prisoners who win civil rights suits must pay 25 percent of the damages they recover toward awards of attorney\u2019s fees.\n\nThe case concerned Charles Murphy, an Illinois inmate badly beaten by prison guards, who crushed his eye socket. Mr. Murphy sued the guards, winning about $307,000 and $108,000 in attorney\u2019s fees.\n\nThe question in the case was how to interpret a federal law that says in such cases \u201ca portion of the judgment (not to exceed 25 percent) shall be applied to satisfy the amount of attorney\u2019s fees awarded against the defendant.\u201d\n\nA trial judge ordered Mr. Murphy to pay 10 percent of his award to his lawyers, but an appeals court ruled that the law required the full 25 percent.\n\nJustice Gorsuch, writing for the majority, said the law left no room for judicial discretion. \u201cWhen you purposefully seek or aim \u2018to satisfy\u2019 an obligation, especially a financial obligation, that usually means you intend to discharge the obligation in full,\u201d he wrote. Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Thomas and Alito joined the majority opinion.\n\nIn dissent, Justice Sotomayor argued that the law\u2019s language contemplated partial payments. She said, for instance, that a partial payment of a credit card debt would be generally understood to be \u201capplied to satisfy\u201d the debt. Justices Ginsburg, Breyer and Kagan joined the dissent in the case, Murphy v. Smith, No. 16-1067.\n\nAppeals After Guilty Pleas\n\nBy a 6-to-3 vote, the court ruled that a North Carolina man who pleaded guilty to violating a federal law that bars firearms on the grounds of the United States Capitol may nonetheless challenge the constitutionality of the law on appeal.\n\nThe defendant, Rodney Class, was charged with violating the law after guns and ammunition were found in his car in a parking lot on the Capitol grounds. On appeal, he sought to argue that the law violated the Second Amendment and the Constitution\u2019s due process clause. The appeals court refused to consider the arguments, saying that Mr. Class had waived them by pleading guilty.\n\nJustice Breyer, writing for the majority, said, \u201cClass\u2019s valid guilty plea does not, by itself, bar direct appeal of his constitutional claims in these circumstances.\u201d Chief Justice Roberts and Justices Ginsburg, Sotomayor, Kagan and Gorsuch joined the majority opinion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn dissent, Justice Alito wrote that the majority had provided no clear guidance about when appeals after guilty pleas are permitted. \u201cThere is no justification for the muddle left by today\u2019s decision,\u201d he wrote, adding: \u201cI fear that today\u2019s decision will bedevil the lower courts.\u201d Justices Kennedy and Thomas joined Justice Alito\u2019s dissent in the case, Class v. United States, No. 16-424.", "title": "Supreme Court Rules on Terrorism, Whistle-Blowers and Prisoners", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Supreme Court on Monday declined an unusual White House request that it immediately decide whether the Trump administration can shut down a program that shields some 700,000 young undocumented immigrants from deportation. The move meant that the immigrants, often called \u201cDreamers,\u201d could remain in legal limbo for many months unless Congress acts to make their status permanent.\n\nThe Supreme Court\u2019s decision not to hear the administration\u2019s appeal was expected, as no appeals court has yet ruled on the issue. The court\u2019s order was brief, gave no reasons and noted no dissents. It said it expected the appeals court to \u201cproceed expeditiously to decide this case.\u201d\n\nPresident Trump ended the program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, last September, calling it an unconstitutional use of executive power by his predecessor and reviving the threat of deportation for immigrants who had been brought to the United States illegally as young children.\n\n\n\nBut two federal judges have ordered the administration to maintain major pieces of the program while legal challenges move forward, notably by requiring the administration to allow people enrolled in it to renew their protected status. The administration has not sought stays of those injunctions.\n\n", "title": "Supreme Court Turns Down Trump\u2019s Appeal in \u2018Dreamers\u2019 Case", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 With her jet-black hair, alabaster skin and pale green eyes, Susie Cave\u2019s darkly drawn beauty has bewitched designers (Azzedine Ala\u00efa and Yves Saint Laurent), and photographers (Helmut Newton, David Bailey and Steven Meisel) \u2014 not to mention her husband, the Australian rock star Nick Cave.\n\nThese days there are new people under Ms. Cave\u2019s spell: fans of her fashion label, The Vampire\u2019s Wife, a runaway success since its introduction in 2014.\n\n\u201cI originally started designing clothes for myself because I couldn\u2019t find anything that I wanted to wear, especially for the evening,\u201d Ms. Cave, 51, said last week. A former model, she was wearing one of her latest retro-glam creations: a silk velvet maxi dress with a high neckline, puffed shoulders and bell sleeves, and a hem that all but hit the floor. From one wrist hung an 18-karat gold bracelet she recently designed with the jeweler Annoushka Ducas, laden with charms inspired by Mr. Cave\u2019s songs, including \u201cWhere the Wild Roses Grow\u201d, \u201cMermaids\u201d and \u201cThe Mercy Seat.\u201d\n\nSitting in the cocoon of a velveteen armchair, Ms. Cave said she never thought her business \u2014 started from her home in the British seaside town of Brighton \u2014 would take off as it did. Her skirts and dresses are now beloved by glossy A-listers, and Ms. Cave has been getting ready to debut her first handbag designs. The jewelry collaboration will be unveiled at an installation in Dover Street Market next week.", "title": "Susie Cave on Designing Delicate Dresses With Bite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "For the latest news in the wake of the Florida school shooting, read Thursday\u2019s coverage.\n\nPARKLAND, Fla. \u2014 The suspect in one of the deadliest school shootings in modern American history confessed to the police that he \u201cbegan shooting students that he saw in the hallways and on school grounds,\u201d according to a police arrest report released Thursday.\n\nThe suspect, Nikolas Cruz, 19, carried a black duffel bag and backpack, where he hid loaded magazines, the report said. He arrived at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland in an Uber at 2:19 p.m. on Wednesday and pulled out a semiautomatic AR-15 rifle, according to details described by the authorities at a news conference on Thursday.\n\nMr. Cruz also shot people inside five classrooms on the first and second floors of the freshman building. He eventually discarded the rifle, a vest and ammunition in a stairwell, blended in with fleeing students and got away, the authorities said.\n\nAfter leaving the school, Mr. Cruz walked to a Walmart, and bought a drink at a Subway. He also stopped at a McDonald\u2019s. He was arrested by the police without incident as he walked down a residential street at 3:41 p.m.\n\n\u201cHe looked like a typical high school student, and for a quick moment I thought, could this be the person who I need to stop?\u201d said Officer Michael Leonard.\n\nHere are the takeaways:\n\n\u2022 Mr. Cruz faces 17 counts of premeditated murder \u2014 one for each of the people he is accused of killing on Wednesday in a shooting that was captured on cellphone video by terrified students. He is being held without bond at the main Broward County jail, where he has been placed on suicide watch, according to Gordon Weekes, the county\u2019s chief assistant public defender.\n\n\u2022 The AR-15 rifle used in the attack was purchased legally, at Sunrise Tactical Supply in Florida, according to a federal law enforcement official. The arrest report said Mr. Cruz purchased it in February 2017. \u201cNo laws were violated in the procurement of this weapon,\u201d said Peter J. Forcelli, the special agent in charge for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives in Miami.\n\n\u2022 The F.B.I. said on Thursday it received information last year about a comment made on a YouTube channel which has been attributed to the gunman, but was unable to identify the person.\n\n\u2022 In Florida, an AR-15 is easier to buy than a handgun. Read more on how the AR-15 became one of the weapons of choice for mass killers, and the research that tries to explain the high rate of mass shootings in the United States.\n\n\u2022 With this shooting, three of the 10 deadliest mass shootings in modern United States history have come in the last five months. Here is a graphic that records the grim toll of school shootings across the nation.\n\n\u2022 A huge crowd gathered at Pine Trails Park in Parkland for an emotional vigil to commemorate the victims, 14 of whom were students. Read more about the victims here. The football team gathered separately nearby, forming a circle and locking hands before praying for a coach and an athletic director who were killed.\n\nVideo\n\n\u2022 Sign up for the Morning Briefing for news and a daily look at what you need to know to begin your day.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe victims \u2014 14 students and three faculty \u2014 ranged from 14 years old to 49.\n\nAmong them was a popular football coach and a geography teacher credited with saving a boy\u2019s life when he stood in front of a classroom door.\n\nThe coach, Aaron Feis, was seen as someone who looked out for students who got in trouble, those who were struggling, those without fathers at home. \u201cHe\u2019d go out of his way to help anybody,\u201d said Mr. Feis\u2019s grandfather, Raymond. Read more about the victims here.\n\nMr. Cruz made his first court appearance, clad in an orange jail jumpsuit.\n\nShackled around his hands, feet and waist, Mr. Cruz was asked if he understood the circumstances. \u201cYes, ma\u2019am,\u201d he whispered.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s sad. He\u2019s mournful,\u201d his public defender, Melisa McNeill, said afterward. \u201cHe is fully aware of what is going on, and he\u2019s just a broken human being.\u201d\n\nMr. Weekes, the chief assistant public defender, said the lawyers were still trying to piece together the details of Mr. Cruz\u2019s life. Mr. Cruz has a \u201csignificant\u201d history of mental illness, according to Mr. Weekes, and is possibly autistic or has a learning disability.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Mr. Weekes was not yet ready to say whether he would pursue a mental health defense.\n\nHoward Finkelstein, the chief public defender in Broward County, said the case will present a difficult question: Should society execute mentally ill people?\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no question of whether he will be convicted of capital murder 17 times,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen we let one of our children fall off grid, when they are screaming for help in every way, do we have the right to kill them when we could have stopped it?\u201d\n\nSince his mother\u2019s death last year, Mr. Cruz was living with another family, said their attorney.\n\nThe family that took him in, the Sneads, had seen signs of depression in Mr. Cruz, but nothing indicated that he was capable of this kind of violence, Jim Lewis, the family\u2019s attorney, said. The family had allowed Mr. Cruz to bring his gun with him to their house, insisting that he keep it in a lockbox.\n\nMr. Lewis had encouraged Mr. Cruz to attend adult education courses, work toward his G.E.D., and take a job at a local Dollar Tree store, he said in a brief interview. The Sneads\u2019 son, a junior, knew Mr. Cruz from Stoneman Douglas High.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Cruz and the Sneads\u2019 son were texting until 2:18 p.m., Mr. Lewis said \u2014 about five minutes before the first 911 calls about the shooting. \u201cBut there was nothing crazy in the texts,\u201d Mr. Lewis said. Here is our profile on Mr. Cruz.\n\nGino Santorio, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Broward Health, said the hospital where Mr. Cruz was taken, Broward Health North, enacted safety protocols when he arrived on Wednesday.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe staff treated the suspect \u201clike every patient they treat,\u201d Mr. Santorio said.\n\n\u201cWe were able to seclude the patient, treat and get them out without any issues,\u201d he added.\n\nBroward Health North received nine patients, including the suspect, according to Kelly Keys, manager of emergency preparedness for the health system. Two patients died, three remain at the hospital, and three have gone home.\n\nVideo\n\nThe school community urged action from lawmakers, including tougher gun legislation: \u2018We need change.\u2019\n\nStudents and parents in Parkland, an affluent suburb in Florida\u2019s most intensely Democratic county, said a focus from policymakers on treating mental illness was not enough.\n\nLori Alhadeff, whose daughter Alyssa, 14, was killed, made an emotional plea for action.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump, we need action, we need change,\u201d she said, the urgency rising in her voice. \u201cGet these guns out of the hands of these young kids and get these guns off the streets.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf we\u2019re constantly having our children worried about getting shot at, what are we telling our future?\u201d said David Hogg, 17, a senior, who said two of his 14-year-old sister\u2019s friends were killed. \u201cAnd that\u2019s what these people are killing, our future.\u201d\n\nSuperintendent Runcie did not mince words: \u201cNow is the time for the country to have a real conversation on sensible gun controls in this country,\u201d he said.\n\nDemocrats in Congress welcomed a gun control debate. \u201cAt some point, we\u2019ve got to say enough is enough,\u201d Senator Bill Nelson of Florida said on the Senate floor.\n\nBut in an interview on WIBC radio on Thursday, House Speaker Paul Ryan said that public policymakers \u201cshouldn\u2019t just knee-jerk before we even have all the facts and the data.\u201d He added, \u201cWe need to think less about taking sides and fighting each other politically, and just pulling together.\u201d\n\nIn an address to the nation, President Trump announced he would visit Parkland and work with the nation\u2019s governors \u201cto help secure our schools, and tackle the difficult issue of mental health.\u201d But he made no mention of guns.\n\nThe F.B.I. had information about a suspicious comment on YouTube.\n\nBen Bennight, a bail bondsman in Mississippi, said in an interview that he reported a suspicious comment left on his YouTube channel last fall by a user named \u201cnikolas cruz.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going to be a professional school shooter,\u201d the Sept. 24 comment said.\n\nMr. Bennight took a screenshot of the comment and flagged it to YouTube, which removed the post. Mr. Bennight said he then left a voice mail message at his local F.B.I. field office alerting it to the comment.\n\nMr. Bennight, 36, said that when he originally reported the comments to the F.B.I., a pair of agents interviewed him the next morning. Mr. Bennight said two F.B.I. agents visited him a few hours after the shooting on Wednesday, spending about 15 to 20 minutes with him. The agents told him they thought the person who posted on his channel might be connected to the Florida shooting because they had the same name.\n\nVideo\n\nThe F.B.I. on Thursday released a statement that said it received information about a comment made on a YouTube channel in September 2017. \u201cNo other information was included in the comment which would indicate a particular time, location, or the true identity of the person who posted the comment,\u201d the statement said. The F.B.I. said it conducted database reviews and other checks, but was unable to further identify the person who posted the comment.\n\nOn Thursday, Jordan Jereb, a leader of a white supremacist group based in North Florida, told The Associated Press that Mr. Cruz had joined the group, but later Mr. Jereb said that he did not know whether that was true. Sheriff Israel said he could not confirm any ties Mr. Cruz might have had to white nationalists.\n\nThe suspect\u2019s Instagram accounts showed guns and hinted at animal cruelty.\n\nTwo Instagram accounts that classmates said belonged to Mr. Cruz were filled with images of weaponry, as well as the hats and bandannas he liked to wear to school. Among more innocuous pictures of animals, including a dog and a gecko, was a picture of a slaughtered toad. In response to a comment on that image, Mr. Cruz wrote that toads tended to run away when they saw him, because \u201cI killed a lot of them.\u201d\n\nOther posts on the first account, like one captioned \u201carsenal,\u201d showcased collections of firearms, including what appears to be a Savage Axis bolt-action rifle, a Smith and Wesson M&P15-series rifle, and at least two shotguns.\n\nVideo\n\nIt was unclear whether the profile picture for that account, a face nearly entirely covered with a \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d hat and large bandanna, was an image of Mr. Cruz.\n\nThe profile picture for the second account also featured a face almost fully covered, this time with an Army beanie. The account included several pictures of a figure wearing several different Army hats and carrying guns and knives. It also contained a picture of a Google search for the Arabic phrase \u201cAllahu akbar\u201d \u2014 God is great.\n\nInstagram did not immediately reply to a request for comment.\n\n\u2018The shots were something I\u2019ll never forget\u2019\n\nMoises Lobaton, a senior, was in psychology class when gunfire boomed. The students scurried to try to hide as far away from the door as possible.\n\n\u201cThere wasn\u2019t enough space behind the desk, so not all of the kids could fit,\u201d he said.\n\nShots shattered a glass window on the door, injuring at least three of his classmates, including a girl who \u201cwasn\u2019t moving at all.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe was next to a pool of blood, but I couldn\u2019t tell if it was hers or the guy next to hers,\u201d he said. The boy had been shot in the arm and was bleeding profusely. His classmates wrapped the arm in cloth. Another boy called 911.\n\n\u201cThe shots were something I\u2019ll never forget. It sounded like bombs going off, one at a time,\u201d he said. \u201cIf I was one or two feet to the right, I would have died.\u201d\n\nIn New York, two students were arrested after threatening on social media to \u2018gun down\u2019 their Brooklyn high school, police said.\n\nCole Carlberg, 16, turned himself in, and the police picked up Joshua Schechter, 16, after receiving a 911 call at about 9 a.m. on Thursday. Both were charged with making terroristic threats, aggravated harassment and criminal possession of a weapon, a New York police sergeant, Brendan Ryan, said.\n\nOn Wednesday, the teenagers had posted on Snapchat that they had planned to shoot up Brooklyn Prospect Charter School on Fort Hamilton Parkway, Sergeant Ryan said, adding that the school contacted parents about the threat. One of the teenagers had an \u201cair pistol rifle\u201d that Sergeant Ryan described as a pellet or BB gun, but said it was unclear who owned it. \u201cThat\u2019s still under investigation,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Carlberg and Mr. Schechter remained in custody on Thursday night, Sergeant Ryan said.", "title": "Suspect Confessed to Police That He Began Shooting Students \u2018in the Hallways\u2019", "authors": ["Julie Turkewitz", "Patricia Mazzei", "Audra D. S. Burch"]} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "A Lebanese man suspected in the death of a Filipina maid whose body was found stuffed in a freezer in Kuwait has been arrested, the Philippine foreign secretary said on Friday.\n\nThe discovery of the body of the maid, Joanna Demafelis, on Feb. 6 in an apartment in Kuwait City, where it had reportedly been kept for more than a year, spurred outrage and refocused attention on the plight of poor Filipinas toiling as maids abroad.\n\nAlan Peter Cayetano, the foreign secretary, said he had told President Rodrigo Duterte about the arrest in Lebanon of Nader Essam Assaf, but added that Mr. Assaf\u2019s Syrian wife, who is also a suspect in Ms. Demafelis\u2019s death, remains at large. Mr. Assaf and his wife employed Ms. Demafelis as a maid in their home.", "title": "Suspect in Philippine Maid\u2019s Death Arrested in Lebanon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Critics of Poland\u2019s new law say it goes too far. Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson said the legislation \u201cadversely affects freedom of speech,\u201d and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel compared it to a form of Holocaust denial.\n\nTensions flared anew on Saturday when Mr. Netanyahu and Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland both attended a security conference in Munich.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Morawiecki appeared to fumble his defense of the new law while responding to a question from an Israeli reporter about what kind of speech it restricted. \u201cOf course it\u2019s not going to be punishable, not going to be seen as criminal, to say that there were Polish perpetrators, as there were Jewish perpetrators, as there were Russian perpetrators, as there were Ukrainian, not only German perpetrators,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Netanyahu responded quickly, calling the comment \u201coutrageous\u201d in a statement on Saturday. \u201cThere is a problem here of an inability to understand history and a lack of sensitivity to the tragedy of our people,\u201d he said.\n\nThe next day, Reuters reported that the swastika graffiti had been found at the Polish Embassy in Tel Aviv.\n\nAnother statement from Israel on Sunday said Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Morawiecki had spoken by phone and agreed to \u201ccontinue their dialogue,\u201d and a statement from the government of Poland said the prime minister\u2019s comment was \u201cby no means intended to deny the Holocaust, or charge the Jewish victims of the Holocaust with responsibility for what was a Nazi German perpetrated genocide.\u201d\n\nThe tensions come at a tumultuous time for both Israel and Poland.\n\nIsrael experienced heightened clashes along the Gaza border this weekend, and engaged directly with Iranian forces in Syria last weekend. On Tuesday, the Israeli police recommended that Mr. Netanyahu be charged with bribery, fraud and breach of trust.\n\nPoland, which is governed by the right-wing Law and Justice Party, has been criticized for increasingly nationalist policies that have threatened press freedom, judiciary independence and European unity. Mr. Morawiecki became prime minister in December and announced a sweeping cabinet reshuffle last month.", "title": "Swastikas Discovered at Polish Embassy in Israel", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBEIJING \u2014 A Hong Kong-based bookseller with Swedish nationality, snatched from a train to Beijing by the Chinese police last month for undisclosed reasons, resurfaced on Friday to declare in a police-arranged interview that he wanted no help from the outside world.\n\nThe interview between the bookseller, Gui Minhai, and several Hong Kong and Chinese journalists was the latest twist in a case that has generated an international furor, opening a rift between China and Sweden.\n\nMr. Gui, whose business sold gossipy books critical of China\u2019s leaders, was secretly spirited from Thailand to China in 2015 and held for two years, amid diplomatic tensions over his rights.\n\nHe was formally freed last year but ordered to remain in China, where he lived in an apartment in the eastern city of Ningbo. He disappeared again in January, seized from a Beijing-bound train as two Swedish diplomats were accompanying him to the Swedish embassy in the Chinese capital for a medical examination. Mr. Gui has shown symptoms of possible amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also called A.L.S. or Lou Gehrig\u2019s disease, a neurological disorder that degrades muscle actions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Chinese authorities\u2019 handling of Mr. Gui has drawn criticism from Sweden. Foreign Minister Margot Wallstr\u00f6m of Sweden said on Monday that taking him from the train had been a \u201cbrutal intervention\u201d and \u201cChina\u2019s actions were in contravention of basic international rules on consular support.\u201d\n\nBut the Chinese government has become adept at rebuffing criticism of its detentions by parading detainees in televised confessions in which they often abjectly apologize, praise their treatment by the authorities, and tell foreign governments to stay away.", "title": "Swedish Bookseller Held in China Surfaces for Video Apology", "authors": ["Chris Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFRIDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Friday and Saturday puzzles typically don\u2019t have themes, but they do have seed entries, which are the first few entries a constructor will try to place in different sectors of a puzzle grid. These seeds tend to be lively, edgy entries that will make the overall solve more interesting, and they influence how the constructor fills the rest of the puzzle.\n\nIn his notes below, Randolph Ross explains which entries were his seeds and why he used them. WITCH HUNT and BLAME GAME are lively entries even without a political connection, and you can\u2019t say that SEXCAPADE doesn\u2019t just jump out at you. Also, today I learned what a \u201ccranny\u201d is. I\u2019ve used the phrase \u201cnooks and CRANNIES\u201d my entire life, and never really thought about whether they were \u201cNarrow openings\u201d or any different from nooks.\n\nMr. Ross\u2019s Friday puzzle gave me some resistance as a Friday puzzle should, but I ran into a few speed bumps in the form of partials and abbreviations, like A DOSE, ONE B and HGT.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n25A: I had WMD before IED for \u201cIraq War danger, for short.\n\n31A: I had never thought of the word JIVES as a synonym for \u201cTaunts,\u201d but apparently it\u2019s a thing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n32A: Not only is BIS the Latin term for \u201cTwice, musically,\u201d but it is also used in medical prescription instructions. \u201cBIS in die,\u201d or its abbreviation, \u201cb.i.d.,\u201d is used to instruct patients to take a medication twice a day.", "title": "Symbol of Strength", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "GENEVA \u2014 As bombs continued to rain down on the Damascus suburb of eastern Ghouta on Monday, the United Nations secretary general, Ant\u00f3nio Guterres, demanded that the Syria cease-fire resolution that the Security Council adopted unanimously over the weekend take effect immediately.\n\nThe secretary general\u2019s anger was matched by that of his colleague, Zeid Ra\u2019ad al-Hussein, the United Nations\u2019 top human rights official, who pinned responsibility for the prolonged misery in Syria and other conflict zones on the five permanent members of the Security Council.\n\n\u201cSecurity Council resolutions are only meaningful if they are effective,\u201d Mr. Guterres said at the opening of a session of the Human Rights Council in Geneva. \u201cEastern Ghouta cannot wait. It\u2019s high time to stop this hell on earth.\u201d\n\nThe resolution approved on Saturday by the Security Council after days of haggling by permanent members called for a 30-day cease-fire in Syria, but it contained loopholes that allowed intensive bombing and shelling of the beleaguered enclave to continue.", "title": "Syria Cease-Fire Must Take Effect Immediately, U.N. Billy Graham referred to the Scopes \u201cmonkey trial,\u201d so we thought we\u2019d revisit the case.\n\nIt was a turning point in the acceptance of evolution in the U.S.\n\nIn 1925, after Tennessee barred schools from teaching evolution, the American Civil Liberties Union offered to defend anyone who challenged the law. Residents of Dayton convinced a young teacher named John Scopes to do so, in a bid for publicity.\n\nThey got it. The proceedings became a nationally watched showdown between science and religion, each represented by a prominent figure: Clarence Darrow, a lawyer and agnostic, defended Scopes; William Jennings Bryan, a Christian orator, prosecuted him.\n\nDayton officials encouraged the spectacle. They considered moving the trial to a baseball field. A barbecue pit was dug in the courthouse\u2019s lawn. And The Times described a display of \u201ctwo chimpanzees and a strange-appearing man who is called the \u2018missing link.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the trial\u2019s climactic moment, Darrow called Bryan as a witness, grilling him on biblical literalism. Darrow declared that he wanted to keep \u201cbigots and ignoramuses from controlling\u201d education. Bryan retorted that he needed to protect religion from the country\u2019s \u201cgreatest atheist and agnostic.\u201d\n\nIn the end, Scopes was convicted after eight minutes of jury debate and fined $100, a decision later overturned on a technicality. But it was Darrow\u2019s impassioned critique of fundamentalism that won hearts and minds across the country.\n\nJillian Rayfield contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. In researching the Miami River, she became interested in the Everglades and persuaded her publisher to let her write about them instead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Everglades: River of Grass\u201d was published in 1947. An environmental classic, the book changed the way the U.S. viewed its wetlands, as important ecosystems and surge buffers rather than worthless swamps more useful when drained.\n\nBut despite Mrs. Douglas\u2019s warning that \u201cThere are no other Everglades in the world,\u201d development has continued to encroach.\n\nThe school now in the news was named in her honor in 1990, commemorating her 100th birthday. She died eight years later, in the same Miami cottage in which she\u2019d lived since 1926.\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\n\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? A close relative of the squirrel, it digs burrows and can reach a furry 15 pounds. It\u2019s known in some areas as a whistle pig, for its short, sharp cries, but more commonly, as a woodchuck.\n\nThat\u2019s where the day\u2019s simplicities end. The tradition of predicting weather by when animals wake from hibernation goes back centuries. It arrived in the U.S. with European immigrants and \u2014 though there are many Groundhog Day events \u2014 the most celebrated ceremony is in Punxsutawney, Pa.\n\nEach Feb. 2, a groundhog named Punxsutawney Phil emerges from his winter\u2019s nap at a place called Gobbler\u2019s Knob. (In fact, he\u2019s looking for a mate.) Tradition holds that if Phil sees his shadow, it means six more weeks of winter. No shadow, and an early spring is on the way.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s all in fun, of course. And that\u2019s a good thing for the poor groundhog: Since 1887, according to one tally, he\u2019s been right only 39 percent of the time.\n\nCharles McDermid contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Cape Town\u2019s sharp restrictions on water use have helped push back to July the day when taps may run dry, but the South African city remains in a water crisis. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 \u201cHistory is not exactly repeating itself, but it certainly is rhyming.\u201d The struggle between Kenya\u2019s president and the opposition leader is rooted in their fathers\u2019 rivalry. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In Spain, the Supreme Court upheld the conviction of a rapper who argued that freedom of expression allowed for lyrics that praise terrorist groups. The space agency is shifting its focus to the moon. [The New York Times]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.", "title": "Syria, Poland, Winter Olympics: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Airstrikes continued against a rebel-held suburb of Damascus where more than 500 civilians have been killed in the past week.\n\nThere were new reports of a suspected chlorine attack, despite a U.N. Security Council resolution on Saturday that called for a 30-day cease-fire.\n\nOur correspondents examined two phenomena in the regional turmoil: a Russian effort to repatriate women and children from territory held by the crumbling Islamic State, and a push for gender equality that\u2019s swelling in Kurdish-controlled areas.", "title": "Syria, Samsung, Xi Jinping: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 A showdown in Syria: Militias loyal to the government of President Bashar al-Assad reclaimed the northwestern enclave of Afrin, in a setback for the monthlong Turkish assault on Kurdish militias there.\n\nIt was a diplomatic success for Russia, which has maneuvered to forge cooperation between the Syrian government and the Kurds. Meanwhile, at the U.N. Security Council, Russia stalled plans for a cease-fire that would have allowed humanitarian aid to reach the rebel-held enclave of eastern Ghouta.\n\nIn Washington, the White House has decided that it needs no new legal authority from Congress to indefinitely keep U.S. military forces in Syria and Iraq.", "title": "Syria, Winter Olympics, Neanderthals: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Iran, which just witnessed an uprising by its own people, demanding that Tehran spend its money at home, not in Syria, is subcontracting the ground war that Russia subcontracted to Iran to Iran\u2019s proxies \u2014 Hezbollah and various Shiite mercenaries from Iraq, Pakistan and Afghanistan. This way Iran can control Damascus and use Syria as a forward base to put pressure on Israel but pay \u201cwholesale,\u201d not \u201cretail.\u201d\n\nU.S. Special Forces are arming and advising Kurdish fighters from northern Syria to carry out the ground war against ISIS. Turkey is using Sunni rebels to fight the same Kurds. Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Jordan all use various Sunni rebels to fight the pro-Iranian, pro-Shiite regime forces, and Israel is using the long arm of its air force.\n\nIn 2003 I wrote a column in the run-up to the U.S. toppling of Saddam Hussein, which I supported, in which I warned: \u201cThe first rule of any Iraq invasion is the pottery store rule: You break it, you own it. We break Iraq, we own Iraq.\u201d\n\nSo in Syria today, the abiding rule is, \u201cYou own it, you fix it.\u201d And because no one wants to own responsibility for fixing Syria \u2014 a gargantuan project \u2014 they all want to just rent their influence there.\n\nThere is something very 21st century about this war.\n\nBut this is distressing. It means none of the local parties has enough power, resources \u2014 or willingness to compromise \u2014 to stabilize Syria from the bottom up, and none of the external parties is ready to invest enough power and resources to stabilize it from the top down.\n\nThe \u201cgood news,\u201d sort of, is that because everyone is so \u201closs averse\u201d in Syria, it\u2019s less likely that any party will get too reckless. The Iranians and Hezbollah will most likely continue to prod and poke Israel, but not to such a degree that the Israelis do what they are capable of doing, which is to devastate every Hezbollah neighborhood in Lebanon and hit Iran\u2019s homeland with rockets; Israel knows that its high-tech corridor along its coastal plain would be devastated by Iranian rockets coming back.\n\nThe Turks don\u2019t want a war with America. America doesn\u2019t want a war with Russia, and the Russians just want to siphon off as much oil as they can from Syria, and use it as a base and an ego booster, without clashing with anyone \u2014 because they are much weaker than they look.\n\nMaybe, eventually, the players will get tired and forge a power-sharing accord in Syria, as the Lebanese eventually did in 1989 to end their civil war. Alas, though, it took the Lebanese 14 years to come to their senses. So get ready for a lot more news from Syria.", "title": "Opinion | Syria: You Own It, You Fix It, So Just Rent It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Those forces were trying to join Kurdish militias defending Afrin from Turkish troops who crossed the border and were advancing from the north. They retreated after Turkish jets and artillery bombarded them, the Turkish government said.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nThe government\u2019s move to support the Kurds threatened to unravel months of diplomatic efforts by Russia, Turkey and Iran to de-escalate the conflict. It also signaled a new phase of the war with a greater potential for military engagements between other countries with a stake in the outcome, among them Turkey, Iran and the United States.\n\nIn the Ghouta area, Monday was the deadliest day in three years, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a Britain-based war monitoring group. The Union of Medical Care and Relief Organizations put the two-day death toll at 200 or more.\n\nEastern Ghouta, a cluster of concrete-block towns and farmland with an estimated population of nearly 400,000, is one of the last major areas held by insurgents fighting the government of President Bashar al-Assad. Rebels based there periodically shell government-held neighborhoods of Damascus.\n\nAs the government airstrikes have stepped up, so has the rebel shelling. On Tuesday, another 12 people were killed and dozens were wounded.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nFive medical facilities in rebel-held eastern Ghouta were damaged in government attacks overnight, and several medical workers were killed, according to doctors working at hospitals supported by the Syrian American Medical Society.\n\n\u201cSuch targeting of innocent civilians and infrastructure must stop now,\u201d Panos Moumtzis, the United Nations regional humanitarian coordinator for the Syria crisis, said in a statement.\n\nVideo\n\nThe Syrian government and Russia have escalated an aerial campaign to subdue the rebel-held area, which has been besieged for years. And pro-government forces were gathering nearby for a possible ground assault. General Hassan\u2019s video showed military vehicles said to be massing nearby.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nResidents described the events as more like an all-out attack on civilians and infrastructure to force a surrender, a tactic used in previous battles across Syria. The government claims that there are few civilians in eastern Ghouta and that those who remain are being held as human shields.\n\n\u201cWe are still alive, we can\u2019t walk outside the house, even a few meters,\u201d Mr. Dimashqi said.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nReferring to his daughter, whom he calls Loulou, after the 1950s actress Gina Lollobrigida, he said, \u201cI have only this baby, and we can\u2019t find food for her.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe have no other choice except resisting until the last moment,\u201d he said. \u201cDeath and life became equal to me.\u201d\n\nMany in eastern Ghouta have been hiding in shelters. Shadi Jad, the father of a three-week-old, said the infant had not seen the sun or breathed fresh air in 48 hours.\n\n\u201cWe have a small window in our shelter,\u201d he said. \u201cI bring him close to the window just for seconds, to get some warmth from the sunlight.\u201d\n\nWassim Khatib, a resident reached by video chat, said that recent negotiations for hard-line insurgents to leave the area had failed.\n\n\u201cCivilians were never allowed to leave,\u201d he said, looking pale and exhausted. \u201cIf the regime wanted the civilians to be evacuated, they could have announced that or at least dropped leaflets.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUntil last year, tunnels provided a way for goods and people to enter and leave the besieged suburb, but smuggling fees were always high. Movement has become nearly impossible since government forces took over surrounding territory. Roads were opened briefly, but only government employees were allowed to go back and forth, residents said.\n\nThe government-run news agency Sana said that reports of an escalation in eastern Ghouta were \u201clies, deception, and fabrications\u201d used by \u201cterrorist organizations and their sponsors within capital cities conspiring against Syrians.\u201d\n\nMr. Moumtzis of the United Nations called on all parties to \u201cstrictly adhere to their obligations under international humanitarian law to take all feasible measures to protect civilians from harm, including the prohibition on launching of indiscriminate attacks and principles of proportionality and precautions.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe humanitarian situation of civilians in East Ghouta is spiraling out of control,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s imperative to end this senseless human suffering now.\u201d\n\nNo Syrian government forces were involved in the assault on Afrin, but the attack drew a sharp rebuke from Turkey, which fired an artillery barrage at the advancing militia forces. The militias appeared to have halted their advance in the face of Turkish bombardment.\n\nPeople\u2019s militias, a mixture of pro-government tribal volunteers from eastern Syria and Shiite groups from northern Syria supported by Iran, were shown on Syrian state television crossing the administrative border of Afrin. Dozens of vehicles passed, loaded with fighters making victory signs and flying government flags.\n\nOne government supporter filmed what he said were Turkish spotter planes and black plumes of smoke rising in the distance from artillery bombardment.\n\nThe advance by pro-government forces into Afrin came after a Kurdish official announced an agreement had been made for the Syrian government to support the Kurdish militias in Afrin against advancing Turkish forces.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet Turkey seemed to have been surprised by the agreement and the swift advance of the pro-government militias, and fired artillery strikes to stop their advance on Tuesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTurkey\u2019s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, said the government advance on Afrin was halted after he spoke with President Vladimir Putin of Russia by telephone Monday. He also spoke with Iran\u2019s president, Hassan Rouhani. Mr. Erdogan announced that the military operations against Afrin would continue, partly so that hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees in Turkey could return home.\n\n\u201cWe haven\u2019t gone there to burn down what comes in front of us,\u201d Mr. Erdogan said in a speech to his party\u2019s lawmakers at the Parliament. \u201cWe entered there to make it a safe, livable place for those hundreds thousands of people who still live in our country.\u201d\n\n\u201cIn the following days, the siege of Afrin will take place more swiftly,\u201d he added.", "title": "Syrian Bombardment Takes Its Deadliest Toll in Years", "authors": ["Anne Barnard", "Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Turkey mobilized hundreds of C.I.A.-trained Syrian Arab fighters from the opposition Free Syrian Army to spearhead its attack, and bombarded the enclave with jets and artillery fire.\n\nBut Turkish forces have struggled to make headway against the well-prepared Kurdish fighters. In a month of fighting, Turkish forces have lost 32 soldiers. They have taken several dozen villages along the Turkish border, but have yet to reach the main cities.\n\nThe Syrian government has opposed the Turkish action from the start, accusing it of a breach of Syrian sovereignty, but Russia, which controls Syrian airspace, opened airspace to Turkish war planes.\n\nSyrian and Kurdish officials suggested from the start that the Syrian government could move in to help the Kurdish forces.\n\nIbrahim Hamidi, a Syrian journalist for the London-based Arab newspaper Asharq al-Awsat, reported on Wednesday that senior Russian and Syrian government officials met with Saban Hamo, the leader of the Kurdish People\u2019s Protection Units, or Y.P.G., in the city of Aleppo to work out a deal.\n\nThe head of the Syrian government forces\u2019 security committee, Brig. Gen. Malek Alia, attended the meeting along with the head of the Russian Army Reconciliation Center in northern Syria, Mr. Hamidi reported.\n\nIn separate meetings on the opposing side, American and Turkish officials gathered to work out a solution for the town of Manbij, he added. Mr. Erdogan has demanded that Y.P.G. forces also be removed from Manbij, where United States forces have a base and work with the Y.P.G. in its fight against the Islamic State. Mr. Erdogan has threatened to expand the Afrin operation to attack the town, straining United States-Turkish relations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Kurdish militias have welcomed Syrian government support in their fight against Turkish forces but risk losing their autonomy.
