Watch the 12-minute film above. While you watch, you might take notes using our Film Club Double-Entry Journal (PDF) to help you remember specific moments.\n\n2. After watching, think about these questions:\n\n\u2022 What moments in this film stood out for you? Why?\n\n\u2022 Were there any surprises? Anything that challenged what you know \u2014 or thought you knew?\n\n\u2022 What messages, emotions or ideas will you take away from this film? Why?\n\n\u2022 What questions do you still have?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n3. Next, join the conversation by clicking on the comment button and posting in the box that opens on the right. (Students 13 and older are invited to comment, although teachers of younger students are welcome to post what their students have to say.)", "title": "Teaching With: \u2018Black Colleges in the Age of Trump\u2019", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Film Club"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "In this short documentary, \u201cSinking Islands, Floating Nation,\u201d a filmmaker and visual anthropologist follows Anote Tong, former president of the Republic of Kiribati, as he travels the world to ring the alarm about climate change\u2019s dire consequences for his nation. Rising sea levels are forcing Kiribati to make difficult choices.\n\nStudents\n\n1. Watch the seven-minute film above. While you watch, you might take notes using our Film Club Double-Entry Journal (PDF) to help you remember specific moments.\n\n2. After watching, think about these questions:\n\n\u2022 What moments in this film stood out for you? Why?\n\n\u2022 Were there any surprises? Anything that challenged what you know \u2014 or thought you knew?\n\n\u2022 What messages, emotions or ideas will you take away from this film? Why?\n\n\u2022 What questions do you still have?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n3. Next, join the conversation by clicking on the comment button and posting in the box that opens on the right. (Students 13 and older are invited to comment, although teachers of younger students are welcome to post what their students have to say.)", "title": "Teaching With: \u2018Sinking Islands, Floating Nation\u2019", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Film Club"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Note: We would like to hear from teachers who use Film Club as part of their curriculum, such as the teacher from Apopka, Florida who has been bringing her (or his?) class regularly. Please email us at LNFeedback@nytimes.com \u2014 we hope to share your teaching ideas about this feature on The Learning Network.\n\n_________\n\nThis short documentary, The Bionic Man, is the third episode in a Bits video series called Robotica, examining how robots are poised to change the way we do business and conduct our daily lives. The film features Les Baugh, who lost his arms as a teenager. Engineers at Johns Hopkins are trying to give them back, but better. Mr. Baugh is testing a robotic prosthetic that he can control with his mind.\n\nStudents\n\n1. Watch the eight-minute film above. While you watch, you might take notes using our Film Club Double-Entry Journal (PDF) to help you remember specific moments.\n\n2. After watching, think about these questions:\n\n\u2022 What moments in this film stood out for you? Why?\n\n\u2022 Were there any surprises? Anything that challenged what you know \u2014 or thought you knew?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 What messages, emotions or ideas will you take away from this film? Why?\n\n\u2022 What questions do you still have?", "title": "Teaching With: \u2018The Bionic Man\u2019", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Film Club"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Then assign students to watch an Olympic event on TV and describe a dramatic sports moment in detail, paying close attention to word choice, sentence structure and tone.\n\nFor fun, you can ask students to remove any references to the actual name of the sport in their descriptions, and then have them read their sports moment aloud. The rest of the class should listen carefully and try to name the Olympic event.\n\n_________\n\n2. Global Politics\n\nVideo\n\nIn \u201cHow South Korea Left the North Behind,\u201d The Times explores how the two countries have diverged in the last 30 years:\n\nIn 1988, the last time South Korea hosted the Olympics, North and South Korea were more alike than different, separated by an arbitrary line yet joined by history, language and the bonds of family. Both Koreas had come a long way, emerging from colonial rule and rebuilding their economies after a devastating civil war. But the Olympics in Seoul in 1988 ended up being a turning point. Over the past 30 years, the two countries have diverged sharply \u2014 economically, politically and culturally.\n\nTensions on the Korean Peninsula have sharply escalated recently, with North Korea firing a ballistic missile over Japan and threatening to launch missiles into waters near Guam, and President Trump mocking the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, as \u201cRocket Man,\u201d and Mr. Kim responding by calling Mr. Trump a \u201cmentally deranged U.S. dotard.\u201d\n\nBut then the Olympics approached, and suddenly the tone seems to have changed. Athletes from North and South Korea will march under one flag; the two countries will field a joint women\u2019s hockey team; and a North Korean pop orchestra will stage performances in South Korea during the Games. Do the 2018 Winter Olympics offer a real chance to ease political and nuclear tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula?\n\nHave students watch the video \u201dCan the Olympics Bring the Koreas Together?\u201d and read the related article. Then have students argue, in writing or discussion: Will the 2018 Winter Olympics be a turning point in relations between North Korea and South Korea? Are these latest overtures of cooperation and civility the beginning of a new chapter? Can sports actually promote peace? Or is something else going on?\n\n_________\n\n3. Design and Fashion\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Olympics are more than just an athletic competition; they are a fashion runway as well, especially during the opening and closing ceremonies. In her Nov. 2 On the Runway column, Vanessa Friedman wrote in anticipation of this year\u2019s Games:\n\nThe 100-day countdown to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, may have just begun, but the race to the fashion finish line among the various teams is well underway.\n\nShe continued:\n\nThus far, the leader seems to be ... sportswear! That may sound ridiculous, but fashion has become so much a part of recent Olympics (in the same way fashion has attempted to send its tentacles into pretty much every part of designed life), that the out-of-competition clothing that athletes wear, and even some of the in-competition stuff, has increasingly started to seem like basic runway merch. A list of the designer brands that have played wardrobe coach includes Stella McCartney, Giorgio Armani, Lacoste and Prada, to name a few. But this year, it\u2019s as if, in the weird circular way of fashion, sports clothing, which has been exerting its own influence in ateliers and on catwalks for the last few seasons in the form of streetwear and athleisure, has now effectively changed that game enough so that when designers move to the Olympics, their actual sportswear looks again like sportswear. Roll your eyes if you want to. It\u2019s true.\n\nHave students read the entire column \u2014 especially so they can consider how \u201cone of the biggest challenges of designing for the Olympics is balancing national pride and technical needs.\u201d Then, ask students to watch an event at the Olympics, such as the opening ceremony or men\u2019s curling (this 2010 video provides some context), from a fashion critic\u2019s point of view. They should choose one country\u2019s outfits \u2014 perhaps their favorite or the most interesting \u2014 and describe the clothing in writing.\n\nThen, assign students to propose a new clothing design for a country, perhaps for the 2020 Summer Games in Tokyo or the 2022 Winter Games in Beijing. They should draw a sketch and write a description.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlternatively, they can design a unified Korean team logo for the North Korean and South Korean athletes who will march together under one flag, or a logo for Russian athletes who will compete under a neutral flag as an Olympic AthleteFrom Russia, or OAR. They can submit their designs to The Times by Feb. 9, and some designs may get published.\n\n_________\n\n4. Geography\n\nPhoto\n\nOver 90 countries are taking part in the 2018 Winter Olympics, and that means students can explore geography while watching their favorite sports. Have students select a participating country, research that country\u2019s performance in previous Winter Games and keep track of the up-to-date 2018 medal count. They can also read relevant news articles by selecting their country from the pull-down menu on the Pyeongchang 2018 Game News page. For additional context, students could research their country\u2019s history, culture and geography and how they might affect its performance in the Winter Games. At the end of the Olympics, students can present an overview of their country\u2019s performance at the Games and what they learned.\n\nTo turn this research into a competition with other students around the world, the class can participate in Fan School\u2019s Olympics challenge. For this challenge, students must make predictions by the end of the opening ceremony on Feb. 9 about medal counts as well as news coverage in The Times. To help make their predictions, students can use this interactive displaying medal results at the Winter Games from 1924 to 2014.\n\n_________\n\n5. Physics\n\nPhoto\n\nHave students use the language of physics to describe what is taking place in various Olympic events. To help them deconstruct athletic feats like the quadruple jump in figure skating or the backside double-cork 1080 in snowboard slopestyle, students can use Times interactives that slow down and narrate the action in the following sports:\n\nFigure skating (augmented reality)\n\nGiant slalom\n\nHalfpipe snowboarding\n\nIce hockey (augmented reality)\n\nLuge\n\nShort-track speedskating and Short track (augmented reality)\n\nSki jumping\n\nSnowboard slopestyle and Slopestyle (augmented reality)\n\nMake sure they use relevant academic vocabulary they have studied in class, such as kinetic energy, angular momentum, friction and aerodynamics.\n\nTo continue exploring physics, visit our 2010 lesson plan \u201cGetting Physical: The Physics and Other Science Behind Winter Olympic Sports.\u201d\n\n_________\n\n6. Argument Writing and Discussion\n\nPhoto\n\nAny event that brings together delegations from over 90 countries for two weeks is bound to stir up some controversies and questions. Teachers can use these issues as prompts for argument writing and discussion before, during and after the Olympics. Each prompt includes a link to a related Times article. Note: The list below is just a starting place, since certainly more issues will arise before the Games are completed.\n\n1. Did the International Olympic Committee make the right decision in banning Russia from competing in the 2018 Winter Olympics because of state-backed doping during the 2014 Sochi Games? Did it make the right decision in allowing Russian athletes who can prove they are \u201cclean\u201d to compete under a neutral flag?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n2. Did the National Hockey League make the right decision not to hold a three-week break during its season to allow players to participate in the Winter Games, as they did in 2014?\n\n3. Did North and South Korean politicians make the right decision in deciding to field a joint women\u2019s hockey team for the sake of \u201ca grand gesture of sports diplomacy\u201d? Is the decision unfair to the individual players who have worked hard to get to the Olympics, yet might lose playing time or be benched for some games?\n\n4. How anxious should the world be about holding the 2018 Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea, \u201cin the shadow of a nuclear standoff\u201d and just 50 miles from the world\u2019s most heavily fortified border? Should participating countries hesitate to send their delegations because of North Korea\u2019s recent nuclear and ICBM tests? Should visitors be reluctant to attend the Games this year?\n\n_________\n\n7. South Korea\n\nPhoto\n\nAsk students: How much do you know about South Korea? They can do a quick-write and pair-share.\n\nThen, have them take our Country of the Week quiz, which tests students on their map skills, along with their geography and culture knowledge.\n\nNext, invite students to plan a last-minute trip to the Winter Games in Pyeongchang. They can use this Times guide to figure out logistics for a visit to the Olympics. And have them tack on extra vacation time after the Games to experience more of South Korea. They can use the Times Travel section, the internet and guidebooks to do their planning.\n\nThe final product can be a written day-by-day itinerary, including location, activities and highlights, plus a travel map. Here\u2019s an example of a possible entry:\n\nDay 10\n\nLocation: Busan, South Korea\n\nActivities: Jagalchi market, Busan Sea Life Aquarium, Dongbaekseom Park and Haeundae Beach\n\nDay\u2019s Highlight: Wander the stalls and fish tanks at the Jagalchi market to see rows and rows of seafood caught fresh that morning. Buy a fish, then head upstairs to one of the small restaurants to have it cooked \u2014 and eat it with chopsticks!", "title": "Teaching the Winter Olympics Across the Curriculum, With Help From The New York Times", "authors": ["Michael Gonchar"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI didn\u2019t expect tonight to be as competitive as it was,\u201d said Team LeBron Coach Dwane Casey, who normally presides over the Raptors.\n\nAn overwrought pregame show hosted by the actor and comedian Kevin Hart fell flat \u2014 and reviews of the singer Fergie\u2019s rendition of the national anthem were even worse \u2014 so the occasion was by no means perfect. Yet there is undeniable momentum for the N.B.A. to carry this new format into next year\u2019s game. And factoring in what is sure to be a near-unanimous push to televise the roster selections for the 2019 game only increases the chances for a highly watchable event, one in which Michael Jordan\u2019s Charlotte Hornets will be serving as hosts.\n\n\u201cI thought tonight was a great first step going forward,\u201d Casey said.\n\nThe night was also a victory for a group of players who made a notable contribution of their own to the N.B.A.\u2019s midseason festival. James was the tone-setting force in the game and deservedly won his third All-Star Most Valuable Player Award with 29 points, 10 rebounds and 8 assists in 31 minutes. But you also couldn\u2019t miss the sheer number of players on the floor representing countries other than the United States.\n\nThe Knicks\u2019 Kristaps Porzingis (Latvia) was forced to miss his first All-Star appearance because of his recent season-ending knee injury, but Joel Embiid (Cameroon) and Goran Dragic (Slovenia) made their All-Star debuts without him. Additionally, Giannis Antetokounmpo (Greece) made his second consecutive All-Star start and was joined on Team Stephen by two representatives of the Dominican Republic: Al Horford and Karl-Anthony Towns.\n\nPhoto\n\nYou can stretch this concept even further by noting that Kyrie Irving is Australian-born.\n\nThe N.B.A., mind you, has so far shown a willingness to implement a United States vs. Rest of the World template only for its Rising Stars game, which features first- and second-year players. Resistance in some corners to taking the idea any further would be understandable in a league with well over 300 players born in the United States and only 24 All-Star spots to compete for as it is.\n\nYet it is also true that, in his four-year tenure as N.B.A. commissioner, Adam Silver has been continually receptive to new ideas. It\u2019s tantalizing, then, to wonder if the notion of a U.S.A./World format for the actual All-Star Game will someday get serious consideration.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDon\u2019t forget that Nikola Jokic (Serbia) and Ben Simmons (Australia) were also All-Star contenders this season. Or that Marc Gasol (Spain) has already made three career All-Star appearances. Or that the Chicago rookie Lauri Markkanen (Finland) is increasingly regarded as future All-Star material, with at least two highly coveted foreign-born players \u2014 Luka Doncic (Dragic\u2019s Slovenian countryman) and DeAndre Ayton (Bahamas) \u2014 widely expected to be top-five selections in the June draft.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re getting there,\u201d said Steve Nash, who was born in South Africa, grew up in Canada and is now a part-time coaching consultant with the Golden State Warriors after retiring from the N.B.A. in 2015 with two M.V.P. trophies. \u201cIt\u2019s a natural and welcome evolution of the game.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the general manager of the men\u2019s national-team program in Canada, Nash is likewise well aware that R.J. Barrett \u2014 the son of Nash\u2019s former Canadian teammate, Rowan Barrett \u2014 is widely regarded as a top contender to be selected No. 1 over all in the 2019 draft. That would be just five years removed from June 2014, when another Canadian, Andrew Wiggins, was drafted No. 1.\n\nSpeaking specifically about the likes of Antetokounmpo, Embiid and Porzingis, Nash said: \u201cIn five years, two or three of these guys might be top-10 players in this league.\u201d\n\nBy the time Nash ascended to an All-Star level in Dallas alongside Germany\u2019s Dirk Nowitzki, there were a number of top players born outside the borders of the United States, including Nowitzki, Pau Gasol (Spain), Yao Ming (China), Tony Parker (France) and Manu Ginobili (Argentina). But Nash, who on Saturday received a Class of 2018 Basketball Hall of Fame nomination, couldn\u2019t bring himself to buy into suggestions back then that a Rest of the World contingent could credibly take on the American-born All-Stars.\n\nNow, Nash feels differently.\n\n\u201cMaybe in 2022 \u2014 30 years after the Barcelona Olympics and how the first Dream Team grew the game internationally \u2014 maybe that\u2019s the time to try it,\u201d Nash said. \u201cWe might be ready for World vs. U.S.A. in 2022. And that would obviously bring some life back to the All-Star Game if we\u2019re still struggling to find some.\u201d\n\nIn large part due to how engaged James was on Sunday night and the example he set, sufficient life was restored to the All-Star Game to allow time for more contemplation and discussion. And more juice may be pumped into next year\u2019s contest if the two captains indeed end up on live TV selecting their 22 All-Star colleagues, at midcourt before tipoff, in true schoolyard style.\n\nYou know what they say, though: It\u2019s always good to have options.", "title": "Team Lebron vs. Team Steph Wasn\u2019t Bad. But How About U.S. vs. the World?", "authors": ["Marc Stein", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "MINNEAPOLIS \u2014 Practically the entire population of Minnesota was functioning on about four hours of sleep on Thursday. And happy to be doing so.\n\nThis is the land where hockey rules, curling is coming up fast on the outside and cross-country skiing claims a prized niche in the state\u2019s Scandinavian heritage.\n\nFrom Warroad, the little town near the Canadian border with a lengthy Olympic hockey heritage, to the Twin Cities and farther south, lights stayed on well into Thursday morning as the United States women\u2019s hockey team, with seven Minnesotans on the roster, beat Canada, 3-2, in a shootout for the gold medal to end 20 years of Olympic frustration.\n\n\u201cWe probably woke up the neighbors about 1:30 or 2 o\u2019clock,\u201d said Mark Manney, who coached goaltender Maddie Rooney on the Andover High School boys\u2019 team.", "title": "Team U.S.A.? More Like Team Minnesota", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 For all the optimism, innovation and wealth that are produced here, the Bay Area can also feel like a place that doesn\u2019t work quite right.\n\nThe cost of housing has priced out teachers and line cooks. Income inequality is among the widest in the nation. The homeless crisis never seems to ebb. Traffic is a mess. On bad days, transit is, too. And local governments are locked in conflict.\n\nClearly, the region has not been optimized.\n\n\u201cIt could be so much better,\u201d said Ben Huh, who moved to San Francisco in 2016 after running the Cheezburger blog empire in Seattle. \u201cThere\u2019s so much wealth. There\u2019s so much opportunity.\u201d\n\nIn the maddening gap between how this place functions and how inventors and engineers here think it should, many have become enamored with the same idea: What if the people who build circuits and social networks could build cities, too? Wholly new places, designed from scratch and freed from broken policies.", "title": "Tech Envisions the Ultimate Start-Up: An Entire City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Computer science programs are required to make sure students have an understanding of ethical issues related to computing in order to be accredited by ABET, a global accreditation group for university science and engineering programs. Some computer science departments have folded the topic into a broader class, and others have stand-alone courses.\n\nBut until recently, ethics did not seem relevant to many students.\n\n\u201cCompared to transportation or doctors, your daily interaction with physical harm or death or pain is a lot less if you are writing software for apps,\u201d said Joi Ito, director of the M.I.T. Media Lab.\n\nOne reason that universities are pushing tech ethics now is the popularization of powerful tools like machine learning \u2014 computer algorithms that can autonomously learn tasks by analyzing large amounts of data. Because such tools could ultimately alter human society, universities are rushing to help students understand the potential consequences, said Mr. Ito, who is co-teaching the Harvard-M.I.T. ethics course.\n\n\u201cAs we start to see things, like autonomous vehicles, that clearly have the ability to save people but also cause harm, I think that people are scrambling to build a system of ethics,\u201d he said. (Mr. Ito is a director of The New York Times Company.)\n\nLast fall, Cornell University introduced a data science course where students learned to deal with ethical challenges \u2014 such as biased data sets that include too few lower-income households to be representative of the general population. Students also debated the use of algorithms to help automate life-changing decisions like hiring or college admissions.\n\n\u201cIt was really focused on trying to help them understand what in their everyday practice as a data scientist they are likely to confront, and to help them think through those challenges more systematically,\u201d said Solon Barocas, an assistant professor in information science who taught the course.", "title": "Tech\u2019s Ethical \u2018Dark Side\u2019: Harvard, Stanford and Others Want to Address It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTreat Teenage Moms Like Moms,\u201d by Tracey A. Wilkinson, Brownsyne Tucker Edmonds and Aaron E. Carroll (Op-Ed, Feb. 14):\n\nThat parents of underage moms in labor can deny their daughters an epidural is astonishing.\n\nHere in New York, it is mandatory to offer pain relief to laboring women if they feel they\u2019re experiencing pain; denying a suffering patient analgesia is considered akin to insisting on pulling out wisdom teeth without any anesthesia.\n\nThat this can happen in our country today is a jolting reminder that much still needs to be done to fix glaring inequities and injustices.\n\nSure, there are women who choose to experience labor without medical intervention, but that should obviously be their decision no matter their age.\n\nI myself would risk civil penalties and order an epidural for a young patient who needs one \u2014 regardless of what her abusive parents want. Otherwise, I\u2019m a party to their child abuse.", "title": "Opinion | Teenage Moms in Labor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "After their arrest, Ms. Geyser and Ms. Weier said they had stabbed Payton Leutner because they wanted to please Slender Man, a fictional character generally depicted as a tall, shadowy figure with a blank face. They said they believed that Slender Man was real and lived in a mansion in the woods in northern Wisconsin, and that by killing Ms. Leutner, they would become his \u201cproxies.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, Ms. Geyser spoke briefly at her sentencing hearing and began crying as she apologized to Ms. Leutner, referring to her by a nickname.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI just want to let Bella and her family know I\u2019m sorry,\u201d she said. \u201cI never meant this to happen. And I hope that she\u2019s doing well.\u201d\n\nThe crime happened more than three years ago, when Ms. Geyser, Ms. Weier and Ms. Leutner were sixth graders at Horning Middle School in Waukesha. In May 2014, Ms. Geyser and Ms. Weier lured Ms. Leutner into the woods, where Ms. Geyser stabbed her 19 times with a kitchen knife as Ms. Weier urged her on.\n\n\u201cAnissa told her to lie down so she wouldn\u2019t lose blood so quickly, and told her to be quiet,\u201d Ms. Geyser told Judge Bohren, her voice trembling. \u201cAnd we left.\u201d\n\nMs. Leutner managed to crawl out of the woods and find an adult. Over the course of several months, she recovered from her injuries and was able to return to school. But doctors said one of the stab wounds had come within a millimeter of an artery whose breach would have killed her.\n\n\u201cIf the knife had gone the width of a human hair further, she wouldn\u2019t have lived,\u201d Dr. John Kelemen, a thoracic and cardiac surgeon who operated on her, told ABC News at the time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a letter to the judge read in court in December at Ms. Weier\u2019s sentencing, Ms. Leutner\u2019s mother said her daughter would \u201cstruggle with the events of that day and physical and emotional scars it left for the rest of her life.\u201d\n\nAnthony D. Cotton, a lawyer for Ms. Geyser, said in a phone interview on Thursday that the sentence was expected. Under Wisconsin law, he noted, commitments to psychiatric facilities can be terminated early if the patient is compliant, so it can make sense for a judge to \u201cimpose a larger number and evaluate as time goes on.\u201d\n\nMr. Cotton said Ms. Geyser\u2019s lawyers intended to petition for her release regularly, \u201cas long as Morgan continues to do well.\u201d He said the team had not yet decided whether to appeal the sentence.\n\n\u201cAs long as she takes her medication and follows her orders, she\u2019s certainly well enough to be in a less restrictive setting than inpatient commitment,\u201d he said. \u201cThere are services available in a more therapeutic, less restrictive environment that she should be able to take advantage of.\u201d", "title": "Teenager in \u2018Slender Man\u2019 Stabbing Gets 40 Years in Mental Hospital", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "As Flow of Foreign Students Wanes, U.S. Universities Feel the Sting\n\nColleges have cut programs amid a drop in international enrollment tied to several factors, including more restrictive immigration policies.\n\nNo College Kid Needs a Water Park to Study\n\nTrustees must rein in frivolous spending at public universities.\n\nFraternity Is Banned From Pennsylvania After Student\u2019s Hazing Death\n\nA Baruch College freshman died after taking part in a fraternity hazing, and the fraternity was convicted of aggravated assault and involuntary manslaughter.\n\nPhoto\n\nMore College Students Seem to Be Majoring in Perfectionism\n\nNew data indicates that perfectionism, especially when influenced by social media, has increased by 33 percent since 1989.\n\nOnline Courses Are Harming the Students Who Need the Most Help\n\nOnline education helps school districts that need to save money make do with fewer teachers. But for every dollar they earned, Grady would turn around and spend 50, a lot of it on cocaine. We ended up fleeing with our tail between our legs to San Antonio, where my dad had to get another job and basically reinvent himself.\n\nImage Bryan Mealer Credit Wyatt McSpadden\n\nI thought of writing it as a novel at one time. I was trying to figure out what I was going to do next. My grandmother died in 2011, and it was a really moving experience for me. I flew down to Big Spring and we all gathered around her bed. She was a wonderful gospel singer, had grown up singing in the church. One of her last requests when we were all around her in the hospice was for us all to sing. And we did. I wanted to find the source of what I felt in the room, call it the Holy Ghost or whatever. It was a power.\n\nWhat\u2019s the most surprising thing you learned while writing it?\n\nThat poor people don\u2019t leave paper trails, unless they\u2019re criminals. Early in my research I was really hitting a wall. All I had was census records and occasional documents I would pull from county clerks\u2019 offices: property deeds and whatnot; but nothing really firsthand to drive a narrative. Then through Ancestry.com, of all places, I found out I had a cousin Frances in Arizona who was in her 90s, and she had a diamond-sharp memory. She basically took me through the Depression. Her dad \u2014 my grandfather\u2019s brother \u2014 died of dust pneumonia in 1936. Frances\u2019 mother had a nervous breakdown. The family bought food by selling cardboard. They warmed their house by burning tires they found in the road. It was tough living.\n\nFinding her was journalist gold. And now she\u2019s one of my best friends; and a big Trump supporter, so we go back and forth on that.\n\nIn what way is the book you wrote different from the book you set out to write?\n\nI had this idea of structuring it like \u201cAll the King\u2019s Men,\u201d where Grady was the Willie Stark character and he pulled around this group of pilot fish with him. My editor didn\u2019t think Grady could carry the book. He urged me to dig into my family history, which I\u2019d never done and it turns out no one in my family had ever done. I ended up going back to find my great-grandfather and how he came west from Georgia to find adventure and riches. Like so many others, what he found instead was reality and hardship. He lost his farm to drought in 1916. His wife died of Spanish flu while they were uprooted and living on the road. During the first oil boom, when the Permian field was just opening up, that\u2019s what my family did, worked in oil. I went in to tell the story of Grady and this brief period in Texas, and came out with this multigenerational story about America.", "title": "Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: A Texas Oil Boom Fuels a Family Saga", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "When \u201cAngels in America\u201d premiered on Broadway in 1993, The New York Times\u2019s Frank Rich called it \u201cthe most thrilling American play in years.\u201d Tony Kushner\u2019s two-part epic about American life, set against the AIDS crisis and Ronald Reagan\u2019s presidency, quickly became, by consensus, one of the 20th century\u2019s most essential works of theater. (The play is coming back to New York, at the Neil Simon Theater, beginning previews this month and opening in March.) In 2016, Slate published an oral history of the show, in which Mr. Kushner and more than 50 others talked about the production\u2019s long and often difficult road to success. Now the authors of that history \u2014 Isaac Butler, a theater director himself, and Dan Kois, an editor and writer for Slate \u2014 have published a new book that expands on it: \u201cThe World Only Spins Forward: The Ascent of \u2018Angels in America.\u2019\u201d The book covers the development and life of the play, as well as Mike Nichols\u2019s adaptation of it as a mini-series for HBO in 2003. Below, Butler and Kois talk about the influence of the political climate on their book, a film adaptation of \u201cAngels\u201d that never came to pass and more.\n\nWhen did you first get the idea to write this book?\n\nDAN KOIS Isaac and I were conducting interviews for the Slate story in spring 2016. We kept getting so much amazing stuff. Every single person we talked to would tell us the kind of story you tell about the defining artistic and intellectual moment of your life. No one was like, \u201cOh yeah, it was great. I don\u2019t remember much about it.\u201d One week, we each interviewed members of the original cast. I interviewed Kathleen Chalfant \u2026\n\nISAAC BUTLER and I interviewed Ellen McLaughlin. And at some point in that interview \u2014 which was 2 \u00bd hours long; not what I thought it was going to be \u2014 Ellen said, \u201cYou might not have realized this yet, but you\u2019re actually working on a book.\u201d I told Dan, \u201cEllen said this very charming thing on our phone call.\u201d And Dan said, \u201cChalfant said the same thing to me.\u201d As in many things, Ellen and Kathy were right.\n\nKOIS Both of us, in our late teens or early 20s, came out of \u201cAngels in America\u201d transformed politically and artistically. I had always assumed, and heard thirdhand, that it had an appropriately epic origin story \u2014 technical drama and legal drama and angels falling from the sky. And that seemed like a story that ought to be told.", "title": "Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: An Oral History of \u2018Angels in America\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s the most surprising thing you learned while writing it?\n\nI knew that people were brave. But once I started asking them for their stories in details, I was surprised by just how many risks they took. And when I spoke to their family members, they received threats and had themselves been wrapped up in this and terribly impacted. Yet they had never tried to get them to stop doing their work. In fact, Mar\u00eda Victoria, Iv\u00e1n\u2019s wife, kept some very serious threats made against her secret because she didn\u2019t want him to give up what he was doing. She knew it would break him because it was such an important part of who he was, to follow through on his commitment.\n\nImage Maria McFarland S\u00e1nchez-Moreno Credit George Baier IV\n\nWith Calder\u00f3n, I didn\u2019t realize the sort of risks he had taken. I knew him as a journalist, and I knew he had exposed these scandals and efforts to smear Vel\u00e1squez. I didn\u2019t realize just how intrepid he was because he was just so humble. Years later, I found out he had actually been abducted by his sources in the intelligence service at one point. They thought he was going to betray them and they needed to know if he was being straight with them. They gave him this drug to tell the truth and he lost consciousness overnight. He just kept going with his work; met with them the next day and they apologized.\n\nIn what way is the book you wrote different from the book you set out to write?\n\nI started out with a very important story about one man who led these investigations and was attacked and then prevailed. It turned into a much richer story when I brought in these other characters and dug into the history. Once I had a broader scope and more characters, I could trace the arc of how the paramilitaries grew and what they were, and how they were able to gain so much power and influence and develop all these connections, in a way I wouldn\u2019t have been able to do if the book had been about one set of investigations.\n\nWho is a creative person (not a writer) who has influenced you and your work?\n\nPhotojournalists, in general, who have worked in some of these conflicts. One of them is Stephen Ferry, with whom I worked very closely in Colombia. He captured the humanity and all sorts of nuances of the reality of Colombia in ways that aren\u2019t usually presented in journalism and in the policy world. Seeing someone who\u2019s able to capture those deeper aspects of reality made me also want to do that.\n\nAnother piece that made an impression on me while I was writing the book was Joshua Oppenheimer\u2019s movie \u201cThe Look of Silence,\u201d a sequel to \u201cThe Act of Killing.\u201d He\u2019s able to show what it means for people to live with a legacy of mass atrocity while the perpetrators are still in power, and in a way that\u2019s what was happening in Colombia while I was there.\n\nPersuade someone to read \u201cThere Are No Dead Here\u201d in 50 words or less.\n\nIt\u2019s a fast-paced true story, something of a thriller. It introduces you to brutality and corruption in a country at the center of the United States\u2019 war on drugs. It also offers hope that brave, committed people who care about what\u2019s right can make a difference.", "title": "Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Fighting Terror and Corruption in Colombia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s the most surprising thing you learned while writing it?\n\nImage George Dohrmann Credit Adam Moore\n\nI talked to Susan Harter, a renowned child psychologist, about how kids receive their parents\u2019 fandom. She told me that we shouldn\u2019t be introducing our kids to fandom until adolescence. This runs contrary to what we do. We put a baby in a Green Bay Packers onesie. This is what we see all the time, and we celebrate it, posting pictures of it and saying how cute it is. But a kid I wrote about, an Eagles fan, was just melting down in YouTube videos while the Patriots were beating his team.\n\nHarter said kids want to see the world in black and white. They want to divide the world into good and bad. And sports does that. But the kids don\u2019t understand that the fact that their teacher is an Auburn fan doesn\u2019t make them a bad person. They don\u2019t understand that daddy\u2019s going to be O.K. when his team loses. They lack perspective. They can\u2019t say, \u201cWell, it\u2019s been a good season even though we lost this game.\u201d\n\nSometimes now I watch a game outside the home so my kids don\u2019t see me yelling at the TV and see that it\u2019s important to me. I don\u2019t want them to make it important right now.\n\nIn what way is the book you wrote different from the book you set out to write?\n\nInitially I wanted to have more fan-athlete engagement in the book, more opportunities for athletes to confront the fans who often say critical things about them. I thought that would make for good reading. And I did reach out to some athletes, but ultimately I concluded that part of fandom \u2014 \u201cblazing\u201d is what they call it, that troll behavior \u2014 while it exists, it felt like falling into a trap, just looking at the worst of fans. There is some bad behavior in the book, but it felt too voyeuristic to keep highlighting these really extreme negative fans.\n\nWho is a creative person (not a writer) who has influenced you and your work?\n\nFor a long time, my favorite U.S. national team player was Clint Dempsey. I liked him because he was successful, but I loved how he was successful, and why. I loved that he grew up poor, and had to go outside the traditional soccer development system. He wasn\u2019t put on the conveyor belt to greatness. That\u2019s inspiring, someone who works outside the system and still gets to the top of it. He would take risks on the field. It was like he was saying, \u201cI\u2019m going to try for greatness, and I might look foolish sometimes, and it might not work out, but I\u2019m going to shoot for greatness here.\u201d That was something to love and admire about him, and something that anyone can bring into their own work. We have to take shots here.", "title": "Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Inside the Fevered Minds of Sports Fans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Given all the attention paid to \u201cMade in Italy\u201d over the last few years, it seems almost wishful to posit style as an expression of nationality.\n\nST But postwar Italian fashion was something very specific. From its beginnings, Italian fashion benefited from a very integrated system, starting with the fabrics and continuing to the designers and manufacturers.\n\nWouldn\u2019t the same have been true of, say, France?\n\nST When you think about the American or the French systems, they didn\u2019t have that organization, from designing fabrics to distribution. Often the fabrics they used were imported from Italy. A lot of French fabrics and even products were made in Italy.\n\nWhy was that?\n\nST It was the high quality of the products and at an affordable price. After the war, during the \u201950s and \u201960s, Italy was full of very low-cost workers. Many had inherited family traditions of craftsmanship. The idea we had with this show was to demonstrate both the qualities and also the shortcomings of the Italian fashion system.\n\nIf traditions of quality craft were the positive, what was the negative?\n\nST There was an overall lack of managerial experience, a lack of coordination. Some of it was the fault of the government, which didn\u2019t invest in infrastructure or education to bring Italian fashion to a level where it could compete with what was happening in other countries. But, where the government failed, Italian ingenuity stepped in. When you ask what Italian fashion was in that period, you could characterize it by saying Italy produced clothes of great quality at an affordable price. There was an incredible versatility in times of change \u2014 the fact, say, that small Italian fashion companies could shift direction every six months, alter the kinds of product they were putting out.", "title": "Telling Italy\u2019s Story Through Its Clothes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 A bitter struggle between a Trump Organization hotel business and the owners of the Panama City hotel that carries the Trump name escalated on Monday when the Panamanian authorities announced that they had begun a formal investigation into the dispute.\n\nThe country\u2019s Public Ministry said in a brief statement that it was looking into whether there had been any \u201cpunishable conduct\u201d in the matter. The decision came in response to a complaint filed with the ministry on Friday accusing Trump executives of illegal \u201cencroachment\u201d on the property, the ministry\u2019s statement said.\n\nThe owners association has been trying for months to dump President Trump\u2019s company, which manages the property, the Trump International Hotel and Tower, blaming the Trump company and brand for declining revenues.\n\nThe Trump Organization\u2019s involvement in the hotel began well before the property officially opened in 2011. But Orestes Fintiklis, a Miami-based investor whose firm bought a majority of the hotel\u2019s units last year, has led the charge to drive it out. The owners association voted last year to end its relationship with the Trump company, and the sides entered into arbitration in October.", "title": "Tempers Flare as Panama Hotel Owners Try to Oust Trump Company", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "THE ENDLESS SUMMER\n\nA Requiem\n\nBy Madame Nielsen\n\nTranslated by Gaye Kynoch\n\n148 pp. Open Letter Books. Paper, $14.95.\n\nSOME NOVELS are dense as lead, their every line, character and event heavy with import. Others belie their weighty payloads with a veil-like fluttering, shunning complex characters and precise details in favor of less fixable quantities like mood, movement and texture. The Danish author Madame Nielsen\u2019s debut in English translation, \u201cThe Endless Summer,\u201d is very much in the latter category, telling the story of a family that indulges in life\u2019s lightness, ultimately paying the price for ignoring the weight of being.\n\nNielsen is many things \u2014 a musician, actor, playwright and performance artist who has journeyed to Iran and who walked with refugees all the way from the Balkans to Denmark. But she is probably best known for declaring her birth-identity, Claus Beck-Nielsen, dead in 2001 and producing work under a series of names that culminated in \u201cMadame Nielsen\u201d in 2014. This change involved a switch from male to female dress and gender pronouns, although readers coming to \u201cThe Endless Summer\u201d expecting a dissection of transgender themes will be disappointed. This is not a criticism of the novel \u2014 clearly Nielsen has no intention of foregrounding gender in this particular work. It\u2019s a reminder that in an era profuse with identity politics, authors like Nielsen will remain interested in many different things.\n\nImage\n\nIf gender is mainly absent from \u201cThe Endless Summer,\u201d the questions that do occupy it include vagabondage, romanticism, sexuality, art and what the author calls \u201clife\u2019s unfurling as destiny and tale.\u201d The book begins with a Danish patriarch who comes into a large inheritance and moves his wife, stepdaughter and four sons into an enormous estate. He unfortunately then falls into a depression when he is overcome by both his wife\u2019s infidelity and the upkeep on the new property (which is far beyond his capacities or income). So he disappears into the night.", "title": "Tempting Fate With a Season of Romance, Sex, Art and Destiny", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "In court papers filed on Friday, prosecutors described how Mr. Parker set the Nov. 17 fire. He entered the building with a red gas can and rode the elevator to the sixth floor, where he lived with his father and mother. Mr. Parker then doused one of the rooms with gas and lit it on fire before running down the stairs and leaving the building, all in 20 minutes. His exit from his parents\u2019 smoke-filled apartment was captured on surveillance video, the authorities said.\n\nAs the fire continued to spread, Mr. Parker went to a bus station and boarded a bus to North Carolina, where his sister, who lives there, picked him up, according to court documents.\n\nThe fire drew over 250 firefighters and emergency workers to the scene and displaced more than 30 families, most of them immigrants from the Dominican Republic. Mr. Parker was unaccounted for immediately after the fire, which led firefighters to sift through the rubble of his apartment, fearing he was dead.\n\nBut investigators tracked him down in North Carolina and interviewed him over the phone the day after the fire.\n\nIn a series of interviews that day, Mr. Parker told investigators that he had left the building to buy cigarettes across the street and minutes later saw smoke coming from the window of his apartment.\n\n\u201cI had incense burning in the apartment, but I put it out,\u201d Mr. Parker told investigators. \u201cI did not make any mistakes that would cause the fire.\u201d\n\nHe also said that, on the day of the fire, three people from Harlem Hospital Center came to visit his apartment at his mother\u2019s insistence, according to court documents.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI felt like they were stalking me,\u201d Mr. Parker said. \u201cI had no incidents for three months. No massive arguments with my mother.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Parker told investigators the incident that day left him rattled, and added that he was upset with his mother.\n\nThe authorities said Mr. Parker left North Carolina for California, where he was arrested after the Los Angeles Police Department encountered him. Officers determined that an arrest warrant had been issued for Mr. Parker in New York (though it had been placed under seal and thus was not public).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
