View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRam\u00f3n Ortiz, a tenant who lived in the apartment beneath Mr. Parker\u2019s, said Mr. Parker suffered from schizophrenia. Mr. Parker\u2019s father told Mr. Ortiz about his son\u2019s condition after Mr. Ortiz complained about a series of loud banging noises coming from the Parker apartment early one morning.\n\nMr. Ortiz, who lived in the apartment building for 20 years, said Mr. Parker grew up in the building with his parents.\n\n\u201cThey were a very decent family,\u201d Mr. Ortiz said. \u201cBut there were times that those sounds from upstairs wouldn\u2019t let me sleep, and I had to confront them.\u201d\n\nMr. Parker\u2019s mother apologized for the noises, and Mr. Parker\u2019s father later confided in Mr. Ortiz that their son had mental health problems.\n\nMr. Ortiz said Mr. Parker was often admitted to hospitals for long stretches of time. He would return, \u201clooking super well and rehabilitated.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe would see me in the elevator and joyfully ask me, \u2018Hey, do you remember me?\u2019\u201d Mr. Ortiz said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout eight months ago, Mr. Ortiz said he saw officers arresting Mr. Parker in the building lobby.\n\nMr. Parker looked agitated, Mr. Ortiz recalled, as the officers tried to calm Mr. Parker after he had a heated discussion with his parents. Mr. Ortiz said he told the police about Mr. Parker\u2019s mental health problems before they handcuffed Mr. Parker and took him away.\n\nIn one of his telephone interviews with investigators after the fire, Mr. Parker said he had stood outside watching the fire and left once firefighters arrived, according to court documents.\n\n\u201cSo I just went to the bus station because my mother or father were not home so I just left,\u201d Mr. Parker told investigators. \u201cI got on the bus at 8:30 p.m. I didn\u2019t have a phone. I didn\u2019t take anything with me.\u201d\n\nThen, according to the court papers, he volunteered his innocence:\n\n\u201cDude, it was most likely an arsonist. I wasn\u2019t the arsonist.\u201d", "title": "Tenant Used Gas to Start Upper Manhattan Fire, Prosecutors Say", "authors": ["Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhile we work closely with C.C.O.P., we refuse to limit resident engagement to one group because all tenants deserve to have input,\u201d Ms. Blake said in a statement.\n\nThe lawsuit is the latest blow to the authority, which is already under pressure to improve living conditions for its residents even as the federal government cuts funding.\n\nThe United States attorney\u2019s office is examining safety issues, including elevated lead levels in tenants; the public advocate, Letitia James, announced an investigation into the lead paint problems in November; and a special master is overseeing the authority\u2019s handling of mold.\n\nThree authority officials, including the general manager, Michael P. Kelly, have resigned, and one was demoted. There are persistent calls for the authority chairwoman, Shola Olatoye, to resign or be removed, though Mayor Bill de Blasio has remained supportive of her.\n\n\u201cLots of different of organizations have sued Nycha, but this is a first,\u201d Nicholas Dagen Bloom, an associate professor of social science at New York Institute of Technology and the author of \u201cPublic Housing That Worked: New York in the 20th Century,\u201d said about the lawsuit. \u201cIt does show a mounting, spreading activist spirit. Generally speaking, that council was a rubber stamp and it has been widely criticized for decades, though not always fairly.\u201d\n\nJim Walden, a lawyer for the Citywide Council of Presidents, called the lawsuit a \u201cwatershed moment\u201d created by a group of tenants who felt it was the only way the residents\u2019 concerns would be addressed.\n\n\u201cWe have a mayor that ran on the tale of two cities and he\u2019s forgotten the largest community in New York City, which also happens to be the neediest,\u201d Mr. Walden said. \u201cIf Nycha does not clean up its act and comply with the law, then there\u2019s the possibility that executives from Nycha will be held in contempt of court.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nResidents of the authority\u2019s 326 developments have a right to organize tenant associations. Each association is in one of nine districts. The leaders of the associations vote on a president from each district to represent them on the citywide council, which then chooses its own president.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Barber-Walker became president of the council in January. Standing inside his 15th-floor apartment, he recited from memory the federal housing codes and city rules and regulations that he believes the authority has violated in his own four-bedroom railroad apartment \u2014 including the need for a paint job in his kitchen and the mold that used to line his bathroom wall and ceiling.\n\n\u201cIf this was any other section of the city, residents wouldn\u2019t be treated this way,\u201d he said. \u201cNycha residents just want to be treated like any other resident.\u201d\n\nThe lawsuit charges that the authority failed to comply with federal and state law by not conducting timely lead paint inspections, even failing to notify residents when the potentially hazardous paint was found in their apartments. The authority has also failed to provide its tenants with heat and hot water. Between Oct. 1, 2017, and Jan. 22, 143,000 apartments were without heat and hot water for an average of 48 hours, authority officials said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFederal regulations require the authority and its contractors to hire Nycha residents, low-income people or individuals receiving housing assistance. The law also applies to businesses owned by people from those groups or who hire people from those groups.\n\nIn 2016, the authority was supposed to award 10 percent of the $150 million in capital fund construction contracts to businesses who hired people who lived in Nycha buildings, were low-income or received housing assistance. Only 0.4 percent, or $60,857, of contracts awarded fit that specification. Three percent of $66 million in nonconstruction contracts was supposed to be awarded to people and businesses in those categories, a total of $1.98 million, but less than 1 percent, $634,670, was awarded, according to authority records.\n\nThe suit also says that the authority \u201cmakes unilateral decisions on virtually every important policy matter,\u201d and does not consult tenant leaders or residents. Federal regulations require that \u201cresidents shall be involved and participate in the overall policy development and direction of Public Housing operations.\u201d Authority meetings with its tenants are usually held to announce policy decisions, according to the lawsuit.\n\nIf the city followed the rules and fixed the problems, the authority \u201ccould be a model of how to treat people equally and fairly,\u201d Mr. Walden said.\n\nAn independent monitor is not necessarily the solution to the authority\u2019s problems, Mr. Bloom said. The authority needs a significant financial investment, he added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think anyone will remember pre-K or any of the progressive stuff de Blasio did if he allows Nycha to continue its decline,\u201d Mr. Bloom said.\n\nAn appearance by Mr. Barber-Walker in the lobby of his building means handshakes, hugs and kisses from residents he has helped. Almost everyone who passes calls out \u201cDanny\u201d before stopping to talk about one thing or another.\n\n\u201cFor me to sit here and keep hearing the complaints from the mothers and the grandmothers and not do anything, I am just as guilty as Nycha,\u201d Mr. Barber-Walker said.\n\nBut after spending 18 years on public housing tenant organizations, this suit is also personal. He said the recently removed mold in his bathroom exacerbated his mother\u2019s breathing problems. And now that she is gone, Mr. Barber-Walker is the guardian of his brother, Kenneth Massey, 29, who has seizures, cerebral palsy, scoliosis, arthritis and is blind and partially deaf.\n\nMr. Massey is in near constant pain and the cold adds to his discomfort, Mr. Barber-Walker said. During the recent cold snap, Mr. Massey had no heat in his room for eight days, his brother said.\n\n\u201cWhen you get tired of something, enough is enough,\u201d Mr. Barber-Walker said. \u201cWe are here to tell everyone today that enough is enough and we are not taking it any longer.\u201d", "title": "Tenants Sue New York City Housing Authority: \u2018We Have Let Other People Speak for Us for Too Long\u2019", "authors": ["Jeffery C. Mays"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "These productions are mostly represented here on paper, via rough drafts, scripts, programs, notebooks, correspondence and sketches for sets. In other words, the living flux that is theater is reduced to two dimensions.\n\nLook closer, though, at the framed pages on display, and a fraught and excited dialogue surfaces, reminding us that what is now archival was once trembling potential. Penciled notations on the rough drafts show a writer still sculpting and shaving material that, in its finished form, has acquired the solidity of sacred texts in a canon.\n\nBut how fungible they once were, names and characters and stories still swirling before settling into the shapes of posterity, and how different they might have been. The typewritten text for a late addition to \u201cThe Glass Menagerie,\u201d its concluding scene, offers that much-quoted benediction from its narrator, Tom, to his sister: \u201cBlow out your candles, Laura.\u201d\n\nThose are not, however, the play\u2019s last words. They are \u201cAnd so, goodbye.\u201d And we can see here that this curtain-closing farewell has been penciled in, not by Williams, but by the producer of the original production of \u201cMenagerie,\u201d Margo Jones.\n\nSequential versions of what would become \u201cStreetcar\u201d are on display across a long wall. One draft (dated 1945-46) is titled \u201cThe Passion of a Moth,\u201d and instructions, in the author\u2019s hand on the upper right corner of the title page, read, \u201cTypist \u2014 please change \u2018Ralph\u2019 to \u2018Stanley\u2019 whenever found in script.\u201d The Blanche character appears as \u201cGladys\u201d in a precursor to \u201cStreetcar\u201d called \u201cInterior: Panic,\u201d a title that speaks volumes about both the character\u2019s and her creator\u2019s states of mind.\n\nThere\u2019s chatter \u2014 frenzied and buoyant, discouraged and exultant \u2014 in these changes, which suggest endless exchanges among a writer and early readers. You have the chance to examine, side by side, the four \u2014 count them, four \u2014 alternative endings that Williams proposed to the director Elia Kazan for \u201cCat on a Hot Tin Roof,\u201d each of which slants the play toward slightly different degrees of optimism, cynicism and resignation.\n\nWilliams\u2019s steamroller mother, Edwina, and his delicate sister, Rose \u2014 whom with the playwright made up the quarrelsome tribe of fantasists that inspired \u201cMenagerie\u201d \u2014 are represented here by snapshots that look as if they had been freshly unglued from the pages of a family scrapbook. The presence of his adored Rose, who would spend her life in mental institutions after being given a prefrontal lobotomy, feels especially vivid.", "title": "Tennessee Williams, Restless and Revising", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "On Tuesday, Elon Musk had a Tesla Roadster launched toward an orbit around the sun. A day later, he and his car company came back to earth.\n\nThe electric-car maker said Wednesday that it lost more than three-quarters of a billion dollars in the fourth quarter as it scrambled to root out glitches from its manufacturing operations and ramp up production of its highly anticipated Model 3 sedan.\n\nIn a conference call with analysts, Mr. Musk, the chief executive, acknowledged that Tesla still faced challenges in putting the Model 3 into mass production. \u201cWe were in a deeper level of hell than we expected, still a few levels deeper than we would like to be,\u201d he said.\n\nThe company reported a quarterly net loss of $771 million, more than tripling the loss it reported for the same period a year earlier. Revenue increased 44 percent to $3.3 billion, on rising sales of its Model S luxury sedan and Model X, a sport-utility vehicle.", "title": "Tesla Model 3, Elon Musk\u2019s Grail, Remains a Costly Pursuit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Alex and Maia Shibutani of the United States, who are brother and sister, gave a stirring performance to the Coldplay song \u201cParadise,\u201d and took the bronze medal with 192.59 points. They finished just ahead of teammates Madison Hubbell and Zachary Donohue, who took third in the short program but slipped to fourth over all after the free dance as the Shibutanis rose to the medal podium.\n\n\u201cIt feels like gold,\u201d Alex Shibutani said.\n\nThe gold and silver medal performances were \u201ctwo of the best free dances I\u2019ve ever seen,\u201d said Jackie Wong, a skating analyst from New York. \u201cThe energy in the crowd was so different simply because of the types of programs they were skating. Tessa and Scott were much more projecting out to the crowd, whereas Gabby and Guillaume were more insular, inward programs.\u201d\n\nThe reaction of the spectators most likely made little difference in the judges\u2019 scores, Wong said, \u201cbut I\u2019m sure Tessa and Scott fed off the energy of the crowd. When they do that, that\u2019s when they bring out that great performance.\u201d", "title": "Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir Are Ice Dancing\u2019s King and Queen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Goshua had always been fascinated with how the brain and the nervous system worked, and it seemed possible that this profound weakness was not a reaction to how ill he had been but evidence that he was still sick. He hoped that the physical exam, often discounted by doctors and patients alike in these days of high-tech testing, could help him figure out what was going on. Goshua had been taught to start his exam with the hands and then to work inward to the rest of the body. He picked up the man\u2019s right hand; the arm hung limply against the bed. He held the man\u2019s middle finger and flicked the nail down. As the fingertip snapped up, the right thumb jerked toward the index finger. He did it again, and again the thumb leapt toward the index finger, as if to make, paradoxically, an A-O.K. sign. The patient had a positive Hoffman\u2019s sign.\n\nA Simple Test\n\nThis reflex test, developed by the 19th-century neurologist Johann Hoffman, indicates a problem in the nerves that emerge from the brain to make up the spinal cord in the neck. It is a test that medical students still learn but rarely use, in part because the pathology it detects is rare, and in part because the test, like so much of the physical exam, is not terribly reliable on its own. When positive, as it was here, the problem is actually present only 60 percent of the time. Still, it was a clue. Was there any other evidence that a problem in the spinal cord was causing the weakness? Goshua tapped the right knee to elicit the usual kick reflex. If the patient was just weak from illness, his kick should have been normal or even reduced. Instead it was so brisk that the left leg jerked a little, too.\n\nEmergency Surgery\n\nGoshua knew that it was essential that the patient quickly get an M.R.I. of his neck that night. The scan indicated that the same infection that had already been carried to his brain, his kidneys and his swollen right foot was also raging in the bones of his neck right where it met the shoulders and inside the spine, impinging on and compressing the spinal cord.\n\nThe man\u2019s wife was sitting at her husband\u2019s bedside after the test when her mobile phone rang. Her husband needed to go to surgery right away, she was told. If they didn\u2019t operate immediately, he would never regain his strength. Indeed, it might already be too late.\n\nIt was past 3 in the morning when the surgeon carefully cut away the infected bone and the abscess compressing the man\u2019s spine, but it would be weeks or months before they would know if they had gotten there in time.\n\nLooking for the Source\n\nAs the man recovered, he and his wife wondered where the initial infection came from. When the patient first arrived at the hospital, it was noted that he had a healing sore on his left hand next to his thumbnail. His wife remembered that it was filled with pus and looked awful. Her husband applied what he called \u201cblack salve\u201d \u2014 a pine-tar-based ointment used in medicine since the time of the ancient Greeks. It reduces inflammation and pain. But it did not treat the infection, which spread from his thumb throughout his body to his brain, his ankle and his spine.\n\nThe patient needed six weeks of antibiotics to get the bug completely out of his system. It took much longer for the rest of him to recover. When he came home after five months of intensive rehab, he still couldn\u2019t walk. But he never gave up. And slowly, slowly, he got better. Two years later he can walk without a cane. And he\u2019s back at work \u2014 with his builder, and around the house.\n\nAs for Goshua, who cared for the patient just that one time, the amazing recovery felt like proof that the physical exam, even today, remains an essential tool.", "title": "Tests Indicated His Infection Was Getting Better. Why Did He Feel Worse?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "In a soliloquy, the speech is kept private from the other characters in the play, and, although the audience is privy to the character\u2019s thoughts, the character is talking to him or herself alone. Soliloquies can create dramatic irony, because the audience is made aware of thoughts and events that the other characters in the play are not.\n\n\u201cHamlet\u201d has captured the imaginations of audiences for four centuries. It is Shakespeare\u2019s most performed play around the world \u2014 and, of course, one of the most-taught works of literature in high school and college classrooms. In fact, Hamlet\u2019s \u201cTo be or not to be\u201d speech is the best-known soliloquy in the world.\n\n\u201cLes Mis\u00e9rables\u201d is Victor Hugo\u2019s 1862 historical classic about Jean Valjean, imprisoned for 19 years for stealing a loaf of bread, and his life of compassion and contribution after his release. The novel has been adapted countless times for film, television, radio, musicals, plays and concerts.\n\nThe French stage musical by Claude-Michel Schonberg premiered in Paris in 1980. French lyrics for the musical were written by Alain Boublil and Jean-Marc Natel, and English lyrics were written by Herbert Kretzmer. The musical is the longest-running show in London, and the second longest-running musical in the world (after \u201cThe Fantasticks\u201d). The stage musical inspired the most recent film version \u2014 the popular 2012 film directed by Tom Hooper and starring Anne Hathaway, Russell Crowe and Hugh Jackman.\n\nIn the soliloquies we pair here, Hamlet and Jean Valjean are each at a crossroads in their lives, and each wrestles mightily with his conscience. Both characters seek moral clarity, both struggle with existential questions, and both argue with themselves in an effort to come to some realization. At the end of each speech, each character is closer to a path forward.\n\nTo work with the two texts, you might first discuss the conventions, requirements and standards of a soliloquy, and, using this video, compare them to a monologue and an \u201caside.\u201d Ask students, what different conditions within the play might cause a playwright to use a soliloquy, a monologue or an aside? Are they interchangeable? Why or why not?\n\nStudents might also view \u2014 or act out themselves \u2014 different interpretations of the \u201cTo be or not to be\u201d speech. They can begin with the video of Laurence Olivier embedded at the top of this lesson, then view this video of five actors giving different interpretations. (And, possibly, an additional one, here). Which is their favorite? Why? How would they compare the actors\u2019 deliveries? How can different readings change the meaning of a soliloquy? What examples can they give?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFinally, as they watch and read the two speeches together, you might ask students to think about how Hamlet and Jean Valjean think about the following questions: What happens after death? What is the best way to live, or die, morally, in the eyes of God? Is it better to act or to remain inactive? Is existence worth the pain? Where does a man\u2019s responsibility to himself, and to others, begin and end?\n\n\n\nThe outcomes for Hamlet and Jean Valjean are different, but for each, his soliloquy expresses a pivotal moment in determining how to live the rest of his life.\n\n_________\n\nKey Questions\n\n\u2022 How do soliloquies work as a literary device to illuminate characters and themes?\n\n\u2022 What do these two soliloquies in particular reveal about the characters speaking them and the themes of the works they are from as a whole?\n\n_________\n\nActivity Sheets\n\nAs students read and discuss, they might take notes using one or more of the three graphic organizers (PDFs) we have created for our Text to Text feature, which matches often-taught texts with Times articles and other content.\n\n\u2022 Comparing Two or More Texts\n\n\u2022 Double-Entry Chart for Close Reading\n\n\u2022 Document Analysis Questions\n\n_________\n\nText One: HAMLET SOLILOQUY ACT 3, SCENE 1\n\nPhoto\n\nTo be, or not to be: that is the question:\n\nWhether \u2019tis nobler in the mind to suffer\n\nThe slings and arrows of outrageous fortune\n\nOr to take arms against a sea of troubles,\n\nAnd by opposing end them?\u2014To die,\u2014to sleep,\u2014\n\nNo more; and by a sleep to say we end\n\nThe heartache, and the thousand natural shocks\n\nThat flesh is heir to,\u2014\u2019tis a consummation\n\nDevoutly to be wish\u2019d. To die,\u2014to sleep;\u2014\n\nTo sleep: perchance to dream:\u2014ay, there\u2019s the rub;\n\nFor in that sleep of death what dreams may come,\n\nWhen we have shuffled off this mortal coil,\n\nMust give us pause: there\u2019s the respect\n\nThat makes calamity of so long life;\n\nFor who would bear the whips and scorns of time,\n\nThe oppressor\u2019s wrong, the proud man\u2019s contumely,\n\nThe pangs of despis\u2019d love, the law\u2019s delay,\n\nThe insolence of office, and the spurns\n\nThat patient merit of the unworthy takes,\n\nWhen he himself might his quietus make\n\nWith a bare bodkin? who would these fardels bear,\n\nTo grunt and sweat under a weary life,\n\nBut that the dread of something after death,\u2014\n\nThe undiscover\u2019d country, from whose bourn\n\nNo traveller returns,\u2014puzzles the will,\n\nAnd makes us rather bear those ills we have\n\nThan fly to others that we know not of?\n\nThus conscience does make cowards of us all;\n\nAnd thus the native hue of resolution\n\nIs sicklied o\u2019er with the pale cast of thought;\n\nAnd enterprises of great pith and moment,\n\nWith this regard, their currents turn awry,\n\nAnd lose the name of action.\n\n_________\n\nText Two: Anatomy of a Scene: Les Mis\u00e9rables\n\nVideo\n\nWhat have I done,\n\nSweet Jesus, what have I done?\n\nBecome a thief in the night\n\nBecome a dog on the run\n\nAnd have I fallen so far\n\nAnd as the hour so late\n\nThat nothing remains but the cry of my hate\n\nThe cries in the dark that nobody hears\n\nHere where I stand at the turning of the years\n\nIf there\u2019s another way to go\n\nI missed it twenty long years ago\n\nMy life was a war that could never be won\n\nThey gave me a number and they murdered Valjean\n\nWhen they chained me and left me for dead\n\nJust for stealing a mouthful of bread\n\nYet why did I allow this man\n\nto touch my soul and teach me love?\n\nHe treated me like any other\n\nHe gave me his trust\n\nHe called me brother\n\nMy life he claims for God above\n\nCan such things be\n\nFor I had come to hate the world\n\nThis world that always hated me\n\nTake an eye for an eye\n\nTurn your heart into stone\n\nThis is all I have lived for\n\nThis is all I have known\n\nOne word from and I\u2019d be back\n\nbeneath the lash, upon the rack\n\nInstead he offers me my freedom\n\nI feel my shame inside me like a knife\n\nHe told me that I have a soul\n\nHow does he know\n\nWhat spirit comes to move my life\n\nIs there another way to go\n\nI am reaching, but I fall\n\nand the night is closing in\n\nAs I stare into the void\n\nto the whirlpool of my sin\n\nI\u2019ll escape now from that world\n\nFrom the world of Jean Valjean\n\nJean Valjean is nothing now\n\nAnother story must begin!\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_________\n\nQuestions for Writing and Discussion\n\n1. What is the rhetorical question Hamlet addresses in his soliloquy? What is the rhetorical question Jean Valjean addresses? What are the inner arguments each character wrestles with, and why?\n\n2. How is each soliloquy both a rant and a reflection? What emotions are revealed by Hamlet? By Jean Valjean? How do they change within the soliloquy?\n\n3. How does each soliloquy move from the general to the specific, from the abstract to the concrete, and back again?\n\n4. How \u2014 and where \u2014 do the authors weave figurative language, from imagery to hyperbole, metaphor, allusions, simile, symbolism, irony and puns, into their soliloquies? How do those literary devices seem to help the character understand himself more clearly, as he speaks aloud?\n\n5. How do shifts in tone for both Hamlet and Jean Valjean help make meaning for the audience? Where do those shifts in tone occur for each soliloquy?\n\n6. How do Hamlet and Jean Valjean each reach an increased self awareness, and then a resolution of sorts, by the end of their speeches? How does each man arrive at his decision \u2014 or at his acceptance of indecision?\n\n7. To what extent is the presentation itself important when considering the effectiveness of the two soliloquies? Does a soliloquy that is sung, in the case of Jean Valjean in this adaptation of \u201cLes Mis\u00e9rables,\u201d add or detract from that meaning, and how? Could Hamlet\u2019s soliloquy be sung, or be staged in another way? How?\n\n_________\n\nGoing Further\n\nMemorize a Monologue or Soliloquy...\n\nPhoto\n\nIn \u201cMemorize That Poem!\u201d Molly Worthen argues that, though \u201cpoetry memorization has become deeply unfashionable,\u201d memorizing and reciting can be \u201chighly expressive\u201d acts. Her piece begins:\n\nLate one night this spring, Justin Snider, an assistant dean at Columbia University, was riding the uptown No. 2 in Manhattan when the train ground to a halt. After about 15 minutes \u2014 with little information about the delay and no cell service \u2014 everyone in the car was getting restless. Suddenly, inspiration struck. \u201cI asked neighboring passengers if they wanted to hear some Shakespeare, and no one objected,\u201d Mr. Snider told me. He had memorized Hamlet\u2019s \u201cTo be or not to be\u201d speech more than 15 years earlier, to pass the time on a cross-country bike trip. \u201cI was definitely nervous because I\u2019d never performed publicly before,\u201d he said. Although his jaded audience neglected to clap when he finished \u2014 they did applaud when the train started to move again \u2014 Mr. Snider was pleased that he didn\u2019t forget a line. The soliloquy was fixed in the architecture of his brain, ready to serve in a moment of boredom or underground anxiety. It\u2019s no coincidence that Mr. Snider has asked students to memorize poetry many times in his career in education.\n\nHave students read the article and then memorize the soliloquy or monologue of their choice. Then, debrief the class on the experience: How difficult was it for them to memorize? What benefits did they find? For instance, did they feel it helped them understand the text or character better? How? What did they begin to notice about the language and ideas?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_________\n\n...and Then Perform It\n\nVideo\n\nIn 2013, The New York Times asked high school and college students to use Instagram to record short videos of lines from Shakespeare\u2019s tale of royal intrigue and revenge, and nearly 500 seized the opportunity. This piece calls out some of the most interesting results.\n\nMany teachers use performance as a way to get students to connect with and embody the text. After your students have memorized a monologue or soliloquy, invite them to get the words \u201con their feet\u201d by staging a monologue slam patterned after the one described in the short news clip above.\n\n\n\nTo learn more, have them read this article about the competition and how it got started:\n\n\n\nAspiring actors are accustomed to having doors slammed in their faces, but lately in a modest club in the East Village, a few have been doing some slamming of their own. At a frenetic monthly competition called the Manhattan Monologue Slam, performers looking for that fabled big break, or even a small break, are squaring off against one another in a flurry of three-minute monologues, with a casting director or other industry professional sitting as judge. First prize is a one-on-one meeting with that judge for career input \u2014 the kind of meeting many struggling actors can only fantasize about. The slam, patterned after a poetry slam and with the same mutually supportive, raucous atmosphere, is the creation of Robert and Philip Galinsky, brothers who know the struggling-Village-actor life from firsthand experience. \u201cWe were sitting in my living room one afternoon, thinking about how could we control our destiny and not just be another actor trying to get the head shot onto somebody\u2019s desk,\u201d Robert Galinsky, 40, said, recalling how the first slam came about in April 2003. \u201cAfter we brainstormed a little bit, we came up with, \u2018Hey, let\u2019s do the structure of a poetry slam, but do it for actors with monologues.\u2019 And that was it.\u201d\n\nHow can you stage your own monologue/soliloquy slam? Can other classes in your school get involved? Could your drama department help students prepare?\n\n__________\n\n\u201dLes Mis\u00e9rables\u201d Adapted\n\n\u201cRarely has any work of literature received such a pummeling at the hands of a succession of publishers, translators, filmmakers and musical impresarios,\u201d writes The Times about \u201cLes Mis\u00e9rables\u201d in a review of a book about the life of this classic work. Though the review argues that \u201cperhaps the most damaging deformation belongs to the all-conquering stage musical \u2018Les Miz,\u2019\u201d it is likely that it is through that musical that students know the work best.\n\nFor an in-depth look at the novel\u2019s transformation to a Broadway musical, have students read this 1987 Times review by Frank Rich. He acknowledges that:\n\nThe evening may not appeal to those enraptured by the 1,300-page edition of Hugo. The musical thinks nothing of condensing chapters of exposition or philosophical debate into a single quatrain or unambiguous confrontation; encyclopedic digressions and whole episodes are thrown out.\n\nBut, he argues, \u201cWhile facts and psychological nuances are lost and even the plot is often relegated to a program synopsis, the thematic spirit of the original is preserved. Sequence after sequence speaks of Hugo\u2019s compassion for society\u2019s outcasts and his faith in God\u2019s offer of redemption.\u201d And he ends his review, \u201cThe stirring sentiments belong to hallowed 19th-century literature, to be sure, but the fresh charge generated by this \u2018Miserables\u2019 has everything to do with the electrifying showmanship of the 20th-century musical.\u201d\n\nWhat do your students think? If they have read the novel and seen the musical or any of the films, what do they think of the adaptations? What, in their opinion, is essential to preserve across adaptations about the original? Why?\n\nEven if your students have not read the book, they may enjoy watching some of the musical. Here is Philip Quast, playing the policeman Javert, in a video from the musical\u2019s 10th anniversary. To extend their study of the soliloquy, have them read the lyrics of his song \u201cStars,\u201d and consider as they watch and read: Does Javert\u2019s song fit the criteria of a formal soliloquy? Why or why not?\n\nWhat does Javert reveal, and what is he certain of at the end of his speech? To what extent is his inner character revealed to the audience, and to himself, by the end of the song? To what extent does Javert wrestle with the same questions of death, life, suicide, revenge and vengeance that Jean Valjean does in his soliloquy? How does each character justify or base his actions on his personal version of morality, and why?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_________\n\nWrite Your Own Soliloquies\n\nHave students try their hands at writing a soliloquy themselves, taking care to include all the formal elements.\n\nThey might choose to write one from the point of view of a character in a book or play they have read, studied and discussed. Or, students could write this speech from the point of view of someone currently in the news, whether a political figure, an actor or an athlete.\n\nYou might set requirements like these:\n\nYour soliloquies must:\n\n\u2022 be written in first person\n\n\u2022 be written in unrhymed or blank verse\n\n\u2022 begin with a rhetorical question\n\n\u2022 incorporate at least three poetic or literary devices\n\nStudents should remember they are writing something intended to be spoken, so should try to hear the words as they write.\n\nThe soliloquy can be written factually, using the explicit conditions, events, characters and plot of the book and character they have selected, or the real-life figure they have chosen. Or, the soliloquy can be inferential, even fabricated. It can address something that is not explicitly stated in a text \u2014 or, in the case of a real-life figure, something that hasn\u2019t happened in real life but that students can infer from actual events, plot, characters or tone.\n\nAfter writing, students should read their soliloquies to the class and have classmates guess who is speaking, and what play, film, novel or political figure was selected. Students can critique one another\u2019s work in small groups, and then make revisions based on classmates\u2019 suggestions.\n\n_________\n\nConsider the Monologues of Late Night Hosts as Mentor Texts\n\nAmong other Times coverage, the \u201cBest of Late Night\u201d by Giovanni Russonello reports on late night talk show hosts and their monologues. Have students compare and contrast several of the monologuists below, and decide which person \u2014 and which specific speech \u2014 is most persuasive, funny, or effective \u2014 and why.\n\nAsk students, \u201cHow does the monologuist turn the personal into the political, and what does that strategy do for the monologue?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey can start with The Times\u2019s coverage of Jimmy Kimmel\u2019s emotional monologue about his new son\u2019s heart condition, or his monologue on gun laws, which begins:\n\n\u201cThis morning, we have children without parents and fathers without sons, mothers without daughters. We lost two police officers. We lost a nurse from Tennessee. A special-ed teacher from a local school here in Manhattan Beach. It\u2019s the kind of thing that makes you want to throw up or give up. It\u2019s too much to even process \u2014 all these devastated families who now have to live with this pain forever because one person with a violent and insane voice in his head managed to stockpile a collection of high-powered rifles and use them to shoot people.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY KIMMEL\n\nAnother option is to read this 2016 Times article, with a transcript of Chris Rock\u2019s opening monologue for the Oscars, or Trevor Noah\u2019s November 2017 monologue on the Republican tax bill.\n\nStudents can also get inspired looking at highlights of the 2017 \u201cBest of Late Night\u201d wrap up.\n\nAnother excellent source for the question above is Times coverage of Stephen Colbert and his monologue on the New York City subway bomber, which begins:\n\nClearly relishing the opportunity, Mr. Colbert lit into a string of jokes about the resiliency of New York commuters \u2014 and the travails of having to travel on the subway every day. \u201cBut I\u2019ve got something to say to this guy. Seriously? You tried to terrorize New York subway commuters? Nice try. Nice try. New York commuters don\u2019t even flinch when the subway breakdancers kick two inches away from their face. They have to battle rats for the seat \u2014 which, for the record, you should only give up if the rat is pregnant. Come on. Come on. You tried to sow chaos and confusion in the Port Authority bus station? That is the normal state of affairs at the Port Authority bus station. There\u2019s a pretty good chance your little explosion may have scoured some of the grime off the wall, thanks. Now you\u2019re going to jail for a long, long, long time. And all New Yorkers want to know is, does that mean your apartment is free? And is it rent-controlled?\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\n_________\n\nHear Shakespeare\u2019s Words in New Contexts\n\nPhoto\n\nA March 2017 Times article, \u201cUsing Shakespeare to Ease the Trauma of War,\u201d speaks to the ways that Shakespeare\u2019s words can resonate outside their original context, to help veterans heal. The piece begins:\n\nStephan Wolfert was drunk when he hopped off an Amtrak train somewhere in Montana, toting a rucksack of clothes and a cooler stocked with ice, peanut butter, bread and Miller High Life \u2014 bottles, not cans. It was 1991, he was 24, and he had recently seen his best friend fatally wounded in a military training exercise. His mind in need of a salve, he went to a play: \u201cRichard III,\u201d the story of a king who was also a soldier. In Shakespeare\u2019s words, he heard an echo of his own experience, and though he had been raised to believe that being a tough guy was the only way to be a man, something cracked open inside him. \u201cI was sobbing,\u201d Mr. Wolfert, now 50 and an actor, said recently over coffee in Chelsea. \u201cI didn\u2019t know you could have emotions out loud.\u201d That road-to-Damascus moment \u2014 not coming to Jesus, but coming to Shakespeare \u2014 is part of the story that Mr. Wolfert tells in his solo show, \u201cCry Havoc!,\u201d which starts performances Wednesday, March 15, at the New Ohio Theater. Taking its title from Mark Antony\u2019s speech over the slain Caesar in \u201cJulius Caesar,\u201d it intercuts Mr. Wolfert\u2019s own memories with text borrowed from Shakespeare. Decoupling those lines from their plays, Mr. Wolfert uses them to explore strength and duty, bravery and trauma, examining what it is to be in the military and what it is to carry that experience back into civilian life.\n\nChallenge students to reread some of the Shakespearean soliloquies they have studied and consider what resonance they have today. Do they parallel anything happening in our world, or to a particular group of people? To whom might particular lines or speeches offer solace or instruction, the way the \u201cIf it were done when \u2019tis done\u201d soliloquy, Macbeth\u2019s debate with himself about whether to kill Duncan, the king, is meaningful to one veteran described in this piece?\n\n_________\n\nRelated Resources from The Learning Network\n\nShakespeare:\n\nCelebrate Shakespeare on His 450th Birthday: Seven Ideas for Teaching and Learning\n\nTeaching Shakespeare With The New York Times\n\nOther Authors and Works:\n\nHere is what we have so far, and the collection is always growing:\n\n\u201cThe Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian,\u201d \u201cAll Summer in a Day,\u201d Maya Angelou, \u201cAntigone,\u201d Jane Austen, \u201cThe Book Thief,\u201d \u201cThe Catcher in the Rye,\u201d \u201cThe Crucible,\u201d \u201cDeath of a Salesman,\u201d Roald Dahl, Charles Dickens, \u201cEnrique\u2019s Journey,\u201d \u201cFrankenstein,\u201d \u201cThe Giver,\u201d \u201cThe Glass Castle,\u201d \u201cThe Grapes of Wrath,\u201d \u201cThe Great Gatsby,\u201d \u201cHarry Potter,\u201d \u201cThe Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,\u201d \u201cThe Hunger Games,\u201d \u201cThe Kite Runner,\u201d \u201cLord of the Flies,\u201d \u201cOf Mice and Men,\u201d John Milton, \u201cThe Necklace,\u201d Orwell and \u201c1984,\u201d \u201cThe Outsiders,\u201d \u201cA Raisin in the Sun,\u201d Henry David Thoreau, Mark Twain and \u201cHuckleberry Finn,\u201d \u201cThe Scarlet Letter,\u201d \u201cSpeak\u201d, \u201cTo Kill a Mockingbird\u201d and \u201cWonder.\u201d", "title": "Text to Text | Soliloquies From \u2018Hamlet\u2019 and \u2018Les Mis\u00e9rables\u2019", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Like the novel\u2019s narrator Aza, Mr. Green has struggled with severe anxiety and obsessive compulsive disorder for as long as he can remember:\n\nMr. Green was about 6 years old when he first became aware of his obsessive thought patterns. He was often afraid that his food was contaminated, and would only eat certain foods at particular times of day.\n\nAs he got older, he was able to keep his anxiety in check, with the right mix of medication and cognitive behavioral therapy. But every once in a while, uncontrollable thoughts can overwhelm him.\n\nIn a video he posted before the book\u2019s release, Mr. Green discussed how his experience living with obsessive compulsive disorder led him to write his latest novel. \u201cI wanted to try to find form and expression for this way-down non-sensorial experience of living inside of thought spirals,\u201d he said.\n\nAs students watch the video and read the article, encourage them to note ways in which Aza\u2019s experience and thoughts echo those of the author. To get started, students might focus on excerpts from the book like the following. What parallels can they find in what Mr. Green says about his own experience?\n\nOn how language fails to capture abstract feelings, like pain:\n\n[During a session with Dr. Karen Singh, Aza\u2019s therapist]\n\n\u201cYou often try to understand your experience through metaphor, Aza: It\u2019s like a demon inside of you; you\u2019ll call your consciousness a bus, or a prison cell, or a spiral, or a whirlpool, or a loop, or a \u2014 I think you once called it a scribbled circle, which I found interesting \u2026 One of the challenges with pain \u2014 physical or psychic \u2014 is that we can really only approach it through metaphor. It can\u2019t be represented the way a table or a body can. In some ways, pain is the opposite of language.\u201d\n\nOn romanticizing mental illness:\n\nYou hear a lot about the benefits of insanity or whatever \u2014 like, Dr. Karen Singh had once told me this Edgar Allan Poe quote: \u201cThe question is not yet settled, whether madness is or is not the loftiest intelligence.\u201d I guess she was trying to make me feel better, but I find mental disorders to be vastly overrated. Madness, in my admittedly limited experience, is accompanied by no superpowers; being mentally unwell doesn\u2019t make you loftily intelligent any more than having the flu does.\n\nOn the \u2014 often-unrealistic \u2014 expectation that illness is something you overcome:\n\nI wanted to tell her that I was getting better, because that was supposed to be the narrative of illness: It was a hurdle you jumped over, or a battle you won. Illness is a story told in the past tense.\n\nOn intrusive thoughts:\n\nI have these thoughts that Dr. Karen Singh calls \u201cintrusives,\u201d but the first time she said it, I heard \u201cinvasives,\u201d which I like better, because, like invasive weeds, these thoughts seem to arrive at my biosphere from some faraway land, and then they spread out of control. Supposedly everyone has them\u2014you look out from over a bridge or whatever and it occurs to you out of nowhere that you could just jump. And then if you\u2019re most people, you think, Well, that was a weird thought, and move on with your life. But for some people, the invasive can kind of take over, crowding out all the other thoughts until it\u2019s the only one you\u2019re able to have, the thought you\u2019re perpetually either thinking or distracting yourself from.\n\nAfter they\u2019re done, you might ask students some of these questions:\n\n\u2022 To write authentically about the experience of living with obsessive compulsive disorder, was it necessary for Mr. Green to have lived with the mental illness himself?\n\n\u2022 Is it helpful for readers to know about an author\u2019s personal connection to the content of a novel? Or is there a case to be made for separating a work from the author\u2019s experience?\n\n\u2022 Mr. Green\u2019s editor called the book an \u201cunbelievable act of translation.\u201d Do you agree that the book \u201cgives readers a glimpse of what it\u2019s like to suffer from mental illness\u201d? If so, how is this accomplished?\n\n\u2022 If you were writing a novel, would you model the main character after yourself in any way? Why or why not?\n\n__________\n\nRead, Kids, Read", "title": "Text to Text | \u2018The Fault in Our Stars\u2019 and \u2018You May Want to Marry My Husband\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "In other words, the prevailing narrative of FISA hasn\u2019t been just that it\u2019s an imperfect system, but that those acting within it routinely lie to the court and that judges can\u2019t be trusted to do their job.\n\nThe right has seized on the claim, made in the Nunes memo, that F.B.I. and Justice Department officials hoodwinked the FISA court with false evidence and that the federal judge approving it didn\u2019t bother to dig deeper. In doing so, it has simply co-opted the left\u2019s position on FISA: Don\u2019t bother to have faith in the process, because the rule of law has no meaning even to those who are sworn to uphold it.\n\nThe assumption that everyone in government is a bad actor imperils our democracy. Following this logic, no set of rules or checks could ever produce a fair result, because no one can be trusted. That means any investigation, or its conclusions, are always illegitimate.\n\nWe are a nation founded on distrust of government power, and questioning that power is essential to promoting transparency and accountability. But those questions ought to leave room for the assumption \u2014 in the absence of specific evidence to the contrary \u2014 that most government servants are ultimately acting in good faith and within the constraints of the law.\n\nThis is particularly true in the FISA context. It was, after all, the F.B.I.\u2019s rigid adherence to FISA protocol which prevented it from sharing intelligence among its own agents, leading to the failures of the Sept. 11th attacks.\n\nAnd on that high rate of approval by the FISA court? When Timothy Edgar was a lawyer at the A.C.L.U., he was among those criticizing the FISA process as a \u201crubber stamp.\u201d But when he became a senior official in the office of the director of national intelligence and witnessed the intensive vetting process firsthand, he retracted his characterization.\n\nWe don\u2019t know whether the memo\u2019s allegations of abuse can be verified. It\u2019s worth noting, however, that Barack Obama\u2019s final year in office saw the highest number of rejected and modified FISA applications in history. This suggests that FISA applications in 2016 received more scrutiny than ever before.\n\nUnfortunately, because FISA\u2019s critics \u2014 from the left, and now on the right \u2014 have primed the public to distrust the people involved, the damage has already been done.", "title": "Opinion | Thank Progressives for the Nunes Memo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "During them, programming has included screenings of ethical pornography, a \u201cKiss and Tell\u201d story-sharing event, \u201cDildo Bingo,\u201d a ropes-and-bondage workshop and an Antioch traditional event that students attend dressed to express themselves along the gender continuum.\n\nA \u201csex positive\u201d culture has everything to do with the S.O.P.P., Mx. Olson said. \u201cBeing able to talk to a partner or multiple partners about what you like, what you would like to experiment with \u2014 to have a negotiation whether it\u2019s about B.D.S.M. or extra cuddling, whatever gets you going \u2014 those discussions are what make sex wonderful. You have more control of the situation.\u201d\n\nThe college\u2019s administration sees this all as a big selling point for the school. \u201cOur students and our alumni have always been very involved with activism, and social justice is in our DNA,\u201d said Mila Cooper, Antioch\u2019s vice president for diversity and inclusion and the director of the Coretta Scott King Center. \u201cThere\u2019s a heightened awareness of sexual violence and sexual assault right now with the MeToo movement, but I do think Antioch has been involved in these conversations long before. It\u2019s not just a policy, you know, it\u2019s part of the education and the culture here.\u201d\n\n\u2018We Live in a Culture Where So Many Are Penetrated Physically, Emotionally and Verbally\u2019\n\n\u201cWe talk about taking up space in a lot of different ways,\u201d said Toni Jonas-Silver, 23 and a fourth-year student, while sipping tea at the Emporium, a coffee bar and wine shop that is something of an off-campus commissary during the day. \u201cEven in these conversations in class, some people have the tendency to talk so much that it diminishes the chance that other voices will be heard. It\u2019s related to people who have more privilege and are more used to being encouraged to take up that space.\u201d\n\nThe discussions connect back, sometimes directly, to the policy. \u201cThe S.O.P.P. is a reminder of who we are and what we\u2019re here to do,\u201d said Michelle De Le\u00f3n, 23, a second-year student. \u201cIt lets us say, \u2018Hey, you\u2019re in a community and you\u2019re in a space with other people and be mindful of the space you\u2019re taking up.\u2019 Women, nonbinary people, queer people, people of color \u2014 we\u2019re not living in a culture that gives them space. We live in a culture where so many are penetrated physically, emotionally and verbally by anyone at any moment.\u201d\n\nIn the media, it\u2019s been misunderstood, many Antiochians say. \u201cPeople think it\u2019s a harsh policy,\u201d Ms. Nalubega said. \u201cBut it\u2019s not. It\u2019s saying that when you do touch a person, your touch is exciting and welcoming to that person.\u201d", "title": "Thank You for Asking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "My file?\n\nAll these years later, I assume my name appears in multiple files at the C.I.A., the National Security Agency and perhaps other corners of the sprawling security bureaucracy, with gripes and comments related to my coverage of how America stumbled into torture; how drone strikes went wrong; espionage cases; WikiLeaks cables; Snowden documents; Russian hackers and the Shadow Brokers; and probably stories I\u2019ve forgotten.\n\nIt is a peculiar strength of American democracy, even by Western standards, that journalists are empowered by the First Amendment to pry into even the most protected government secrets with, generally speaking, little to fear. Skulking around the secret world over the years, I interviewed William Colby, the retired C.I.A. director, not long before he took a canoe trip on the Chesapeake Bay from which he would never return. I was among the first journalists to get inside the K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow during a brief experiment in glasnost. I traveled to Switzerland to understand how American intelligence had infiltrated a Swiss company that supplied encryption machines to many countries.\n\nI was detained by the N.S.A.\u2019s police force while peering through a fence, trying to figure out what the eavesdroppers did where. I took a joy ride with a former C.I.A. pilot who rolled his little plane and flew it upside down until I assured him I was impressed with his skills.\n\nAnd there have been dark moments: I watched a former intelligence officer who had helped me with a few stories, and who in my view had revealed nothing that could harm national security, go to prison for disclosing classified information.\n\nMany reporters have such spy stories, and people like to hear them. What is the universal appeal of spying? What makes it such rich fodder for fiction and movies?", "title": "That Time the C.I.A. Tried to Recruit Me: Our National Security Reporter on Covering Spies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "A tsunami alert buzzed phones across multiple states on Tuesday morning, but it was missing a critical piece of information: This was a test.\n\nThe message, issued by the National Weather Service as part of a monthly exercise, was passed along as a real warning by AccuWeather, a private weather company headquartered in State College, Pa.\n\nAccuWeather blamed the weather service for the erroneous alert, accusing it of sending out a \u201cmiscoded\u201d warning, but the government disputed that account on Tuesday night.\n\n\u201cOur investigation into this routine monthly tsunami test message confirmed that it was coded as a test message,\u201d the National Weather Service said in a statement. \u201cWe are working with private-sector companies to determine why some systems did not recognize the coding.\u201d", "title": "That Tsunami Alert Was Just a Test. Relax, Bushwick.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I have one app on my fourth-generation Apple TV that freezes every once in a while, and the only way I can get out of it is to unplug the whole Apple TV box. Is there an easier way to get back to the home screen?\n\nA. As with apps on Apple\u2019s Mac computers and iOS devices, you can force-quit a misbehaving tvOS program without having to unplug anything. The next time an app freezes, quickly press the TV button twice on the Apple TV remote. When you do, the Apple TV goes into the app-switching mode used by iOS devices, where you see a series of application preview windows on the screen.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf the misbehaving app is not already selected, use the touch pad on the Apple TV remote to swipe left or right until you land on the app you want to close. With the app\u2019s preview window selected, swipe up on the remote\u2019s touch pad to forcibly close the program.\n\nPhoto\n\nRestarting the Apple TV may help stop the forcibly closed app from freezing again. You can restart it from the remote by holding down the TV and Menu buttons until you see the light on the front of the box flash. Alternatively, use the remote to navigate to the Settings app to System and select Restart. (While you are in the System settings, you can also check for updates to the Apple TV\u2019s software or turn on automatic updates.)\n\nThe remote can be used to rearrange apps or delete them as well. To move an app, select its icon and press down on the remote\u2019s touch pad. When the icon begins to wiggle, swipe across the touch pad until you get to the spot you want. Press the touch pad again to release the icon. To delete a wiggling app, press the Play/Pause button and choose Delete.", "title": "Thawing a Frozen Apple TV App", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAs sexual misconduct continues to dominate the news, we\u2019re providing updates and analysis in a new newsletter. Sign up here to receive future installments and be tuned for more from The New York Times\u2019s new Gender Initiative.\n\nWhat is \u201cgray zone\u201d sex? This expression has been used to describe a particular kind of sexual encounter, one that may not be viewed as \u201csexual assault,\u201d but that constitutes something far murkier and more troubling than simply a \u201cbad date.\u201d Until recently, few women had the words to describe it, though it\u2019s a place where most of us have been.\n\nBut in this #MeToo moment, many women privately and publicly have found the language to speak out about it. It was there in The New Yorker short story, \u201cCat Person,\u201d which went viral a few months ago; it was there again in a young woman\u2019s online account of an incident involving Aziz Ansari.\n\nMuch in the same way that the cases of Harvey Weinstein and others exposed the nasty pervasiveness of workplace sexual harassment and assault, these \u201cgray zone\u201d stories have prompted equally important conversations about sexual consent, sexual assault and how we understand the interplay of \u2014 and at times ambiguity between \u2014 the two.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt has forced many of us to rethink and reflect on our own sexual pasts.\n\nOn college campuses, that discussion has been particularly pronounced \u2014 in part because, for some time, students and administrators have grappled with how best to talk about and teach consent.", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: Navigating Sex in the \u2018Gray Zone\u2019", "authors": ["Jessica Bennett"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Phillips\u2019 25-year-old daughter, Pearl Stanley, has no such qualms. Watching her Facebook feed fill with stories of women abused by men, she said she sees it as \u201cintense, dark,\u201d yet exhilarating and clarifying.\n\n\u201cEverybody pretty much has dealt with something that you could put on #MeToo,\u201d she said. \u201cThe #MeToo movement just appeared, so it\u2019s not perfect. But it\u2019s here now, and it\u2019s better than not.\u201d\n\nI too am a mother. How to talk about predators is tough. We have told our daughters not to talk to strangers, that their bodies were their own, to trust their instincts. We want to give them a sense of power and confidence, not vulnerability and weakness.\n\nBut surely the Harvey Weinstein revelations and the rise of #MeToo has created a new chapter in this mother-daughter conversation. Should we now be talking more openly about sexual harassment and exploitation? And if so, what do we say? Is it really that bad?\n\nAs I was thinking about these questions, I asked my younger daughter, now a college student, whether she thought there was a generation gap in the way women see the #MeToo movement. \u201cThere was at Thanksgiving,\u201d she answered.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn my recollection of our family meal, it was not that the mothers at the table denied the existence of sexual harassment, far from it. But they voiced whether the reports were accurate \u2014 was the behavior really that prevalent, or that corrosive. \u201cIt\u2019s only sex,\u201d a 50-something female guest at the Thanksgiving table said.\n\nBut the daughters at the table, including my own, did not see anything \u201conly\u201d about it. They saw #MeToo in more starkly black-and-white terms, as a wakeup call to change society, and as an invitation to men, even men of good will, to rethink their behavior.\n\nMy niece, 16, a Louis C.K. fan, talked about how saddened and betrayed she felt by the downfall of someone whose wit and intelligence she had respected\u2014but glad it was clear that such behavior was no longer acceptable.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother woman I spoke to, Deirdre Diamint, 52, said her 15-year-old daughter has been old enough to absorb the anger of the movement, but too young to completely understand it.\n\nMs. Diamint, who works in sales, has noticed that her daughter has begun to attract men\u2019s attention on the street. S he tells her just to keep walking.\n\nShe said she wants to teach her the resilience that she says has served her well.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to teach my daughter to be a victim,\u201d she said. \u201cI want to teach her to be strong about what she wants. I want to teach her to get up and leave. I want her to call me and tell me, \u2018You gotta hear about this terrible date we had last night,\u2019 and then we both laugh about it.\u201d\n\nThose conversations may reflect how far the women\u2019s movement has come \u2014 that daughters are willing to speak out about abuse their mothers and grandmothers once learned to put up with. Their mothers have been too polite for too long, the daughters say.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re just too used to it,\u201d said Ms. Stanley, the 25-year-old. She said that when she worked as a waitress in New Orleans, male customers seemed to think that they could get away with pinching her behind if they left a good tip.\n\nBut \u201cyou don\u2019t have to say \u2018it\u2019s OK.\u2019 You can be like, \u2018I\u2019m OK.\u2019\n\n\n\nSign up here to receive future installments of The MeToo Moment or read past issues here. Tell us what you think at nytgender@nytimes.com.", "title": "The #MeToo Moment: When Mothers and Daughters Talk #MeToo", "authors": ["Anemona Hartocollis"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "There is more, though. If you somehow neglect to report income that you should have, and it\u2019s more than 25 percent of the gross income you did report, then you should keep your records for six years from the due date. If you don\u2019t bother filing at all in certain periods, the I.R.S. expects you to keep records for those years forever.\n\nOur tax collectors also offer the following bit of unintentionally hilarious guidance on a tip sheet for people who own small businesses: \u201cKeep records indefinitely if you file a fraudulent return.\u201d In other words: Please, don\u2019t cheat on your taxes. But if you do, ignore the voice in your head telling you to shred all records of your activities from that year, lest you end up in trouble one day and are unable to reconstruct the truth.\n\nDeductible Expenses\n\nSo you have some receipts. Hundreds, perhaps, from charitable contributions and meals bought for customers in pursuit of side hustles or full-time small businesses. The I.R.S. says that if you scan things on paper and save them digitally, the auditors won\u2019t demand originals years later. Credit-card statements will suffice, too. There are a few quirks with keeping records on charitable contributions; consult I.R.S. Publication 526 for more on those.\n\nPhoto\n\nCan your bank bail you out with transaction data years later? Ask before you assume anything. JPMorgan Chase, for instance, keeps records of checks, credit and debit card transactions going back seven years. If you\u2019ve left it for another bank, it will still look up the information (because you won\u2019t have online access anymore), but there may be a fee.\n\nInvestments\n\nOne troublesome area for people with taxable brokerage accounts is that you need to keep track of what you paid for a stock or a mutual fund in order to calculate capital gains or losses later.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGenerally, you can rely on your brokerage firm to do this for you, especially since new record-keeping rules went into effect for most transactions starting in 2011. Even if you switch firms, the so-called cost basis information for your investments is supposed to be transferred electronically to your new firm. Check carefully within a month or two of switching to make sure this actually happened.\n\nIt also can\u2019t hurt to keep these records yourself as a backup. For instance, you could just dump every electronic trading notification into an email file, or scan a paper statement or a year-end summary of all transactions and store it in a cloud account, or perhaps two of them just to be safe.\n\nKeep in mind that technology reaches back only so far. Fidelity has records for brokerage transactions going back to 1993, while Vanguard has records dating from 1998. Vanguard adds that it can provide duplicate tax forms for any year it generated one for a participant who invested in a 401(k) plan.\n\nFidelity warns that it may not be able to serve as your backstop when it comes to nondeductible individual retirement accounts. That\u2019s because it doesn\u2019t have access to the relevant I.R.S. form, 8606, that taxpayers fill out. So you\u2019ll want to hang on to that one until you\u2019ve withdrawn all your nondeductible contributions to the account.\n\nAnother crucial bit of I.R.A. record-keeping is any record of conversions from regular I.R.A.s to Roth I.R.A.s, which allow you to withdraw the money free of taxes decades later. Your accountant may have these documents, too. Mine did when I went looking for them last year, and that backstop was a good reminder of the benefit of doing business with the same people for long periods of time.\n\nEverything Else\n\nThere are dozens of other things you should hang onto as well. I\u2019d follow the I.R.S. rules up above for receipts related to a health savings account. UnitedHealthcare keeps relevant data from its explanation of benefits forms for 10 years from the claim date, and it will give you free copies even if you or your employer are no longer customers.\n\nIf you or a parent expect to qualify for Medicaid coverage for long-term care, your state will probably want to examine all of your transactions (not just health-related ones) for several years before the year you apply.\n\nKeep copies of all major insurance policies, and a home inventory of things you\u2019ll want to replace if they are damaged or stolen. And hang onto the agreements for all major loans, from student to mortgage, and any letters confirming payoff. Keep child support, alimony and other payment records forever too, along with the divorce documentation, especially if things are acrimonious.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHome improvement receipts are essential if you think the value of your home will rise hundreds of thousands of dollars over time, as I explained in a 2015 column. Birth certificates and Social Security cards still seem to come in handy, and you may need military discharge papers once in a while, too.\n\nEstate planning documents can also be a source of contention, so hold onto the originals of any will, trust and related documents, plus beneficiary designations from insurance policies or investment accounts. If you\u2019ve received an inheritance or a gift, you\u2019ll need to document the event and the value as well, perhaps through a formal appraisal. Vanguard notes the need to keep the relevant I.R.S. forms \u2014 706, 709 and 8971 \u2014 indefinitely. Yes, the I.R.S. may be able to retrieve lost tax forms for you, but that could take a while.\n\nThe Joy of Paper\n\nAs much as I know that I should digitize everything, I still haven\u2019t quite come around on going completely paperless. I like being able to write on statements easily and enjoy the well-sorted feeling of opening an orderly filing cabinet.\n\nAnd as I examined my files with a more critical eye than usual this week, I noticed something else. While I have a few memory boxes elsewhere in my apartment, there are also artifacts of my life in nearly every filing cabinet drawer. There was the flier from my first high school dance party at Cabaret Metro in Chicago in 1985, and out fell an autographed picture of Artis Gilmore, from the days when he played basketball for the Bulls and I still answered to \u201cRonnie.\u201d\n\nSeeing these artifacts makes the filing chore tolerable, even pleasurable. Just be careful if you pare back the files and put things through the shredder every so often. You wouldn\u2019t want photos of childhood sports heroes like Dave Kingman and Dave Corzine sliced into 1,000 pieces.", "title": "The (Long) List of Financial Documents You Should Keep", "authors": ["Ron Lieber", "Your Money"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "RE: Oregon\n\nJennifer Percy wrote about the fear of the federal government among some ranchers in eastern Oregon.\n\nI grew up in rural Colorado and have lived in the western United States nearly my entire life. To a degree, I get where the people written about in this article are coming from; the West they believe in \u2014 remote and desolate, yet awesomely beautiful and resource-rich, far from that icky urban environment \u2014 is a familiar, comfortable home. But much of what they believe is demonstrably false. If all the federal land out West that\u2019s not a military installation or a national park were devolved to the states or to private landowners, the locals would probably not stand to gain anything. If the states were to end up with federal lands, grazing and mineral-extraction fees would almost certainly go up, and by quite a bit.\n\nCould the federal government do a better job coordinating with local interests when it comes to the use of federal lands? Yes, but that doesn\u2019t equate to the right to use the land to the point where it can no longer sustain either cattle or indigenous fauna or where streams that so many rely on for drinking water are polluted. Since the declaration of the never-ending War on Terror, the equally brutal special ops of the United States and the slaughter of how many innocents in especially the Muslim world (even al-Awlaki and two of his children, all United States citizens), these questions should be answered by the United States too. Gary MacDonald, Cranbrook, British Columbia\n\nPhoto\n\nI\u2019m not sure Arafat \u201celuded\u201d anything. The Israelis eventually determined that he should not be killed. Whether the Palestinian Arabs derived any benefit from Israel\u2019s forbearance is easily answered with a resounding no. Although Arafat did fine for his family, amassing huge sums of money that his wife and the Palestinian Authority fought over after his death, he did nothing to prepare \u201chis\u201d people for peace and for the most part kept them in line with threats of (or actual) violence. The sex is less like intimacy and more like performance. People are in a sense watching themselves and each other.\n\nIt\u2019s no mystery why, after having an encounter crippled by this sense of persistent distance from your partner and even your own feelings, you might feel anxiety, disappointment, resentment, disgust or shame.\n\nPorn is really bad training for good sex. Can we admit that genuinely good sex isn\u2019t detached? It\u2019s passionate, vulnerable, generous, engaged, at ease. Portia, Massachusetts\n\nPhoto\n\nAs an 18-year-old who watches porn, I was surprised by this article \u2014 that seniors didn\u2019t know what lube is, for example! I have always realized that porn is not real life and that its focus has always been on the male and his desires, so I strive to do the opposite. All my friends realize this as well. We place the girl\u2019s needs first and always ask what she wants and verbally ask if every action we take is O.K. Some may think it \u201cruins the moment,\u201d but it\u2019s important that you and your partner are on the same page, both having a good time.\n\nThe only class we ever had that dealt with sex was a generic sex-ed class, explaining S.T.D.s and the basic organs \u2014 but nothing more. And it was too late \u2014 in eighth grade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a son of divorced parents who lives with my mom, I never received \u201cthe talk\u201d and was left to figure it out via porn and friends. Mitch, Connecticut, on nytimes.com\n\nPhoto\n\nAs a retired teacher, I found Jones\u2019s feature disturbing on many levels. What will it require to similarly stimulate young people who have seen, and heard, every conceivable human sex act by the age of 14? How long will they be able to stay with a single partner? To what extent will their premature sophistication cause them to question their own natural sexuality?\n\nWe already know that porn consumption can cause ennui and eventual dissatisfaction within otherwise stable long-term relationships. You can only wonder how long it will take the boy who began watching porn on his cellphone as a ninth grader to find eventually repetitious sex with the same someone a poor use of his time. (We ought not \u2014 in this time of increased focus on sexual abuse \u2014 shy away from realizing that the rough, seemingly playful sex that women seem to \u201clike\u201d in porn romps can veer by increments into unpleasant variants.)\n\nIt seems to me that decades-long pair-bonding will be an even unlikelier outcome for these children than it has already become \u2014 under myriad other pressures \u2014 for 21st-century couples. Jim Walker, Massillon, Ohio", "title": "The 2.11.18 Issue", "authors": ["The New York Times Magazine"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "RE: THE OLYMPICS ISSUE\n\nFourteen writers contributed to The Enthusiast\u2019s Guide to the Winter Games, covering every sport from speedskating to curling.\n\nSam Anderson\u2019s dour portrait misses the subtlety and grace in cross-country skiing. Yes, it is a grueling sport \u2014 as are rowing, running, speedskating, cycling and swimming \u2014 and Anderson pays fair homage to this aspect. But fitness, strength and perseverance in the face of fatigue alone are not enough to win.\n\nTo be a good skier requires balance, rhythm and an animal-like ability to respond to constant variations in topography and snow conditions. Every meter of trail varies in slope, pitch and smoothness. Skis will slide differently over snow that has been shaded or lies on a north-facing slope versus snow in an open, sunny field. And snow changes day by day, hour by hour. Skiers must maintain balance over their skis as they glide over what may be a rough or rutted surface or when they hit a patch of snow that is softer and slower. Losing balance costs speed, and long practice is needed to attain this skill. But once it is mastered, the skier can speed across the landscape, almost floating above the snow. And on downhills, good skiers preserve their momentum and use it to glide up the next hill. And therein lie the joys of what I will argue is a most elegant and engaging sport. Harry Read, Madison, Wis.", "title": "The 2.4.18 Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "#Speakingindance\n\nThe 20-Year Itch\n\nIn honor of Arcell Cabuag\u2019s 20th season as a member of Ronald K. Blige and Common", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "They work for the three ice managers (often called the chief of ice or the ice meister) at four competition venues \u2014 two arenas for hockey, one for long-track speedskating and one for both figure skating and short-track speedskating. There are also two practice rinks for hockey, a training center for short-track and a practice rink for figure skating.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFilling the roster with South Korean drivers proved difficult.\n\nSouth Korea has only a couple of dozen rinks, organizers said, so the talent pool of top drivers is small. And no rinks have two ice-resurfacing machines. Multiple Zambonis on the ice simultaneously can be a seductive dance to watch, but terrifying to drive.\n\nThere were other limiting factors in securing local talent. Some could not get the six or eight weeks off that the job required. And without firm post-Olympic plans for several venues (the speedskating oval, for example, is likely to be converted to convention space), there was little opportunity for locals to find lasting employment by learning during the Olympics and taking over the ice-making operation afterward, as happened in places like Vancouver and Salt Lake City.\n\nMoffatt used an all-Korean crew during hockey test events here last year, with the idea he might do the same during the Olympics. He discovered that younger Korean drivers deferred to older drivers, afraid to disrespectfully show them up with their skills. But five of them had enough talent, he thought, to be invited to the Olympics.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWith us non-Koreans, there is less of that,\u201d Moffatt said. \u201cStill some, but less.\u201d\n\nMainly, the ice chiefs found trusted drivers by tapping into connections at home. Most of those at the hockey venues work at N.H.L. arenas in places like Edmonton, St. Paul and Denver. At the figure skating and short-track speedskating sites, most drivers work smaller arenas or oversee the ice operations at recreation centers. Those at the long-track oval have specific experience in ovals, which require a more pristine sheet of ice.\n\n\u201cIt has to be absolutely perfect,\u201d said Paul Golomski, whose job at home is facility director of Pettit National Ice Center in Milwaukee. \u201cThickness is critical. The amount of speed they\u2019re carrying, the ice has to be perfectly flat.\u201d\n\nEvery ice sport demands a different surface, with variations in thickness, temperature and hardness. At Gangneung Ice Arena, Boehler split his crew between figure skating and short-track specialists. Figure skating requires thicker, softer ice.
