Short-track needs colder ice, but not too brittle that it gives way on the tight corners.\n\nBeyond the complex refrigeration systems, Zambonis are the primary tool in making the ice and keeping it in good condition, a big machine that does a lot of detail work.", "title": "The 22nd-Largest Team at the Olympics: Zamboni Drivers", "authors": ["John Branch"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "A version of this article appears in print on , on Page ST 11 of the New York edition with the headline: The Breeds That Dominate on Instagram", "title": "The 5 Most Popular Dogs on Instagram", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "In 1973, Roe v. Wade changed all this. At first, people didn\u2019t understand what the decision meant. \u201cPlainly,\u201d Chief Justice Warren Burger wrote, \u201cthe court today rejects any claim that the Constitution requires abortion on demand.\u201d\n\nBut then everything polarized. The pro-life movement grew on the right and withered on the left. Republicans introduced an anti-abortion plank into their platform in 1976. A new electoral coalition was born.\n\nThe G.O.P. became an alliance between its traditional pro-business wing and its burgeoning pro-life wing. Millions of Americans became single-issue voters. They consider the killing of the unborn the great moral issue of our time. Without pro-life voters, Ronald Reagan never would have been elected. Without single-issue voters who wanted pro-life judges, there would never have been a President Donald Trump.\n\nI understand that our donors (though not necessarily our voters) want to preserve a woman\u2019s right to choose through all nine months of her pregnancy. But do we want late-term abortion so much that we are willing to tolerate President Trump? Do we want it so much that we give up our chance at congressional majorities? Do we want it so much that we see our agendas on poverty, immigration, income equality and racial justice thwarted and defeated?\n\nLet\u2019s try to imagine what would happen if Roe v. Wade was overturned. The abortion issue would go back to the states. The Center for Reproductive Rights estimates that roughly 21 states would outlaw abortion. Abortion would remain legal in probably 20 others. There\u2019s a good chance that a lot of states would hammer out the sort of compromise the European nations have \u2014 legal in the first months, difficult after that. That\u2019s what most Americans support.", "title": "Opinion | The Abortion Memo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSmearing Woody Allen\u201d (column, Feb. 10): One of Bret Stephens\u2019s remarks unwittingly exemplifies one reason abuse victims are so afraid to talk about their abuse and to ask for the support they need: \u201cNobody else has come forward in 25 years with a fresh accusation of assault against him.\u201d\n\nIn other words, because no one else has accused Woody Allen of abuse for all these years, we might safely believe that the abuse of Dylan Farrow never happened.\n\nI am not going to say whether I believe Woody Allen is guilty or not guilty. However, as a victim of child abuse myself, I feel strongly that it is wrong and harmful to doubt Dylan, or anyone else, based on the \u201cwell, he hasn\u2019t done it to anyone else so far as we know\u201d argument.\n\nMEGAN LYDEN, BELLEVUE, WASH.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nA teacher victimized my child in 2013, and it was with a roiling stomach that I read Bret Stephens\u2019s column. Mr. Stephens denigrates Dylan Farrow for going public again about Woody Allen\u2019s alleged abuse and doubts her account. He writes, \u201cMost parents know that young children are imaginative and suggestible and innocently prone to making things up.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Abuse Accusation Against Woody Allen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Droga5, a prominent advertising agency, fired its chief creative officer, Ted Royer, on Thursday after having placed him on leave earlier this week, citing a commitment to \u201cmaintaining a safe and inclusive environment for all our employees.\u201d\n\nThe termination is of note because it follows a string of executive exits from other major ad agencies in recent months, including the Martin Agency and Wieden + Kennedy, which were accompanied by similarly nonspecific official statements invoking company values and guidelines.\n\nThe New York agency told its staff earlier this week that it had hired an outside firm to conduct an investigation into Mr. Royer, according to Adweek. Droga5 said that it could not share any information about the type of firm it had hired or the nature of any complaints, according to a spokeswoman, who added, \u201cThis is a legal matter now.\u201d\n\nWomen across industries nationwide have felt emboldened to report workplace misconduct after the publication of sexual harassment allegations in The New York Times and other news outlets against the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein and many other men in positions of power.", "title": "The Advertising Firm Droga5 Fires Its Chief Creative Officer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Many of the worst effects of the tax bill President Trump signed in December could take years to emerge. But the damage to the federal tax credit program that finances nearly all affordable housing built in America is already painfully evident. Unless Congress rescues this crucial program, a quarter million fewer affordable units will be built over the next 10 years, deepening an already serious crisis.\n\nThe federal low-income housing tax credit, created in 1986, allows companies to reduce their tax liabilities by investing in housing for some of the nation\u2019s neediest families and individuals, many of them seniors, veterans and people with disabilities. The program has produced roughly three million rental units since its inception, but has fallen far short of the growing demand for affordable housing.\n\nFor example, a 2017 report from Harvard\u2019s Joint Center for Housing Studies shows that about 11 million families \u2014 or about a quarter of all renters in the United States \u2014 spend more than half of their incomes on housing. These families often have to choose between making rent and paying for essentials like food, child care and health care, and many are just one financial emergency away from eviction.\n\nThe pressure on low-income renters has worsened for other reasons as well. In recent years, higher-income people who once would have bought homes have turned to renting, driving up housing costs for poor and working-class families. The declining value of low-income housing tax credits will make all of this worse. It started last year, when President Trump and congressional Republicans made clear that they intended to dramatically lower the corporate tax rate, giving companies less reason to worry about tax liabilities.", "title": "Opinion | The Affordable Housing Crisis Is About to Get Worse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "The cultural critic Mark Dery galvanized a generation of artists and intellectuals when he argued during the 1990s that African-Americans whose histories had been obscured by slavery and racism were in danger of being written out of the future as well \u2014 unless they engaged the areas of art, literature and technology through which that future was being envisioned.\n\nMr. Dery coined the term \u201cAfrofuturism\u201d to describe the work of artists who used the tools of science fiction to imagine possible futures. The list of practitioners was relatively short at the time: It included black science fiction writers like Samuel Delany and Octavia Butler and the fantastical orchestra leader Sun Ra, who carried the name of the ancient Egyptian sun god and offered an allegory of salvation in which African-Americans were urged to escape tribulation by emigrating to the stars.\n\nThe ranks of the Afrofuturist creators have grown considerably over the last 25 years. They expanded in dramatic fashion with the release of the wildly successful film \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d the first major superhero movie to feature a black director and writers and a majority black cast. The film\u2019s most important distinction is that it is told from an Afrocentric point of view; it breaks with the spirit of derision that has always saturated Hollywood films about Africans.\n\nThe movie takes its title from a 50-year-old Marvel comic superhero who might easily have passed out of existence had he not crossed paths with the African-American comic book writer Christopher Priest, who broke into this white industry during the 1980s and achieved influence in time to keep Marvel from hollowing out the character that has now become one of its most lucrative properties.", "title": "Opinion | The Afrofuturism Behind \u2018Black Panther\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The costuming for Nakia, played by Ms. Nyong\u2019o, made the broadest leaps, Ms. Carter said. The spy\u2019s river tribe was based partly on the Suri of Ethiopia, so her traditional look was made of shells, beads and leaves.\n\n\u201cThat cultural specificity was very, very helpful,\u201d Ms. Nyong\u2019o said. \u201cI looked at images of those people and their particular way of life. It\u2019s another layer of character development.\u201d\n\nBut she also has a high-wattage fight scene in a casino in South Korea, for which she wears a striking green, high-neck, open-shoulder dress. Ms. Carter and her team designed the fabric and had it 3-D-printed. They started with a kente cloth, \u201cextracted the line work and created a pattern, hand-painted it,\u201d she said. It\u2019s covered with Wakandan text \u2014 boxes with slashes inside \u2014 and it\u2019s sexy but not revealing. \u201cIt was her Bond Girl moment,\u201d Ms. Carter said, \u201cbut also, she could fight and move in it, and it wasn\u2019t constricting.\u201d\n\nNakia\u2019s civilian clothes were the real challenge. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to figure out what a person\u2019s casual looks are when they\u2019re a war dog, a C.I.A. operative, a casino girl,\u201d she said. \u201cWe were trying things on all the time in the fitting room.\u201d\n\nMs. Nyong\u2019o said, \u201cThere were days when, like, last minute, we still didn\u2019t know what I was going to wear.\u201d But Ms. Carter never panicked, she said admiringly. \u201cShe\u2019s so relaxed, in a way that is just spellbinding.\u201d", "title": "The Afrofuturistic Designs of \u2018Black Panther\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "This year\u2019s batch of nominations contains names that will be familiar to any Oscar devotee, and the writers of three of the five songs are repeat nominees. But there are first timers other than Mr. Stevens as well: Mary J. Blige, Raphael Saadiq and Taura Stinson are up for \u201cMighty River,\u201d from \u201cMudbound.\u201d Also, in what is possibly an Oscars first, one team of writers is up against their former babysitter.\n\nThe Bagger asked the songwriters about the impact of the nominations, and how they went about writing songs for the screen.\n\nPhoto\n\nFirst and foremost, they all said landing an Oscar nomination was obviously a good thing.\n\n\u201cBeing in this conversation of course broadens the horizons,\u201d Ms. Blige, who is the first person to earn Oscar nominations for songwriting and acting in the same year, wrote in an email. \u201cJust like a Grammy, it elevates the game.\u201d\n\nBut several of the songwriters noted that an award as the end goal could have a poisoning effect.\n\nBenj Pasek and Justin Paul, who collected the best song Oscar last year for \u201cCity of Stars,\u201d from \u201cLa La Land,\u201d have found themselves nominated again this year, for \u201cThis Is Me,\u201d a chart topper and Golden Globe winner sung by Keala Settle in \u201cThe Greatest Showman.\u201d\n\nMr. Pasek said the recognition helped counterbalance the often torturous process of songwriting. \u201cThere are so many dark, dreary days where you feel incredibly inadequate, and completely lost,\u201d he said. \u201cPeople you look up to or inspire you, a community of artists that you listen to and draw inspiration from, are saying, \u2018keep going.\u2019 \u201d\n\nBut, Mr. Paul added, the pair didn\u2019t necessarily view it as a stamp of \u201cnow we\u2019re really good.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe all know people who have won awards who have gone on to make terrible things, and people who\u2019ve never won an award who\u2019ve done great things,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Pasek, as it happened, used to babysit for Kristen Anderson-Lopez and her husband, Robert Lopez, who are up for the tender ballad \u201cRemember Me,\u201d from the Oscar-nominated \u201cCoco,\u201d the Pixar animated film about Mexican family life and folklore (both the film and the song are favorites in their respective categories).\n\n\u201cSuch a sweet and warm guy,\u201d Mr. Lopez wrote in a text, of Mr. Pasek. \u201cWe\u2019d use him again, though I think he\u2019s busy.\u201d\n\nThe Lopezes are Oscar winners, too, having gifted the world with \u201cLet It Go,\u201d one of the most ubiquitous songs of 2014. (The artist who sang that, Idina Menzel, had her name gloriously mangled by John Travolta at that year\u2019s Oscars, where he introduced her as \u201cAdele Dazeem.\u201d)\n\nMs. Anderson-Lopez said \u201cRemember Me\u201d was born partly out of parental guilt. Working in the music industry often takes her and Mr. Lopez away from their two daughters, so she leaves them with personalized lullabies that she has their babysitters sing. Mr. Lopez also sang it at his mother\u2019s funeral in August. \u201cI don\u2019t know how I made it through,\u201d he said.\n\nThe couple said having their first Oscar nomination, and win, behind them has let them breathe easier this awards season. In 2014, they found themselves \u201cin a constant state of fight or flight,\u201d Ms. Anderson-Lopez said. This year\u2019s ceremony will also be a break from their work in New York, where they are preparing \u201cFrozen\u201d for Broadway. \u201cWriting for the screen, you don\u2019t have to think about applause moments,\u201d Ms. Anderson-Lopez said.\n\n\u201dRemember Me\u201d was also deeply personal for its Grammy-winning singers, Miguel, whose father is Mexican, and the pop star Natalia LaFourcade, who is from Mexico City. \u201cOn a political, cultural side, a movie like this has great timing,\u201d Miguel said. Ms. LaFourcade said the movie, and song, gave her country a much-needed boost. \u201cEspecially being next to the States, it\u2019s very important, and a reminder of so many good things we have,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cStand Up for Something,\u201d from \u201cMarshall,\u201d a film about the first African-American Supreme Court justice, was written by Diane Warren, who\u2019s on her ninth Oscar nomination, and Common, who, along with John Legend, won the category three years ago for \u201cGlory.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCommon said his first round of movie awards attention gave him access to power players he had never before known, like the Starbucks executive Howard Schultz, with whom he ended up partnering on a jobs initiative in Chicago.\n\nMs. Warren said she had always known she wanted to work with Common on the song, which he performed with the singer Andra Day, but didn\u2019t pop the question until she found herself sitting alongside him on a plane trip to Sundance. \u201cIt\u2019s probably the most important song I\u2019ve ever done,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cPeople are more likely to call you, any success you have,\u201d Ms. Warren said. \u201cThe fact that you\u2019re chosen out of hundreds of nominated songs is quite an honor. That being said, it would be nice to win.\u201d\n\nMr. Stevens remains a little baffled by his nomination, and the intensity of being part of an awards campaign. A staunchly independent and autonomous songwriter, he\u2019s had little exposure to the entertainment industry complex, and \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d which is also a best picture contender, is distributed by Sony Pictures Classics, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment. The song he is nominated for also wasn\u2019t even the first one he penned for the film; that was \u201cVisions of Gideon,\u201d which he describes as \u201centrenched in sorrow, a moment of realizing and resignation, and a bit of a downer when you\u2019re up against Pixar.\u201d So, he said, he understood why \u201cMystery of Love\u201d was instead used in the film\u2019s awards campaign.\n\nAs for the Oscar night tuxedo, Mr. Stevens has a pretty sweet connection. He\u2019ll be wearing Gucci, he said, because \u201cLuca is close with the Gucci people because he lives near Milan.\u201d To be determined: whether he\u2019ll accessorize with wings.", "title": "The Agony, Absurdity and Ecstasy of the Oscar for Best Song", "authors": ["Cara Buckley", "The Carpetbagger"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "At the Winter Olympics, many gold medals are earned in the air. Generally the athletes that manage to defy gravity for the longest can pull off the most complex maneuvers, positioning themselves for the podium.\n\nNew York Times photographers have captured airborne athletes throughout the Pyeongchang Games. Here\u2019s a look at some of their favorites photos.", "title": "The Airborne Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "NASHVILLE \u2014 No one was shocked last week when SouthComm Inc., a Nashville-based media company, announced it was selling The Nashville Scene, its flagship alternative newsweekly. SouthComm had already sold or was in the process of selling its newspapers in Atlanta, Cincinnati, Kansas City, Tampa and Washington. And alt-weeklies around the country have been declining for years.\n\nGone are The Baltimore City Paper, The Philadelphia City Paper, The Boston Phoenix. Last year, here in Tennessee, The Knoxville Mercury shut down. Also last year, Atlanta\u2019s Creative Loafing laid off all but one person on the entire editorial staff. Even The Village Voice, the alt-weekly that invented alt-weeklies, now survives only online.\n\nSeeing The Scene on the auction block might not be surprising, but it\u2019s still heartbreaking. In a shortsighted effort to make the paper more appealing to buyers, SouthComm laid off some passionate, immensely talented journalists and seriously overburdened those who remained. Some of them are people I know because I once wrote for The Scene, and I have spent more than 20 years watching the difference this newspaper has made to my city.\n\nIn 1996, the summer my second child was born, I sent an envelope full of essays to The Nashville Scene. I was not a journalist \u2014 I was an English teacher on maternity leave \u2014 but the managing editor offered me a weekly column anyway. In time, I moved on to writing book reviews and then to editing them. In 2009, The Scene\u2019s owners killed the book page in a round of cost cutting, but within months I was back, in a way: I had gone on to edit a new nonprofit website designed to compensate for dwindling book coverage in newspapers. The site, an initiative of Humanities Tennessee, offers local literary news to state media outlets at no charge in exchange for byline credit and a link online. The first paper to sign up for our content was The Nashville Scene. It is still our partner today.", "title": "Opinion | The Alt-Weekly Crisis Hits Nashville. And Democracy.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "I recently met Jim Chuquirima, a 16-year-old American citizen whose mother is undocumented. He is bespectacled, painfully shy and builds computers out of spare parts that his mother, Nelly Cumbicos, buys him. Ms. Cumbicos is a movie-star-beautiful single mother from Ecuador who had sworn off men before she met Ram\u00f3n Mu\u00f1iz, a roofer and die-hard union man who lived on the first floor of the multifamily home in Meriden, Conn., where Jim and Nelly rented the third floor. He would fix Nelly\u2019s car, pick Jim up from school while she was at work and leave unsigned love letters on the windshield of her car. They married in their home on Halloween in 2015.\n\nAn American citizen, he insisted in 2015 that she let him petition for her green card, even though she was afraid it would put ICE on her trail. She was right: When ICE became aware of Ms. Cumbico\u2019s whereabouts, it located a deportation order from more than a decade before that she says she had never received because it was sent to a wrong address. ICE gave her a temporary stay on Feb. 5 only to inexplicably rescind it four days later. Like a botched execution, it left the family newly traumatized. Their legal fees have nearly bankrupted them. Her deportation is set for Wednesday.\n\n\u201cI feel like this is my fault,\u201d Mr. Mu\u00f1iz said. \u201cI put her in danger, but all I wanted was to protect her. I\u2019m lost without her.\u201d\n\nIn the early 1900s, American women who married foreigners lost their citizenship. Those laws are off the books now. But does that mean American citizens have the constitutional right to be protected from the deportation of an immediate family member? Lower courts haven\u2019t thought so. In one case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit decided the deportation of an American-born infant\u2019s parents didn\u2019t violate her right to grow up in this country because either her parents could surrender her to foster care in America before they left or she could leave with them and return to the United States as an adult. The Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit has declared that a parent\u2019s deportation has only \u201cincidental impact\u201d on a child. Studies, however, have shown that children with parents who are under threat of deportation or have been deported fall into depression and anxiety and are more likely to have behavioral problems and to experience drastically decreased academic performance. Couples who are separated by oceans are very likely to end up divorced.\n\nThe Supreme Court has historically declared that it is \u201cintolerable\u201d to force a citizen to choose between two constitutional rights. But what then of the American families of deportees? Isn\u2019t the Trump administration forcing them to make a terrible choice, between either staying in the United States and having their families rived in two, or forfeiting their lives in America so that they can keep their families intact?", "title": "Opinion | The Americans Left Behind by Deportation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Accusations about the practice \u2014 known as \u201ccollars for dollars\u201d \u2014 have dogged the department for decades. The Mollen Commission\u2019s 1994 report about police corruption, which used the term, detailed the various and devious overtime schemes that have been used.\n\nIn one, the police would involve additional officers in making an arrest, maximizing the number of people eligible for overtime. In a typical arrangement, those extra officers might claim to have discovered evidence that the defendant had tried to hide, or in some other way they would enter the case as peripheral witnesses. They would need to be on hand to handle paperwork or be available to testify \u2014 so they too would get overtime pay.\n\nIn another practice, known as \u201ctrading collars,\u201d officers sometimes directed arrests to the member of their team who stood to get the most overtime. Felony arrests are often presented to a grand jury about five days after the incident; but if an officer who took part was scheduled to work on the anticipated grand jury date, he or she might defer to a colleague who was not.\n\nThe second officer would \u201ctake the arrest,\u201d and receive the extra pay for going to court on a day off \u2014 even if that meant testifying about events the officer had never witnessed, the report maintained.\n\nOne of the city\u2019s most infamous overtime frauds occurred in the late 1980s among officers from the 73rd Precinct in Brownsville, Brooklyn, known as the Morgue Boys. At their federal corruption trial in Brooklyn, Daniel Eurell, an officer who pleaded guilty, testified that he and his colleagues often made arrests when their shifts were almost over to ensure receiving overtime. The group would then file false reports, or \u201ccover stories,\u201d to justify the arrests, Officer Eurell said.\n\nThe notion that police officers have financial incentives in making arrests also emerged at the trial last month of a Queens detective convicted of perjury. The detective, Kevin Desormeau, had arrested a man on drug charges after claiming, falsely it turned out, to have witnessed the suspect dealing drugs. In arguing the case, prosecutors noted that Detective Desormeau had filed for four hours and 24 minutes of overtime for \u201can arrest that was illegal.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIf Mr. Cordero\u2019s allegations that he was falsely arrested to boost overtime pay are upheld, it would seem to suggest that years of attention and reform have only had a marginal effect on curbing the connection between false arrests and overtime, said Harry G. Levine, a professor of sociology at Queens College who has written extensively about drugs and policing. It would also trigger the second broader trial, which lawyers and policing experts in New York said would be a rarity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe pattern of making arrests to get overtime pay is historic and longstanding,\u201d Professor Levine said.\n\nGabriel Harvis, Mr. Cordero\u2019s lawyer, has suggested that a second trial, should one indeed occur, would set the stage for the biggest challenge to unconstitutional policing practices in New York since a 2013 federal trial about the department\u2019s overreliance on stop-and-frisk tactics. \u201cPhase II is the rare opportunity for a Federal District Court to review controversial citywide practices of the N.Y.P.D.,\u201d Mr. Harvis wrote in an email.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe stop-and-frisk trial, which found the practice was unconstitutional, resulted in a huge decline in the tactic\u2019s use and the creation of a court-appointed monitor to track it. While it remains unclear what effect a finding of liability against the city in a second Cordero trial might have, the judge in the case, Jack B. Weinstein, could take similar action.\n\nThe lawsuit has accused the officers of concocting the basis of Mr. Cordero\u2019s arrest \u201cin order to obtain overtime for completing the attendant paperwork,\u201d court filings state. The officers, who are being defended by lawyers for the city, have denied the charges. The city\u2019s Law Department said that the arrest was \u201csupported by probable cause.\u201d\n\nThe case began at 1 p.m. on Oct. 24, 2014, when Officer Hugo Hugasian was sitting in an unmarked police car watching the mini-market as part of a plainclothes street narcotics team. Court papers state that Officer Hugasian saw a man \u2014 later identified as Matthew Ninos \u2014 walk up to the store with a cellphone at his ear.\n\nThen someone left the store, approached Mr. Ninos and handed him \u201ctwo little zips or bags\u201d in exchange for money, Officer Hugasian said. After a description of the buyer was sent out on a radio, Mr. Ninos was arrested on a charge of having 0.138 grams of cocaine. He later pleaded guilty to drug possession.\n\nThe seller went back into the mini-market, court papers said. Though two other officers, Peter Rubin and John Essig, went inside to find him, they were unable to identify him. So Officer Hugasian, who said that he had witnessed the deal, went into the store. Court papers state he bought a bottle of water and identified the seller as Mr. Cordero, a cashier at J & C Mini Market who is 59 years old.\n\nMr. Cordero was arrested within minutes, according to the papers, but when he was searched, the police did not find any drugs or drug paraphernalia. He did, however, have $580 in his pocket, which he said was \u201cfor emergencies.\u201d Both Mr. Cordero and the owner of the store, Fausto Tineo, told the police that he had never left the market and had been serving customers when the drug deal supposedly occurred. Mr. Cordero was held for several hours, but five months later \u2014 on March 4, 2015 \u2014 the Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office dismissed the charges against him.\n\nThe encounter led Mr. Harvis to conclude that the arrest was a sham and had been orchestrated to generate overtime. In court filings, he noted that the street narcotics unit filed for at least 22 hours of extra pay that day \u2014 most of it by Officers Hugasian and Essig.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth men, according to the lawsuit, had been scheduled to work on the day of the arrests from 7 a.m. to 3:35 p.m. Police records show that Mr. Cordero and Mr. Ninos left the precinct at 5:30 p.m. and were taken to the courthouse. While Officer Hugasian never met with an assistant district attorney, court papers said that he was interviewed by phone about Mr. Cordero\u2019s arrest. Shortly after 8 p.m., the papers said, Mr. Cordero was released from the courthouse. (Mr. Ninos had also been released.) But Officer Hugasian filed documents claiming that he worked until 12:25 a.m. the next day, and Officer Essig said that he remained on duty until 11:30 p.m.\n\nIn October, Judge Weinstein issued an order saying that if any officer was found liable, a second trial would explore Mr. Harvis\u2019s theory that \u201cthe Police Department has long been aware of a widespread practice of false arrests at the end of tours of duty.\u201d The second trial would be likely to rely on Police Department records about overtime abuse, which the city has filed under seal as part of Mr. Cordero\u2019s case but could become public.\n\n\u201cA reasonable jury may find that this practice is not isolated to a few \u2018bad\u2019 police officers,\u201d Judge Weinstein wrote, \u201cbut is endemic, that N.Y.P.D. officials are aware this pattern exists and that they have failed to intervene and properly supervise.\u201d", "title": "The Arrest Was a Bust. The Officers Got Overtime Anyway.", "authors": ["Alan Feuer", "Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Soon after Marianne Ways arrived at her office one Monday morning this month, she called to check on sales for that night\u2019s performance of Butterboy, the weekly showcase of stand-up comics she produces at Littlefield in Gowanus, Brooklyn. Then she started worrying.\n\nOnly 26 tickets sold. The space fits 250. \u201cThat sucks,\u201d she said by phone, and not only for business reasons: a sparse crowd gets self-conscious and is hesitant to laugh. Ms. Ways, 37, has been putting together comedy shows long enough to know she would have to come up with a quick fix.\n\nPart of what makes New York the greatest city in the world to see live comedy is the large number of cheap, easily accessible and impressively curated live shows outside the clubs. These were once considered alt comedy; now some (Whiplash on Monday, Sweet on Tuesday) are institutions. Their hosts may get the applause, but the far less well-known bookers are the crucial players who establish the vision and quality control. To understand the art of her job, I followed Ms. Ways for one week, keeping in touch by email and phone to see what went into putting together a lineup.\n\nMs. Ways is one of the most important gatekeepers in Brooklyn\u2019s fertile stand-up scene, which is centered not in clubs, but in bars and performing spaces like Union Hall and Bell House. She first established her reputation in the borough in 2010, booking Hot Tub, which was created by the hosts Kristen Schaal and Kurt Braunohler on Monday nights. When that popular show moved to Los Angeles, Night Train, which she created with the host Wyatt Cenac, took over the slot. As soon as it ended in November (Mr. Cenac will have a show on HBO), she started Butterboy with three new hosts, Jo Firestone, Aparna Nancherla and Maeve Higgins. All of these became popular hits, sharing the same diverse aesthetic, progressive vibe and balance of famous names and new voices.", "title": "The Art and Anxiety of Booking a Hit Comedy Showcase", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Some families, perhaps the top 20 percent, have some ability to absorb these risks. But for the vast majority, there are major setbacks around every corner.\n\nMr. Trump and Congress have done nothing to alleviate those anxieties and, especially in higher education, the financial industry and health care, have worsened them. By contrast, Social Security and bank deposit insurance, while very different New Deal policies, all served the goal of security. They don\u2019t interfere with the free market \u2014 they just give people a bit of confidence in navigating it. The Affordable Care Act expanded this social contract, enabling people to share risk rather than taking it all on themselves.\n\nThe policies of the Trump-Ryan coalition weaken that confidence in three ways. The carelessness about policy, exemplified by the frantic process that led to the withholding mess, is the least important of the three. Specific policies also deliberately shift risk toward individuals: Consider the rules in the new tax act that encourage pass-through businesses, which will lead employers to convert employees into independent contractors, costing them protections such as unemployment insurance and health care.\n\nA proposal for paid family leave recently floated by Ivanka Trump and Senator Marco Rubio takes the policy of \u201cgive with one hand, take away with the other\u201d to an absurd extreme: New parents could pay for leave from their future Social Security payments, trading a week of paid leave for a week of retirement benefits, as if people could make a rational, informed choice between needs that will typically fall 40 years apart in the life cycle.\n\nFinally, this administration has eagerly taken down the guardrails intended to protect individuals from the worst predators: the \u201cfiduciary rule,\u201d which had required investment advisers to act in the interest of their clients; the hard-fought rules that protect students from worthless for-profit colleges and student loans they can\u2019t repay; and even the recent Labor Department rule requiring that employees receive the tips that are intended for them. Virtually every enforcement action of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been put on hold or canceled \u2014 even the investigation of the Equifax hack that disclosed the financial records of millions of people \u2014 exposing all of us to even more scams and tricks.\n\nThese rules are particularly vulnerable because they are recent \u2014 newer regulations are easier to reverse. They\u2019re recent because it was only in the third through last years of the Obama administration, once the urgency of the economic crisis of the late 2000s had receded, that the administration seemed to see reining in the scam economy as a defining goal and the new rules of the Dodd-Frank Act, including the powers of the C.F.P.B., were finally put into place. But the problem in political terms was that these pieces were not knitted into a big theme. Each action was in its own policy universe: student loans, investor protection, worker rights.\n\nGiving people some security from the scam economy is never going to involve one big program or idea, like universal basic income or single-payer health care. It will always involve dozens of policies, even to replace the dozens that are currently being dismantled.\n\nBut together they add up to a big theme, ensuring that people who pursue education, work hard and try to save for the future have some assurance that they will be able to navigate a complex and quickly changing economic climate. Progressives should give it a name, because it connects with the experience of every American outside of the very wealthy.", "title": "Opinion | The Art of the Scam", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHERE\u2019S A SCENE in the first season of \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d where Tony\u2019s sitting in the waiting room of his therapist\u2019s office, transfixed by a painting of a barn. He\u2019s convinced Dr. Melfi has hung it there manipulatively, to coax him into some kind of breakthrough. \u201cIt\u2019s just a picture I bought in a little gallery in Provincetown,\u201d she tells him. \u201cThat is a special-made, psychological picture,\u201d Tony counters, though of course it isn\u2019t.\n\nOne doesn\u2019t move through the world expecting emotional communions with workplace d\u00e9cor, but in New York, a number of seemingly anonymous locations \u2014 the lawyer\u2019s office, the doctor\u2019s, the dentist\u2019s \u2014 have become places to see the kind of art that you might only hope to view in a gallery or a museum. The contemporary art world is one of the most insular and self-satisfied subcultures in history, a milieu we think of as unplagued by anything so banal as paperwork or bodily functions. But every highly self-regarding tribe \u2014 no matter how creative or eccentric \u2014 has its own group of service providers: the people who maintain the tedious parts of life. What\u2019s remarkable about those who tend to the New York art world is not only how few of them there are but how many of them are paid: not with money, but with art.\n\nWHEN THE ART law attorney John Koegel opened his eponymous firm in SoHo, then the center of the art world, in 1982, a silver-haired Ileana Sonnabend and an elegantly dressed Leo Castelli \u2014 dealers responsible for the careers of Andy Warhol and Robert Rauschenberg \u2014 could be seen walking to their respective galleries in the mornings. In 1997, as the area\u2019s galleries began their northern migration to Chelsea, Koegel relocated a few blocks west, to the corner of Sixth Avenue and Spring Street, where he still works.\n\nKoegel\u2019s clients have included artists like David Salle, Judy Pfaff, Barbara Kruger, Jeff Koons and William Wegman, as well as some of the city\u2019s most prominent blue-chip art galleries and the estates of Max Ernst and Larry Rivers. His clients\u2019 work hangs in his office and in his house around the corner on Sullivan Street. \u201cEverything I own is by an artist I know,\u201d he told me. After attending law school at Fordham, Koegel worked for the Justice Department, and then went in-house at the Museum of Modern Art. When he moved his private practice to SoHo, simply being in the neighborhood where artists and gallerists lived was enough to secure his status as their resident lawyer.\n\nPhoto\n\nKoegel performed his first advice-for-art trade while working for a corporate firm in the early 1970s. He took on a largely unknown artist as a pro bono client and successfully sued a gallerist on his behalf for delayed payments. In lieu of a check, Koegel received a boxlike sculpture that resembled a work by surreal assemblage artist Joseph Cornell, which he still has. \u201cI want you to have this artwork because I hope one day I can afford a real lawyer,\u201d the artist told him. \u201cWhat do you think I am?\u201d Koegel remembered thinking.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrading services for goods is an anachronism, a barter system borne out of one party\u2019s poverty and the other\u2019s munificence. And yet in the art world, it\u2019s endured, even thrived; the practice is, if nothing else, humanizing, moving art from the marbled floors of the institution to some of the places we least anticipate beauty. Nowadays, of course, the trades are made not out of necessity, but from a mutual savviness about art and its market. Collecting art can be like dealing in futures, and one could argue that the credentialed lawyer who bills hourly is acting as a kind of speculator and taking on all the risk when he trades for what is in a sense magically minted money \u2014 but on the other hand, it\u2019s the artist whose work has the potential to appreciate in market value.", "title": "The Artist Has a Cavity", "authors": ["Alice Gregory", "The Artist S Life"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The austerity plan at Cond\u00e9 Nast coincided roughly with the sale of the once-mighty Time Inc. to the Meredith Corporation \u2014 the Des Moines-based publisher of Better Homes and Gardens and Family Circle magazines \u2014 in a $2.8 billion deal made possible by an equity infusion from Koch Industries, the conglomerate run by Charles G. and David H. Koch.\n\nWith Emerson Collective as its new patron, The Atlantic has avoided the grim fates of its fellow news organizations. In a memo to the staff, Mr. Cohn said that circulation is at an all-time high \u2014 it rose 13 percent last year \u2014 and that visits to TheAtlantic.com rose by 25 percent in 2017.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think quality journalism is a scarce commodity these days and I think the discerning readers reward places that are making stories that mean something,\u201d Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor in chief of The Atlantic, said.\n\nThe planned additions to the newsroom are meant to bolster the magazine\u2019s coverage of Washington, Hollywood, Europe and the tech industry.\n\n\u201cIt will be a mix of writers and editors and video producers and podcast producers and live events producers,\u201d Mr. Cohn said. \u201cThose are areas of coverage that we want to focus on, and we\u2019ll do it across all our platforms: digital, print, live events, video, audio, newsletters.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther jobs will go to engineers, designers and members of a new team the magazine has called Talent Lab, which is intended to \u201chelp us achieve one of our paramount goals: ensuring that our team is truly representative of America in all of its diversity,\u201d Mr. Cohn wrote.\n\nWhen it acquired a majority stake in The Atlantic, Emerson Collective \u2014 which focuses on education, the environment and immigration \u2014 expanded its portfolio of media and entertainment holdings. It is also an investor in Axios, a media company started by the Politico co-founder Jim VandeHei and its former star reporter, Mike Allen, and in Pop-Up Magazine. In 2016, it took a minority stake in Anonymous Content, the production and talent management company behind the movie \u201cSpotlight.\u201d\n\nThe organization also supports several nonprofit journalism organizations, including The Marshall Project, Mother Jones and ProPublica. It was founded in 2004 by Ms. Powell Jobs, the widow of the Apple co-founder Steven P. Jobs, who died in 2011.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEmerson is eager to see us grow and succeed, and they were excited at helping to make this happen,\u201d Mr. Cohn said.\n\nMr. Goldberg said he looks forward to bringing The Atlantic back to its 19th-century roots, when its founders, including heavyweights like Ralph Waldo Emerson and Oliver Wendell Holmes, viewed the magazine as a forum for some good old intellectual brawls and tussles.\n\n\u201cWe are in a moment of national fracturing, and our expansion allows us to do a lot more of the kind of work that really is in our DNA,\u201d Mr. Goldberg said. \u201cWe can double down on our coverage of Washington and this administration. We can double down on publishing the best and most interesting and thought-provoking ideas about the American future.\u201d", "title": "The Atlantic Plans a Hiring Spree", "authors": ["Jaclyn Peiser"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "This morning\u2019s job market report was definitely good. Job creation was surprisingly strong for this late in an economic expansion; wages are finally rising, although still far more slowly than they were before the Great Recession. You never want to make too much of one month\u2019s report, but this was clearly positive.\n\nAnd stocks plunged. What?\n\nOne answer is that stocks gonna do what they\u2019re gonna do \u2013 as Paul Samuelson famously put it, the market predicted nine of the last five recessions. But there\u2019s a bit of economic logic here too. One way of looking at recent economic data is that they\u2019re actually telling us that future U.S. growth will be lower than one might have hoped.\n\nIf we care about the medium term \u2013 say, 5 or 10 years \u2013 prospects for U.S. growth depend on two things. First, how much slack is there in the economy? How many people who aren\u2019t working can still be drawn into employment without inflation taking off?\n\nSecond, how fast will productivity \u2013 output per person-hour \u2013 rise?\n\nThe first question has posed something of a puzzle. Standard indicators like the unemployment rate and the quit rate suggest an economy at more or less full employment. (Quits matter because they tell us how easily workers expect to find new jobs.) But low wage growth suggested that there might still be substantial room to run.", "title": "Opinion | The Bad News in the Good News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The kids know it \u2014 they get that people who should be looking after them are looking the other way. After Trump spoke, a sophomore at the Parkland school stated the obvious in an interview with CNN. \u201cThere\u2019s no reason that a kid 19 years old that\u2019s been investigated already, and not even a year ago, being able to purchase an AR-15,\u201d said Isabella Gomez.\n\nThe gun used in Florida is similar to the kind of rapid-firing weapons used to mow down first graders in Newtown, club-goers in Orlando, civil servants in San Bernardino, and music-lovers in Las Vegas. In our country, a nation with a gun homicide rate 49 times higher than other wealthy countries, lunatics have easy and legal access to these guns.\n\nThe cops know the politicians are failing the kids as well. \u201cWhat about the rights of these students?\u201d said the Broward County sheriff, Scott Israel, in relaying the grim news of the latest massacre. \u201cDon\u2019t they have the right to be protected by the United States government, to the best of our ability?\u201d\n\nOf course they do. But the government will not protect them. The invertebrates in Congress and the soulless blowhard in the White House will not take even the most common-sensical measures to limit the use of militarized weapons by deeply troubled people.\n\nRemember the outrage over bump stocks, the modification used by the man who killed 58 people in Las Vegas last fall? If you don\u2019t, please remember it next November, at the ballot box. Congress has done nothing on this issue, but many states are moving on it, pressed by popular movements unafraid of the gun lobby.\n\nOther countries act to protect their people, which is the most elemental duty of governance. After Australia suffered the deadliest mass shooting in its history, a massacre of 35 people in 1996 by a man with a semiautomatic rifle, the country banned such weapons. There hasn\u2019t been a mass shooting since.\n\nLet me try another take for you bad parents in office. Pretend you live in a pleasant, well-protected community of like-minded people, and you\u2019re in charge. O.K., you don\u2019t have to pretend. And let\u2019s say there was a natural gas leak every three days in one of the homes in that community, a leak that killed entire families.\n\nYour response would be to pray and do nothing. Or to pray and talk about everything except the gas leak. Or to pray and say you\u2019re powerless to act because the gas company owns you. The response of those suffering would be to take control and kick you out. That\u2019s what we have to do, and will, next November.", "title": "Opinion | The Bad Parent Caucus", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cAmerica\u2019s Real Digital Divide\u201d (Op-Ed, Feb. 12):\n\nAs a public school educator, I find Naomi Schaefer Riley\u2019s analysis of the digital divide troubling. She begins with a range of research that I do not question regarding the problems associated with excessive television watching and video game playing for children. Oddly, she then uses this research to attack public schools for providing technology to students for learning.\n\nUsing technology in the classroom to ensure that students can communicate, create, collaborate or code is not the subject of screen-time research. While schools have more work to do to ensure that technology investments are used well to support student creativity and mastery of content, dismissing the digital divide as a gap between parents who do and don\u2019t limit screen time is simply arrogant.\n\nWhile most children have access to devices, the digital divide is between those children given the opportunity to create with technology and those using it only as consumers. Schools have an obligation to ensure that all children are learning to use technology as creators, contributors and collaborators.\n\nPAUL FOSTER\n\nSPRINGFIELD, MASS.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nWe applaud Naomi Schaefer Riley\u2019s Op-Ed essay. As parents, we know all too well the screen-time struggles that families face. Yet, as researchers of computer science education, we believe that Ms. Riley overemphasizes the quantity of screen time while ignoring the quality and content.", "title": "Opinion | The Battle Over Screen Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "The North Vietnamese captured Hue as part of the Tet offensive, a countrywide attack on American and South Vietnamese positions that began at the end of January and lasted, in some places, for weeks. In Hue, they occupied the Citadel, with its Chinese-style palace, which was built in the early 19th century to house Vietnam\u2019s emperors. With its surrounding moat, high walls and stone towers, the Citadel provided ideal defensive positions. It took the Marines, operating from a compound across the Huong River, almost a month to recapture it.\n\nI was embedded with Delta Company of the First Battalion, Fifth Marines, nicknamed Dying Delta because of its high casualty rate. On the day I shot my photos, they were advancing south along the eastern wall of the Citadel under fire from hidden positions. Civilians who had been hiding in their homes would appear from time to time and dash down the street, hoping to escape the battle zone. Sometimes they made it. Sometimes they didn\u2019t.", "title": "Opinion | The Battle for Hue, 1968", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere\u2019s a spirit to Peckham that you won\u2019t find anywhere else in London,\u201d said Luds van de Belt, site director of the newly-launched Peckham Levels, a 10-story car park that\u2019s been transformed into a studio block for artists. The enterprise, off the neighborhood\u2019s main street, Rye Lane, offers some of the least expensive artists studio in the area \u2014 a 12 square feet studio space rents from \u00a3260 to \u00a3290 (about $340 to $380) per month. Yearly, 10 studios are offered for monthly rents of just \u00a390 to artists with the lowest incomes.\n\nThe artist and craft maker Anastasya Martynova, who has a studio at Peckham Levels, sees the area as an integral part of her creative process. \u201cI think art as a whole has a tremendous power to unite people and encourage positivity,\u201d she said, \u201cand Peckham is the creative center of South East London. There is a real feeling of optimism for the future, and lots of raw, creative talent.\u201d\n\nThe requirements for Peckham Levels membership reflect the neighborhood\u2019s deeply-rooted sense of community. You have to be local and 10 percent of membership fees will go back into neighborhood initiatives. Members also have to commit at least one hour a week to volunteering in local projects.", "title": "The Beating Heart of London\u2019s Most Dynamic Art Scene", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nMy column today is about a recurring phenomenon: Trumpism for thee and not for me.\n\nPresident Trump and his congressional allies keep trying to protect their own constituents and allies from the agenda they\u2019re putting in place for the rest of the country. It\u2019s happened on offshore drilling, health care and taxes. And it\u2019s a sign that Trump and congressional leaders know how unpopular their agenda is. They\u2019re trying to protect their own supporters from it.\n\nOne of the stories I tell in the column is about Berea College, a small college in Kentucky that was the beneficiary of a special carve-out in last week\u2019s spending bill. The carve-out exempts Berea from a tax on colleges with substantial endowments. Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, went out of his way to protect Berea, the only college in Kentucky \u2014 the state he represents \u2014 that would have been subject to the tax.\n\nI find this episode especially unfortunate because Congress could have used Berea\u2019s example to pass a positive piece of education policy.", "title": "Opinion | The Berea College Carve-Out", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Last night, Raf Simons debuted his fall/winter 2018 men\u2019s wear collection, filled with models in heavy outerwear \u2014 almost 24 hours after Tom Ford\u2019s offering, in which they wore next to nothing. To see highlights from the New York men\u2019s shows, which mark the culmination of the men\u2019s collections that have spanned London, Florence, Milan and Paris, click through the slide show below (and be sure to check back throughout the week for our coverage of the women\u2019s shows).", "title": "The Best Images From Raf Simons and Tom Ford", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Watching, The New York Times\u2019s TV and movie recommendation site.\n\nEvery month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for February, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes schedules without giving notice. (Unfortunately, streaming information provided in our Watchlist listings applies only to viewers in the United States.)\n\nMovies New to Netflix\n\n\u201842 Grams\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAs part of the wave of innovative Chicago fine-dining destinations, chef Jake Bickelhaupt\u2019s 42 Grams picked up two Michelin stars within a year of opening, in part because of its uniquely intimate setting and ever-evolving menu. With Bickelhaupt\u2019s wife, Alexa, running the front of the house, the two entered into a successful partnership that nonetheless buckled under the combined stresses of their personal and professional lives. \u201c42 Grams\u201d offers up the eye candy of a typical foodie doc, but it also witnesses the volatility and ego that sabotage their dreams.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Being John Malkovich\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nFeb. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe screenwriter Charlie Kaufman burst onto the scene with this wholly original, playfully surreal comedy about a portal into John Malkovich\u2019s head that allows people to experience his state of being for 15 minutes at a time. Kaufman and director Spike Jonze delight in playing around in this metaphysical space, while also offering up such absurd creations as an office space on a half-floor and a 60-foot Emily Dickinson puppet. Yet \u201cBeing John Malkovich\u201d is sneakily moving, turning on the common and melancholy yearning of what it\u2019s like to want to escape your own skin.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Blue Crush\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLoosely based on Susan Orlean\u2019s magazine article \u201cSurf Girls of Maui,\u201d this late-summer hit from 2002 may be primarily about beautiful beaches and bodies in motion, but it overachieves in every respect. Director John Stockwell, who made the fine teen romance \u201cCrazy/Beautiful,\u201d has a good handle on the emotional state of a gifted young surfer (Kate Bosworth) who\u2019s trying to make it back in the water after near-fatal incident. Her comeback follows the usual sports-movie formula, but for surfing footage so spectacularly rendered, that much is forgiven.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Friday Night Lights\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBefore \u201cFriday Night Lights\u201d was developed into one of best dramas in recent network history, it existed onscreen as a solid adaptation of Buzz Bissinger\u2019s nonfiction book about a football-obsessed small town in Texas. Director Peter Berg doesn\u2019t have time to explore fully the characters and social complexities of Bissinger\u2019s book, but he does capture the pressure-cooker atmosphere of a place where football is religion. All that pressure is brought to bear on the coach (Billy Bob Thornton), who\u2019s expected to win every game or lose his job.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018In Good Company\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cIn Good Company\u201d has a record-scratch of a premise: A middle-aged advertising executive (Dennis Quaid) not only cedes his position to a new boss half his age (Topher Grace), he\u2019s also dealt the added humiliation having that young man date his daughter (Scarlett Johansson). Yet writer-director Paul Weitz, fresh off \u201cAbout a Boy,\u201d works the premise through an unexpectedly low-key comedy-drama, where the power dynamic between the two men shifts back and forth, revealing vulnerabilities about each.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Moon\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nFeb. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDuncan Jones\u2019s auspicious directorial debut feels composed of equal parts \u201c2001: A Space Odyssey\u201d and \u201cDark Star.\u201d Like the \u201c2001,\u201d it\u2019s a metaphysical head-trip about an astronaut (Sam Rockwell) relying on a possibly diabolical sentient computer (GERTY, voiced by Kevin Spacey) for companionship. Like \u201cDark Star,\u201d it has an abundance of low-budget charm, with a space station set that looks like an old rental, and an openness to whimsy. Rockwell stars as a loopy energy contractor who\u2019s thrown into chaos just as his final year on a lunar outpost is about to end.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Nightcrawler\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nFeb. 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWith a title that sounds like a reference to a B-movie monster, \u201cNightcrawler\u201d offers a ferocious beast in its antihero (Jake Gyllenhaal), an amateur cameraman who seeks out grisly footage to feed the \u201cIf it bleeds, it leads\u201d maxim of local broadcasts. His combination of ambition, shamelessness and moral vacuity makes him perfect for the job \u2014 and also the perfect target for the writer-director Dan Gilroy\u2019s dark, scabrously funny attack on media venality. Gyllenhaal\u2019s natural charisma makes it frighteningly easy to accept his character as a go-getter type, which allows Gilroy to escort the audience to some disturbing places.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Rolling Stones: Crossfire Hurricane\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe Rolling Stones haven\u2019t exactly been hurting for documentary immortalization, having already been the subject of films by the Maysles Brothers (\u201cGimme Shelter\u201d) and Martin Scorsese (\u201cShine a Light\u201d), just for starters. But the montage maestro Brett Morgen (\u201cThe Kid Stays in the Picture,\u201d \u201cJane\u201d) cuts together a fascinating, in-depth profile of the band from a combination of audio from new interviews and 50 years worth of archival film and video. If nothing else, the film is a reminder that the Stones were once revolutionaries, not just a bunch of dinosaurs playing the hits in football stadiums.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018A Most Violent Year\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 7\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cA Most Violent Year\u201d is the perfect example of the type of top-drawer production that would have thrived in theaters in the \u201960s and \u201970s \u2014 it might have shared marquee space with a film like \u201cSerpico\u201d \u2014 but doesn\u2019t fit any contemporary model for success. This superb third feature from J.C. Chandor (\u201cMargin Call,\u201d \u201cAll Is Lost\u201d) stars Oscar Isaac as a straight-arrow heating-oil magnate who has to bend the rules when payments on a new waterfront fuel yard come due and his drivers are suddenly harassed by violent carjackings. That leads some of the drivers to start carrying, themselves. We watch as a good man is led down the road to corruption.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Midnight Special\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 7\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn his first big swing for the studio fences, director Jeff Nichols (\u201cMud,\u201d \u201cTake Shelter\u201d) leaned heavily on Steven Spielberg\u2019s \u201cClose Encounters of the Third Kind\u201d for inspiration, but he couldn\u2019t help making a Jeff Nichols film instead. Audiences didn\u2019t know what to make of this interstellar curiosity, but cult fandom surely awaits this story of a father (a typically wired Michael Shannon) who steals back his son \u2014 a boy with extraordinary and perhaps otherworldly powers \u2014 from a religious cult that has been built around him. \u201cMidnight Special\u201d has that \u201cClose Encounters\u201d mix of obsession and wonder, but it is filtered through a more peculiar sensibility.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Django Unchained\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 15\n\nFeb. 15 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nQuentin Tarantino\u2019s biggest hit is also among his most audacious, a historical revenge fantasy along the lines of \u201cInglourious Basterds\u201d but with the action leading to a Mississippi plantation during slavery. Tarantino tramples over any sacrosanct notions of how such a racially sensitive topic might be approached \u2014 and in the same year \u201c12 Years a Slave\u201d won an Oscar, no less. But there\u2019s plenty of righteous exploitation-style kick to this story of a freed-slave (Jamie Foxx) who teams up with a bounty hunter (Christoph Waltz) to liberate his girlfriend (Kerry Washington) from an evil slaver (Leonardo DiCaprio).\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018The Final Year\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 18\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nShooting over 90 days in 21 countries, the documentary director Greg Barker expected to cement the legacies of three Barack Obama foreign policy appointees: Ben Rhodes, the Deputy National Security Adviser for Strategic Communications; Samantha Power, the Ambassador to the United Nations; and Secretary of State John Kerry. But the election of Donald Trump turned \u201cThe Final Year\u201d into an excruciating run-down of hard-won negotiations and accomplishments that were deemed likely to undone by the coming administration. Depending on your political persuasion, it\u2019s either a bittersweet reminder of Obama-era policymaking or a cause for schadenfreude.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix Original Movies\n\n\u2018On Body and Soul\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNetflix gambled smartly by picking up this Golden Bear-winning Hungarian drama, which just made the cut for an Oscar nomination for best foreign language film. Geza Morcsanyi and Alexandra Borbely star as workers at a slaughterhouse who happen to have the same dream every night, where they\u2019re deer that meet in the forest and fall in love. It seems only natural that the two are fated to be together, but reality and dreams turn out to be some distance apart.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Seeing Allred\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe nation\u2019s most prominent and controversial feminist lawyer, Gloria Allred was in the news recently for representing one of the women accusing Roy Moore, the Alabama Republican candidate for United States Senate, of sexual misconduct with a minor. This admiring documentary profile from Sophie Sartain and Roberta Grossman catches Allred just as she was shining a big media spotlight on a wave of Bill Cosby\u2019s accusers. But the film also takes a broader view of Allred\u2019s advocacy for women, and how it was able to develop considerable power.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix Original TV Series\n\n\u2018Altered Carbon\u2019: Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: Feb. 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis promising (and expensive-looking) Netflix Original series has a \u201cBlade Runner\u201d look and an intriguing premise, set in a future where human consciousness can be preserved on disks and transferred to new bodies. Joel Kinnaman plays one such body, a handsome specimen with martial-arts skills who\u2019s trying to solve a murder while experiencing echoes of previous corporeal forms. \u201cAltered Carbon\u201d has the look of modern noir \u2014 and a reputed abundance of sex and violence to match \u2014 but the premise opens up the possibility for a hard sci-fi treatment of memory and identity.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest (all categories): \u201cAbout Time\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cApollo 13\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cChef\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cThe Danish Girl\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cJohn Mellencamp: Plain Spoken\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cLimitless\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cThe Mermaid\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cOculus\u201d (Feb. 1). \u201cRay\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cThe Theory of Everything\u201d (Feb. 1), \u201cThe Mindy Project\u201d: Season 6 (Feb. 2), \u201cBaywatch\u201d (Feb. 9), \u201cMy Next Guest Needs No Introduction With David Letterman: George Clooney\u201d (Feb. 9), \u201cThe Joel McHale show With Joel McHale\u201d (Feb. 18), \u201cMama\u201d (Feb. 19) and \u201cBegin Again\u201d (Feb. 26).", "title": "The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Canada in February", "authors": ["Scott Tobias"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Watching, The New York Times\u2019s TV and movie recommendation site.\n\nEvery month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for March, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes schedules without giving notice. (Unfortunately, streaming information provided in our Watchlist listings applies only to viewers in the United States.)\n\nMovies New to Netflix\n\n\u2018Casino\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nMartin Scorsese\u2019s sumptuous three-hour epic about gangsterism in Las Vegas in the \u201970s and early \u201980s lays out the mechanics of a stem-to-stern scam while suggesting that the Disneyfied Vegas of today merely puts a better face on the city\u2019s criminal underpinnings. Sporting an astonishing wardrobe of retina-searing suits \u2014 44 in all \u2014 Robert De Niro stars as Ace Rothstein, a peerless sports handicapper who takes over the Teamsters-funded Tangiers Casino for the Chicago Outfit, but finds his efforts undermined by a vicious mob grifter (Joe Pesci), a prostitute-turned-hustler (Sharon Stone) and the local political cronies.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Fast Five\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNetflix is adding the first five entries in the \u201cFast & Furious\u201d franchise, but those disinclined to binge-watch 10 hours\u2019 worth of middling gear head action are advised to skip ahead to the fifth one. Although newcomers to the series will miss the patched-together mythology that brings its characters together, \u201cFast Five\u201d is essentially \u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven\u201d on wheels, an ensemble heist movie that steers into the curve of its own absurdity. Here, Vin Diesel and Paul Walker gather a team in Rio de Janeiro to peel away with $100 million of a shady businessman\u2019s money.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Steve Jobs\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nYour affinity for \u201cSteve Jobs\u201d will strongly correspond to your level of toleration/appreciation for the caffeinated dialogue in Aaron Sorkin\u2019s script for this biopic, which casts the turtlenecked Apple co-founder as half visionary, half megalomanic. Sorkin\u2019s smartest contribution is to divide Walter Isaacson\u2019s sprawling biography into three distinct acts, each around a product launch: The Macintosh computer in 1984, the NeXT computer in 1988, and the iMac computer in 1998. The actor Michael Fassbender channels Jobs\u2019s intensity and brilliance without downplaying his callousness.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018The Stanford Prison Experiment\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 3\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOffering the modest fee of $15 per day, Philip Zimbardo, a Stanford University psychologist, hired 15 male students to take roles as prisoners and guards in a 14-day experiment designed to help better understand prison culture and the root causes of abusive behavior. Six days later, the project was abruptly shut down. \u201cThe Stanford Prison Experiment\u201d is a scrupulous fictionalized recounting of the fiasco, which has endured as both a lesson in scientific ethics and a legitimate study in power dynamics. Michael Angarano is particularly good as an mediocre student who turns into a drawling John Wayne-style thug when cast as a guard.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Benji\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 6\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWith a new \u201cBenji\u201d coming to Netflix on March 16, Netflix is making the \u2026 er \u2026 \u201cclassic\u201d titles available, including the 1974 original, the first of five written around the scrappy little stray. In a twist on the typical family-dog scenario, the pup begins the franchise as a homeless freelancer who works his way into the hearts of the townspeople, especially a pair of siblings who feed and play with him behind their parents\u2019 backs. When the children are kidnapped, it\u2019s up to Benji to do the sleuthing necessary to find them.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Wind River\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAfter establishing himself as a strong genre-movie screenwriter with \u201cSicario\u201d and \u201cHell or High Water,\u201d Taylor Sheridan stepped behind the camera for \u201cWind River,\u201d a hard-edge murder mystery set on the Wind River Indian Reservation in Wyoming. Jeremy Renner stars as a game tracker for the United States Fish and Wildlife service, who agrees to help an F.B.I. agent (Elizabeth Olsen) investigate the murder a Native American girl on the reservation. The case forces him to confront the trauma of having lost his own daughter years before.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Crazies\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 31\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFrom the department of unlikely remakes comes this 2010 twist on a lesser-known allegorical horror film by George Romero, who is better regarded for \u201cNight of the Living Dead\u201d and its sequels. The early image of a gunman opening fire on a small-town baseball field was already tough to watch before James Hodgkinson attacked a Congressional baseball team last year. But \u201cThe Crazies\u201d soon settles into a non-zombie zombie movie about an Iowa sheriff (Timothy Olyphant) who tries to stop the spread of mass psychosis. An attack inside a carwash is particularly memorable.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 31\n\nMarch 31 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThough Charlie Kaufman may be the most original screenwriter of his generation, his scripts for films like \u201cBeing John Malkovich\u201d or \u201cAdaptation\u201d all follow a certain formula, constructing a high-concept latticework around a core emotional idea. That pattern continued with \u201cEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,\u201d which spends much of its time following Jim Carrey as he dashes around his own consciousness, chasing the memories he has paid to have erased after a failed relationship. But the film arrives at a poignant observation: The sum of our romantic experiences, even the ones that end badly, is greater than the pain we might wish to blot out.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Let Me In\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 31\n\nMarch 31 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 2010 Americanization of the fantastic 2008 Swedish vampire film \u201cLet the Right One In\u201d seemed unnecessary when it arrived, especially for fans of the original. But \u201cLet Me In\u201d isn\u2019t the artless remake many feared. Two excellent young actors, Kodi Smit-McPhee and Chlo\u00eb Grace Moretz, capably assume the lead roles as a bullied kid and the ageless vampire who befriends him. Director Matt Reeves maintains the moody, hushed integrity of \u201cLet the Right One In,\u201d resisting the urge to amplify the horror, and the film\u2019s effects are an unqualified improvement.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 31\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNascar culture gets an affectionate and riotously funny sendup in \u201cTalladega Nights,\u201d Adam McKay and Will Ferrell\u2019s follow-up to \u201cAnchorman,\u201d another comedy about a particular strain of macho overconfidence. Ferrell and John C. Reilly star as stock-car racers who dominate the circuit as the duo known as \u201cShake\u201d and \u201cBake,\u201d But their partnership unravels when a French Formula One racer (Sacha Baron Cohen) makes a claim for supremacy. For someone directing a comedy, McKay shoots the racetrack sequences with surprising brio, but the film belongs to Ferrell, whose All-American lunkhead calls his children \u201cWalker\u201d and \u201cTexas Ranger\u201d and thanks the Lord Baby Jesus for all the blessings at his dinner table.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018A Walk Among the Tombstones\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 31\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt\u2019s hard to keep track of all the bone-crunching Liam Neeson vehicles since \u201cTaken\u201d turned him into an action star, but \u201cA Walk Among the Tombstones\u201d stands out for its authentic grit, which puts it more in line with the noirs and Westerns of old than with contemporary action movies. Adapting the novel by Lawrence Block, the screenwriter-turned-director Scott Frank (\u201cOut of Sight\u201d) sends Neeson\u2019s alcoholic private eye in a bloody assignment to figure out who killed a drug kingpin\u2019s wife and kidnapped that man\u2019s daughter. There are no good guys in the film, including the hero, who has to sort out the bad from the irredeemably awful.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Winter\u2019s Bone\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 31\n\nMarch 31 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn retrospect, the \u201cHunger Games\u201d movies that made Jennifer Lawrence an A-list star are no more than a young adult fantasy version of her breakthrough role in \u201cWinter\u2019s Bone,\u201d which cast her as an intrepid teenager who\u2019s willing to sacrifice herself for her family. Instead of the rapacious dystopia of Panem in \u201cThe Hunger Games,\u201d Lawrence here has to fight through the rapacious dystopia of the Ozarks, where she searches for her father in a dangerous, meth-ravaged landscape. If she doesn\u2019t find him, her desperately poor family drops off the precipice.\n\nNew Netflix Original Films\n\n\u2018Layla M.\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nHow might radicalization actually work? The Dutch director Mijke de Jong offers a persuasive case study with this fictional account of a young Muslim woman in Amsterdam (Nora El Koussour) whose anger over Islamophobic policies leads her to get married, drop out of school and follow her husband to an austere religious community in Amman, Jordan. \u201cLayla M\u201d is about a headstrong woman whose convictions are met with different forms of oppression in Amsterdam and Jordan, tying her to a grim destiny like ropes to a railroad track.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix Original Series\n\n\u2018Collateral\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe veteran playwright and screenwriter David Hare, a two-time Oscar nominee for \u201cThe Hours\u201d and \u201cThe Reader,\u201d scripted this original four-episode BBC Two series about the investigation of a London murder with sensitive sociopolitical ramifications. Carey Mulligan stars as one of the officers investigating the case of a Syrian refugee who was shot and killed as he was working a food delivery job. As the case unfolds, the motives behind his assassination tip toward a disturbing commentary on England itself and its growing anti-immigrant sentiment.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Love\u2019: Season 3\n\nStarts streaming: March 9\n\nMarch 9 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nCreated by Judd Apatow and Lesley Arfin, and written with Paul Rust, this series about love and friendship between two immensely screwed-up singles in Hollywood was always funny, but it has become more textured and real as it has progressed. Mickey (Gillian Jacobs) and Gus (Rust) could be called \u201cfriends with benefits,\u201d but the ambiguity of their status tortures them both, along with their mutual gifts for self-destruction and sabotage.
