It basically announced that the end of the world was at hand. The decision to stop the clock on the running of a state\u2019s statute of limitations was an insult to the states, Justice Gorsuch declared, \u201cno small departure from our traditional principles of federalism.\u201d\n\nHe ended his 18-page opinion with a history lesson. \u201cWe\u2019ve wandered so far from the idea of a federal government of limited and enumerated powers that we\u2019ve begun to lose sight of what it looked like in the first place,\u201d he informed his colleagues. \u201cIf the federal government can now, without any rational reason, force states to allow state law causes of action in state courts even though the state law limitations period expired many years ago, what exactly can\u2019t it do to override the application of state law to state claims in state court? What boundaries remain then?\u201d\n\nThe author of a dissenting opinion in the Supreme Court has two choices. One is to proclaim that all is lost. That approach serves as a declaration of war that illuminates the defeat on a giant billboard and leaves no room for compromise the next time around, and there is always a next time. The other choice is to minimize the loss by sending the message that nothing much has happened here, saving the losing side\u2019s fire for the inevitable next round \u2014 or for things that really count.\n\nI can only guess that Chief Justice Roberts, if he was tempted for a split second to view this little case as the dissent saw it, recoiled from Justice Gorsuch\u2019s superheated language. What boundaries remain, indeed? My sense is that the chief justice reads this heavily freighted political moment as a time to avoid spending the Supreme Court\u2019s limited capital needlessly, in contrast to his junior colleague\u2019s evident desire to make as much noise as he can.\n\nMaybe I\u2019m wrong about that. But there\u2019s a clich\u00e9 in journalism that it takes three to make a trend, and I\u2019ve counted to three in just the past three weeks. If I\u2019m right, there\u2019s a realignment, however subtle, in progress at the court now that portends a future more hopeful, or at least more interesting, than appeared likely even a few months ago.", "title": "Opinion | The Chief Justice, Searching for Middle Ground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Spokane, Wash.\n\nNative country: Kenya\n\nAge when entered the United States: 6\n\nKamau, his mother and 1-year-old sister entered the United States legally, with visas to join his father, who was studying at an American university. His father was unable to renew his visa before it expired, after which the family stayed in the country illegally.\n\nWe lived a little bit outside of Nairobi. I walked to school at 6 years old, so we\u2019d see an airplane fly over, and my mom would say, \u201cDad took one of those and he went somewhere else and we are also going to get on a plane and go to be with him.\u201d\n\nI remember really weird things: having to go to different offices and take pictures for passports, go to the embassy, which is in the city. I don\u2019t think we had a phone in our house, so we would go to one of my aunt\u2019s houses to use one of those pay phones, the kind that you have to wind up.\n\nI remember packing a sweater that was way too big for me, but if I remember correctly, my grandmother had made it. I think it had a Transformer character on the front, and I remember she had told me in Swahili that I would grow into it. It took up a lot of space because it was a thick wool sweater. So I had to sacrifice a lot of things to make sure that it fit in my suitcase.\n\nHis class threw a goodbye party. The teacher had saved some time at the end of the day. There was a cake brought out. My friends sang and we celebrated and cut the cake. And afterward, my uncle pulled up with my mom and my sister and waved goodbye and we left.\n\nI think we had two transfer flights, maybe. I don\u2019t remember exactly, but only one of them had a movie in it. And the other was just very long because you just sat there and didn\u2019t have a lot to do. I just remember feeling like it was so long.\n\nI remember kind of just waiting for the people to come around with the snacks. That was the most excitement there was on the ride.", "title": "The Childhood Journeys That Made Them \u2018Dreamers\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Two years ago, Geetha Siddappa, a senior business analyst for a software company, was transferred from her home in Bangalore, India, to Iowa for work. It was a move that excited Ms. Siddappa and her husband, Abhishek Shanbog, who met a decade ago while working at a call center.\n\nThey lived in a two-bedroom apartment in West Des Moines with a balcony, dishwasher and washer-dryer, in a complex with a gym and pool, for which they paid around $1,050 a month.\n\nBut \u201cwe both were brought up in city culture, and living in West Des Moines was a letdown,\u201d Mr. Shanbog said. Though neighboring Des Moines is the state\u2019s capital, it seemed to shut down on weekends, he added: \u201cWe had imagined it would be crowded and superfun, but it was the opposite of that.\u201d", "title": "The City Trade-Off", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.\n\nTo Atlanta rappers like Gucci Mane and the members of Migos, Drew Findling is more than just a criminal lawyer \u2014 he\u2019s an indispensable ally, a mentor and, for some, a father figure. But Mr. Findling, the subject of a recent profile in The Times, also sits at the tricky junction of rap and criminal justice, a vantage that he says has spurred his activism on issues like mass incarceration and the parole system.\n\nPopcast The Complex Intersection Where Rap and the Legal System Collide A conversation with a criminal lawyer about the racial politics of legal representation, the Meek Mill saga and the future prospects of incarcerated would-be stars. Audio\n\nKenneth J. Montgomery, a fellow criminal lawyer who was raised in Brooklyn and built his practice there, is well-versed in these same worlds and civil rights issues. For a time, he defended the young rapper Bobby Shmurda, who was arrested in a gang sting just as his career was taking off. He has also worked with rappers including Mr. MFN eXquire and Sean Price; sued companies like Bad Boy and Roc-A-Fella; and observed the on-the-ground effects of hip-hop becoming pop music on the black youth in his community.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn this week\u2019s Popcast, Joe Coscarelli, The Times\u2019 pop music reporter, uses his story on Mr. Findling as a jumping-off point for an interview with Mr. Montgomery about rap\u2019s fraught relationship with the law. They discuss, among other topics, the racial politics of legal representation, the Meek Mill saga and the future prospects of incarcerated would-be stars like Bobby Shmurda and Kodak Black.\n\nEmail your questions, thoughts and ideas about what\u2019s happening in pop music to popcast@nytimes.com.", "title": "The Complex Intersection Where Rap and the Legal System Collide", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "But fewer people have considered what conservatives are risking: Union fair-share fees do not exist in an employment vacuum; the same logic and legal framework that permits the government to mandate these fees allows the government to conduct itself as an employer. Janus is largely being discussed as a case that is likely to defund and disrupt labor unions, but the case cannot simply injure unions and leave everything else intact.\n\nAt last count, federal, state and local governments employed over 21 million workers, so the courts have had to develop a framework for governments to be able to manage their work forces without constantly confronting the Constitution. Imagine if a teacher called in sick, and an administrator had to procure a warrant before searching her desk drawer for a text book, or else risk violating the Fourth Amendment. Or imagine if a police sergeant who tells an officer that he didn\u2019t have time to listen to a complaint about the break room now has to worry that he violated the First Amendment.\n\nThe Supreme Court has spent decades developing a framework for managing this tension and how the Constitution applies to the public-sector workplace. Starting in 1968, the court held that the \u201cgovernment has significantly greater leeway\u201d in managing citizen employees than in \u201cbringing its sovereign power to bear on citizens at large.\u201d\n\nThe Supreme Court has said the First Amendment applies only when the public employee can show that she spoke as a citizen on a matter of public concern. Similarly, in 1987, the court upheld a public employer\u2019s search of an employee\u2019s desk after balancing \u201cthe invasion of the employees\u2019 legitimate expectation of privacy against the government\u2019s need for supervision, control, and the efficient operation of the workplace.\u201d In 2010, the court extended this approach to employer-issued electronic devices, allowing a public employer to search them without a warrant if the search is \u201cmotivated by a legitimate work-related purpose.\u201d\n\nThe 1977 Abood case recognized that the government has an interest in \u201clabor peace,\u201d in permitting its employees to have an exclusive representative that can bargain on their behalf, and that workers who benefit from the union\u2019s activities should pay to support this collective-bargaining function. Therefore, the court created a balancing test that weighed the government\u2019s interest as employer in managing its work force with the employee\u2019s rights of free speech and association. According to this balance, any employee in the bargaining unit can choose not to join the union, and as a result pays only fair-share fees that cover union activities that are germane to collective bargaining.", "title": "Opinion | The Consequences of Judicial Activism on the Supreme Court", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Even those who have long since accepted the premise that Donald Trump is corrupt, self-centered and dishonest seem a bit shocked by his tirades over the Presidents\u2019 Day weekend. Using the Parkland, Fla., massacre as an excuse to attack the F.B.I. for investigating Russian election intervention on his behalf \u2014 while lying about his own past denials that such intervention took place \u2014 took vileness to a new level, which is truly impressive given Trump\u2019s previous record.\n\nYet if you step back a bit and think about it, Trump\u2019s latest outbursts were very much in character \u2014 and I don\u2019t just mean his personal character. When did you last see a member of the Trump administration, or for that matter any prominent Republican, admit error or accept responsibility for problems?\n\nDon\u2019t say that it has always been that way, that it\u2019s just the way people are. On the contrary, taking responsibility for your actions \u2014 what my parents called being a mensch \u2014 used to be considered an essential virtue in politicians and adults in general. And in this as in so many things, there\u2019s a huge asymmetry between the parties. Of course not all Democrats are honest and upstanding; but as far as I can tell, there\u2019s almost nobody left in the G.O.P. willing to take responsibility for, well, anything.\n\nAnd I don\u2019t think this is an accident. The sad content of modern Republican character is a symptom of the corruption and hypocrisy that has afflicted half of our body politic \u2014 a sickness of the soul that manifests itself in personal behavior as well as policy.", "title": "Opinion | The Content of the G.O.P.\u2019s Character", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "In sports, a vanquished people have been made promotional symbols for the aspirational ferocity of their vanquishers \u2014 on helmets, jerseys and souvenirs, from \u201cmenace\u201d to \u201cmerch.\u201d Go, warriors. I\u2019ve never seen tens of thousands of Indian tribesmen waving tomahawks in my direction. But I have seen 50,000 Atlanta Braves fans do it \u2014 chanting with foam tomahawks \u2014 and it\u2019s scary and savage in an altogether more disturbing manner. Had any of those chanters considered who beyond the stadium world would feel that chop? It\u2019s a loaded gesture that to some of us can be received as a threat.\n\nAmerican popular culture has long been marked by an absence of empathy for American Indians. Westerns doubled as a campaign against so-called savages in a way that desensitized us to the savages we\u2019d become. You don\u2019t even need to like these movies for their power as propaganda to work on you. Hollywood\u2019s spell was one anybody could fall under, even little Spokane Indian boys, like the writer Sherman Alexie. In a 1998 Los Angeles Times column, the adult Alexie laid out his own cognitive dissonance, in explaining just how John Ford\u2019s \u201cThe Searchers\u201d had ensorcelled him.\n\n\u201cI rooted for John Wayne as he searched for his niece for years and years,\u201d Alexie wrote. \u201cI rooted for John Wayne even though I knew he was going to kill his niece because she had been \u2018soiled\u2019 by the Indians. Hell, I rooted for John Wayne because I understood why he wanted to kill his niece. I hated those savage Indians just as much as John Wayne did.\u201d If that\u2019s the effect westerns could have on an American Indian, imagine the pride a white kid might feel in seeing Wayne, in movie after movie, outrun and defeat assorted Indian tribes, who sometimes weren\u2019t even the main villains so much as existential ones, and were typically played by white actors.\n\nThat\u2019s really what\u2019s vexing. You are what white American English speakers say you are. The young black and Hispanic men who in 1989 were accused of bludgeoning and raping a white woman in Central Park were dubbed the \u201cwolf pack.\u201d The New York Daily News ran a notorious headline about the victim: \u201cWolf Pack\u2019s Prey: Female Jogger Near Death After Savage Attack by Roving Gang.\u201d There, \u201csavage\u201d appears to capture the true barbarity of the crime. But alongside the rest of that animalizing language, it winkingly indicts the accused \u2014 who were teenagers \u2014 not only for being criminals but also for being black. In the media at the time, their blackness was made to seem inextricable from their presumed criminality. (In 2002, all five of their convictions were vacated after a convicted rapist confessed to the attack.)\n\nTo the wider world, the case introduced the word \u201cwilding,\u201d an offshoot of \u201csavage\u201d and an atmospheric description that felt more damning. \u201cEpisodes of poor, minority youths roaming the streets looking for trouble\u201d is how it\u2019s put in the publisher\u2019s description of Natalie Byfield\u2019s 2014 book \u201cSavage Portrayals: Race, Media and the Central Park Jogger Story.\u201d But \u201cwilding\u201d has always struck me less as a descriptor of behavior and more as a presumptive state of mind, a fever. Whatever ugly force seized the young Salem witches in Arthur Miller\u2019s \u201cThe Crucible\u201d had supposedly gripped those boys. (Of course, one person\u2019s wilding would just have been a typical group of teenagers to someone else.)", "title": "The Cost of Being \u2018Savage\u2019 in a Supposedly Civilized World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The Department of Homeland Security may soon formalize the abhorrent practice of detaining the children of asylum-seekers separately from their parents. Immigrant families apprehended at the southwest border already endure a deeply flawed system in which they can be detained indefinitely. In this immigration system, detainees too often lack adequate access to counsel. But to unnecessarily tear apart families who cross the border to start a better life is immoral.\n\nSadly, such separations are already happening. The Florence Project in Arizona documented 155 such cases by October and other immigrant advocacy organizations report that children are being taken away from their parents. If the secretary orders this practice to be made standard procedure, thousands of families could face unnecessary separation.\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s goal is to strong-arm families into accepting deportation to get their children back. Kirstjen Nielsen, the secretary of homeland security, admitted this when she told the Senate on Jan. 16 that separating families may \u201cdiscourage parents\u201d from seeking refuge in America.\n\nBut the increasing informal use of family separation has not proved to be a deterrent. Last year, the number of family apprehensions at the southwestern border skyrocketed from 1,118 families in April to 8,120 in December.", "title": "Opinion | The Cruel Ploy of Taking Immigrant Kids From Their Parents", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Consider the cocktail umbrella. Like their larger counterparts, these wee things can be furled and unfurled easily. Once you tire of playing with them, you can lock them into the open position with a little latch before continuing to enjoy your drink.\n\nNow imagine you have hundreds of cocktail umbrellas under your skin. This, it turns out, is fairly close to reality for cuttlefish, the sprightly relatives of squids and octopuses, according to new research.\n\nBiologists at the University of Cambridge and the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Mass., have discovered that cuttlefish, masters of camouflage whose shape-shifting talents have fascinated biologists for decades, can lock hundreds of tiny structures under their skin into an upright position, giving themselves a particular texture, then go on their way without expending any energy to keep up the look.", "title": "The Cuttlefish, a Master of Camouflage, Reveals a New Trick", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "After more than 30 years of research and more than $200 billion, the nation\u2019s ballistic missile defense program remains riddled with flaws, even as the threat from North Korean missiles escalates.\n\nStill, President Trump persuaded Congress to increase spending for the program to $14 billion, from $10 billion, in the 2018 budget, claiming in his national security strategy that plans to push the system \u201cwill include the ability to defeat missile threats prior to launch.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump is overselling the program, an interlocking network of interceptors, radars, sensors and so-called kill vehicles. He has boasted that the system is 97 percent effective in preventing limited-scale attacks; the truth is more like 50 percent. So its defense against North Korean weapons is hardly a sure thing.\n\nThe program\u2019s failings were on display as recently as last month, when, during a test off the Hawaiian coast, an interceptor missile launched from a test site in Kauai failed to hit its target, an incoming dummy missile. That was the second failure in three tests of the interceptor, the SM-3, which is intended to be a mainstay of American regional missile defense systems being deployed in Romania, Poland and Japan to guard against medium-range missiles. The Pentagon has not disclosed what went wrong.", "title": "Opinion | The Dangerous Illusion of Missile Defense", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "When I asked Peter Gasser how he remained calm during big air competitions, a family friend blurted out, \u201cTranquilizers!\u2019\u2019\n\nLauren Anderson, whose 27-year-old daughter, Jamie, won her second gold medal in slopestyle last week, said she wasn\u2019t one bit nervous that Jamie was now competing in the big air event as well. Even though Jamie has already broken her collarbone and pelvis, and once ruptured her spleen.\n\nLauren Anderson has eight children and raises alpacas on a farm in Vermont. She said she encouraged her children to learn from the heart and from \u201cthe friendly universe,\u201d and not necessarily from schoolbooks.\n\n\u201cWhen you have so many kids, you have to let them fall down and pick themselves up,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I also think, it\u2019s always going to be what it\u2019s going to be, so why don\u2019t you just relax and watch the show?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nI also approached Laura and Brook Corning, the parents of 18-year-old Chris Corning, who is from Colorado and among the world\u2019s top-ranked snowboarders.\n\nHis parents said they trusted that their son was both athletic and skillful enough to make big air not as perilous as it might seem.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChris Corning\u2019s whole life has been filled with what his parents call \u201ccalculated risk.\u201d At 3, he was already a skateboarder, with homemade ramps in their basement. At 7, he was a snowboarder. He once broke his thumb when it got stuck in a corrugated pipe in a snowboard park. He played football in high school, too, but eventually went just with snowboarding because the schedules conflicted.\n\nBesides, Laura Corning said, \u201cfootball is dangerous.\u201d\n\nMastering big air is all about starting small and making incremental improvements as a snowboarder, the Cornings said. First you try a half turn, then a full turn. Then eventually you\u2019re hitting 1080s, and more. It\u2019s how big air, eventually, doesn\u2019t seem like a big deal.\n\n\u201cWhat you want to do is just put Bubble Wrap on them because you don\u2019t want to see them get hurt or go through the pain,\u201d Laura Corning said. \u201cBut you can\u2019t. That\u2019s just not the best way to raise a child.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Laura Corning, a court reporter, this has been a learned mind-set. Brook Corning, a mechanical engineer, is the one with risk-taking in his genes.\n\nOnce, when Chris was about 9, his father took him backcountry snowboarding. Brook Corning said that he had to sign \u201cabout a billion waivers\u201d before they could go and that he had to strap a beacon onto Chris so the boy could be found in an avalanche. They were also given shovels and probes, in case they needed to dig out.\n\n\u201cWhen we were hiking across a knife\u2019s edge and there were cliffs on both sides, I thought, \u2018Hmm, maybe this really isn\u2019t a good idea,\u2019\u201d Brook Corning said. \u201cBut at the end of the day, we had so much fun. I\u2019ve always trusted Chris\u2019s athletic ability. It\u2019s astounding.\u201d\n\nHowever, when they came home, exhausted, and described where they had been, Laura Corning was furious.\n\n\u201cI just lost it and might have said a few curse words,\u201d she said. \u201cBasically, I\u2019ve been prepped for this big air and all that crazy stuff my entire parenthood.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA parenthood that sometimes means watching her son hobbling away after a jump or even being taken off the slope on a stretcher. In December, Chris Corning qualified for the Olympics despite hip and back injuries, and he gingerly stepped onto the podium afterward.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen he competes, Laura Corning said, she prays. \u201cGod, please keep him safe, angels\u2019 wings, angels\u2019 wings,\u201d she repeats to herself.\n\nThat nervous scene is partly why Cheryl Maas, the Dutch big air rider coming off a broken neck, doesn\u2019t want her parents watching her compete.\n\nHer mother, she said, \u201cfreaks out quite a bit,\u201d a reaction that was especially intense after Maas\u2019s crash at a World Cup event in Germany in 2016. \u201cI broke my face,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I think that scared her a lot.\u201d\n\nBut there is another reason Maas doesn\u2019t want her parents around \u2014 so she can skip worrying about them.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s always like, are they having a good time, how are they dealing with the mix of culture, are they able to get a bus, did they make it on the bus?\u201d Maas said. \u201cI don\u2019t want to think about that.\u201d\n\nMaybe, too, there\u2019s just a little less for Maas\u2019s parents to worry about than I first thought. When the announcer mentioned Maas\u2019s broken neck, he didn\u2019t bother to say that she hadn\u2019t hurt it while competing.\n\nIt actually happened on a vacation in Cyprus, where Maas dove into a shallow hotel pool.\n\nPeople can get hurt doing just about anything. Still deciding whether I\u2019ll tell my daughter that.", "title": "The Daredevils Above, Their Parents Below: Welcome to Big Air Snowboarding", "authors": ["Juliet Macur", "Sports Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "In this video Op-Ed, Emily Lynne offers a musical satire on dating in the #MeToo era. Below are the lyrics to her song.\n\nWhat Did You Say?\n\nI\u2019m single this year for the very first time.\n\nAll I want is a man who\u2019s not committed a crime.\n\nBut that feels very unlikely in this landscape we\u2019re in,\n\nmuch to my chagrin.\n\nAnd so I\u2019m going on dates,\n\nAnd I\u2019m truck\u2019n along,\n\nBut then all of these dudes,\n\nthey say a million things wrong.\n\nSo here\u2019s some examples of the straight dating scene", "title": "Opinion | The Dating Blues? #MeToo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Until now, he told me, most people assumed that no president would dare to flout norms against profiting from the office. Trump has shown otherwise. \u201cSo we need to have legislation that No. 1, requires the release of tax return information and, No. 2, requires presidential compliance, to the full extent allowed by the Constitution, with conflict-of-interest law,\u201d Eisen said.\n\nEisen also suggests strengthening the power of the inspectors general, officials charged with investigating fraud and abuse in government agencies. He argues that the Office of Government Ethics \u2014 which until now has relied largely on administration officials\u2019 capacity for shame \u2014 be given legal teeth, including subpoena power.\n\nAnd he thinks we need statutes laying out what it means to comply with the Constitution\u2019s emoluments clause, which prohibits government officials from accepting payments or gifts from foreign governments, and which no president has ever ignored the way Trump has. \u201cWe now know there\u2019s nothing to save us if you have a president who runs roughshod over these things,\u201d Eisen said.\n\nSteven Levitsky, a Harvard professor and a co-author of the recent book \u201cHow Democracies Die,\u201d cautions that new laws aren\u2019t enough to knit together the fraying civic fabric that allowed for Trump\u2019s rise.\n\n\u201cNo set of rules anywhere can respond to every situation, cover every ambiguity,\u201d he said. Even the most exacting regulations can\u2019t compensate for bad faith and a total-war approach to politics. Our political parties are so \u201cintensely polarized \u2014 and this polarization is being driven by Republican Party extremism \u2014 that they are willing to basically employ any means necessary to win,\u201d Levitsky said. \u201cAs long as that\u2019s the case, you\u2019re going to see politicians breaking norms and skirting rules, or using the letter of the law in ways that undermine its spirit.\u201d\n\nThis is almost certainly true, but people outside the Republican Party don\u2019t have the power to moderate it. All they can do is forcefully rebuke it, and the banana republic governance the party has imposed on the country it purports to love. De-Trumpification would be a way to officially mark this obscene presidency as aberrant, a negative example for future generations. Like a lot of parents I know, I\u2019m dismayed that my kids, now too little to understand what a president is, will someday study Trump in school. One of the great tasks of the post-Trump era will be ensuring that the lessons of his presidency are the right ones.", "title": "Opinion | The De-Trumpification Agenda", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The veterinarian who came to the house was very professional; she specializes in at-home euthanasia. Having heard the story and met Akeela, she concurred with our assessment.\n\nThe process of euthanasia involves two injections \u2014 one to sedate the dog and a second to stop the heart. Apparently, some dogs become agitated by the first injection, but Akeela quickly became very sleepy.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s tired,\u201d the veterinarian said.\n\nAs a physician, I was skeptical that Akeela\u2019s response to the sedative truly indicated whether it was time for her to go. But on an emotional level, what the vet had said made sense. Because of her Cushing\u2019s, Akeela had been panting on and off for months. And the worsening restlessness and circling had to have been taxing for her.\n\nI took Akeela\u2019s death hard. I truly believe that relieving her suffering was the humane thing to do.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut what did Akeela\u2019s end say about my own practice of medicine?\n\nIn contrast to veterinary practice, the medical profession has long forbidden the notion of speeding death. The Hippocratic oath, which dates to Greece in the fifth century B.C., states that a physician must not \u201cadminister a poison to anybody when asked to do so nor \u2026 suggest such a course.\u201d\n\nInstances in which physicians have participated in euthanasia have generally been wholly unethical. These include a program started by Nazi physicians in the 1930s to kill mentally ill and chronically infirm persons and over 100 controversial deaths facilitated in the 1990s by Dr. Jack Kevorkian, a pathologist who believed that terminal patients had a right to determine when they died.\n\nThere is one current exception to the prohibition on physicians expediting death: physician aid-in-dying. In six states and Washington, D.C., physicians may legally prescribe medications that terminally ill patients may take when they so wish. Numerous protections are written into these laws, such as making sure that the person is really dying and has full capacity to make decisions.\n\nI could think of stories similar to that of Akeela among my own patients. There was the blind woman who was bedbound, in pain and partially paralyzed from a stroke; another woman was skeletal from metastatic cancer and required constant sedation and analgesia. There have been many more. Some of these patients had explicitly expressed a wish to die, hoping that we doctors might, humanely, \u201cend it all.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMy experiences with Akeela led me to reflect on these cases. If suffering was so obvious and not reversible, and there was a way to provide immediate relief, was my reflexive refusal to assist in the dying process always the right thing to do? And if the patient, fully understanding all of his or her options, was asking for death, didn\u2019t this make him or her more worthy than a dog, whose suffering could only be assumed? I had little doubt that family members, seeing a loved one suddenly at peace, might have said what our vet said to us: \u201cShe was tired.\u201d\n\nBut in my own practice, I can never countenance euthanasia. Hippocrates\u2019 sentiments from over 2,000 years ago resonate for me. Doctors are in the business of healing bodies, not harming them \u2014 even if that \u201charm\u201d potentially provides relief from the same type of suffering we find unacceptable in our pets.\n\nHaving said this, I am not opposed to telling my patients about physician aid-in-dying. Indeed, were they so inclined and prepared to move to a state where it is legal, I might help them make the transition. And if aid-in-dying became legal in my own state, New York, I would consider making a referral to a physician who might prescribe the necessary drugs.\n\nOf course, for most patients, moving to another state near life\u2019s end is neither desirable nor practical. And in many cases, the process could never be implemented in time. Fortunately, though, there are now better medications to treat the symptoms of dying and a specialty, known as palliative care, that can provide expert guidance in doing so.", "title": "The Death of the Doctor\u2019s Dog", "authors": ["Barron H. Lerner"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "If you do this as a barometer activity, post the terms \u201cStrongly Agree\u201d and \u201cStrongly Disagree\u201d at opposite ends of the classroom. Ask students to stand up and move to a spot in the classroom that most aligns with their beliefs about each statement. After you have read a statement and students have taken a stand on the continuum, ask a few volunteers to explain why they decided to stand where they did. If you choose to do this in pairs, have students talk together about their reactions. In both cases, you may want to first set ground rules about the language students should use to ensure that discussion of these issues is respectful.\n\nVideo: Then, have students watch this brief video featuring immigrants currently protected by DACA. Ask students to write down their reactions and any questions they have. Have the class share.\n\n_______\n\nArticle and Questions\n\nPhoto\n\nTo get a better understanding of the politics surrounding DACA, have students read \u201cWhat Is DACA? Who Are the Dreamers? Here Are Some Answers,\u201d also available in this PDF (slightly abridged).\n\nHere is an excerpt:\n\nWhat is DACA? The program was introduced in 2012 by President Barack Obama as a stopgap measure that would shield from deportation people who were brought into the United States as children. The status is renewable, lasting two years at a time. The program does not provide a pathway to citizenship. Participation in the program comes with a range of benefits. Along with permission to remain in the country, recipients can also get work permits, through which many have obtained health insurance from their employers. The ability to work has also allowed them to pay for school, pursue higher education and, in some states, drive legally. The program also opened up access to in-state tuition and state-funded grants and loans in some states. And depending on where they live, recipients can also qualify for state-subsidized health care.\n\nAsk students to answer the following questions as they read:\n\n1. When was DACA introduced, and what benefits does it provide its participants?\n\n2. Who are the Dreamers? What requirements must they meet to be eligible for DACA?\n\n3. Why did President Trump announce in September he was ending DACA?\n\n4. What concessions do the White House and many Republican lawmakers want in exchange for providing a path to citizenship for DACA beneficiaries?\n\n5. Why are many progressives, immigrant advocates and DACA recipients hoping for a \u201cclean\u201d Dream Act, and what would that law offer the Dreamers?\n\n6. What will happen if Congress cannot come up with a solution and the injunction against the DACA phaseout is lifted by the courts?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_________\n\nActivity\n\nPhoto\n\nQuote Sort: In this activity, students work in small groups to sort eight quotes about DACA, included in this PDF, into three piles:\n\nPile 1: Quotes we primarily agree or sympathize with\n\nPile 2: Quotes we primarily disagree or do not sympathize with\n\nPile 3: Quotes we cannot agree on\n\nStudents can take turns reading quotes aloud. After each quote is read, the group discusses which pile the quote belongs in.\n\nHere are two examples of quotes included in the PDF:\n\nThe common misconception is that DACA is a handout, however it\u2019s anything but. The only thing DACA \u201chanded\u201d to me was hope. I was able to get a job for the first time, I was allowed to get my license, and go to college. To have hope about my future. Currently I\u2019m studying communication and media, with no federal student aid as I did not qualify as a DACA student, just the scholarships and grants I earned in school. I don\u2019t know what the future holds, but I\u2019m not afraid. I\u2019m 21 years old and spent 15 of those years in the USA. This is my home and I\u2019m here to stay. \u2014 Mila Ipek Acar, student from New York, N.Y. Granting legal status to Dreamers could potentially cause a domino effect in which other families bring young children, hoping that in time their children will be granted legal status. \u2014 Jaclyn Haak, 19, a chemical engineering student at the University of Minnesota\n\nAfter students sort the quotes, groups can report back to the class about which quotes they tended to agree or disagree with \u2014 or which quotes ended up in Pile 3 because they could not reach a consensus.\n\nClosing Activity or Exit Ticket: Each student should choose one quote from the previous activity that he or she disagrees with and write a thoughtful response capturing what they think about the DACA program and what Congress should do. You may want to have students write their response as a letter addressed to that individual.\n\n_________\n\nFollow-Up Activity\n\nThe Learning Network will announce its Fifth Annual Student Editorial Contest on Feb. 28, and submissions will be accepted from then until April 5. Students can write editorials about anything, but one topic that certainly seems relevant right now is the issue of DACA and what will happen with the Dreamers. You can consult our 2017 rules to learn more about the contest while waiting for this year\u2019s official announcement.\n\nBefore they get started, students can do additional research. Relevant articles in The Times include:\n\nA Typical \u2018Dreamer\u2019 Lives in Los Angeles, Is From Mexico and Came to the U.S. at 6 Years Old\n\nWith DACA in Limbo, Teachers Protected by the Program Gird for the Worst\n\nMost Americans Want Legal Status for \u2018Dreamers.\u2019 These People Don\u2019t.\n\nThe Childhood Journeys That Made Them \u2018Dreamers\u2019\n\nFor DACA Recipients, Losing Protection and Work Permits Is Just the StartAmerican Dreamers\n\nTrump Immigration Plan Demands Tough Concessions From Democrats\n\nSenate Begins \u2018Wild\u2019 Week of Debate on Immigration, Outcome Unknown\n\n\n\nAlternatively, you can have students write their opinions in a letter or email that they send to a member of Congress. Use these links to find your Representative\u2019s contact information and your Senator\u2019s contact information.\n\n_________\n\nAdditional Resources\n\nPBS | Lesson plan: How DACA Demonstrates the Importance of Civic Engagement\n\nKQED | Lesson Plan: The History and Human Face of DACA\n\nAnti-Defamation League | What Should Be Done About DACA?", "title": "The Debate on Dreamers : A Lesson Plan for Teaching About DACA", "authors": ["Michael Gonchar"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Darrisaw and Mr. Cheeks met at a party at his West Village apartment in February 2012.\n\n\u201cShe was really pretty,\u201d Mr. Cheeks said, \u201cbut I thought she was a little stuck-up.\u201d\n\nBut he had scored a few points by ordering vegetarian appetizers from her favorite vegan restaurant.\n\n\u201cMy first thought was that he was cute and kind of charming,\u201d she said. \u201cThere was a bit of a spark.\u201d\n\nSeveral months later, Ms. Darrisaw, who was now single, was out with friends celebrating a new job. They were at a restaurant in Harlem when Mr. Cheeks, also unattached, walked through the door.\n\n\u201cHe looked extra nice that day,\u201d said Ms. Darrisaw, who wasted no time turning that old spark into a new flame. \u201cYou should take me on a date,\u201d she said, momentarily stunning Mr. Cheeks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Cheeks, who said that Ms. Darrisaw \u201cseemed on par with my original feeling that she was stuck up,\u201d said he simply told her, \u201cFine, give me your number.\u201d\n\nHe did not call that weekend. \u201cI thought maybe he just blew me off,\u201d she said.\n\nAs it turned out, Mr. Cheeks lost his cellphone in a cab and had to ask their mutual friend, through Facebook, for Ms. Darrisaw\u2019s number. When he finally connected with her in August 2012, she appeared to be putting him off, saying that she was headed to the 2012 Olympics in London, and would start a new job shortly thereafter. She also said she planned on spending about three months concentrating on her new job, which meant that she wouldn\u2019t be able to see him until October.\n\n\u201cAt first I was aggressive with him, and then I went and flipped the script,\u201d Ms. Darrisaw said. \u201cSo I thought for sure he wouldn\u2019t stick around.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Cheeks surprised her. \u201cI thought, \u2018O.K., she\u2019s very serious about her career, and that\u2019s a good thing,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cIf she wanted to take it slow, well, I had some time on my hands.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce again, he scored a few more points.\n\n\u201cThe fact that he was cool about my plan and he didn\u2019t seem offended made him very attractive to me,\u201d Ms. Darrisaw said. \u201cThat told me that he was very respectful of my work and my boundaries.\u201d\n\nIn October he called, and they went on a first date at the same restaurant where he had first ordered vegetarian appetizers for her.\n\n\u201cShe was cooler and a lot more down to earth than I expected her to be,\u201d Mr. Cheeks said.\n\nShe was feeling much the same about him. \u201cA part of me had thought that since he was the son of a great N.B.A. player, he\u2019d be a little full of himself,\u201d Ms. Darrisaw said. \u201cBut we laughed so much and had such good chemistry together.\u201d\n\n\u201cI was never someone who kissed on a first date,\u201d she said, \u201cbut I definitely did some kissing that night.\u201d", "title": "The Delay Game Worked for Both of Them", "authors": ["Vincent M. Mallozzi"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "What happened in America in 2016 is exactly what I would have predicted for a developing country pursuing elections in the presence of a deeply resented market-dominant minority: the rise of a populist movement in which demagogic voices called on \u201creal\u201d Americans to \u201ctake back our country.\u201d\n\nTrumpism is part of a global pattern, but Europe\u2019s right-wing nationalist movements aren\u2019t the only or even most apt comparison. American politics today has as much in common with the developing world as it does with Europe. Time and again, vote-seeking demagogues with few political credentials have swept to power in developing countries by tapping into deep-seated resentment toward a market-dominant minority. President Trump is neither the world\u2019s first \u201ctweeter-in-chief\u201d nor the first head of state to star on a reality TV show. That would be Hugo Ch\u00e1vez of Venezuela.\n\nVenezuela, too, has a market-dominant minority: the light-skinned, insular elite that historically controlled the country\u2019s corporate sector and its staggering oil wealth. Like Mr. Trump, Mr. Ch\u00e1vez swept to victory in 1998 on an anti-establishment platform, attacking the mainstream media, the \u201crotten oligarchs\u201d and a slew of \u201cenemies of the people.\u201d He won over millions of the country\u2019s have-nots with unscripted rhetoric that struck elites as vulgar, outrageous and often plainly false. But Venezuela\u2019s majority saw in Mr. Ch\u00e1vez a leader who looked and spoke like them.\n\nSeeing coastal elites as a market-dominant minority is sobering. In my research, I\u2019ve found no examples of countries successfully overcoming this problem. On the contrary, all over the world, when this dynamic takes hold of a nation\u2019s politics, a result has been an erosion of trust in institutions and in electoral outcomes. Countries lurch toward authoritarianism, hate-mongering and an elite backlash against the popular side of democracy.\n\nSigns of all these developments are present in the United States. As to the latter, right before the 2016 election, a book review in The New Yorker discussed \u201cthe case against democracy,\u201d including proposals to impose knowledge tests on voters (something Latin American elites have been writing about for a long time). The review quoted from a book by Jason Brennan, a libertarian political philosopher at Georgetown, who wrote that \u201cexcluding the bottom 80 percent of white voters from voting might be just what poor blacks need.\u201d\n\nThis is not the way forward. If any way out exists, it will have to be both economic and cultural. Restoring upward mobility should be viewed as an emergency. Upward mobility is what made America different from developing countries that have disintegrated. Research shows that zero-sum political tribalism is worst under conditions of economic insecurity and lack of opportunity.\n\nBut the emergence of coastal elites as an insular minority is also rooted squarely in the breakdown of national unity \u2014 in the fracturing of our country into two (or more) Americas in which people from one tribe see others not just as the political opposition, but as immoral, evil and un-American. America desperately needs leaders with the courage to break out of the tribalist cycle, but where are we going to find them?", "title": "Opinion | The Destructive Dynamics of Political Tribalism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s a warning to the Senate minority leader, Chuck Schumer, and other environmentally inclined Senate Democrats, like Sheldon Whitehouse and Ed Markey: A legislative minefield lies dead ahead, pocked with destructive amendments of Republican origin hostile to clean air, clean water, endangered species and fragile landscapes. And here\u2019s a plea: Stop these measures from becoming law.\n\nFollowing its approval of the big budget deal on Feb. 9, Congress began writing the dozen appropriations bills that direct federal dollars to specific agencies. These bills are likely to be incorporated in one giant omnibus spending measure to be negotiated over the next few weeks by House and Senate leaders in advance of the March 23 expiration of the continuing budget resolution that has kept the government going.\n\nGiven its urgency, the bill is fertile ground for the kind of mischief the Republicans in particular have been notorious for over the years \u2014 loading up must-pass bills like this one with provisions, known as riders, that in most cases could not survive on their own and thus need protective cover. In years past, such riders were usually inserted at the last minute on the House or Senate floor. Here they are in plain sight, having been approved in earlier votes or endorsed by powerful committee chairmen or chairwomen who will do their level best to make sure they are included in the final bill. Mr. Schumer can prevent that from happening. The Democrats are effectively 49 in number, the Republicans 51. By holding his party together, he can deny the Republicans the 60 votes they need to overcome a filibuster \u2014 ensuring a clean bill, and a cleaner environment.\n\nPublic interest groups have counted nearly 90 of these riders, but here are several of the worst:\n\nClean water In 2015, the Obama administration adopted a landmark rule intended to clarify and broaden protections for smaller streams and wetlands vital to the country\u2019s drinking water and wildlife. Although the bill simply reaffirmed the reach of the original 1972 Clean Water Act, developers and big farmers complained to Scott Pruitt, the industry-friendly head of the Environmental Protection Agency, who has begun the lengthy process of replacing the rule with something more favorable to commercial interests. That\u2019s not fast enough for the leaders of three separate appropriations panels \u2014 in the House, the interior and environment subcommittee and the energy and water development subcommittee; and in the Senate, the interior and environment subcommittee \u2014 who are pushing nearly identical riders that would kill the rule right away, without consulting the public or conducting the scientific analysis required by law.", "title": "Opinion | The Dirty Little Deals That Would Foul the Environment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Subways get delayed for all kinds of reasons these days \u2014 electrical problems, sick passengers, debris on the tracks.\n\nOn Friday, it was a runaway dog.\n\nHer name was Dakota, and she shut down F service between Brooklyn and Manhattan for more than an hour before a subway worker found her two stations away from where she entered.\n\nDakota, a poodle, was at the dog park in Brooklyn near the Manhattan Bridge at 2:55 p.m., the police said, when something spooked her. She ran.", "title": "The Dog Was Running, So the Subway Was Not", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "As far as I can tell, this is an excuse to continue to criticize men and masculinity without attending to the positives of men and masculinity. It will not do anything to bring our country together, or to end the tensions between the sexes.\n\nMichael Ian Black: 1. Aggression can certainly be a beneficial trait. The flip side of this in your examples are the often debilitating symptoms soldiers, police officers, and firefighters exhibit as a result of their jobs. So many of these men are reluctant to seek help for the simple reason that, for so many men, needing help is the same as being weak, anathema for men.\n\n2. I agree with you that a shooter\u2019s motive cannot be reduced to something as simple as \u201cbeing a man,\u201d nor did I mean to imply so. My larger point is that we need to examine why only men commit these crimes. What is going on with our boys and young men that allows them to walk into a public space and open fire, but not girls and young women? My piece is an attempt to start talking about that question.\n\n3. My interest in writing this piece was not \u201cbring the country together; it was an attempt to reduce gun violence and try to broaden the conversation from guns to other possible contributing factors, including the preponderance of boys committing these crimes.\n\nBobotheclown: To have a loving father figure requires that he be secure, which requires that he has a job. In today\u2019s world there are millions of people with no hope of ever being employed again. The real problem is that work itself is broken and the means by which men have always defined themselves is disappearing. A man without work is not a man at all, in the internal calculus of American masculinity. A man who no longer has a positive self-image cannot possibly raise a boy to have one. The problem is not just that our boys are broken but that our men are broken as well.", "title": "Opinion | The Downsides (and Upsides?) of Aggressive Masculinity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Or consider how this dynamic might apply in the restaurant industry (or retail, or tourism).\n\nThe basic technology for self-serve kiosks has been around for years. But when the unemployment rate was at its post-crisis highs, employers could have their pick of good workers at relatively low prices. Now, with the jobless rate at 4.1 percent, good workers are harder to find. And, perhaps unsurprisingly, companies have been more open to installing technology that may have a significant upfront cost and require reworking how a restaurant is organized, but allow more sales without hiring more workers.\n\n\u201cA consequence of a really tight labor market is a higher turnover rate,\u201d said Liah Luther, marketing manager at Nextep Systems, a Michigan company that sells self-ordering kiosks to restaurants, casinos and corporate facilities. \u201cOnce you eliminate the need for extensive training on a point of sale system, you can focus on soft skills like customer service, and reduce the cost of turnover.\u201d\n\nThe optimistic case for both productivity and overall economic growth goes like this: For the last several years, a lack of demand and plenty of spare capacity of both workers and equipment made businesses complacent and unwilling to invest in new equipment, software or new ways of doing things that might allow more output per hour of labor.\n\nNow, with companies having a harder time finding qualified workers and with demand for their products rising, they\u2019ll have no choice but to re-engineer how they work to try to increase productivity. Higher productivity will in turn make it easier to justify higher wages, creating a self-reinforcing cycle of higher economic growth.\n\nThere are some risks to that rosy forecast, which Ms. Remes and Mr. Manyika warn about.\n\nThey see a great deal of potential from digitization of businesses that have been slow to embrace the lessons of the cutting-edge companies in their industry. But this might be slow to generate the kinds of big productivity gains that are possible.\n\nEven as more retailers adapt to an age of digital commerce and learn from Amazon, for example, they may in the near term end up simply doubling up traditional retail and e-commerce-focused workers, making such companies less productive rather than more.\n\nAnd if automation leads to more income going to owners of capital, who already tend be wealthy, that could hollow out middle-class jobs and fuel higher inequality.", "title": "The Economy Is Getting Hotter. Is a Productivity Boom Next?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Such individual experimentation is not the same thing as the scientific method; it lacks the proving tests of replication and consensus. But the two approaches are more closely related than today\u2019s apostles of scientism often suggest. They proceed from the same intense curiosity, the same desire for understanding through experience \u2014 and personalized experimentation can be the only way to be empirical when your subject is the strange nexus of the self.\n\nEvery human life is, in this sense, a science experiment, and how we choose to react when our assumptions are tested defines the real scope of our curiosity. If you refuse any non-F.D.A.-blessed treatment for chronic illness because there\u2019s no controlled study proving that it works, or have a religious experience and pre-emptively dismiss it as an illusion without seeing what happens if you pray, you may be many things, but you are not really much of an empiricist.\n\nWhich is why in many instances the interests that Pinker dismisses as irrational hugger-mugger, everything from astrology to spiritualism, have tended to strengthen during periods of real scientific ferment. It\u2019s why Isaac Newton loved alchemy and the Victorians loved s\u00e9ances; it\u2019s why charismatic Christianity has spread very naturally with economic development in Africa and Latin America and why the Space Age coincided with the spread of all those health food stores.\n\nIt\u2019s not that there is some quantum of unreason that needs an outlet when reason\u2019s power grows. Rather, it\u2019s that when people and societies are genuinely curious they are very reasonably curious about everything, including things happening in their bodies and their consciousness and more speculative realms.\n\nWhich is why if Pinker and others are genuinely worried about a waning appreciation of the inquiring scientific spirit, they should consider the possibility that some of their own smug secular certainties might be part of the problem \u2014 that they might, indeed, be stifling the more comprehensive kind of curiosity upon which the scientific enterprise ultimately depends.", "title": "Opinion | The Edges of Reason", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "These days at Barbetta, most guests dress casually. On a recent evening, Rick Miramontez, the press agent for \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d and \u201cSpringsteen on Broadway,\u201d sat tie-less in the lounge, something he would not have dared to do when he visited for the first time in 1979. \u201cIt was very dressy, very starched, a necktie place through the \u201980s, no question,\u201d he said.\n\nIndeed, from its townhouse exterior to its brocade chairs and swag curtains, Barbetta is a throwback to the days of the fancy restaurant. There are no distressed-wood tables, no mixologists or vertical gardens on the premises. How it has managed to stay in business boils down to the realities of commercial real estate, the restaurant\u2019s jewelry-box d\u00e9cor and reputation as an oasis of quiet refinement. And also the constant devotion of Laura Maioglio.\n\nIn the 1960s and \u201970s, besides the chic theatrical types who frequented Barbetta, the restaurant was also part of a high-society dining scene in Midtown that served as the backdrop for a shifting culture. In 1969, for example, Ms. Maioglio had a front row seat to what The Times described as the \u201cpants suit onslaught\u201d \u2014 some establishments had started to permit women in pants, while others did not. One evening, Laura and her mother were refused a table at La C\u00f4te Basque when a ma\u00eetre d\u2019 accused her of wearing pants, which were forbidden. \u201cThey were palazzo pajamas,\u201d she said. \u201cYou couldn\u2019t even tell they were split; they looked like an evening dress. \u2018Very good,\u2019 my mother said. \u2018We\u2019re going to the Four Seasons.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Maioglios were hospitable to the core. Along with an older brother, Vincenzo, Sebastiano had opened his first restaurant, Maioglio Brothers, on West 39th Street in 1906 when he was a 26-year-old immigrant from Fubine, in Northern Italy (where Ms. Maioglio still owns a small palazzo and vineyard). The original restaurant was near the old Metropolitan Opera House and luminaries who dined there included Enrico Caruso, Giacomo Puccini and Arturo Toscanini.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1925, Mr. Maioglio paid around $250,000 for four contiguous brownstones on West 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, built by the Astor family in the latter 1800s. He moved the restaurant to his new collection of buildings and renamed it Barbetta, Italian for \u201clittle beard,\u201d in honor of Vincenzo\u2019s facial hair. His brother died the following year. Laura was reared in an apartment upstairs, in a neighborhood that some maps refer to as Hell\u2019s Kitchen.\n\n\u201cIt was not Hell\u2019s Kitchen,\u201d Ms. Maioglio said heatedly. \u201cIt\u2019s a very ugly term and was not used in my lifetime.\u201d\n\nBarbetta is the oldest restaurant on the block. \u201cAs every retailer and restaurateur knows these days, if you own your property instead of renting it, that\u2019s the significant factor in being able to last in New York City,\u201d said Tim Tompkins, president of the Times Square Alliance. \u201cLaura has stuck with her business through enormous odds, the nature of the challenges on that block going from too much drug traffic in the \u201970s and \u201980s to too much car traffic in the last decade.\u201d\n\nIn 1973, when 16 establishments lined that particular strip, Mayor John Lindsay designated it Restaurant Row. Today, more than three dozen restaurants \u2014 stalwarts like Joe Allen, Orso and Becco \u2014 steal some of the spotlight from Barbetta, whose incandescent, vertical sign is made of opal glass. A forerunner of neon, it is the last of its kind in the city, according to the book, \u201cNew York Neon,\u201d by Thomas E. Rinaldi.\n\n\u201cBarbetta itself and Restaurant Row more broadly represent the contrast of tradition and turnover,\u201d Mr. Tompkins said. \u201cTo use an automobile metaphor, Barbetta is a Bentley, whereas Joe Allen is a Range Rover. When you look at the mix of other places on the street, there are five Japanese restaurants and a Bareburger that cater to a new demographic.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite her heritage, Laura Maioglio was not groomed for the restaurant industry. She attended the Brearley School on the Upper East Side and studied art history at Bryn Mawr. Her parents steered her toward cultural pursuits, taking her to Carnegie Hall, to the opera, on trips across America and to Italy.\n\n\u201cMy father was highly intellectual, interested in the arts and music, but his family couldn\u2019t afford to give him a university education,\u201d she said. \u201cHe didn\u2019t think running a restaurant would satisfy me. Nevertheless, I was very determined and naughty.\u201d\n\nHer strong will came into full force when her father became ill. In the early 1960s, she went behind his back to beg a buyer to renege on a deal he\u2019d made to take over Barbetta. She couldn\u2019t bear to see it leave the family.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHow could you have done this?\u201d was the only criticism Laura heard from her ailing father when he learned she\u2019d scuttled the transaction.\n\n\u201cUntil the middle of the 20th century, nearly all restaurants were owned and run by individuals, or families, as opposed to companies,\u201d said William Grimes, a former New York Times reporter and the author of \u201cAppetite City: A Culinary History of New York.\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s only in our own time that we have seen the corporatization of the restaurant business and the rise of upscale operations like the Union Square Hospitality Group.\u201d\n\nOnce Ms. Maioglio had saved the family business, she set to work refurbishing the interior, scouring Italy for chandeliers and antiques and ordering reproductions of upholstered chairs she saw in museums. What began as a handsome, inexpensive restaurant became a haute experience emphasizing the Piedmont region and its prized Barolo and Barbaresco wines. She reimagined the backyard as an Italianate garden. A fairy-tale wisteria tree of tangled vines is nearly big enough to camouflage a cast of \u201cInto the Woods.\u201d At the center is a fountain where four peeing cherubs sit astride the rim.\n\nNow in its 112th year, Barbetta is one of the city\u2019s oldest family-owned Italian restaurants and certainly the oldest second-generation, family-owned Italian restaurant. Bamonte\u2019s, in Williamsburg, is a little older, founded in 1900, but the fourth generation is now dominant.\n\nThere is no third generation waiting to take over at Barbetta. Ms. Maioglio and her husband, G\u00fcnter Blobel, who won the 1999 Nobel Prize in Medicine, have no children.\n\nMs. Maioglio won\u2019t disclose her age. \u201cAge is a number and mine is unlisted\u201d is her line. On a night in late December, she wore a black and white patterned dress, gold Adidas sneakers and a jaunty beret over silver hair that fell past her shoulders. A walking stick was propped nearby. At intervals, she greeted passing guests \u2014 largely out-of-towners \u2014 with a nod and a genial \u201cbuona sera.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRecalling that night when Mr. Jagger waited for his tardy friends \u2014 his bandmates \u2014 Ms. Maioglio schooled her mother on the Rolling Stones before they were led to a table. Piera Maioglio offered them a bottle of Dom P\u00e9rignon \u201cand acted like she\u2019d been listening to them for years.\u201d They were so delighted by Piera they dubbed her \u201cMum\u201d and became regulars. When she died in 1984, a band member \u2014 Ms. Maioglio can\u2019t remember which \u2014 brought flowers to the restaurant.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve served Keith Richards,\u201d said Eduardo Maglio, 67, a garrulous man in a black tuxedo who has worked at the restaurant since 1989. He denied having a title other than \u201cdoing anything Laura tells me, but mostly talking to people and serving celebrities. I\u2019m very good at that.\u201d\n\nEfforts to track down the Rolling Stones for corroboration failed, but in a 1977 Interview magazine piece, Andy Warhol (who became another regular) asked them, \u201cWhere do you eat in New York?\u201d Ron Wood cited Barbetta, with Jagger chiming in, \u201cRonnie likes Barbetta \u2019cause it\u2019s so romantic.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat romantic reputation has endured. Valentine\u2019s Day is the busiest night of the year. A small orchestra, led by Felix Endico, will perform swing and cafe society music that evening, as they have for several years.\n\nOn Saturday nights year-round, Mr. Endico, 60, wears a pocket square and plays American songbook standards on an upright Steinway piano in a dining room whose hue can be described as blushing. \u201cAs Time Goes By\u201d is part of his repertoire, resonant in a place where time seems to have stopped long ago.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the foyer is a baroque harpsichord that never gets played, shelves of 19th-century Staffordshire truffle hound figurines and a 20th-century (disconnected) phone booth. Throughout the restaurant and its four private dining rooms are original fireplaces, detailed woodwork and massive mirrors fit for the Royal House of Savoy. A computer is on the premises but so is carbon paper for making copies.\n\nFor cash transactions at the bar, Konstantinos Hristeas, known as Gus, springs open the drawer of a brass cash register built in 1912. He wears a black bow tie and white dinner jacket and said that he has been a bartender there for 38 years, or maybe 42.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t pay attention, time goes by,\u201d Mr. Hristeas, 69, said.\n\nHis manner was reserved but his eyes kindled when he recalled his teenage hunger for night life, climbing out the window of his home in Kalamata, Greece, to see his friends. He never wanted to become a baker, like his father, and he followed a sister to New York in the 1960s, when he was 18. He landed a job at El Morocco, the fabled nightclub on East 54th Street. As far as he knows, he is the only ex-staffer still on his feet.\n\n\u201cYou went there to be seen and photographed,\u201d said Mr. Grimes, the reporter. \u201cA dazzling array of film stars, entertainers, socialites, sports figures \u2014 notables of all sorts \u2014 made it their mission to sit on the zebra banquettes and strike a pose.\u201d\n\nBy comparison, Barbetta is quiet and sedate. When Mr. Hristeas sees celebrities, they pass him by on their way to the dining room.\n\nAt El Morocco, Frank Sinatra was one of his regulars. Mr. Hristeas recalled one night when Sinatra, known for his \u201c$100, $150 tips,\u201d asked a manager how much he\u2019d have to pay for a certain crystal object on display. The manager set a price, Sinatra paid, then shattered it at the table. He removed something from the center of the broken glass, Mr. Hristeas said, and set it on fire. It was an image of Ava Gardner, one of Sinatra\u2019s ex-wives.", "title": "The Elegant Relic of Restaurant Row", "authors": ["Julie Besonen"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "In theory, the G.O.P. restrictionist position on immigration is perfectly legitimate. But Trump has fatally entwined it with his constant race baiting. Republican politicians could have denounced the race baiting but remained silent. They allowed themselves to become fellow travelers to bigotry, and spoiled their own cause.\n\nThe fact is that the scarcity mentality and the perpetual warrior style it demands are incompatible with any civilized political creed. At first the warriors seem to be fighting for the creed but eventually they transform it.\n\nUnder the influence of this mentality, evangelicalism turns from a faith into a siege-mentality interest group that reveres a pagan immoralist. Under the influence of this mentality, liberalism goes from a creed that values individual rights and deliberation to one that values group separatism and intellectual intolerance.\n\nThe scarcity mentality always ends up eating the host philosophy because it operates on a more fundamental level of the psyche.\n\nAll of this would be survivable if the mentality was going away in a few years. But it is not going away. The underlying conditions of scarcity are only going to get worse. Moreover, the warrior mentality builds on itself. As the right pulverizes the left, the left feels the need to pulverize back, and on and on. This is a generational challenge. Trump will be succeeded by some other warrior.\n\nEventually, conservatives will realize: If we want to preserve conservatism, we can\u2019t be in the same party as the clan warriors. Liberals will realize: If we want to preserve liberalism, we can\u2019t be in the same party as the clan warriors.\n\nEventually, those who cherish the democratic way of life will realize they have to make a much more radical break than any they ever imagined. When this realization dawns the realignment begins. Even with all the structural barriers, we could end up with a European-style multiparty system.\n\nThe scarcity mentality is eventually incompatible with the philosophies that have come down through the centuries. Decent liberals and conservatives will eventually decide they need to break from it structurally. They will realize it\u2019s time to start something new.", "title": "Opinion | The End of the Two-Party System", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The variety of baskets in the world \u2014 with their distinct shapes and materials and techniques and uses \u2014 is endless. In the way that history can be told in words, so too can it be read through craft \u2014 objects ingeniously fashioned out of necessity from whatever was on hand. Almost any plant whose parts are pliable, or can be made so by soaking in water \u2014 including roots, vines, pine needles, grasses, stems, even trees \u2014 can be turned into a basket. Broad materials, such as palms in the tropics, are plaited like braids; narrow materials, such as grasses on the Savannah, are coiled like ceramic pots; while stiffer materials, such as willow in the lowlands, are woven like tapestry. Trade, migration and war have meant that techniques and styles spread and have often mingled. There is a beautiful spiral weave done in Burkina Faso that somehow made its way to the Dordogne in Southern France, where it was used for garden baskets. In South Carolina, the Gullah, descendants of slaves, made sweetgrass baskets using a coiling technique brought from West Africa by their ancestors.\n\nPhoto\n\nFew places in the world, however, have as enormous a variety of basketry as England. Most are made of willow, a wonder material that is at once flexible, lightweight, strong, endlessly renewable and easy to cultivate. (Cut the tree to the ground and it will resprout; push a branch into the earth and it will take root.) In the way that Eskimos have 50 or so words for \u201csnow,\u201d the British have nearly 200 for their baskets. There were seven different types for the herring trade alone: for trapping, for sorting, for holding ice, and one, the quarter cran, made to precise government specifications as a measure for pricing. Each particular need \u2014 whether agricultural, industrial or domestic \u2014 would be resolved by a basket uniquely configured for the task. Well into the first half of the 20th century in Britain, there were wicker prams and mail carts; butcher delivery baskets (distinct from bakery baskets); carriers for messenger pigeons and ammunition drops; and containers for broadcasting seed and hauling brick.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe tend to think of basketry as a rural endeavor, which it mostly was until the 1800s, when Britain began to rapidly urbanize. Industrialization, rather than signaling basketry\u2019s demise, heralded a peak, as baskets were required to service the factories and towns. Basket-making became professionalized and specialized, with weavers \u2014 distinguished for the first time from growers, preparers, salespeople and repairmen \u2014 laboring side by side in workshops. This new breed of journeymen weaver underwent five to seven years of apprenticeship; each became proficient at many different baskets (sometimes over a thousand if you include all the variations). But during World War I, cheaper baskets imported from poorer countries, as well as wooden crates, were becoming more readily available; and by the 1960s, the English basketry industry collapsed under the weight of plastic.\n\nOf course, industry demands efficiency, but along with basketry\u2019s diminishment comes the disappearance of the enormous breadth of knowledge embodied in those weavers. Just two of the men (they were all men) who trained under that 19th-century system \u2014 Colin Manthorpe, 80, and Terry Bensley, 79 \u2014 are still alive. They are sought out by some of today\u2019s best makers, such as Adrian Charlton and Hilary Burns. The Devon-based Burns recalls that observing Manthorpe weave a herring cran was like \u201cwatching a dance; there was no wasted movement.\u201d Despite the loss of this know-how, what had already vanished long before was something more profound, namely, the connection of a maker to his landscape, and the life that entails.\n\nPhoto\n\nAFTER THE LEAVES drop from the willow, in January and February, O\u2019Sullivan and McWalter, along with a few friends who have come to love these yearly outings, head into the cold, wet field to harvest the rods with secateurs, or pruning shears. It is physically demanding work, both the cutting and the stacking, as well as the carrying of the heavy bundles, and yet \u201cit is easy to sound nostalgic,\u201d O\u2019Sullivan says. \u201cThere is this gentle connection to the land \u2014 and to one another. In the midst of the drudgery, which it is, you look up at blue sky or birds or you have a cup of tea. You pass each other and have an intense conversation for 15 minutes, and then you drift apart, and after a while you lose each other completely in the tall willow, and then you find your way back to one another.\u201d\n\nBetween March and May, the willow is sorted by variety and size and left to dry. On the short path between kitchen door and studio is the open shed where these satisfyingly neat bundles of willow \u2014 yellow, lime green, mocha, black \u2014 are leaning. After soaking the reeds for a day or two, O\u2019Sullivan begins her work on the floor, using her knee or foot to hold the rods in places as she creates a base. Pushing long pieces in all around it, each of which she scores with a knife and bends upright to form the structure, she builds every basket stick by stick.\n\nO\u2019Sullivan\u2019s decision to fashion her life in this way is a choice that a country basket-maker in the past would not have had the luxury of making. Steeped as her work is in tradition, it is driven by her design sensibility (she invents her own forms), and her desire to live lightly on the land in an increasingly imperiled environment. A basket\u2019s perishability is part of its beauty \u2014 it will last a few lifetimes before disappearing back into the ground. Until then, \u201cI want these baskets to become part of people\u2019s lives, to get battered, to be polished by their hands,\u201d she says, \u201cand to have crumbs and bits of wood in the bottom of them.\u201d", "title": "The Enduring Appeal of: Baskets", "authors": ["Deborah Needleman"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Renewable energy combined with regional integration also allows countries to diversify energy sources, protecting against the impacts of climate change on hydroelectric supplies. Today, Latin America is dependent on hydropower for about half of all energy generation, and changing rainfall patterns caused by climate change are making hydroelectric power more unreliable in some countries.\n\nIn 2001, Brazil experienced a severe drought that led to a drop in water levels at hydroelectric dams, leaving millions of people and businesses without electricity for months. In 2016, Colombia imposed emergency energy-saving measures to avoid blackouts after a major drought. That same year, Venezuela experienced a drought that dried up the supply of water for the main generation basin in the Caroni River.\n\nIf current trends hold, electricity sector emissions of carbon dioxide, the largest source of greenhouse gases, will increase by 19 percent and other dangerous air pollutants like sulfur and nitrogen will grow by over 50 percent between 2016 and 2030. But if the region expands renewable energy and grid integration, electricity sector carbon emissions will drop by 15 percent and other contaminants by 10 percent.\n\nStill, energy integration in Latin America is woefully inadequate. The region needs to add about 12,000 kilometers of cross-border transmission lines with about 15,000 kilowatts of power to take full advantage of its potential. But the principal obstacle standing in the way is political.\n\nMost countries are reluctant to rely on their neighbors for energy, deeming self-sufficiency more important than cost, reliability and sustainability. Rather than pursuing this narrow view of energy security, Latin American countries should embrace the advantages of electricity diversification by interconnecting.\n\nIn addition to building the physical infrastructure, many countries need to develop the right institutions, rules and regulations to enable liquid and efficient electricity markets.\n\nCentral America, for example, would greatly benefit from expanding its regional grid, given the isthmus\u2019s high electricity prices and reliance on imported oil. To encourage investment, the regional electricity market\u2019s regulatory framework must be strengthened.
