This includes determining the cost of transmission rights and tolls for sending electricity across borders, setting up long-term power purchase agreements on the regional market to provide more security for multicountry investments and unifying national and regional regulations.\n\nWhile these steps are technically and economically feasible, they require governments to challenge vested interests and relinquish some control over their national power systems. This is not easy to do, but an integrated energy grid would be good for Latin America and for the planet.", "title": "Opinion | The Energy Solution Latin America Needs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mere days ago, in what feels like a different era now, the biggest thing that people in control of money appeared to fear was complacency. Stock markets in the United States were surging, enthralled by the regulation-slashing, tax-shrinking predilections of President Trump. Every major economy in the world was expanding.\n\nThe worst that could happen, the money masters averred, was that investors would be lulled into reckless investments, taking on too much risk in the belief that the dangers of the marketplace had been tamed.\n\nAs it turns out, the dangers were already at work. A decade-long era of easy access to money engineered by central banks in Asia, Europe and the United States was ending, opening a new chapter in which corporations would have to pay more to borrow and ordinary people would have to pay more to finance homes, cars and other purchases.\n\nTo digest the wild swings in stocks and bonds from New York to London to Tokyo is to absorb this uncomfortable realization taking hold.", "title": "The Era of Easy Money Is Ending, and the World Is Bracing for Shocks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "But there\u2019s no certainty that will happen. It may be that the United States has more growth potential than standard models suggest. Perhaps corporate income tax cuts and looser regulation on business will unleash more capital investment and higher productivity, as conservatives argue. Maybe some of the millions of prime-age adults who have dropped out of the labor force in recent years will come back in, creating more economic potential.\n\n\u201cThe really big question mark we have is how much slack there really is in the economy,\u201d said Donald Marron, a scholar at the Urban Institute who was once acting director of the Congressional Budget Office. \u201cIf you look at conventional measures, unemployment looks really low, but on the other hand if you look back to what we used to think of the potential of the economy a few years ago, we may have some room to grow.\u201d\n\nThe Long Run: Higher Debt-Service Costs and Less Room to Maneuver\n\nThe public debt was already on track to rise relative to the size of the economy before the new tax and spending deals; now it will probably rise faster. The Congressional Budget Office projected last June that the nation\u2019s debt-to-G.D.P. ratio would rise to 91 percent in 2027, from 77 percent in 2017.\n\nThe C.B.O. hasn\u2019t updated those numbers to reflect the new tax and spending legislation, but the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates that it will turn out to be between 99 and 109 percent, depending on whether provisions of the tax law are allowed to expire as they are scheduled to.\n\nBut those numbers are just an abstraction. The question is what effects higher debt loads might have for Americans in 2027 and beyond.\n\nHigher debt service costs are one big one. Taxpayers in 2027 were forecast to pay $818 billion a year in interest costs even before the tax cuts and spending increases, or 2.4 percent of G.D.P. That will presumably be higher, because taxpayers will be paying interest costs on more debt, and probably at higher interest rates.\n\nAnd there is probably some point at which the amount of debt the government takes on crowds out private investment; to the degree that the supply of funds to borrow is finite, every dollar the government borrows is not available to be lent to a homeowner taking out a mortgage or a business looking to expand. That said, in practice, the supply of loanable funds is not finite \u2014 households may save more with higher interest rates, for example, and foreign capital might flow in.", "title": "The Era of Fiscal Austerity Is Over. Here\u2019s What Big Deficits Mean for the Economy.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Since coming to power in Poland in 2015, the nationalist Law and Justice party has enacted one outrageous measure after another, placing the nation\u2019s courts under political control, trying to do the same with the news media, purging the civil service and, most recently, criminalizing any suggestion of Polish complicity in the Holocaust. Behind these moves runs a concerted and dangerous rewriting of history to create a narrative of heroic Polish victimhood \u2014 under the Nazis and Communists, of course, but also as a maligned defender of traditional values against a degenerate and controlling European Union.\n\nThere is more than a little irony in the way Poland has turned on the European Union. Billions in the union\u2019s funds have been used to build Poland\u2019s highways and roads, sewage systems, kindergartens and other facilities. Poland\u2019s exports, largely to other member countries, have boomed, and young Poles travel and work all across Europe. The countryside, where support for Law and Justice is particularly strong, has been among the biggest recipients of the union\u2019s largess. Biting the hand that feeds it is a gentle way of putting it.\n\nNonetheless, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the real power behind Law and Justice, has built his populist appeal on resisting what he describes as the European Union\u2019s effort to dictate cosmopolitan cultural terms (and immigrant quotas). To portray the bloc\u2019s policies as oppressive is ludicrous, but as Steven Erlanger and Marc Santora of The Times recently wrote, Law and Justice has thrived on contrasting a \u201cconservative, Catholic Poland and its family values with a godless, freethinking, gender-bending Western Europe.\u201d\n\nThere has always been a dollop of victimhood in the Polish national narrative, largely for sound reasons, given Poland\u2019s history of partitions. But for Mr. Kaczynski \u2014 as for some other populist leaders in Eastern and Central Europe, most notably Hungary \u2014 the purpose of rewriting history in this way is to gain power.", "title": "Opinion | The European Union Must Stand Up to Polish Nationalism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "TO LOVE AND TO CHERISH: Tayari Jones\u2019s fourth novel \u201cAn American Marriage\u201d \u2014 Oprah\u2019s latest book club pick, currently sitting at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list \u2014 traces the lives of Roy, a black man wrongly convicted of rape, and his wife, Celestial. Their stories unfold through the letters they write each other while he is in prison. \u201cThe horror of this story lies in its banality: An innocent man, happily married, who does all the right things to succeed, is nonetheless sidelined to a concrete cell,\u201d Stephanie Powell Watts wrote in the Book Review.\n\nThe idea for \u201cAn American Marriage\u201d came to Jones one day in an Atlanta mall. She told NPR, \u201cI overheard a couple arguing. He looked fine, but she looked great. And she said to him, \u2018Roy, you know you wouldn\u2019t have waited on me for seven years.\u2019 And he said, \u2018I don\u2019t know what you\u2019re talking about; this wouldn\u2019t have happened to you in the first place!\u2019\u201d\n\nIn her first draft, Jones focused on Celestial. \u201cBut writing about her didn\u2019t seem quite honest,\u201d she explains. \u201cRoy\u2019s situation is so urgent that I just needed to hear his voice. So then I rewrote the whole thing from his point of view. The draft was solid, but I thought it was too familiar \u2014 it was basically a reboot of the \u2018Odyssey.\u2019 Roy was a man returning home after a tremendous battle, and all he wants is to find a faithful wife and a gracious house.\u201d Then, when hearing the poet Claudia Rankine read from her book \u201cCitizen,\u201d the lines \u201cWhat happens to you doesn\u2019t belong to you. It\u2019s not yours. Not yours only\u201d struck her. \u201cThis is when I came to understand that what happens to Roy may be an ancient story, but there is a modern way to tell it,\u201d she says.\n\nWrongful imprisonment and mass incarceration are topics that have \u201calways been at the forefront in black communities,\u201d Jones explains. \u201cSince childhood, I have harbored a fear that prison would abduct the men in my life. I think I can trace it back to when I was a little girl and my father came home late, after getting lost trying to give our housekeeper a ride home.\u201d", "title": "The Experiences That Inspired \u2018An American Marriage\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "2005\n\nWhile on vacation in Florence, Ms. Holderness took a photograph of herself with a black eye, which she said was taken shortly after Mr. Porter punched her. After the photos were published in The Intercept, Mr. Porter said in a statement that the images were misleading. \u201cI took the photos given to the media nearly 15 years ago, and the reality behind them is nowhere close to what is being described,\u201d he said.\n\n2008\n\nMr. Porter and Ms. Holderness divorced.\n\n2009-2013\n\nMarriage to Jennifer Willoughby\n\nNov. 26, 2009\n\nMr. Porter married Jennifer Willoughby. During their honeymoon, Ms. Willoughby said, Mr. Porter frequently became angry and yelled expletives at her.\n\nJune 19, 2010\n\nMs. Willoughby filed a protective order against Mr. Porter in an Arlington County, Va., court after saying that he violated their separation agreement, came to their apartment and punched the glass in the door to their home.\n\nNovember 2013\n\nMr. Porter and Ms. Willoughby divorced.\n\nDecember 2016\n\nA woman dating Mr. Porter at the time reached out to Ms. Willoughby and Ms. Holderness, detailing abuse and seeking advice on how to leave him.\n\n\u201cI work in politics, and despite Rob\u2019s repeated abuse, some of which I think many know about, he continues to rise and I\u2019m afraid to go against him,\u201d the woman wrote to Ms. Holderness, according to Facebook messages. \u201cI\u2019m sorry to bother you. I wanted to reach out and hear your story if you are willing to share \u2014 as well as how you broke out of it with him and mostly, how you recovered.\u201d", "title": "The F.B.I., Domestic Abuse and the White House: A Timeline of the Rob Porter Scandal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "One by one, the hopes crash and the snow flies.\n\nAn athlete falls. The poetry of their movements, calibrated over many years to propel them toward glory, is interrupted in an instant. It twists into something uncoordinated and unrehearsed. Winning form becomes survival mode. Hopes turn to prayers.", "title": "The Fall Games", "authors": ["John Branch"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "But what both activists and their critics are missing is that if #MeToo draws on the work of Ms. MacKinnon and Ms. Brownmiller, it\u2019s also rooted firmly in the tradition of the other radical Second Wavers. These women were absolutely pro-sex, pro-pleasure and pro-freedom. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to learn to sleep with people because we want them,\u201d one woman said in a consciousness-raising session transcribed by the author of \u201cThe Dialectic of Sex,\u201d Shulamith Firestone, in 1968. \u201cNot to prove anything to them, not to make them feel better about their masculinity, not out of weakness or inability to say no, but simply because we want to.\u201d\n\nBut they also understood that if rape and harassment were political, so was bad sex. In a 1980 essay, the radical feminist Alix Kates Shulman remembered that in those early sessions, \u201csex was a central and explosive subject to which we continually returned\u201d; feminists \u201cused their sexual discontents to help them understand the power relations between men and women.\u201d\n\nI was reminded of this history when the website Babe published its Aziz Ansari article in January. The account of the so-called bad date, during which Mr. Ansari is alleged to have badgered a woman into going further than she wanted to, was an example of reckless reporting and was cited by many as #MeToo\u2019s too-far moment. But the instinct that it was an important article was correct. The issue of consensual yet joyless and unsatisfying sex was the same one my mom and her friends were grappling with 50 years ago.\n\nAt bottom, #MeToo is not about hashtags or individual firings. It\u2019s a chance to reset the table of sexual politics \u2014 not by infantilizing women or declaring a war on flirting or administering litmus tests, but by continuing a decades-long push for true equality in the bedroom, for a world in which women are not intimidated or coerced into sex but are also not stuffed into the role of gatekeepers.\n\nFor such a movement, the history of Second Wave pro-sex feminism should serve as both North Star and cautionary tale. Ultimately, the arguments of these women got swallowed up by the more coherent, consistent narrative of sexual conservatism, and later by a largely depoliticized version of pro-sex feminism that presented hot-pink dildos as the key to liberation. One reason this might have happened is that amid these conversations, men were at best ancillary and at worst demonized, an understandable impulse in the 1970s, when the most basic feminist ideas were scary and radical. \u201cA free woman needs a free man,\u201d a woman said in a rare moment of clarity during that same 1968 consciousness-raising session.\n\nBut there may be a deeper reason this history has been obscured. In a 1982 essay, my mother admits that a misstep of the early pro-sex feminists was \u201cthe failure to put forward a convincing alternative analysis of sexual violence, exploitation and alienation.\u201d\n\nThe burgeoning movement, in other words, didn\u2019t make a compelling enough argument for freeing women\u2019s sexuality rather than tamping down men\u2019s, a distinction that makes clear the connection between bad sex and rape culture, between Harvey Weinstein\u2019s monster and Aziz Ansari\u2019s Everyman. Instead, just a few years later, protection from violence became the narrow, defensive definition of feminist sexual politics, and the concept of pleasure became synonymous with narcissism and self-indulgence.\n\nThis is the time to rectify all that. Condemning a culture that excuses sexual assault and harassment isn\u2019t about weakness and victimhood. It\u2019s about what my mom, who died in 2006, scrawled on a pamphlet from the famous 1982 Barnard Conference on Sexuality, which she mailed to me while I was toiling on my thesis. On it, she\u2019d written this plain but transformative note: \u201cFeminism is a vision of active freedom, of fulfilled desires, or it is nothing.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Feminist Pursuit of Good Sex", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 More than 100 gold medals \u2014 102 to be exact \u2014 will be awarded in 15 different sports at these Winter Games in Pyeongchang.\n\nEach one, of course, is special for the athlete who wins it. Only Charlotte Kalla, the Swedish cross-country champion who took the 7.5km + 7.5km skiathlon under a bright, crisp sky Saturday afternoon, will be able to say that she won the first gold medal of the Olympiad, the first gold medal in a Winter Games in South Korea.", "title": "The First Medal of the 2018 Winter Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "What exactly does it mean that scientists are truly beginning to understand the biology of memory well enough to manipulate it? Which reaction is appropriate: the futurist\u2019s, or the curmudgeon\u2019s?\n\nThe only honest answer at this stage is both.\n\nThe developers of the new implant, led by scientists at the University of Pennsylvania and Thomas Jefferson University, built on decades of work decoding brain signals, using the most advanced techniques of machine learning.\n\nTheir implant, in fact, constitutes an array of electrodes embedded deep in the brain that monitor electrical activity and, like a pacemaker, deliver a stimulating pulse only when needed \u2014 when the brain is lagging as it tries to store new information.\n\nWhen the brain is functioning well, the apparatus remains quiet.\n\n\u201cWe all have good days and bad days, times when we\u2019re foggy or when we\u2019re sharp,\u201d said Michael Kahana, a psychology professor at the University of Pennsylvania and senior author of last week\u2019s report.\n\n\u201cWe found that jostling the system when it\u2019s in a low-functioning state can jump it to a high-functioning one.\u201d\n\nIf this system, once refined, one day provides support for people with extreme deficits, it will sharply improve lives (insurers willing). The older person with creeping dementia will have more years living independently. The veteran with traumatic brain injury may regain just enough sharpness to find a decent job, or a career.\n\nFor most everyone else, the central discovery behind the device \u2014 that goosing a wandering brain can make it somewhat sharper \u2014 is already deeply familiar. Human beings have been doing this deliberately, and forever: with caffeine, nicotine, prescription drugs like Ritalin, or more virtuously, with a brisk run around the park.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have good evidence that things like nicotine and aerobic exercise improve some aspects of attention,\u201d said Zach Hambrick, a professor of psychology at Michigan State University. \u201cThe stimulation may be activating some of the same systems, only more directly and precisely.\u201d\n\nOne such ability that people with extraordinarily precise memory have in common is known as selective attention, or \u201cattentional control.\u201d In a common measure of this, the Stroop test, people see words flash on a computer screen and name the color in which a word is presented.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnswering is nearly instantaneous when the color and the word are the same \u2014 \u201cblue\u201d displayed in blue \u2014 but slower when there\u2019s no match, like \u201cblue\u201d displayed in red. The men and women who compete in memory competitions score very highly on such tests and often do so well into their thirties, when the ability is typically on the wane.\n\nThis skill is partly inherited, but psychologists have shown that just about anyone can stretch his or her native ability using the same technique that the memory champs do: mentally arranging new names, facts or words in a deeply familiar place \u2014 along subway stops, for example, or in a childhood room.\n\nIn one continuing study, researchers at Washington University in St. Louis trained a group of 50 older adult volunteers to memorize word lists using location imagery \u2014 a so-called memory palace.\n\n\u201cOne woman in her sixties got to where she could recall more than 100 words in correct order,\u201d said David Balota, who collaborated on the study. \u201cOthers were well up to fifty and sixty words.\u201d\n\nAnd all without surgery, or Ritalin.\n\nBut there was a catch. \u201cThat ability didn\u2019t transfer to any improvement in general cognition, like the ability to concentrate, to store new information without using the technique, or speed of processing,\u201d Dr. Balota said.\n\nIn short, ramping up the ability to recall lists of facts, whether with use of an electric brain implant or imagery-based training, may mean nothing for overall quality of life in people whose memories are functioning normally.\n\nIt is in those with serious deficits that the equation changes.\n\nA device that even partly corrects those injuries might keep crucial details \u2014 whom to call for help, how to use the phone, even navigating back and forth to the bathroom \u2014 firmly lodged in mind. For now, that is where a brain implant is most relevant.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the years to come, scientists are likely to turn this new technology to the task of memory retrieval, rather than just storage.\n\n\u201cWe find there\u2019s even more variability during retrieval than encoding,\u201d Dr. Kahana said \u2014 meaning more potential to ramp up performance. When that happens, the game changes.\n\nGiving people with serious deficits a way to master the crucial facets of daily existence would certainly be a medical advance.\n\nBut giving them, and others, a more vivid and deeper reach into the vast pool of what they already know \u2014 well, there are angels and demons buried there, in addition to facts and names.\n\nThat will be a real-life screenplay we should all watch carefully.", "title": "The First Step Toward a Personal Memory Maker?", "authors": ["Benedict Carey"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "When food obsessives announce that they have discovered a delicious new thing to eat, generally the first or second thing they\u2019ll tell you is the secret ingredient or special technique that makes it possible. These bleats of discovery can be exciting, at least for those of us who thrill to the sense of opportunity afforded by the next new thing in food. Cooking, after all, is alchemy, the transformation of base materials into something valuable and rare. Who wouldn\u2019t want to know the latest incantations?\n\nBut it can be equally magical sometimes, particularly in restaurants, to eat in ignorance and bliss, to not be told anything at all about the food on your plate \u2014 unless of course you are a food obsessive and need to know why it tastes so good. So it was on a recent night when I ate a little packet of bluefish steamed in red chard at Houseman, the Manhattan restaurant of the chef Ned Baldwin. Let me be clear right from the start: Steamed bluefish was not a promising order. People in restaurants tend to like their fish crisp at the edges, at the very least, not steamed. They like it white-fleshed and flaky, not dark and oily, beneath a soft carapace of vegetable matter.\n\nBut Baldwin\u2019s fish was fantastic, almost exploding with flavor: briny, buttery-rich, silky-salty, with a powerful roundness barely checked by the sweetness of the chard that surrounded it. Its preparation haunted me for days, and eventually I broke down and asked Baldwin how he made it. \u201cIt\u2019s dulse butter that does it,\u201d he said, laughing: a compound of unsalted butter and the ground, dried sea lettuce that has been harvested on the coast of Ireland and the shores of the North Atlantic for centuries (the word itself is Gaelic in origin). He said he smears each fillet with the stuff before wrapping it in the chard and cooking it slowly in the oven, flipping the packets often, to keep the meat moist.\n\nPhoto\n\nI started cooking with dulse all the time. Particularly now, when the farm stands near my home are bleak and largely empty, I use dulse (and butter too) to impart big flavor to my cooking, with no one the wiser. I use it as Baldwin does, to anoint fillets of cod and tautog, porgy and weakfish. I use it as a dipping sauce, for steamed clams, and as a medium in which to warm bay scallops before serving them with toast. And I love it particularly in this chowder of root-cellar vegetables, clams and fish, one of the easiest and best things to cook for a winter weekend meal. Using a dulse butter at the base of the soup, for the fat in which I saut\u00e9 the vegetables before deglazing them, makes each individual flavor in the resulting chowder pop, distinctly and with bright effect, from carrot to leek, parsnip to potato, bacon to clam to scallop to fish.\n\nAnd I think there is no reason to explain to anyone why this is the case, how the powdered seaweed acts as a flavor enhancer, how it contains a natural version of monosodium glutamate, how it\u2019s harvested off rocks at the bottom of the tide: dulse, Palmaria palmata, bounty of the sea. In part that is because I prefer the magic of the meal to the explanation of the trick that makes it. And in part it is because like a lot of us I cook for children and sometimes people who act like children, for those who quail at the new, at the odd, at the unfamiliar, the poorly branded, the strange. Seaweed people know this well. There\u2019s no reason to court questions. They don\u2019t say they cook with dulse. They just cook.\n\nRecipe: Seafood Chowder", "title": "The Flavor Enhancer You Don\u2019t Need to Tell Anyone About", "authors": ["Sam Sifton"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "You, responsible gun owners, are the only voice left that can make a difference, the only ones who can put a stop to the madness.
