Those of us who want to be safe at school, church, the movie theater, nightclubs and elsewhere in public apparently don\u2019t matter to lawmakers who continue to take the National Rifle Association\u2019s money and vote against common-sense gun laws.\n\nWe need but will not get mandatory background checks, bans on automatic weapons, and prohibitions on where guns can be carried.", "title": "Opinion | The Florida Massacre: \u2018End This Uniquely American Tragedy\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The figures refer to the effectiveness of the vaccine against all circulating strains, including H1N1 and B strains, which have only barely begun to appear this year.\n\nImage Alex M. Azar II, Secretary of Health and Human Services, in Washington on Wednesday. Credit Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press\n\nBut seatbelts are a telling analogy for flu shots. Studies done since the 1970s have shown them to be only about 40 percent protective against preventing any injury in a crash.\n\nBut they are highly protective against death; that is, when crashes are so severe that some occupants are killed while others live, it is almost always the ones not wearing belts who die.\n\nLikewise, studies like the C.D.C.\u2019s suggest that flu shots do a better job of preventing death than preventing sniffles and aches.\n\nMr. Azar\u2019s news conference, at H.H.S. headquarters, was brief and unusual. It was held midafternoon on only a few hours\u2019 notice. It was televised, but no questions were taken from outside the room.\n\nThe event ended with a large panel of experts awaiting questions. Only one was asked: whether administration officials wished they had done anything differently about flu this year.\n\nDr. Schuchat replied by describing problems that vaccine makers face. She did not address a bigger issue of concern to the C.D.C.: Only about 40 percent of Americans get flu shots each year by the time the season begins in November, and that number has been going down, not up.\n\nThe Trump administration and its top health officials have been criticized for showing little public leadership as the flu season became more dangerous. The news conference appeared to be an attempt to remedy that.", "title": "The Flu Vaccine Is Working Better Than Expected, C.D.C. Finds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nIf you\u2019ve spent any time on an airplane in the last few years, you\u2019ve probably noticed the animals. They seem to be everywhere. The number of flying animals classified in the either \u201cservice\u201d or \u201cemotional-support\u201d category has more than doubled since just 2015, according to the best available statistics.\n\nAnd, yes, many of those animals are really just pets that their owners are masquerading as something else.\n\nMy column today is about this strange phenomenon. In the last few weeks, it may have reached a turning point. I realize it\u2019s not the most important story in the country right now, but I don\u2019t believe we should spend 100 percent of our time thinking about Donald Trump. To me, the story of flying pets is a case study of how mass dishonesty can become acceptable, with some significant costs.", "title": "Opinion | The Flying-Pets Scam", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Now, nothing says that such cascades have to be positive either in their motivations or in their results. The period 2016-17 clearly represented a sort of Alt-Right Spring \u2014 springtime for fascists? \u2014 in which white supremacists and anti-Semites were emboldened not just by Donald Trump\u2019s election but by the evidence that there were more like-minded people than anyone realized, both in the U.S. and Europe. Meanwhile, historians have described 1848 as a turning point where history somehow failed to turn: At the end of the day the old, corrupt regimes were still standing.\n\nI nevertheless find the surge of indignation now building in America hugely encouraging. And yes, I think it\u2019s all one surge. The #MeToo movement, the refusal to shrug off the Parkland massacre, the new political activism of outraged citizens (many of them women) all stem from a common perception: namely, that it\u2019s not just about ideology, but that far too much power rests in the hands of men who are simply bad people.\n\nAnd Exhibit A for that proposition is, of course, the tweeter in chief himself.\n\nAt the same time, what strikes me about the reaction to this growing backlash is not just its vileness, but its lameness. Trump\u2019s response to Parkland \u2014 let\u2019s arm teachers! \u2014 wasn\u2019t just stupid, it was cowardly, an attempt to duck the issue, and I think many people realized that. Or consider how the Missouri G.O.P. has responded to the indictment of Gov. Eric Greitens, accused of trying to blackmail his lover with nude photos: by blaming \u2026 George Soros. I am not making this up.\n\nOr consider the growing wildness of speeches by right-wing luminaries like Wayne LaPierre of the N.R.A. They\u2019ve pretty much given up on making any substantive case for their ideas in favor of rants about socialists trying to take away your freedom. It\u2019s scary stuff, but it\u2019s also kind of whiny; it\u2019s what people sound like when they know they\u2019re losing the argument.\n\nAgain, there\u2019s no guarantee that the forces of decency will win. In particular, the U.S. electoral system is in effect rigged in favor of Republicans, so Democrats will need to win the popular vote by something like seven percentage points to take the House. But we\u2019re seeing a real uprising here, and there\u2019s every reason to hope that change is coming.", "title": "Opinion | The Force of Decency Awakens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Perhaps I shouldn\u2019t be surprised, but that\u2019s just not responsible governing. While I\u2019m all for meeting pressing needs, as part of doing so, both the White House and the Congress have an obligation to find other savings or sources of revenues. Just like every household and business must.\n\nI recognize that those of us who have warned of the ominous consequences of deficit and debt have yet to be proven right by a market crisis or the like. And the current gyrations in both stocks and bonds may not turn out to constitute that proof.\n\nHowever, never in the 35 years since Ronald Reagan managed to eradicate fear of deficits from the national psyche have we flirted so aggressively with potential fiscal disaster.\n\nFor one thing, on present course and speed, deficits of more than $1 trillion will persist indefinitely. Indeed, if current policies are maintained, the gap would exceed $2 trillion by 2027, according to calculations by the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.\n\nThat would mean that the amount of debt relative to the size of our economy (the ratio of debt to gross domestic product) could reach a record 109 percent by 2027, exceeding even post-World War II levels.\n\nFor another, for the first time since at least the 1960s, we have thrown a deficit log onto a fire that was already burning briskly. That Vietnam War era decision \u2014 that we could have both guns and butter \u2014 contributed meaningfully to the raging inflation that erupted a few years later.\n\nAlthough inflation has been quiescent so far in this recovery, potential pressure from rising wages has begun to appear, particularly in last week\u2019s unemployment report.", "title": "Opinion | The G.O.P. Is Flirting With Fiscal Disaster", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The thing is, these aren\u2019t isolated examples. A remarkable number of Trump appointees have been forced out over falsified credentials, unethical practices or racist remarks. And you can be sure there are many other appointees who did the same things, but haven\u2019t yet been caught.\n\nWhy is this administration hiring such people? It surely reflects both supply and demand: Competent people don\u2019t want to work for Trump, and he and his inner circle don\u2019t want them anyway.\n\nBy now it\u2019s obvious to everyone that the Trump administration is a graveyard for reputations: Everyone who goes in comes out soiled and diminished. Only fools, or those with no reputation to lose, even want the positions on offer. And in any case, Trump, who values personal loyalty above professionalism, probably distrusts anyone whose credentials might give some sense of independence.\n\nBut what\u2019s the problem? After all, stocks are up and the economy is steadily growing. Does competence even matter?\n\nThe answer is that America is a very big country with a lot of strengths, and it can run on momentum for a long time even if none of the people in charge know what they\u2019re doing. Sooner or later, however, stuff happens \u2014 and then incompetence becomes a very big deal, as it already has in Puerto Rico.\n\nWhat kind of stuff may happen? The scariest scenarios involve national security. But we can\u2019t count on smooth sailing for the economy, either. And who will manage economic turbulence if and when it hits? After all, we currently have perhaps the least impressive Treasury secretary in U.S. history.\n\nMatters are a bit better at the Federal Reserve, where nobody seems to have bad things to say about Jerome Powell, just confirmed as Fed chairman. On the other hand, why didn\u2019t Trump just follow the usual norms and appoint Janet Yellen, who has done a fantastic job, to a second term?\n\nOne answer may be that Trump is a traditionalist \u2014 and few things are more traditional than passing over a highly qualified woman in favor of a less qualified man. But I also suspect that he found Yellen\u2019s independent stature threatening.", "title": "Opinion | The Gang That Couldn\u2019t Think Straight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. I\u2019ve heard about New York\u2019s Negro Baseball League teams. But where did they play?\n\nA. The earliest confirmed game between two black teams was played in the Town of Jamaica, now part of Queens, on Nov. 15, 1859. The Henson Base Ball Club defeated the \u201cUnknowns\u201d of Weeksville, a free black community in today\u2019s Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood, 54 to 43. (Scores like this were common, as pitchers threw underhand.)\n\nIn those days, baseball fields often doubled as ice skating rinks in the winter. A condescending 1862 article in The Brooklyn Eagle places another all-black match, between the Unknowns and the Monitor of Brooklyn, at the \u201cYukaton Skating Pond.\u201d\n\nDespite professional baseball\u2019s ban on nonwhite players, which became more or less formal in 1887, stadiums used by major league teams also hosted Negro league clubs, particularly after World War I.\n\n\u201cRacism has entertainment value,\u201d said Larry Lester, the author of \u201cBlack Baseball in New York City\u201d and a co-founder of the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum. \u201cIt was a moneymaker for the bookies and promoters.\u201d And for the stadiums, too: Many major league owners opposed integration because they would lose rental fees from Negro teams.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne legendary moment in New York baseball history came in 1934, in a game between the Pittsburgh Crawfords and the New York Black Yankees. Josh Gibson, the Crawfords\u2019 catcher and cleanup batter, hit what is said to be the only home run ever to leave the old Yankee Stadium.", "title": "The Geography of Segregated Baseball in New York", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The disconnect is in part because of Guant\u00e1namo\u2019s long history. It is the oldest United States military installation on foreign soil, leased from Cuba since 1903 after the Spanish-American War, when the U.S. Navy realized that the deep water harbor halfway between Atlantic ports and the Panama Canal would be an ideal point for ships to take on coal. For decades it was also the winter training hub of the Atlantic fleet.In recent times, the 45-square-mile Navy station, with its clear waters and murky legal status, has also served as a kind of constitutional Room of Requirement where the federal government could park people it needed to be close to the U.S., but, for legal reasons, not actually in it.\n\nIn the 1990s, more than 50,000 Cuban, Haitian and Chinese refugees were held in tent cities at the base \u2014 a temporary haven outside the jurisdiction of American courts. The same attribute made it attractive to hold enemy combatants in the so-called war on terror after 2001.\n\nOn my visit, the split between American and un-American popped up in unexpected ways. The base is home to a menagerie of endangered animals, including a flourishing population of Cuban rock iguanas. The cat-size lizards are protected by U.S. law, even though human detainees here are not.\n\nMany in legal circles have worried that the current setup at Guant\u00e1namo could amount to a legal version of Jurassic Park, where precedents in holding people without charge could somehow escape the island and begin preying on mainland legal protections. And for all the small-town America feel here, occasional reminders show up that you\u2019re not in Kansas anymore. Red stickers on the desk phones provided for reporters note that all conversations are subject to monitoring.\n\nBut most people living at the base seem to pay the secret side of Guant\u00e1namo little mind. The majority of residents have nothing to do with the prisons, and know little about what goes on within. And the troops who are familiar with both sides of Guant\u00e1namo can toggle back and forth in a way that would feel absurd anywhere else. One morning, an Army sergeant assigned to be my minder went through the photos on my camera one minute, deleting photos the military chose to censor, then put the camera down and offered me advice on a few good places to go snorkeling.", "title": "The Gift Shop on Guant\u00e1namo Bay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "The news was especially distressing because the property was supposed to be a spacious upgrade from their previous home, a 13-foot-wide townhouse around the corner that they bought in 2004 for about $1.25 million.\n\nThat house \u201cwas super-charming,\u201d Ms. Consi said, with 19th-century woodwork, plaster crown molding and decorative marble fireplaces. But over time, they began to feel squeezed by its narrow layout as their children, Delila, now 13, and Parker, now 11, grew up.\n\n\u201cEverything was awkward,\u201d Mr. Lapidus said. The front door opened directly into the living room, the dining table had to be parked against one wall of the kitchen and dragged out for dinner every night, and the children\u2019s bedrooms were two stories above their bathroom, with no closets.\n\nMr. Lapidus and Ms. Consi had spent years looking at bigger houses nearby, and had made numerous offers, but were outbid every time. Resigned to staying put, they hired Mr. Coburn to develop plans to renovate their matchbox-size home shortly before stumbling upon their new house.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt 18 feet wide, it offered the generous spaces they longed for and appeared to need a renovation that was mostly cosmetic, along with the addition. But after they discovered the structural problems, their renovation budget of $900,000 ballooned to about $1.3 million, and the timeline grew to more than two years.\n\nGiven that time and expense, they were intent on creating exactly the home they desired, in collaboration with Mr. Coburn and their interior designer, Katherine Hammond.\n\n\u201cI definitely wanted all of the traditional touches\u201d for the interior architecture, said Ms. Consi, who planned to furnish the house with vintage midcentury-modern and contemporary pieces.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe interior had to be gutted, but their contractor, Creative Renovations, recreated many of the details, including the crown molding and ceiling medallions in the living room and the front hall. Workers also salvaged pieces of the original joists and repurposed them as shelves and decorative exposed beams in the garden-level family room.\n\nMs. Consi had been so smitten with the woodwork in their old home that she cut away a piece of window trim and removed a staircase spindle so they could be copied for the new townhouse, reinstalling the originals before putting the house on the market.\n\nTo create the storage space the family\u2019s previous home lacked, Mr. Coburn designed extensive built-in cabinetry and shelving, including a bar hidden behind paneling between the living room and the kitchen, a workstation with integrated desks in the family room and a bookcase that wraps around a home office doorway. The children also have generous closets behind pocket doors.\n\nMr. Coburn added the new top floor for the master suite under a standing-seam copper mansard roof, which brought the size of the four-bedroom, three-bathroom home to about 2,700 square feet.\n\nTo furnish the rooms, Ms. Consi spent months scouring stores and websites like Etsy, Chairish, 1stdibs and eBay, in search of pieces both old and new, including a midcentury dining table by Arne Vodder, 1950s Arteluce lamps and a new Oscar sofa from SCP, with guidance from Ms. Hammond. \u201cShe really enjoyed the digging,\u201d Ms. Hammond said. \u201cFinding the perfect pieces was a gradual process that lasted several years.\u201d\n\nThe family moved into their new home in September 2015, and sold their previous one for $2.35 million, which partially made up for the cost of the renovation.\n\nThe process was a shock at the outset, but looking back, there isn\u2019t much they would change.\n\n\u201cWe have a brand-new, gorgeous house now,\u201d Ms. Consi said. \u201cEven though it was quite an experience going through this whole project, it turned out to be my dream house.\u201d", "title": "The Go-for-Broke Renovation", "authors": ["Tim Mckeough", "On Location"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The term comes from the French crudit\u00e9, meaning rawness, yet its culinary use \u2014 always plural \u2014 is of recent vintage, first surfacing in 20th-century France. The American chef James Beard, inspired by a \u201cbouquet of crudit\u00e9s\u201d he was served at a restaurant there, included a recipe for it (\u201cgreen onions, radishes, celery, tiny artichokes, asparagus, turnips, carrots \u2014 all raw\u201d) in a 1965 cookbook, although the foreign term was just a matter of chicness, since he had already advocated for vegetables and dip as hors d\u2019oeuvres as early as the 1940s. By the 1980s, The New York Times was printing recipes for it, and the preferred first course of restaurants in southern France had made its way to New York power-lunch spots. But could Beard have ever anticipated crudit\u00e9s as sculpture or terrarium? What we once ate begrudgingly now makes us gawk, even swoon \u2014 and we pay handsomely for it. So have raw vegetables changed, or have we?\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE HUMAN BRAIN is a hungry beast. Scientists have calculated that our earliest ancestors would have had to eat raw vegetables nonstop for nine hours a day just to fuel it. For early humans with limited tools, a vegetarian diet just wasn\u2019t efficient. The tipping point in evolution came some two and a half million years ago, when our distant progenitors started consuming more meat; over time, their brains grew bigger. Perhaps we absorbed this lesson too well. Vegetables, despite their nutritional value, have long been a sideshow for much of our species. (Certainly in the West; countries in Asia and Africa have longstanding produce-eating traditions, due in part to the intersections of climate and religion.) Ancient Romans ate a kind of ur-salad, the word derived from the Latin for salt, with which lettuces were brined. But by the 16th century, the English Tudors were obliterating them in long-simmered stews.\n\nThere have always been mavericks who disapproved of eating meat, like Saint Catherine of Siena who, in the 14th century, disavowed all food but raw vegetables. The American minister Sylvester Graham, in 1830s Massachusetts, likewise denounced meat as devilish, devising a diet centered on Graham bread (his forerunner to the Graham cracker and that other form of perdition, s\u2019mores). A decade later in that state, Amos Bronson Alcott founded a vegan commune called Fruitlands with nine adults and five children, including his 10-year-old daughter, the future novelist Louisa May Alcott. They favored raw vegetables so as not to cook away the plants\u2019 \u201clife force.\u201d By winter the experiment was over: The Alcotts had to be sheltered and fed by neighbors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNonetheless, toward the end of the 19th century, vegetables started gaining space on American tables, as such then-exotics as olives and celery began to be imported from warmer climates. Upton Sinclair\u2019s 1905 expos\u00e9 of the meatpacking industry, \u201cThe Jungle,\u201d was intended to radicalize the public against free-market capitalism, but instead inspired many to shun meat. (\u201cI aimed at the public\u2019s heart, and by accident I hit it in the stomach,\u201d he wrote.) Interest in vegetables waned during the two world wars, when meat was so scarce it was coveted as a luxury. (Hitler\u2019s reputation for being a vegetarian didn\u2019t do much for the cause.)\n\nBut with the rise of the counterculture in the 1960s came a rejection of factory-farming and a longing to realign our relationship with nature. The Berkeley chef Alice Waters opened Chez Panisse in 1971 as a canteen for her activist friends; now she\u2019s an \u00e9minence grise of sustainable agriculture, and her once fringe vision \u2014 in which the choice of what to eat is as much political as it is personal \u2014 is mainstream, if not yet fully realized.\n\nPhoto\n\nTODAY\u2019S RESURGENCE OF crudit\u00e9s is, then, largely an outgrowth of the farm-to-table movement and its obsession with provenance, which anointed small farms as brand names and their products as premium goods. We fetishize turnips with stems still attached, twists of carrot ending in long wispy threads, cucumbers with rutted, pitted surfaces.\n\nStill, for all the pious injunctions to \u201crespect the ingredient,\u201d the crux of crudit\u00e9s remains the dip. The Italian version is bagna cauda, literally a \u201chot bath\u201d of olive oil and anchovies, while the Swiss favor cheese fondue, turning vegetables into vessels of texture. In perhaps the greatest impudence, at the idiosyncratic San Francisco supper club Lazy Bear, diners receive a crock of bone marrow fondue, while Vicia takes a meta approach, pairing root vegetables with pesto made from their leaves.\n\nPerhaps what crudit\u00e9s offer is a corrective to the recent frenzy for meat and fat, when foie gras was piped into doughnuts and menus were stocked with slabs of pork belly. (While gardening has increased \u2014 a third of American households now grow their own vegetables \u2014 so have domestic sales of pork, up 20 percent since 2011.) Indeed, in the hunter-gatherer hierarchy, the rewards of hunting have always taken precedence over those of gathering: Meat is a main course and vegetables an addendum, even in our current phase of celebrating crudit\u00e9s. Both roles demand intimate knowledge of the land, but stalking an animal and taking its life means going out into the world, while picking berries in the woods or tending a garden is domestic (that is, women\u2019s) work, and valued less. The advent of the New Nordic food movement upended this by glamorizing foraging as a form of hunting, seeking out never-known corners of the wild.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo it\u2019s worth noting that these haute crudit\u00e9s tend to pop up at expensive restaurants run by white male chefs. It takes a certain amount of confidence, even privilege, to ask diners to pay as much as $40 for some vegetables, whether slapped on a board or meticulously arranged with tweezers. Because no matter the display, the vegetables are meant to taste like they\u2019ve just been separated from the ground, and in that case, why do we need a chef at all? Michael Gallina, the chef of Vicia, argues that crudit\u00e9s are a form of advocacy: He wants diners to taste \u201cthe care that goes into growing\u201d the vegetables, in soil that has been taken \u201cout of production for weeks or months\u201d to return nutrients to it, at a sacrifice of \u201cgrowing crops that can earn top dollar.\u201d\n\nFramed like this, raw vegetables are no less luxury goods than dry-aged steaks. The closer they cleave to their origins, the more valuable they are. What they offer is that most elusive of qualities: honesty. Their beauty comes entirely from within; it can\u2019t be enhanced or faked. That\u2019s both a comfort and a rarity in a world dominated by the ersatz and the airbrushed, of novelty food trends like rainbow-dyed bagels and super-size soup dumplings, or sci-fi kitchen experiments involving mortadella foam and edible balloons. Gallina says that Naked Vegetables is \u201cone of the riskiest dishes we serve \u2014 and the one that makes us most proud.\u201d\n\nThe most exciting chefs don\u2019t just please us; they teach us something. They introduce new ingredients, flavors and possibilities, or reframe forgotten ones. I still remember, from more than a decade ago \u2014 long before any of these iced, overgrown bowls of radishes and asparagus appeared \u2014 a dinner at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., which began with carrots from the farm surrounding the restaurant, pierced into a row of nails on a wooden block. The spikes looked sharp and dangerous, like something out of \u201cSpartacus,\u201d and I wondered if the carrots could compete. But when I plucked one and took a bite, it tasted of half-fulfilled sweetness and turned earth, like no carrot I\u2019d ever known. At the same time, it was just a carrot, and suddenly that was enough.", "title": "The Golden Age of Crudit\u00e9s", "authors": ["Ligaya Mishan", "Food Matters"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u200b\u200bThough some Americans\u200b may \u200bfly to another state and begin \u200btheir road trip there, Mr. Cohen and his colleagues are seeing many more people simply driving from home. It\u2019s typically less expensive , and a road trip offers more flexibility in terms of schedule. Travelers can relax, leave at the last minute, and discover historical sites, local cuisine, museums, shopping, hiking, festivals and theme parks along the way.\n\n\u200bDespite taking shorter trips, people nonetheless want to roam as far away as possible. \u201cThey don\u2019t want to spend the night any closer than eight hours from home,\u201d Mr. Cohen said. And the trip has to have multiple overnight stops\u200b with activities and attractions\u200b, \u201cnot just Grandma\u2019s house,\u201d he said. For example, Mr. Cohen said retirees typically visit family during their road trips, but most of the time they stay elsewhere.\n\nFrom the inception of the vacation, to the miles logged along the way, social media is a comparatively new aspect of the road trip. In the last four years MMGY has observed the role of social media in recording and sharing travel experiences explode, mainly among millennials. The percentage of people who say they post vacation photos on social media to make friends and family jealous has doubled over the last four years \u2014 \u201cwe believe that one\u2019s grossly understated,\u201d Mr. Cohen added \u2014 as has the number of people who use social media to record their travel experiences.\n\n\u200bInstagram and the like aside, road-tripping is among the few travel trends today not being, er, driven by millennials. Boomers are the largest group of road-trippers (followed by Generation Xers ), and for them, it seems there\u2019s some element of nostalgia. For millennials, the appeal of the road trip is often economical, though for many, and for a number of Generation Xers, life experiences like road trips matter more than shiny new things, according to MMGY. How people choose where to travel was something of a surprise to Mr. Cohen, who reasonably figured that the first thing most people do when planning a vacation is to decide where to go. Turns out, less than half the people he studied do that. Instead, he said, people tend to say \u201cHere\u2019s what I want to do, now where can I do it?\u201d For millennials it may be, \u201cI have this much money, where can I best spend it?\u201d There isn\u2019t just one type of road-tripper with a single set of goals. And road-tripping is unlikely to experience another dramatic rise.\n\n\u201cIt can\u2019t just keep skyrocketing,\u201d Mr. Cohen said\u200b\u200b. But he expects to see modest growth\u200b this year\u200b as Americans\u200b \u2014 retirees, young families, millennials, Generation Xers without children \u2014 continue rolling on.", "title": "The Great American Road Trip: Shorter and More Popular Than Ever", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "In the next few months, the Supreme Court is expected to rule, at last, on one of the most corrosive practices in modern American democracy \u2014 the drawing of legislative district maps to entrench the party in power, no matter how many voters might want a different result. Even as this behavior, known as partisan gerrymandering, has gotten out of control in recent decades, the court has refused to rein it in because, the claim goes, any possible fix lies with the political branches and not the courts.\n\nThat\u2019s bunk. The justices will see why if they look at what\u2019s happening in several states where lawmakers have been holding clinics in self-interested mapmaking.\n\nBoth Democrats and Republicans draw biased maps, of course \u2014 the two cases before the Supreme Court this term make that clear \u2014 but modern partisan gerrymandering is mostly the work of Republicans, who control a majority of governorships, as well as the legislative chambers in 32 states. Their efforts to lock in this advantage by any means necessary \u2014 including by kneecapping any institutions, including the courts, that try to stop them \u2014 are the work of a party that has become, as the political scientists Norm Ornstein and Thomas Mann put it in 2012, \u201cdismissive of the legitimacy of its political opposition.\u201d At stake are not just hundreds of state legislative seats, but also control of the House of Representatives, which Republicans currently hold by a 45-seat margin.\n\nThe most shocking case is playing out right now in Pennsylvania, where Republican lawmakers in 2011 created maps so skewed that when Democrats won a majority of the popular vote the following year, it translated into only five of the state\u2019s 18 congressional seats.", "title": "Opinion | The Great Republican Power Grab", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "On Monday night, Carter Page was finally ready for his Fox News close-up. It had been nearly a year since he began his one-man public-relations offensive to rebut accusations that, as a Trump campaign adviser, he colluded with Russia. He had appeared numerous times on CNN, MSNBC and the networks, typically opposite their star anchors. Unlike almost everyone else caught up in the Trump-Russia scandal, Page was not only willing to submit to public questions; he would even answer them. Though he didn\u2019t bring much clarity to his role, the appearances did make for great, albeit surreal, television. Like the time he insisted to Anderson Cooper that his conversation with the Russian ambassador during the Republican National Convention was not actually a \u201cmeeting.\u201d \u201cAnderson,\u201d Page explained, \u201ca great analogy is you and I were members of the same health club here in New York previously. And I remember walking by you, even though we didn\u2019t know each other, and I said, \u2018Hi, Anderson,\u2019 and you said hello, and we, you know, had a nice little exchange for half a second. Now, does that to you constitute a meeting?\u201d\n\nBut for all the media stardom these and other interviews brought Page, he had been essentially given a cold shoulder by Fox News; he hadn\u2019t appeared on the network since a few cameos in March and April. When I met with Page late last year for a story for the magazine, his absence from Fox\u2019s airwaves seemed to gnaw at him even more than the considerable distance that Trump\u2019s advisers had sought to put between him and the president. After all, Page understood why Trump wouldn\u2019t want to be associated with him: Page viewed himself, as he put it last year, \u201cthe biggest embarrassment surrounding the campaign.\u201d But Fox was another matter. Considering how roughly he was treated by the mainstream media, he assumed that Fox would have come to his aid. Besides, Page\u2019s father was a devoted Fox viewer, and it would have been nice if he could have watched his son on his favorite shows.\n\nSo it was understandable why Page\u2019s wide, goofy smile was even wider and goofier than usual on Monday night when he appeared on Laura Ingraham\u2019s prime-time show on Fox News. Page was there to give his first interview since House Republicans, three days earlier, released a memo, written by Republican members of the House Intelligence Committee, alleging that the F.B.I. had improperly spied on Page in an attempt to harm Trump\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\n\u201cCarter, it\u2019s good to see you tonight,\u201d Ingraham told Page, teeing up a softball. \u201cI know you have not spoken out about this House Intel memo yet or the reaction to it. What is your reaction?\u201d", "title": "The Happy Martyrdom of Carter Page", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "She has been trying to overcome it since \u2014 not for herself, really, because she has moved on, quite spectacularly, if people would just pay attention more often than every four years. What she was trying to overcome was something ghostlier, something harder to catch and release, which is the nagging feeling that when huge numbers of people think of Lindsey Jacobellis, they see a blooper, not a champion.\n\nShe knew the questions were coming because she faced them in 2010, when she fell short again, and in 2014, when it happened a third time. Certainly, her reward for remaining atop her sport as the 2018 Winter Games approached was to be asked them all again.\n\nThe biggest difference this time, besides the experience and wisdom that come with four more years, is that Jacobellis has Shull. Their pairing was the idea of Peter Foley, the longtime United States snowboard cross head coach.\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s had a bad experience with the Olympics, and in a lot of ways she dreads the Olympics now,\u201d Foley said. \u201cIt would be nice if she could feel better about it.\u201d\n\nShull\u2019s purpose is to see if a new mind-set can make the difference between gold and disappointment. And as much as it frustrates Jacobellis to be reminded of it all, internally she has embraced Shull\u2019s unusual advice: Do not try to put 2006 out of your mind, because that is impossible. Even in the starting gate, even in a gold medal race, if the thoughts creep to the memory of a long-ago fall, not the gauzy vision of the medal stand, seize them.\n\n\u201cWhat you want athletes to do is say, \u2018I\u2019m afraid,\u2019 \u201d Shull said. \u201cBecause they all are. And if they say it, they can use it. If they try to set it aside, it\u2019s lurking around them, interrupting what they normally know how to do.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is the opposite of what many sports psychologists and coaches preach, which is to clear the mind and think only positive thoughts. To Shull, to pretend that negativity does not exist is as ridiculous as children holding hands over their ears and shouting \u201cnuh-nuh-nuh-nuh\u201d to avoid hearing what is being said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe results have been promising. Jacobellis, a 10-time gold medalist in boardercross at the X Games (which discontinued the event in 2017), won her fifth world championship last March and the first two World Cup events this season. She has reasserted herself as the favorite heading into the Olympics.\n\n\u201cHopefully these are all small positive steps, moving forward, that could potentially have things line up for me right for this one,\u201d Jacobellis said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018I Want You Screaming\u2019\n\nJacobellis and Shull mostly talk from distant time zones. They have met in person only a few times. They may be the odd couple of the Olympics.\n\nShull hails from the financial world, having made a living as a trader and trading desk manager. But a deep interest in psychology (her master\u2019s thesis at the University of Chicago was on the neurobiology of Freud\u2019s Repetition Compulsion Theory) had her thinking about mind games on Wall Street, where the general rule is to take emotion out of decision making.\n\nShe began coaching traders and fund managers about harnessing and using emotion, leading to the book \u201cMarket Mind Games,\u201d the founding of a consulting agency called the ReThink Group and appearances on business-related networks like CNBC.\n\nClients, she said, told her that her unusual views on confronting emotion, not ignoring it, helped with out-of-work diversions, too, like golf. A trading desk manager in Asia, Shull said, raced cars as a hobby, and one particularly fear-inducing turn on a racetrack consistently ruined his time.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018O.K., as you go into that turn, I want you screaming in that car that you are terrified,\u2019 \u201d Shull said. \u201cWhat do you think happened? Fastest time ever. Coaches might have a heart attack if they heard a racer say that \u2014 literally, \u2018I\u2019m terrified, I\u2019m terrified, I\u2019m terrified.\u2019 But the chances that they win have gone way up. That contracts the energy in a way it becomes fuel. It focuses the energy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA colleague had a connection to the U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association, and Shull espoused her theories to coaches at a meeting in 2016. Afterward, she was approached by Foley. I think I have a client for you, he said: Lindsey Jacobellis.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t know her,\u201d Shull said. \u201cSo I Googled her.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe learned that Jacobellis grew up in Connecticut and, as a teenager, was an up-and-coming racer in the burgeoning sport of boardercross, where a pack of riders leaves the gate at once and navigates a high-speed roller coaster of a course, racing to the bottom amid the occasional carnage of collisions and crash landings.\n\nHer rise was timed perfectly. She was 20 when snowboard cross, as the Olympics called it, made its Olympic debut in 2006. Jacobellis was anointed, predictably, as a made-for-television sweetheart in a must-see new event, a favorite with cascading ringlets of blond hair and a smile that masked her competitive muscle.\n\nThen, in a moment, she became better known for falling than she would have for winning, the butt of jokes and even the target of animosity. She never really understood it. She tried to smile it away, but strangers seemed more bothered by the fall than she did. Wherever she went, the episode and the questions \u2014 How? Why? \u2014 followed her like a plume of snow.\n\nThe 2010 Winter Games in Vancouver, British Columbia, were considered a chance at redemption, but Jacobellis swerved off course in a semifinal heat and missed the final. In 2014, in Sochi, Russia, she was leading a semifinal heat when she stumbled on a set of late-race rollers and missed the final again.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it has to do with the Olympics,\u201d she said that day in Russia. \u201cIt\u2019s just on a fluke of when things work out for me and when they don\u2019t.\u201d\n\nHer longtime teammate Faye Gulini was more exacting.\n\n\u201cPeople don\u2019t understand how much pressure is put on her,\u201d she said four years ago. \u201cIt breaks my heart because I think it takes the fun out of it for her. Just this event. She loves the sport. She\u2019s a phenomenal snowboarder. But it\u2019s in her head.\u201d", "title": "The Haunting of Lindsey Jacobellis", "authors": ["John Branch"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "You have the agency\u2019s permission to say something rude and hang up. (I\u2019m inferring that \u2014 I.R.S. news releases aren\u2019t quite that entertaining.) Because once a conversation starts, people can find themselves doing strange things.\n\nTake Michelle Albitz, a Pennsylvania woman who lost more than $10,000 to an ersatz I.R.S. caller. According to the account in The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, a gentleman on the phone said she would be arrested if she didn\u2019t pay her back taxes. She withdrew the money from her local bank and, following the instructions from her caller, went to retail stores and bought gift cards. She then read the card information to the swindler over the phone.\n\nWho knew the I.R.S. worked this way? With gift cards?\n\nOh, that\u2019s right. It doesn\u2019t.\n\nThose I.R.S. people aren\u2019t like that. They don\u2019t call, they don\u2019t send email, they don\u2019t demand money from you in Instagram posts. And while David Kautter, the acting commissioner of the I.R.S., is surely somewhat hunky in his own nerd-eriffic way, he will not contact you on Tinder and tell you that you have beautiful eyes and that you need to pay some back taxes. Not even with gift cards.\n\nThe gift card caper that snared Ms. Albitz was unusual, but scammers trying to extract fake tax payments aren\u2019t a new thing. That\u2019s why it is refreshing, in a perverse way, to see crooks coming up with something a little more inventive lately, like this twist on another old fraud.\n\nThe perpetrators fill out fake tax returns in your name, using your actual information. Then they have the I.R.S. deposit the money in your own bank account. After that, the scammers call you up and say that there has been a mistake, and you got a refund you shouldn\u2019t have, and they\u2019re from a collection agency. Would you mind just sending the money to them?\n\nThe I.R.S. has its own official procedures for turning in erroneous refunds, and \u2014 have I mentioned this? \u2014 they don\u2019t involve agents calling you.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNot only will tax agents not call you, the I.R.S. makes it painfully clear that it would rather you not call, either. The signals aren\u2019t even subtle. In a recent news release about \u201cearly filing season myths,\u201d a number of the purported myths come down to: Don\u2019t call us. Not as in \u201cDon\u2019t call us, we\u2019ll call you,\u201d but \u201cDon\u2019t call. We mean it.\u201d\n\nTake myth No. 4, which is about whether calling the I.R.S. will get you a better refund date. Answer: No. Or No. 5: \u201cCalling the I.R.S. Is the Most Convenient Way to Get Answers to Tax or Refund Questions.\u201d Again, nope, nope, nope. Because baby, they\u2019re just not that into you.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI like the agency\u2019s honesty but object to the folks at the I.R.S. calling these things \u201cmyths.\u201d Myths are things people actually believe. Here\u2019s a real myth: that anyone wants to call the I.R.S.\n\nNormal people dread having contact with the agency, aside from sending in their tax return, and, if they are fortunate, getting a refund.\n\nIf you\u2019ve ever been in actual conversation with this agency, it probably means something bad has happened, such as getting a letter about a problem with your taxes, and you\u2019ve had to follow up. That situation is likely to get worse: Once you start calling the agency to clear things up, well, it can be an endless cycle of fix-it calls followed by dunning I.R.S. notices demanding that you fix the thing you just fixed, with more calls to clear things up.\n\nFrankly, dear reader, those so-called I.R.S. myths didn\u2019t sound much like myths to me. For example, the title of one listed by the agency was this: \u201cOrdering a tax transcript a \u2018secret way\u2019 to get a refund date.\u201d That does not sound like anything anyone has said to me ever, even if you interpret the sentence to mean that people use their refunds to go out on a date and the agency will help hook you up. (There\u2019s that Tinder issue again!) By the way, Mr. Kautter, may I say you\u2019re looking very good today?\n\nNo, if you\u2019re going to promise myths, my I.R.S. friends, go large. Try myths people might actually believe, for example, the claim that \u201cBitcoins are untraceable.\u201d (It\u2019s complicated but, in fact, they are traceable.)\n\nThen there\u2019s the old saying that nothing is certain but death and taxes. I always thought it was true, but it has clearly moved into myth territory: Death is still pretty certain, sure. But taxes? With all the revisions to the tax code, a lot of people are very uncertain. And, above a certain income level, you can bet that they won\u2019t be paying much if any tax at all.\n\nThe truly rich, of course, know they don\u2019t need to call the I.R.S. They just call their favorite members of Congress. Or, more likely, they have their people do it.\n\nAnd those calls get taken.", "title": "The I.R.S. Really Doesn\u2019t Want to Hear From You", "authors": ["John Schwartz"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Until now. The new Marvel series \u201cIceman\u201d (whose first five issues became available in January as a single trade paperback) is the kind of compact, character-centered superhero comic that people who like the Marvel movies, or read realist graphic novels (like \u201cFun Home\u201d) but haven\u2019t embraced capes-and-tights books, can enjoy. It\u2019s all about coming out as an adult, establishing your new identity while trying to keep the old one, and trying to meet the needs of the people you already know and love. As depicted by the writer Sina Grace, adult Bobby has a life and a job and a set of awesome responsibilities, including teaching kids how to use the Danger Room, the X-Men training facility. Can he keep all of it? What else should he do?\n\nIceman has been a jokester, a boyish man who hides his feelings, a serial dater of women who could very well be overcompensating, with an exterior that is literally slippery, since his first appearance in 1963. An earlier Iceman adventure sent Bobby home to Long Island, where he gets berated for becoming a hero rather than an accountant. This Bobby (written by J. M. DeMatteis, drawn by Alan Kupperberg, in 1984-85) feels smothered by a father who can\u2019t handle \u201cthe very fact of what I am.\u201d \u201cI like what I am! I hate what I am! \u2026 If only I could tell them who I really am,\u201d he muses. By the end of that story \u2014 having saved himself from a demon disguised as \u201cthe Girl Next Door\u201d \u2014 Bobby exclaims \u201cI\u2019m not running anymore!\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s stories like this one that first gave the X-Men such a strong queer following. Metaphors are great; subtexts are great. But we should not have to rely on them, and only them. Gay readers no longer do. (Trans readers are waiting. Marvel: Call us!)\n\nYoung people benefit from older models: There\u2019s a good reason the X-Men run a school. But learning works in the other direction too. Grace\u2019s adult Bobby \u2014 like many of us \u2014 was moved to change his life after encountering a younger, more confident version of himself. (The comic begins with both Bobbys in a playful ice-slide duel, like a dream of the St. Paul Winter Carnival.) Young Bobby has a steady boyfriend; adult Bobby has \u201cno clue where to start.\u201d In more recent issues of \u201cIceman,\u201d he\u2019s started dating. For the first five, he\u2019s not even looking, just trying to tell his mother and father, having already told \u2014 or texted \u2014 his mutant friends. \u201cMy friends are my family, and my family doesn\u2019t quite get me,\u201d Bobby muses. \u201cBut whose does?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe artists on this comic certainly do. Alessandro Vitti, Rachelle Rosenberg and their colleagues render characters muscular enough for the hyperbole of a fight, but accessibly human enough for a kitchen table talk. One issue focuses almost entirely on a tough conversation between Bobby and his parents, in which he can\u2019t quite tell them he is gay; they ask him to quit flaunting his powers \u201clike you\u2019re all in a parade.\u201d It\u2019s what the legal scholar Kenji Yoshino calls a demand for covering: We\u2019ll let you be who you are, if you don\u2019t make it obvious.\n\nBobby makes his mutant powers obvious \u2014 he enjoys using them, uses them all the time \u2014 as a way to hide from the rest of himself, almost as he uses his endless supply of puns (\u201cIce to meet you\u201d). \u201cI\u2019ve brushed aside any emotion that didn\u2019t quite fit and covered it up with a joke,\u201d he says in the letter he wrote to come out to his parents, a letter that his ex-girlfriend Kitty Pryde \u2014 herself an X-Man whose power is turning intangible \u2014 has to prompt Bobby\u2019s mother and father to read. In pages that take full advantage of comics form, we read the words in the letter while the surrounding panels show Iceman defeating a huge armored bad guy called Juggernaut: \u201cToday was a really bad day,\u201d Bobby tells him, \u201cand punching you helped.\u201d He can do what he\u2019s always done \u2014 and be himself too.\n\nSina Grace, who is gay, has suggested in interviews that Bobby\u2019s coming out reflects the experience of men he has known. It also reflects \u2014 or just is \u2014 a way that superhero comics, at least the ones with mutants, have themselves come out: belatedly, by stages, awkwardly, slowly, still trying to find out what else they can do or be, without abandoning their older roles, and making good on the promises so many of us found there when we were young. It\u2019s satisfying in too many ways to count, even as it leaves some of us wondering \u2014 as Kitty, and Bobby\u2019s other friends, are wondering \u2014 how on earth it took so long.", "title": "The Iceman Cometh Out", "authors": ["Stephanie Burt"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "When an emergency cesarean is performed after membranes rupture and labor has begun, the baby acquires fewer of the mother\u2019s microbes than it would during a vaginal birth but many more than from a scheduled cesarean.\n\nThese differences in the gut microbiota were found to persist in children until at least 7 years of age, according to a study in Finland published in 2004.\n\nCurrently, about one baby in three in the United States is delivered by cesarean section, up from about one in five in the 1990s. Certainly, a surgical delivery can be lifesaving when, for example, the fetus or the mother is at risk of a serious or fatal complication from a vaginal delivery.\n\nBut other reasons for the rise in cesarean deliveries, including the readings from a fetal monitor, are less clear-cut. Even though many babies with borderline readings would be likely to be fine with a vaginal birth, women and their doctors are usually unwilling to take a chance when the monitor suggests that the fetus may be in trouble. And women who have one cesarean, which weakens the uterine wall, are more likely to have a second or third rather than risk a uterine rupture during subsequent labor and delivery.\n\nTo counter the effects of a surgical birth on the infant\u2019s microbiome, a growing number of women whose babies are delivered by cesarean are requesting that medical staff transfer microbes from the mother\u2019s vagina to their infants soon after birth. Some are administering the microbe exchanges themselves. However, an expert committee of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recently warned that the practice, known as vaginal seeding, was premature and possibly hazardous.\n\n\u201cAt this time, vaginal seeding should not be performed outside the context of an institutional review board-approved research protocol until adequate data regarding the safety and benefit of the process become available,\u201d the committee concluded. The committee cited a potential risk of transferring pathogenic organisms from the woman to the neonate.\n\nIf vaginal seeding is being considered, women should be informed of the risks and tested for infectious diseases and potentially pathogenic bacteria, including group B streptococci, herpes simplex virus, chlamydia and gonorrhea, the committee stated.", "title": "The Importance of Infants\u2019 Exposure to Micro-Organisms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLast September, an earthquake southeast of Mexico City killed over 350 people, disastrous hurricanes made landfall in the Caribbean and President Trump threatened to annihilate North Korea. Social media has made well-informed consumers \u2014 including of current events \u2014 of us all, and we no longer have the luxury of not knowing the bad news. Savviness, once a virtue, has become something closer to an obligation.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo how do you express in clothing your desire to not know? Black seems too obvious \u2014 and too resigned. But pastels, once the province of demure cashmere twin-sets and enameled automatic kitchen appliances, of petits fours, babies and the housewives who rock them, are announcing themselves as an unexpected alternative, filling the splash pages of millennial-run websites and dominating the spring collections. In New York last fall, Michael Kors sent a flaxen-haired model down the runway in a double-breasted suit of matte periwinkle, and in Paris, at Loewe, Jonathan Anderson showed slouchy dresses made of color-blocked, sherbet-hued silk: pistachio, strawberry, Creamsicle, custard. But this is not merely escapist dressing. Pastels\u2019 atavistic connotations \u2014 of traditional femininity and nostalgia for a pre-Voting Rights Act America \u2014 have been subsumed, like so much else, by ironic self-awareness and maybe even by a subtle sense of tragedy. (No woman could see the dusky pink and pale blue handbags at Tod\u2019s, studded with rubber pebbles, and not think of the birth control pills tucked away \u2014 for now \u2014 in her own purse.) Wearing pastels feels like reappropriating a slur. \u201cWho\u2019s the na\u00eff now?\u201d they seem to whisper, while remaining unsure whether anyone can hear. Red may be the color of all-out rebellion, but pastels, which by definition are a dilution of pigment, can provide a sneakier kind of insurrection. Sometimes, there\u2019s no better way to disguise the taste of poison than with a sugar coating.", "title": "The Irony of Pastels", "authors": ["Alice Gregory", "Notes On The Culture"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "In doing her brother\u2019s bidding, Kim Yo-jong is airbrushing a dictator who authorizes public executions that, according to defectors, must be watched by all adult citizens, so that they can savor the wages of disobedience. She is diverting attention from his roles in the murders of his half brother, who was smeared with a fatal toxin while walking through an airport, and of many senior government officials, slaughtered in grotesque ways. Is it any wonder that she\u2019s making the effort? The alternative, apparently, is being drawn and quartered.\n\nSo bizarrely nonjudgmental was some of the chatter about her that BuzzFeed News published what it cheekily labeled a public service announcement. The headline, referring to a disapproving glance that she\u2019d thrown at Vice President Mike Pence, reminded Americans that she was \u201cnot your new fave shade queen,\u201d and the article bluntly asked those who seemed to be so taken with her, \u201cWhat the hell is wrong with you people?\u201d\n\nIn National Review, David French floated some answers, positing that hatred of President Trump was so blinding that his opponents regarded all international incidents as potential diminutions of his administration. To these appalled critics, Pence exists on the same level as Kim\u2019s sister \u2014 or even below it. French filed this under the rubric of overheated partisanship, which is indeed a problem but not tidily applicable here. Anti-Trump fervor has as much to do with his out-of-bounds actions and words as with any reflexive tribalism.\n\nAnd Trump himself has been guilty of galling equivalences. When he campaigned for the presidency and made goo-goo eyes at Vladimir Putin, he famously minimized Putin\u2019s reputation for having journalists and political adversaries eliminated, telling Joe Scarborough, \u201cWell, I think that our country does plenty of killing, too, Joe.\u201d\n\nBoth French\u2019s complaint and the BuzzFeed News article touch on something troubling and important: a tendency \u2014 in the media and beyond it \u2014 to treat all of public life as a pageant and a public relations contest, with winners and losers determined less by their souls than by their sizzle. Kim Yo-jong got points for being a fascinating distraction. That\u2019s a role that Trump has long played.\n\nBut there can be no mistake: America is in a rotten moment. North Korea is rotten to the core.", "title": "Opinion | The Ivanka Trump of North Korea? Oh, Please", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "It just got easier to see performances at the Joyce Theater. On Tuesday the Joyce announced two new initiatives designed to improve access to its programming.\n\nThe JoycePass gives registered dance professionals the opportunity to buy $10 tickets to any performance this season. The Pay What You Decide initiative invites patrons to watch selected shows and then decide what they would like to pay.\n\nLinda Shelton, the Joyce\u2019s executive director, said both initiatives were meant to remove barriers that might keep viewers away. \u201cThey\u2019re both about accessibility but they\u2019re targeted at two different audiences,\u201d she said by phone.\n\nMs. Shelton said the JoycePass was created to respond to dancers\u2019 needs. The Joyce already has $10 tickets, but \u201cthey\u2019re on a first-come-first-served basis and they sell out quickly,\u201d she said. \u201cWorking dancers can\u2019t always make it. They don\u2019t know their rehearsal schedules. They can\u2019t plan far enough out.\u201d She added that administrators and other dance professionals also needed flexibility and were therefore included in the program.", "title": "The Joyce Theater Announces Two Ticketing Initiatives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Anyone who has ever been on a diet knows that the standard prescription for weight loss is to reduce the amount of calories you consume.\n\nBut a new study, published Tuesday in JAMA, may turn that advice on its head. It found that people who cut back on added sugar, refined grains and highly processed foods while concentrating on eating plenty of vegetables and whole foods \u2014 without worrying about counting calories or limiting portion sizes \u2014 lost significant amounts of weight over the course of a year.\n\nThe strategy worked for people whether they followed diets that were mostly low in fat or mostly low in carbohydrates. And their success did not appear to be influenced by their genetics or their insulin-response to carbohydrates, a finding that casts doubt on the increasingly popular idea that different diets should be recommended to people based on their DNA makeup or on their tolerance for carbs or fat.\n\nThe research lends strong support to the notion that diet quality, not quantity, is what helps people lose and manage their weight most easily in the long run. It also suggests that health authorities should shift away from telling the public to obsess over calories and instead encourage Americans to avoid processed foods that are made with refined starches and added sugar, like bagels, white bread, refined flour and sugary snacks and beverages, said Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian, a cardiologist and dean of the Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy at Tufts University.", "title": "The Key to Weight Loss Is Diet Quality, Not Quantity, a New Study Finds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Porzingis, Jackson told his pal Charley Rosen in one of his 2015 diary confessionals, \u201cmight almost be too tall for the game.\u201d He added, \u201cWhat I mean is that his core strength might never be good enough, and that he might not be able to get low enough to get himself into prime defensive position to body power rebounders or drivers.\u201d\n\nNo one wishes to ever inscribe that on the likable Porzingis\u2019s career tombstone. It\u2019s just that with the Knicks\u2019 luck, and the early medical data, the cautionary caption bubble floating above the franchise player\u2019s head is not so easily burst.\n\nSans Porzingis, who had surgery on Tuesday and is projected to be out for up to a year, the Knicks surrendered a 27-point lead Wednesday night and lost to the Washington Wizards, 118-113, at a sold-out Garden, their eighth consecutive loss in a continuation of the astonishingly familiar cohabitation of losing basketball and devout fan loyalty.\n\nLogically, the remainder of the season should be a study in development of the team\u2019s young players. Illogically, among those to whom the majority of Wednesday night\u2019s minutes went were the 29-year-old journeyman gunner Michael Beasley; the 32-year-old shooting guard Courtney Lee; and the 34-year-old point guard Jarrett Jack. Those three took a combined 41 shots and made 13.\n\nNtilikina, the No. 8 pick of last June\u2019s draft, played a shade under 11 minutes, roughly half the amount granted to Emmanuel Mudiay, who at 21, after falling into disfavor in Denver, was acquired at the trade deadline last week and immediately promoted ahead of Ntilikina as the apparent point guard heir even before he knew the plays.", "title": "The Knicks at Midseason: Full Arena, No Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Today, the politics of the issue are very different. The attacks on the bill have relented now that it has passed. A steady stream of good economic news, including announcements of bonuses and raises that some corporations are attributing to the tax cut, have amounted to a substantial if belated public relations campaign for the bill. It is also possible that voters have realized they\u2019ve gotten a tax cut.\n\nThe bill isn\u2019t exactly staggeringly popular, according to more recent polls that still show that more Americans disapprove of the bill than support it. But it\u2019s polling a lot better than it did a month ago and even fairly well by the standards of President Trump\u2019s approval rating.\n\nRegardless of how it polls over all, there can be little doubt that many Republicans, who might have been dissatisfied with the accomplishments of the Republican Congress, have now gotten one of their biggest wishes.\n\nDoes that add up to a lasting change in the national political environment? Who can say. What can be said, fairly confidently, is that two weeks of good polling for the Republicans are not enough to declare that such a shift has taken place.\n\nTake a look at two ways of calculating the generic ballot polling average. Both account for the biases of various pollsters, and give more weight to higher-quality and less frequent pollsters. In light gray is a sensitive estimate \u2014 the sort of polling average you would use heading into Election Day. It doesn\u2019t care much about polling from a few weeks ago. Wednesday\u2019s Monmouth poll, which showed Democrats ahead by just two points, is far and away the most important single data point in its estimate.\n\nIn dark purple is a less sensitive estimate. It\u2019s as sensitive as the Upshot Senate model from 2014 would have been nine months from a congressional election. It\u2019s not sensitive at this stage for a simple reason: Bumps and blips don\u2019t tell you too much this far from an election.\n\nAt the moment, the two estimates tell very different stories about the generic ballot. The longer-term estimate is essentially right in line with the average since late July, when health care reform failed in the Senate. The short-term average, on the other hand, is as low as it has been since the F.B.I. director Jim Comey was fired in May.", "title": "The Last Two Weeks of Polls Have Been Great for Republicans. Do They Signal a Shift?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Offering a more traditional, but no less impressive, relationship between art and prose, THE WEIGHT OF WORDS (Subterranean, $40) is a stunningly produced anthology of original fiction inspired by the work of Dave McKean, a British artist perhaps best known for his album covers (Counting Crows\u2019 \u201cThis Desert Life\u201d) and frequent collaborations with Neil Gaiman (\u201cThe Sandman,\u201d \u201cCoraline,\u201d \u201cThe Wolves in the Walls\u201d and \u201cThe Day I Swapped My Dad for Two Goldfish,\u201d to name a few). Edited by McKean and William Schafer, the stories \u2014 by Gaiman, Alastair Reynolds, Maria Dahvana Headley, Catherynne M. Valente, Caitlin R. Kiernan, M. John Harrison, Joe R. Lansdale, Joe Hill and Iain Sinclair \u2014 are each bookended by McKean\u2019s instantly recognizable mixed-media surrealism. The anthology also includes a short comic and piece of prose fiction by McKean.\n\nMany anthologies are organized around a stated theme, but few are organized around a mood; what most impressed me about \u201cThe Weight of Words\u201d was its sustained core of loneliness, memory and loss across extraordinarily different styles of storytelling, from the sinuous far-future elegance of Reynolds\u2019s \u201cBelladonna Nights\u201d to the sharp, fragmented opacity of Sinclair\u2019s \u201cBroken Face.\u201d Every piece felt steeped in the sepia tones of McKean\u2019s unsettling art even if it seemed to make only the most glancing contact with the image\u2019s contents: Valente\u2019s \u201cNo One Dies in Nowhere,\u201d for instance, opens next to a pencil-sketched image of a bird-headed person in a long thick scarf and coat, but spins from it an affecting story of afterlives that\u2019s C. S. Lewis\u2019s \u201cThe Great Divorce\u201d dressed in hard-boiled noir by way of \u201cThe Pilgrim\u2019s Progress.\u201d Other stories are more visibly interpretations of and responses to the art. A violin cradling a naked woman beneath a tree growing out of its curves leads to Headley\u2019s \u201cThe Orange Tree,\u201d a story about an 11th-century female golem with a stringed instrument in her belly who resists her creator\u2019s abusive programming; Kiernan\u2019s \u201cObjects in the Mirror\u201d \u2014 a story of doubleness and doppelg\u00e4ngers partially written as a screenplay set in a therapist\u2019s office \u2014 is preceded by an image of a stylized head containing a person cringing from the eyepiece of a telescope, as if afraid to be seen.\n\nThe caliber of fiction here is genuinely remarkable. I fully expected the stories by Valente and Headley, whose writing I\u2019ve long loved, would be among my favorites, and they were, but Hill\u2019s \u201cAll I Care About Is You\u201d and McKean\u2019s \u201cThe Language of Birds\u201d \u2014 the first fiction I\u2019ve read by either \u2014 shocked and moved me in equal measure. In Hill\u2019s gut-punchingly perfect story, a girl struggling to adjust to her family\u2019s reversal of fortune finds a robotic friend who will be her devotee for a single paid hour, while McKean\u2019s experimentally displayed story \u2014 the sepia from his images bleeding into, over and through the text in places \u2014 speaks to the anguish of losing the \u201csweet wine golden flow\u201d of childhood perception, potential and possibility. The anthology is more than worth it for these four stories alone.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJo Walton\u2019s STARLINGS (Tachyon, paper, $15.95) \u2014 her first collection of short fiction, rounded out by poetry and a play \u2014 represents a different kind of conversation piece, one that shows an author in conversation with her work. Most of its contents are reprints, having appeared in magazines, anthologies or on Walton\u2019s website; others have been available only behind the author\u2019s walled Patreon garden.\n\n\u201cStarlings\u201d collects a range of works written between 2000 and 2017, prefaced with an introduction that lays out Walton\u2019s relationship to short fiction. \u201cFor the longest time,\u201d she says, \u201cI didn\u2019t know how to write short stories \u2026 I went on to write, and sell, a couple \u2026 that is, specifically, two. You\u2019ll find them toward the end of this book. I continue to think of myself as a novelist and a poet and not really a short fiction writer at all.\u201d\n\nAn odd start \u2014 but what emerges from the collection is not Jo Walton, writer, but Jo Walton, conversationalist. The whole volume is an entertaining discussion with its author that equals, if not exceeds, the fiction and poetry and drama in the book.\n\nWalton follows each story with a brief afterword elaborating on some combination of its origins and publication history, often debating whether the work is, in fact, a story. I often disagreed with Walton\u2019s assessment of her own work: I wanted to argue with her that \u201cThree Twilight Tales\u201d is, in fact, good short fiction and not a poem, or that some of what she calls opening chapters to unwritten novels are very accomplished short stories as well. Eventually I found myself reading the stories less to see what happened and more to see what she had to say about them.\n\n\u201cStarlings\u201d is valuable, too, as a potted history of genre communities on the internet. Walton often refers to Livejournal \u2014 many of the poems in the book first appeared there \u2014 and small online magazines like Eric Marin\u2019s Lone Star Stories, which was deeply beloved during its five years of operation from 2004 to 2009, citing them as catalysts and curators of her work and conversations.\n\nOf the poems, the standouts for me were \u201cStarlings\u201d and \u201cSleepless in New Orleans\u201d; of the stories, \u201cThree Twilight Tales,\u201d \u201cTurnover\u201d and \u201cA Burden Shared.\u201d The play, \u201cThree Shouts on a Hill,\u201d is emblematic of the entire collection: The narrative dissolves into a conversation about narrative, with a sort of grumpy impatience that manages the surprising trick of also being generous and kind.", "title": "The Latest in Science Fiction and Fantasy", "authors": ["Amal El-Mohtar"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump presidency has brought a political awakening for American progressives. It began even before he took office, with the organizing for the Women\u2019s March. Then came the citizen activists who protested at airports and later helped save health insurance for millions of people. Now high school students are trying to transform the gun debate.\n\nIn a new article in the journal Democracy, two academic researchers tell the story of the energized progressive movement. The leaders are most often suburban women alarmed by President Trump\u2019s assaults on decency and the rule of law. The movement is more bottom-up than top-down, more face-to-face than virtual, more Middle American than coastal. It does not always identify itself with the Democratic Party, even if it supports almost exclusively Democrats.\n\nThe movement is \u201cpervasively pragmatic,\u201d write the researchers, Lara Putnam of the University of Pittsburgh and Theda Skocpol of Harvard. It spans \u201cthe broad ideological range from center to left\u201d and (despite media coverage to the contrary, they argue) spends little time on Bernie-versus-Hillary fights. Above all, it is trying to elect progressives, including to oft-ignored local offices \u2014 and it\u2019s now focused on the 2018 midterms.\n\nThat\u2019s smart. Elections are precisely what progressives should be emphasizing. Protests can have an effect, as happened with Obamacare repeal and is happening on guns. But major progress on almost every issue \u2014 climate change, immigration, middle-class living standards and gun deaths \u2014 depends on electing people who want to make progress. Trump and the current leaders of Congress plainly do not.", "title": "Opinion | The Left Is Energized.
