Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWho knew it could be so windy in such a lovely place? Actually, Olympic organizers did. The Pyeongchang 2018 Organizing Committee had a \u201cmeteorology and climate team\u201d that supplied a 26-page report about weather, updated last year.\n\nThe most dominant pattern this time of year, the report warned, was the \u201cSiberian High,\u201d as cold and dry winds from the northwest come with little obstruction all the way from Siberia.\n\n\u201cHigh winds and low windchill temperatures are the most influential factors in particular during the Olympic period,\u201d the report said.\n\nThat explains the wind turbines.", "title": "The Most Dominant Force at the Olympics? Wind", "authors": ["John Branch"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI used to gargle with salt water every night,\u201d said Sara Studebaker-Hall, a former United States Olympian in the biathlon. \u201cMy mom is a nurse, and she said there was research that showed that would help. I was, like, great.\u201d\n\nArturs Darznieks, a Latvian luger, eats cloves of raw garlic, a habit he swears does not bother his girlfriend. Or his teammates, who have taken to eating cloves of garlic, too.\n\n\u201cWe are all stinky in the room,\u201d he said after his second test run down the course on Thursday. \u201cBut it\u2019s good for your immune system.\u201d\n\nScience is not convinced. James Gern, a professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison who has studied immunology, was skeptical of many of the cold-ducking practices used by Olympians. He endorsed the basics, such as sleeping, hand-washing and reducing stress. Eating raw garlic? Maybe it just keeps people at bay, he guessed. The athlete idea he liked the most belonged to Lehtonen, the guy who yanked his children out of kindergarten.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe most efficient spreaders of rhinovirus are kids,\u201d Gern said. \u201cThey are totally unhygienic and they need a lot of care. If you live with a 2-year-old who has a cold, just go get yourself a box of tissues.\u201d\n\nThe inherent problem is that winter is a cold-catching season (and flu, too, especially this year), which means the Winter Games are a more infection-focused affair than their summer counterparts. And even before the recent outbreak of norovirus, the Olympics in Pyeongchang seemed determined to turn everyone into a germaphobe.\n\nAt Incheon Airport near Seoul, travelers were greeted by a placard about the Madagascar Plague \u2014 turn yourself into the quarantine office was the gist \u2014 right before walking through a body-heat detector that flags fevers. On the way to the baggage carousel, a female voice on a recorded message offered a lengthy health-related public service announcement that included the word \u201cvomiting.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKoreans walking around with white face masks are not an uncommon sight here; it is hard to tell if they are contagious or fretting about contagion. There are signs all over the Games with instructions for how to cough properly.\n\nInto your sleeve, please.\n\nOlympians don\u2019t need the pointers. Many are acutely aware that they are especially vulnerable during the Games. There are athletes coming together from all over the world, some bearing viruses, placed in close quarters, eating in huge cafeterias with serve-yourself buffets.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t touch the big spoon unless I\u2019m wearing gloves,\u201d said Johanna Matintalo, another Finnish cross-country skier.\n\nMatintalo is proof that any contest with the rhinovirus is a gamble, even for someone who bets with care. She caught a cold a week before the Games began and has suffered a fate that is familiar to her peers: She\u2019s been banished, at least partially.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI have my own apartment,\u201d she said. \u201cI should be with my four teammates, in this apartment with five rooms, but they want to wait to make sure that I\u2019m 100 percent.\u201d\n\nThe team physician comes and takes a swab from her nose, which is then tested in a piece of equipment that Matintalo enthusiastically described as \u201cvery cool.\u201d She predicted she would move back in with roommates in another day or two.\n\nThe Australian team takes a more pitiless approach. The 20 or so members of the squad who have been deemed medal contenders have been hived off to live in what a spokesman called a \u201csub site\u201d that puts plenty of distance between them and the lesser members of the team.", "title": "The Most Dreaded Opponent at the Olympics: The Common Cold", "authors": ["David Segal"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "MILAN \u2014 He may potentially be the most powerful man in Italy, yet few people know who he is. Foreign ambassadors seek him out, even though he holds no public office. He claims to be but a simple member of a political movement, volunteering free technical assistance, but critics say he and his small Milan company control the votes, the candidates and the policies of the country\u2019s leading party.\n\nAs Italy faces critical national elections on Sunday, the media-shy internet entrepreneur, Davide Casaleggio, is the Wizard of Oz-like figure behind the tightly drawn curtain of the country\u2019s front-running Five Star Movement as it approaches real political power.\n\nSince its birth less than a decade ago, the party has confounded Europe\u2019s establishment and promoted itself as an internet-based insurgent party that could change Italy\u2019s politics. It has gained support, especially among young voters, by presenting itself as a truly transparent, egalitarian political movement that votes on its candidates \u2014 as well as positions \u2014 on the web.\n\nYet on the way to becoming a forum for unfiltered democracy, Five Star has grown into Italy\u2019s most opaque political party, and Mr. Casaleggio its most enigmatic leader in an era when the web is a mire of hacking, fake news and hidden interests.", "title": "The Mystery Man Who Runs Italy\u2019s \u2018Five Star\u2019 From the Shadows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "When the first American ground forces, the Marines, landed at Danang in 1965, V.O.V., which was based in the north, started propaganda broadcasts to the troops.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy then the airwaves over North and South Vietnam had become a confusing battleground of conflicting propaganda voices. Working on the premise of \u201ccapture their minds and their hearts will follow,\u201d both sides supported dozens of radio stations spewing malice and disinformation 24 hours a day. Hannah\u2019s scripts were written by North Vietnam Army propaganda experts, and advised by Cubans. Her programs were soon extended to 30 minutes and broadcast three times a day.\n\nShe was a source of news, as well. Hanoi Hannah broke one of the most shocking stories of the Vietnam War \u2014 the massacre of several hundred civilians in the village of My Lai in 1968. Just weeks after the massacre, Hannah accurately named the location and estimated the civilian death toll, but she misidentified the American Army division involved, enabling the Americans to deny the report and treat it like another example of disinformation from North Vietnam.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI first heard the silken voice of Hanoi Hannah in September 1965, in a Special Forces base at An Lac, about a hundred miles west of Nha Trang. As a news correspondent, I had been on patrol with Montagnard irregulars and their American advisers. It had been raining hard for a week, keeping the supply plane that was my ticket out from coming in. At night after the perimeter was secured there wasn\u2019t much to do but play cards, read, drink Ba Moi Ba beer and listen to the radio. Up there in the Central Highlands, the Voice of Vietnam boomed in loud and clear.\n\nThat night Hannah was interspersing Western rock music with her reports. The sounds of the Animals, singing \u201cWe Gotta Get Outta This Place,\u201d was followed by Hannah: Now for the war news. American casualties in Vietnam. Army Corporal Larry J. Samples, Canada, Alabama \u2026 Staff Sergeant Charles R. Miller, Tucson, Arizona \u2026 Sergeant Frank Hererra, Coolige, Arizona.\u201d\n\nHer broadcasts were mostly exaggerated war news, encouragement to \u201cfrag\u201d \u2014 assassinate \u2014 an officer and go AWOL, or suggestions that the soldiers\u2019 wives or girlfriends were cheating on them. She was mostly greeted with loud laughter. But taped interviews with downed pilots or from American antiwar advocates like Jane Fonda were heard with anger.\n\nFor bored G.I.s, Hannah\u2019s broadcasts were often rare sources of amusement. A man\u2019s radio was, after his rifle, his most valued possession. Like the rifle butt, the radio was often wrapped in frayed black tape for protection. Troops would laugh over Hannah\u2019s attempts to scare them into defection or suggestions to frag an officer. However, they did wonder if she was as lovely as she sounded, and many considered her the most prominent enemy after Ho Chi Minh.\n\nHannah regularly addressed her comments to black American G.I.s. In one broadcast, she said, \u201cA Vietnam black G.I. who refuses to be a victim of racism is Billy Smith. It seems on the morning of March 15th a fragmentation grenade went off in an officer\u2019s barracks in Bien Hoa killing two gung-ho lieutenants. Smith was illegally searched, arrested and put in Long Binh jail and brought home for trial. The evidence that showed him guilty was this: being black, poor and against the war and refusing to be a victim of racism.\u201d\n\nWhen violence broke out in Detroit on July 23, 1967, Hannah jumped on the news. American military stations were quiet; she broadcast every detail she had available.\n\nMike Roberts, a soldier from Detroit based in Danang, remembers that week well. \u201cHannah comes on and she knows what guard unit was called in and what kind of weapons were used,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s when it starts to hit home. We knew what kind of fire power and devastation that kind of weapon can do to people, and now those same weapons were turning on us, you know, our own military is killing our own people. We might as well have been Viet Cong. But Hannah picked up on it and talked about it.\u201d\n\nHanoi Hannah could always be assured of at least the American audience that would hear her broadcasts \u2014 the prisoners of war in places like the Hanoi Hilton. John McCain, a Hanoi Hilton inmate for over five years, recently remarked: \u201cI heard Hannah every day. She was a marvelous entertainer. I\u2019m surprised she didn\u2019t get to Hollywood.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLt. Cmdr. Ray Voden, shot down over Hanoi on April 3, 1965, listened to her for eight years. \u201cHannah often stirred up arguments among the P.O.W.s. There were nearly fist fights over the programs. Some guys wanted to hear them, while others tried to ignore them. Personally, I listened because I usually gleaned information, reading between the lines.\u201d\n\nFor almost five years after I became a correspondent for ABC News, I would tape-record her programs almost daily, in case she said something newsworthy or presented a captured American pilot on her program. To me, she was just another source of information or disinformation to be checked out and sorted in the communications pudding of the Vietnam War.\n\nIn May 1978, I returned to Vietnam and asked the Foreign Ministry to arrange an interview for me with Trinh Thi Ngo. By then Hanoi Hannah had left her beloved Hanoi and moved to Ho Chi Minh City, the renamed city of Saigon, with her husband, who was a southerner and a Vietnamese Army officer. The appointment was set up for the rooftop bar of the Rex Hotel, where I waited along with Ken Watkins, who had been a Marine corpsman and a regular listener to Hannah.\n\nWhile we waited, Ken recalled his memories of Hannah. \u201cThe signal was pretty good around Danang and we would tune in once or twice a week to hear her talk about the war,\u201d he said. \u201cHannah didn\u2019t necessarily make sense; she used American English, but really didn\u2019t speak our language in spite of hip expressions and hit tunes, even tunes banned on U.S. Army radio. The best thing going for her was that she was female and had a nice soft voice.\u201d\n\nI asked if he was still angry at her. \u201cSure,\u201d he said, \u201csome antagonism, add it to the Vietnam list. But this trip back is about coming full circle on a lot of things, and she is another voice from the past I want to confront in person.\u201d\n\nSo an ex-Marine and an old war correspondent waited that sunny morning for the real Hanoi Hannah to appear, waiting for reality to sweep away the years of bitter images in the windmills of our minds. Dragon Lady? Psy-warrior? Prophet? Or what?\n\nLike so many phantoms of the war, she was not what we imagined. She didn\u2019t look like the \u201cDragon Lady\u201d from \u201cTerry and the Pirates\u201d comics. Elegant and attractive in a striking yellow ao dai, the Vietnamese traditional dress, she appeared happy to answer our questions.\n\nAfter she sat down, I asked where she got her information.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. Army Stars and Stripes,\u201d she replied, referring to the main military newspaper. \u201cWe read from it. We had it flown in every day. We also read Newsweek, Time and several other newspapers. We took remarks of American journalists and put them in our broadcasts, especially about casualties.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDid she ever feel anger toward the American troops?\n\n\u201cWhen the bombs came on Hanoi, I did feel angry,\u201d she said. \u201cTo the Vietnamese, Hanoi is a sacred ground. But even then, when I spoke to the G.I.s I tried always to be calm. I never felt aggression toward Americans as a people. I never called them the enemy, only adversaries.\u201d\n\nWe chatted for a while, about her aims, her successes, her regrets. Then I had one more question \u2014 what would she say now, if she had one final broadcast to American G.I.s?\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s let bygones be bygones,\u201d she replied. \u201cLet\u2019s move on and be friends. There will be many benefits if we can be friends together. There is no reason to be enemies.\u201d\n\nMeeting and interviewing Hanoi Hannah was, for me, like being Dorothy parting the curtains hiding the Wizard of Oz. The terrible Hannah behind the facade that we constructed, turned out to be a mild-mannered announcer who spoke English and read the Stars and Stripes.\n\nTrinh Thi Ngo died on Sept. 30, 2016 at the age of 85. She was interred in Long Tri, Chau Than District, Long An province, following the Vietnamese custom of burial next to her husband and his family. Her only son escaped Vietnam in 1973 and now lives in San Francisco.", "title": "The Mystery of Hanoi Hannah", "authors": ["Don North"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The top voting machine maker in the country, ES&S, distributes modems or modeming capability with many of its DRE and optical-scan machines. (Some states, including California and New York, require voting machine makers to not only remove communication devices from their systems but also eliminate communications capability from their software for security.) About 35,000 of ES&S\u2019s newest precinct-based optical scanner, the DS200, are used in 31 states and the District of Columbia and can be outfitted with either analog or cellular modems to transmit results. Maryland, Maine, Rhode Island and the District of Columbia use only DS200 machines statewide (though they also use two other systems specifically for disabled voters and absentee ballots); Florida and Wisconsin use the DS200s in dozens of counties, and other states use them to lesser degrees. ES&S\u2019s earlier model M100 optical scanners, which also can be equipped with modems, have long been used in Michigan \u2014 a critical swing state in the 2016 presidential election \u2014 though the state is upgrading to DS200 machines this year, as well as machines made by Dominion Voting Systems. Dominion\u2019s machines use external serial-port modems that are connected to machines after an election ends.\n\nNot every polling place with embedded modems uses them to transmit results. Richard Rydecki, Wisconsin\u2019s state elections supervisor, says counties in his state decide individually whether to transmit election results. Fred Woodhams, spokesman from the Michigan Department of State, said the same is true in his state. But even if a precinct doesn\u2019t use its modems, having them embedded in voting machines is still a risk, experts say.\n\n\u201cIf it is available for use\u201d by an attacker, says Stauffer, \u201cit can be used.\u201d\n\nES&S insists that its security measures would prevent hackers exploiting or interfering with modem transmissions. According to a one-page document the company provided, the voting machines digitally sign voting results before transmitting them via modem and encrypt them in transit using SFTP \u2014 secure file transfer protocol. The election-management systems that receive results then check the signature to authenticate the data transmission. This theoretically means results couldn\u2019t be swapped out and replaced with different ones. That is, unless an attacker can obtain ES&S\u2019s signing key.\n\nThese keys, explains noted cryptographer and computer-security expert Matt Blaze, \u2018\u2018need to be stored in the machine, and if they\u2019re stored in the machine and under control of the software, any compromise of that software could be used potentially to extract\u201d them. Blaze, who teaches at the University of Pennsylvania, says that ES&S machines he examined for Ohio\u2019s secretary of state a decade ago had a number of security problems, including with key security.\n\nAs for using the modems to hack into machines and compromise their software, ES&S says its modems are configured to only initiate calls, not receive them, and can make calls only after an election ends, preventing anyone from dialing in or having them dial out at other times. The company also says results are not sent directly to the election-management systems but to a data communications server that operates as a DMZ, or \u2018\u2018demilitarized zone,\u2019\u2019 separated from the internet and the election-management system by firewalls. The election-management system accesses the DMZ to collect the results.\n\nES&S advises election officials to configure the external firewall that protects the DMZ to only accept connections from IP addresses assigned to the voting machines. And election officials in Rhode Island, which uses ES&S\u2019s DS200 machines with modems, told me that the modems only transmit for about a minute, which wouldn\u2019t be sufficient to hack into voting machines or results servers.\n\nBut Stauffer and others say none of this would prevent a skilled hacker from penetrating the machines via their modems. Although overwriting the machine\u2019s firmware, or voting software, would be difficult to do in just a minute, Stauffer says installing malware on the underlying operating system would not. An attacker might be able to do this directly through the modem to the voting machine, or infect the election-management system on the other end and install malware that gets passed to voting machines when officials program future elections. In either case, the malware could disable modem controls on the voting machines and make the devices secretly dial out to whatever number an attacker wants whenever he wants, while also altering system logs to erase evidence of these calls. This would let an attacker connect to the machines before or during an election to install malicious voting software that subverts results.", "title": "The Myth of the Hacker-Proof Voting Machine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "But there will be no such drama this weekend in Los Angeles. Indeed, there will be no deals at all \u2014 blockbuster or otherwise. The N.B.A.\u2019s annual trade deadline was on Feb. 8 this year, marking the first time in at least four decades that it occurred before the All-Star Game was played.\n\nIt\u2019s difficult to be more precise than that because the league\u2019s official records on the matter date only to 1987. But a research assist we received from an indispensable Twitter follow for fans of the game\u2019s rich (but often overlooked) past \u2014 @ProHoopsHistory \u2014 confirmed that the trade deadline had come after the All-Star Game going as far back as the 1978-79 season.\n\nWhat can be said without hesitation is that without any trade talk in the background, this All-Star weekend feels drastically different from any in recent memory. Just as the N.B.A. had hoped.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cOur goals in moving up the trade deadline were twofold \u2014 to avoid it being a distraction over All-Star weekend and to allow traded players to use the All-Star break to get acclimated to their new teams and cities,\u201d Adam Silver, the N.B.A. commissioner, said earlier in the week. \u201cEarly returns have been positive.\u201d\n\nThe reviews have been closer to glowing. The Cleveland Cavaliers, in fact, were prepared to submit their enthusiastic support as soon as the calendar change was announced last summer.\n\n\u201cWe were thrilled,\u201d the Cavaliers\u2019 general manager, Koby Altman, said.\n\nAltman certainly never envisioned in July that he would end up making three massive trades right at the Feb. 8 deadline to essentially reconfigure half his roster.\n\nYet as Altman noted in an interview on Friday afternoon, shortly after he landed in Los Angeles for the All-Star festivities, Cleveland has \u201chistorically always made some sort of move\u201d around the trade deadline. So the Cavaliers were always on board with moving up the deadline, which, in turn, would speed the transition process for any on-the-fly additions to the roster.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAdditions that the Cavaliers ended up making in dramatic fashion to essentially remake half the team around LeBron James.\n\nAltman chuckled when he was asked to imagine what it would have felt like on Sunday, for both him and his star player, if the trade deadline had not yet passed and James would be on the court with the other All-Stars while the Cavaliers were still trying to complete all of their trade business.\n\nThe Cavaliers still have two open roster spots to fill despite the moves they made. Still, Altman is now comfortable enough with the state of his team\u2019s makeover that he felt free to join three other Cavaliers staff members on Thursday night on a scouting trip to Tempe to watch Arizona beat Arizona State.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m certainly relieved,\u201d he said.\n\nWhich, in turn, makes for a more enjoyable All-Star weekend. When I spoke on Friday with Mark Cuban, the Dallas Mavericks\u2019 owner, he joked that he was still recovering from his All-Star experience in New Orleans a decade ago. During that weekend, in February 2008, Dallas and the Nets strained to agree on terms that the league would accept so that a blockbuster deal headlined by Jason Kidd could go through.\n\nDespite two motivated teams, the proposed trade hit roadblock after roadblock and collapsed multiple times.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI still remember that weekend of the J-Kidd trade \u2014 brutal,\u201d Cuban said. \u201cThis is much better. Far less stress than before.\u201d\n\nWe\u2019ll have to see, of course, whether the removal of all that trade angst helps Sunday\u2019s show. There\u2019s no question that fan interest a year ago was fixated far more on the prospect of Cousins being moved than on the game itself, especially after the Kings had publicly and privately insisted Cousins was going nowhere.\n\nPerhaps the absence of smothering trade speculation, along with the well-chronicled format change that established James and Stephen Curry as team captains instead of employing the traditional East vs. West format, will provide the game with the jolt it needs and the N.B.A. has been trying to manufacture.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstinct tells you, at the very least, that it won\u2019t be hard for the TV cameras to find Magic Johnson during Sunday\u2019s broadcast. Johnson will undoubtedly be visible in his new role as president of the Los Angeles Lakers after the Lakers happily played their part in the Cavaliers\u2019 trade spree 10 days ago.\n\nA year ago, of course, no cameras could have zeroed in on Demps. The only way to know where he was at the time would have been to find out from his wife.\n\nDennis Lindsey, the Utah Jazz executive who had worked alongside Demps years earlier in San Antonio, did cross paths with Anita Demps as the All-Star Game was being played and asked if her husband was around.\n\nWhich is how Lindsey ended up in Demps\u2019s office. The old friends visited for a bit, but Demps never let on that he was only a Sacramento signoff away from sealing a deal to acquire Cousins.\n\nWhen news of the trade began to spread later that evening, Demps promptly received a text from Lindsey that read: \u201cMan \u2026 I\u2019m never playing poker with you.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s really nothing in sports these days quite like trade poker in the N.B.A. But the final buzzer on that activity, like it or not, has sounded until June, when the draft comes into focus and all the wheeling, dealing and, yes, bluffing starts anew.", "title": "The N.B.A. All-Star Game Has Shed a Major Distraction", "authors": ["Marc Stein", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn the dunk contest, if you are having LeBron and Paul George, it would be very popular,\u201d said Clyde Drexler, who, when he was an active player, took part in both the dunk and the 3-point contest. \u201cA lot of guys are afraid to get in the dunk contest because they may not win and it\u2019ll hurt their brand.\u2019\u2019\n\nThe N.B.A. has taken steps to try to revamp the dunk contest. It has, at different times, changed the number of competitors, allowed first-round byes and then taken them away, changed the scoring system, added and then taken away a wheel that selects what dunk a player should perform and incorporated fan voting. In contrast, the rules for the 3-point competition, which began in 1986, have stayed largely the same.\n\nNevertheless, notes Michael Bass, the chief spokesman for the N.B.A., the dunk contest remains the highest-rated event on the Saturday night of All-Star weekend, even if the 3-point contest is drawing bigger-name players. \u201cMaybe we will see that change over time,\u2019\u2019 he added. \u201cThe interest in the 3-point-shooting contest has certainly taken off.\u2019\u2019\n\nEven with that surge in interest, there is talk of altering the 3-point format. Knicks Coach Jeff Hornacek, a former 3-point contest participant, has suggested holding separate contests for big men and guards. Fraser has wondered about the possibility of adding a deeper, half-court shot that would be worth more points. Miller excitedly detailed why the league should have a former 3-point contest winner team with a current N.B.A. shooter in an old-school/new-school competition.\n\n\u201cThis is the one way you would get me out of retirement to participate: have a legend \u2014 Ray Allen, Dell Curry, Dale Ellis \u2014 team up with the current guys,\u201d Miller said. \u201cI would go first, he would go second. People want to see Ray Allen. People would want to see Larry Bird. I think that would be hot.\u201d\n\nFor now, at least, the total prize money for the dunk and 3-point contests remains the same. It\u2019s $200,000 for each, although the winner of the four-player dunk contest will get $105,000 and the first-place finisher in the eight-player 3-point competition will take home $60,000.\n\nBut the biggest payoff is the attention garnered by finishing first. And being the 3-point champion is perhaps starting to mean more than being the best dunker.", "title": "The N.B.A. Dunk Contest Has the History. The 3-Point Contest Has the Stars.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Hundreds have been killed in mass shootings at a high school in Littleton, Colo., a church in Charleston, S.C., an office party in San Bernardino, Calif., a nightclub in Orlando, Fla., and elsewhere in the past 20 years. After 20 first graders and a half-dozen adults were slaughtered in Newtown, Conn., in 2012, it seemed that a line would be drawn in the sand. Enough was enough, people said. But nothing was done. People have been injured or killed in eight school shootings in the first seven weeks of 2018 alone.\n\nThough many Americans, and some elected officials, have taken a stand to stanch the epidemic of gun violence, the National Rifle Association and its congressional servants have been an unyielding obstacle to sensible reform.\n\nBut the gun lobby\u2019s stranglehold on our elected officials does not need to continue, if candidates stand up to the lobby and voters demand that they commit themselves to the sorts of changes that a vast majority of Americans want.\n\nWith midterm elections coming up this fall, America has a chance to get that message across. Candidates must realize that reducing gun violence is a winning and moral issue. Aggressive turnout by voters who believe this can defeat the N.R.A. at the polls. Until then, the bloodshed will continue.", "title": "Opinion | The N.R.A. Can Be Beat", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAs gunshots echoed through the high school, a geography teacher, Scott Beigel, 35, paused to usher stragglers into his classroom before locking the door, only to be shot and killed himself as the shooter strode by.\n\nA parent, Jennifer Zeif, credited Mr. Beigel for saving her son\u2019s life. Her son, Matthew, 14, had been the last one to slip inside the class, just ahead of Mr. Beigel. Seconds later, the room filled with a smoky haze, Matthew said, and he turned to see his teacher lying near the door, pale and bleeding.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMr. Beigel could have passed Matthew up and gone in the classroom first,\u201d Ms. Zeif said. \u201cIn that case, Matthew would have been the one in the doorway.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, as officials identified 17 people killed in the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., some of the victims, like Mr. Beigel, were remembered for having tried to spare others in the moments of chaos that unfolded inside the school.\n\nAaron Feis, a popular football coach who was killed, also had tried to protect students, officials said. \u201cHe was that kind of guy,\u201d said Jack Fris, a former football player at the school.\n\nFriends said they were not surprised that Mr. Beigel, a much-beloved figure at a Pennsylvania summer camp that he attended and later helped to run, had put his students\u2019 safety above his own.\n\n\u201cThousands of people at Camp Starlight looked up to Scott,\u201d said Grant Williams, 33, an emergency room nurse who worked with Mr. Beigel at the camp for several summers and was mourning long-distance with former camp counselors and campers on Thursday. \u201cHe was someone you strive to be like,\u201d said another former Starlight counselor.\n\nAt the Florida high school, teachers and students were among the dead. There was a soccer player, a student nicknamed Guac and a trombonist in the marching band. Eight of the victims were girls and young women; nine were boys and men. They ranged from 14 years old to 49.\n\nThese are some of their stories.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlyssa Alhadeff\n\nAlyssa Alhadeff, 14, had played competitive soccer since she was 3 years old. Like any athlete, she had her ups and downs. But when her club, Parkland, faced off against the rival team from Coral Springs on Feb. 13, she was at the top of her game.\n\n\u201cHer passing was on, her shooting was on, her decision-making was on,\u201d her mother, Lori Alhadeff, recalled. With her outgoing personality, Alyssa had a wide circle of friends at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. She placed first in a debate tournament, was taking Algebra 2 and Spanish 3, and was honing her skills as an attacking midfielder. The score at what was to be her last time on the soccer field was 1-0, Parkland.\n\n\u201cI was so proud of her,\u201d her mother said. \u201cI told her it was the best game of her life.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMartin Duque Anguiano\n\nMartin Duque Anguiano, a 14-year-old freshman, was \u201ca very funny kid, outgoing and sometimes really quiet,\u201d his brother, Miguel Duque, wrote on a GoFundMe page for funeral expenses.\n\n\u201cHe was sweet and caring and loved by all his family,\u201d Miguel wrote. \u201cMost of all he was my baby brother.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNicholas Dworet\n\nNicholas Dworet, a promising high school swimmer, took a recruiting visit to the University of Indianapolis a few weeks ago. After a group dinner, he pulled the coach aside and said he wanted to compete there after he graduated this spring.\n\n\u201cHe was an instant part of our family,\u201d said Jason Hite, the university\u2019s swim coach. Mr. Hite said Nicholas, 17, had received an academic scholarship and planned to study physical therapy.\n\nUniversity officials and a youth swim team in Florida said Nicholas was among those killed on Wednesday. A post on the Facebook page for TS Aquatics, the Florida club where he swam, described Nicholas as an amazing person who had been \u201con a major upswing in his life.\u201d\n\nNicholas had improved academically and athletically since starting high school, Mr. Hite said, and his mentors in Florida \u201cfelt like the best was still to come for him.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe were going to continue to groom him to be a future leader for our team,\u201d Mr. Hite said.\n\nMr. Hite said he sent Nicholas a text message on Wednesday afternoon after hearing about the shooting at his school. He got no response.\n\n\u201cThe saddest thing to me is how much life this kid had and how hard he had worked to change directions and change paths,\u201d Mr. Hite said. \u201cHe was really going in the right direction and he had really created some opportunities for himself.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAaron Feis\n\nAt Stoneman Douglas, Mr. Feis was known to all \u2014 an assistant football coach and a security monitor. But he too had graduated from the school, played on the football team, and knew exactly what it was like to be a student in these halls.\n\nSo he was seen as someone who looked out for students who got in trouble, those who were struggling, those without fathers at home. \u201cThey said he was like another father,\u201d Mr. Feis\u2019s grandfather, Raymond, recalled. \u201cHe\u2019d go out of his way to help anybody.\u201d\n\nSchool officials said that Mr. Feis, 37, did the same on Wednesday. When there were signs of trouble, they said, he responded immediately to help. \u201cWhen Aaron Feis died, when he was killed \u2014 tragically, inhumanely \u2014 he did it protecting others; you can guarantee that,\u201d said Scott Israel, the sheriff of Broward County.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know when Aaron\u2019s funeral is,\u201d Sheriff Israel said. \u201cI don\u2019t know how many adults are going to go, but you\u2019ll get 2,000 kids there.\u201d\n\nIn Parkland, Austin Lazar, a student, recalled his former coach as cheery and selfless. \u201cHe always put everybody before himself.\u201d\n\nMr. Feis was married, his family said, and had a daughter, Arielle.\n\nPhoto\n\nJaime Guttenberg\n\nJaime Guttenberg, 14, danced nonstop. Sometimes she went on for hours, her aunt, Ellyn Guttenberg, said. Jaime was warm, too, always taking Ms. Guttenberg\u2019s son, who has special needs, under her wing.\n\n\n\nJaime\u2019s Facebook page, now memorialized, shows photos of her dancing, hanging out with friends, enjoying the beach and snuggling a dog.\n\nHer father, Fred Guttenberg, posted this on Facebook: \u201cI am broken as I write this trying to figure out how my family gets through this.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nChristopher Hixon\n\nChristopher Hixon, 49, the school\u2019s athletic director, was a well-known figure in Florida high school sports. One man, Jose Roman, posted on social media that Mr. Hixon was \u201ca great coach and an awesome motivator\u201d when he was a freshman athlete years ago.\n\nMr. Hixon was named athletic director of the year in 2017 by the Broward County Athletics Association.\n\nPhoto\n\nLuke Hoyer\n\nLuke Hoyer, 15, spent last Christmas with his extended family in South Carolina, where he bowled, joined in a big holiday meal and swapped stories with relatives.\n\nA cousin, Grant Cox, who was at the Christmas gathering said the family had been told by the police that Luke, a freshman at Stoneman Douglas, was among those killed on Wednesday.\n\nMr. Cox said Luke was a basketball player who was ambitious about the sport and admired N.B.A. stars like LeBron James and Stephen Curry.\n\n\u201cI know Luke loved his family,\u201d Mr. Cox said. \u201cI know he did. He had a huge heart.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe was quiet, but a very happy individual,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nCara Loughran\n\nCara Loughran, 14, loved the beach. She adored her cousins. And she was an excellent student, her family said.\n\n\u201cWe are absolutely gutted,\u201d by her death, her aunt, Lindsay Fontana, wrote in a Facebook post. \u201cWhile your thoughts are appreciated, I beg you to DO SOMETHING. This should not have happened to our niece Cara and it cannot happen to other people\u2019s families.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nGina Montalto\n\nGina Montalto, 14, was identified in local news accounts as a member of her school\u2019s winter color guard team.\n\nAndy Mroczek, who has worked as a choreographer at Stoneman Douglas, posted a tribute to Gina on Facebook. \u201cWe lost a beautiful soul tonight,\u201d he wrote.\n\nPhoto\n\nJoaquin Oliver\n\nPeople often spelled Joaquin Oliver\u2019s first name wrong, so he went with a snappy nickname: Guac.\n\nHe played basketball in the city recreational league \u2014 his jersey number was 2 \u2014 and he loved to write, filling a notebook with poetry, said Julien Decoste, a close friend of Joaquin\u2019s and a fellow senior at Stoneman Douglas.\n\n\u201cGuac and I always wanted to graduate together and prove everyone wrong, that we would be successful together,\u201d Julien said.\n\nOn Tuesday, Joaquin, 17, asked Julien to help out at his next basketball game, which was scheduled for Thursday.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll be there,\u201d Julien texted his friend. \u201cGood looks brotha,\u201d Joaquin responded.\n\nOn Wednesday, as he hid inside a closet during the shooting, Julien texted Joaquin to check in.\n\n\u201cYou good?\u201d Julien texted. \u201cBro I need you to answer me please.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlaina Petty\n\nAlaina Petty, 14, had helped do cleanup work in Florida after Hurricane Irma, her family said in a statement, and she was an active member of a volunteer group with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.\n\n\u201cHer selfless service brought peace and joy to those that had lost everything during the storm,\u201d the family\u2019s statement said. \u201cWhile we will not have the opportunity to watch her grow up and become the amazing woman we know she would become, we are keeping an eternal perspective.\u201d\n\nAlaina was also a member of the Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps, her family said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMeadow Pollack\n\nMeadow Pollack, 18, was a senior at the high school who was planning to go to Lynn University in Boca Raton, Fla., next year, according to her father, Andrew Pollack, who said his daughter was among the dead.\n\n\u201cShe was just unbelievable,\u201d Mr. Pollack said. \u201cShe was a very strong-willed young girl who had everything going for her.\u201d\n\nMr. Pollack described his daughter as smart, beautiful and caring. She worked at her boyfriend\u2019s family\u2019s motorcycle repair business.\n\n\u201cShe just knew how to get what she wanted all the time,\u201d Mr. Pollack said. \u201cNothing could ever stop her from what she wanted to achieve.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHelena Ramsay\n\nHelena Ramsay, 17, was smart, kindhearted and thoughtful, her relative, Curtis Page, wrote on Facebook.\n\n\u201cThough she was somewhat reserved, she had a relentless motivation towards her academic studies, and her soft warm demeanor brought the best out in all who knew her,\u201d he said, later adding: \u201cShe would have started college next year.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlex Schachter\n\nAlex Schachter, 14, played the trombone in the Stoneman Douglas marching band, and was proud to have participated in winning a state championship last year. A freshman at the high school, he often played basketball with friends and was \u201ca sweetheart of a kid,\u201d his father, Max Schachter, said. Earlier this week, the two had discussed which classes Alex would take next semester.\n\nMr. Schachter said Alex had loved his mother, who died when he was five years old. His older brother also attends Stoneman Douglas and survived the shooting. Alex \u201cjust wanted to do well and make his parents happy,\u201d his father said.\n\nPhoto\n\nCarmen Schentrup\n\nCarmen Schentrup, a 2018 National Merit Scholarship semifinalist, was the smartest 16-year-old that her cousin, Matt Brandow, had ever met, he said in a Facebook post.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m in a daze right now,\u201d he wrote.\n\nPeter Wang\n\nPhoto\n\nPeter Wang, 15, a freshman, helped his cousin, Aaron Chen, adjust when he settled in Florida.\n\n\u201cHe was always so nice and so generous,\u201d Aaron, 16, said, adding that even though Peter was younger he had worked to be sure Aaron didn\u2019t get bullied when he first arrived.\n\nPeter was last seen in his gray uniform for the Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps, or J.R.O.T.C., on Wednesday. On Thursday, Aaron and another cousin said the authorities had informed the family that Peter was among those killed in the shooting.\n\n\u201cHe was the kid in school who would be friends with anyone,\u201d said the other cousin, Lin Chen, 24. \u201cHe didn\u2019t care about popularity.\u201d", "title": "The Names and Faces of the Florida School Shooting Victims", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood", "Amy Harmon", "Mitch Smith", "Maya Salam"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "First, as mass immigration increases diversity, it reduces social cohesion and civic trust. This is not a universal law, as the economics writer Noah Smith has pointed out; there are counter-examples and ways to resist the trend. However, it is a finding that strongly comports with the real-world experience of Europe and America, where as cultural diversity has increased so has social distrust, elite-populist conflict, and the racial, religious and generational polarization of political parties.\n\nMoreover, the trust problem is not a simple matter of racist natives mistrusting foreigners, since social trust is often weakest among minorities \u2014 which is one reason why the most diverse generation in American history, the millennials, is also the least trusting. So you can see the political effects of distrust even if you ignore the Trump Republicans entirely: It\u2019s one reason why campus politics are so toxic, why Democrats struggle to keep their diverse coalition politically engaged, and why the Bernie-Hillary contest produced so many cries of racism and sexism.\n\nThen linked to these ethno-cultural tensions are the tensions of class, where mass immigration favors stratification and elite self-segregation. In the United States, as in France and England, regions and cities with the largest immigrant populations are often the wealthiest and most dynamic. But this doesn\u2019t mean that poorer regions are dying from their own xenophobia, as is sometimes suggested. The hinterlands are also filled with people who might want to move to wealthier regions (or who used to live there) but can\u2019t because an immigrants-and-professionals ecosystem effectively prices out the middle class.\n\nIt is a testament to immigrants\u2019 grit and determination that they can thrive working long hours for low wages while living in crowded housing with long commutes. But the social order of, say, the Bay Area or greater Paris is not one that can serve for an entire country \u2014 and it ill-serves not only lower-middle-class natives but also the descendants of the immigrants themselves, whose ability to advance beyond their parents is limited by a continued arrival of new workers who compete with them for jobs and wages and housing.\n\nThus our rich and diverse states also often feature high poverty rates when their cost of living is considered, while second and third-generation immigrants often drift into the same stagnation as the white working class \u2026", "title": "Opinion | The Necessary Immigration Debate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "So why is portraiture returning now? For one, there is an institutional urgency to speak to a more diverse audience with painting that depicts the black community, the Asian-American experience, the Latino face, to attract the various people who had been excluded from the museum by remaking the history of figurative painting, this time with color. Not that the trend toward realist portraits is exclusive to artists of color. It is evident in the rococo renderings of Sam McKinniss, who paints pop culture figures \u2014 Prince, Lorde, Flipper \u2014 like hallowed aristocrats. It was clear in a series of self-portraits by Justin Vivian Bond \u2014 who is best known for experimental cabaret performances \u2014 that were displayed at the New Museum last fall, and seemed to casually but definitively announce Bond\u2019s identity as a trans artist.\n\nAnd there is another reason for figurative paintings\u2019 resurgence as well: We live in a time in which reality is almost daily warped in ways that were unimaginable even 18 months ago. We have swiftly entered an era where the very notion of truth, or facts, is considered fungible. As we reassess the various power structures that landed us here, it is stabilizing and reassuring to look at the work of an artist who is clearly in control of her craft, who is able to depict a reality that is material and grounded in recognition \u2014 of seeing, in the Facebook age, a painting that looks like who it is meant to.\n\nTHE CURRENT GENERATION of figurative paintings owes a debt to Kerry James Marshall, whose 2016 multicity retrospective cemented the artist\u2019s often-stated goal, one that is as straightforward as it is enormous: to put blackness into art history. The painter\u2019s brilliantly simple gambit, one that has allowed for decades of elaboration, was to literalize that blackness. Starting in 1980 with a mischievous little egg-tempera \u2014 \u201cA Portrait of the Artist as a Shadow of His Former Self,\u201d which features a grin missing a crucial tooth \u2014 Marshall has painted his African-American subjects mostly in unmixed black paint. Ever since, these figures have been seen \u2014 boldly and yet barely \u2014 in a variety of settings: the artist\u2019s studio, the hairdresser\u2019s, parks, bedrooms, outer space. Their blackness makes each inclusion subtly register as an exclusion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis idea is expanded upon in the work of Amy Sherald, who was Michelle Obama\u2019s choice to paint her official portrait. Sherald uses grisaille \u2014 a method of painting in gray monochrome \u2014 for her subjects\u2019 skin. Because her gradations slyly allude to the mixed and often unacknowledged backgrounds of African-Americans, Sherald\u2019s paintings make an important statement about our racial history. One 2016 image, \u201cListen, You a Wonder. You a City of a Woman. You Got a Geography of Your Own,\u201d features a woman wearing a skirt dotted with black flowers. As if to underline the point, she is suspending a black purse in front of her belly.\n\nPhoto\n\nArtists like Marshall and Sherald suggest that in its exclusion of people of color, the issue of representation in painting is really a matter of misrepresentation. The best portrait painters working today introduce something new into art not through stylistic innovations, but by whom they choose as subjects. Aliza Nisenbaum, who was among the most prominent artists in last year\u2019s Whitney Biennial, looks at undocumented immigrants from Latin America in her work. The artist, who hails from Mexico City, shifted her painting practice from abstract to portraiture around 2010, while working with Cuban artist Tania Bruguera\u2019s Immigrant Movement International, an art project in Queens which provides social services to the neighborhood\u2019s large immigrant community. Nisenbaum realized that the portrait process \u2014 long, slow, intimate \u2014 gave her a way to get to know this community. Additionally, she recognized that painting these people\u2019s pictures would be one way to address their erasure in other areas of life. Nisenbaum has since expanded the project to include portrait-making workshops for the immigrants themselves. As if to complete the circle, the 2017 work \u201cWise Elders Portraiture Class at Centro Tyrone Guzman. En Familia hay Fuerza with mural on the history of immigrant farm labor to the United States,\u201d shows the students holding the portraits they themselves learned to draw.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s most surprising about the recent return of classical portraiture is realizing how utterly absent it was from the art world for so many years, to such an extent that Andy Warhol \u2014 one of the people ostensibly responsible for killing the form \u2014 helped found the New York Academy of Art in 1982 in order to salvage the kind of technical fine arts training (most notably figure drawing) that seemed at the time in danger of becoming extinct. The Neo-Expressionism of the 1980s \u2014 led by painters like Julian Schnabel and David Salle \u2014 helped popularize abstraction by making it into a desirable commodity, but it also rendered the realism of a painter like Alice Neel pass\u00e9. But painting, perhaps because it is so old, seems unusually inclined to rebirth, to responding to its time in surprising ways. As the commercialism of the art world expanded in the 2010s, painting became a subset of interior decorating, something that was easy to mass produce and inoffensive to live with: paintings marked by bold colors and forms, sometimes literally depicting flowers (the work of Nate Lowman) or sunsets (Alex Israel). In 2014, at the peak of this stylistic moment, New York\u2019s Museum of Modern Art hung its first survey composed exclusively of contemporary painting since 1958, \u201cThe Forever Now,\u201d a show that responded to the current age of distraction, in which contemporaneity was constantly being replaced by something newer. Only the works of Amy Sillman and Nicole Eisenman, who both have portrait-painting practices, hinted at the fact that in our next, emphatically historical moment, something old would be doing the replacing.\n\nBut an ever-widening chasm exists between 2014 and today. If the news of the world feels every day more like a pulpy political thriller with an unhinged plotline, painters have responded by grounding their work in observable, human reality. Most of this work isn\u2019t overtly political on its surface \u2014 there is Henry Taylor\u2019s monumental 2012 portrait of a woman grilling chicken on a barbecue, or Celeste Dupuy-Spencer\u2019s 2016 painting of a man making a playlist on his laptop, a cigarette-filled ashtray in front of him. But they also suggest that, in a time of chaos, there could be nothing more necessary \u2014 more defiant \u2014 than simply showing life as it\u2019s being lived.", "title": "The New Face of Portrait Painting", "authors": ["Dushko Petrovich"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "In spite of the occasional yawn, Dolan seems happy to be immersed in clothes-making \u2014 and with good reason. This show may only be his second, but the Massachusetts-born, Australia-raised designer has been a cool kid of the fashion world since he earned his master\u2019s from Parsons in 2014. It was around this time that his signature impractically oversize denim pieces caught the attention of Lady Gaga and Rihanna, who has continued to wear Dolan\u2019s garments on the street, for photo shoots and in music videos.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe designer\u2019s success may be attributed, in part, to how effectively his clothing articulates an essential \u201chigh-low-ness\u201d in American style. Wearing a Dolan garment requires embracing an outfit that might not, on first glance, really fit you. \u201cIt\u2019s about taking something you aspire to and making it your own,\u201d he says. This makes it the perfect uniform for Rihanna, who has, in recent years, rewritten the rules for celebrities working in fashion.\n\nThe singer is responsible, in part, for the emphasis on tailoring that\u2019s apparent in Dolan\u2019s latest collection. \u201cI had never made a full suit before the suit I made for Rih,\u201d he says, referring to a much-photographed khaki suit that Rihanna wore to the 69th Parsons benefit last May.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis season, I was looking at how to take that big silhouette and make it into something that felt a bit more constructed,\u201d Dolan says. \u201cIt\u2019s built into the garments \u2014 a flared coat and shaped tailored sleeves. It\u2019s very purposeful, rather than something that\u2019s just so big.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHeading into the season, Dolan was reading a biography of Jackie Kennedy, and her influence is clear. \u201cI went crazy with checks, and there are subtle references in the tailoring to \u201960s couture,\u201d he says. The collection includes cable-knit sweater sets in fuchsia, cobalt and Kelly green, and a cropped, double-breasted jacket that evokes the iconic image of John F. Kennedy Jr. at his father\u2019s funeral (which Dolan has pinned to the back of the studio door).\n\nThese \u201cstaples of the American closet\u201d are paired with the designer\u2019s take on classic streetwear, like an extra-large Carhartt vest inspired by \u201990s rap group Da Youngstas. \u201cI\u2019ve always been obsessed with the dualities that exist in the idea of American style,\u201d Dolan says. \u201cElitism versus democracy.\u201d\n\nDenim, which Dolan returns to again this season, may the be the perfect expression of this contrast. \u201cIt represents so many different things,\u201d he says, as he holds up a pair of wide-leg jeans. \u201cIt\u2019s western, but it\u2019s also hip-hop. It\u2019s Dolly Parton and Aaliyah.\u201d", "title": "The New York Designer Subverting American Workwear", "authors": ["Merrell Hambleton"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI feel like we are touring in our own city,\u201d Mr. van Zweden said in a recent interview with editors and reporters of The New York Times. \u201cThis is not just for certain people. This is for all of us, everybody.\u201d\n\nMs. Borda said that forging connections would be an important part of her tenure. \u201cI hope that people will start to perceive us as more outward-facing than frankly, I think, we have been in the past,\u201d she said in the Times interview, sitting next to Mr. van Zweden.\n\nWhen Mr. van Zweden was appointed, some critics worried that, since his reputation was based largely on performances of the standard repertory, he would give new music short shrift. His first season is carefully calibrated to suggest it should not have to be an either/or proposition.\n\nMr. van Zweden will conduct plenty of old favorites, including Mozart\u2019s \u201cJupiter\u201d Symphony, Beethoven\u2019s Symphony No. 5, and works by Brahms, Bruckner, Mahler and Shostakovich. But he will also lead five world premieres: Louis Andriessen\u2019s \u201cAgamemnon,\u201d part of a focus on that Dutch composer; Julia Wolfe\u2019s \u201cFire in My Mouth,\u201d a multimedia choral work about the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire; David Lang\u2019s opera \u201cprisoner of the state,\u201d a take on Beethoven\u2019s \u201cFidelio\u201d and the centerpiece of a season-ending festival of \u201cmusic of conscience\u201d; and pieces by Ashley Fure, who will write a new work for opening night on Sept. 20, and Conrad Tao.\n\n\u201cA lot of people thought I was the guy who likes Bruckner, Brahms, Beethoven \u2014 and that\u2019s absolutely true,\u201d Mr. van Zweden said. But he emphasized that he had been an advocate for new music as chief conductor of the Netherlands Radio Philharmonic Orchestra from 2005 to 2013. \u201cIt\u2019s fine if people did not recognize that,\u201d he added. \u201cBut I\u2019m very happy that I can bring some new works to the New York Philharmonic and to its audiences.\u201d", "title": "The New York Philharmonic\u2019s Fresh Start: A Season Spent at Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "It was after the birth of her second child that the personal chef Karolina Palmer got into eating clean. \u201cI was growing more interested in adaptogenic herbs and superfoods to support myself in that crazy postpartum period,\u201d she says. Then, Palmer got invited to a potluck dinner. What could she possibly make from a pantry filled with things like ashwagandha and He Shou Wu? Inspiration struck when she spotted a bag of raw cocoa, and decided to whip up chocolate truffles infused with herbal mushrooms, rice bran solubles, maca, goji berries and pumpkin seeds. The batch, she says, was \u201ca hit.\u201d\n\nIt was such a hit, in fact, that a year later, in 2016, Palmer launched an entire line of indie chocolates from that same recipe. Called Freaky Health Chocolates, the 1.8-ounce bars ($8) contain her go-to adaptogens (herbs used for centuries in Eastern medicine to revitalize the body) and other healing botanicals meant to do everything from increase immunity to brighten the skin. A Hershey bar this is not.\n\nPalmer is just one of many gurus currently transforming chocolate into a holistic superfood. \u201cIt\u2019s delicious, packed with minerals and antioxidants, and I get a little bliss-y from the neurotransmitter-boosting properties in it,\u201d says Amanda Chantal Bacon, founder of the Moon Juice apothecary in Los Angeles, of her chocolate obsession. But unlike the sugar-laden, processed varieties, this next-generation breed of chocolate is made with raw, or minimally heated, cocoa beans to preserve their antioxidant benefits. The beans are typically sun-dried, slow-ground and blended with the kind of tinctures found in your favorite health food store.\n\nAt Moon Juice, Bacon\u2019s most recent creation, Deep Chocolate Adaptogenic Protein ($50), contains ketogenic brown rice and maca root intended to build stamina, energy and drive, and can be stirred into coffee and even baked goods. Cindy diPrima Morisse, the co-founder of CAP Beauty in New York, meanwhile, often sells out of Sun Potion\u2019s gluten-free Anandamide ($26), a powdered blend of raw cocoa, turmeric and cardamom. \u201cIt\u2019s essentially an ultra-healthy, spicy hot chocolate,\u201d she says. Sakara Life\u2019s Beauty Chocolates ($45), crafted with skin-plumping phytoceramides, have also developed a cult following. So has The Beauty Chef\u2019s Inner Beauty Chocolate Powder ($80), made with bio-fermented greens (chlorella, kale, spinach) and 12 forms of bacteria to support digestion. Consider it the wellness equivalent of Nesquik chocolate milk.", "title": "The New, Healthier Chocolate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Of particular interest would be to measure the amount of sulfur dioxide in the first few weeks, before the gas combines with water vapor to make the reflective aerosols.\n\nIt would also be important to monitor the aerosols over time, to see how big they get and how they eventually break down. Bigger aerosols would fall out of the atmosphere sooner, lessening the cooling impact.\n\nSome environmental satellites can monitor volcanic eruptions, but balloon flights would be an important component of any rapid-response program. Balloons are relatively low cost and can be launched from various locations. It would be important to fly them near the same latitude as the erupting volcano, because the gas plume tends to spread east-west first.\n\nOver the longer term, a robust monitoring program would need aircra ft from NASA and other agencies, said Jack Kaye, associate director for research at NASA\u2019s earth science division. That would most likely involve diverting aircraft time from other research projects, he said. \u201cIt may mean some people\u2019s plans will have to change,\u201d he said.\n\nMost planes do not fly high enough to reach the part of the atmosphere where the aerosols form, although they can be outfitted with sensors to take measurements from below. \u201cIt would be a huge redirection of resources,\u201d Dr. Newman said. \u201cYou\u2019re only going to do this if you have something really big to look at.\u201d\n\nNASA officials play down the benefits to the study of geoengineering of a volcano-research program. Geoengineering has long had an outlaw image among much of the scientific community, viewed as risky last-resort measures to solve climate problems that would be better dealt with by cutting greenhouse gas emissions. Even discussing geoengineering concepts has long been considered taboo among many scientists.", "title": "The Next Big Volcano Could Briefly Cool Earth. NASA Wants to Be Ready.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The cheer squad first appeared in 2002 during the Asian Games in Busan, and have also been at the 2003 Summer Universiade in Daegu and the 2005 Asian Athletics Championships in Incheon, but the Olympics will be their global coming-out moment.\n\nPhoto\n\nChosen, according to reports from An Chan-Il, a defector who runs the World Institute for North Korea Studies, by strict criteria on height and family background \u2014 Ri Sol-ju, the wife of Kim Jong-un, was originally in the cheer squad \u2014 they have worn everything from traditional Korean garb to Nike baseball caps and T-shirts, and often use flags and fans in the routines they do from the stands.\n\nNike! Just like you and me.\n\nIn front of the millions who will watch the Olympics and who have a very specific stereotype of a hermit kingdom in mind, colored in shades of drab, the garb may provide a jolt of outreach. Clothes can do that. They are an access point everyone can read and relate to.\n\nAfter all, when Kim Jong-un appeared in a gray tailored suit during his New Year\u2019s address instead of his usual army uniform, it caused ripples across the internet.\n\nThough exactly how normal 230 young women wearing precisely matched clothing and acting in lock step really is, is up for debate. Even the athletes, marching into the arena in their team uniforms, express more sartorial individuality than the cheer squad.\n\nSo it\u2019s possible that the squad\u2019s image-ineering could backfire, could strike the world as yet another example of the way the authoritarian regime dictates every aspect of its citizens\u2019 lives. But everything is relative. And compared to the perception of dress in the country, the cheer squad has a glow of color and style that is both unexpected and weirdly mesmerizing.\n\nEither way, given the global attention paid to the impeccably coordinated opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics with its choreographed displays of harmony, there\u2019s no doubt the cheer squad is going to get a lot of attention. Odds are they will be chronicled and photographed regularly throughout the Games, and may make most of the fashion news (at least until Ivanka Trump arrives).\n\nIndeed, it\u2019s not hard to imagine a certain famous TV watcher also tuning in for the Games and being struck by the allure of having a national cheer squad. What better accompaniment to the military parade President Trump reportedly desires? Rah-rah.", "title": "The North Korean Cheer Squad Is Playing a Different Olympic Game", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman", "On The Runway"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "The memo does state in passing that Mr. Steele\u2019s evidence was an essential part of the application. But we can\u2019t make heads or tails of it without knowing what else was in the affidavit. Whether the memo is revealing a significant error or none at all depends on the big picture that the memo keeps secret. But we have no way to evaluate that, and critics are claiming it\u2019s wrong.\n\nSecond, the memo offers scant detail on what the government told the court about Mr. Steele. We get only glimpses. The court knew Mr. Steele had been hired to do his research by a \u201cnamed U.S. person,\u201d the memo reports. On the other hand, judges were not specifically told about the role of the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton campaign in ultimately funding the investigation.\n\nWithout more details, however, it\u2019s hard to know what to make of this. The court might have received a balanced and accurate picture of Mr. Steele\u2019s credibility that did not specifically name the Democratic National Committee or Hillary Clinton. Without knowing all the facts of what the government told the court, we can\u2019t tell if the government did anything wrong.\n\nThird, the memo ignores the fact that judges usually expect informants to be biased without being told of it. Judges routinely uphold warrants in criminal cases that fail to disclose bias in informants far worse than Mr. Steele\u2019s. An informant might be the target\u2019s wife, who the government fails to point out is engaged in a bitter divorce battle with him. An informant might be a known criminal facing fresh charges, who the affidavit fails to disclose was promised a break if he shares information about others.\n\nJudges expect this. As a result, courts say, it\u2019s not necessarily a problem to omit it from the warrant affidavit. As one appellate court has written, only a \u201cvery na\u00efve\u201d judge would expect a source to \u201cdrop in off the street with such detailed evidence and not have an ulterior motive.\u201d And who is more likely to lie: Criminals promised leniency or a former British intelligence agent hired for his expertise?\n\nFinally, the memo questions the government\u2019s evidence based on what we know today rather than what the government knew then. For example, it claims that the application relied on a Yahoo News article since traced to Mr. Steele without explaining the Steele connection.\n\nInvestigators are not expected to be clairvoyant. If they didn\u2019t know the source of the Yahoo article at the time, it wouldn\u2019t be wrong for them to include it.\n\nThe memo gives us too little information to make a conclusion about whether the government abused the surveillance laws. It\u2019s a partial view when we need a panorama to know what happened.", "title": "Opinion | The Nunes Memo Is All Smoke, No Fire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "It was a \u201cstrikingly different\u201d approach by the two artists, according to the Times\u2019s co-chief art critic Holland Cotter.
