View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. de Lesseps says she has quit smoking, been practicing yoga, regularly attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings and rehearsing rigorously. A few months ago, she moved to the Upper West Side, where she enjoys walking her dog, a Westie named Aston, in Riverside Park.\n\nBut she also has a lot of travel coming up, and Mr. Stritch has been making recordings of his musical arrangements for her to take on the road so she can practice. One is a beat-box track for a \u201cHousewives\u201d castmate, Sonja Morgan, who will accompany Ms. de Lesseps on a \u201cHamilton\u201d-inspired version of her 2010 dance hit \u201cMoney Can\u2019t Buy You Class.\u201d\n\nOn Feb. 10, Ms. de Lesseps was leaving for a holiday with Ms. Morgan, and promised Mr. Rimalower that she would \u201cwrangle her,\u201d and make her practice the beat-boxing element. She refused to say where they were going or whether cameras would be rolling for Season 10 of \u201cHousewives.\u201d\n\nAmanda Long, a Bravo representative stationed in Ms. de Lesseps\u2019s kitchen, wouldn\u2019t confirm that Ms. de Lesseps was part of the cast. Any time the show came up in conversation, she piped in: \u201cWe can\u2019t go there.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cGuess what?\u201d Ms. de Lesseps said, throwing up her hands. \u201cI might not have a job!\u201d\n\nHearing this, her dog Aston jumped up and started shaking. \u201cHe\u2019s so nervous!\u201d Ms. de Lesseps said. \u201cI\u2019ve never seen him this way.\u201d\n\nBut it seems safe to assume that The Countess, an enduring fan favorite who has been part of the show for all of its past nine seasons, will make the cut. (Bravo will be filming at Ms. de Lesseps\u2019s cabaret, Ms. Long said later, with the caveat that \u201cnothing is confirmed to make it into the final episodes.\u201d)\n\nOne of the highlights of last season featured Ms. de Lesseps on a tequila-fueled trip to Mexico, gracefully dancing off a ledge and falling into a bush. It was a moment that became an enduring internet meme, resurfacing recently when Ms. de Lesseps was Photoshopped into the verdant background of Kehinde Wiley\u2019s portrait of President Barack Obama. (\u201cDying over this reinterpretation of Obama\u2019s official portrait, featuring Lu!\u201d Andy Cohen, an executive producer of \u201cHousewives,\u201d wrote in a caption of the photo on Instagram.)\n\nAfter the cabaret, Ms. de Lesseps plans to finish a new single called \u201cMake It Part of the Dance,\u201d inspired partly by the falling incident in Mexico, but also celebrating her philosophy of life.\n\n\u201cThe important thing is to not take yourself so damn seriously,\u201d she said. \u201cI always think, \u2018I can survive this if I keep on moving.\u2019\u201d", "title": "The Show Goes On for Arrested \u2018Housewife\u2019 Luann de Lesseps", "authors": ["Rachel Dodes"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "American readers who are rightly worried about similarly distressing developments in the United States will feel fortified by the publication of \u201cTo Fight Against This Age: On Fascism and Humanism,\u201d which brings these two pieces together in a single slim volume and establishes Riemen as an erudite, well-meaning and inspiring ally in the struggle to combat anti-liberal political trends. Whether he is an especially wise guide to that struggle is another matter.\n\nThe message of the book is simple, insistent and powerful: The West is not confronting a threat of \u201cpopulism,\u201d as so many contemporary analysts claim. It\u2019s facing a threat of fascism \u2014 the form of modern mass politics that actively cultivates \u201cour worst irrational sentiments: resentment, hatred, xenophobia, lust for power and fear!\u201d Above all, fascism mobilizes ignorance and prejudice by nurturing and flattering them, by persuading democratic citizens to cut themselves off from the wisdom contained in \u201cpoetry and literature, philosophy and theology, the arts and history\u201d \u2014 in short, from \u201cthe domain of culture\u201d that puts us in touch with \u201cwhat unites us and makes the unity of mankind possible.\u201d\n\nThe proper response to the fascist threat, according to Riemen, is therefore education \u2014 the cultivation of individuals who are as \u201cfree and responsible\u201d as \u201cSocrates and Spinoza,\u201d and also capable of resisting our \u201cnihilist kitsch society\u201d in which \u201cnationalism, resentment and hatred\u201d blossom and thrive. Education can accomplish this task by teaching the \u201ccare for the soul\u201d that, at its peak, European culture exemplifies.\n\nPhoto\n\nRiemen maintains that such an education in \u201cculture, philosophy and art\u201d can bring forth a \u201chumanist society\u201d that is \u201cmorally mature\u201d and thus capable of standing against \u201cthe rebirth of nationalism, the triviality of technology, the vulgarity of commerce and the cultivated stupidity of the media and the universities.\u201d Only when such an education has spread the love of \u201ctruth, goodness, beauty, friendship, justice, compassion and wisdom\u201d will the West have succeeded in immunizing itself against \u201cthe deadly bacillus called fascism.\u201d\n\nNo one who\u2019s tasted the glories of European high culture or who\u2019s appalled by the latter-day descent of our politics into the gutter can fail to be moved by Riemen\u2019s rousing rhetoric. But that doesn\u2019t mean his diagnosis of what ails us is correct, or his cure for it sensible.\n\nTake his insistence, now widely shared by commentators on both sides of the Atlantic, that \u201cfascism\u201d is on the rise across the West. Yes, the centrist consensus of the postwar era, and especially the neoliberal one that has dominated since the end of the Cold War, is being challenged today by many on the right and some on the left. But is this challenge really best understood as a revival of the kind of politics that was practiced in Hitler\u2019s Germany, Mussolini\u2019s Italy and Franco\u2019s Spain?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn some respects, perhaps. But one necessary component is missing: a uniform, galvanizing ideology that could plausibly animate a centralized totalitarian state to co-opt civil society, driving out dissent by employing a combination of surveillance, repression and propaganda. The threat facing liberal politics today is quite different and in some ways the opposite: a rising tide of polarization and chaos in civil society driven by numerous forces, some structural (social media) but others political (right-wing disinformation, Russian meddling), that threatens to empower a form of postmodern, kleptocratic authoritarianism. That\u2019s certainly bad, and potentially antidemocratic. But it\u2019s not fascism.\n\nThe error is important not only because inaccurately tossing around the f-word contributes to the hyperbole that is turning civil society into a circus of inflammatory charges and countercharges, but also because it reveals a serious failure of understanding \u2014 one that\u2019s troublingly pervasive in Europe and even common among a distressingly large number of American liberals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe misunderstanding concerns nothing less than the nature of politics itself. For many liberals, politics involves bureaucratic administration, the management of government benefits and the jostling of interest groups. One party or coalition tweaks the numbers in one direction, another nudges them a different way. Such fiddling with policy is a good part of modern politics. But it\u2019s not the whole of politics. At a more elemental level, the one to which Aristotle directed much of his attention, politics is about more existential issues: this bounded community in this place with this history and heritage, determining its own character for itself, deciding who is and who is not a citizen, who will rule and in the name of which vision of the good life.\n\nAfter the cataclysm of World War II, European leaders concluded that the disaster was a product of an excess of politics in this elemental sense. Emphasizing certain transcendent themes in Western humanism, they advocated the universalism of human rights and denigrated any and all attachment to particular nations or cultures. The Common Market and then the European Union itself were experiments in devising a postpolitical politics that treated particular attachments as morally unacceptable and therefore politically out of bounds. Favoring anything less than open borders became invariably xenophobic, caring about the ethnic and cultural character of one\u2019s own nation became invariably racist and fearing outsiders who wish to do it harm became invariably fascist.\n\nFor a while it looked as if Europe\u2019s experiment in forging an antipolitical politics might succeed. Not so much anymore.\n\nRiemen\u2019s book is admirable in many ways, but it is an unusually hermetic example of the thinking that led so many Europeans to believe in the first place that it was possible, necessary and desirable to produce a civilization in which citizens are expected to look down on the love that has always defined citizenship \u2014 the love of one\u2019s own. We have ample reason to doubt that liberal politics can be saved by more of the same.", "title": "The Sickness of Our Time: Is It Populism or Fascism?", "authors": ["Damon Linker", "Rob Riemen"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "VANG, Norway \u2014 It seems an unlikely event to be emblazoned in a nation\u2019s collective memory. But if you\u2019re from Norway, and you\u2019re over 50, you almost certainly have a vivid recollection of this:\n\nA man named Oddvar Bra is skiing the final segment of the men\u2019s 4x10-kilometer cross-country relay at the 1982 world championships in Oslo. Surging up a hill, he passes and sideswipes the only person ahead of him, Alexander Savyalov of the Soviet Union.\n\nImmediately, Bra realizes that the impact has had a terrible consequence. His right pole has snapped in two.\n\n\u201cLet him get a pole, man!\u201d shouts the sportscaster for what is then Norway\u2019s only national TV station.\n\nAs if on cue, someone in the crowd bolts into view and hands off a pole. His equilibrium restored, Bra battles Savyalov in a sprint to the finish line.", "title": "The Ski Pole That Norway Will Never Forget", "authors": ["David Segal"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Norway has one of the smallest men\u2019s Alpine teams on the World Cup circuit, and only about 2.5 million men in the country to build a team from. And yet the Norwegian skiers are dominating the Olympics again.\n\nAksel Lund Svindal and Kjetil Jansrud won gold and silver in the downhill here on Thursday. Norway has three racers in the top four of the current World Cup overall standings, and they are among the favorites to take home more Olympic hardware before these Games are through.\n\nIn an era in which every world-class athlete seems fixated on personal brand-building and competing for the most Facebook likes and Twitter followers, the Norwegians embrace an altogether different approach to success. It is a contrarian mix of humility, egalitarianism and basic respect \u2014 plus sharing an absurd amount of meals over the course of a schedule that has them spending roughly 250 days together every year.\n\nThey get along so well and feel so strongly about collegiality that they even share beds sometimes.\n\n\u201cWe believe there is no good explanation or justification for why you have to be a jerk to be a good athlete,\u201d Jansrud, the defending Olympic super-G champion, said. \u201cSo we just won\u2019t have that kind of thing on our team. You have to get along with everyone.\u201d", "title": "The Ski Team That Sleeps Together Wins a Lot of Gold Medals Together", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "But since the State of Connecticut declined to press charges against Allen, it is what we have to go on. Shouldn\u2019t the weight of available evidence, to say nothing of the presumption of innocence, extend to the court of public opinion, too?\n\nThat is a thought lost in some of the commentary about the case. Dylan Farrow is a persuasive interviewee who seems absolutely sincere in her belief that she was molested by Allen as a child. Allen, by contrast, comes across as a grouchy neurotic who, in his late 50s, had a distasteful affair with Mia Farrow\u2019s adopted, barely adult daughter, Soon-Yi Previn. In the contest of sympathies, it\u2019s not hard to guess who wins.\n\nBut it\u2019s precisely because Dylan\u2019s account plays to our existing biases that we need to treat it with added skepticism. Most parents know that young children are imaginative and suggestible and innocently prone to making things up. The misuse of children\u2019s memories by ambitious prosecutors against day-care center operators in the 1980s led to some of the worst miscarriages of justice in recent U.S. history. You don\u2019t have to doubt Farrow\u2019s honesty to doubt her version of events.\n\nNor have we learned anything else about Allen in the intervening years that might add to suspicions of guilt. He married Soon-Yi and has been with her ever since. Nobody else has come forward in 25 years with a fresh accusation of assault against him.\n\nIf Allen is in fact a pedophile, he appears to have acted on his evil fantasies exactly once. Compare that to Larry Nassar\u2019s 265 identified victims.\n\nIt goes without saying that child molestation is a uniquely evil crime that merits the stiffest penalties. But accusing someone of being a molester without abundant evidence is also odious, particularly in an era in which social-media whispers can become the ruin of careers and even of lives.\n\nThat\u2019s something for all of us to think about, even when it comes to wealthy, peculiar old men for whom we feel no love. We still live in a country that paints a bright line between accusation and fact. Smear the accused, smudge the line, and the truth will never out. \u2610", "title": "Opinion | The Smearing of Woody Allen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nScientists have decoded the genome of the axolotl, the Mexican amphibian with a Mona Lisa smile. It has 32 billion base pairs, which makes it ten times the size of the human genome, and the largest genome ever sequenced.\n\nThe axolotl, endangered in the wild, has been bred in laboratories and studied for more than 150 years. It has the remarkable capacity to regrow amputated limbs complete with bones, muscles and nerves; to heal wounds without producing scar tissue; and even to regenerate damaged internal organs.\n\nThis salamander can heal a crushed spinal cord and have it function just like it did before it was damaged. This ability, which exists to such an extent in no other animal, makes its genes of considerable interest.\n\nNow researchers, using one genetic sequencing technique to do their analysis and then another to \u201cproof read\u201d it, have provided researchers with the tools to study and manipulate the genes of the axolotl. Their study appears in Nature.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe techniques in this paper are all at the cutting edge,\u201d said Ryan Kerney, a biologist at Gettysburg College who has published widely on amphibian genetics but was not involved in this study. \u201cAnd the data they generated are incredibly thorough for any genome, much less one this large.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis is the first salamander genome ever sequenced. The reason it took so long is that it has so many repetitive parts, according to Elly M. Tanaka, a senior scientist at the Research Institute of Molecular Pathology in Vienna and senior author of the new study. The study was a huge computational effort, requiring techniques developed expressly for the purpose.", "title": "The Smiling Axolotl Hides a Secret: A Giant Genome", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "A version of this article appears in print on , on Page 186 of T Magazine with the headline: Acts of Rebellion", "title": "The Softer, More Sensual Side of Punk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "It turns out that the \u201cCreep\u201d situation is pretty much universal. Songs that came out decades earlier are now, on average, most popular among men who were 14 when they were first released. The most important period for men in forming their adult tastes were the ages 13 to 16.\n\nWhat about women? On average, their favorite songs came out when they were 13. The most important period for women were the ages 11 to 14.\n\nGranted, some results of my research are not surprising. One of the facts I discovered is that Coolio\u2019s \u201cGangsta\u2019s Paradise\u201d is extremely unpopular among women in their 70s. Thank you, Big Data, for uncovering that nugget of wisdom!\n\nBut I did find it interesting how clear the patterns were and how much early adolescence matters. The key years, in fact, match closely with the end of puberty, which tends to happen to girls before boys. This also adds one more piece of evidence to the growing scientific consensus that we never really leave middle school and high school.\n\nFor both men and women, their early 20s were half as influential in determining adult musical tastes as their early teens.\n\nOf course, musical taste is not fully determined by when you are born, but the generational effects are large. And this data does give me the ability to predict what will happen this Wednesday, which is Valentine\u2019s Day. My sophisticated econometric analysis tells me to expect 30-year-olds to celebrate with Beyonc\u00e9\u2019s \u201cCrazy in Love,\u201d 45-year-olds with Van Halen\u2019s \u201cWhen It\u2019s Love\u201d and 60-year-olds with Marvin Gaye\u2019s \u201cLet\u2019s Get It On.\u201d\n\nIt was fun to find patterns in the Spotify data. But actually they did little to explain my disagreement with my brother. \u201cBorn to Run,\u201d it turns out, is not particularly popular among people of my generation. (I\u2019m 35.)", "title": "Opinion | The Songs That Bind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "They stretched in right field, played catch with each other to warm up, and worked in the same group of outfielders, rotating among all three positions. They also hit in the same group \u2014 along with Gary Sanchez and Jacoby Ellsbury \u2014 for batting practice against the catching coach Jason Brown.\n\nThey failed to hit many home runs. Out of the 40 pitches each saw during batting practice, Stanton hit four homers and Judge \u2014 who fouled off the first two pitches he saw \u2014 hit two, though each flashed a glimpse of their prodigious power. Stanton hit a ball off the top of the 40-foot high scoreboard in left-center field and Judge, who proclaimed himself 100 percent recovered from surgery on his left, non-throwing shoulder, whistled one over the pavilion in left field.\n\n\u201cToday, I was playing pepper with the cage a little bit,\u201d Stanton said with a smile.\n\nThe fans who turned out on Monday did not seem at all disappointed that only a few balls had left the ballpark. They oohed when high flies were hit only to land softly on the outfield grass.\n\nThere has not been this type of buzz around the Yankees\u2019 opening training camp since 2015, and that fuss was for a rather different reason \u2014 Alex Rodriguez\u2019s return from a performance-enhancing drug suspension.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen Judge, who is listed as 6-foot-7, 282 pounds, walked toward home plate to hit, one baritone voice from the crowd bellowed: \u201cAll rise.\u201d Judge turned and smiled sheepishly.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been a while since I heard it,\u201d Judge said, joking that maybe the chant would start popping up when he shopped at a drugstore. \u201cIt was pretty funny, so I had to give him a little wave.\u201d\n\nThe flash of humor was a rare one for Judge, who then assumed his usual countenance: friendly and humble, but revealing little. Stanton, meanwhile, had cut the sleeves off his warm-up top \u2014 revealing the ample biceps on his 6-foot-6, 245-pound frame. Later, he also showed off an ease in front of the cameras.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nUnlike Judge, who just offered that it seemed like any other spring training opener, Stanton \u2014 who had spent his previous 10 years in the Marlins organization, readily admitted, \u201cI\u2019m a deer in the headlights here.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe added: \u201cThe moment we touched the dirt they were buzzing and ready for us to get in the cage and hit. That was really cool; nothing like I\u2019ve experienced in spring.\u201d\n\nAsked if it exceeded his expectations, Stanton smiled.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d he said. \u201cI left that open ended.\u201d\n\nOf course, there are days when the ballparks \u2014 whether in Florida for spring training or in the Bronx or on the road during the season \u2014 will be far more full to watch batting practice. The Yankees will open Steinbrenner Field an hour earlier than usual during spring training \u2014 three hours before the first pitch \u2014 so that fans can watch Judge, who hit 52 homers last season, and Stanton, who hit 59, take batting practice.\n\nIf Stephen Curry\u2019s pregame shooting routine has become appointment viewing for fans at Golden State Warriors games, Boone suggested Judge and Stanton may well transform batting practice before Yankees games into something \u201csexy.\u201d\n\nIt was that type of lure that drew so many fans to Steinbrenner Field on Monday.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m hoping they get into a personal competition and try to outplay each other, like Mantle and Maris did,\u201d said Mark DeGroot, who wore a judge\u2019s rob and white wig while he watched batting practice with his wife, Rebecca, and their 6-year-old daughter Filamina. \u201cThis could be good for both of them.\u201d\n\nBut the Yankees will be more than Judge and Stanton this season. Sanchez showed off his power by rattling ESPN\u2019s set in left field with a home run, shortstop Didi Gregorius and first baseman Greg Bird appear to be burgeoning stars and the Yankees bullpen is shaping up as one of the best in baseball.\n\nBut as was clear on Monday, the bright lights will be trained on the biggest stars.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a big deal because they\u2019re good players, but obviously they\u2019re both kind of larger-than-life human beings \u2014 you don\u2019t see people like them in baseball,\u201d Bird said. \u201cIt\u2019s good. It\u2019s a good hype. I mean obviously there\u2019s a lot of attention on them but it\u2019s good for baseball, it\u2019s good for them and it\u2019s good for this team.\u201d", "title": "The Stanton and Judge Show Debuts to Rave Reviews", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Daniela Vega glanced appraisingly into the makeup mirror. Her eyelids, slicked with gloss by a tirelessly hovering makeup artist, gave her the humid, come-hither look of a 1930s cinema vamp. Pretty much as she\u2019d planned.\n\n\u201cI want to look like a period piece,\u201d said Ms. Vega, the 28-year-old Chilean star of \u201cA Fantastic Woman.\u201d Ms. Vega, a transgender actress who plays a passably stylish transgender woman in the film (a contender for the Best Foreign Language Oscar), acknowledged that, on screen or off, fashion has long been a formidable tool in her arsenal.\n\nShe was prepping last week in her gray-on-gray suite at the strenuously modish Langham Hotel in the southern part of Midtown Manhattan, riffling through her outsize closet in anticipation of the multicity tour promoting the movie\u2019s release. (It opens nationally on Feb. 2.) She would be visiting Washington the next morning, followed in whirlwind succession by Tokyo, Madrid and, within a brief span of days, New York again.\n\nShe wasn\u2019t complaining. Dressing for an imagined public is, to her mind, a performance.\n\n\u201cLife is a \u2018pasarela,\u2019 a runway,\u201d she said. Switching gamely between her native Spanish and occasional bursts of un-self-conscious English, she added, \u201cYou can shine or be low key. I always prefer to get attention.\u201d", "title": "The Star of \u2018A Fantastic Woman\u2019 Picks a Few Come-Hither Dresses", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "As with \u201cWonder Woman\u201d last year, another movie that spoke to an underserved population at a moment of acute political anxiety, audiences have reacted with partisan fervor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get expert TV and movie recommendations from the Watching newsletter The best of what to watch and where to watch it, delivered to your inbox twice a week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cBlack Panther\u201d is already a phenomenon on social media, where eager fans are teasing their opening-night outfits, ruminating on race and representation with the hashtag #WhatBlackPantherMeansToMe and showing their support for the #BlackPantherChallenge (a spontaneous campaign to buy tickets and popcorn for children). The film recently broke the advance ticket sales record for any movie released in the first quarter, according to the online vendor Fandango, surpassing \u201cThe Hunger Games\u201d and the 2017 live-action remake of \u201cBeauty and the Beast.\u201d\n\nThe morning after a red-carpet premiere in Hollywood last month that left Twitter swooning, the stars, director and producer of the film gathered for a spirited conversation about their role in challenging standard depictions of the African diaspora on screen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTaking part in the discussion were Mr. Coogler; Chadwick Boseman, who plays T\u2019Challa, a.k.a. Black Panther, king of the fictional African nation of Wakanda; Lupita Nyong\u2019o (Nakia, a Wakandan spy and T\u2019Challa\u2019s love interest); Michael B. Jordan (Erik Killmonger, an African-American adversary of Black Panther\u2019s); Danai Gurira (Okoye, Wakanda\u2019s greatest warrior); and Kevin Feige, a producer of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d and president of Marvel Studios. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nI read a funny tweet the other day that said this movie is basically reparations.\n\n[Rolling laughter]\n\nCHADWICK BOSEMAN I still want my reparations! I still want my reparations!\n\nRYAN COOGLER [laughing] I think only reparations can be reparations.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s silly, but is there a kernel of truth there for any of you? The idea that Disney and Marvel investing so much in a movie with a black cast and crew can count as something like restitution?\n\nDANAI GURIRA What it does in such a beautiful way, to me, is it sets a precedent. We\u2019ve read a lot of subtitles for German and Russian \u2014 we can read subtitles for African languages now. People can\u2019t go back and say, \u201cNo, that\u2019s going to be too hard, it\u2019s Africa.\u201d They can\u2019t do that. And that is so thrilling to me.\n\nMICHAEL B. JORDAN It couldn\u2019t have been done on a bigger level. If Marvel is behind it, then it\u2019s gotta be O.K. Moving forward, everybody\u2019s going to start to have the courage to tell bold stories that people didn\u2019t think were lucrative, didn\u2019t think that anybody wanted to see. All of that, I feel, is getting ready to dissolve.\n\nBOSEMAN It has to.\n\nGURIRA No, it will.\n\nCOOGLER What I\u2019ll say is, this is my second time working in the studio system, and they say it\u2019s the studio system, but it\u2019s really the people system. It\u2019s who\u2019s running the studio? How are they running it? When you look at Disney with [Tendo Nagenda, executive vice president for production at Walt Disney Studios, and Nate Moore, a producer at Marvel Studios and an executive producer of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d], it\u2019s a place that\u2019s interested in representation, not just for the sake of representation, but representation because that\u2019s what works, that\u2019s what\u2019s going to make quality stuff that the world is going to embrace, that\u2019s what leads to success.\n\nPhoto\n\nKevin, there\u2019s long been this idea in Hollywood that movies with black casts don\u2019t perform well internationally. Does that end with \u201cBlack Panther\u201d?\n\nKEVIN FEIGE I certainly hope so. One thing I would always remind Ryan of when we would talk about humor and entertainment value in the film was that the biggest statement this movie can make is to be a success around the globe. And I think he\u2019s delivered a movie that\u2019s going to do that, and that disproves [beliefs] that had maybe never been true but had never been tested.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the actors, what did joining this film mean to you and how did it feel different from other movies you\u2019ve done?\n\nBOSEMAN I\u2019ve done other films that have had historic significance because of what has happened in the past, but this not only refers to the past, it sets the stage for where we\u2019re going.\n\nGURIRA I\u2019ve had a passion for telling African stories for a really long time, being American-born and Zimbabwe-raised. That biculturalism is something that I try to address in my work as a playwright [her 2016 drama \u201cEclipsed\u201d was nominated for a Tony for best play], but nothing can address it like a Marvel movie. I had a childlike glee after my meeting with Ryan \u2014 I kind of floated around, found my car somehow. You think you\u2019re alone in the struggle until you meet someone and then you think, \u201cOh wow, we\u2019re all in it together? And y\u2019all are doing this already? And I just have to be in it?\u201d It was just so beautiful.\n\nLUPITA NYONG\u2019O Seeing it yesterday, I\u2019m even more excited about the celebration of pan-Africanism, because this movie is really about a contemporary Africa relating very intimately with a contemporary America via the characters of Black Panther and Killmonger. We\u2019re talking about some really deep issues that we don\u2019t often voice but we all feel. [Ms. Nyong\u2019o was born in Mexico to Kenyan parents and raised in Kenya.]\n\nPhoto\n\nBOSEMAN A lot of times, being [a black man] in Hollywood, when you get material you\u2019ll read it and you\u2019ll be like, \u201cThat\u2019s not us.\u201d When I got the initial call from Kevin Feige, my hope was that they would have the courage to give Black Panther its true essence and put somebody behind it that would have my same passion for what it could be. And they did that.\n\nOn set, did you have that feeling of \u201cThis is important\u201d or did you just try to do good work like normal?\n\nCOOGLER I learned a skill from playing football. I was a wide receiver \u2014 they throw you the ball, you can\u2019t drop it. So I learned that you gotta tune everything else out.\n\nIf I get to set and there\u2019s a hundred black people on the side of a waterfall and Lupita is dressed in this adornment and Danai is dressed in this adornment and they\u2019re like, \u201cHey Ryan, do I stand here or here?\u201d I can\u2019t think, \u201cAh, this is amazing, I\u2019m making \u2018Black Panther\u2019 and there\u2019s all these black folks on screen!\u201d I really gotta tell Danai that she needs to move over here, and I gotta tell her five reasons why she\u2019s gotta move over here, because she\u2019s gonna wanna know \u2019em! [Laughter]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut seriously, I grew up reading these comic books and watching all these movies. If I really thought about the fact that I\u2019m making one of these things right now, with people I know and love, I would break down emotionally. I wouldn\u2019t be no good to anybody.\n\nNYONG\u2019O A moment when I really felt a vibration was when we were shooting [the waterfall scene]. There were hundreds of extras and we were all in these traditional clothes and there were all the tribal colors and drumming, and between takes, the drummers started riffing to [Snoop Dogg\u2019s] \u201cDrop It Like It\u2019s Hot.\u201d The whole crowd started to go [sings the melody] and we were all dancing as Ryan figured things out below.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn that moment, I was like, \u201cThis is big.\u201d I had never been on a set with so many black people before and we were all so focused and I could feel a vibration in the air. We all felt so privileged to have an opportunity to be a part of this moment in history.\n\nMichael, one of the interesting complexities of the film comes from Killmonger\u2019s identity as an African-American, which contrasts against T\u2019Challa\u2019s African-ness. What did you want to bring to the character?\n\nJORDAN Ryan [and I] started getting into the back story of where he came from and how his upbringing really affected his personality, his outlook, his rage, his agenda. We felt like we could show where Erik is coming from and make people feel why he is so angry, why he is so lost. He doesn\u2019t know who he is, but he knows the answers are out there.\n\nBOSEMAN For me, [Killmonger and T\u2019Challa] are two sides of the same coin \u2014 African and African-American. As an African-American, if you\u2019re disconnected from your ancestry and your past, you have this conflict that comes from that and so there is a healing experience that is possible because of that.\n\nCOOGLER The fracture that Killmonger has, that\u2019s the fracture I lived with my whole life. I\u2019m from a place that I\u2019d never been to and that nobody who I loved had been to because they couldn\u2019t afford to go [to Africa. Mr. Coogler grew up in Richmond in Northern California]. So I would hear stories from them about this place that they didn\u2019t even know anything about, and those stories were a counterbalance to the awful things that we did hear about them.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the movie, Wakanda disguises vast technological resources from the world, and white people who aren\u2019t in the know refer to it dismissively as a primitive backwater. That\u2019s a very real view that a lot of people hold about Africa, as recent comments attributed to the president made clear. What do you hope will be the effect of introducing audiences to this counternarrative about the continent?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCOOGLER The narrative about the continent that we know is actually a fairly recent narrative, if you think about human history. It\u2019s a narrative that was born out of what happened when the countries of Africa were conquered.\n\nBut the truth is that some of those places that people might refer to as backwaters \u2014 and these recent comments definitely aren\u2019t the first time somebody has said something like that \u2014 were the cradle of civilization. They were the first places to do anything that we would consider to be civilized.\n\nAll the structures that we built in Wakanda, they\u2019re taller structures of what you\u2019ll find in Africa. Some of them we switched up \u2014 instead of mud we used [the fictional supermetal] vibranium \u2014 but those are buildings that you\u2019ll really find in Mali, in Ethiopia, in Nigeria.\n\nI spent about three weeks in Africa [doing research for \u201cBlack Panther\u201d] and I truly felt that seeing it for myself was necessary for my growth as a human being. That experience made me not only capable [of writing] this film, but it made me whole as a person.", "title": "The Stars of \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Waited a Lifetime for This Moment", "authors": ["Reggie Ugwu"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Recall that in June 2016, after British voters said they wanted to leave the European Union, the stock markets fell into what seemed, at the time, to be a major panic. Less than a week after that vote, though, markets resumed their rise. Since then, the American market, measured by the S.&P. 500, was in positive territory every single day \u2014 until the cumulative declines of 2018 pulled the index into the red on Feb. 5 and into a correction on Feb. 8. On Friday, the S.&P. 500 closed at 2619.55.\n\nEven if the current downturn doesn\u2019t deepen, some sectors are already feeling severe pain. Traders who had bet that calm conditions would continue have lost fortunes. In just two days, the assets in two funds that trade in instruments linked to the VIX \u2014 officially, the Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index \u2014 shrank from a combined total of $3 billion to about $150 million. There are few indications so far that trading losses in those instruments \u2014 or in the battered cryptocurrency markets \u2014 have damaged the overall financial system, but that is a worry in a serious downturn.\n\nThere have been major losses in the broader market, however. Through Thursday, the stocks in the S.&P. 500 had lost $5.2 trillion from the index\u2019s peak on Jan. 26, according to Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S.&P. Dow Jones Indices. That is a staggering amount, but even with those losses, the S.&P. 500 through Thursday had swollen by $3.55 trillion since the 2016 election.\n\nHow far will the current market decline go? I wish I knew. One troubling factor is the change in the leadership of the Federal Reserve, with Jerome H. Powell taking over as chairman on Feb. 3, succeeding Janet L. Yellen. In his confirmation hearings, Mr. Powell signaled a continuation of Fed policy, but the markets are testing him and it is not clear how he will respond.\n\nThe timing is awkward. The Fed has been tightening monetary policy while the federal government is loosening fiscal policy by cutting taxes, and then adding hundreds of billions of dollars in government spending in a last-minute budget deal on Friday. Furthermore, the Trump administration has been pushing for lighter regulation of financial markets. These shifts during a period of stress raise short-term risks for investors in stocks and bonds.\n\nBear markets in stocks \u2014 defined as downturns, from peak to trough, of at least 20 percent \u2014 rarely occur without a recession, and, at the moment, none is visible. That\u2019s one reason for Mr. Detrick\u2019s belief that the market is \u201cprobably getting fairly close to its bottom now.\u201d\n\nWhile that history is comforting, the 20 percent threshold for a bear market is arbitrary, and the link between recessions and the stock market is not ironclad. The bear market of 1987 occurred without a recession, for example. And who would really be surprised if the unusual political conditions in the United States today fostered unexpected patterns in the economy and stock market?\n\nWhat is safe to say is that the market has entered a new, troubling phase. The current turmoil may turn out to be blissfully brief, but it makes sense to be ready for the worst.", "title": "The Stock Market Has Turned Nasty. It Was Long Overdue.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The fear generated by Wall Street\u2019s sharp fall in recent days had been greatly magnified by the calm that preceded it. Before the 8 percent decline in United States stocks over the past week \u2014 which was followed by a bounce back of nearly 2 percent on Tuesday \u2014 the S. & P. 500 had gone two years without suffering a drop that large. Spoiled by this unnaturally placid stretch, many Americans had forgotten what a routine market setback even looks like.\n\nThey better get used to this. In a typical year, according to data going back three decades, the market experiences a correction of about 10 percent. What Americans are witnessing now is thus a return to normal market behavior, which has never followed a straight line.\n\nThis year could be pivotal, because the conditions that underpinned the steady upward march of stock prices are now likely to deteriorate. In the United States and around the world, stocks have been buoyed by the trifecta of accelerating global growth, low inflation and loose central bank policies, all of which are now poised to turn against the bubbly market.\n\nOptimists believe that the global economy this year can still grow 4 percent, the pace it maintained during the post-World War II miracle. But the miracle was driven mainly by the postwar baby boom, which ended years ago. Many investors have yet to internalize the fact that 4 percent growth is unrealistic. Fewer workers means slower economic growth and will make it difficult for the world economy to sustain even its 2017 pace of just over 3 percent growth.", "title": "Opinion | The Stock Market Is Volatile Again. Get Used to It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Even milder versions of high inflation, such as the inflation that topped out at more than 14 percent in the United States in 1980, is damaging. At that level, those who have accumulated savings or fixed pensions see their purchasing power vanish over time, and borrowing costs skyrocket (ask anyone who took out a home loan in the early 1980s what their mortgage rate was). That dynamic can impede growth and create broad unhappiness. The economist Arthur Okun even invented the \u201cmisery index\u201d in the 1960s, calculated by adding up the unemployment rate and inflation rate.\n\nBut when inflation turns negative \u2014 that would be deflation, meaning the purchasing power of a currency rises over time \u2014 it can also be disastrous. Debts become more onerous over time, and consumers and businesses have incentive to hoard cash rather than spend or invest it.\n\nThat\u2019s what the United States and other countries experienced during the Great Depression, and it has been experienced in milder forms by Japan over much of the last 20 years and Europe since 2010.\n\nSo how much inflation do we want?\n\nIt might seem inherently bad to have the purchasing power of a falling dollar. But having a bit of inflation seems to grease the wheels of the economy while not distorting economic decisions too much. It helps cushion against deflation, and gives the Fed room to cut interest rates and stimulate the economy during a downturn, helping keep the economy on an even footing.\n\nOver the last couple of decades, central bankers around the world have mostly settled on 2 percent per year as the optimal level of inflation that they aim for. It\u2019s a level low enough that the purchasing power of their currencies is fairly stable and people don\u2019t have to worry about inflation all that much in doing business with one another, while also keeping a buffer to prevent deflationary effects from taking hold.\n\nThat said, 2 percent is a fairly arbitrary number, and some economists argue that steady inflation at a somewhat higher level would help prevent recessions.\n\nThe important thing is arguably less the exact level of inflation and more that it is fairly stable over time. It is big swings that tend to be most disruptive, favoring either debtors (inflation) or creditors (deflation), and generally contributing to lack of faith in a country\u2019s financial system.", "title": "The Stock Market Is Worried About Inflation. Should It Be?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Why it has done so is the subject of speculation. \u201cWe\u2019ve got hypotheses,\u201d said Michael Kelly, a finance professor at Lafayette College, who has studied the issue. \u201cBut we don\u2019t really know why it happens.\u201d\n\nOne possibility, he said, is that frequent traders laboring under the \u201cillusion of control\u201d believe that they can respond easily to information and events during the day but can\u2019t do so as easily after hours, when there are far fewer market participants and less money, or \u201cliquidity,\u201d involved in trading. \u201cPeople may be inclined to sell at the market close so they can feel in control of their money overnight,\u201d he said.\n\nThere is some evidence that smaller traders are prey to this tendency and tend to sell late in the day \u2014 and that some big institutional traders, who are well aware of the day-night gap, tend instead to buy at the close and sell at the open.\n\nBecause relatively few people actually trade after the market closes, orders tend to build up overnight, and in a rising market, that will produce an upward price surge when the market opens. But during extended declines, overnight sell orders may cause prices to plummet when the market opens.\n\nIf there were no trading costs \u2014 possible in a thought experiment but not in the real world \u2014 an excellent strategy over the last few decades would have been buying shares at the last possible moment during regular trading hours and selling them methodically at the opening bell every day, Professor Gulen of Purdue said.\n\nWhile transaction costs make that strategy uneconomical, he said, the concept may still have a certain value. \u201cIf you do know that you are going to make a trade on a given day, and you have the ability to choose when you do it, you might be able to take advantage of this pattern \u2014 buying late in the day and selling early.\u201d Of course, the pattern doesn\u2019t hold every single day, and you could easily be disappointed.\n\nPart of the gap in returns can probably be explained by the human tendency to panic at bad news, Professor Kelly said. \u201cThat panic seems to happen during the day,\u201d he said. \u201cOne advantage of not trading during the day is that you aren\u2019t as likely to participate in panicky selling.\u201d", "title": "The Stock Market Works by Day, but It Loves the Night", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "This compliment was offered even though only the Democratic majority staff prepared the report and concerns were raised over its accuracy by former C.I.A. directors and deputy directors. Now that Republican members of a committee have prepared a memo, The Times claims that is proof of a \u201cpartisan witch hunt,\u201d and those who ignore concerns about the memo\u2019s accuracy have gone too \u201cfar down the rabbit hole.\u201d\n\nThese inconsistencies justifiably give rise to suspicions that The Times has sacrificed its principles for petty politics.\n\nMAXWELL ANDERSON\n\nLINCOLN, NEB.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cRepublicans in House Release Secret Memo on Russia Inquiry\u201d (nytimes.com, Feb. 2):\n\nThe principal thrust of the G.O.P. memo is that an application to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court failed to identify the source of some of the research used and therefore \u201cmisled\u201d the court into granting a warrant that should never have been issued. Given the political acrimony surrounding this issue, it seems clear that neither the G.O.P. memo nor the Democratic response, if it ever sees the light of day, will resolve the facts.\n\nNevertheless, there\u2019s a way to do just that: As recently suggested by Jeffrey H. Smith, a former general counsel for the C.I.A., the FISA court could appoint a special master to determine, based on all the available evidence, whether the court was misled. Our political parties are obviously incapable as acting as credible fact-finders. Fortunately, that\u2019s a role that could still be carried out by a court.\n\nROBERT FERGUSON\n\nSTAMFORD, CONN.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI have read the much anticipated memo and am shocked that so much has been made of it in the media. It is truly \u201cmuch ado about nothing.\u201d This was clearly drafted at the behest of a Trump sycophant, Devin Nunes, who is simply trying to kiss up to his leader. Most people should find it nothing more than inside the Beltway political backstabbing. I hope that it will have no impact on the special counsel\u2019s investigation and search for truth.", "title": "Opinion | The Storm Around a G.O.P. Memo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The question for those yet to join the enablers is: What\u2019s the price \u2014 a record stock market in which 10 percent of Americans own 84 percent of the market wealth, a tax cut that burdens the working poor in years to come \u2014 for saying nothing?\n\nEvangelical Christians were among the first to sign on to a Stormy Daniels proposition. In the infamous words of Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council, Trump gets a \u201cdo-over\u201d for the infidelity allegation. Yes, because nothing says family values like a thrice-married man who allegedly cheats on his latest wife just after she gives birth to their son. And Pat Robertson, the mush-headed moralist who still fogs up many a television screen with his gaseous utterances, told Trump last summer, \u201cI\u2019m so proud of everything you\u2019re doing.\u201d\n\nFor these self-appointed guardians of the soul, the bargain is bigger than 30 pieces of silver: It\u2019s a promise that Trump will continue to protect their tax-exempt empires, in the name of religious freedom.\n\nFor Republicans in Congress, the pact is more consequential. They will ignore the pleadings of career law enforcement officials in order to stoke fantasies of a deep-state coup against the president. These politicians are counting on a base that will look the other way as they undermine Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation into Russian tampering with the election.\n\nIt\u2019s a good bet. After Trump called the American justice system \u201ca joke\u201d and \u201ca laughingstock,\u201d after he fired the F.B.I. director because he would not pledge loyalty to him, after he told another top lawman that his wife was \u201ca loser,\u201d after he referred to members of the intelligence community as \u201cpolitical hacks,\u201d it was all quiet on the Republican front.\n\nHe can falsely say that his State of the Union speech drew the highest audience in history \u2014 in fact, it ranked ninth since 1993 \u2014 because this president has told more than 2,000 lies in a year and hasn\u2019t been called out for them by the people who signed on to silence.\n\nBut what happens if the bargain crumbles? What if the market tanks \u2014 as the Dow did in losing more than 500 points a few days ago? Do the sycophants bail? Or do they hold out for something more \u2014 like the lobbyists now drafting legislation and gutting regulations that affect the companies that pay them?\n\nBeware, those of you who have made your deal with the Stormy Daniels presidency. You can take your settlement money \u2014 as the people who signed up for the fraudulent Trump University did \u2014 but you still got suckered.", "title": "Opinion | The Stormy Daniels Presidency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Even though Artforum\u2019s large readership helped circulate the image of Chicago far and wide, no one quite anticipated the effect it would have on people. \u201cIt became a symbol, I guess,\u201d Chicago explains. The photograph was taken just on the cusp of the women artist\u2019s movement. A year later, Linda Nochlin would publish her seminal essay \u201cWhy Are There No Women Artists?\u201d in Artnews; four years after that, the Guerrilla Girls would launch their first protest against the lack of inclusion of women artists at MoMA. \u201cI was traveling and lecturing and when I would visit women artists they would have the boxing ring ad up in their studios,\u201d Chicago says. \u201cI\u2019d meet male artists and they\u2019d ask me, \u2018Do you want to box?\u2019\u201d Chicago had struck a nerve.\n\nToday, Chicago is proud of the image\u2019s legacy. Her excitement in recreating it for T \u2014 now with Collier Schorr behind the camera, and models Dilone and Jenny Shimizu (both champions of diversity in the fashion industry) in the ring \u2014 is genuine. This time, she didn\u2019t dress like a boxer and wore her own clothes. She said, \u201cI wanted to send the message that I fought for a place in a male dominated environment and I fought as a woman. I\u2019m a woman. I made a mark as a woman. I wanted to transmit that in how I dressed.\u201d But even so, Chicago remembers the battle, how hard it was to fight for what she deserved. \u201cYou have to understand that for a very, very long time, I didn\u2019t fit in,\u201d she says. \u201cI had to be isolated. I told Sasha that there were a lot of times in my career when I didn\u2019t know what to do.\u201d By stepping into the ring once more, Chicago is an example to us all.", "title": "The Story Behind T\u2019s Judy Chicago Cover", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen Mart Crowley\u2019s \u201cThe Boys in the Band\u201d debuted Off Broadway in April of 1968, The New York Times refused to use the word \u201cgay,\u201d sodomy was a crime and the Stonewall riots that would ignite the LGBT movement were still a year away. So it can hardly be ignored that the play\u2019s 50th-anniversary revival, opening this spring on Broadway, is addressing a radically different culture, one that \u2014 on the surface, at least \u2014 seems to have sacrificed this undeniably queen-y play on its march toward equality.\n\nAs the actor Zachary Quinto told The New York Times\u2019s co-chief theater critic Jesse Green in an interview for his essay, he originally had \u201ca dismissive take\u201d on \u201cThe Boys in the Band,\u201d having never seen it. But after reading the script and speaking with the producers, he eventually agreed to the part of Harold, the sharp-tongued gay man whose birthday provides the play with its setting. \u201cThe criticism was that it offered a stereotypical quality to who these characters are,\u201d Quinto said. \u201cBut what gets lost is that characters like these had never been seen on the American stage before.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nT\u2019s editor in chief, Hanya Yanagihara, saw an early reading of the play last summer and \u201cwas struck by how crackling and relevant this 50-year-old play still was: its humor, but also how vividly it telegraphed the characters\u2019 shame and despair,\u201d she says. \u201cBut what made it poignant was seeing, before me, nine openly gay actors who had made successful careers for themselves as themselves. I knew by the end of the reading that this would be an important cultural moment, and that I wanted the cast for the cover of T.\u201d\n\nMagazines being what they are, Yanagihara adds, it took about six months of planning before the cast gathered for T\u2019s Dec. 17 shoot in New York, photographed by Inez and Vinoodh. Quinto and the rest of the revival\u2019s leads \u2014 including Jim Parsons, Andrew Rannells and Matt Bomer \u2014 were joined by co-producer Ryan Murphy and director Joe Mantello, and, in a nice departure from the usual turmoil of group photo shoots (which are usually complicated by scheduling conflicts and clashing egos), there was very little drama. \u201cEveryone was on time and played nice with each other on set: no jockeying for specific positioning,\u201d says T\u2019s creative director, Patrick Li. \u201cThe fact that the shoot proceeded without incident was the only thing that was unexpected.\u201d These men, who represent the first generation of out-and-proud gay stars, frequently work together \u2014 often in Murphy\u2019s television projects \u2014 and their genuine affection for one another gave the shoot \u2014 and the play \u2014 its sense of intimacy and warmth.", "title": "The Story Behind T\u2019s \u2018The Boys in the Band\u2019 Cover", "authors": ["Kurt Soller"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "It was no surprise that Christopher Bailey had time on his mind this season. On Saturday in London, he presented his final collection for Burberry after serving 17 years as the brand\u2019s chief creative officer and president \u2014 a role in which he honored the label\u2019s 150-plus year legacy, while also ushering it into the future.\n\nWhat did surprise were the clothes themselves \u2014 a rainbow-striped tribute to \u201990s British style tribes and contemporary LGBTQ+ youth \u2014 and the choice of setting. For the finale, Bailey transformed his industrial show space into a cathedral of club culture, lit up by planes of neon-bright laser lights. But mostly, the models walked beneath the more subtly dramatic pendulum lights of \u201cOur Time\u201d (2016), the epically proportioned art installation by the British art collective United Visual Artists (UVA). Bailey had loaned the piece from its permanent home, the Museum of Old and New Art (MONA) in Hobart, Australia.", "title": "The Story Behind the Mesmeric, Moving Light Installation at Burberry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "But reality set in quickly with a congratulatory letter from Citibank, stating the terms of my debt and repayment, which could be deferred by two six-month periods, but that\u2019s it, no more, and after that, I\u2019d better run the bank its money or else. It\u2019s blasphemous but I\u2019ve been entirely unable to follow Oprah\u2019s wise words. Instead, I live in fear \u2014 fear that one day I may fall too far behind on payments, and fear of what that would mean for my mother, who co-signed my loans with great trepidation.\n\nThere\u2019s no relief for my wallet or my self-esteem. Every time I fork over another payment, I think about all of the other ways I could have financed my education. Why didn\u2019t I take more part-time jobs? I was in Washington \u2014 why didn\u2019t I try to date some closeted politician and be his well-compensated secret? Or spend more time at the campus gym and land a job stripping? I could have paid for classes in cash!\n\nAnd for so long, I took to heart the poisonous folklore about student-debt martyrs who selflessly scrape by to pay off their loans \u2014 those \u201cI only ate Spam and paid off my $160,000 debt in 96 hours\u201d stories. I blamed myself, thinking that if I had just worked harder and sacrificed more, I wouldn\u2019t be in this situation.\n\nBut the truth is, a lot of this was always out of my control. The student loan industry is a barely regulated, predatory system, and with Donald Trump in the White House and those equally useless people in Congress, oversight of the industry is becoming nonexistent.\n\nI was trying to do the right thing for myself and my family. Despite the cost, going to college is still the only way high-achieving, lower-income students can hope to get a good job with a decent wage. It\u2019s not our fault that no one told us the system beyond higher education was set up for us to fail.\n\nI am a member of that class of college students that graduated into a financial crisis, not long after a 2005 bankruptcy bill was passed that made private student loans nondischargeable unless borrowers could demonstrate that loan repayment put an \u201cundue hardship\u201d on their finances. Spoiler: The undue-hardship exception has virtually never applied to anyone. It\u2019s so vague that it\u2019s basically meaningless.\n\nI think of that slippery little phrase every time I field a nasty phone call from my student loan oppressors. If only I were a corporation or a bank, privy to loopholes, tax havens, lenient bankruptcy provisions and so many other measures that allow it to be treated far more humanely than actual human beings.", "title": "Opinion | The Student Loan Serenity Prayer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Regular readers of this column know that capturing moments of my kids\u2019 childhood is an acute anxiety of mine; I\u2019ve even wired my home with cameras to preserve a kind of reality show of life in my house.\n\nBut you don\u2019t have to be as crazy as I am to share slivers of this fear \u2014 that your kids or your pets are constantly doing things that you\u2019ll later want to remember, but that smartphones often miss. An intelligent camera gets these times because it doesn\u2019t ask you to break the moment to capture them.\n\nBut, obviously, setting up a camera that doesn\u2019t need to be specifically triggered to take a picture is problematic. It raises the worry of spying \u2014 that Google can spy on you, or that you can use it to spy on others.\n\nGoogle addresses that creepiness in two ways. The device is mostly unconnected from the internet. It can take pictures without a connection, and it requires your phone for viewing or saving the clips. But even then, all its A.I. happens on the device, and it doesn\u2019t even need you to have a Google account, the company said.\n\n\u201cWe spent a lot of time thinking about privacy, and making sure this was a device people would actually want,\u201d said Eva Snee, who heads Google\u2019s research on how people interact with Clips. \u201cWhat we learned was that cameras don\u2019t creep people out when they\u2019re used deliberately and the person is part of the process.\u201d\n\nClips also raises the memory of other products in this vein, including Snap\u2019s Spectacles and Google Glass, the search company\u2019s failed attempt to get consumers to use glasses that can take photos.\n\nTo ensure that, Clips is designed to look like a camera. When it\u2019s on, it flashes a white LED to signal that it could be recording. It also does not record audio, because that might have felt too much like spying.", "title": "The Sublime and Scary Future of Cameras With A.I. Brains", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The sight of a giant vacuum sucking up litter at his stop in northern Manhattan one recent morning heartened Ajanthan Balasinkam, an actuary \u2014 but then he wondered why he had never seen one before. With litter a major contributor to track fires, the Transportation Authority has beefed up its cleaning operation as part of the emergency plan.\n\n\u201cWhat we are doing is taking the backlog of deferred maintenance that hasn\u2019t been done in the past and doing it,\u201d said Phil Eng, the Transportation Authority\u2019s chief operating officer.\n\nSome riders, while lauding what they see as the transit authority\u2019s sense of urgency, said the work has yet to alter their commuting experience.\n\nKarla Mileski, 36, works in advertising and commutes to Times Square from the 40th Street station in Sunnyside, Queens, where countdown clocks were recently installed. Several weeks ago, she said, they stopped working.\n\nMs. Mileski also said she is unsure of the value of the more detailed explanations she sometimes hears when things go wrong. \u201c \u2018A signal malfunction.\u2019 I don\u2019t understand that as a human being,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t understand if that means it\u2019s going to be five minutes \u2014 or 10 minutes.\u201d\n\nTransit officials said they are looking into Ms. Mileski\u2019s countdown clock complaint. Still, she said she is not optimistic about the subway\u2019s future. \u201cThe sense I get is that the system is so far gone, that it would be really, really hard to fix it at this point,\u201d she said. \u201cSo if I see a few guys working on the tracks on a Saturday, I don\u2019t think they\u2019re fixing it. I don\u2019t think they possibly could.\u201d\n\nJemilah Magnusson, who lives in Harlem and works at an urban planning nonprofit in Union Square, said, \u201cThe communication is getting better, but the commute is not.\u201d For the past six months, she has checked two separate apps to figure out which train to take. \u201cIt adds another layer of work that you have to do in a city that\u2019s very demanding,\u201d Ms. Magnusson, 39, said. \u201cWe all have demanding jobs and demanding lives and to also need to problem-solve for what\u2019s going to happen with the subway \u2014 it\u2019s tough.\u201d\n\n", "title": "The Subway Is Being Fixed, but Can Riders Tell?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Olympics\u2019 decision to allow figure skating routines set to songs with lyrics was greeted as an important step toward modernizing the sport and broadening its appeal, and television audiences got their first peek late Thursday night during the men\u2019s and pairs team events. While traditionalists may fear for the integrity of the sport, the relaxed rules will at least make for a livelier peanut gallery over the next two weeks.\n\nThe highly touted 18-year-old American skater Nathan Chen finished a disappointing fourth in his Olympics debut, but viewers were at least excited about his selection of Benjamin Clementine\u2019s double-time waltz \u201cNemesis\u201d for his routine.\n\nCanada\u2019s Patrick Chan, who won the men\u2019s singles silver medal in Sochi four years ago, fell while skating to the Kansas stoner-existential classic \u201cDust in the Wind,\u201d leading the NBC commentator Johnny Weir to quip that \u201cthe routine was dust in the wind.\u201d But points should have been awarded for being the first Olympics performance to conjure both \u201cBill & Ted\u2019s Excellent Adventure\u201d and \u201cOld School.\u201d\n\n\n\nThe fellow Canadians Meagan Duhamel and Eric Radford fared a bit better, finishing second for their pairs routine to April Meservy\u2019s cover of U2\u2019s \u201cWith or Without You,\u201d which didn\u2019t necessarily score well with all judges.\n\nLess subdued was Alexei Bychenko, skating for Israel to a Jewish folk classic \u2014 or as Mr. Weir put it, bringing \u201cHava Nagila realness\u201d \u2014 which was good for a second-place finish.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Anyway, here\u2019s a bunch of people making \u201cAnyway, here\u2019s \u2018Wonderwall\u2019\u201d jokes in response to him skating to Paul Anka\u2019s 2005 schmaltzy cocktail-jazz cover of Oasis\u2019 \u201cWonderwall.\u201d If he were French, he probably would have picked the Ed Sheeran version.", "title": "The Surprise Stars of Olympic Skating: Ed Sheeran and Paul Anka", "authors": ["Steve Kandell"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJan Castro, an art critic from Brooklyn, was browsing the vials at Enfleurage on a recent Sunday. She asked Joe Richkus, the production manager of the shop, which house blend he recommended \u2014 the musky smelling \u201cearth\u201d or the brighter toned \u201cwater\u201d? Mr. Richkus seemed momentarily at a loss, but Amie Castaldo, an acupuncturist who practices in Midtown Manhattan, jumped in to take Ms. Castro\u2019s pulse and examine her tongue. Its peachy paleness disclosed \u201can excess of water,\u201d according to Chinese traditional medicine. A regular customer, Ms. Castaldo clearly knew her way around the tinted bottles on the shelves. \u201cI\u2019d recommend you get \u2018earth\u2019 to balance it,\u201d she suggested. And the sale was made.\n\nEntering the elegantly appointed, shoebox-narrow establishment, which first opened its doors on 13th Street in 2011, can be a puzzling experience. To the uninitiated, the mysterious bottles and dome-shaped, metallic objects might not immediately disclose their purpose. But the sweet aroma that permeates the place soon settles the matter of what Enfleurage is selling.\n\nThe vials on the display rack bear curious labels like Rose Otto and Osmanthus Absolute. If you ask about them, you are likely to get some fascinating back story. The lavender, for instance, which boasts 1,200 natural compounds, is harvested in the Alps by delinquent French teenagers from Nice who are sent to the floral farm for emotional healing.\n\nThat Sunday there was a class, which is usually held every other week. Mr. Richkus, a thin-faced man with hair that spills over his shoulders, was expounding on how to burn incense to a dozen mostly young enthusiasts. He lit a chip of rare agarwood from Assam, India, and slowly made the rounds, offering everyone a whiff. The aroma from the diseased wood (trees produce the fragrance as an antidote to fungal infections) is musky and mysterious, like something you might expect to smell in an ancient tomb.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not crazy about that,\u201d said Lynn Davis, an amateur aromatherapist who visits Enfleurage weekly.\n\nPhoto\n\nMore familiar was the lemony frankincense resin, which is still burned in Catholic churches. Trygve Harris, who owns the store, spends most of the year supervising a frankincense distillery in the Sultanate of Oman.", "title": "The Sweet Smell of Osmanthus Absolute", "authors": ["Richard Schiffman", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "So, too, with the specific cases that the Atlantic essay focuses on: Trump\u2019s insouciance about Russian interference in the last presidential election, and his continuing attacks on law enforcement professionals over the probe into his campaign\u2019s possible involvement with that interference. Just consider the following caveat that Wittes and Rauch append to their brief:\n\nWe don\u2019t mean to deny credit where it is due. \u2026 Last year, pressure from individual Republicans seemed to discourage Trump from firing Attorney General Jeff Sessions and probably prevented action against Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Moreover, Republicans as a group have constrained Trump on occasion. Congress imposed tough sanctions on Russia over the president\u2019s objections. The Senate Intelligence Committee conducted a serious Russia investigation under the leadership of Richard Burr. But the broader response to Trump\u2019s behavior has been tolerant and, often, enabling.\n\nSo according to authors who are trying to convince Trump-skeptical Republicans to vote against every single G.O.P. politician on principle, many Trump-era Republicans have 1) defended and protected a sweeping probe into their president\u2019s campaign and possibly his family\u2019s finances; 2) passed legislation punishing Russia for its interference; and 3) conducted a \u201cserious Russia investigation\u201d from within the United States Senate. All of which seems like \u2026 quite a bit? Perhaps even a sign that many prominent Republicans are not really just \u201cenabling\u201d Trump at all?\n\nNow it\u2019s quite true that other Republicans, especially in the House, have run interference for Trump\u2019s attacks on Mueller\u2019s probe, and encouraged rank-and-file conservatives and frequent \u201cHannity\u201d viewers to believe the worst about the F.B.I. and other \u201cdeep state\u201d organs. But partisan attacks on a special counsel\u2019s probe are not the same thing as a sustained presidential assault on democratic institutions. Nor are angry presidential tweets that lack any sustained follow-through: If the president yells about his persecutors and little or nothing happens \u2014 the Mueller probe continues, Rod Rosenstein keeps his job, etc. \u2014 what\u2019s undermined is presidential authority, not the rule of law.\n\nAnd if many House Republicans are working to enable Trump\u2019s authoritarian instincts while various Senate Republicans work to constrain them, surely that\u2019s cause for precisely the kind of discriminating thinking that Wittes and Rauch want their Republican readers to rule out \u2014 for praising Richard Burr and criticizing Devin Nunes, let\u2019s say, or for hoping Republicans keep the Senate while not minding if they lose the House, or otherwise judging conservative leaders case by case rather than insisting that they\u2019re all rubber-stamping an incipient dictatorship.\n\nAll judgments about a year-old presidency are provisional. It is very easy to imagine a scenario in which the Wittes and Rauch argument would become persuasive. For instance, if Trump were to actually fire Rosenstein and Mueller and close down the Russia investigation and Senate Republicans did nothing. Or, to be a little more imaginative, if Trump started overruling his own foreign policy team and making various unwarranted, Manchurian-candidate-style concessions to the Russians, and the Senate simply went along.\n\nOr if he invaded a country and toppled its government without Senate approval, or if he began prosecuting journalists on dubious grounds, or if tried to unilaterally rewrite immigration laws, or if he ordered the C.I.A. to torture prisoners at black sites \u2026\n\n\u2026 aah, sorry, I became carried away with memories of the last two administrations, neither of which corroded democratic norms through Twitter outbursts and personal sleaziness, to their credit, but both of which made big norm-eroding moves on other fronts that Trump has not yet come close to matching.\n\nWhich is why, for now, the constant claims that Republicans are enabling an \u201cAmerican Pinochet\u201d (as New York magazine\u2019s Jonathan Chait suggested this week) and that honorable conservatives are therefore duty-bound to hand every elected office over to a Democratic Party that, as Wittes and Rauch themselves concede, has become more ideologically extreme \u2014 well, at best they are premature, based on things that haven\u2019t happened yet but might; at worst they are a species of hysteria.\n\nI wish that Donald Trump were not the president; I blame Republicans for enabling his rise. But once his election was accomplished, their promise of containment became a reasonable approach. And so long as he remains weak and trammeled and conventional in policy, the case that conservatives have a moral obligation to vote like liberals won\u2019t convince.", "title": "Opinion | The Taming of a Demagogue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "A high-grade, 10-year municipal bond issue currently has an average yield of roughly 2.5 percent. That compares with a 3.3 percent taxable yield for someone in the 24 percent federal tax bracket, and 4 percent for a taxpayer paying the top federal rate of 37 percent. The taxable equivalent yield is even higher if the income is also exempt from a state tax.\n\nBy comparison, the yield on a 10-year Treasury bond is below 3 percent and the yield on the Vanguard Total Bond Market Index fund, which invests in taxable government and corporate bonds, was recently only 2.5 percent.\n\nDespite the appeal of munis, though, you need to be careful: The muni market can be tricky.\n\nFor one thing, amid fiscal belt tightening since the financial crisis, the pace of new municipal bonds hitting the market has declined. The tax law revision also eliminated advance refunding issues, a type of municipal bond financing that accounts for around 15 percent of the market, intensifying supply constraints.\n\nAt the same time, individual investors own about 70 percent of the municipal bonds, and demand from them seems likely to remain strong. Morningstar Direct reported $34 billion in net inflows to municipal bond funds and exchange-traded funds in 2017 \u2014 even before investors in high-tax states had the chance to huddle with their advisers to assess the impact of the new tax law.\n\nWith hungry investors chasing a smaller pool of municipal issues, the prices of bonds are likely to be bid higher. (In the world of bonds, yields move in the opposite direction from prices; so higher bond prices mean lower yields.)\n\nPhoto\n\nThat pressure has already caused the yield difference between municipal bonds and comparable Treasuries to widen \u2014 reducing the muni advantage. For much of the last decade, the tax-free yield on a 10-year high-grade municipal bond was at least 90 percent of the taxable yield on a 10-year Treasury. That ratio is now down to the low 80s. Hugh McGuirk, head of the municipal bond team at T. Rowe Price, expects that this ratio will \u201cbe even under more pressure\u201d as a result of these supply and demand issues.\n\nMunicipal bonds issued within your home state can be enticing because of the extra tax features. Around one-quarter of the nearly $700 billion in muni bond funds and E.T.F.s is invested in single-state portfolios, according to Morningstar Direct.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Adam Stern, co-head of research at the fixed-income specialist Breckinridge Capital Advisors, cautioned that sticking with in-state issuers could be difficult. \u201cIn California, where there are hundreds of different issuers, you can create a pretty-well-diversified portfolio. But a state like New Jersey is a little tougher. With fewer issuers, it\u2019s harder to figure out a diversified portfolio.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. McGuirk said the national funds run by T. Rowe Price usually own issues backed by 250 to 300 guarantors, compared with just 60 to 80 for single-state funds. Owning out-of-state bonds in a national fund can provide diversification, though you will pocket only the federal interest-income tax break, and have a liability for state and local taxes. Bonds from five states account for about half the assets in the Fidelity Intermediate Municipal Income fund, which has a recent yield of 2.6 percent.\n\nHigh-yield municipal bonds carry more risk, but John Miller, co-head of fixed income at Nuveen Asset Management, expects them to have a solid 2018, mainly because he does not see a recession on the near-term horizon.
