You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nVermont has some of the weakest gun laws in the country. After the school shooting in Florida last week, Vermont\u2019s governor \u2014 Phil Scott, a Republican \u2014 initially vowed that those laws would remain the same.\n\nBut then he changed his mind.\n\nHe changed it just one day after his initial response. Why? In the meantime, an 18-year-old from Poultney, Vt. \u2014 a small town in the southwestern part of the state \u2014 was arrested for allegedly planning yet another school shooting.\n\n\u201cIf we are at a point when we put our kids on a bus and send them to school without being able to guarantee their safety, who are we?\u201d Scott said, according to Seven Days, a Vermont publication. \u201cI need to be open-minded, objective and at least consider anything that will protect our kids.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | There\u2019s Reason for Hope on Guns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Activists have done their own sleuthing.\n\nOver six years, Mike Provost of Windsor, who helps run the Facebook page, has amassed more than 4,000 pages of daily observations about the duration, intensity and characteristics of the sound and the weather conditions at the time.\n\nHe has had to fend off skeptics and theorists who believe that the hum is related to secret tunneling, U.F.O.s or covert government operations, he said.\n\nMr. Provost, a retired insurance salesman, said his work was a blend of obsession and hobby. \u201cI\u2019ve got to keep going,\u201d he said in a phone interview. \u201cI\u2019m not going to quit this.\u201d\n\nThe hum is not limited to Windsor, a city of about 220,000 people on the Detroit River. Mr. Provost said he had received reports from McGregor, Ontario, 20 miles to the south, and from east of Cleveland, about 90 miles away.\n\nTracey Ramsey, a member of the Canadian House of Commons, said in a phone interview that she regularly gets calls from constituents about the health effects of the hum. Residents have complained of headaches, sleeplessness, irritability and depression, among other symptoms.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s something they are desperate for an answer to,\u201d she said.\n\nTracing the noise\u2019s origins is complicated by who hears it, and when and where.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTim Carpenter, a retired consulting engineer who specialized in geotechnical engineering and machine vibrations and is an administrator of the Facebook page, says not everyone can hear it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s as if you had a fire hose moving back and forth and the people who have the water falling on them hear the noise, and if you\u2019re outside that stream, you don\u2019t hear the noise,\u201d he said.\n\nResearchers have found no trends related to gender or age for the \u201chearers.\u201d\n\nDr. Darius Kohan, the director of otology and neurotology at Lenox Hill Hospital and Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, said that the low-frequency hum was unlikely to cause long-term hearing damage but that it could be as debilitating as tinnitus, a persistent ringing in the ears.\n\nScott Barton, an assistant professor of music at Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts, said in a phone interview that infrasound, which is below 20 hertz, can create a sense of unease because it is unintelligible to human hearing but still detectable. While it is possible to be accustomed to certain noises (the hum of an air-conditioner, for example), this low-frequency noise is challenging because it has been so inconsistent, he said.\n\nSeeking intervention by government regulators for the hum is difficult because regulations typically address decibel levels that can lead to hearing loss or damage, not those that can affect quality of life, Rebecca Smith, a sound engineer and doctoral student at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, who researches urban noise, wrote in an email.\n\n\u201cThink about the sound of a dog barking,\u201d she said. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t need to be loud enough to physically damage you to be really annoying and distracting.\u201d\n\nThe University of Windsor report said the hum\u2019s likely source was blast furnace operations on Zug Island on the Detroit River, which is densely packed with manufacturing. Activists complained that United States Steel, which operates the furnaces, has been uncooperative and secretive. A company spokeswoman did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nA principal investigator on the study, Professor Colin Novak, told CBC News in 2014 that researchers needed more time and cooperation from the American authorities to pinpoint the source. \u201cIt\u2019s like chasing a ghost,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHums similar to Windsor\u2019s have been reported in at least a dozen communities worldwide, including in Australia, England and Scotland, the study said. In the United States, high-profile hums have been reported in Taos, N.M., and Kokomo, Ind.\n\nResearchers studied the Taos hum in 1993 but did not pinpoint a source. Karina Armijo, the town\u2019s director of marketing and tourism, said in a telephone interview that complaints had subsided.\n\n\u201cI have never heard the Taos hum, but I\u2019ve heard stories of the Taos hum,\u201d she said. \u201cThere\u2019s not been a lot of buzz about it in the last few years.\u201d\n\nA 2003 study in Kokomo by the acoustics and vibration consulting company Acentech prompted two industrial plants to install silencing equipment, providing relief to some residents but not all, a 2008 paper about the study said.\n\n\u201cIn fact, one affected resident had become so disturbed that she moved more than 700 miles away to relieve her symptoms,\u201d it said.\n\nMr. Carpenter said it was possible a major source of the Windsor hum could be eliminated and other mechanical sources would replace it, entering the \u201cheard spectrum.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s possible that no matter what is done to relieve or attenuate the noise, it might never be enough,\u201d he said.", "title": "There\u2019s a Persistent Hum in This Canadian City, and No One Knows Why", "authors": ["Christopher Mele"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Ruddy began producing \u201cGravid Water\u201d (the title comes from a Flann O\u2019Brien novel and if you buttonhole Mr. Ruddy he will tell you all about it) in 2004. Studying improv at U.C.B. and acting at the Atlantic Acting School, he was struck by the overlap. \u201cIt\u2019s all about reacting honestly in the moment,\u201d he said.\n\nHe didn\u2019t know if the first \u201cGravid Water\u201d would work, but he put together an evening featuring the writings of Woody Allen, Thornton Wilder and Theresa Rebeck, hoping \u201cit wouldn\u2019t be quite the train wreck you\u2019d think it would be,\u201d he said.\n\nThirteen years in, the January show was a flighty grab bag, with one scene that thrilled, a couple that tickled, two others that floundered. But as Mr. Ruddy said, because neither the actor nor the comedian knows how the scene will go, \u201cThe tension isn\u2019t just dramatic. It\u2019s real.\u201d\n\nIn the first \u2014 and best scene \u2014 Ms. Milioti played a character from Stephen Dietz\u2019s 1995 \u201cTrust,\u201d a bride being measured for a wedding dress. Tami Sagher (\u201cDon\u2019t Think Twice\u201d) improvised the seamstress, giving her a thick Slavic accent.\n\nLike Ms. Sagher, I hadn\u2019t met Mr. Dietz\u2019s play before, but when it premiered Ben Brantley called it \u201c \u2018Melrose Place\u2019 with a thesaurus and a reflective streak of self-consciousness,\u201d frowning on the heavy-handed dialogue.\n\nWell, that dialogue became a lot lighter with Ms. Sagher around. At one point she went into an aptly vulgar riff on Kobe Bryant, and I think I heard a shout out to Cynthia Plaster Caster, too.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome of the lines were wittier and more character-focused than that, as when Ms. Miloti\u2019s character asked, \u201cAre you married?\u201d and Ms. Sagher replied, \u201cNo. But I have been. Many times. A good dressmaker learns from her mistakes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat was most remarkable was the way the two women listened to each other, the way Ms. Milioti stayed quiet until Ms. Sagher gave her an opening to sensibly segue to her next line, the way Ms. Sagher used each dribble of information to both set up jokes and create real conflict.\n\nMs. Milioti, who will appear again in the Feb. 26 show, said that she loves the uncertainty of the scenes, the intense focus they require, the need to be \u201c1,000 percent present,\u201d and the surprise when \u201csomething molecular happens\u201d and she and the improviser find a groove. \u201cIt is incredibly exhilarating,\u201d she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe only musical number at the January show was a fragment of \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d If you\u2019re thinking, wait, everyone knows \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d I give you Mr. Stack, who transformed the Cornelius and Barnaby scene into a sweetly loopy father-son chat.\n\n\u201cWe are not coming back to Yonkers until we\u2019ve each kissed a girl,\u201d Todd Buonopane\u2019s Cornelius said. \u201cI never even kissed your mother,\u201d Mr. Stack replied. When \u201cPut on Your Sunday Clothes\u201d struck up, he managed to rhyme Yonkers with bonkers.\n\nHow has Mr. Stack, a writer for \u201cThe Late Show With Stephen Colbert,\u201d lived 53 years without knowing \u201cHello, Dolly!\u201d?\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a blind spot for me,\u201d he said. He keeps coming back to \u201cGravid Water\u201d for the times when \u201ccorny as it sounds, it almost seems like there\u2019s a psychic connection,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Ruddy likes to tell a story about a show years ago that included a scene from Lillian Hellman\u2019s \u201cThe Children\u2019s Hour.\u201d Usually, one schoolmistress declares her love to another and is rebuffed.\n\nNo one told the \u201cGravid Water\u201d improviser. She declared it right back. Instead of a prelude to suicide, \u201cIt became a touching, sincere scene about two people realizing they are in love,\u201d Mr. Ruddy said.\n\nI wasn\u2019t crazy about every scene in the January show. Honestly, I wasn\u2019t crazy about most of them. Some went on too long, another never got started. But as someone who sees a lot of plays and a lot of the same plays, I\u2019m a fan of the cheerful sedition at its heart.\n\nEven the spluttering scenes suggest that we don\u2019t always have to play by the published script or accept the roles we\u2019re handed. They imply that maybe, every so often, a work or a line or a person can still surprise us.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo step on it, Godot.", "title": "These Actors Are Off Book. Way Off.", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "That does not mean it\u2019s entirely a marketing gimmick. The United States Department of Agriculture began regulating organic foods in 2002. Organic crops are supposed to be grown without genetic modifications or synthetic pesticides and other synthetic additives, though there are exceptions. Organic livestock is raised without antibiotics.\n\nWhile regulators give out a \u201cU.S.D.A. Organic\u201d label, Goldfish don\u2019t qualify. Still, you are allowed to say a product features an organic ingredient as long as it \u201ccontains at least 70 percent organically produced ingredients (excluding salt and water).\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Campbell Soup Company, which owns the Goldfish brand, started selling three kinds of Goldfish with organic ingredients in 2016. Chris Foley, chief marketing officer at Pepperidge Farm, a division of Campbell\u2019s, said organic was a natural fit for the brand.\n\n\u201cI think Goldfish start from a very healthy place,\u201d he said. (We\u2019ll set aside that this is a brand that offers flavors like S\u2019mores and Cookies & Cream.) \u201cWe have no artificial flavors and preservatives. It\u2019s 100 percent real cheese. We source our colors from real plants.\u201d\n\nThe move into organic was driven by market research.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re always listening to our moms \u2014 that\u2019s our primary buyer,\u201d Mr. Foley said. \u201cCertainly there are more moms looking for more organic options.\u201d\n\nMoms aside, there\u2019s an elephant in the room we have not addressed.\n\nOr, to be more accurate, a bunny.\n\nThe advent of 70 percent organic Goldfish almost certainly has something to do with the rise of Cheddar Bunnies, made by Annie\u2019s Homegrown, which General Mills acquired in 2014. One blog for moms declared Cheddar Bunnies \u201cthe Goldfish of this generation\u201d in 2015, the kind of sentiment that probably didn\u2019t sit well at Campbell.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOrganic Goldfish appear to emulate Cheddar Bunnies, which debuted in 2003. Both are made with organic wheat and are 70 percent organic. Annie\u2019s did also start selling a fully organic, U.S.D.A.-certified variety of Cheddar Bunnies in 2008, though the lesser organic variety remains the flagship.\n\nGoing 70 percent organic limits additives like autolyzed yeast extract, \u201cwhich provides savory background flavor notes\u201d to Cheddar Goldfish but is left out of organic wheat Goldfish, Campbell said. Going fully organic would require further paring of the industrial pantry, and might be a distinction lost on many consumers anyway.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn response to questions about its view of Goldfish, Annie\u2019s took the high road. In a statement, the company said, \u201cWe believe that organic food is good for people and the planet we all share, so we\u2019re always excited to see increased access to organic options for consumers.\u201d\n\nI went back to Campbell and asked if Annie\u2019s had anything to do with organic Goldfish. Mr. Foley held to his position. In an email, he said the decision \u201cwas about listening to our customers: moms going up and down supermarket aisles searching for \u2018better for you\u2019 options.\u201d\n\nNow that we\u2019ve caught up on Big Food\u2019s chess match over salty animal crackers, does any of this matter? Is organic healthier?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile organic crops are not pesticide free, peer-reviewed studies have found they have fewer pesticide residues than conventional crops. Still, the Environmental Protection Agency has found that the pesticide residues found on almost all crops are within acceptable tolerances. But debate on the topic continues.\n\n\u201cExisting data shows that when we eat organically, we reduce our pesticide exposure,\u201d said Cynthia Curl, an assistant professor at Boise State University who has studied the topic extensively. \u201cObservational studies, while not conclusive, are consistent with the idea that there may be health benefits from reducing pesticide exposure, particularly during pregnancy. But the science simply isn\u2019t there to say for sure.\u201d\n\nMeanwhile, I\u2019ll keep chomping my way through my own research. When I\u2019m stuffing my face with organic wheat Goldfish, or regular Cheddar Bunnies, I now know to feel 70 percent better about myself than if I were eating regular Goldfish, but 30 percent worse than if I were gobbling up the U.S.D.A.-certified organic Cheddar Bunnies. And I haven\u2019t tried the Flavor Blasted\u00ae Kick It Up a Nacho Goldfish, but I think there\u2019d be some guilt involved.\n\nFor the big food manufacturers, organic simply fills another market niche. I asked Mr. Foley if Goldfish with organic wheat was any healthier than the regular kind, a tricky question for an executive at a large food company to answer.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an alternative,\u201d he said.", "title": "These Goldfish Are 70 Percent Organic", "authors": ["Danny Hakim"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "About 375 million years ago, a pioneering fish crawled out of a prehistoric ocean and kick-started the evolution of salamanders, lizards, you, me and all other land vertebrates that have ever existed.\n\nThe circuits of neurons that govern walking, many have long thought, emerged sometime after that, as creatures transitioned from swimming to limb-based locomotion.\n\nBut a new report, published in the journal Cell on Thursday, overturns that notion, suggesting the template for walking originated in ancient fish millions of years before the first vertebrate ever ambled on dry land. The little skate, a fish closely related to sharks and rays, not only displays walking behavior on the seafloor, but uses neurons and genes that are nearly identical to the ones vertebrates use to walk on land, said Jeremy Dasen, an associate professor at the N.Y.U. School of Medicine\u2019s Neuroscience Institute and senior author of the paper.\n\nYou can trace the heritage of little skates and land vertebrates back to a common ancestor that lived about 420 million years ago. This primitive fish gave rise to the vast majority of vertebrate species, including all fish with paired fins. Typically, these pectoral and pelvic fins \u2014 which correspond to forelimbs and hindlimbs in land vertebrates \u2014 are small and largely used for balance and steering. To really propel themselves, most fish wriggle their powerful tails.", "title": "These Skates Are Made for Walking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Chazzie said: \u201cMom, Dad look at me \u2014 isn\u2019t my hair awesome? Isn\u2019t it fabulous? I want long hair,\u201d Ms. Grosshandler recalled.\n\nYears later, Chazzie cried while getting ready for school, and asked: \u201cMom, what happens if I\u2019m a girl? Because I really believe I am a girl. What will happen to me? Will you love me? Will Dad love me? Will my brothers love me?\u201d\n\n\u201cThat was a huge moment for us,\u201d Ms. Grosshandler said. She eventually left her consulting practice to focus on advocacy.\n\nSoon after, she created the GenderCool Project with Gearah Goldstein, a transgender woman who trains people on how to create gender-inclusive environments.\n\n\u201cOur mission is to just get rid of the stigmas and just live our lives,\u201d said Nicole, one of the participants. \u201cAnd that\u2019s what everybody else is doing. So my question to the world is: \u2018Why can\u2019t we? Why should we not?\u2019\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMeet the \u2018champions\u2019\n\nThe project seeks to humanize members of a minority group who are increasingly visible but who find their gender identity at times overshadowing everything else about them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s pretty unique,\u201d said Debi Jackson, a family organizer at the National Center for Transgender Equality. There are a lot of websites that explain how to navigate a child\u2019s transition, she said, but they aren\u2019t focused on celebrating the kid you have.\n\nBeing \u201cgender cool\u201d is about being \u201ccool with whomever anyone else is,\u201d Ms. Grosshandler said. She calls the participants champions. And their stories are aspirational rather than full of adversity.\n\nGia, 14, is one of her school\u2019s top field hockey players and a straight-A student. Nicole, 16, is an actress with perfectly manicured nails who hopes to appear on Broadway one day. Stella, 13, lobbies politicians for protections for trans students. Landon, 15, is an accomplished trumpet player and artist whose latest work explores \u201chow society puts down men and boys for being feminine.\u201d Daniel, 12, is a photographer. (Their last names and hometowns are being withheld to protect their privacy.)\n\nOn Sunday, they sat side by side, laughing and chatting as if they had known one another for years, even though their first meeting in person was only a day earlier. Later, a spirited game of Never Have I Ever (\u201cNever have I ever been to Sephora!\u201d \u201cNever have I ever legally changed my name!\u201d) was followed by a snowball fight in Central Park. Together, they were buoyant.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re all diamonds. Being trans is just one face, one edge of the diamond,\u201d Landon said. \u201cBut there is so much else that makes us diamonds. It\u2019s not just a single sliver.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2018I just want to show other people that they\u2019re not alone\u2019\n\nWhen Gia first transitioned, she was nervous. She had heard only negative stories about transgender people.\n\n\u201cI was confused, honestly,\u201d she said. \u201cShould I really transition? Like, what\u2019s going to come of this?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOnce she did, her fears subsided. \u201cI haven\u2019t had a single person make fun of me.\u201d\n\nThat wasn\u2019t everyone\u2019s experience. Stella was bullied, and Nicole said she hadn\u2019t seen her father in four years because he does not approve of her gender identity.\n\n\u201cBut I had a very supportive family, except for him,\u201d Nicole said. \u201cI had a very supportive school.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe and the other participants said they hoped to make the world a less lonely place.\n\n\u201cWhen other kids see this, they can be like: \u2018Oh my God, I\u2019m like that. I\u2019m like that girl,\u2019\u201d Chazzie said, wiping tears from her eyes. \u201cI just want to show other people that they\u2019re not alone.\u201d\n\nPresenting a different narrative\n\nAn estimated 150,000 people ages 13 to 17 in the United States identify as transgender, according to a January 2017 report by the Williams Institute at the U.C.L.A. School of Law, which researches law and public policy on gender identity and sexual orientation.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn December, a Williams Institute study of gender nonconforming youths in California found that they were more than twice as likely as their gender conforming peers to have experienced psychological distress. The 2015 National School Climate Survey found that transgender students experienced more hostility than others. And four out of 10 transgender adults report having attempted suicide, according to a 2017 study by Human Rights Campaign and the Trans People of Color Coalition, the majority having done so before age 25.\n\nThe outlook for transgender youth often improves, however, when they say they feel supported.\n\nAccording to the group Trans Student Educational Resources, those with supportive parents were much more likely to have high self-esteem and less likely to suffer from depression.\n\n\u201cI see these kids thriving all the time,\u201d said Stella\u2019s mother, Lisa. \u201cIt\u2019s not newsworthy because it\u2019s not tragic or sensationalized.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s important to highlight the difficulties faced by trans people, she said. \u201cBut it\u2019s also equally important to show how extraordinary these kids are.\u201d\n\nA campaign aimed at \u2018folks in every town\u2019\n\nMs. Grosshandler and Ms. Goldstein have rolled their campaign out strategically.\n\nThey introduced it in February because at this time last year, President Trump rescinded protections for transgender students that had allowed them to use bathrooms corresponding with their gender identity.\n\nAnd they appeared on \u201cMegyn Kelly Today\u201d because her program appeals to different groups, Ms. Grosshandler said, including \u201cmany people who have never met a young transgender child.\u201d\n\nMs. Kelly, a former Fox News host, wasn\u2019t necessarily an obvious choice. But \u201cwe felt so strongly that we wanted to talk to folks in every town, in every community,\u201d Ms. Grosshandler said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe GenderCool Project is a call to action, Ms. Goldstein said. \u201cWhat are you doing for the community? How are you using voices, how are you telling stories, how are you being inclusive?\u201d As a transgender adult, she added, \u201cI wish I had some positive messaging around when I was growing up.\u201d", "title": "These Transgender Children Say They\u2019re Thriving. They Want to Help Others Do the Same.", "authors": ["Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou heard it,\u201d said David Shamouelian, the owner and C.E.O. of Romeo & Juliet Couture. \u201cThere was power behind these triplets.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s not the first time multiple births have graced the fashion world. Identical twins who go by the names Cipriana Quann and TK Wonder appeared in a recent Kenneth Cole advertising campaign. In October the designer Jun Takahashi cast five sets of identical twins to close his show at Paris Fashion Week.\n\nBut triplets are rarer than twins, and for the past two years these sisters, 24 and living in the Astoria neighborhood of Queens, have convinced multiple designers, television producers and filmmakers that their showcases will be better with their participation.\n\nThey have come down the catwalk for designers including Adrian Alicea and Andre Emery. They have appeared on \u201cGood Morning America.\u201d There is reality-show interest, they said. \u201cWe aren\u2019t allowed to say who just yet,\u201d Arianna said with a grin.\n\nIn September they plan to introduce their own feminine, but not too girlie, clothing line of denim and trucker jackets, jumpsuits and florals. They have a studio in their three-bedroom apartment, where they photograph themselves and other models and actors for extra pay. They also act and have appeared in a few short films including the popular video for Circa Survive\u2019s song \u201cPremonition of the Hex.\u201d\n\nArianna is the stylist and designer, Andrea is the photographer, and Athena is the lead actress. But they almost always market themselves as one.\n\n\u201cThere are a lot of pretty blond girls, but there aren\u2019t that many triplets,\u201d Athena said. \u201cWe should use it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMany multiples try to differentiate themselves as individuals, but for marketing purposes this set is determined to be as identical as possible. If one of them wants a haircut, all must agree to get the same look. \u201cI wanted bangs a couple of months ago, but my sisters told me they didn\u2019t, so we couldn\u2019t do it,\u201d Andrea said. \u201cThey saved me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey don\u2019t always have to try that hard. The morning of the Romeo & Juliet show they put on matching shoes, leggings and oversize sweaters without consulting one another, they said. The apartment is shared with Andrea\u2019s cat, Arianna\u2019s cat and Athena\u2019s 55-pound dog. \u201cThe animals can tell us apart,\u201d Athena said. \u201cThey know who their parents are.\u201d\n\nSince they were young girls, growing up in Hyannis, Mass., the sisters wanted to do things together. At 11 they wore shirts Arianna made out of old pillowcases to school. As seniors, they starred together in \u201cTwelfth Night,\u201d with Athena and Arianna cast as Viola and Andrea playing Feste, the singing fool. \u201cOur teacher was so worried about how to give us all lead roles,\u201d Andrea said. \u201cHe was so relieved when he found out I could sing better than them.\u201d\n\nAfter attending different colleges, study-abroad programs and graduate schools, they all moved to New York City to give modeling \u2014 something they had done for fun \u2014 a try professionally.\n\n\u201cOther careers were always something we could go back to,\u201d Andrea said. \u201cBut modeling is something we can only do now. And it\u2019s something I can do with my sisters now.\u201d\n\nAnd they have become more value as a threesome.\n\n\u201cWe have done shoots with them individually, but the triplets is what makes a difference,\u201d Mr. Shamouelian said. (Arianna also works part time as one of his assistant designers.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t really know if I would have used them if it was just one because I tend to use models that are 5\u20329 and up,\u201d Mr. Emery said. (The Levesques are 5-foot-6.) \u201cBut because they are triplets I knew I could be creative with them. I knew people would say, \u2018Whoa, this is a new trend.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe triplets have a long list of bigger designers they want to model for, including Dolce & Gabanna and Tom Ford.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut there are downsides to the sisters working together, said Sara Ziff, the founder and executive director of the Model Alliance, a New York City advocacy organization for models.\n\n\u201cBooking triplet models is a very specific choice on the part of the client,\u201d she said. \u201cI imagine it might be limiting for the models themselves if they are always sold as a package deal.\u201d (The triplets respond by saying that they encourage each other to get big gigs on their own. It will only elevate all of them, they reason.)\n\nMs. Ziff also worries that the presence of identical-triplet models reinforces a notion in the fashion world that all models should look exactly the same. \u201cIt\u2019s arresting to see people as carbon copies. With hair and makeup, models are often made to look interchangeable, and their individuality is subsumed by the brand,\u201d she said. \u201cHaving the same DNA takes that to another level.\u201d\n\nMr. Emery, though, dresses the triplets differently, with one in a robe for his debut, another looking like she was headed to a nightclub. \u201cI want them to have their own individual style and taste,\u201d he said.\n\nAnd the models insist they don\u2019t care so long as the clothes fit well and are flattering.\n\n\u201cThe only important thing is that we are either all the same or all different,\u201d Athena said. \u201cI just don\u2019t like it when two people are the same, and I have to be different. We are triplets.\u201d", "title": "These Triplet Models Want to Take This Town by the Throat", "authors": ["Alyson Krueger"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Two side-by-side anthropomorphic vases by Picasso are painted with the faces of a king and queen, her eyes seeming to throw a side glance toward him. \u201cThat\u2019s representative of our relationship,\u201d mused Mr. Pritchard.\n\nFollowing are edited excerpts from a conversation with the Pritchards.\n\nDo you see any parallels between your work as a geologist and your attraction to abstraction?\n\nPhoto\n\nMR. PRITCHARD I\u2019ve never thought about it that way, but geology is a lot more abstract than engineering \u2014 just being able to visualize things in the subsurface, particularly when you\u2019re searching for oil. At my company, Indigo, on the walls are these beautifully colored maps on the thicknesses of zones and the structures that look very similar to the paintings on the walls here.\n\nHow would you describe your collecting approach?\n\nMR. PRITCHARD I\u2019m impulsive. She does the research.\n\nMRS. PRITCHARD We love going to shows like Art Basel Miami or the ADAA [the Art Show of the Art Dealers Association of America] in New York. We\u2019ve also bought at auctions. That can be frustrating when you get into a bidding war.\n\nDo you get swept up in the competition?\n\nMR. PRITCHARD We have a not-greater-than number and we always seem to exceed it. That de Kooning work on paper just ran up. We chased it, over two times the high end of the estimate.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s an example of an impulse buy?\n\nMRS. PRITCHARD We flew to London to look at one of Yayoi Kusama\u2019s \u201cInfinity Nets\u201d we were interested in buying at Victoria Miro. It wasn\u2019t the Kusama we were dreaming of, but the gallery had these eight photo-collages up by Chris Ofili [each titled \u201cHound (Study for \u201cDiana & Actaeon)\u201d], and we came home with them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMR. PRITCHARD There was a ballet in London of Diana and Actaeon. Ofili drew the costumes for the ballet and the dancers had these heads of the dogs.\n\nDo you have a favorite piece in the collection?\n\nMRS. PRITCHARD I would say the Pousette-Dart. It started everything. We had never spent that much on almost anything before.\n\nMR. PRITCHARD We just love it for sentimental value. But Pousette-Dart\u2019s trajectory seems to be improving more recently at the auctions. We\u2019ve never sold anything and have no plans to ever sell anything, but it\u2019s always nice to know your artists are doing well.", "title": "They Built a Home, and With It, a Collection", "authors": ["Hilarie M. Sheets", "Show Us Your Wall"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Those films featured seasoned actors. \u201cThe 15:17 to Paris\u201d is part of a long tradition of heroes playing themselves in movies. The baseball pioneer Jackie Robinson starred in \u201cThe Jackie Robinson Story\u201d (1950) and the World War II veteran Audie Murphy re-created his exploits for \u201cTo Hell and Back\u201d (1955).\n\nThe new film\u2019s stars met the director when he presented them with Hero Awards at the Guys Choice ceremony on the cable channel Spike in 2016. \u201cThe three of us huddled and said, \u2018We have to jokingly pitch him on making the movie,\u2019 because we were working on a book at the time, and we didn\u2019t want to waste the opportunity,\u201d Mr. Sadler recalled. \u201cHe said, \u2018You never know \u2014 send me the book.\u2019\u201d\n\nAfter the director warmed to the inspirational story and the screenwriter Dorothy Blyskal turned it into a script, Mr. Eastwood began auditioning actors for the leads. Mr. Stone, Mr. Skarlatos and Mr. Sadler suggested in jest that they should be played by Chris Hemsworth, Zac Efron and Michael B. Jordan. \u201cI got a crazy idea maybe these guys should play themselves,\u201d Mr. Eastwood said. \u201cThey\u2019re genuinely charismatic. I figured I\u2019d roll the dice, what the hell? What can they do to me at this stage?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThree weeks before shooting started, Mr. Eastwood asked the three to come in for a meeting, ostensibly to assess the screenplay\u2019s accuracy, which they had discussed before. Only this time, he had a camera, and he asked them to re-enact the events. Then he offered them the chance to play themselves. \u201cWe hadn\u2019t even joked about that \u2014 it wasn\u2019t on our radar as a possibility,\u201d said Mr. Skarlatos, who, like his two friends, hadn\u2019t ever acted in so much as a school play. \u201cWhen he asked us, we immediately said yes, because, I mean, you can\u2019t tell Clint Eastwood no.\u201d\n\nMr. Stone doubted that decision on his first day of filming last summer. \u201cI looked over and there was Clint Eastwood, and I felt like I was in \u2018The Twilight Zone,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cI bombed my first few takes, but then I got myself together and said, \u2018Come on, you said yes to this, just suck it up and do it,\u2019 and from there, it got easier and easier.\u201d\n\nThe low-key atmosphere Mr. Eastwood\u2019s sets are known for helped soothe the fledgling stars\u2019 nerves. \u201cI\u2019ve become an anti-anxiety specialist,\u201d the director said. \u201cIn the old days, when I started doing small parts in the \u201950s, assistant directors would ring bells and yell, \u2018Quiet!\u2019 even if it was quiet already. But you don\u2019t want to jar anybody\u2019s nervous system. You just want them to have the most comfortable situation you can.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe stars said Mr. Eastwood also kept it simple when guiding them. \u201cHe talked to us the same way he talked to the other actors, which was not very much in terms of direction,\u201d said Mr. Skarlatos, whose experienced co-stars included Jenna Fischer (\u201cThe Office\u201d) as his mother and Judy Greer (\u201cJurassic World\u201d) as Mr. Stone\u2019s mother. \u201cAll he said to us was, \u2018Do it how you did it.\u2019 He lets you do your job, which I thought was strange, since acting wasn\u2019t our job.\u201d\n\nAt least it wasn\u2019t until now: All three men intend to pursue acting. (Mr. Stone and Mr. Skarlatos have since left the military.) \u201cFor sure, if I can make it a career, then why the heck not?\u201d Mr. Stone said. \u201cI\u2019ve gone full Hollywood. I got a big agency, U.T.A., and hopefully things will take off.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe novices even got some career advice from their director. \u201cI told them after they were done shooting this movie, they could take acting lessons,\u201d Mr. Eastwood said. \u201cIt\u2019ll probably screw them up for a while, but they\u2019ll be all right.\u201d\n\nAs for his own future, Mr. Eastwood is keeping his options open. He first stepped behind the camera when he briefly filled in for the flu-stricken director Don Siegel on the set of \u201cDirty Harry\u201d in 1971. \u201cI thought, well, I\u2019ll try this for a while, and at a certain time in life, I\u2019ll probably look up at the screen and say, \u2018Nuh-uh,\u2019\u201d Mr. Eastwood said. \u201cI don\u2019t know if that\u2019s happened yet. But I\u2019ve never gotten bored.\u201d\n\nAt 87, he\u2019s also not ruling out a return to acting, if the right part comes along. Although he chose not to appear in \u201cThe 15:17 to Paris,\u201d a poster for another film Mr. Eastwood directed, \u201cLetters From Iwo Jima,\u201d can be seen in Mr. Stone\u2019s childhood bedroom. \u201cThat\u2019s better than having me do a cameo, like Alfred Hitchcock did,\u201d Mr. Eastwood said. \u201cI didn\u2019t want to be distracting.\u201d\n\nIn the end, as Dirty Harry said in \u201cMagnum Force,\u201d \u201cA man\u2019s got to know his limitations.\u201d If only Mr. Eastwood had figured that out before his \u201cMister Ed\u201d turn. \u201cThat wasn\u2019t an example of great acting, I don\u2019t think,\u201d he said with a laugh. \u201cBut I haven\u2019t seen it in many years.\u201d", "title": "They Foiled a Terror Attack. Now They\u2019re Starring in the Movie.", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Swan, the executive assistant from New York who traveled with Ms. Pearson, said that the trip to Gander was therapeutic. \u201cI\u2019ve been in New York City for 13\u00bd years, so it\u2019s easy to get bogged down in the pressures,\u201d she said. \u201cGoing there and seeing what a positive mind-set these people have, I catch myself more when I\u2019m stressing.\u201d\n\nThe people of Gander may be welcoming tourists with open arms, but they are also taking full advantage of their moment in the sun. The town now has official van tours, welcome centers and signs for \u201cCome From Away\u201d fans. Gander\u2019s website warns those planning to visit during peak season (summer) to book accommodations and car rentals well in advance. Mr. Elliott, however, doesn\u2019t think this is an issue. \u201cIf there is no more room just give someone a call, and you can stay in their home,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s just the way we are.\u201d\n\nMr. and Ms. Emerson are heading back sometime in 2018 to see sites like Gros Morne National Park. Ms. Pearson and Ms. Swan are also taking another trip in June to take in the icebergs, the whales and some little towns they missed on their first trip.\n\nThe exchange goes both ways. The \u201cIslanders,\u201d as they call themselves in the musical, are visiting New York, too.\n\n\u201cIt was an eerie feeling being at ground zero,\u201d Mr. Elliott said. \u201cIt was like I was walking on sacred ground. You look around and close your eyes and you can envision what these people were going through that day and what terror must have been going through everybody over here.\u201d\n\nFor Ms. Davis, the retired teacher, the Broadway premiere provided an opportunity for her to visit New York for the first time. She found that when she opened up to New Yorkers about her story, they were as hospitable to her as she had been to them. While in line at the 9/11 Tribute Museum, one man insisted on paying her admission fee. Outside the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, she asked a local couple to take her picture. They ended up inviting her to their home for dinner. \u201cSaying no was one of my biggest regrets of my time in New York City,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was being on the receiving end of people giving. Going to places and having someone pay your meal or offer to take you somewhere,\u201d she continued. \u201cIt\u2019s an overwhelming experience.\u201d", "title": "They Just Want to Meet the Nice People", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Classen does style many of his clients for formal appearances, but he has made a specialty of casual off-carpet looks. When he struck out on his own as a stylist in 2015, labels tightly guarded their stores, lending clothes only for specific red carpet occasions. \u201cNow, if it\u2019s for a street style or an airport, they\u2019re going to give it to me right away,\u201d Mr. Classen said.\n\nPhoto\n\nNot that the red carpet has disappeared. It remains, ready when needed, for the Oscars, the Emmys, the Grammys, the premieres. And so remain, at the ready, the legion of red carpet stylists. But joining them are a new wave of \u201cday stylists\u201d whose forte is the casual, tossed-off, this-old-thing look of street style: what the stars would throw together on their own (but often don\u2019t have to).\n\nEven the most casual of looks \u2014 the jeans, beanie and pap-proof goggle shades the star may wear to scurry to the gate of her departing flight \u2014 may well take a village. (The highest-profile stars may have separate stylists to work on their biggest red carpet events. Ms. Gomez, for example, also works with the stylist Kate Young.)\n\n\u201cA lot of people probably think that they choose on a daily basis from their own closets,\u201d said Mimi Cuttrell, 26, a stylist who works with Gigi Hadid, Ms. Gerber and Ms. Hadid\u2019s mother, Yolanda Hadid. \u201cSometimes there are outfits that are completely planned out from head to toe. I\u2019m really particular with tailoring, too. There\u2019s a lot of pieces and back work that goes into getting one street style look ready.\u201d\n\nBig brands aren\u2019t immune to the charms of the street-style moment, and regularly send out news releases with watermarked photos from outlets like Splash News (familiar to readers of Us Weekly and In Touch) touting their designer wares in the wild: at Narita International Airport in Tokyo, at LAX, \u201cout and about in Los Angeles.\u201d (Spot the hotel doorman in the background, or the bodyguard at the ready.)\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd not by accident, important labels and noisemakers have co-opted the street as their own: Balenciaga\u2019s new ad campaign features models hiding from paparazzi photographers as they make their security-escorted way; Kanye West showed his latest Yeezy collection with a series of famous friends in faux paparazzi shots, disseminated on social media.\n\nBut the moment has been especially fruitful for up-and-coming labels, some of which have enjoyed the boost of such patronage before they were fully up and running. Alexia Elkaim, the founder and creative director of Miaou, whose high-waisted, belted-and-grommeted jeans have become a uniform for digital-age starlets, had barely gotten out of the gate when a pair of her pants found their way to Bella Hadid in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was almost like that verified my brand as a real brand, you know?\u201d Ms. Elkaim said. \u201cI probably had 45, 50 pairs of jeans at the time.\u201d Gigi Hadid, Ms. Gerber and others followed, reaching out either directly or via their stylists; and in the new gravity they have helped to shift, an order from Bergdorf Goodman followed them.\n\nThe rush that comes after a good placement \u2014 a selfie, say \u2014 was immediate. \u201cI had never seen that before,\u201d Ms. Elkaim said. \u201cAt the beginning, it was kind of like you\u2019re chasing a high.\u201d\n\nJason Stalvey\u2019s line of exotic-skin handbags and accessories, Stalvey (his gateway item is an alligator baseball cap, $5,000), was in its infancy when the Hadids got wind of him.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cGigi was basically the first person to start the madness,\u201d he said. She has been carrying a small top-handle bag ($11,500), so small as to be more or less impractical. In one photo, Mr. Stalvey spotted a phone cord dangling out of it: \u201cShe was literally using it as a phone charger.\u201d\n\nWhen Ms. Hadid began carrying the bag, it was not yet available for sale. Even so, Mr. Stalvey said, retailers began increasing their orders. Traffic on his website went \u201cup and up,\u201d he said, eventually cresting at eight times its usual amount.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not like a person can run to Barneys or the Webster or wherever and at least see it in pink and come to the website and order it in green,\u201d Mr. Stalvey said. \u201cThey were truly buying the product sight unseen. These girls really drove the wave.\u201d\n\n(In fact, they drove the wave among one another. Bella Hadid\u2019s stylist reached out to see if her client could borrow the same bag as Gigi, her older sister, was carrying. \u201cThat consumed my entire afternoon,\u201d Mr. Stalvey said \u201cAt the end of the day, I said: \u2018I can\u2019t pull it from Gigi. Why doesn\u2019t Bella go and ask her sister?\u2019 The very next day, Bella was carrying the bag.\u201d)\n\nThe point of such styling is to look effortless, natural and, in one of fashion\u2019s favorite terms, \u201cauthentic\u201d \u2014 even when that authenticity is mediated by an on-hand stylist to offer up the glossiest version of your authentic self. So much so that many of the millions of fans watching along on social media may not realize they\u2019re looking at a tailor-made ensemble.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a version of giving your friend advice on what to wear, but then there\u2019s actual results from it,\u201d said Emma Jade Morrison, 27, who in the fall left a job at Vogue magazine to begin styling Ms. Ratajkowski professionally. \u201cI find now that a really strong street style outfit can resonate more than a red carpet outfit. There\u2019s such a fashion-conscious public now. They know that the red carpet gowns are custom-made, that the jewelry is borrowed.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith street styling, she added, her goal as a stylist is to gussy up her clients without a trace, an invisible hand of the market. \u201cYou want to believe \u2014 at least I want to believe \u2014 that they own this,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s what matters. Maybe it\u2019s not, and maybe we\u2019re all aware of that, but it should look like it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Morrison stressed that whether items are borrowed, bought or gifted, her clients look like the best possible versions of themselves. She described working on Ms. Ratajkowski\u2019s street styling as: \u201cI make the buffet, and she makes her plate from it.\u201d (For red carpet and much photographed events like fashion weeks or the Cannes Film Festival, Ms. Morrison guides with a firmer hand.)\n\nFor the pieces soon to come down the pike at New York Fashion Week, and fashion weeks in London, Milan and Paris after that, their star turns may well be on the street. Mr. Classen noted that many more collections are now showing sneakers rather than heels, the choice of the street versus that of the red carpet. And without a doubt, many of these women will be on hand to see these shows, casually yet fabulously assembled (with just a little help).\n\nEven those who still may benefit from red carpet placement are in no rush to restore its former domination.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe street wear moment, I personally like it more than the red carpet,\u201d Mr. Stalvey said. \u201cDon\u2019t get me wrong, red carpet is amazing. But to see a girl using a bag because she wants to use it, she gravitates to it for her personal wear, to me just means so much more. In the wave of social media, my guess is, the customers themselves, the girls watching these girls, they respond to that, because they see it as being truer to their personal taste or more authentic than seeing something on a red carpet.\u201d\n\nThat said, some of the moment\u2019s beneficiaries sounded the occasional note of regret for the fashion\u2019s former elevated glamour, even as the new world order has democratized the system.\n\n\u201cGrowing up, I had another idea of what fashion was,\u201d Ms. Elkaim said. \u201cToday it\u2019s at the mercy of paparazzi photos. It\u2019s just different.\u201d\n\nStill, she said, \u201cIt\u2019s easier and it\u2019s more accessible, and it\u2019s incredible from a business point of view.\u201d", "title": "They Only Look Casual", "authors": ["Matthew Schneier"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "After an incompletion and a sack, New England faced third and 20 from its 16. In the huddle, Moss said, Brady kept reminding them that they had time, then told Moss what play they would run. It was the same call, Stallworth said, that resulted in Moss\u2019s go-ahead touchdown against the Giants in December.\n\n\u201cHe said we were running an over route \u2014 like three deeps and they were going to run me on the over,\u201d Moss said. \u201cSo I\u2019m on the backside by myself. Tom tells me, \u2018Randy, run the over and as soon as I look back at you, you beeline and take it back high angle to the corner.\u2019 So when Tom looks at me, I take off.\u201d\n\nBrady launched a pass that traveled almost 70 yards in the air. Moss, tracked by Webster and safety Gibril Wilson, slowed down and reached up just as Webster did. The ball caromed off both players\u2019 fingertips.\n\n\u201cI missed the ball,\u201d Moss said. \u201cI was tired, and still till this day I still sit there and wonder what could I have done different to be able to try and catch that ball. My specialty was going deep.\u201d\n\nMoss said that he had run more in that game than in any other during his career, and that it took him a few weeks to overcome the soreness.\n\nStallworth said of Brady and Moss: \u201cI figured we had two of the best players to ever play the game, and if anyone\u2019s going to do it, it\u2019s going to be those two dudes.\u201d\n\nHe said he needed about three weeks before he could bring himself to watch the highlights. It\u2019s all worth reading, but the section on self-acceptance is deeply resonant: \u201cIt\u2019s amazing how much energy and effort we all put into trying to be perceived as \u2018cool.\u2019 We deliberately curate our Instagram pictures and Facebook status updates. We\u2019re cautious about what we choose to reveal out of fear of being labeled uncool. But the effort we put into being cool, to sanding off our rough edges can be truly exhausting.\u201d\n\nGet a flu shot\n\nYes, you should still get one, even though we\u2019re deep into flu season.
