But certain measures may help.\n\nKeep Your Head Up: How Smartphone Addiction Kills Manners and Moods \u201cText neck\u201d is becoming a medical issue suffered by countless people, and the way we hang our heads has other health risks, too.\n\nNew Year\u2019s Resolutions\n\nTo kick off resolutions month in this newsletter, I\u2019ve invited Abby Langer, a registered dietitian and friend of SL, to share some tips about staying strong if your resolution this year is to eat healthier.\n\nSimplify\n\nIf you\u2019ve resolved to do a complete diet overhaul and are getting overwhelmed, simplify your plan by choosing one simple goal. For example, resolving to eat five servings of vegetables a day can be easier and more sustainable than changing your entire diet. Once your goal becomes habit, build on it from there.\n\nAcknowledge the wins\n\nWhat matters is that you\u2019re moving in the right direction. Only manage to bring your lunch to work once a week instead of four times? You\u2019re good! As long as you\u2019re making progress with your resolution, however small, consider it a win: Flexibility is not failure.\n\nEnlist help\n\nWhether it\u2019s outsourcing some of your meals to a delivery service, joining a healthy-lunch club at work, or asking for support from like-minded friends, you don\u2019t have to do this alone. There\u2019s no shame at all in finding shortcuts or asking for help.", "title": "Things You Should Think About or Accomplish This Week", "authors": ["Tim Herrera"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Suburban life outside the nation\u2019s largest cities has its pleasures, but commuting to and from work isn\u2019t one of them.\n\nRealtor.com recently looked at the 150 largest metro areas in the United States to see which had the best and worst commutes, according to four criteria: the average one-way commute time; the condition of the roads; the condition of the bridges; and the average time a commuter spent in congestion annually. (Sources included the Census Bureau and the Department of Transportation.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe overall ranking the company came up with weighed the various factors, some of which were surprising.\n\n\u201cYou think of Los Angeles, and you think of traffic and car culture,\u201d said Lance Lambert, who worked on the project for Realtor.com. \u201cYes, they spend a lot of time in congestion, but their actual average one-way commute time is shorter than in places like Atlanta and Washington.\u201d\n\nStill, Los Angeles was ranked the next-to-worst commuting city over all.\n\nAnd the worst? New York, with an average one-way commute of almost 36 minutes and an even more dreadful average of 89.4 hours spent in congestion every year by the typical New Yorker.\n\nOur chart shows the five best and worst cities on the list, with two of the reasons they earned those rankings.", "title": "Think Your Commute is Bad?", "authors": ["Michael Kolomatsky"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe didn\u2019t know it was a special thing,\u201d Mr. Izhaki, 45, said in a recent Skype interview, of the company\u2019s initial reception. \u201cWe didn\u2019t expect the fascination. Everyone was interested in it.\u201d He was joined in the conversation by Rabbi Schwartz, Mr. Azoulay and two other Ka\u2019et dancers, Eyal Ogen and Yair Barbash, all in their 30s.\n\nThe embrace of the group, by both audiences and critics, speaks to Ka\u2019et\u2019s ability to challenge the stereotypes of both art and faith. \u201cIt shakes you a bit out of your orientation, your categorizing of people,\u201d said Ruby Edelman, the chief executive and an artistic director of the Machol Shalem Dance House in Jerusalem. \u201cThey can reach people; they can open the discussion.\u201d\n\nDance and devotion have a long, rich relationship in Judaism. And dance continues to be used by some groups, including the Hasidim, as a form of ecstatic spiritual expression. For the members of Ka\u2019et, all of whom identify as dati leumi, or religious Zionists (akin to modern Orthodox in America), dance also offered a way into prayer. As Rabbi Schwartz said, \u201cI can\u2019t fully express myself spiritually without connecting to my body.\u201d But putting that body on a theatrical stage, in front of an audience, was a bold and unusual move.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe ensemble\u2019s path began in 2000, when Mr. Izhaki, who is secular and lives in Tel Aviv, the center of Israel\u2019s dance scene, was asked to teach an experimental dance workshop for Orthodox men in Acre as a way to integrate physicality into prayer. There, he was inspired watching the men pray during breaks. \u201cIt was the most delicate movement I\u2019ve seen in my life,\u201d he said.\n\nThe workshop was brief, but its influence lingered. A few years later, Mr. Ogen, one of the students, asked Mr. Izhaki for private lessons. \u201cWhen I started I was hiding it from my father and family,\u201d he said. \u201cI was ashamed of what I was doing.\u201d Some in Orthodox Judaism consider anything aside from textual study to be a distraction; others look at the public performance of dance suspiciously because of its inherent sensuality, which they feel contradicts the closely held tenet of modesty.\n\nBut Mr. Ogen continued and more students soon joined, including Rabbi Schwartz, who said he was \u201cthirsty to learn the wisdom of the body\u201d \u2014 wisdom he now imparts to his students at the yeshiva where he teaches both Torah studies and movement classes. By 2007, they had a small school. Eventually they developed what the company members call \u201ca new Jewish contemporary dance.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat new style, and Ka\u2019et\u2019s focus on exploring the tension between orthodoxy and pluralism, has resonated outside of Israel as well. \u201cHeroes\u201d was commissioned by JW3, a Jewish communal and cultural center in London, and made its debut there in 2016. That fall, Megan Whitman, director of the Lambert Center for Art + Ideas at the Manhattan JCC, saw an excerpt from the work in Israel. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t just that it was novel,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was that it was profound, how these disconnected elements of society could be brought together in such a beautiful way.\u201d\n\nShe also saw parallels back home. Referring to how local audiences from Crown Heights, Brooklyn, to Manhattan\u2019s Upper West Side might identify with Ka\u2019et, she said, \u201cWe\u2019ll see reflections of that same divide.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Ka\u2019et, \u201cHeroes\u201d represents an artistic evolution. Compared with earlier works, Mr. Edelman said, \u201cthe layers of this piece are much more sophisticated.\u201d Its sources include the pioneering Jewish dancer Baruch Agadati, the influential German choreographer Pina Bausch and the biblical story of Jacob and Esau. The work is \u201crelevant to what\u2019s happening in contemporary dance culture,\u201d Mr. Edelman said. \u201cIt\u2019s not isolated, it\u2019s not their own island.\u201d\n\nThat evolution also reflects a new willingness among the dancers to probe their faith\u2019s traditions and assumptions. \u201cAt the beginning, we had to do something religious,\u201d Rabbi Schwartz said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t have the courage to play with it. We have the courage now and the freedom to search new things.\u201d\n\nMore than a decade after beginning secret lessons with Mr. Izhaki, Mr. Ogen now manages the Ka\u2019et school where 45 students train three days a week in ballet, modern dance and Gaga, a popular movement language developed by the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin. (All students and teachers are male.)\n\nEnthusiasm for contemporary dance has been growing among religious Jews, Mr. Edelman said, including women. \u201cThe body is part of the soul,\u201d he explained, \u201cand it\u2019s supporting their belief.\u201d When people realize they can combine the two, \u201cThey\u2019re hungry for this.\u201d Machol Shalem is currently hosting a three-month program for religious dance teachers.\n\nDespite the meaningful support and growing acceptance, Mr. Ogen said, \u201cthere are places I go where I think twice about whether I say I\u2019m a dancer.\u201d And other Ka\u2019et members said they still faced skepticism from many in their community. But increasingly, they are met with curiosity and even a bit of envy. When Rabbi Schwartz recently attended a yeshiva reunion, he mentioned that he was a dancer. The guy next to him said, \u201cMy life isn\u2019t as interesting.\u201d", "title": "Thirsty for Wisdom of the Body, Finding It in Dance", "authors": ["Brian Schaefer"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "The sculptor and philanthropist Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney occasionally posed for portraits in unconventional clothing. Around 1911, her artist friend Howard Gardiner Cushing painted her wearing an androgynous ballet costume, with pink pants and a sharply flared jacket. He hung the canvas at her studio in Old Westbury, N.Y., as part of a stairwell mural that measures 125 feet long and also depicts hallucinogenic plants, Persian harems and Mughal palace rooms.\n\nIn the last year, Mr. Cushing\u2019s descendants have spent a few million dollars acquiring the flamboyant artwork and having it removed and restored for public display. Scholars had known little about the mural, which includes images of Whitney, the founder of the museum that bears her name; Mr. Cushing\u2019s wife, Ethel; and assorted courtesans, musicians and slaves. Mr. Cushing based the clothing and scenery on Ballets Russes costumes, Japanese prints and Whistler\u2019s paintings, among other sources, and the background vegetation includes poppies, oleander and nightshade.\n\nAlexandra Cushing Howard, an architectural historian who is a granddaughter of Mr. Cushing, spearheaded the mural removal project and is now contacting museums about possible exhibitions. The canvas series, which is currently in storage, has been turned into 18 framed panels. The imagery, she said, \u201cis so sophisticated and subversive but it\u2019s so joyful as well.\u201d\n\nThe studio in Old Westbury was left empty and neglected for decades after Whitney\u2019s death in 1942. A year ago, staff members from the Julius Lowy Frame and Restoring Company in New York began painstakingly lifting the Cushing paintings off the walls and rolling them for transport. Lauren Rich, Lowy\u2019s senior paintings conservator, said that given the flaking paint in some areas, \u201cwhat we were dealing with was hanging by a thread.\u201d", "title": "This Century-Old Mural Was Rescued From a Whitney\u2019s Stairwell", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Brady did nothing to diminish his standing over 60 minutes of football. Trailing by 22-12 at halftime, he led the Patriots on three straight touchdown drives. He pinpointed his receivers like a sharpshooter at a carnival arcade, beating back the Eagles\u2019 celebrations each time they seemed to have put the Pats away.\n\nThere was little doubt during much of the game that Brady was the best player on the field. That\u2019s no knock on Foles, who finished with 373 passing yards and three touchdowns (plus a fourth he caught himself) and who, most important of all, brought Philadelphia its first Super Bowl championship.\n\nFoles all but levitated with joy afterward. He showed up for postgame interviews with his shoulder pads still on and an aw-shucks smile on his face. Heck yeah, he had been nervous.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never been here before,\u201d he said. \u201cSo there are normal nerves \u2014 you\u2019ve got butterflies. It\u2019s a big game. It doesn\u2019t get any bigger than this. But I felt good, felt calm. I think the big thing that helped me was knowing I didn\u2019t have to be Superman.\u201d\n\nBut Foles, 29, was Superman \u2014 at least for one day. He knew it, too, and tried to explain how it felt. \u201cTime does stop,\u201d he said.\n\nDon\u2019t tell Brady that.\n\nBrady had prompted the postgame questions about his return by making no secret that he intended to play the game for a long time.", "title": "This Is Not Tom Brady\u2019s Epilogue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe were scared in the beginning,\u201d Francesca Bettrone, a long-track speedskater from Italy, said. \u201cI still don\u2019t know what they say.\u201d\n\nThere have been at least 14 emergency alerts sent to cellphones over the past week, and those around the Olympic Park here received eight separate, bleating alerts on Wednesday alone.\n\nAfter the fifth or sixth alert on Wednesday (it was easy to lose count), a couple of strangers waiting in line for food at the speedskating arena began trading tips on how to alter the settings on their iPhones to block the emergency notifications.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey could have simply followed the lead of Marten Liiv, a speedskater from Jogeva, Estonia, who never purchased an international data plan for his phone.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve heard all about them, but I don\u2019t get them,\u201d Liiv said with a shrug. \u201cI\u2019m lucky, maybe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn email to the Pyeongchang Olympics Organizing Committee seeking a response to whether they had planned for the stir the alerts have caused was not immediately answered.\n\nIt hasn\u2019t helped that phone alerts, and the prospective scary message they could be carrying, had been on people\u2019s minds after a mistaken text alert last month in Hawaii about an inbound ballistic missile.\n\nWith nuclear tension related to North Korea still running high on the peninsula, some athletes said the emergency notifications had sent their imaginations into overdrive.\n\n\u201cIt was a little bit like, \u2018What is this?\u2019\u201d Thomas Ulsrud, a Norwegian curler, said about an alert he received this week in the athletes\u2019 village. \u201cWe\u2019re in the same building as the North Koreans, so it was like, \u2018What is going on here now?\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe emergency alerts sent on Wednesday warned of extreme winds in the area and the possibility of forest fires.\n\nThose arriving early for the Olympics received alerts about the cold and the smoke from an isolated fire in Gangneung, where several events are held.\n\nSome athletes remained calm at first about the jarring alerts \u2014 until they started interrupting their sleep.\n\n\u201cIt woke me up, and I didn\u2019t know what it was, so my phone got thrown across the floor,\u201d said Peter Michael, 28, a speedskater from Wellington, New Zealand. Michael said he waited to hear if there was a fire alarm or something else to indicate what was going on. Moments later, he went back to sleep. \u201cI figure if it\u2019s something really bad, someone can come get me,\u201d he said.\n\nJust past 5 a.m. on Sunday, phones blared simultaneously around the athletes\u2019 accommodations as people were informed about an earthquake that had occurred about 100 miles from Pyeongchang.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was sleeping, and I thought, \u2018Why is this keeping me awake?\u2019\u201d Bart Swings, a Belgian speedskater, said with a mock sigh. \u201cFirst, I can\u2019t read it. Second, my phone was on silent. But apparently that doesn\u2019t matter.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe alarms have useful information,\u201d Swings added, \u201cbut maybe they should put it also in English during the Olympics.\u201d\n\nNow somewhat desensitized to the alerts, athletes have resorted to simply hoping that someone will tell them if there is an emergency.\n\nNina Roth, a curler from McFarland, Wis., said the United States team\u2019s security official had been handling inquiries about the alerts from concerned, or simply curious, athletes.\n\n\u201cShe assured us that if it was anything that was an actual issue, she\u2019d let us know,\u201d Roth said.\n\nSpectators at a competition last weekend puzzled over the texts.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all in Korean \u2014 as, you know, it should be,\u201d Julie Morreali, visiting from Sycamore, Ill., said with a laugh. \u201cWe got one in the middle of the night, and we didn\u2019t know what it was. You hope for the best. I mean, what are we going to do? We can\u2019t talk to anyone.\u201d\n\nHer friend Jen Mendigutia of San Diego nodded in agreement. \u201cI should have learned more Korean before I got here,\u201d she said.", "title": "This Is Not a Drill: Another \u2018Emergency\u2019 Alert Is On Its Way", "authors": ["Andrew Keh"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "A less than two-hour class, taught about six times a year. Conference calls taken poolside, or from the car. A handful of posts each week on the company social media account, sharing colorful cartoons or titles of children\u2019s books related to energy conservation.\n\nThese were some of the duties that earned Lisa Toscano-Percoco, the wife of a former top state official, $90,000 a year while she was employed by a Maryland-based energy company, Competitive Power Ventures, in what federal prosecutors characterized as a \u201clow-show job.\u201d Prosecutors say the job was provided by one of the company\u2019s former executives as a bribe to Ms. Toscano-Percoco\u2019s husband, Joseph Percoco.\n\nMr. Percoco, once Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo\u2019s executive deputy secretary, is on trial along with the executive, Peter Galbraith Kelly, and two Syracuse-area developers. He is accused of trading his clout as the governor\u2019s confidant and enforcer for more than $300,000 in bribes, including his wife\u2019s salary; in return, prosecutors say he worked to help C.P.V. land a state contract. Ms. Toscano-Percoco has not been charged with any wrongdoing.\n\nThe focus on Ms. Toscano-Percoco\u2019s job over the last few days has been a departure from the rest of the trial, which is in its fifth week in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Up to this point, much of the testimony has focused on almost stereotypically unsavory political maneuverings. There have been mocking emails and profanity-laced phone calls, luxury fishing trips and allusions to \u201cThe Sopranos.\u201d", "title": "This Is What a $90,000 \u2018Low-Show Job\u2019 Looks Like in Albany", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "When asked about the scandal on the red carpet at the October premiere for her Broadway play, \u201cThe Parisian Woman,\u201d an intrigue about a glamorous woman in President Trump\u2019s Washington written by \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d creator Beau Willimon, she looked steely and said she was waiting to feel less angry before she talked about it.\n\n\u201cI used the word \u2018anger\u2019 but I was more worried about crying, to tell you the truth,\u201d she says now. \u201cI was not a groundbreaker on a story I knew to be true. So what you really saw was a person buying time.\u201d\n\nBy Thanksgiving, Thurman had begun to unsheathe her Hattori Hanzo, Instagramming a screen shot of her \u201croaring rampage of revenge\u201d monologue and wishing everyone a happy holiday, \u201c(Except you Harvey, and all your wicked conspirators \u2014 I\u2019m glad it\u2019s going slowly \u2014 you don\u2019t deserve a bullet) \u2014 stay tuned.\u201d\n\nStretching out her lanky frame on a brown velvet couch in front of the fire, Thurman tells her story, with occasional interruptions from her 5-year-old daughter with her ex, financier Arpad Busson. Luna is in her pj\u2019s, munching on a raw cucumber. Her two older kids with Ethan Hawke, Maya, an actress, and Levon, a high school student, also drop by.\n\nIn interviews over the years, Thurman has offered a Zen outlook \u2014 even when talking about her painful breakup from Hawke. (She had a brief first marriage to Gary Oldman.) Her hall features a large golden Buddha from her parents in Woodstock; her father, Robert Thurman, is a Buddhist professor of Indo-Tibetan studies at Columbia who thinks Uma is a reincarnated goddess.\n\nBut beneath that reserve and golden aura, she has learned to be a street fighter.\n\nShe says when she was 16, living in a studio apartment in Manhattan and starting her movie career, she went to a club one winter night and met an actor, nearly 20 years older, who coerced her afterward when they went to his Greenwich Village brownstone for a nightcap.\n\n\u201cI was ultimately compliant,\u201d she remembers. \u201cI tried to say no, I cried, I did everything I could do. He told me the door was locked but I never ran over and tried the knob. When I got home, I remember I stood in front of the mirror and I looked at my hands and I was so mad at them for not being bloody or bruised. Something like that tunes the dial one way or another, right? You become more compliant or less compliant, and I think I became less compliant.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | This Is Why Uma Thurman Is Angry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "In November 2010, I took a bus from my home in Philadelphia to the National Mall in Washington. The night before the trip, I stood in my kitchen and wrote in large letters on cardboard: \u201cThe People\u2019s Work Starts Now!\u201d\n\nWhen the bus reached the mall and we stepped out into the bitter wind, I looked at the monuments and realized that I was not there as a tourist this time, but as an activist \u2014 an idea I would have been allergic to just a year before.\n\nBut I, like millions of others, was becoming the new American radical, defined by my belief in a limited government that allows people, not bureaucracy, to flourish.\n\nBefore all of this, my main contributions to American politics were voting, voraciously reading American history and Austrian economic theory and irritating liberals at dinner parties.", "title": "Opinion | This Isn\u2019t What the Tea Party Fought For", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Soon the hobbyist was giving away the crayfish to his friends. And not long afterward, so-called marmorkrebs were showing up in pet stores in Germany and beyond.\n\nAs marmorkrebs became more popular, owners grew increasingly puzzled. The crayfish seemed to be laying eggs without mating. The progeny were all female, and each one grew up ready to reproduce.\n\nIn 2003, scientists confirmed that the marbled crayfish were indeed making clones of themselves. They sequenced small bits of DNA from the animals, which bore a striking similarity to a group of crayfish species called Procambarus, native to North America and Central America.\n\nTen years later, Dr. Lyko and his colleagues set out to determine the entire genome of the marbled crayfish. By then, it was no longer just an aquarium oddity.\n\nFor nearly two decades, marbled crayfish have been multiplying like Tribbles on the legendary \u201cStar Trek\u201d episode. \u201cPeople would start out with a single animal, and a year later they would have a couple hundred,\u201d said Dr. Lyko.\n\nMany owners apparently drove to nearby lakes and dumped their marmorkrebs. And it turned out that the marbled crayfish didn\u2019t need to be pampered to thrive. Marmorkrebs established growing populations in the wild, sometimes walking hundreds of yards to reach new lakes and streams. Feral populations started turning up in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Croatia and Ukraine in Europe, and later in Japan and Madagascar.\n\nSequencing the genome of this animal was not easy: No one had sequenced the genome of a crayfish. In fact, no one had ever sequenced any close relative of crayfish.", "title": "This Mutant Crayfish Clones Itself, and It\u2019s Taking Over Europe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "How hard could it be to replace a 90-year-old toilet? It seemed like something a plumber could handle, maybe even the one standing in my bathroom in 2013, telling me that a crack in my tank meant mine was toast.\n\nNo problem, I thought, I\u2019ll just swap it out.\n\nAnd this is when I learned rule number one for owners of old houses: Never utter the phrase \u201cjust swap it out.\u201d\n\nI will not belabor the details of early 20th-century plumbing, but trust me when I say that if I had simply replaced my commode, a new model would have been perched roughly half a foot from the wall. To get to the shower, I would have had to climb over the new fixture.\n\nThe solution? Rip up the original tile floor and move the plumbing. Other problems would have followed: The mint-colored wall tiles would have likely been damaged and needed replacement, too. I might have had to open the kitchen ceiling to access the pipes above. In other words, to replace the toilet, I would have had to gut my vintage 1924 bathroom to the tune of $25,000.", "title": "This Old House Is a Chore", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "How is skiing on man-made snow different?\n\nIt\u2019s a little faster. So the same World Cup courses that we race get more and more dangerous with man-made snow because it gets icy. One of my teammates broke his leg on a corner on a course where it never should have been as fast as it was. Real snow, it feels softer. It\u2019s not as hard when you fall.\n\nWhat about people who say that fighting climate change is going to hurt the economy?\n\nYou can look at different solutions for the economy, but you only get one earth to live on, and you have to breathe the air that is on this earth. We have to do it in a way that doesn\u2019t hurt families economically, which is why I\u2019m supporting the carbon fee and dividend solution, because it puts a fee on carbon and returns the revenue to households.\n\nWhat do you say to those who say, \u2018You\u2019re just an athlete, stay in your lane\u2019?\n\nI\u2019m also someone who lives on this planet. I think you need to be able to stand up for things you believe in, and saving winter is something I believe in. It just breaks my heart because this is such a cool sport, and winter is so amazing and beautiful and I feel like we\u2019re actually really at risk of losing it. Thus you have some Scotch makers using old sherry or bourbon casks. In Brooklyn, Allen Katz\u2019s New York Distilling Company has started giving some of his Ragtime Rye, a whiskey he introduced last fall, a sojourn in barrels that held applejack. His inspiration was George Washington, a distiller of rye who also had a penchant for applejack. The new 100-proof whiskey \u2014 for sipping neat or on ice \u2014 has a honeyed, spicy aroma and a warm flavor with hints of leather, baked bread and cinnamon: Applejack Barrel Finished Ragtime Rye Whiskey, $42 at Bottlerocket Wine & Spirit, 5 West 19th Street (Fifth Avenue), 212-929-2323, bottlerocket.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. But arming overworked and undersupplied teachers is the act of a fool. You simply refuse to recognize the problem is the guns. Is that because you\u2019re afraid of the monstrous N.R.A. and disarming your big game-hunting sons?\u201d\n\nWith beady blue eyes, the snake watched his victim gasp for air. He ignored the note from Hope to \u201cPretend you care.\u201d\n\n\u201cOh, dying woman, you really don\u2019t get it,\u201d he said. \u201cThe N.R.A. poured millions behind me early \u2014 earlier than any other candidate in history \u2014 and I never will forget it.\u201d\n\nHer muscles clenching, her organs failing, the woman found herself wailing. \u201cIt is just like when you promised a \u2018bill of love\u2019 to save the Dreamers. And from what I\u2019ve seen, love doesn\u2019t often work that way. Having too many choices is in itself inefficient and fantasy inducing.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn my view, love is best found not in a haystack but in a pea pod. Here are your five peas. Or maybe nine peas. The anthropologist Helen Fisher claims that a human brain can reasonably consider only nine or 10 choices; beyond that, they turn to noise. So if you were to limit yourself to nine people and get to know them, give each a chance, you\u2019d probably fall in love with one.\n\nEven so, I\u2019m not one of those people who moan about how dating apps make things worse. It\u2019s just different, much the way online shopping differs from brick-and-mortar.\n\nWhen shopping online, you buy more stuff because it\u2019s so easy. Then you probably fantasize a little more about your new shoes or flying drone as you await their arrival, which means you\u2019re going to be disappointed more often because the shoes don\u2019t fit or the drone is poorly made. So you return them and start over \u2014 same as with the average online date. In the store, meanwhile, all of that trying on and rejecting would have happened in real time, much like getting to know and rejecting people at the bar or a party happens in real time, leaving you little time to fantasize.\n\nWhat\u2019s particularly misleading about online dating is how everyone on the site is trying to seduce you. They\u2019re trying to seduce everyone. They\u2019re all saying, \u201cDate me!\u201d\n\nWhen you walk into a bar, does everyone rush up to you with a big smile and a glowing r\u00e9sum\u00e9? No. Everyone ignores you. But online, a little piece of you believes. Because you\u2019re being pitched, you allow yourself to believe in these people\u2019s vulnerability and desire. Which is why meeting people online tends to heighten our fantasies and deepen our disappointment.\n\nOur smartphones now include photos, chat transcripts, contacts and more. Is it good for relationships to have so much of our lives public?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat I\u2019ve noticed about young people who\u2019ve grown up with social media is the degree to which they bring a sense of audience to nearly everything they do. They see their own life as a performance, one that is constantly \u201creviewed\u201d by friends, family, aunts, cousins, strangers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut what\u2019s refreshing to me is how goofy a lot of it is. It\u2019s curated but not always to show perfection; in fact, imperfection seems to be the goal, something to laugh at, an ugly or embarrassing moment or expression or bad experience. They splash it all out there as a way of saying, \u201cThis is me.\u201d I think a lot of us who didn\u2019t grow up with that are horrified about having unflattering pictures of ourselves out there or embarrassing stories. We see that kind of online vulnerability as risky, and they often don\u2019t \u2014 they celebrate it.\n\nHow has tech affected your job editing Modern Love?\n\nTech \u2014 which for me mostly consists of my laptop and phone \u2014 has made me both happier and more stressed out, more engaged with the world and more isolated from my immediate surroundings, more in touch with my friends and family while I see them less and less. In my job, tech allows me incredible freedom \u2014 to do my work at The Times or from the beach, and whether I\u2019m feeling good or am sick in bed. I\u2019m writing this now on a train from New York City to Massachusetts on a brisk, beautiful Saturday in February. It\u2019s glorious, and at the same time my work and personal life have almost no boundary.\n\nWhat tech are you obsessed with in your personal life?\n\nI could not navigate the world without Google Maps, and I could not fully appreciate the world without Google Earth. I still don\u2019t get how either works. They are miraculous.\n\nRecently there has been a lot of talk about smartphone addiction. What\u2019s your advice for couples who struggle to put down their phones and want to remain present with each other?\n\nI\u2019m a bad person to ask about that because I\u2019m on my phone all the time, too. I\u2019m just glad these things didn\u2019t exist when I had small children, because I know I\u2019d be like those parents you see at the playground, staring at their phones as their children try to get their attention.\n\nMy immediate family is scattered \u2014 kids in college, my wife and I frequently in different cities \u2014 and these days that texting connection outweighs the negative of being on our phones when we\u2019re together. But just barely. With phone addiction, it\u2019s all about willpower. These days I\u2019m without my phone only in the shower.\n\nSo I guess my parting advice to couples who want to remain present with each other: Spend more time together in the shower.", "title": "This Valentine\u2019s Day, Considering Tech That Keeps Couples Together", "authors": ["The New York Times", "Tech We Re Using"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts \u2014 it\u2019s a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Feb. 25, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:\n\nArt: Klimt, Schiele in Boston\n\nThrough May 28; mfa.org.\n\nTwo of the many untimely deaths of 1918 were those of the Austrian artists Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele. Klimt, who died of a stroke, was middle-aged and successful, while Schiele, felled at 28 by the influenza pandemic, along with his pregnant wife, was on the threshold of a brilliant career.\n\nKlimt made drawings chiefly as studies for painting, marking out elegant shapes with a sinuously confident but simple line, while Schiele drew with the intensity of a diamond-cutter. Both men elongated the figure, but in Klimt\u2019s case, this resulted in a kind of elfin romanticism, while Schiele\u2019s knobbly portraits can look like prefigurations of heroin chic.\n\nThe two were friends and mutual admirers, though, and for the centenary of their deaths, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has put together a gorgeous little show with five dozen drawings borrowed from Vienna\u2019s Albertina Museum. WILL HEINRICH", "title": "This Week: Klimt\u2019s Drawings, \u2018UnReal,\u2019 Reuniting Grateful Dead Alumni", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Gen. Paul J. Selva, the vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters last week that the remaining Islamic State leadership, even while on the run, still had \u201cfairly robust\u201d communications with its shadowy network of fighters now on the lam.\n\nWhile President Trump highlighted the liberation of almost all of the Islamic State\u2019s territory in Iraq and Syria in his State of the Union address last week, American military and intelligence officials say the group is still able to inspire and enable followers to carry out attacks. Mr. Trump seemed to acknowledged this in his speech, noting, \u201cThere is much more work to be done.\u201d\n\nAnalysts say they are also seeing signs that Islamic State fighters are adopting guerrilla tactics to terrorize civilians.\n\n\u201cThe group is transitioning into an underground organization that places more weight on asymmetric tactics, like suicide bombings against soft targets in government-secured areas like Baghdad,\u201d said Otso Iho, a senior analyst at Jane\u2019s Terrorism and Insurgency Center at IHS Markit in London.\n\nMr. Iho cited an attack by two suicide bombers in Baghdad last month that killed three dozen people and injured 90 more. The attack took place in a busy Baghdad square where day laborers gather to look for work.\n\nEstimates of how many fighters may have escaped into the deserts of Syria or Iraq and beyond are difficult to pin down, but American and other Western intelligence and counterterrorism analysts with access to classified assessments put the number in the low thousands. Many are traveling with spouses and children who are likely to have been radicalized during more than three years of Islamic State control of the region and could pose security risks as well, analysts say.\n\nIn December, Col. Ryan Dillon, the chief spokesman for the American-led military campaign in Iraq and Syria, said in a briefing with Pentagon reporters: \u201cSyrian regime commanders in eastern Syria suggest that ISIS fighters\u201d from the Middle Euphrates River Valley \u201cmay have slipped through porous Syrian and Russian defenses to arrive in areas near Damascus.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked late last month by The New York Times about indications that as many as 1,000 fighters and family members had fled the Euphrates River area just in recent days, Colonel Dillon\u2019s command replied in a statement: \u201cWe know that the Syrian regime has given ISIS the leeway to travel through their area of operations, but we cannot confirm any alleged incidents or operations that are taking place outside our area of operations.\u201d\n\nThe United States military is concerned that a Turkish offensive against the Kurdish-dominated Syrian Democratic Forces in Afrin, in northern Syria, has worsened the problem. The S.D.F. has been working with the Americans in former Islamic State-held areas to interdict fleeing jihadists, but those efforts have been greatly reduced as the Kurds have shifted resources to reinforce Afrin.\n\nMustafa Balli, a spokesman for the Syrian Democratic Forces headquarters, blamed the Turkish assault on Afrin for what he said was the Islamic State\u2019s resurgence.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cSince this invasion of Afrin by Turkey, ISIS is getting stronger in the south,\u201d he said. \u201cThe battle against ISIS in the south, and the Turks in Afrin, is the same battle. The Turks want to give another chance to ISIS to grow again. Before the Turkish invasion, we were very close to finishing ISIS.\u201d\n\nSome 40,000 fighters from more than 120 countries poured into the battles in Syria and Iraq over the past four years, American and other Western officials say. While thousands died on the battlefield, officials say many thousands more probably survived to slip away to conflicts in Libya, Yemen or the Philippines, or have gone into hiding in countries like Turkey. About 295 Americans are believed to have traveled to Iraq or Syria, or tried to, American officials said.\n\nOf more than 5,000 Europeans who joined those ranks, as many as 1,500 have returned home, including many women and children, and most of the rest are dead or still fighting, according to Gilles de Kerchove, the European Union\u2019s top counterterrorism official.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe thought that these foreign fighters who have participated in this fight now for over two years will quietly leave Syria and return to their jobs as shopkeepers in Paris, in Brussels, in Copenhagen, is ludicrous,\u201d said General Selva, the vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs. \u201cThat\u2019s a very compelling problem.\u201d\n\nStill, the number of Islamic State fighters returning home to Europe and North Africa has been much smaller than anticipated, counterterrorism officials say. That is in part because the Trump administration intensified its focus on preventing fighters from seeping out of Raqqa and Mosul, their former stronghold in Iraq, and more militants fought to the death than expected. Hundreds also surrendered in Raqqa.\n\nHundreds of others have been captured and are being held by American-backed Kurdish militias in northern Syria, raising fears among United States military officials of potentially creating a breeding ground for extremists \u2014 repeating a key security mistake of the Iraq war.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the new assessments, bolstered by reports from analysts and smugglers in the region, suggest that Islamic State fighters are fleeing to more hospitable parts of Syria and Iraq, or to third countries where they can lie low.\n\nBeyond the recent suicide bombings in Baghdad, a major American airstrike last month demonstrates the Islamic State\u2019s continued resiliency and threat, military officials said.\n\nArmed Reaper drones and Navy F/A-18 fighters from the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt carried out a strike on Jan. 20 in Al Shafah, Syria, in the Euphrates River Valley, that killed about 150 fighters, the American military said. The strike, one of the largest single aerial assaults against the Islamic State in three years, was based on intelligence collected over about a week. The strike hit two large buildings that were used as a command headquarters and a media distribution center, military officials said.\n\nThe size and concentration of fighters took American officials by surprise. \u201cThe ISIS headquarters contained a heavy concentration of ISIS fighters who appear to have been massing for movement,\u201d Maj. Gen. James B. Jarrard, commanding general for Special Operations forces in Iraq and Syria, said in a statement.\n\n\u201cISIS continues to demonstrate the ability to mass large numbers in its attempt to retain a stronghold in Syria,\u201d the American-led command in Iraq said in the same statement.\n\nAhmad Ramadan, the head of the Euphrates Center Against Violence and Terrorism in Istanbul, said that the Islamic State was still present in many villages east of the Euphrates River \u2014 the informal demarcation line between Russian-backed Syrian troops to the west and American-backed Syrian militias to the east. \u201cISIS nowadays are spreading all over Syria,\u201d he said via Facebook chat.\n\nGovernment and independent analysts in Syria and in Washington, including the Institute for the Study of War, said there was a thriving trade in smuggling Islamic State fighters across the border into Turkey, where intelligence officials believe they are linking with clandestine cells.\n\nAccording to the independent British-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, senior Islamic State operatives from Raqqa and Deir al-Zour, in the Euphrates River Valley, have paid bribes of $20,000 to $30,000 for safe passage into Turkey.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI smuggled about 50 ISIS fighters into Turkey,\u201d said Abu Omar, a smuggler between Syria and Turkey, adding that they were a mix of Syrian and foreign fighters, often disguised in women\u2019s clothes to help elude Turkish border patrols.\n\nAbu Omar added that the number of fleeing Islamic State fighters and senior leaders, including many foreigners, increased over the summer when the American-backed offensive against Raqqa began.\n\n\u201cI was really shocked when I saw them,\u201d he said in a WhatsApp message. \u201cThey were wearing cool clothes, classic jeans with many necklaces, trying to disguise as much as they can. They hid their passports in their boots. They were completely shaved; you never guess they are ISIS. They didn\u2019t speak any Arabic, few words.\u201d", "title": "Thousands of ISIS Fighters Flee in Syria, Many to Fight Another Day", "authors": ["Eric Schmitt"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Paper Valentines spanning three centuries of optimism about romance have been delivered to the Huntington Library, Art Collections and Botanical Gardens in San Marino, Calif. The collection of about 12,000 cards was assembled over four decades by Nancy Rosin, a historian and collector in Franklin Lakes, N.J., whose family has donated it to the museum.\n\nMrs. Rosin spent up to thousands of dollars each for the Valentines, which were produced as early as the 1680s. Their motifs, aside from the expected hearts and Cupids, can seem unsentimental. Images of battlefield tents represented spaces where soldiers could carve out time to write to their sweethearts, and depictions of caged mice may symbolize a desire to keep beloveds captive.\n\n\u201cLove was expressed in so many ways,\u201d said Mrs. Rosin, who also helps catalog valentines at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.", "title": "Three Centuries of Valentines Offer 12,000 Ways to Say \u2018I Love You\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "From afar, the sugary frills and flounces of Cecilie Bahnsen\u2019s clothes may seem girlish and saccharine, but upon closer inspection there\u2019s a distinct Scandinavian minimalism to her designs: Sharp-edged silhouettes and voluminous skirts give her pieces a sense of modernity. Her world is filled with crisp white organza smocks, baby-doll dresses and slouchy Welsh knitwear worn over quilted silk skirts. These are informed by her perennial inspirations \u2014 school uniforms, old-school dresses, midcentury couture \u2014 as well as more esoteric nods to contemporary art.\n\nBahnsen has shown her collections in Copenhagen\u2019s Galleri Nicolai space for the last two seasons, and has let them mirror the themes of the shows that hang on the walls at the time of the show. This time, it was one of Dan Graham\u2019s glass sculptures, which Bahnsen interpreted as being \u201cabout humans and layers.\u201d Despite studying at the Royal College of Art in London and working as a design assistant at Erdem, Bahnsen returned to her hometown Copenhagen last year to set up a studio. Today, she draws on the city\u2019s popular look of T-shirts over skirts and dresses, preferring to dress her clothes down with casual pieces.\n\nBahnsen\u2019s much-loved label has already been a finalist for the LVMH Prize, and in the last year alone her stockists have jumped to 22 retailers around the world. (Dover Street Market was one of the first; Ssense, Selfridges and Lane Crawford swiftly followed.) It\u2019s little surprise, then, that her show has become one of the most anticipated at Copenhagen Fashion Week. A big year awaits her now, especially as she just launched a debut prefall collection \u2014 and she\u2019ll introduce footwear, bags and jewelry further down the line. She\u2019s also hoping to join the London Fashion Week schedule in September. \u201cWhat I\u2019d like is for what we show on the catwalk to be what you can get in the stores,\u201d she says.", "title": "Three Independent Danish Brands to Know", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Together, Alice and Ezra watch baseball games on TV, eat appetizers purchased at Upper West Side delicatessens, hone inside jokes, attend concerts, read side by side and have sex. In many ways, Ezra, who has everything he could want besides a Nobel Prize, is Alice\u2019s tutor \u2014 instructing her on whom to read (Primo Levi, Hannah Arendt), how to think (unsentimentally) and where to buy a proper winter coat (Searle on Madison Avenue). But Alice is early in her career and herself talented, which gives her an underrated sort of power, the prospective and untested kind. It might not have a name, but any young woman who has it or has seen it harnessed knows it\u2019s real.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen Ezra suggests that their relationship might be \u201ca little bit heartbreaking,\u201d Alice refutes it. \u201cI don\u2019t think so,\u201d she says. \u201cMaybe around the edges.\u201d The peripheral sadness is mostly a result of Ezra\u2019s physical frailty (aqua fitness, a quintuple-bypass scar, 27 pill bottles in the bathroom), which is relentlessly remarked upon, both by Alice and by Ezra himself, though almost always leavened with sly deadpan exposition: \u201cShe gave him a cord for his reading glasses. He gave her another thousand dollars to spend at Searle.\u201d\n\nAn otherwise traditional narrative of their romance is interrupted every few pages by modernist intrusions of text. A passage from \u201cTropic of Cancer,\u201d one of the books that Ezra has bought for Alice, is presented, italicized and unsourced. So is part of a news article about the invasion of Iraq, and the phrase \u201cCALLER ID BLOCKED,\u201d and abortion clinic literature. In a novel that is ultimately about writing itself, it\u2019s a clever device that allows for a realistic depiction of what it means to be a person who considers reading an emotionally instructive and intellectually legitimate form of lived experience.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first-person second section \u2014 \u201cMadness\u201d \u2014 belongs to Amar Jaafari, a funny and morally serious Iraqi-American economist who is being detained at Heathrow in 2008. \u201cMadness\u201d switches between a present-tense account of \u201cMr. Jaafari\u2019s\u201d interrogation, and \u201cAmar\u2019s\u201d memories of his childhood spent first in Baghdad \u2014 \u201ca place in which you could not forget about politics for one minute, never mind the time it takes to eat a meal or read a poem or make love\u201d \u2014 and then in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.\n\nThough Amar\u2019s problems are larger and more historic in scale than the ones that afflict Alice or Ezra (he is racially profiled; members of his family get killed), Halliday grants him apolitical, intricately private thoughts. Both his memories and his moment-by-moment experience of British immigration officials\u2019 tedious, unjust bureaucracy are refracted through what Amar himself calls \u201cthe incessant kaleidoscope within.\u201d He recalls first seeing the woman who would become his girlfriend and thinking she was \u201cbeautiful in the way some girls are beautiful despite having bypassed pretty entirely,\u201d and instead of finding London \u201cfabulous and enviable,\u201d Amar feels there \u201cthe way you do when you take one step too many at the bottom of a flight of stairs: brought up short by the unexpected plateau and its dull, unyielding thud.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTrapped at the airport, Amar lets his consciousness wander. He tries to reconstruct periods of his life of which he has no memory \u2014 \u201cContemplating the blackouts in their aggregate makes my breath come short\u201d \u2014 and pursues epistemological puzzles with the casual and discursive intelligence of the truly bored. Even a novelist, he thinks, \u201cis forever bound by the ultimate constraint: She can hold her mirror up to whatever subject she chooses, at whatever angle she likes \u2014 she can even hold it such that she herself remains outside its frame, the better to de-narcissize the view \u2014 but there\u2019s no getting around the fact that she is always the one holding the mirror. And just because you can\u2019t see yourself in a reflection doesn\u2019t mean no one can.\u201d\n\nThroughout Amar\u2019s account, tiny details from Alice\u2019s story echo dimly though, enough to seem like coincidence: offhand descriptions of purple clothing, the music of Janacek, the vague phonetic qualities of Amar\u2019s own name. Only in the short third section \u2014 not even 30 pages \u2014 do we begin to understand how their stories fit together.\n\nThe book ends with the transcription of \u201cDesert Island Discs,\u201d a BBC radio program in which cultural figures select their favorite pieces of music, which are played on air between interview segments. The guest is Ezra Blazer, and the year is 2011. He tells charming boyhood anecdotes, flirts with the host, and at the end of a convoluted answer to a question about depression exposes the secret logic of \u201cAsymmetry.\u201d The reveal is both astonishing and retrospectively inevitable.\n\nHalliday has written, somehow all at once, a transgressive roman \u00e0 clef, a novel of ideas and a politically engaged work of metafiction. \u201cAsymmetry\u201d is extraordinary, and the timing of its publication seems almost like a feat of civics. The effect on the reader feels identical to the way Ezra describes a piano suite by Isaac Alb\u00e9niz, which he selects near the program\u2019s end. \u201cEach of the pieces builds on the last,\u201d he says. \u201cThey\u2019re discrete and yet all the richer for being heard together, and you just ache with the mounting intensity of it.\u201d", "title": "Three Lives, and the Tenuous Ties That Bind Them", "authors": ["Alice Gregory", "Lisa Halliday"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The announcement on Monday of charges against Major Evans and two others \u2014 Lt. Kashka Meadors and James Ramsey-Guy, a correctional officer \u2014 came more than nine months after that inquest, a relatively rare court proceeding in which jurors review evidence relating to a death and decide whether to recommend charges. The four other jail employees who were faulted by jurors at the inquest are not expected to face charges, Mr. Chisholm said, but the investigation was continuing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Thomas was arrested in April 2016 and accused of shooting a man and later firing a gun inside a hotel and casino, according to local news reports. A federal lawsuit filed by Mr. Thomas\u2019s estate said he had bipolar disorder and had been prescribed medication by a psychiatrist.\n\nOnce he was at the jail in downtown Milwaukee, prosecutors said, Mr. Thomas flooded his cell by stuffing his mattress cover into the toilet. The charging documents said that when Mr. Thomas was moved to another cell, Lieutenant Meadors told Mr. Ramsey-Guy to turn off the water supply to that cell. For the next week, Mr. Thomas did not leave his cell, and was not given any water.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe was literally punished for the manifestations of his mental illness,\u201d said Erik Heipt, a lawyer for Mr. Thomas\u2019s estate who has filed a federal lawsuit against Milwaukee County and jail officials. \u201cHe was not in his right mind. You don\u2019t take someone like that and then punish them by turning off their water.\u201d\n\nAfter Mr. Thomas\u2019s death, prosecutors said, Major Evans had a guard watch a week\u2019s worth of security video footage of Mr. Thomas\u2019s cell, which showed that the water had never been turned back on. Prosecutors said she did not take steps to preserve that video, and it was eventually recorded over and deleted.\n\nMajor Evans was charged with obstructing an officer, a misdemeanor, and misconduct in office, a felony. Mr. Ramsey-Guy and Lieutenant Meadors were each charged with felony neglect of a resident of a penal facility, which can carry more than three years in prison.\n\nCourt records did not list lawyers for Major Evans or Mr. Ramsey-Guy as of Monday afternoon. Both defendants \u2014 as well as Lieutenant Meadors \u2014 were suspended with pay on Monday by Richard Schmidt, the acting sheriff of Milwaukee County.\n\nBen Van Severen, a lawyer for Lieutenant Meadors, said his client had worked at the jail for more than 17 years and intended to plead not guilty.\n\n\u201cWe were very surprised to see the charges,\u201d said Mr. Van Severen, adding that \u201cwe would just caution against a rush to judgment.\u201d\n\nSheriff Schmidt said on Monday that he was \u201cvery confident\u201d the jail had been \u201ctransformed\u201d by new leaders since he succeeded David A. Clarke Jr. as sheriff last year. Mr. Clarke\u2019s tough-on-crime approach was lauded by President Trump and other conservatives, but critics said he led a troubled department and a dangerous jail. Four inmates died at the Milwaukee County Jail in 2016, and a Wisconsin congresswoman called for a federal investigation of the facility.\n\nAsked on Monday whether Mr. Clarke, who was not charged, had been investigated in connection with Mr. Thomas\u2019s death, Mr. Chisholm said he believed his office had charged the people who were most culpable.\n\nSheriff Schmidt said the accusations against his employees were \u201chorrific\u201d and that \u201cmy heart bleeds\u201d for Mr. Thomas\u2019s family.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSheriff Schmidt said a decision on departmental discipline for the officers could be made as soon as Friday. \u201cThis is serious stuff,\u201d he said. \u201cI care.\u201d", "title": "Three Milwaukee Jail Officers Charged in Dehydration Death", "authors": ["Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "DAKAR, Senegal \u2014 An attack by three suicide bombers has left at least 20 people dead and more than 20 others wounded at a fish market outside the sprawling Nigerian city that gave rise to the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram, officials and news reports said on Saturday.\n\nThe bombers set off explosives on Friday at the market, about 15 miles from the center of the city of Maiduguri, Reuters reported. No one claimed responsibility for the attacks, but they were similar to scores of others in and around the city in the past few months.\n\nThe attackers were all female, according to The Associated Press, and the victims were mostly women and children, local news outlets reported. Boko Haram has been known to deploy young women and children as suicide bombers, in addition to sending men to attack mosques, markets and other places where crowds gather.\n\nThe police commissioner of Borno State, Damian Chukwu, said at least 18 people died and 22 others were wounded in the attack on Friday, according to Reuters. Hospital officials said two patients later died of their injuries.\n\nThe war with Boko Haram, which has displaced millions, is entering its ninth year. Militants raging against decades of economic inequality and government corruption in the region want to create a state that adheres to a harsh version of Islam. In their quest, they have burned villages, slaughtered men and boys who refuse to join their ranks, raped and enslaved women and girls, and strapped suicide bombs to terrified hostages.\n\nThe Nigerian military has made progress in the past weeks in chasing fighters from their forest hide-outs, and this month the military secured the release of high-profile hostages \u2014 a group of female police officers and several university professors who had been held by the fighters.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNegotiations for the release of about 100 young women kidnapped from a school in Chibok in 2014 are still underway. Dozens of other Chibok girls have been released after similar negotiations or after escaping. Thousands of other residents from villages overrun by Boko Haram are also believed to be held in miserable conditions by the militants, who are known to conscript children into fighting.\n\nMilitary and government officials have announced the defeat of Boko Haram several times, even as fighters have launched attacks and released propaganda videos taunting officials.\n\nLast week, Abubakar Shekau, the leader of Boko Haram, appeared in a 10-minute video released by the group, according to an A.P. report. In the clip, he disputed the Nigerian military\u2019s claims that Boko Haram militants had been defeated in the Sambisa forest of northeastern Nigeria.\n\nIn the footage, he is wearing all black and holding a rifle, while two masked men stand alongside him. At one point, he looks into the camera and addresses the military saying, \u201cIf you have killed us, why are we still alive?\u201d\n\nIt is unclear when and where the footage was recorded.\n\nThe militants unleashed bombers across Maiduguri in numerous attacks last year, but recently, they have sent suicide attackers to more rural areas.", "title": "Three Suicide Bombers Kill at Least 20 in Nigeria", "authors": ["Dionne Searcey"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Sofia Jaramillo may have been mountain biking ahead of the pack, but as she soon found out, that was nothing compared to being behind the herd. Twelve years old at the time, she was attending her first mountain bike camp in her hometown, Ketchum, Idaho, riding on a bumpy forest road when her tire slid into a rut.\n\nThings didn\u2019t just get hairy, they got downright woolly.\n\n\u201cSuddenly, I looked up and hundreds of sheep were blocking the road,\u201d she recalled. \u201cI panicked, turned my wheel, hit my front brakes and flew over my handlebars. When I opened my eyes, I was surrounded by sheep. I ended up landing on my hip so hard I had to get stitches.\u201d", "title": "Through Forests and Farmlands, Peruvian Sheep Herders of the Pacific Northwest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Cooks in Baja often eschew lard in favor of olive oil from area farms; wines from Valle de Guadalupe and oysters, sea urchin and the large clam geoduck from the ocean are on the menus. And the back-and-forth north to California has inspired chefs on both sides of the wall. San Diego has some of the best Mexican food outside Mexico, and the California city\u2019s booming craft brewery scene has spread south of the border.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe people who have restaurants in Baja, a lot of them grew up going between San Diego and Tijuana,\u201d Mr. Esparza said. \u201cThere\u2019s definitely that relationship between these two places.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA Tijuanan culinary stalwart who exemplifies that relationship is Javier Plascencia, whose dining empire has included restaurants on both sides of the border. Shyema and I Ubered from Zona Centro to Zona Rio to eat at Plascencia\u2019s Mision 19, Tijuana\u2019s most elegant restaurant, all white tablecloths and dim lighting in a nondescript office building. Mr. Plascencia grew up in both San Diego and Tijuana and sometimes crosses two or three times a day.\n\n\u201cI opened Mision 19 seven years ago, when the city was not in good shape, when everything was happening,\u201d Mr. Plascencia said. \u201cWe thought if we open this restaurant, people will want to come and see that Tijuana is not going away, it\u2019s not going to die. It\u2019s going to get better.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe result is a modern celebration of Baja cuisine, the type of place where local residents come to mark a special occasion, perhaps over house-made pasta with octopus, beef fillet picadillo and Mexican chile peppers, or local tuna with cactus, xoconoxtle (a sour cactus fruit), black mole caramel and short-rib chicharron. \u201cBaja California is a young cuisine, not very traditional, and very creative,\u201d he said. \u201cNobody\u2019s telling us how to cook or what to do.\u201d\n\nOver the next day and a half, we raced to sample every place on my list. Throughout the city, tacos were mostly between 20 or 40 pesos apiece ($1 to $2); Uber rides were typically 20 to 60 pesos. Saturday\u2019s first breakfast was at Telef\u00f3nica Gastropark, a new food-truck trailer park where we tucked into chilaquiles and papas de zefe in outsize portions from La Carmelita. It\u2019s the kind of place that you expect would be overrun by gringo hipsters, but we found locals descending in droves. Brunch was the best sandwich of my life, found, unexpectedly, at a carwash a few blocks away: Tortas Wash Mobile has been plying its tortas since 1964, and a crowd of people hungrily tearing into their sandwiches was huddled around the garish yellow stand. I went around the corner to devour mine on the stoop of a nearby building, inhaling the pile of spicy citrusy carne asada swathed in mayo, guacamole and tomato and nestled in pillowy ciabatta-like bread. A few blocks away I tried the cabeza \u2014 cow head \u2014 tacos at Tijuana\u2019s so-called \u201cTaco Alley.\u201d\n\nSan Diego Club Tengo Hambre California Mexico VIA INTERNACIONAL Tijuana Av. C Ni\u00f1os H\u00e9roes & Calle Salvador D\u00edaz Mir\u00f3n 4ta. Tijuana R. Zona Urbana Rio Tijuana One Bunk Tijuana Zona Centro Caesar\u2019s Cevicheria La Mas Nais Taqueria Franc La Cahua Del Yeyo Asadero El Nuevo Tecolote Azarosa Telefonica Gastro Park Kokopelli Tortas Wash Mobile Taco Alley\n\nOther stops that weekend included Asadero El Nuevo Tecolete, a stand specializing in carne asada; Taquer\u00eda Franc, a loud late-night spot where locals and tourists alike spill onto the street; La Cahua del Yeyo for stingray and shrimp tacos; a return to Telefonica Gastropark for the ricotta-draped French toast at Azarosa; and Tras/Horizonte, an upscale eatery where I tried the Chicano, a grilled-octopus taco. Shyema lost her goodwill toward me somewhere between the papas and the stingray. But if I was indeed trying to kill her, there are surely worse ways to go than death by deliciousness.\n\nTras/Horizonte is the brainchild of chef Oso Campos, who, as he said, was \u201cborn and made in TJ\u201d but who has traveled extensively throughout Mexico and California. \u201cWe serve Mexican border cuisine,\u201d he said. \u201cUs as a people, we are a mix of all different cultures and lenguas.
