Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo days later, Mr. Trump again expressed doubt during the second presidential debate that Russia was responsible:\n\n\u201cBut I notice, anytime anything wrong happens, they like to say the Russians are \u2014 she doesn\u2019t know if it\u2019s the Russians doing the hacking. Maybe there is no hacking. But they always blame Russia. And the reason they blame Russia because they think they\u2019re trying to tarnish me with Russia.\u201d\n\nDecember 2016: \u201cI don\u2019t believe they interfered. That became a laughing point, not a talking point, a laughing point.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with Time magazine that December, Mr. Trump, then the president-elect, rejected the notion of Russian interference, even as he entertained the possibility but then suggested other culprits:\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t believe they interfered. That became a laughing point, not a talking point, a laughing point. Anytime I do something, they say, \u2018Oh, Russia interfered.\u2019 Why not get along with Russia? And they can help us fight ISIS, which is both costly in lives and costly in money. And they\u2019re effective and smart. It could be Russia. And it could be China. And it could be some guy in his home in New Jersey. I believe that it could have been Russia and it could have been any one of many other people. Sources or even individuals.\u201d\n\nAfter reports from The Times and The Washington Post that the intelligence communities concluded that Russia acted to aid Mr. Trump in December, Mr. Trump again disagreed. \u201cUnless you catch \u2018hackers\u2019 in the act, it is very hard to determine who was doing the hacking. Why wasn\u2019t this brought up before election?\u201d he wrote.\n\nOn Dec. 29, outgoing President Barack Obama issued sanctions against Russia and ejected 35 suspected Russian intelligence operatives from the United States. Two days later, Mr. Trump said he still wasn\u2019t convinced that Moscow had played a role in the vote:\n\n\u201cAnd I know a lot about hacking. And hacking is a very hard thing to prove. So it could be somebody else,\u201d he said to reporters in Palm Beach, Fla.\n\nJanuary 2017: \u201cRussia, China, other countries, outside groups and people are consistently trying to break through the cyberinfrastructure of our governmental institutions.\u201d\n\nOn Jan. 6, the intelligence community released an unclassified report about Russia\u2019s multifaceted attempt to influence the 2016 presidential election. After being briefed on the full report that day, Mr. Trump pointed to \u201cRussia, China, other countries, outside groups and people.\u201d\n\nMay: \u201cIf Russia did anything having to do with our election, I want to know about it.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with NBC\u2019s Lester Holt, Mr. Trump spoke of Russian interference as a hypothetical possibility:\n\nMr. Trump: \u201cIf Russia hacked \u2014 if Russia did anything having to do with our election, I want to know about it.\u201d Mr. Holt: \u201cWell, there\u2019s already \u2014 there\u2019s already intelligence from virtually every intelligence agency that yes, that happened.\u201d Mr. Trump: \u201cI\u2019ll tell you this. If Russia or anybody else is trying to interfere with our elections, I think it\u2019s a horrible thing and I want to get to the bottom of it. And I want to make sure it will never, ever happen.\u201d\n\nJuly: \u201cSomebody did say if he did do it, you wouldn\u2019t have found out about it.\u201d\n\nAfter meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a Group of 20 summit meeting, Mr. Trump said in an interview:\n\n\u201cFirst question \u2014 first 20, 25 minutes \u2014 I said, \u2018Did you do it?\u2019 He said, \u2018No, I did not, absolutely not.\u2019 I then asked him a second time, in a totally different way. He said, \u2018Absolutely not.\u2019 \u201cSomebody did say if he did do it, you wouldn\u2019t have found out about it. Which is a very interesting point.\u201d\n\nNovember: \u201cEvery time he sees me, he says, \u2018I didn\u2019t do that.\u2019\u201d\n\nDuring a trip to Asia, Mr. Trump met privately with Mr. Putin and told reporters that he believed Mr. Putin\u2019s sincerity as he continued to cast doubt on the F.B.I.\u2019s handling of hacked emails. He also criticized Ms. Clinton\u2019s campaign chairman, John D. Podesta, and described John O. Brennan, the former C.I.A. director, and intelligence officials as \u201cpolitical hacks.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf his meeting with the Russian leader, Mr. Trump said:", "title": "Trump Falsely Claims, \u2018I Never Said Russia Did Not Meddle\u2019", "authors": ["Linda Qiu"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 In 2006 and again in 2013, Republican moderates joined Democrats in the Senate to pass sweeping overhauls of the nation\u2019s immigration laws with a pathway to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants, only to see the compromises torpedoed by a wave of angry activism in the conservative news media and grass roots.\n\nThis time, as senators again search for a way forward on immigration, a revolt from the right has so far failed to materialize, in large part because of the intransigence of a different player: a man in the White House who has mostly satisfied immigration hard-liners.\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s gamble was risky. And at first his plan struck many conservatives as too generous because it would offer 1.8 million young immigrants who came to the United States illegally as children the opportunity to become citizens. But by coupling his offer with demands to sharply reduce legal immigration \u2014 a trade-off many Democrats say they cannot accept \u2014 then threatening to veto anything that does not meet those demands, the president has made a bipartisan compromise exceedingly difficult.\n\nThat may have been the point, as it sits just fine with many on the right who never wanted a deal in the first place.", "title": "Trump Gets What He Wants in Immigration Debate: Quiet on the Right", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Steven Gold, a sociologist at Michigan State University, emailed me:\n\nMany Democrats fear that extensive investments and political posturing made on behalf of immigrants will be regarded as of little value to a large swath of independent voters whose support Democrats need to increase their representation in Congress.\n\nIn a reference to the demonstrated electoral liabilities of so-called \u201cidentity politics,\u201d Gold argued that concerned Democrats worry that\n\nby emphasizing particularistic rather than practical issues with a broad impact, they will once again lose the politically advantageous position that appears to be taking shape for them in 2018 and 2020.\n\nMore bluntly, Nolan McCarty, a political scientist at Princeton, declared in an email responding to my inquiry:\n\nThe Democrats don\u2019t have a lot of good options other than to support it enough that it can pass with unified Republican support.\n\nMcCarty explained further:\n\nBlocking it would allow the Trump Administration to suggest that the Democrats were willing to trade Dreamers for \u201clottery\u201d and \u201cchain\u201d migration, as well as position them as soft on border security.\n\nAn advantage in accepting the Trump proposal, McCarty continued,\n\nis that border security appropriations and visa programs can be fixed if the Democrats regain control. The effects of Dreamer deportations and/or sending them back into the shadows is far less reversible.\n\nTrump and Stephen Miller, a senior adviser to the president, have clearly made this calculation and decided that they win either way. Take, for example, the following tweet from the president\u2019s account on Jan. 27:\n\nI have offered DACA a wonderful deal, including a doubling in the number of recipients & a twelve year pathway to citizenship, for two reasons: (1) Because the Republicans want to fix a long time terrible problem. (2) To show that Democrats do not want to solve DACA, only use it!\n\nRobert L. Borosage, president of the left-liberal Institute for America\u2019s Future, argued that Democrats should make every effort to get the immigration issue off center stage. \u201cIn my view,\u201d Borosage said in an email, \u201cTrump wins as long as we\u2019re arguing about this. So it would be good to get this done soon.\u201d\n\nBorosage went on:\n\nWhat should Democrats do? I\u2019d take the deal, after pushing for concessions on family unification and lottery system, and pushing against full commitment of $25 billion as an outrage.\n\nBruce Cain, a political scientist at Stanford, makes the case that political logic favors Democratic cooperation with Trump on immigration:\n\nIf the Democrats compromise on a few of the non-DACA items and the (Congressional) Republican position is no DACA relief, then the Republican position becomes untenable and looks as though are caving to their extreme nativist faction. And if the Democrats make their position a clean bill on DACA and no compromise on the other items, it hands the Republicans a perfect wedge item going into the 2018 election, possibly keeping them in control of both houses.\n\nIn fact, I found an unexpectedly high percentage of the experts I contacted \u2014 most of whom are sympathetic to the plight of immigrants \u2014 in general agreement that Democrats would be wise to come to some kind of an agreement with Trump.\n\nDaniel Hopkins, a political scientist at the University of Pennsylvania, noted, for example, that the public supports both \u201ca pathway to citizenship for Dreamers\u201d and \u201cenhanced border security.\u201d But, he warned,\n\nin today\u2019s political climate, it\u2019s very hard to imagine a deal that will placate both sides for long, as both parties seem to define winning in zero-sum terms.\n\nSo far at least, arguments in favor of cutting a deal are not selling with the Democratic leadership \u2014 although the leaders\u2019 position may be more of a bargaining tactic than a principled stance.\n\nChuck Schumer, the Senate Democratic leader, tweeted on Jan. 26 that \u201cthis plan flies in the face of what most Americans believe,\u201d adding\n\nWhile @realDonaldTrump finally acknowledged that the Dreamers should be allowed to stay here and become citizens, he uses them as a tool to tear apart our legal immigration system and adopt the wish list that anti-immigration hard-liners have advocated for years.\n\nNancy Pelosi, the Democratic House leader, was more outspoken. In a Jan. 26 statement that received wide press coverage, she described Trump\u2019s proposal as \u201cpart of the Trump Administration\u2019s unmistakable campaign to make America white again.\u201d\n\nAfter Trump reiterated his immigration proposals in his State of the Union address Tuesday night, Pelosi stood firm in her opposition:\n\nThe president represents himself as generous towards Dreamers, but he is holding them hostage with the most extreme anti-immigrant agenda in generations. We heard more insulting words of ignorance and prejudice towards patriotic immigrant families last night.\n\nIn a detailed critique of the Trump proposal, William Frey, a demographic specialist at Brookings, argued that\n\nthe so-called compromise between DACA and border security is extremely disproportional \u2014 weighted heavily toward the latter which is characterized by simple bumper sticker messages about family migration, border security and the visa lottery that is aimed at appealing to the extreme anti-immigrant wings of Trump\u2019s Republican base.\n\nFrey wrote in his email that he could\n\nnot imagine Democratic senators or congressmen agreeing to anything close to this plan \u2014 in light of their base which not only includes Hispanics, Asian-Americans and other minorities \u2014 but also rising support in recent state and local elections they have received from suburban college graduate women and millennials.\n\nNonetheless, in a Washington Post op-ed published in 2015, Frey pointed out that\n\nDemocrats cannot make the politics of fear go away simply by courting the young-adult and minority voting blocs. While it is true that the supersize turnout and support of those groups helped elect President Obama twice, the white portion of the electorate, which votes strongly Republican, underperformed in support of John McCain in 2008, and white turnout was down in 2012.\n\nThere is, Frey continued, \u201ca sharp lag in diversity between the overall population and the portion that turns out on Election Day.\u201d It is \u201cthe older electorate \u2014 those most greatly fearing change,\u201d he wrote,\n\nthat will be gaining as baby boomers continue to age. By my calculation, the number of (mostly white) eligible voters over age 45 will be 26 percent larger in 2024 than those under age 45. This disparity will be further widened by the higher turnout of older white voters, who may not determine future elections but will continue to have a strong voice.\n\nWhen I asked him if there was a disparity between his recent comment to me and the Post op-ed, Frey wrote back:\n\nI stand by the fact that the politics of fear (to older non-college whites) can work to some extent. But I also think white women, especially college graduate white women, can help to mute the impact on the immigration issue because of their disdain for Trump. If Dems are looking at 2018, it\u2019s not just the immigration issue that is important to those women but Trump\u2019s stance on women\u2019s issues in general \u2014 critical of planned parenthood, abortion, his support of Roy Moore in Alabama, his disdain for political correctness and his overall boorishness may counter whatever gains he may get, on immigration, from older white non-college men and women (and even the latter support may be more tenuous). Another group is millennials, now strongly anti-Trump, who could be motivated to turn out in greater numbers. In short, the base that will respond to Trump playing the \u201cimmigration card\u201d may be dwindling in light of his other positions and demeanor since in office \u2014 including his handling of the Russian investigation. I think the Democrats are counting on that.\n\nIt may seem surprising now, but the Pew Research Center found that from 1994 to 2006 there was very little difference between the views of Republican and Democratic voters on immigration. Since that time they have diverged sharply.\n\nIn response to the question, \u201cWhich comes closer to your view, \u2018immigrants today strengthen the country because of their hard work and talents,\u2019 or \u2018immigrants today burden the country by taking jobs, housing and health care\u2019?\u201d there was almost no difference in the responses of Democrats and Republicans in 2006.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Has Got Democrats Right Where He Wants Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Long Island, where prosecutors say two girls were beaten to death by MS-13 members in 2016, is one of the many places where the gang has expanded. The police have been fighting the gang there since 2007, but MS-13 continues to murder and grow more powerful because the authorities have failed to attack the organization at its roots.\n\nThe people accused of killing those girls were not hardened murderers with tattoos, members of a \u201ccartel,\u201d as Mr. Trump described the gang in 2017. They were teenagers. They were also part of the gang\u2019s hard-core American ground forces: young immigrants, either with or without papers, lost and lonely in a new and violent world, where they have responded to the first institution that has lent them a hand \u2014 MS-13, not the United States government.\n\nTo say that the gangs \u201cwin over\u201d these young people is misleading, because it implies that the American government is doing something to compete with them, which it is not. The United States is not fighting for these boys.\n\nAmericans keep talking about deportation but focus comparatively little on how budget cuts in education serve to feed gang recruiting activity, as Howard Koenig, the superintendent of public schools in Central Islip on Long Island, recently pointed out.\n\nAmericans also keep talking about the wall President Trump wants to build, but few people have acknowledged that \u201cthe government\u2019s total failure to establish an efficient process and meaningful oversight of the placement\u201d of unaccompanied minors has led to the MS-13 crisis, as Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said last June. Many of these children come from dysfunctional families, with parents who barely have time or money to take care of them; the government essentially releases them to the streets. Of the more than 240,000 unaccompanied minors detained at the border since 2012, only 56 were suspected of having connections to MS-13 when they arrived. If they made those connections after entering the United States, the United States is to blame.\n\nMr. Trump will continue to use his favorite word for MS-13 gang members: \u201canimals.\u201d And few people will focus on the fact that at high schools like Uniondale, home to two of Long Island\u2019s MS-13 clicas, there are only three social workers for over 2,000 students. One of those social workers, Sergio Argueta, told me that many of these students are recent arrivals still lost in their new surroundings. He works to help at-risk youth in Long Island through an organization called Strong.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Is Making MS-13 Stronger", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "This past week was meant to be dedicated to a rare open debate on immigration in the Senate, and once again, centrist Democrats and Republicans proposed a pair of similar and reasonable compromises on what has arguably become the most charged issue of the day. Alas, they both fell before the anti-immigration furor of the Trump administration. But then President Trump\u2019s own hard-line immigration bill fell much harder, leaving the fate of the so-called Dreamers in limbo.\n\nThe compromise measures would have resolved the fate of the Dreamers, the 1.8 million immigrants who were brought to the United States illegally as children and whose plight has generated broad sympathy. One bill written by a bipartisan group of senators calling itself the Common Sense Coalition would also have given Mr. Trump money for his much-ballyhooed wall along the Mexican border, though over a 10-year period, while putting off more contentious questions about immigration.\n\nUnfortunately, Mr. Trump is not interested in resolving a difficult problem if he can exploit it for political gain. After threatening to veto any measure that didn\u2019t include his tough demands, and getting Department of Homeland Security officials to bad-mouth the compromise measures, the president succeeded in getting most Republicans to vote against them, leaving both short of the 60 votes they needed, one by eight votes and one by six.\n\nMinutes later, the Senate even more decisively beat the White House\u2019s own proposal, which would have provided a path to citizenship for the Dreamers while also severely limiting family-based immigration and ending the diversity visa lottery program. The bill fell 21 votes short of the needed 60.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Kills Compromise on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "White House officials had released only a terse statement after the market\u2019s decline earlier this week. Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said in a statement on Monday that \u201cthe President\u2019s focus is on our long-term economic fundamentals, which remain exceptionally strong, with strengthening U.S. economic growth, historically low unemployment, and increasing wages for American workers.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, the Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, tried to walk a fine line in distancing the administration from the recent drop in stock prices while still taking credit for the run of success that preceded it.\n\n\u201cWe are very focused on long-term economic growth, and we believe that the policies that we have enacted, including tax reform, are very positive for long-term economic growth,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said at a House Financial Services Committee hearing.\n\nAsked after the hearing if the administration would in the future refrain from embracing the stock market as a proxy now that it has become such a volatile measure, Mr. Mnuchin made clear that he was not ready to do so.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve always been looking at the long-term impact of the stock market. It\u2019s still up over 30 percent since the election, and we continue to think America is a great place to do business,\u201d he said. \u201cWe couldn\u2019t be happier with companies\u2019 response with more and more investments in the U.S.\u201d", "title": "Trump Laments the Stock Market Plunge as a \u2018Big Mistake\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI can\u2019t get into any of that,\u201d Mr. Cohen said.\n\nCharles Wolfram, an emeritus professor of legal ethics at Cornell University, said the situation raised a host of potential issues, but that more facts were needed to understand which rules applied to it.\n\n\u201cThe thing seems so weird that it invites an inquiry into what you\u2019re doing,\u201d he said. \u201cLawyers don\u2019t go around giving $130,000 to strangers, benefiting their clients, without billing their clients.\u201d\n\nKeith Davidson, a Los Angeles lawyer who represented Ms. Clifford in the 2016 transaction, issued a statement Wednesday declaring that Mr. Cohen had told him at the time that the $130,000 payment was coming from his own funds.\n\n\u201cI represented Stephanie Clifford in the Michael Cohen/Stephanie Clifford transaction,\u201d Mr. Davidson\u2019s statement said. \"I read today that Michael Cohen reports that the source of the $130,000 paid to Ms. Clifford was from his own personal funds. That assertion is in complete harmony with what he informed me of at the time of the transaction.\u201d\n\nMs. Clifford believes that Mr. Cohen, in making his statement, has breached a nondisclosure agreement she signed in connection with the payment, releasing her from the confidentiality commitment, according to Gina Rodriguez, her manager. Ms. Clifford, she said, is now offering to sell her story to media outlets so that she can tell her version of events.\n\nMr. Cohen worked as a lawyer for the Trump Organization for roughly a decade, with an office near Mr. Trump\u2019s on the 26th floor of Trump Tower in Manhattan. Part fixer, part pit bull biting back at anyone who attacked Mr. Trump, Mr. Cohen frequently badgered reporters over stories he found unflattering toward his boss during the campaign. He was often quoted in interviews lavishing praise on his boss.\n\nMr. Cohen\u2019s statement on Tuesday acknowledging that he had sent the money to Ms. Clifford was linked to a deadline requiring him to respond to a complaint filed with the Federal Election Commission by Common Cause, a liberal-leaning watchdog group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe group alleges that the payment amounted to an undisclosed, in-kind contribution to Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential campaign that violated the individual contribution limit of $2,700. (Such limits do not apply to candidates spending their own money.)\n\nIn his statement to The Times on Tuesday, Mr. Cohen insisted that the payment did not violate campaign-finance laws, saying, \u201cThe payment to Ms. Clifford was lawful, and was not a campaign contribution or a campaign expenditure by anyone.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut on Wednesday, Paul S. Ryan, the vice president for policy and litigation at Common Cause, said that if the funds were truly Mr. Cohen\u2019s, the payment was an excessive contribution, and if not, \u201cwe still need an investigation to figure out whose money this was.\u201d\n\nIf the commission dismisses the complaint without an investigation, he said, the group is considering filing a lawsuit against the agency or against the Trump campaign.\n\nAnother set of potential issues raised by Mr. Cohen\u2019s admission centers on legal ethics. As a New York lawyer, he is subject to rules of professional conduct in that state and could face disciplinary action \u2014 ranging from private admonishment to losing his license to practice law \u2014 if he violated them, although the still-uncertain details make it impossible to precisely identify which standards apply.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t have the facts,\u201d said Philip Schrag, a Georgetown University law professor and specialist in legal ethics issues. \u201cThere is an awful lot of speculation here about the facts, which we need before we can go into the legal analysis.\u201d\n\nDepending on what the circumstances turn out to be, he and other ethics specialists pointed to Rule 1.8, which governs financial arrangements between a lawyer and a client. One provision generally prohibits lawyers from lending money to clients during contemplated or pending litigation, although Ms. Clifford appears to have been threatening to talk \u2014 not to sue.\n\nAnother provision requires a written and signed agreement if there is a loan between a lawyer and a client. If it turns out that the arrangement was envisioned as a loan that Mr. Trump would eventually repay, Mr. Cohen was obliged to create such a document.\n\nBut if Mr. Cohen intended to make a gift to Mr. Trump by paying off Ms. Clifford without expecting any reimbursement, then no written agreement was required, the specialists said. Nor would the rule have required a document if some third party, like one of Mr. Trump\u2019s wealthy associates, had reimbursed Mr. Cohen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast month, Mr. Cohen sent Wall Street Journal reporters a written statement in Ms. Clifford\u2019s name denying that she had had \u201ca sexual and/or romantic affair\u201d with Mr. Trump or \u201creceived hush money from Mr. Trump.\u201d He also issued his own statement saying that Mr. Trump \u201cvehemently denies\u201d any affair with her.\n\nIf evidence emerged showing that those statements were false and that Mr. Cohen knew they were false, his role in disseminating them could violate Rule 8.4, several legal ethics specialists said. It prohibits lawyers from engaging \u201cin conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation.\u201d\n\n\u201cLawyers are not allowed to lie,\u201d with some exceptions, said Lisa Lerman, a legal ethics professor at the Catholic University of America, and they are \u201calso not allowed to induce other people to engage in conduct that they are prohibited from.\u201d\n\nBut Stephen Gillers, a New York University professor of ethics law, said that in practice, the ethics rule against dishonesty is generally not interpreted so broadly as to cover facilitating a lie to the public or to journalists.\n\nStill, Mr. Gillers said that Mr. Cohen\u2019s \u201cexplanation is sufficiently improbable to spark a disciplinary committee investigation.\u201d Anyone can file a complaint asking the committee to investigate him, or it can open a file on its own, he said, cautioning that it works slowly and that its proceedings are secret unless they result in public discipline.\n\n\u201cThe committee has the jurisdiction to get to the bottom of it if it wishes to do so.\u201d", "title": "Trump Lawyer\u2019s Payment to Porn Star Raises New Questions", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Those two facts go a long way toward explaining why there were so many Democratic-friendly analyses of voting demographics and polls over the last decade. The exit polling made it seem as if the Republicans, in a diversifying country, could not win with big gains among older, white working-class voters.\n\nAnd if the exit polls overestimate Republican vote share among various demographic groups, then pre-election national polls will seem to show Democrats doing well, since they\u2019re weighted by education and aren\u2019t adjusted to match a result. The exit poll tendency to overestimate Republican vote share will also tend to obscure Republican strength in pre-election polls, like Mr. Trump\u2019s big gains among white voters without a college degree.\n\nOver the last year or so, national media organizations have made a concerted effort to cover those white working-class voters. Some have argued that those efforts have gone too far. But so far there has been little or no movement to better represent white working-class voters in public political data and analysis. Only a handful of state pollsters have begun to weight by education, and the exit polls have not announced any methodological changes intended to remedy these issues either.\n\nThe consequences can be significant. For better or worse, lawmakers and campaigns make policy decisions based on political calculations, and the exit polls play a huge role in shaping how people judge the landscape of American electoral politics. Even Fox News\u2019s Sean Hannity briefly supported comprehensive immigration reform in November 2012, after the exit polls made it seem as though Hispanic voters, not white working-class Midwesterners, decided the election in President Obama\u2019s favor.\n\nOne way to avoid the issue: retire the use of the exit polls in post-election analysis, and make apples-to-apples comparisons between current and older pre-election polls. The most important trends of the 2016 election were more apparent using this approach, including Mr. Trump\u2019s strength among white working-class voters. And today, it would make President Trump seem more resilient among well-educated white voters.", "title": "Trump Losing College-Educated Whites? He Never Won Them in the First Place", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "The president, they noted, promised unwavering fealty last year to the National Rifle Association, drawing thunderous applause at its annual convention by declaring, \u201cTo the N.R.A., I can proudly say I will never, ever let you down.\u201d The group in turn enthusiastically endorsed Mr. Trump and spent $30 million on his campaign.\n\nSenator Christopher S. Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, who sponsored the latest background check measure with Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, said he was unimpressed by Mr. Trump\u2019s openness to it. \u201cLet\u2019s not pretend this is some huge concession on his part,\u201d he said. \u201cIf this is all the White House is willing to do to address gun violence, it\u2019s wholly insufficient.\u201d\n\nThe background check bill, which seeks to improve the existing database used to prevent gun purchases by criminals and the mentally ill, is a small nod in the direction of gun control that does nothing to close loopholes that allow millions of gun sales without a background check. Last year, N.R.A. officials said they were fine with it.\n\nIt is also unclear whether Mr. Trump\u2019s statement of support for the measure, which included a desire for some \u201crevisions,\u201d might be linked to other legislation that the N.R.A. backs. In the House, a similar background check measure was combined with legislation that would effectively allow people to legally carry concealed weapons in all 50 states.\n\nThat legislation is the top priority for the N.R.A., and gun control activists have promised to fight it aggressively.\n\n\u201cThat normalizes the carrying of guns on all American streets,\u201d said John Feinblatt, the president of Everytown for Gun Safety, a group that advocates gun control measures. He said joining the two measures would be a \u201ccraven\u201d bait-and-switch and \u201cdisrespectful for all the families\u201d of the Florida school that suffered through last week\u2019s shooting.\n\nThe president\u2019s bump stock announcement surprised the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, which did not appear to have been informed of the pending remarks from Mr. Trump. The Justice Department announced a review of the devices in early December. Led by the A.T.F., the review sought to determine whether the bureau \u2014 which is responsible for policing firearms \u2014 was able to regulate the devices without action from Congress.", "title": "Trump Moves to Regulate \u2018Bump Stock\u2019 Devices", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, said the Trump administration was promoting \u201cjunk insurance.\u201d The House Democratic leader, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, said people buying these plans could be \u201cone diagnosis away from disaster, discovering they have been paying for coverage that may not cover basic care such as cancer treatment.\u201d\n\nSome health policy experts say that if large numbers of healthy people buy short-term coverage, it could drive up premiums for those who remain in Affordable Care Act plans.\n\nThe Trump administration said these concerns were unfounded. But in a preamble to the proposed rules, it said, \u201cIndividuals who are likely to purchase short-term, limited-duration insurance are likely to be relatively young or healthy.\u201d\n\nAnd if those consumers develop chronic conditions, it said, they could \u201cface financial hardship\u201d until they enroll in more comprehensive plans that comply with the 2010 law.\n\nSome insurers worry that consumers will be confused and may see short-term policies as a substitute for major medical coverage.\n\n\u201cExpanded use of short-term policies could further fragment the individual market, which would lead to higher premiums for many consumers, particularly those with pre-existing conditions,\u201d said Kristine Grow, a spokeswoman for America\u2019s Health Insurance Plans, a trade group for insurers.\n\nBut Representative Greg Walden, Republican of Oregon and the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, welcomed the announcement as an important step to \u201cexpand consumer choice, competition and access to health care.\u201d", "title": "Trump Moves to Relax Rules on Cheaper Health Insurance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nI read \u201cOne Honorable American\u2019s Love of Trump,\u201d by Roger Cohen (column, Feb. 10), in which he interviewed a Trump supporter, with great interest. The quote that made me literally gasp was Shannon Kennedy\u2019s defense of President Trump: \u201cIf I thought he was a racist, I\u2019d be off the train so fast you\u2019d have to mail me my shadow.\u201d\n\nI feel the need to talk to Shannon\u2019s shadow. I would like to remind his shadow that President Trump perpetuated for years the racist lie that President Barack Obama was not born in America. I would like to remind Shannon\u2019s shadow that Mr. Trump said some neo-Nazis were \u201cvery fine people.\u201d\n\nI would like to remind Shannon\u2019s shadow that Representative Paul Ryan said, in regard to the president\u2019s assertion that Judge Gonzalo Curiel could not do his job because he was \u201ca Mexican,\u201d that it was the \u201ctextbook definition of a racist comment.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s racist train left the station long ago, Shannon.\n\nHEATHER HACH HEARNE\n\nMANHATTAN BEACH, CALIF.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Not a Racist? Bah!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "It was not clear why Mr. Yun had decided to retire so suddenly. He did not immediately return a request for comment. Heather Nauert, spokeswoman for the State Department, said in a statement that Mr. Yun was retiring \u201cfor personal reasons\u201d and that Rex W. Tillerson, the secretary of state, \u201creluctantly accepted his decision.\u201d\n\nAnalysts were taken aback.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s definitely sad news,\u201d said Andrei Lankov, the director of Korea Risk Group, a consultancy, and a professor at Kookmin University in Seoul, South Korea. Mr. Yun \u201cis very much in favor of compromise and negotiations, and it seems that his voice is not going to be heard.\u201d\n\nFor the last year and a half, tensions have been building on the Korean Peninsula as both Mr. Trump and Kim Jong-un, North Korea\u2019s leader, have ratcheted up bellicose attacks that seemed to push the United States and the North closer to a confrontation.\n\nThe respite of the Olympics \u2014 to which North Korea sent 22 athletes and an entourage of dignitaries, cheerleaders and musical performers \u2014 along with a break in North Korean missile and nuclear tests since last November raised hopes that tensions were finally easing.\n\nBut no sooner had the North and the United States declared their willingness to talk to each other \u2014 something they have in fact done before \u2014 than it became clear that the two sides remained stubbornly far apart.\n\n\u201cThe North Koreans have always said they would be happy to talk to the United States, and in fact they are eager to come and talk to us \u2014 as one nuclear weapons state to another,\u201d said Ralph Cossa, president of the Pacific Forum at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. \u201cAnd the U.S. is willing to talk to the North Koreans if they are prepared to put nuclear weapons on the table. So both sides are willing to talk, but not about the same thing.\u201d\n\nWhile leading the United States delegation to the Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, earlier this month, Vice President Mike Pence planned to secretly meet with a high-level delegation from North Korea, but the North Koreans canceled at the last minute, according to the State Department.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is the real challenge with North Korea,\u201d said Mr. Cossa. \u201cIf you try to confront them, they get their backs up and feel they have to be more confrontational back, to show they are not afraid.\u201d\n\n\u201dBut if you make an overture, they see this as a weakness they have to exploit,\u201d he added. \u201cAnd if you offer them the moon and the stars, they say \u2018O.K., we want the sun also.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe United Nations Security Council has imposed increasingly strict sanctions on North Korea over its weapons program, but policing violations can be difficult. On Tuesday, Japan\u2019s Foreign Ministry announced that a Japanese military plane on Saturday had detected a North Korean and a Maldavian-flagged ship conducting what Japan judged to be ship-to-ship transfers banned by the Security Council.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany analysts say that the North Korean leadership will never agree to talks if they have to promise to give up their nuclear weapons to get the dialogue started.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m very suspicious that there are conditions under which North Korea will denuclearize peacefully,\u201d said Bridget Coggins, an associate professor of political science at University of California at Santa Barbara.\n\nGiven that North Korea believes that nuclear weapons protect the country from an attack by the United States, \u201cI don\u2019t see there being a lot of breakthroughs,\u201d she said. \u201cThere would never be a security guarantee that would be sufficient enough for denuclearization to happen.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTo get any kind of dialogue going, Ms. Coggins said the United States might have to accept a freeze in missile or nuclear tests instead of demanding that the North agree to give up its arsenal altogether.\n\n\u201cIt seems like there have been a lot of opportunities to win points and move the ball forward in terms of pulling back from crisis if that is in fact what the United States wants,\u201d said Ms. Coggins. \u201cAnd those opportunities haven\u2019t been seized.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump did not specify what he meant by the \u201cright conditions\u201d for talks, but Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, added context in remarks to reporters on Monday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLet us be completely clear,\u201d she said. \u201cDenuclearization must be the result of any dialogue with North Korea. Until then, the United States and the world must continue to make it known that North Korea\u2019s nuclear and missile programs are a dead end.\u201d\n\nMr. Yun had previously hinted that while getting North Korea to give up its weapons program was the ultimate goal of the United States, talks might begin on the basis of a freeze in the North\u2019s nuclear and missile testing.\n\n\u201cNorth Korea stopping missile tests and nuclear tests would be a great first step,\u201d Mr. Yun said last month at a conference in Tokyo.\n\nAnalysts said one of the obstacles to talks was that the Trump administration continuously sends inconsistent signals.\n\n\u201cThe administration isn\u2019t reading from one book on North Korea policy,\u201d said Ankit Panda, a senior editor at the Diplomat, a foreign affairs magazine, and a regional security analyst. \u201cWe\u2019ll hear different officials hint at different approaches.\u201d\n\nWith the United States and South Korea likely to resume joint military exercises soon, Mr. Panda warned of \u201ca spiral of U.S. and South Korean exercises being responded to by new provocations from the North.\u201d\n\nThere is more promise of talks continuing between North and South Korea. On Tuesday in Seoul, Kim Yong-chol, the chief North Korean delegate, had breakfast with Unification Minister Cho Myoung-gyon of South Korea and Suh Hoon, director of the South\u2019s National Intelligence Service. The two sides agreed that the North and South would continue to work to improve ties and help ensure peace on the peninsula.\n\nMs. Coggins said that such talks were not likely to lead to a change in the North\u2019s nuclear program, but they could lead to promising moves, like reunions of families that have been divided since the Korean War.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese are smaller things that are impactful and meaningful, in not just a sentimental way but to kind of bridge the social divide between North and South in a way that is productive going forward,\u201d said Ms. Coggins. She said such talks might even help bring about the release of three Americans still detained in North Korea.\n\nAnalysts said that if South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, accepts an invitation to visit Kim Jong-un in Pyongyang, Mr. Moon might broker talks between the United States and the North.\n\n\u201cThe scope and space for diplomacy is wider today than it was,\u201d said Scott Snyder, director of United States-Korea policy at the Council on Foreign Relations.", "title": "Trump Opens Door, Just Slightly, to Talking With North Korea", "authors": ["Motoko Rich"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 State and local law enforcement officials are fighting a Trump administration proposal to move oversight of a $275 million drug prevention program to the Justice Department, fearing that such a move would steer the country\u2019s drug-fighting strategy toward federal legal crackdowns and away from years of holistic, community-based approaches.\n\nA draft budget plan by the Office of Management and Budget would place federal law enforcement officers in charge of the drug trafficking grants rather than the Office of National Drug Control Policy, which has served as the White House\u2019s clearinghouse for drug strategy across the government and as a neutral arbiter in the historically territorial relationship between federal, state and local authorities.\n\nThe move would also effectively gut the drug office, whose influence has waned since President Trump took office. The office manages the grants, known as the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area Program, sending millions of federal dollars to 28 task forces across the country, composed of state, local and federal law enforcement officers, who use the money to combat drug trafficking in their communities.\n\nDirectors of the grant program have descended on Capitol Hill this week to try to bolster support from Congress, which would need to approve any White House changes to the drug office or the program. Lawmakers have shown little appetite to alter a federal initiative that benefits state and local authorities and constituents.", "title": "Trump Plan to Move Drug Prevention Program to Justice Dept. He also appeared to suggest that if his recently unveiled infrastructure plan were unsuccessful, it would be the Democrats\u2019 fault.\n\nThe threat on negotiations over the Obama-era program known as the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, comes as the Senate holds a rare open-ended debate on immigration. Mr. Trump ended the program in September, giving lawmakers until March 5 to agree on a replacement so that about 700,000 young immigrants are not deported. That deadline, however, is not as firm as the president suggests. A federal judge in California ordered the Trump administration to restart the program last month.\n\nIn a separate Twitter post on Tuesday, Mr. Trump suggested that the onus was on Democrats to come to an agreement on his infrastructure plan, which some lawmakers see as unrealistic.\n\nMr. Trump plans to meet with Republicans and Democrats this week to discuss his proposal.", "title": "Trump Pressures Democrats Over DACA and Infrastructure Plan", "authors": ["Eileen Sullivan"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "The president rejected a bipartisan immigration proposal put together by a group of senators last month, and the standoff over immigration helped lead to a three-day government shutdown. Instead, appropriating a term used to describe the younger immigrants, he said, \u201cAmericans are dreamers, too,\u201d a line that angered Democrats.\n\nMr. Trump expanded on that on Thursday at the Republican retreat, rejecting the term. \u201cSome people call it Dreamers,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s not Dreamers. Don\u2019t fall into that trap.\u201d\n\nThe president expressed pique at Democrats for not applauding during his State of the Union address, even when he hailed record-low unemployment rates among black and Hispanic people.\n\n\u201cWhen I made that statement the other night, there was zero movement from the Democrats,\u201d he said. \u201cThey sat there stone cold, no smile, no applause. And let\u2019s just take that off the table and move forward.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump did not acknowledge the criticism and moved quickly to remarks from Gov. She praised the students from the school who have been demanding action from politicians.\n\n\u201cI have been heartened to see children across this country using their voices to speak out and try to create change,\u201d Mrs. Trump said. \u201cThey\u2019re our future and they deserve a voice.\u201d\n\nMs. Sanders said later that the president also supported the students who had been protesting, even though he opposes the ban on assault weapons that many of them have been calling for.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the reason why he had a number of them here at the White House just last week,\u201d Ms. Sanders said. \u201cIt is one that is very important and should be listened to. We want to continue that dialogue as well as continue the conversations with state, local and federal officials.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe governors came away impressed by Mr. Trump\u2019s resolve to address the issue, according to Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana, a Democrat and the vice chairman of the association. \u201cI don\u2019t want my teachers armed. I don\u2019t think most Americans do.\u201d", "title": "Trump Says He Would Have Rushed in Unarmed to Stop School Shooting", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump, who is in Florida for the weekend, took to Twitter to proclaim his innocence and denounce the investigation a day after the release of the highly contentious classified memo, which he had authorized to be made public. The document claimed that top law enforcement officials had abused their powers to spy on a Trump campaign adviser, Carter Page, who was suspected of being an agent of Russia.\n\nThe memo, while trying to paint the origins of the Russia investigation as tainted, did nothing to clear Mr. Trump of either collusion or obstruction \u2014 the lines of inquiry being pursued by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.\n\nThe memo in fact undermined Republicans\u2019 efforts to cast doubt on the roots of the investigation by confirming that the inquiry was already underway when law enforcement officials obtained a warrant from a secret intelligence court to conduct surveillance on Mr. Page.", "title": "Trump Says Republican Memo \u2018Totally Vindicates\u2019 Him", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "In October, Mr. Trump boasted that under his administration, \u201cwe have stopped or eliminated more regulations in the last eight months than any president has done during an entire term. It\u2019s not even close.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump later compared the deregulatory actions in his first year in office to all of those taken during the full \u201cfour years, eight years, or, in one instance, 16 years\u201d in all previous presidential administrations.\n\nNo American president has served for 16 years; Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected to four presidential terms but only served for 12 years before dying in office.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBeyond that, comparing regulatory activity across administrations is an imperfect exercise. Standards for making and revoking rules are frequently changing, and courts and Congress can tweak and review them as well. But available metrics indicate that Mr. Trump is wrong to claim he has already stopped or eliminated more federal rules than any other president.\n\nThe Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs says it withdrew 635 rules in 2017 \u2014 a fast pace over a one-year period by any measure. But that is not more than any previous presidency \u2014 Mr. Obama withdrew 1,814 federal rules during his eight-year term and Mr. Bush eliminated 2,813 while in office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Program for Economic Research on Regulation, at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., combs the Federal Register to quantify the number of rule-making actions by regulatory agencies. University researchers found that federal regulations actually grew by about 0.65 percent during Mr. Trump\u2019s first year in office. They also noted that the rate of growth was slower than what it was annually from 1970 to 2016, when it averaged about 2.1 percent.\n\nExperts said that Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts to cut through the bureaucracy fall far short of the structural changes made under Ronald Reagan, who abolished entire regulatory agencies and eliminated some economic regulations in the transportation, telecommunications and energy industries. \u201cNothing Trump has done to date compares to that in terms of impact on Americans,\u201d Ms. Dudley said.\n\nCary Coglianese, the director of the Penn Program on Regulation at the University of Pennsylvania, agreed that \u201ca lot of the key institutions\u2019 processes that we have today, dealing with regulation, were established by Reagan.\u201d He pointed to the 1981 enactment of cost-benefit analyses and legal challenges to Mr. Reagan\u2019s deregulation policies that set current standards for administrative law, which govern how federal, state and local agencies operate.\n\nDeregulatory Successes and a Word of Caution\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s hyperbole not withstanding, he can claim some deregulatory successes.\n\nPrevious reports in The New York Times have detailed the Trump administration\u2019s lax enforcement of certain rules across several agencies. Early in his administration, Mr. Trump rolled back Obama-era rules though an unprecedented use of the 1996 Congressional Review Act, which allows Congress to \u201cdisapprove\u201d regulations issued within 90 days with the help of the president.\n\nDan Goldbeck of the American Action Forum, a nonprofit conservative group that promotes smaller government, said he sees a more concerted effort to streamline and trim back regulations under Mr. Trump than under many previous administrations.\n\nThe pace of consideration for significant regulations also has slowed. The Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs reviewed 60 rules that were described as economically significant between Jan. 21, 2017, to Jan. 20, 2018. The last time so few federal rules were reviewed in one-year was 1984, under Mr. Reagan.\n\nRegulations, Going Forward\n\nThe federal regulatory system will continue to evolve throughout \u2014 and beyond \u2014 Mr. Trump\u2019s time in office. So will his own approach, experts said.\n\nSo far in the 2018 fiscal year, the administration has shifted its deregulation efforts toward making substantive changes through the regular rule-making process, Mr. Goldbeck said. As evidence, he pointed to a new rule to amend the federal meat inspection process that the Department of Agriculture estimates could save millions of dollars annually, according to a department estimate. \u201cBut expect to see a delay\u201d in how much fruit these efforts will bear Mr. Goldbeck said. \u201cThat\u2019s just nature of the process.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Mr. Trump has reversed at least one of his own decisions, backtracking on his waiver to regulate state government drug-testing rules.\n\nAdditionally, there is no guarantee that regulations that have been waived will survive legal challenges, nor that they will remain in place in future presidential administrations. Once agencies complete the rule-making process, Ms. Dudley said, \u201cthey will likely have to defend their deregulatory action in court, where they may or may not succeed.\u201d Congress also could later decide to reverse Mr. Trump\u2019s actions.\n\n\u201cRegulatory change is not forever. They\u2019re not like diamonds,\u201d Mr. Coglianese said.", "title": "Trump Says \u2018No President Has Ever Cut So Many Regulations.\u2019 Not Quite.", "authors": ["Linda Qiu"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "The number of illegal immigrants who would eventually qualify for an amnesty, whether they are Dreamers or not, will probably be much larger than current estimates suggest. Back in 1986, one provision of the Immigration Reform and Control Act was expected to grant amnesty to 400,000 farm workers. In fact, 1.1 million applied. When California granted illegal immigrants the opportunity to get a driver\u2019s license in 2013, Department of Motor Vehicles offices were swamped, with illegal immigrants coming in at twice the expected rate.\n\nAny attempt at limiting chain migration creates a new problem. There is a waiting list of about 3.9 million chain-migration applicants, and many have waited years for the golden ticket. Amazingly enough, some potential immigrants from the Philippines have been waiting since Oct. 1, 1994. Many people will think that we need to grandfather in those applicants. But that would require temporary rules that might allow, say, 400,000 immigrants per year until the queue was cleared out.\n\nWe should also be skeptical of claims that an amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants, many of whom have little schooling, or even just to the Dreamers, who typically have a high school diploma, will be an economic boon. The amnesty is going to be expensive. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the net cost of granting amnesty to the Dreamers (the additional expenses minus the taxes they pay) would run to $25 billion over the next 10 years. An amnesty will be far costlier if it is extended to the entire illegal population, which is less skilled on average.\n\nSo the first step in any deal will be \u2014 must be \u2014 securing the border. A deal where enforcement is the first priority ensures that illegal immigration will be greatly curtailed, and this provision alone may well be worth its weight in gold. Past administrations, both Democratic and Republican, looked the other way as illegal immigration graduated from a relatively minor problem (the 1986 immigration act granted amnesty to fewer than three million illegal immigrants) into a major distortion of the immigration system.\n\nA sensible immigration policy that generates economic benefits for Americans and for immigrants already here ensures that we can better adapt to the economic shocks that will visit us in the next few decades. And the best way to maximize those benefits is to filter the pool of persons who want to migrate.\n\nBefore jumping in to claim that such \u201cfiltering\u201d is un-American, it\u2019s worth remembering that anything short of open borders inevitably involves filtering. Between the 1920s and 1965, the filtering was done through national origin, giving preference to immigrants born in Western European countries. Since 1965, we have preferred immigrants who have relatives already living here. Filtering on the basis of economic potential ensures that immigration generates the largest possible economic gain for our country.\n\nThere is some concern that whatever deal the Trump administration reaches will be easily undone by the next administration. I\u2019m not so sure this is a valid point. History teaches us that it is extremely difficult to change immigration policy. The stars aligned only twice in the past century: once in the 1920s and then again in the 1960s.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Sets Up a Grand Bargain on Immigration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "While enthusiastic about the handful of Senate candidates, including Mr. Romney, he has helped recruit, Mr. McConnell offered a sober assessment of what the party faces in the first midterm election of Mr. Trump\u2019s unpopular presidency.\n\n\u201cThe odds are that we will lose seats in the House and the Senate,\u201d Mr. McConnell said in the 30-minute interview in his Capitol office, adding: \u201cHistory tells you that, the fired-up nature of the political left tells you that. We go into this cleareyed that this is going to be quite a challenging election.\u201d\n\nBut Republicans have a significant structural advantage as they try to protect their one-seat majority in November: They are defending just eight seats, while Democrats have to protect 26, including those of two independents who caucus with them. Of the seats Democrats are trying to retain, 10 are in states that Mr. Trump carried in 2016.\n\nAnd after struggling to woo top-tier candidates in some states, Republicans are starting to find more success as they receive a lift from the tax overhaul they passed in December. In addition to Mr. Romney, Representative Kevin Cramer of North Dakota, after heavy lobbying by Mr. McConnell and Mr. Trump, reversed himself and said on Friday that he would challenge Senator Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat seeking re-election in a state that the president won by 36 points.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvisers to Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, in an indication that he intends to challenge Senator Bill Nelson, a third-term Democrat, have moved to set up a \u201csuper PAC,\u201d according to two Republican officials. And Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee, after saying he would not run again and ridiculing Mr. Trump, indicated this past week that he may not retire after all.\n\nMr. Corker\u2019s public misgivings, however, have complicated the Tennessee race, where Representative Marsha Blackburn, a staunch conservative, was already lining up support, and where Democrats landed a formidable candidate, former Gov. Phil Bredesen.\n\nMr. McConnell, who is close to Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, an ally of Mr. Corker, was guarded in his comments about the election, but he chuckled when pressed on the incumbent\u2019s apparent change of heart.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt does underscore that people want to be in the Senate,\u201d he said, trying to make the best of what could become a messy primary contest. \u201cAnd that\u2019s a different environment from late summer, early fall,\u201d when the Republicans were stung by their failure to repeal the Affordable Care Act.\n\nEqually delicate is the fate of Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi, who at 80 has had a series of health problems and whose seat is being eyed by a hard-line state senator, Chris McDaniel, who nearly beat him in a bitter 2014 primary race.\n\nMr. McConnell called it \u201cpremature\u201d to assess the prospect of a special election this year to replace Mr. Cochran, but did acknowledge that \u201cthere could be\u201d one. \u201cIt\u2019s up to Senator Cochran to make that decision,\u201d he said.\n\nPrivately, though, Republicans are already scrambling to protect Mr. Cochran\u2019s seat. Party leaders fear that a candidacy by Mr. McDaniel could create a competitive race, and perhaps even spiral into a debacle similar to what happened in Alabama last year, when Roy S. Moore\u2019s loss gave the state\u2019s Democrats their first Senate election victory in 25 years.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
