McMaster, who had said at a security conference in Germany on Saturday that the indictment provided \u201cincontrovertible\u201d evidence that Russia had interfered in the American democratic system.\n\nMr. Trump said his adviser had \u201cforgot to say that the results of the 2016 election were not impacted or changed by the Russians and that the only Collusion was between Russia and Crooked H, the DNC and the Dems.\u201d The nation\u2019s intelligence agencies believe that it is not possible to make such a calculation about the election outcome.\n\nThen, on Sunday, Mr. Trump said that he had \u201cnever said Russia did not meddle in the election,\u201d quoting a comment he had made in a 2016 presidential debate.\n\n\u201cI said \u2018it may be Russia, or China or another country or group, or it may be a 400 pound genius sitting in bed and playing with his computer,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cThe Russian \u2018hoax\u2019 was that the Trump campaign colluded with Russia \u2014 it never did!\u201d\n\nYet he has repeatedly denied that Russia was behind any meddling, going so far in November as to suggest that he believed President Vladimir V. Putin\u2019s denials of interference over the conclusions of American intelligence agencies.\n\nMr. Trump also called Mr. Schiff, the California congressman, \u201cLiddle Adam Schiff\u201d and branded him \u201cthe leakin\u2019 monster of no control,\u201d even as he praised him for his criticism of Mr. Obama\u2019s muted response to the Russian threat.\n\nThe president in the past has traded bitter Twitter messages with Mr. Schiff, accusing him of leaking classified information from the House Intelligence Committee\u2019s investigation into Russia\u2019s actions. Mr. Schiff shot back at Mr. Trump on Sunday, saying on Twitter that \u201cif McMaster can stand up to Putin, why can\u2019t you?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInitially, Mr. Trump had been swayed by advisers who described the indictment announced on Friday as a victory for him, since it identified particular bad actors outside the campaign and used the word \u201cunwitting\u201d to describe the contacts with the Trump campaign.\n\nBut as the weekend went on, Mr. Trump\u2019s longstanding frustrations with an inquiry that he has branded a \u201cwitch hunt\u201d once again came to the fore. While the deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, had noted repeatedly in announcing the indictment that it does not say that Russia changed the outcome of the election, Mr. Trump was angry because his own team had not gone further in his defense.\n\nThat included General McMaster, who, as an active duty military officer, takes the constrictions on what he can say politically very seriously. When he spoke in Germany, Mr. McMaster did not believe he could go further than the cold facts of the document, a reality that deeply frustrated the president, two administration officials said.\n\nAlthough incensed by coverage of the Russia investigation, Mr. Trump spent part of the weekend focused on the school shooting. On Sunday, the White House announced that he would hold a \u201clistening session\u201d with high school students and teachers in Washington on Wednesday, and meet with state and local officials on school safety on Thursday.\n\nMr. Trump also called three local officials, including Christine Hunschofsky, the mayor of Parkland. In an interview, Ms. Hunschofsky said she was struck by how affected the president had seemed by his hospital visit.\n\n\u201cHe gave his condolences, and then he talked quite a bit,\u201d Ms. Hunschofsky said. \u201cHe said he had talked to somebody recovering in the hospital. I remember he kept saying, \u2018How do you recover from that?\u2019\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Evolution From Relief to Fury Over the Russia Indictment", "authors": ["Katie Rogers", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Infrastructure privatization raises costs for basic services, undermines transparency and is frequently used to keep government costs \u201coff the books.\u201d Disastrous examples in the United States include a deal by the water company Suez and the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to privatize the water system in Bayonne, N.J., which has left some residents in danger of losing their homes after skyrocketing water rates.\n\nAlthough business executives, national officials and other global financiers and deal-makers may disagree with Mr. Trump on trade, they are with his administration on infrastructure privatization. The World Bank, to take a prominent example, has a long history of pushing the privatization of people\u2019s most basic infrastructure need \u2014 water. Perhaps the best-known example is Cochabamba, Bolivia, where popular opposition to the privatization of the water system forced a return to a publicly run system in 2000. In another failed privatization, this time branded as a public-private partnership, residents of Manila face unreliable access, infrastructure neglect and rates that are unaffordable for many.\n\nWhile the World Bank claims to have no preference between public and private infrastructure, promoting public-private partnerships remains its bread and butter. At a 2016 training event, bank staff learned \u201chow to promote water P.P.P. projects\u201d and convince government officials \u201cof the interest of the P.P.P. approach.\u201d What\u2019s more, bank leadership is now evangelizing what it calls the \u201cCascade\u201d approach, which prescribes the bank to \u201cfirst consider private investment for projects; then public-private partnerships; and if the first two are not available then, only then, consider public finance.\u201d\n\nThe budget of the World Bank\u2019s International Development Association, which advances the bank\u2019s development priorities in the lowest-income countries, recently added $2.5 billion to provide corporations with risk insurance, guarantees, loans and equity investments.\n\nThe Trump administration and World Bank leadership clearly have shared interests, despite Mr. Trump\u2019s threat of deep cuts to development funding. The bank\u2019s president, Jim Yong Kim, has raised eyebrows by offering bank staff members to advise Mr. Trump on infrastructure policy. At a World Bank conference last October, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin praised what he called the Cascade approach\u2019s key pillar: that the World Bank \u201cwill not provide financing if the private sector is able to do so.\u201d Perhaps this shared pro-corporate vision is why Mr. Trump has proposed funding the World Bank at levels close to the Obama-era budget last year.\n\nAs Puerto Rico\u2019s dire situation proves, the United States, like much of the rest of the world, has critical infrastructure problems to fix. But the privatization solution promoted by the Trump administration and popular among global elite is not the answer. Already, the toll that privatization takes has provoked resistance from Pittsburgh to Lagos.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Faux-Populist Infrastructure Plan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Here is a history of the president\u2019s responses to sexual misconduct and abuse allegations.\n\nRob Porter is \u2018very sad now\u2019\n\nMr. Porter announced his resignation on Wednesday after the news surfaced that his two former wives, Colbie Holderness and Jennifer Willoughby, said he had been physically and verbally abusive.\n\nImage Rob Porter, left, on Monday. Credit Pete Marovich for The New York Times\n\nThe allegations, which Mr. Porter denied, were reportedly known to some people in the White House, including John F. Kelly, the president\u2019s chief of staff. But Mr. Trump praised Mr. Porter when asked about him on Friday. \u201cHe worked very hard,\u201d the president said, adding that he was surprised by the allegations.\n\n\u201cHe did a very good job when he was in the White House, and we hope he has a wonderful career, and he will have a great career ahead of him,\u201d he said. \u201cBut it was very sad when we heard about it, and certainly he\u2019s also very sad now.\u201d\n\nRoy Moore \u2018totally denies it\u2019\n\nIn November, Mr. Trump defended Roy S. Moore, the Republican Senate candidate in Alabama, who had been accused of sexually assaulting and preying on teenage girls.\n\nImage Roy S. Moore in December. Credit Bob Miller for The New York Times\n\nMr. Moore denied the allegations, which dated back decades and dogged him throughout the campaign. He lost the race to Doug Jones, a Democrat, despite the president\u2019s support.", "title": "Trump\u2019s History of Defending Men Accused of Hurting Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Also reaping payments for event production services was Hargrove Inc., of Lanham, Md., a company that plans trade shows and other events, which was paid $25 million. David Monn of New York, who also is known for orchestrating society events and planned a state dinner for former President Barack Obama, was paid $3.7 million, which the operative said was primarily to plan two events, one of which was billed as a \u201ccandlelight dinner\u201d attended by Mr. and Mrs. Trump, and Vice President Mike Pence and his wife, Karen Pence.\n\nThe committee spent heavily on administrative expenses, including $9.4 million on travel, $500,000 on legal fees, $237,000 on fund-raising and $4.6 million on salaries and benefits for its 208 employees. That included $100,000 paid to Rick Gates, the former Trump campaign aide, who has since been indicted on a host of charges by the special counsel investigating Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election, according to the operative who worked with the inaugural committee.\n\nMr. Barrack, a California real estate investor, picked Mr. Gates to help lead the committee\u2019s efforts. But many people with long experience in Republican politics remained wary of Mr. Trump as the inauguration approached and did not get involved with the committee.\n\nThe inaugural committee official said wrap-up costs were more significant than had been anticipated, and indicated that the committee\u2019s finances were affected by its lack of a large deal for broadcast rights to the inaugural balls. But its brisk fund-raising \u2014 the $107 million it raised was about twice as much as Mr. Obama\u2019s inaugural committee raised for the festivities around his 2009 swearing-in \u2014 allowed it to cover all its costs.\n\nThe inaugural committee closed out October with $2.8 million in the bank, according to the tax filing. It indicated in the release that the remaining funds also would be donated to charity once remaining expenses were paid.\n\nThe tax return indicated that the committee already donated to six nonprofit groups, and inaugural officials pointed out that the $5 million in total charitable donations to those groups was more than Mr. Obama\u2019s committee donated.\n\nAmong the recipients of charitable donations, the White House Historical Association received $1 million, while the Vice President\u2019s Residence Foundation, which is devoted to decorating and furnishing the vice president\u2019s residence on the grounds of the Naval Observatory in Washington, received $750,000.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Inaugural Committee Paid $26 Million to Firm of First Lady\u2019s Adviser", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump infrastructure blueprint is almost certain to call for expensive new roads, bridges, airports and other projects in areas that are increasingly vulnerable to rising waters and other threats from a warming planet. Engineers and researchers say that construction plans should consider these design constraints at the outset. Their concern is that a plan led by a White House that has both discounted climate science and weakened climate change regulations could mean that costly projects may be vulnerable to damage or, in a worst-case scenario, quickly rendered obsolete by the changing environment.\n\n\u201cThe impact of not considering climate change when planning infrastructure means you end up building the wrong thing, in the wrong place, to the wrong standards,\u201d said Michael Kuby, a professor of geographical sciences and urban planning at Arizona State University and contributing author to the National Climate Assessment, the federal government\u2019s most comprehensive scientific study of the effect of global warming on the United States. \u201cThat\u2019s a whole lot of waste.\u201d\n\nClimate change already poses one of the most significant threats to the nation\u2019s infrastructure, according to dozens of scientific and engineering studies, including several prepared by the federal government. A 2017 report by the Environmental Protection Agency concluded that, through the end of the century, up to $280 billion will be needed to adapt the nation\u2019s roads and railways to the effects of a warming climate.\n\nA White House spokeswoman, who asked to remain anonymous because the plan was not yet public, declined to discuss whether climate change reports were considered in the preparation of Mr. Trump\u2019s blueprint. \u201cThe president\u2019s team spent almost a full year formulating his infrastructure plan and all relevant scientific data was considered,\u201d she said in an emailed statement.\n\nSince the beginning of his administration, Mr. Trump and his appointees have steadily worked to roll back climate change regulations. Mr. Trump\u2019s E.P.A. chief, Scott Pruitt, has taken the lead role in the administration\u2019s efforts to undo climate policies and question the validity of climate science. On Wednesday, Mr. Pruitt suggested that global warming could benefit humanity.\n\nThose views are contradicted by research conducted by his own agency.\n\nThe 2017 E.P.A. report warned that some 6,000 bridges nationwide face a greater risk of damage in coming decades from the effects of a warming climate. It provides analysis showing that \u201cproactive adaptation\u201d \u2014 essentially, planning for global warming before you build \u2014 could save the government up to 70 percent in future costs of repairing damage caused by climate change-driven weather events such as deluges, coastal flooding and heat waves.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Infrastructure Plan May Ignore Climate Change. It Could Be Costly.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA private corporation has a fiduciary obligation to make a profit. The government is supposed to be providing a public service,\u201d Mr. Sclar said.\n\nThe president\u2019s plan recasts the federal government as a minority stakeholder in the nation\u2019s new infrastructure projects. Half of the $200 billion promised over 10 years will be used for incentives to spur even greater contributions from states, localities and the private sector. Mr. Trump also wants to speed up the approval process.\n\nThe White House budget, separately released on Monday, also gives federal agencies the authority to sell assets that would be better managed by state, local or private entities in cases where a sale would \u201coptimize taxpayer value.\u201d The budget suggests that Ronald Reagan Washington National and Dulles International Airports could be among the assets ripe for new owners.\n\nComing up with the $200 billion in federal funding will not be easy. Republicans have already ballooned the deficit in last week\u2019s spending agreement and with their tax cuts. Democrats are unlikely to go along with cuts that would offset the cost of Mr. Trump\u2019s plan.\n\nWith his infrastructure framework, the president is rethinking Washington\u2019s role.\n\nEconomic development has been the justification for federal involvement going back to the country\u2019s efforts in the early 1800s to improve harbors and rivers for navigation. It animated the 1902 Reclamation Act that funded irrigation projects that developed the western United States.\n\n\u201cNational economic development benefits were the cornerstone of federal support,\u201d said Debra Knopman, a principal researcher at the RAND Corporation. \u201cThat was the point.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPublic health, safety and national defense were added in the 20th century as core values, when the government developed the national highway system and passed the Clean Water Act.\n\n\u201cNow, they\u2019re putting out incentive programs that don\u2019t have to generate national or regional economic developments,\u201d said Ms. Knopman, the lead author of a new 110-page RAND report on transportation and water infrastructure in the United States. \u201cIt may happen, but that\u2019s not what they\u2019re interested in and that\u2019s not the way they\u2019re screening these projects.\u201d\n\nThe math for the infrastructure plan also relies on a lot of unknowns.\n\nAlong with private investors, cities and states are being counted on to put up significant funds. They have a need. States have been struggling for years to rejuvenate creaky roads, bridges and ports. And even if the plan appears to put much of the onus on them to finance projects, any additional federal funding is welcome.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cStates won\u2019t look down their nose at adding more money for infrastructure,\u201d said John Hicks, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers. \u201cIt\u2019s seen primarily as a positive, because it continues to shine light on a shared need of infrastructure improvement.\u201d\n\nBut cities and states are not necessarily flush with cash for new infrastructure projects.\n\nCongress has thrown their finances into upheaval, with local lawmakers still trying to come to grips with the effects of the $1.5 trillion tax overhaul that was passed last year. Many states have already expressed concern that it will be hard for them to increase state and local taxes, because deductions on them have been limited.\n\nSome are considering other ways, such as gasoline taxes, to raise funds, but it may not be enough to fund new infrastructure projects. A report released last month by Fitch, the ratings agency, found that many states could see their tax revenue fall from the changes to the individual and corporate taxation laws.\n\nDavid Damschen, Utah\u2019s treasurer, said his state faces many infrastructure challenges as it works to accommodate a growing population, expand its stock of affordable housing and improve the transportation system. He said Utah was already looking for new sources of tax revenue to fund projects because sales tax and gas tax revenue had been declining.\n\nBut Mr. Damschen also noted that public-private partnerships do not tend to work well in his state. \u201cWhen things roll out, you\u2019ll find what the market will do with these ideas,\u201d he said. \u201cSometimes creative ideas don\u2019t always have the level of acceptance in the marketplace as you hoped.\u201d\n\nThe amount of federal funds \u2014 $20 billion a year \u2014 will be spread very thin when stretched across the entire country. It is also unclear how much new money, as opposed to repurposed funds, the federal government is actually supplying.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne analysis by the Penn-Wharton Budget Model at the University of Pennsylvania said that other pieces of the White House budget could end up reducing federal infrastructure spending by $55 billion over 10 years \u2014 despite the president\u2019s new plan.\n\nDouglas Holtz-Eakin, former director of the Congressional Budget Office and the president of the conservative American Action Forum, complimented aspects of the president\u2019s initiative that dealt with streamlining regulations and using federal credit guarantees. But he doubted the promised total could be reached.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to get the $200 billion to $1.5 trillion, if you do the arithmetic,\u201d he said.\n\nBeyond the math, the revamped selection standards, too, are untested. The new criteria likely stemmed from the administration\u2019s attempt to distinguish its program and try something new.\n\nIndeed, criteria announced just last year by the Trump administration for other transportation and infrastructure grants relied on more traditional standards. One lists safety, overall condition, economic competitiveness, environmental sustainability and quality of life as \u201cprimary selection criteria.\u201d Another cites \u201csupport for national or regional economic vitality\u201d as the No. 1 one objective, while coming up with new money was second.\n\nThe new plan \u201cdoesn\u2019t allocate money in terms of congestion, economic need or the public good,\u201d said Martin Klepper, the former executive director of the Transportation Department\u2019s Build America Bureau. \u201cIt does it mostly on the basis of the leverage issue.\u201d\n\nMr. Klepper, who spent decades in the private sector developing, financing and selling large infrastructure projects, was recruited to lead the bureau in the final weeks of the Obama administration. He said he decided to take the job even after the Democrats lost, because of the new administration\u2019s commitment to public-private partnership and Mr. Trump\u2019s promise of a major infrastructure plan.\n\nHe resigned in November 2017.\n\n\u201cI left because I was pretty frustrated and disappointed with where the program was going,\u201d Mr. Klepper said. \u201cNo one has any idea to the extent with which states and localities will be able to come up with the money to match the federal government.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Infrastructure Plan Puts Burden on State and Private Money", "authors": ["Patricia Cohen", "Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump on Monday will propose offering $100 billion in federal incentives to encourage cities and states to invest in road, bridge and other building projects, the centerpiece of a plan to spur $1.5 trillion in infrastructure spending over the next decade without devoting significant federal money.\n\nThe proposal, to be unveiled the same day as Mr. Trump\u2019s 2019 budget, faces long odds on Capitol Hill, where members of both parties \u2014 particularly Democrats \u2014 are skeptical of any plan that fails to create a dedicated new funding stream to address the nation\u2019s crumbling infrastructure. Lawmakers are also doubtful that such a small federal investment will be sufficient to spur an infrastructure spending boom.\n\nThe president, who plans to invite Democrats and Republicans to the White House this week to call for a sweeping bipartisan infrastructure initiative, will propose to devote a total of $200 billion in federal dollars to the program, according to senior White House officials who previewed the plan on the condition of anonymity. Half of that amount would go toward matching funds that states and cities commit to financing their own infrastructure projects.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s plan, the officials said, would also provide $50 billion in block grants to governors to fund rural infrastructure projects, and a $20 billion increase in loans and bonds to finance transportation, water, rail and other projects. A major element of the proposal would be to speed the approval of such projects to two years, the latest in a series of attempts by the Trump administration to reduce government regulations, including a host of environmental restrictions, that corporations say are costly and burdensome.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Infrastructure Plan: Modest Federal Incentives, Facing Long Odds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 A week ago, President Trump stood before Congress as an improbable unifier. \u201cTonight,\u201d he declared, \u201cI call upon all of us to set aside our differences, to seek out common ground and to summon the unity we need to deliver for the people.\u201d\n\nThis week, Mr. Trump is back to being a disrupter. After accusing Democrats of being un-American and even treasonous for refusing to applaud during his State of the Union speech, he said on Tuesday that he would welcome a government shutdown if he cannot reach a spending deal with Congress that tightens immigration laws.\n\nA week ago, Mr. Trump called for a grand compromise with Democrats on the legal status of the undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers \u2014 a deal, he said, \u201cwhere nobody gets everything they want, but where our country gets the critical reforms it needs.\u201d After all, the president added, \u201cAmericans are dreamers too.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, his chief of staff, John F. Kelly, said that many Dreamers failed to register for protected status with the government because they were \u201cwere too afraid to sign up\u201d or were \u201ctoo lazy to get off their asses.\u201d He said he doubted Mr. Trump would extend the March 5 deadline that shields them from deportation.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Latest Surprise: Shutdown Might Be a Good Idea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The Fourth Circuit, by a 9-to-4 vote, ruled that the latest ban, like an earlier one, most likely violated the Constitution\u2019s Establishment Clause, which forbids religious discrimination by the government. The majority based its conclusion in large measure on statements Mr. Trump has made as a candidate and while in office.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Ninth Circuit, by contrast, ruled on statutory grounds, saying that Mr. Trump had exceeded the authority Congress had given him over immigration and had violated a part of the immigration laws barring discrimination in the issuance of visas.\n\nThe Supreme Court will consider both the constitutional and statutory arguments in the appeal from the Ninth Circuit\u2019s decision, which is likely to be heard in April.\n\nWriting for the majority in Monday\u2019s decision, Chief Judge Roger L. Gregory said that judicial second-guessing of the president was a delicate matter but was required in this case.\n\n\u201cOur constitutional system creates a strong presumption of legitimacy for presidential action, and we often defer to the political branches on issues related to immigration and national security,\u201d Judge Gregory wrote. \u201cBut the disposition in this case is compelled by the highly unusual facts here.\u201d\n\n\u201cPlaintiffs offer undisputed evidence that the president of the United States has openly and often expressed his desire to ban those of Islamic faith from entering the United States,\u201d he wrote.\n\nIn dissent, Judge Paul V. Niemeyer said the majority had made a serious mistake in considering Mr. Trump\u2019s political comments to interpret his executive order.\n\n\u201cThe public debate over the administration\u2019s foreign policy and, in particular, its immigration policy, is indeed intense and thereby seductively tempts courts to effect a politically preferred result when confronted with such issues,\u201d Judge Niemeyer wrote. He explained that the final cost would be determined by the size, scope and length of the parade.\n\n\u201cWe will continue to work with you folks if we decide to continue forward with this initiative,\u201d Mr. Mulvaney said. \u201cOf course, you\u2019d have to appropriate funds for it or we would have to find funds that we\u2019ve already appropriated.\u201d\n\nStan Collender, a former staff member on the House and Senate budget committees, said that the funding for the parade could be found without a formal budget request by using existing money already in the Department of Defense budget or possibly from the Department of Homeland Security or the National Park Service.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Military Parade Could Cost $30 Million", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "After the indictment on Friday Mr. Trump declared in a Twitter post that \u201cthe results of the election were not impacted. The Trump campaign did nothing wrong \u2014 no collusion!\u201d He made no mention of Russia as a \u201crevisionist power,\u201d the description used in his own National Security Strategy, or of the elaborate $1.2 million-a-month effort that the indictment indicated Russia\u2019s Internet Research Agency spent in an effort to discredit the election system and ultimately to support his candidacy.\n\nVice President Mike Pence, speaking this past week in Washington, misstated American intelligence conclusions about the election hacking, arguing \u201cit is the universal conclusion of our intelligence communities that none of those efforts had any effect on the outcome of the 2016 election.\u201d The intelligence chiefs have said they have not, and cannot, reach such a conclusion.\n\nSergey V. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe accusations and counteraccusations about cyber- and social media attacks were the main point of division between the Americans and the Russians, but hardly the only ones expressed at the conference.\n\nMr. Kislyak argued that the Trump administration\u2019s new nuclear strategy involved the manufacture of low-yield weapons and made nuclear war more probable. The Americans argued they were just matching Russian capabilities and charged that Moscow was in continued violation of the Intermediate Nuclear Forces agreement, limiting tactical weapons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet the cyberattacks on the Democratic National Committee and others, and the use of Facebook, Twitter and other social media platforms to spread propaganda, dominated the discussion and reflected how quickly the use of these techniques has become the new battleground in a very different kind of post-Cold War conflict.\n\nThe White House cybercoordinator, Rob Joyce, was particularly direct in his accusations that Russia was behind the broad attack on Ukraine last June, called \u201cNotPetya.\u201d He described the attack as \u201cindiscriminate\u201d and noted that it paralyzed operations far beyond Ukraine, the intended target, and included the Maersk shipping system. He said the United States would retaliate, but did not say how, adding \u201cwe will not telegraph these punches.\u201d\n\nMr. Joyce is no newcomer to offensive cyberoperations; previously he ran the Tailored Access Operations unit of the National Security Agency, overseeing American cyberaction against other counties. \u201cWe are going to conduct cyberoperations,\u201d he said. But \u201cwe need to do it in a responsible, balanced way.\u201d\n\nGeneral McMaster, in his comments, argued that Russia had bridged the partisan divides in the United States, citing a 98 to 2 vote in the Senate to impose Russian sanctions. He did not mention that the administration has yet to impose those sanctions, saying the threat of them alone has begun to change Russian behavior.\n\n\u201cThat sanctions bill has not yet been used as a tool against the Russians,\u201d Christopher Painter, a former coordinator for cyberissues at the State Department, who also attended the conference. \u201cThe question now is whether they will actually use it to create consequences. I don\u2019t know.\u201d\n\nGeneral McMaster was questioned by the chairman of the foreign affairs committee of Russian Federation Council, the country\u2019s equivalent of the Senate, about whether the United States was ready to enter into some kind of negotiation with Russia about the use of cyberweapons.\n\nIt was not the time for that yet, General McMaster said, adding, \u201cI\u2019m surprised there are any Russian cyberexperts available based on how active they have been in undermining the democracies\u201d of the world.", "title": "Trump\u2019s National Security Chief Calls Russian Interference \u2018Incontrovertible\u2019", "authors": ["David E. Sanger"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump\u2019s nominee to lead the Indian Health Service has withdrawn his name from consideration for the position, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Humans Services said Wednesday.\n\nThe withdrawal of the nominee, Robert Weaver, follows Wall Street Journal reports that said he had inaccurately represented his qualifications to the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs after his nomination in October. Trump in 2016. Representative Martha McSally of Arizona may not have, either, but she will not say. And Senator Dean Heller of Nevada now insists that he did cast his ballot for Mr. Trump, but for many months, he would not reveal his vote.\n\nSenator Bob Corker supported Mr. Trump, but seemed to regret it last year when he concluded that the country had deposited an unruly toddler in the Oval Office.\n\nYet as these Republicans pursue a Senate run this year \u2014 or in the case of Mr. Corker, reconsiders one \u2014 they are essentially making peace with a president they once shunned. Their hopes for a d\u00e9tente with Mr. Trump, who effectively staged a hostile takeover of a party he joined only in 2012, reflect the realization that rank-and-file Republicans have come to embrace the president.\n\nThere is little appetite on the right for Trump skeptics in the halls of Congress.\n\n\u201cTo the activists, those who vote consistently in Republican primaries, it\u2019s very much Trump\u2019s party,\u201d said Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona, who effectively decided against running for re-election because he did not want to accommodate such voters.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Republican Critics Find a Sudden Need for His Support", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Jason Grumet, the president of the Bipartisan Policy Center, an organization in Washington that favors an agreement, said Mr. Trump clearly wanted to reach an immigration deal but was not receiving good advice about how to achieve that. \u201cLast night\u2019s speech didn\u2019t preclude a deal, but it sure squandered an opportunity to advance one,\u201d he said.\n\nIn the address, Mr. Trump offered what he called an \u201copen hand\u201d on the issue of immigration and challenged Congress to \u201cfinally get the job done\u201d on a long-delayed overhaul of the system. But in describing the outlines of a plan that he said \u201cfulfills my ironclad pledge to sign a bill that puts America first,\u201d Mr. Trump turned to the disturbing imagery of teenage girls murdered by immigrant members of the MS-13 gang.\n\nWith their parents in the audience, Mr. Trump described the night that \u201cthese two precious girls were brutally murdered while walking together in their hometown.\u201d Asking the parents to stand, the president said: \u201cTonight, everyone in this chamber is praying for you. Everyone in America is grieving for you.\u201d\n\nDemocrats, in particular, reacted angrily, saying the president was linking immigration to gang violence and murder. Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, called the remarks \u201cdangerous\u201d and counterproductive to resolving the debate over the fate of the Dreamers.\n\n\u201cThe president presents himself as generous toward Dreamers, but he\u2019s holding them hostage to the most extreme anti-immigrant agenda in generations,\u201d Ms. Pelosi said. \u201cWe heard more insulting words of ignorance and prejudice \u2014 prejudice toward patriotic immigrant families last night.\u201d\n\nThey also heard Mr. Trump try to appropriate the term Dreamer with his applause line about Americans. Publicly and privately, the president has recoiled at using the nickname, instead referring to them as \u201cthe DACA people\u201d or the \u201cfolks from DACA,\u201d after the acronym for President Barack Obama\u2019s program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, that gives them work permits and protection from deportation. During a White House dinner with the top Democrats in Congress in the fall, Mr. Trump urged them not to use the word Dreamers in public.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe has experimented with phrases to turn the argument around for months. \u201cWe must also have heart and compassion for unemployed, struggling and forgotten Americans,\u201d Mr. Trump said in September when he ordered an end to the DACA program. \u201cAbove all else, we must remember that young Americans have dreams, too.\u201d\n\nThe term Dreamers was tied to legislation that has never passed Congress called the Development, Relief, and Education for Alien Minors Act, or the Dream Act. Mr. Krikorian said that for too long, liberals had been able to set the terms of the debate. \u201cThe very notion, Dreamers, was a marketing coup quite frankly,\u201d he said. \u201cThe president\u2019s attempt at taking back the term Dreamers is likely to resonate.\u201d\n\nStephen Miller, the president\u2019s top immigration adviser, and other aides devised a four-part plan to carefully navigate the difficult political terrain that has prevented numerous earlier attempts to overhaul immigration during the past two decades.\n\nPart 1 was a concession to immigration activists that would give 1.8 million young immigrants a path to citizenship, effectively restoring and expanding Mr. Obama\u2019s DACA program by enshrining it into law. Part 2 would create a $25 billion trust fund for a border wall. Part 3 would end decades of rules allowing legal immigrants to bring their families to the country. And Part 4 would shut down a lottery program aimed at encouraging immigration from underrepresented countries.\n\nThe White House described the plan last week as \u201cextremely generous\u201d and predicted that it would gain wide support from both sides of the aisle. That was probably overly optimistic.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSenators from both parties met before Mr. Trump\u2019s speech on Tuesday to continue negotiations \u2014 but without much regard to his four-point plan. One Democratic aide said that the group was largely ignoring the president\u2019s proposals and was making good progress toward a measure that could receive at least the 60 votes needed to break a filibuster. Staff members for the group are scheduled to continue discussions over the weekend.\n\nWhite House officials dismissed the criticism, pointing to instant polls that showed that large numbers of people agreed with the president\u2019s immigration comments and noting that the speech drew positive reaction from Republicans, conservatives and law enforcement officials.\n\n\u201cIt made by heart swell to hear him say Americans have dreams, too,\u201d said Mary Ann Mendoza, whose son was killed in a head-on collision with a car driven by an illegal immigrant who was high on meth. She said Mr. Trump had made a good-faith immigration proposal. \u201cI think the Democrats need to embrace that. They need to go into it with an open mind and get to work.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, rejected the notion that Mr. Trump was refusing to compromise as \u201claughable.\u201d She pointed out that the president\u2019s plan would provide legal status for nearly three times the number of people who had signed up for protection from deportation under the DACA program started by Mr. Obama.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s advisers insisted that Democratic complaints were more evidence that liberal lawmakers did not want to find a solution to fix the immigration system and protect young immigrants.\n\n\u201cThey simply are sitting on their hands and being angry instead of coming to the table to have real negotiations,\u201d Ms. Sanders said Wednesday on CNN.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Speech Leaves Two Sides Further Apart Than Ever on Immigration", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "What companies do with the trillions of dollars they\u2019re bringing back to the United States, and the money they will save each year on their tax bills, will in large part determine whether the plan is a success or a failure.\n\nAs the tax cuts kick in, companies have laid out a variety of uses for the money. Some are paying out one-time bonuses to employees. Others are raising salaries. Others plan to open new factories.\n\nIn the fourth quarter, American companies\u2019 investments in things like factories and business equipment grew by 6.8 percent. That was the fastest growth rate since 2014, but far from the giant surge in capital spending that was promised ahead of the tax overhaul.\n\nBut the buying back of shares is also at record levels.\n\nAlmost 100 American corporations have trumpeted such plans in the past month. American companies have announced more than $178 billion in planned buybacks \u2014 the largest amount unveiled in a single quarter, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm.\n\nSuch purchases reduce a company\u2019s total number of outstanding shares, giving each remaining share a slightly bigger piece of the profit pie.\n\nCisco said this month that in response to the tax package, it would bring back to the United States $67 billion of overseas cash, using $25 billion to finance additional share repurchases. Alphabet, the parent company of Google, authorized up to $8.6 billion in stock purchases. PepsiCo announced a fresh $15 billion in planned buybacks. Chip gear maker Applied Materials disclosed plans for a $6 billion program to buy shares. Late last month, home improvement retailer Lowe\u2019s unveiled plans for $5 billion in purchases.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Buffett said on CNBC that Berkshire might be open to buy some of its shares. The remarks helped send Berkshire\u2019s stock \u2014 and the broader market \u2014 higher.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore buybacks are almost certainly on the way. UBS analysts covering Apple said the iPhone maker might authorize another $30 billion in share purchases when it reports its next quarterly earnings in April. That would be on top of the $30 billion it already spends each year to buy back its shares.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m expecting buybacks to get to a record for 2018,\u201d said Howard Silverblatt, a senior index analyst with S.&P. Dow Jones Indices. \u201cAnd if I\u2019m disappointed, there\u2019s a lot of people with me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe flurry of planned buybacks has been good for the stock market. Early this month, stocks were down more than 10 percent from their January peak. The prospect of companies flooding markets with \u201cbuy\u201d orders helped the market recoup some of its losses.\n\nThe broader impact on the economy is less clear. Economists believe a rising stock market benefits the economy, helping support consumer and business confidence. But the vast majority of the billions of dollars in planned share purchases will benefit the richest 10 percent of American households, who own 84 percent of all stocks. The top 1 percent of households own about 40 percent of all stocks.\n\nUltimately, the effect of the rising stock market depends on how those wealthy investors use their windfall. It helps the economy more, for example, if they put the money toward productive new companies than if they invest in government bonds.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCompanies typically decide to make long-term investments in things like new workers and factories based on whether they will make the company more profitable \u2014 not merely because the companies are sitting on a pile of money that they otherwise would have paid in taxes.\n\nAt a news conference Thursday, the head of the White House\u2019s Council of Economic Advisers, Kevin Hassett, acknowledged that many companies were spending their money on buying their own shares.\n\n\u201cRight now we\u2019re going to have an adjustment where you see probably more dividends and share buybacks than wage increases,\u201d Mr. Hassett said. \u201cBut going forward we\u2019re going to see a lot of capital formation and wage growth.\u201d\n\nThat is not what happened in 2005, when a one-time tax holiday allowed companies to repatriate money on the cheap. That plan, championed by President George W. Bush, was sold as a way to get American companies to invest more in the domestic economy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome $300 billion came back to the United States that year. But economists estimated that as much as 92 percent of it may have been paid out to companies\u2019 shareholders \u2014 mostly in the form of buybacks.\n\nStudies have shown that the tax change lifted companies\u2019 stock prices but did not expand their American work forces.\n\nUntil the early 1980s, the practice of buying shares with corporate money was considered borderline illegal because it was thought to potentially open the company up to charges of manipulating share prices.\n\nBut in 1982 the Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a rule that gave the green light to most share repurchases, as long as they followed certain rules.\n\nHistorically, American companies had paid out profits with a quarterly check, known as a dividend. But after the S.E.C.\u2019s rule change, companies started using more of their profits to buy their own shares, in the process giving their shareholders a bigger piece of the company.\n\nBuybacks soon soared. By 2016, the most recent year for which there is complete data, companies spent $536 billion on purchasing their own shares, according to data from S. & P. Dow Jones Indices.\n\nThat was about 5 percent less than those companies spent on new plants, research and development and other investments. By contrast, 20 years ago, companies spent four times as much on such investments as they did on buybacks.\n\nSome economists think the surge in share buybacks has something to do with the relative decline in capital investments, which recently have been lower than expected.\n\n\u201cWe have some causal evidence that because of short-termism companies are doing some stock repurchases that maybe they shouldn\u2019t do,\u201d said Heitor Almeida, a professor of corporate finance at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. \u201cAnd maybe that\u2019s causing them to reduce investment.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Tax Cuts in Hand, Companies Spend More on Themselves Than on Wages", "authors": ["Matt Phillips"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAm I concerned that Trump\u2019s attacks on the Department of Justice, the F.B.I. and the ongoing investigations into collusion may undermine fundamental institutions and norms including the rule of law?\u201d Shanto Iyengar, a political scientist at Stanford, wrote me by email. \u201cFor sure.\u201d\n\nIyengar posed the following hypothetical:\n\nLet\u2019s assume that Mueller uncovers evidence of collusion and close associates of the Prez are implicated. Republicans are likely to deny the validity of the charges on the grounds that the investigators are biased and Republicans in Congress, as they\u2019ve repeatedly demonstrated, will stick by Trump since the base is with him. Trump, of course, will continue with the \u2018hoax\u2019 narrative, and his surrogates in the media will be only too happy to back him up. At that point, we will have a very real threat to the rule of law.\n\nTrump\u2019s attacks on the F.B.I. are a case study in his polarization strategy. Since its founding in 1908, the F.B.I. has had substantial popular support, especially among Republicans. Historic poll data is revealing. A 1949 Gallup poll asked \u201cWhat is your opinion of the F.B.I.?\u201d 41 percent said \u201cvery high, excellent, it does wonderful job,\u201d and 53 percent said \u201cgood, approve of it,\u201d for a total of 94 percent. Three percent voiced \u201cmild disapproval,\u201d and the responses of 1 percent were \u201cderogatory.\u201d\n\nMore recently, the NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll tracked partisan views of the F.B.I. from December 2014 to January 2018. Over that three-year period, the percentage of Democrats voicing \u201ca great deal or quite a bit of confidence\u201d in the agency rose from 34 to 53 percent.\n\nRepublican confidence moved in the opposite direction, from 46 to 31 percent.\n\nJust this month, a February 1-2 Survey Monkey poll sponsored by Axios found that favorable views of the F.B.I. among Republicans \u2014 putatively members of the law-and-order party \u2014 had fallen to 38 percent, while a plurality, 47 percent, disapproved. Among all voters, 49 percent approved of the F.B.I. and 28 percent disapproved; Democrats were favorable by 64-14.\n\nAlex Theodoridis, a political scientist at the University of California-Merced, wrote me:\n\nPolarization by party identity is so powerful at the moment that most voters see the world through thick red and blue lenses. Almost everything is politicized. And, in almost every study I have run, I find that Republicans are more intense partisans than Democrats on average. We\u2019ve seen partisanship color Republican evaluations of the FBI (negatively) and Russia and Putin (positively).\n\nTheodoridis argued that the damage to \u201cany given institution is not likely to last beyond its usefulness in a specific political context.\u201d But, he warned,\n\nthe more pernicious problem is the very phenomenon of universal politicization. If everything, even the most esteemed institutions and norms, is subjected to the power of partisan motivated reasoning, then there really cease to be esteemed institutions and norms.\n\nMoving from politicization to politics, how likely are these trends to play out in the midterm elections?\n\n\u201cA Democratic turnaround in 2018 is far from assured,\u201d Robert Y. Shapiro, a political scientist at Columbia, emailed me:\n\nIf the economy stays strong and swing voters see benefits to the economy and themselves from tax cuts, the Republicans may well hold on to the House and, more easily, the Senate.\n\nThe recent volatility of the stock market poses dangers to Trump and the Republican Party generally. Still, Trump\u2019s ratings, always unfavorable, have improved in recent weeks.\n\nIn a setback for Democrats, the generic House vote in opinion surveys \u2014 \u201care you likely to vote for a Democrat or Republican for the House?\u201d \u2014 has fallen from a 12.9 point Democratic advantage as recently as Dec. 30 to a 6-point Democratic advantage on Feb. 7. A rough rule of thumb is that Democrats will need at least a 10-point advantage on the generic vote to have a shot at retaking the House.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Tool Kit Does Not Include the Constitution", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Many years ago, when dinosaurs roamed the earth and some Republicans still talked sense, the Reagan administration pursued a policy of tax cuts and military buildup even as the Fed was tightening monetary policy to fight inflation. This policy mix bore some obvious resemblance to Trumponomics. And two things happened at more or less the same time: for the first time ever, the U.S. began running large peacetime full-employment budget deficits, and we began running large, sustained trade deficits.\n\nAt the time, Martin Feldstein famously linked the two, calling them \u201ctwin deficits.\u201d While this oversimplified matters \u2013 in the late 1990s we ran both budget surpluses and trade deficits, thanks to booming investment \u2013 the logic made sense. Fiscal stimulus directly raised trade deficits by boosting overall spending, and the fiscal-monetary collision raised interest rates, pushing up the dollar and shifting spending from U.S. to foreign goods.\n\nNow the always interesting Brad Setser suggests that a similar story might be unfolding now, with tax cuts feeding a rising trade deficit \u2013 an irony given Trump\u2019s obsession with trade deficits as the root of all economic evil. His post is well worth a read, but I have a few suggestions/modifications to make.\n\nOne is simply to note that so far we\u2019ve seen only modest increases in interest rates and no rise at all in the dollar. So this doesn\u2019t look much like Reaganomics yet. Maybe it\u2019s still something that will happen; or maybe the Trump tax cuts won\u2019t deliver much fiscal stimulus, just pile up in retained earnings or get used for stock buybacks that don\u2019t do much for consumer spending. Or maybe, as Setser implicitly suggests, we need to do a \u201cbut for\u201d: but for the tax cut other factors, like the very real strengthening in the European economy, would be driving the dollar sharply lower.", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Twin Deficits (Wonkish)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "In his telling, that bureaucracy, now run by his own appointees, is a nest of political saboteurs out to undermine him \u2014 an accusation that raised fears that he was tearing at the credibility of some of the most important institutions in American life to save himself.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t think of another time when this has happened,\u201d said Jack L. Goldsmith, a Harvard law professor who headed the Justice Department\u2019s Office of Legal Counsel under President George W. Bush. \u201cAnd it\u2019s happening largely because the president is being investigated.\u201d\n\nThe attacks are having an impact. A SurveyMonkey poll for Axios, a news website, released on Saturday showed that only 38 percent of Republicans have a favorable view of the F.B.I., compared to 64 percent of Democrats. In interviews, more than a dozen officials who work at or recently left the Justice Department and the F.B.I. said they feared that the president was mortgaging the credibility of those agencies for his own short-term political gain as he seeks to undercut the Russia inquiry led by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.\n\n\u201cThanks to this rhetoric, there is a subset of the public that won\u2019t believe what comes out of the Mueller investigation,\u201d said Christopher Hunter, a former F.B.I. agent and prosecutor who left the Justice Department at the end of last year. Mr. Hunter said he worried that juries might be more skeptical of testimony from agents even in criminal trials unrelated to Mr. Trump. \u201cAll it takes to sink a case,\u201d he said, \u201cis for one juror to disbelieve the F.B.I.\u201d\n\nFor some career professionals, a siege mentality has taken hold. \u201cUntil recently, people in the department were in raised eyebrow mode,\u201d said Sharon McGowan, a former principal deputy chief of the appellate section of the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department who left soon after the new administration took over. \u201cBut now they\u2019re starting to get worried.\u201d\n\nSince taking office, Mr. Trump has assailed a number of major institutions in society, including Congress, the courts, the news media, intelligence agencies, Hollywood, professional sports and even his own party. But the attacks on law enforcement are tied up with his own political fate as investigators bear down.\n\nThe closest analogy historians summon is the Saturday Night Massacre in 1973, when President Richard M. Nixon ordered the firing of the Watergate prosecutor, and both the attorney general and his deputy resigned rather than comply, leaving it to the Justice Department\u2019s No. 3 official to carry it out. Even then, Nixon was publicly targeting the prosecutor, not the institutions themselves.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEver since, the notion of a president dismissing investigators looking at his own actions had been unthinkable in Washington \u2014 at least until Mr. Trump fired James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director, last year. President Bill Clinton\u2019s surrogates relentlessly criticized Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating him, but ousting him was never a viable option, and as much as Mr. Clinton detested Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. director at the time, he did not launch a sustained public attack on him or the agency.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven before this past week, Mr. Trump had publicly assailed Attorney General Jeff Sessions for recusing himself from the Russia investigation and left open the possibility that he might even fire him. Last summer, Mr. Trump sought to fire Mr. Mueller, only to back down after the White House counsel threatened to resign, The New York Times reported last month. He also considered firing Mr. Rosenstein, who oversees Mr. Mueller.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s scary when someone can use the forces of government for their own benefit, the way Nixon did and the way this president is now doing,\u201d said Sidney Davidoff, a onetime adviser to Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York and one of 20 people on Nixon\u2019s original enemies list. \u201cAs an attorney and as a private citizen, I\u2019d like to believe that the investigatory agencies are doing a job for the American people, not at someone\u2019s whim. It\u2019s not a monarchy.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s advisers dismiss such concerns as overwrought. They said the memo, drafted by Republicans led by Representative Devin Nunes of California, the Intelligence Committee chairman, and declassified by Mr. Trump, raised serious and legitimate questions about the way the F.B.I. used information gathered by a former spy paid by Mrs. Clinton\u2019s campaign and the Democrats to help justify a warrant for surveillance on a former Trump campaign adviser tied to Russia.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s critics, his advisers argue, are turning a blind eye to government misconduct out of their own partisan animus toward the president. Neither the F.B.I. nor the Justice Department should be above questioning, they say, and Mr. Trump\u2019s willingness to do so should not be taken as a slight against the vast majority of people who work there.\n\n\u201cThe president has stated many times that he respects the rank and file of the F.B.I., the 25,000 men and women who do a great job there,\u201d Kellyanne Conway, the president\u2019s counselor, said on Fox News. \u201cThis particular investigation has taken a lot of twists and turns, and it\u2019s led us to a few bad actors who had direct responsibility for an investigation about his political opponent who are obviously biased against him.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump seized on the memo on Saturday to assert that it renders the Russia investigation moot. \u201cThis memo totally vindicates \u2018Trump\u2019 in probe,\u201d he wrote on Twitter. \u201cBut the Russian Witch Hunt goes on and on. Their was no Collusion and there was no Obstruction (the word now used because, after one year of looking endlessly and finding NOTHING, collusion is dead). This is an American disgrace!\u201d\n\nFor Mr. Trump, the memo represents the latest example of a secret document containing explosive information that shadowy, powerful figures do not want made public, like the famous long-form birth certificate that President Barack Obama was supposedly hiding to cover up that he was born in Kenya. (Mr. Obama eventually released the form, which showed that he was born in Hawaii, and Mr. Trump ultimately acknowledged that Mr. Obama really is a native-born American.)\n\nDuring the 2016 campaign, Mr. Trump often seized on documents as a potential holy grail. At one point, it was sealed pages of a congressional report into the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks that he argued would show who was behind them. At other moments, he pointed to Mrs. Clinton\u2019s deleted emails or the hacked emails of Mrs. Clinton\u2019s campaign chairman, John D. Podesta, which were released by the website WikiLeaks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDavid Strauss, a University of Chicago law professor, said Mr. Trump\u2019s accusations against the F.B.I. and the Justice Department were not mere political rhetoric, but messages with consequences. \u201cWe have a president who seems to have no understanding of the professional ethos of the Justice Department, who has no understanding how these people think about their jobs,\u201d he said.\n\nEspecially upsetting, some former officials said, is that Mr. Trump has publicly taunted specific individuals \u2014 a top F.B.I. official, an F.B.I. lawyer and an F.B.I. supervisor.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one thing for the president to criticize political appointees \u2014 although it is quite odd for him to criticize his own political appointees,\u201d said Alan Rozenshtein, a lawyer who left the Justice Department\u2019s national security division in April and now teaches at the University of Minnesota law school. But to attack career employees at the F.B.I. who are barred by regulations from publicly responding, he said, \u201cthat\u2019s really bad.\u201d\n\nJosh Campbell, who spent a decade at the F.B.I. and worked directly for Mr. Comey at one time, wrote in The Times on Saturday that he was resigning so that he could speak out. \u201cThese political attacks on the bureau must stop,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIf those critics of the agency persuade the public that the F.B.I. cannot be trusted, they will also have succeeded in making our nation less safe.\u201d\n\nOne F.B.I. supervisor in a field office said public shaming of his colleagues had wiped out any desire he had to work at the bureau\u2019s headquarters in Washington. \u201cI\u2019d rather chew glass,\u201d he said.\n\nMary McCord, a former acting assistant attorney general for the national security division, left the Justice Department in May after 23 years. Every new administration, she said, ushered in new priorities and policies. But only Mr. Trump, she said, had put the entire department under a cloud.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never seen attacks on the F.B.I. or the D.O.J. like we\u2019ve seen in the last year,\u201d she said. \u201cIt makes me just really sad.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s Unparalleled War on a Pillar of Society: Law Enforcement", "authors": ["Sharon Lafraniere", "Katie Benner", "Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump\u2019s calls this week for more vocational schools have received a lukewarm reception from the higher education community, including from the educators who teach in the programs he is championing.\n\nThe president first raised expanding vocational education in his State of the Union address on Tuesday \u2014 the only nod to education policy in the speech \u2014 as a work force development strategy. On Thursday, Mr. Trump expounded on the proposal, asserting that efforts to teach students trades had diminished since he attended an elite military boarding school, where he said he had a classmate who wasn\u2019t the \u201cgreatest student\u201d but \u201cwas able to fix a car engine blindfolded.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe had a different kind of a talent, and we should have vocational schools,\u201d Mr. Trump said during a speech at a Republican congressional retreat in West Virginia. \u201cYou learn mechanical, you learn bricklaying and carpentry and all of these things. We don\u2019t have that very much anymore. And I think the word \u2018vocational\u2019 is a much better word than in many cases, a community college. A lot of people don\u2019t know what a community college means or represents.\u201d\n\nPolicy experts and organizations that advocate the trade programs \u2014 which for more than a decade have been recognized as career and technical education, or C.T.E. \u2014 took issue with the president\u2019s antiquated characterization of a sector of higher education that has expanded beyond laborers who are not cut out for academia.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Vision for Vocational Education Gets a Tepid Reception", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The world began to notice that Kelly was perhaps not as cool, calm and collected as we\u2019d bargained for when he was coordinating a condolence call by the president to Myeshia Johnson, whose husband, Sgt. His idea of comfort, she said, was to tell her La David knew \u201cwhat he was signing up for.\u201d Trump naturally denied everything. Representative Frederica Wilson, a family friend, made the whole disaster public. Kelly then waded in with an emotional speech in which he assailed Wilson for taking credit for getting funding for a Florida building named after two slain F.B.I. agents. Its overall weirdness was matched only by its total inaccuracy.\n\nThe next step, in theory, would be an apologetic call from Kelly to the congresswoman. FIRST CLASS\n\nScott Pruitt, the champion of fossil fuel interests who is busily trying to destroy the Environmental Protection Agency, and his aides have made the ludicrous argument in recent days that he must fly first class because he is not safe in economy. This has elicited howls of laughter from aviation experts. Mr. Pruitt and his staff have racked up a tab totaling many thousands of dollars for domestic and international trips, including $1,641 for a brief flight from Washington to New York. Mr. Pruitt told The New Hampshire Union Leader that he has to travel in the front of the cabin because people in coach are mean to him. \u201cWe\u2019ve reached the point where there\u2019s not much civility in the marketplace, and it\u2019s created, you know, it\u2019s created some issues,\u201d he said.\n\nEUROPEAN IDYLL\n\nIn other travel news, the secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, David Shulkin, last week struggled to explain why the government spent $4,000 to fly his wife to Europe so she could accompany him for what was supposed to be a trip to attend a conference on veterans\u2019 issues. Turns out, the happy couple spent nearly half the trip checking out sites like Amalienborg Palace in Copenhagen and Buckingham Palace in London. Oh, and they also improperly accepted free tickets to watch a tennis match at Wimbledon, according to the V.A.\u2019s inspector general. Dr. Shulkin said he was repaying the Treasury for the cost of his wife\u2019s ticket, though not before producing an unusual 28-page rebuttal to the inspector general\u2019s report.\n\nFAVORITISM AT THE F.C.C.\n\nAt the Federal Communications Commission, Chairman Ajit Pai is under fire from Democrats in Congress for relaxing rules that restrict how many local TV stations a business can own in one market, weeks before a large conservative broadcaster, Sinclair, announced it was acquiring more stations by buying Tribune Media. The commission denies any wrongdoing, but has refused to respond to members of Congress who have sought information about Mr. Pai\u2019s contacts with Sinclair executives. The Times reported in August that the chairman and his staff met and corresponded with Sinclair several times. Earlier, The New York Post reported that Mr. Trump had met with Sinclair officials and discussed the F.C.C. rules. Clearly, there is nothing to see here.\n\nFAMILIAL SUPPORT\n\nIt is hard to get good help when unemployment is at 4.1 percent. Perhaps that\u2019s why Ben Carson, the secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, saw fit to let his son, Ben Carson Jr., organize a \u201clistening tour\u201d for the secretary in Baltimore, despite warnings from department lawyers that doing so could violate ethics rules. One lawyer wrote in a memo that the son\u2019s involvement could give \u201cthe appearance that the secretary may be using his position for his son\u2019s private gain\u201d because his son and his son\u2019s wife might be doing or seeking business with people invited to attend events on the tour, according to The Washington Post. Mr. Carson says that he and his family did nothing wrong and that they were \u201cunder attack by the media.\u201d\n\nThis is hardly a complete list. We haven\u2019t even gotten to the Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, his wife, Louise Linton, and their penchant for traveling on military planes when far cheaper options are available. And there are Trump appointees like Tom Price, the former health and human services secretary, and Brenda Fitzgerald, the former director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, who have had to bail out of the administration because of scrutiny they were under for expensive air travel (Mr. Price) and dubious investments (Dr. Fitzgerald).", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s \u2018Best People\u2019 and Their Dubious Ethics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Scott Gottlieb, the Food and Drug Administration commissioner, has tried to win over critics while also paying attention to the concerns of the drug and health industries.\n\nCredit Eric Thayer for The New York Times", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s \u2018Decent Appointment\u2019 to the F.D.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Instead, the idea, according to two administration officials who worked on the proposal, was a political gambit by fiscal hawks in the administration aimed at outraging liberals and stirring up members of the president\u2019s own party working on the latest version of the farm bill. The move, they said, was intended to lay down a marker that the administration is serious about pressing for about $85 billion in other cuts to food assistance programs that will be achieved, in part, by imposing strict new work requirements on recipients.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think there\u2019s really any support for their box plan. And, I worry that it\u2019s a distraction from the budget\u2019s proposal to cut SNAP by some 30 percent. That\u2019s the real battle,\u201d said Stacy Dean, vice president for food assistance policy at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a progressive Washington think tank. \u201cThe dangers are these other proposals to cut benefits. But all anyone is talking about today are the boxes.\u201d\n\nSenator Debbie Stabenow, the ranking Democrat on the agriculture committee, doubted the motives behind the plan.\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t a serious proposal and is clearly meant to be a distraction,\u201d Ms. Stabenow said.\n\nAgriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue stealthily pitched the idea over the last few weeks to the White House\u2019s Domestic Policy Council as a novel way to reach the administration\u2019s self-imposed goal of slashing federal food assistance programs by $214 billion over the next decade. It was quickly embraced by Mr. Mulvaney, a fiscal hawk who is seeking to steer a debate increasingly dominated by free-spending Republicans and Mr. Trump, who has insisted on major budget increases for the Pentagon and Homeland Security.\n\nNeither man had any illusions that the plan would be immediately embraced by congressional Republicans, who were not given advance notice of the proposal, the officials said.\n\nThat the food-box approach has been tried only in small demonstration projects and never been seriously discussed during dozens of congressional hearings on the SNAP program in recent years did not stop administration officials from putting the force of Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency behind it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
