Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe budget documents released on Monday omitted other important details, including the real costs of creating a nationwide distribution network for the boxes, especially in rural areas hard hit by the economic downturn and the opioid crisis.\n\n\u201cWe have had like 25 hearings on SNAP. The witness list was controlled by Republicans and this idea was never, ever broached,\u201d said Representative Jim McGovern of Massachusetts, ranking Democrat on the House subcommittee that oversees federal food assistance programs. \u201cI think it\u2019s dead on arrival \u2014 I hope it is \u2014 but either way it\u2019s a cruel joke. My God, these people are awful. In addition to being totally misinformed on policy, they are really just not nice people.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement, Mr. Perdue defended the proposal as humane and cost effective, saying his plan offered the \u201csame level of food value\u201d provided by the SNAP program, which replaced the food stamp program in the late 1990s.\n\nHe described the boxes as \u201ca bold, innovative approach to providing nutritious food to people who need assistance feeding themselves and their families \u2014 and all of it is grown by American farmers and producers.\u201d\n\nStill, the idea landed with a thud. It was quickly dismissed by two Republican committee chairmen, Senator Pat Roberts of Kansas, who leads the Senate agriculture committee, and his counterpart in the House, Representative K. Michael Conaway of Texas.\n\nMr. Conaway is drafting a farm bill that is expected to slash billions in spending in the SNAP program through the tightening of some eligibility requirements. Mr. Roberts is overseeing an effort to craft a version of the bill that is expected to include fewer cuts in hopes of gaining the bipartisan support needed to push the measure through the Senate.\n\nSNAP, like many other safety net programs, is designed to expand during hard economic times and contract when the economy improves. Nonetheless, the program\u2019s rolls have remained at historically elevated levels, reaching a peak of 47.8 million recipients in 2012 before edging down to 45.6 million last year, according to federal estimates.\n\nMr. Perdue, in particular, has been outspoken in his call to reduce its rolls, criticizing what he calls a culture of dependency among SNAP recipients.\n\nBut Mr. McGovern said the administration was painting \u201ca distorted picture\u201d of the poor and ignoring the fact that most SNAP recipients are employed and more than a quarter are disabled and unable to seek work.\n\n\u201cThey have to stop playing to the cheap seats,\u201d he said. \u201cThe majority of people in the program are children and seniors and people working in jobs that pay too little to feed their families.\u201d", "title": "Trump\u2019s \u2018Harvest Box\u2019 Isn\u2019t Viable in SNAP Overhaul, Officials Say", "authors": ["Glenn Thrush"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cMichigan State\u2019s Remedial Education\u201d (editorial, Feb. 1):\n\nThe breadth and depth of the governance failure at Michigan State University are clear, and calls for action against those who let down the more than 200 survivors of Larry Nassar\u2019s abuse of female gymnasts and other athletes are understandable and necessary.\n\nBut it also remains unclear as the timeline unfolds precisely how much information the board of trustees had available to it to fulfill its fiduciary and oversight responsibilities.\n\nWhile the board clearly should have asked harder questions and not acquiesced to university administrators, now is not the time for mass resignations or removals, which will further destabilize an already troubled institution.\n\nMichigan State now has a new president; the board must now do its job, commission an independent investigation and move the university forward. If it cannot fulfill this basic responsibility of governance, there will be time for recrimination and change.", "title": "Opinion | Trustees at Michigan State", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "On the icy deck of the Kings Point, a 94-foot tug based in New York Harbor, Jess Yeomans picked up a thick, heavy rope and flung it with the skill of a rodeo cowboy onto a steel post about 10 feet away, and then just as deftly flipped it free again.\n\nAs a deckhand on a tugboat, being skilled with lines as thick as baseball bats is obligatory, and it is something that is picked up from other seamen.\n\n\u201cThese are traditions that are passed down,\u201d said Ms. Yeomans, who is aware of another tugboat tradition: It is mostly men who work on them.\n\nHer tasks include hustling around the deck and throwing and catching lines to fasten the tug to barges and large ships in need of guidance. At times, she directs the captain when his vision is blocked, coordinating with him via a radio. Sometimes this means scrambling up a ladder onto a fuel barge being guided by the tug \u201con the hip,\u201d or from the side.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen the tug is underway, Ms. Yeomans can take the wheel and navigate the boat under the captain\u2019s close supervision. In the wheelhouse on a recent morning, she steered the Kings Point through Buttermilk Channel, between the Brooklyn waterfront and Governors Island.", "title": "Tugboat Jess Pulls Her Weight", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon", "Character Study"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEven if stocks continue to rise, they could rise more slowly and could be subject to large drops,\u201d said Kate Warne, an investment strategist at Edward Jones.\n\nMany Gains Slip Away The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index climbed 27 percent since President Trump took office, but by Friday it had given up more than a third of those gains since peaking on Jan. 26. PEAK +26.9% +25 % The stock market since President Trump was inaugurated +20 Percentage change in daily closes of the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index since Jan. 19, 2017 +15 FRI. +15.7% +10 INAUGURATION +5 0 J F M A M J J A S O N D J F \u201917 \u201918 PEAK +26.9% +25 % The stock market since President Trump was inaugurated Percentage change in daily closes of the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index since Jan. 19, 2017 +20 +15 FRIDAY +15.7% +10 INAUGURATION +5 0 J F M A M J J A S O N D J F \u201917 \u201918\n\nShe said investors were moving money out of riskier stocks like Apple and Disney, which are considered \u201cconsumer discretionary\u201d stocks because they don\u2019t serve basic daily needs, and into safer areas like utility stocks and United States Treasury notes.\n\n\u201cLonger-term investors should stay invested and not let this worry them. This is an opportunity to buy at lower prices,\u201d Ms. Warne said.\n\nMany investors are now growing nervous that central banks will raise interest rates in a bid to keep inflation at bay. If policymakers move too quickly, their efforts could temper the global growth.\n\nAnthony Clemente, the chief executive of Canaras Capital, which specializes in high-yield loans and has $1.3 billion under management, said some of the market movement appeared to be an effort by portfolio managers to protect themselves from volatility in stocks rather than a broader fear of market turmoil.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really out of equities and inflows into the debt markets,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s an expectations that yields \u2014 fixed income and debt instrument \u2014 are the place where you will want to be at some point.\u201d\n\nWhatever the cause, there is now little doubt that markets are jittery.\n\nAfter being lulled into a sense of complacency by years of steadily rising stocks, even small worries can snowball into a bad day for stocks. The losses can then feed on themselves in a financial industry dominated by computerized trading systems, with the weakness in the United States spreading around the world.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAsia is going to be the tail that gets wagged by the U.S. dog,\u201d Timothy Moe, chief Asia Pacific strategist at Goldman Sachs, said on Friday.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs with stocks in the United States, Chinese shares have surged in recent months, on the back of a strong economy. An improved global outlook has led to more buying of Chinese exports. The authorities also seem to have slowed what had been an alarming borrowing binge.\n\nBut the Chinese market does offer reasons for concern. Investors kept a careful eye this week on China\u2019s currency, the renminbi, which is carefully managed by the Chinese government. It took a hit on Thursday, falling as much as 1.2 percent before strengthening a bit on Friday.\n\nBefore that, the renminbi had been rising steadily against the American dollar, leading to worries that Beijing might step in further to contain it. World markets can be sensitive to sharp swings in China\u2019s currency.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe tough day of trading on Friday put Chinese shares by some measures into correction territory. \u201cWe are witnessing the longest rally in the history of Chinese stocks,\u201d analysts at Goldman Sachs wrote to clients early this week, adding, \u201cA tactical correction appears overdue, and markets could fall further.\u201d\n\nShares in Shanghai fell about 4 percent on Friday, while Hong Kong shares lost 3.1 percent. Shares in Tokyo fell 2.3 percent. In Europe, stocks wavered, off more than 1 percent in afternoon trading.\n\nIn the logic of stock markets, bad news can sometimes be good news. Recent gains in the value of the euro against the dollar and other major currencies were expected to slow exports and potentially put the brakes on the eurozone economy.\n\nSlower growth would, in turn, dissuade the European Central Bank from raising interest rates too soon, prolonging the cheap money that has been partly responsible for the bull market.\n\n\u201cThe E.C.B. has, in fact, a vital interest in keeping euro area interest rates at low levels,\u201d Ralph Solveen, an analyst at Commerzbank, said in a note to clients on Friday.", "title": "Tumultuous Week on Wall Street Ends With a Small Rally", "authors": ["Emily Flitter", "Alexandra Stevenson"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Perhaps with a view to that potential flash point in western Syria, and another one farther east around the city of Manbij, Mr. Tillerson vowed after the meeting that the days when the two countries operated independently in the fight against the Islamic State were over.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to act alone any longer. We\u2019re not going to be the U.S. doing one thing and Turkey doing another,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to act together from this point forward. We\u2019re going to lock arms. We\u2019re going to work through the issues that are causing difficulties and we\u2019re going to resolve them and we\u2019re going to move forward.\u201d\n\nBut while the war in Syria is perhaps the most pressing of the disagreements between the two countries, it is by no means the only one.\n\nThe Trump administration has also been perturbed by Mr. Erdogan\u2019s creeping authoritarianism, his increasingly cozy relations with Moscow, his security detail\u2019s brazen attack in Washington on peaceful protesters, and Turkey\u2019s arrests of American citizens and State Department employees.\n\nThe Turks, for their part, are furious at the administration\u2019s refusal to extradite the Muslim cleric Fethullah Gulen, whom Turkey accuses of orchestrating a 2016 coup attempt from his self-imposed exile in Pennsylvania.\n\nThe last time Mr. Tillerson was in Ankara, he showered praise on the Turks and largely avoided listing American grievances, while receiving an earful of complaints. This time, he was much tougher in his remarks, reflecting his growing belief in the importance of the public aspects of diplomacy.\n\n\u201cWe continue to have serious concerns about the detention of local employees of our mission in Turkey and about cases against U.S. citizens who have been arrested under the state of emergency,\u201d he said. He called for the release of Andrew Brunson and Serkan Golge, American citizens detained during Mr. Erdogan\u2019s purges after a coup attempt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Tillerson\u2019s visit is part of a flurry of high-level meetings between top American and Turkish officials in recent days. In Brussels on Thursday, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis met with his Turkish counterpart, while the national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, met on Sunday in Istanbul with Turkey\u2019s senior presidential adviser, Ibrahim Kalin.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe seeds of the rift between the two countries were planted in 2014, as the Islamic State swept across Iraq and Syria. Looking for partners, President Barack Obama pleaded with Mr. Erdogan to help in the fight against the militants, but Mr. Erdogan initially refused.\n\nWith the Iraqi Army in shambles, the Americans reached out to the Kurdish militias, the only force in the region not aligned with Iran that was able and eager to fight. The Americans knew that their use of Kurdish forces might one day lead to a reckoning with Baghdad and Ankara, but felt they had little choice.\n\nIn Iraq, that day came in October, when the Iraqi army attacked the oil-rich and ethnically divided city of Kirkuk, driving Kurdish forces out. In Syria, the trouble has only just started.\n\nAmerican officials have tried to mollify the Turks by insisting that their support of the Kurds is limited in time and resources. But news that Washington was preparing to create a 30,000-strong Syrian border force out of the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, or Y.P.G. \u2014 a plan since disavowed by the Trump administration \u2014 was the \u201clast straw,\u201d Fahrettin Altun, a columnist for a pro-government newspaper, Daily Sabah, wrote Thursday. That announcement directly precipitated Turkey\u2019s military offensive against Kurdish militias in the enclave of Afrin in western Syria, Mr. Altun wrote.\n\nTurkey views the Y.P.G. as an arm of the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party, or P.K.K., an insurgent group in Turkey that has carried out attacks here for decades. The Turkish view of the connection between the two groups was bolstered this week by an American intelligence assessment equating them and concluding they \u201cprobably will seek some form of autonomy\u201d \u2014 exactly what Turkey fears.\n\nThe last time Mr. Tillerson was in Ankara, the Turkish news media was in a frenzy about a leaked phone record that to them suggested American collusion in the 2016 coup attempt, an accusation American officials found almost laughable. This time, newspapers were filled with references to the \u201cOttoman slap.\u201d Public expressions of anti-American sentiment here have become routine and intense since 2016.\n\nIn an indication of just how far apart the two sides remain, Mr. Cavusoglu said that Mr. Tillerson had promised that the Y.P.G. would soon leave the strategically important city of Manbij.\n\n\u201cOnce the Y.P.G. leaves there, we will have trust,\u201d Mr. Cavusoglu said. \u201cThis is a commitment that the United States of America has made to us and we will be talking about how this implementation will be made.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn his own remarks, Mr. Tillerson would say only that security around Manbij was \u201ca topic of discussion going forward.\u201d\n\nThe Turkish military has been advancing slowly in its offensive against Kurdish militias in Afrin. So far it has cleared 44 villages, the Anadolu news agency reported, but has yet to take any of the main towns. Turkey has lost 31 soldiers in the operation that began on Jan. 20, the Defense Ministry says.\n\nTurkish officials say the Kurdish militias in Afrin have fired more than 100 rockets and mortars over the border into Turkey in that time, killing seven civilians and one soldier in a border observation post.", "title": "Turkey and U.S. in Talks on Worsening Syria Crisis", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris", "Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Turkey has now jailed more than 50,000 people and suspended over 140,000 from their jobs, since an attempted coup in July 2016 that the government charges was orchestrated by a group of military officers and followers of the United State-based Islamist preacher Fethullah Gulen.\n\nSince then, Mr. Erdogan\u2019s crackdown has rounded up not only the suspected coup plotters, but also purged thousands of political opponents, academics and journalists. Half the country\u2019s judges were suspended, compounding the problem of managing the judicial process.\n\n\u201cMany of us are concerned today by the length and scope of the ongoing state of emergency,\u201d Thorbjorn Jagland, the secretary general of the Council of Europe, said in a speech to some 400 candidate judges and prosecutors from the Turkish Justice Academy. \u201cMeasures taken must be strictly proportionate to the situation and limited in time.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are concerned that so many journalists, members of parliament, mayors and human rights defenders are deprived of their liberty,\u201d he went on. \u201cThe result of casting the net too widely is to spread a chilling effect across society as a whole.\u201d\n\nMr. Jagland, a former prime minister of Norway, met with President Erdogan and senior officials in Ankara on Thursday to raise the issues, as he sought to remind Turkey of its commitments to the rule of law as a member of the Council of Europe and signatory of the European Convention on Human Rights.\n\nMr. Jagland\u2019s words carried weight in Turkey. He was one of the first foreign officials to condemn the attempted coup of July 2016 \u2014 he won applause from his audience in appreciation \u2014 and he spoke with understanding of the trauma Turkey had experienced from the bloody events, which left 250 people dead.\n\nHe emphasized the need to prosecute those responsible. But he also laid out the judicial quandary that Turkey has presented to the Council of Europe and in its broader relationship with Europe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEvery citizen of Turkey has the right to apply to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg if their rights are violated. The court faces being inundated with cases if the rule of law fails in Turkey, Mr. Jagland said.\n\nNearly 120,000 purged government employees have applied to have their cases reviewed in Turkey. If they do not find justice, they are likely to turn to Strasbourg for recourse. Some 2,000 Turks have already appealed to the European court.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt would be much better for Turkey to handle them at home,\u201d Mr. Jagland said in an interview after his speech.\n\nIf thousands of cases came to Strasbourg, it would ruin Turkey\u2019s relations with Europe and its chances to be accepted into the European Union, he added.\n\nThe case of two of the journalists condemned to life imprisonment Friday \u2014 a well-known author and journalist, Ahmet Altan; and his brother, a columnist, Mehmet Altan \u2014 showed the arbitrary nature of Turkey\u2019 judicial system that has become the norm in recent months.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBoth men had appealed to Turkey\u2019s constitutional court questioning the legality of their pretrial detention. Although the constitutional court ordered their release, the lower court ignored the decision and handed down the most severe penalty possible \u2014 \u201caggravated life.\u201d\n\nThere is little doubt among lawyers, human rights officials and journalists following the myriad cases before Turkey\u2019s courts that politics plays a large part in the decisions.\n\n\u201cThis shows that there is no judicial security for anyone in Turkey,\u201d said Turgut Kazan, a veteran lawyer and former head of the Istanbul Bar Association. \u201cAn issue is resolved as part of Turkey-Germany meeting, but three important journalists were sentenced to aggravated life for using violence. How they can use violence by writing articles?\u201d\n\nFour others in the case also received the same sentences: Nazli Ilicak, a news anchor and columnist; Fezvi Yazici, a page designer; Yakup Simsek, an advertising director; and Sukru Tugrul Ozsengul, a former police officer and commentator on security issues.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Turkish judiciary has never been in such a bad period as today,\u201d he added.\n\nWith Germany\u2019s small breakthrough on Friday, many in Europe are looking at how it has handled Turkey.\n\nGermany\u2019s foreign minister Sigmar Gabriel drew a line with Turkey last summer after a German national was among 10 human rights professionals arrested during a conference in Istanbul. Germany issued a travel advisory warning business travelers and tourists that they risked arbitrary arrest if they traveled to Turkey.\n\nThe threat to investment and tourism was enough to cause the Turkish government to change its ways, European diplomats and analysts say. Turkey toned down it antagonistic rhetoric, and started to release some of the citizens that Germany considered political cases.\n\nOf a dozen in jail last summer, about half have been released, although most still faces charges. Mr. Yucel\u2019s case has been among the most prominent.\n\n\u201cThe Turks seem to be walking a fine line between strong rhetoric and finding areas of compromise,\u201d said Amanda Sloat, a senior fellow at Brookings and former foreign policy official in the Obama administration. \u201cDoing the right thing removes a bilateral irritant but does not fully repair relations.\u201d\n\nMr. Gabriel urged that the moment Friday be seized as a chance to resume discussions with Turkey, despite domestic debates over Turkey\u2019s use of German tanks against the Kurds in northern Syria.\n\nBut he, too, nodded to Europe\u2019s concerns that Mr. Erdogan was using his state of emergency to roll back democratic norms.\n\n\u201cLarge differences of opinion between us remain, but I think there is also evidence that it makes sense despite such difficulties to remain in dialogue with one another and to try to help Turkey to end the state of emergency, to return to the previous, or similar views about the development of the European Union, the rule of law and democracy,\u201d he said.\n\nDespite the relief at one man\u2019s freedom, many Germans remained wary.\n\n\u201cFreed hostages do not make a springtime. There are still Germans sitting in Erdogan\u2019s dungeons, without even mentioning the thousands of Turks,\u201d wrote Berthold Kohler, publisher of the conservative Frankfurter Allgemeine daily. \u201cBut Yucel\u2019s deportation, faced with the threat of 18 years in prison and other sights at least indicated that Turkey, a NATO partner, is interested in d\u00e9tente.\u201d", "title": "Turkey\u2019s Effort to Repair Relations Trips Over Its Crackdown", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall", "Melissa Eddy"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "The deaths occurred on the same day that a Russian warplane was shot down over Idlib, about 50 miles south of Afrin, and the pilot, who had apparently parachuted out, was killed on the ground.\n\nA onetime affiliate of Al Qaeda in Syria, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, or H.T.S., claimed responsibility, broadcasting footage of the plane\u2019s downing. Elements of that same group are among the Free Syrian Army militias, many of them Islamist extremists, who are allied with the Turks and fighting in Afrin, according to the group and to analysts in the area.\n\nRussia, which controls Afrin\u2019s airspace, has allowed Turkey to operate its air force there for the offensive.\n\nIn a speech to supporters on Saturday, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said his forces would reach the city of Afrin soon. \u201cThank God the mountains there started to be taken,\u201d Mr. Erdogan said, according to the state-run news agency Anadolu. \u201cNow we are moving ahead to Afrin, almost there.\u201d\n\nThe city is surrounded by mountainous countryside, where most of the fighting has so far occurred.\n\nAnadolu quoted the Turkish military as confirming the losses of seven troops and one tank. The Defense Ministry said one soldier had been killed in Turkey, in what it called a cross-border attack by the Syrian militants.\n\nTurkey describes the Syrian forces as being with the P.K.K., the initials of the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party from eastern Turkey. Western and independent observers say the Syrian forces in Afrin are mostly from the People\u2019s Protection Units, or Y.P.G., a Kurdish force that controls a large part of northern Syria.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Syrian Democratic Forces are close allies of the United States military in Syria, but American forces are not in Afrin. While the State Department designates the P.K.K. as a terrorist group, it does not consider the Y.P.G. to be one.\n\nThe Y.P.G. and Y.P.J., its female partner force, have acknowledged the loss of 120 of their fighters in Afrin, and hospital officials there have reported 101 civilians in the Afrin area killed since the campaign began.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTurkish forces, including more than 10,000 Syrian fighters from numerous groups in the Free Syrian Army, have attacked Afrin from the west, north and east at 15 different points, but they have not yet managed to enter the city.\n\nTurkey\u2019s Air Force has launched numerous airstrikes, and its army artillery has supported the ground offensive, which includes Turkish soldiers as well as Syrian militants.\n\nThe Russian military fired cruise missiles from ships in the Mediterranean at rebel positions near Idlib in retaliation for the downing of its aircraft, claiming that it had killed 30 militants from the Al Qaeda group in the area. A Russian Defense Ministry statement said it had based that estimate on radio intercepts.\n\nA spokeswoman for the State Department denied speculation that the United States had provided shoulder-fired, antiaircraft weapons to groups in Syria.\n\n\u201cThe United States has never provided Manpad missiles to any group in Syria, and we are deeply concerned that such weapons are being used,\u201d the spokeswoman, Heather Nauert, said, referring to man-portable air-defense systems.\n\n\u201cThe solution to the violence is a return to the Geneva process as soon as possible,\u201d she said, referring to peace talks on Syria. \u201cWe call on Russia to live up to its commitments in that regard.\u201d\n\nTurkey has repeatedly threatened to carry the fight against the Y.P.G. from Afrin into Manbij, about 80 miles to the east of Afrin, which is the western limit of where American forces operate in cooperation with the Syrian Democratic Forces. Their allies the Manbij Military Council control the area.\n\nThe American military has said it will support its Kurdish and Arab allies in Manbij and elsewhere in northern Syria, which has infuriated the Turks, a NATO ally of the United States.", "title": "Turkey\u2019s Worst Day Yet in Syria Offensive: At Least 7 Soldiers Killed", "authors": ["Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "[READ: A Reset, of Sorts, for the United States and Australia]\n\n______\n\n\u201cThe problem is they think Sydney is Beijing. And We Recommend\n\n\u201cThere were a lot more black people in that movie than in other movies,\u201d my 9-year-old son said after we saw \u201cBlack Panther\u201d together last weekend.\n\nAnd that\u2019s why it\u2019s this week\u2019s recommendation.\n\nIt\u2019s not just a thrill ride of an Marvel action movie, complete with stunning visuals, a compelling villain and a playful sibling rivalry. It\u2019s also a teaching tool about representation in media \u2014 a reminder to think more deeply about the stories we see and don\u2019t see because of how cultural production continues to work, not just in the United States, but in Australia too.\n\nAnd after you see it, for a better understanding of what the movie means and why there is so much excitement about it, check out this story from The New York Times Magazine: Why \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Is a Defining Moment for Black America.", "title": "Turnbull Goes to Washington, We Go to the Pub", "authors": ["Damien Cave"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Before the mayor spoke, police officials highlighted a rise in crime on subways in Manhattan, specifically a jump in robberies: There have been 19 so far this year, up from nine in the same period a year ago.\n\nSome police leaders say that the dramatic decreases in crime have directly resulted from decades of attention to the turnstiles \u2014 one of the first widespread examples of the broken-windows philosophy adopted by Mr. Bratton.\n\n\u201cThe New York miracle, if you will, began with fare evasion \u2014 fare evasion enforcement on the subway 25 years ago,\u201d Mr. Bratton said in February 2014, when he was newly appointed by Mr. de Blasio as commissioner. \u201cWe\u2019re still at it.\u201d\n\nThe spat over how to deal with fare evaders cuts to the heart of criminal justice reform: In a city where crime has reached previously unfathomable lows, how much more can the justice system change?\n\nThe answer has divided Mr. de Blasio from typical allies like the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance, and the new City Council speaker, Corey Johnson, both self-identified progressive Democrats. It has also, improbably, aligned the mayor with Joseph J. Lhota, his 2013 Republican rival and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman.\n\nMr. Lhota, who has been engaged in an epistolary battle with Mr. Vance over the policy, suggested on Wednesday that if the new policy led to a surge in fare evasion, he would consider a drastic solution.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going to seriously consider putting the alarms back on the doors,\u201d he said of the emergency doors that emitted an ear-piercing siren when opened and were silenced in 2014 to much fanfare. \u201cThose doors should only be used for emergencies.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Lhota urged Mr. Vance in a letter to reconsider the policy, citing a recent arrest of a man from Virginia whom officers confronted over failing to pay his fare and then discovered that he was wanted for attempted murder in his home state.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIn the name of the millions who both depend upon and pay for M.T.A. services every day, I strongly urge you to reverse this unilateral policy,\u201d Mr. Lhota wrote.\n\nHours later, Mr. Vance wrote back with a point-by-point description of his approach, which began last week and only applies to those arrested in the subways and not on the city\u2019s buses. \u201cOur policy does not alter, in practice or in effect, the N.Y.P.D.\u2019s enforcement of fare evasion,\" he wrote. \u201cIn fact, this policy allows N.Y.P.D. officers to conduct more enforcement of subway crimes,\u201d Mr. Vance added, because officers are encouraged to hand out summonses and return to the beat, rather than spending time in court.\n\nAnd he said that the man from Virginia cited by Mr. Lhota had been \u201cproperly apprehended, and there is no reason why this type of policing will decline under the new Manhattan policy.\u201d\n\nMr. Vance found support from one of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s appointees to the transit board, David R. Jones, who attacked what he called \u201cfear mongering\u201d by Mr. Lhota in a letter of his own on Tuesday that compared the chairman to President Trump. (Mr. Lhota called the comparison \u201cgrossly insulting.\u201d)\n\n\u201cI would be just as strong in opposition to the mayor\u2019s position on this,\u201d Mr. Jones, who is also the head of the antipoverty nonprofit Community Service Society, said. He added that he disagreed \u201cfundamentally\u201d with Mr. de Blasio\u2019s assertion that poverty did not play a role in fare evasion.\n\n\u201cAll the data we have shows that is not true,\u201d he said, citing his group\u2019s study of arrests in Brooklyn last year. \u201cIf they really want to test this out, they should try it out on the Second Avenue subway. This is not a crime of rich kids just joy riding.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Jones favored reduced fares for poor New Yorkers, and tickets rather than arrests for lawbreakers, others went further.\n\n\u201cThe policy should be either reduced fare or free fare; that would eliminate a lot of the problem to begin with,\u201d said Robert Gangi, a criminal justice reform advocate who unsuccessfully challenged Mr. de Blasio in the 2017 Democratic primary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficers are not interested in fare evasion in and of itself, Mr. Gangi and Mr. Jones both suggested: If they were, they would situate themselves to visibly discourage people from hopping the turnstiles \u2014 or more commonly, sneaking through an open emergency entrance door \u2014 rather than secreting themselves to observe the crime and then make an arrest.\n\nNone of the four other district attorneys offices have emulated Manhattan\u2019s approach, though the Bronx and Brooklyn have been reviewing their policies.\n\n\u201cThe penalty right now is disproportionate to the crime,\u201d said Mr. Johnson, the Council speaker, who applauded Mr. Vance\u2019s policy. \u201cWe\u2019re not legalizing people not paying to get on the subway. We\u2019re saying that if you jump a turnstile that you should still be given a summons.\u201d\n\nBy the end of the day, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo weighed in with a statement urging \u201call parties\u201d to find \u201cbalance\u201d \u2014 but declining to take a side.", "title": "Turnstile Jumping Pits de Blasio Against Police Reformers", "authors": ["J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "But this album also has moments of lightness, mild turns in complementary directions that add breathing room and complexity: flickers of Metallica on \u201c(Lost Another) Piece of My World,\u201d Bad Brains (\u201cI Don\u2019t Wanna Be Blind\u201d) and maybe Queens of the Stone Age (\u201cGenerator\u201d). Thanks to the bassist Franz Lyons, Turnstile is more fluent with groove than many of its peers. And the drummer Daniel Fang serves as a bridge between this band\u2019s two instincts, capable of ferociously linear work when it\u2019s called for but also of leaving room for experimentation.\n\nAt what point this ceases to be hardcore might be the fodder of message board debate or jostling in the pit, but it doesn\u2019t much trouble this band, which invited some outside guests to add texture: light R&B drizzles from Tanikka Charra\u00e9 on \u201cBomb,\u201d soulful punk lullabies from Sheer Mag\u2019s Tina Halladay on \u201cMoon,\u201d and some perfunctory bleeps and bloops from Diplo on \u201cRight to Be.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTurnstile isn\u2019t alone in its mission \u2014 it walks alongside hardcore bands like Code Orange (whose latest album was produced by Will Yip, who also produced \u201cTime & Space\u201d) and Trash Talk, which has released music on Odd Future\u2019s label. For the last couple of years, at festivals like Nature World Night Out, hardcore and hip-hop have coexisted side by side. (What\u2019s more, the record executive who signed Turnstile is also a rapper, Cody B. Ware of World\u2019s Fair.)\n\nPerhaps there is more logic to this moment in hardcore than is immediately evident, because strangely, and somewhat unexpectedly, the mantle of heavy music in pop has over the last year or so migrated into hip-hop, thanks to the emergence of SoundCloud rap, which in its purest early form was as dogmatic as hardcore.\n\nMuch of that is owed to the producer Ronny J, who was responsible for several of the scene\u2019s earliest hits (Smokepurpp\u2019s \u201cAudi,\u201d Lil Pump\u2019s \u201cMolly\u201d). The lineage is clear on \u201cOMGRONNY,\u201d his first full-length release, and the most effective of any of the first wave of SoundCloud rap albums. (The others, released by rappers, tend to muddle the sound, suggesting a tug of war between the aggression of the original idea and the impulse to become more mainstream.)\n\nPhoto\n\nRonny J isn\u2019t similarly burdened: \u201cOMGRONNY\u201d \u2014 which features vocals from a retinue of Florida-based SoundCloud rappers \u2014 is intense and dirty, and something like punk. His production is menacing and to-the-point, deploying distorted drums with military precision. \u201cTrauma,\u201d featuring Nell and Danny Towers, is beautifully clangorous, and \u201cFiji Island,\u201d featuring Fat Nick, sounds like it\u2019s moving at two speeds at once, slow creep and fast sledgehammer.\n\n\u201cOMGRONNY\u201d is a useful reminder that what united this scene \u2014 in so much as it ever was one \u2014 was the tenor of the production, followed by the flow patterns it encouraged in its rappers. But this world is diverse. Smokepurpp sounds like a classicist here on \u201cOne Time,\u201d but there are also differing styles: the wordy Wifisfuneral (\u201cSnakes\u201d) and Ronny J himself, who sing-raps on several songs using heavy vocal processing. Throughout, though, the bass rattles and shivers, an unnerving commitment to the scene\u2019s rule book, and maybe also its last document.", "title": "Turnstile Knows Hardcore\u2019s Rules. That\u2019s Why It Can Break Them.", "authors": ["Jon Caramanica"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nThe following entirely believable scenario says much about America\u2019s bizarre (and tragic) legal priorities:\n\nA 19-year-old disturbed young man walks into a Florida big-box store.\n\nYoung man: \u201cI\u2019d like a bottle of OxyContin.\u201d\n\nClerk: \u201cSorry, you need a prescription to buy OxyContin.\u201d\n\nYoung man: \u201cO.K., then give me a six-pack of Bud.\u201d\n\nClerk: \u201cDo you have ID? You have to be 21 to buy alcoholic beverages.\u201d\n\nYoung man: \u201cWell, then, I\u2019ll take an AR-15 semiautomatic rifle.\u201d\n\nClerk: \u201cVery good, sir. Will that be cash or charge?\u201d\n\nDAVID WINTER, ALBUQUERQUE", "title": "Opinion | Twisted Priorities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe user growth is kind of astounding,\u201d said Rich Greenfield, a media and tech analyst at the research firm BTIG, who has been recommending the stock for a year. \u201cThey were barely growing two years ago.\u201d\n\nTwitter originally showed tweets in reverse chronological order \u2014 the latest posts, however mundane, were on top. Now it is using algorithms to try to show the most important tweets first, making the site more engaging.\n\n\u201cIf you show the right tweets to the right person at the right time, it creates user happiness,\u201d Mr. Greenfield said. \u201cThat means more time spent on the site, which means more opportunities for advertising.\u201d\n\nThis has been a good week for social media companies that are not Facebook. On Tuesday, Snap reported much better revenue than expected, and a slightly narrower loss. Its shares also soared on the news. In contrast, Facebook said last week that it had made changes that reduced the hours its two billion users were spending on its pages.\n\nOver all, Twitter reported a profit of $91 million in the final three months of 2017, compared with a loss of $167 million a year earlier. Margins were much better, expenses were lower and stock-based compensation decreased sharply.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOther numbers were not as impressive. Revenue rose 2 percent to $732 million in the quarter. Revenue from advertising, which makes up the bulk of its revenue, increased 1 percent. In general, Twitter exceeded low expectations.\n\n\u201cA solid result across the board and builds upon the momentum\u201d from the third quarter, analysts at UBS wrote in a research note.\n\nOne quarter is not much of a streak, and Twitter has often been unable to keep it up. Jim Cridlin, the global head of innovation at Mindshare, a unit of the advertising giant WPP, said that while Twitter\u2019s momentum continued into the fourth quarter, the company still faced \u201csignificant headwinds.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLeadership is one issue. Mr. Dorsey splits his time between Twitter and his other company, the digital payments firm Square. Last month, Anthony Noto, Twitter\u2019s chief operating officer and one of Mr. Dorsey\u2019s most trusted deputies, left the company to become chief executive of the embattled online lender Social Finance.\n\nTwitter also faces criticism as federal and state authorities scrutinize companies that sold millions of fake followers on social media platforms. More than one million followers of entertainers, athletes and others have disappeared after an article by The New York Times detailed the business practices of a company called Devumi. Twitter previously said it would take action against Devumi\u2019s practices.\n\nFor the current quarter, UBS calculated that Twitter would generate $583 million of revenue, $11 million more than analysts were predicting. That might keep the party going.\n\nWhat really is helping Twitter is that there are only three American social media companies that count. Facebook is by far the largest, but is under pressure from all quarters precisely because of its size and influence. It is trying to moderate the latter without hurting the former, which is going to be tricky. Snap is a singular effort forging its own direction as a communications platform.\n\nThat leaves Twitter, troubled as it might be.\n\n\u201cAdvertisers have a huge desire to be on mobile devices more, but there are not a lot of ways to reach people on applications worthy of your home screen,\u201d said Mr. Greenfield. \u201cTwitter is on your home screen.\u201d", "title": "Twitter Has Good News for Once: Its First Quarterly Profit", "authors": ["David Streitfeld", "Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion), and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | Twitter: The New Nuclear Weapon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. de Blasio said that investigators believed that there were no other people involved, adding, \u201cThere is no additional, imminent threat directed at New York City at this time.\u201d\n\nThe investigation that ultimately led to the Toro brothers began on Dec. 4, when a bomb threat was called into the Harlem charter school where Christian Toro worked, according to the complaint and John J. Miller, the deputy commissioner of intelligence and counterterrorism, who spoke at the news conference with Mr. de Blasio.\n\nA 15-year-old student was arrested and charged with making the threatening call.\n\nA spokesman for the school, Harlem Prep High School, said Christian Toro resigned on Jan. 9. Three days later, his brother returned to the school a laptop computer that the school had given Christian Toro, Mr. Miller said.\n\nHarlem Prep is operated by the charter network Democracy Prep Public Schools.\n\n\u201cAfter he resigned, Democracy Prep did a routine review of his laptop and was deeply disturbed by suspicious content,\u201d said the spokesman, Jeffrey W. Schneider.\n\nPhoto\n\nA technician at the charter school examined Mr. Toro\u2019s laptop, and found on its hard drive a copy of a book that contained instructions for making explosives, the complaint said. The school alerted law enforcement officials.\n\nOn Jan. 31, the police arrested Christian Toro and charged him with raping a minor. A law enforcement official said that the alleged victim was a student at the school where he worked. \u201cThat was something that developed as a result of the investigation of the bomb scare to the school,\u201d according to Mr. Miller. Mr. Toro was released on bail two days later, according to city records. According to Bronx court records, the girl was 15, and Mr. Toro took her home for sex on two occasions.\n\nOn Feb. 8, the F.B.I. and police officers interviewed the Toro brothers in their apartment, and Christian Toro told agents that he had come across the explosives book while doing research about the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing and had not meant to download it onto his computer, according to the complaint. He said that he had never built a bomb, the complaint said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSix days later, on Valentine\u2019s Day, law enforcement agents interviewed students at the charter school, who told them that at least two students had visited the Toros\u2019s apartment to break down the fireworks, storing the powder in containers, the complaint said. It said that the students appeared to have gone to the apartment between October and early January.\n\nOn Thursday morning, law enforcement agents executed a search warrant at the brothers\u2019 apartment, where they lived with a female relative.\n\nThe complaint said that the agents found bomb-making materials in a closet, including a box containing about 20 pounds of iron oxide, five pounds of aluminum powder, five pounds of potassium nitrate, all materials that can be used to build explosives. It also contained about two pounds of confectioners sugar, which the complaint said can be used as fuel in an explosive. They also found firecrackers and other explosive materials and a bag of metal balls that could have been used as shrapnel in a bomb.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Miller said that investigators also found \u201csimulated weapons\u201d at the apartment.\n\nThe complaint said that on a kitchen table the agents found a diary, which contained Tyler Toro\u2019s name in it, along with contact information. The diary contained handwriting that said, among other things, \u201cWe are twin Toros strike us now, we will return with nano thermite.\u201d\n\nIt also said, \u201cIf you\u2019re registered as a sex offender, things will be difficult. But I am here 100%, living, buying weapons, whatever we need.\u201d\n\nThe complaint said that in a bedroom that the brothers share, agents found a yellow backpack belonging to Christian Toro. Inside the backpack was the index card with the writing that said, \u201cUnder the full moon the small ones will know terror.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know at this point in the investigation, other than the criminal charges related to the explosives, the full breadth of what these materials mean,\u201d Mr. Miller said, referring to the writings.\n\nPhoto\n\nA law enforcement official could not say whether the two were affiliated with, or influenced by, an international organization.\n\nRaymond Del Villar, 20, who lives in apartment across from the brothers, said he was on his way to school when he saw up to 20 detectives in the hallway, and his neighbors in handcuffs near the elevator several feet away on Thursday morning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey were bringing stuff out in bags,\u201d he said. \u201cI was surprised.\u201d\n\nAnother neighbor, who declined to give his name, said the boys moved in with a relative about two months ago. He said one of the brother\u2019s worked at a Shake Shack in Yonkers and would give him a discount. That neighbor said the woman who lived with them was \u201ca nice, courteous\u201d woman.\n\nNeighbors said they heard commotion at about 7 a.m. and saw detectives in the hallway and saw police cars outside.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t know what was going on,\u201d the resident said. \u201cLater on, I found out they had bomb-making materials. I got kids! It\u2019s scary to think about people like that in this building.\u201d\n\nOther neighbors described the twins as well-educated, nicely dressed young men who generally kept to themselves.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re nice boys, pleasant, they held the elevator,\u201d said Rochelle Shapiro, 63. \u201cWhy would someone want to do this?\u201d\n\nThe arrests come after a pair of recent terror attacks in New York City.\n\nOn Dec. 11, Akayed Ullah, an immigrant from Bangladesh, tried to detonate a homemade bomb in a subway corridor near the Port Authority, bringing the heart of Midtown to a standstill. He later told investigators that he \u201cdid it for the Islamic State.\u201d\n\nSix weeks earlier, on Halloween, Sayfullo Saipov, an Uzbek immigrant, killed eight people and injured a dozen others, when he rammed a rented Home Depot truck into a crowded bike path in Lower Manhattan, near Stuyvesant High School. And on Oct. 6, federal authorities revealed that they had foiled a plot to detonate bombs in Times Square and the subway system, and to open fire at concert venues.\n\nThe arrests also come two days after Ahmad Khan Rahimi, an Afghan-born immigrant, who was convicted of exploding a pressure-cooker bomb in Manhattan in 2016, was sentenced to two life terms in prison.", "title": "Two Bronx Brothers Arrested in Bomb-Making Scheme", "authors": ["William K. Rashbaum", "William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Even as downtown Nogales, Sonora, also struggles to remain vibrant with fewer Americans crossing over, the rest of the city is thriving, seemingly growing by the day and producing not just art, but a new gastronomic culture, said Alex La Pierre, the program director for the Border Community Alliance.\n\nThe alliance, which works with organizations in both countries to increase social investment and improve Americans\u2019 understanding of the border, offers tours for Americans who prefer to visit with a guide. One of the tours introduces them to nonprofits including a migrant shelter. Another takes them to a craft brewery and to Calle Hermosillo, a long street that is home to many new restaurants and bars.\n\n\u201cSonora, in addition to having the best beef in all of Mexico,\u201d Mr. La Pierre said, \u201calso has some of the best seafood in Mexico, because they\u2019re adjacent to the Gulf of California, which Jacques Cousteau called \u2018the aquarium of the world.\u2019 What I tell our guests is that Sonora really has the best of surf and turf.\u201d\n\nOn a warm Saturday in early January, as I walked the downtown zone, averting my eyes to avoid the many vendors who will immediately try to pull you into their curio shops, I felt the energy change immediately. Mexican border cities are always a little busier and more alive than their American counterparts. Cars backed out of parking spots from every direction, and people moved briskly along the sidewalks. Amid endless pharmacies and dental offices catering to mostly-gone Americans, local life pulsed and thrived.\n\nAs I turned a corner and made my way toward Calle Internacional, the street that once singularly marked the border, to view the wall art, I glimpsed a young woman on the American side of the fence who was reaching through it as she lovingly stroked the head of a teenage boy squatting on the other side. And I remembered Jessy Zamorano\u2019s comment about tourists reacting when they witness these displays of humanity.\n\nIt seems something fantastic happens when you draw a line on the ground: People almost instinctively reach out across it toward each other. And that\u2019s a hard thing to appreciate from anywhere else but the border.", "title": "Two Cities, Two Countries, Common Ground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cShe wanted to know how rich we were, and about how much money I made, in U.S. dollars, and I told her,\u201d said Hyun, who became a celebrity in both Koreas when the Korean women\u2019s team upset China to win the gold medal at those world championships. \u201cI just told her everything, and we became friends. And now I miss her. It was just so natural that we were on a team together.\u201d\n\nBefore that unified team came together, neither Kim Taek-soo nor Hyun could imagine the power of it. They were too young at the time and too single-minded, with their focus on their sport. Both said they realized much later that it had changed the way they looked at life and at their divided country. It forced them to think about reunification, even though it hadn\u2019t been on their minds.\n\nBoth said they were crushed when the good feelings created by their joint team in 1991 vanished shortly after the world championships, just like Kim\u2019s doubles partner vanished. For years after they played together, Kim asked other North Koreans how his partner was doing, but everyone said they had no information. The player had just disappeared.", "title": "Two Koreas, One Flag and All Those Memories of Unification", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "More recently, however, the North and South have come to see international sporting events as a chance to defuse tensions, including the current standoff over North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons and ballistic missile programs. The two Koreas have also learned to use Olympic diplomacy to achieve in a small, symbolic way a much bigger goal that eludes them in the real world: a show of unity across the divided Korean Peninsula.\n\n\u201cIt is not an impossible dream,\u201d South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, said at the United Nations in September. He said the coming Olympics, which are being held in the South Korean resort of Pyeongchang, \u201cwill become a candle that sheds light on peace.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEven the limited show of cooperation during the Pyeongchang Olympics is the culmination of a long process of sports rapprochement that has tracked the ups and downs of the larger political relationship between the Koreas. No evidence has surfaced of the wealthy South paying off its impoverished neighbor in exchange for Olympic cooperation, but the advances have come at times when the South was more forthcoming with aid and investment.\n\nLast year, the administration of Mr. Moon offered to donate $8 million to two United Nations humanitarian programs working in North Korea. Mr. Moon suspended the plan after international pushback that the offer might undermine United Nations sanctions against the North\u2019s nuclear weapons and missile programs.\n\nIn Pyeongchang, South Korea will pay for the joint uniforms to be worn by athletes of both sides during the opening ceremony, and foot the bill for housing and feeding hundreds of North Korean dancers and cultural entertainers who will perform during the Games. However, no money will go directly to them, South Korean officials have said.\n\nThe North Koreans are also quite likely to be the only athletes not to receive a free smartphone from the Olympic sponsor Samsung. South Korean officials said they were eager to dispel concerns, particularly in Washington, that they were making payments to the North that could violate sanctions.\n\n\u201cWe are trying to brief the Americans so thoroughly about every detail of matters concerning sanctions and the North Korean delegation that they get tired of hearing it,\u201d said Cho Myoung-gyon, who as South Korea\u2019s unification minister is in charge of dealings with the North.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe I.O.C. first urged North and South Korean sports officials to meet in 1963, a time when East and West Germany had created a joint Olympic squad. But the two Koreas could get no further than deciding that a hypothetical joint squad would use a well-known Korean folk song, \u201cArirang,\u201d instead of picking one of their national anthems.\n\nThey agreed to talk again before the Los Angeles Olympics in 1984. But when they met on their shared border, the heavily fortified Demilitarized Zone, the talks quickly devolved into mutual recriminations. South Korea demanded that the North apologize for its bombing of Mr. Chun\u2019s presidential delegation in Burma the previous year, which killed 17 South Koreans, while North Korea called Mr. Chun a \u201cbloody-handed\u201d dictator for ordering the massacre of protesters in the city of Kwangju in 1980.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt was nothing but a slandering match,\u201d said Lim Tae-sun, 83, a former South Korean negotiator who was present at the meeting. \u201cWe hardly discussed the real agenda.\u201d\n\nIn 1985, the I.O.C. invited the two Koreas to Lausanne, Switzerland, in an attempt to broker an end to North Korea\u2019s bitter campaign against the 1988 Summer Games awarded to Seoul. The North insisted on sharing the Games, arguing that \u201chosting of the Games by one part of the nation aggravated the antagonism and division between the two peoples.\u201d\n\nIt also made veiled threats, telling a visiting I.O.C. vice president that \u201cany accidental error would have disastrous effects on the peaceful celebration of the Games.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSouth Korea countered by offering only a few events, like table tennis and archery, to the North. When North Korea boycotted the 1988 Games, only a handful of its allies, including Cuba, followed suit.\n\nThe first breakthrough came at the end of the Cold War, when the two Koreas agreed in 1991 to form a joint team for the World Table Tennis Championships in Chiba, Japan.\n\nUnder the deal, the two governments agreed that the unified team would use the name Korea and carry a blue-and-white flag showing an undivided Korean Peninsula. The South also made a key concession, agreeing that each Korea should contribute the same number of players.\n\nThe brief sports d\u00e9tente came to an abrupt end that same year when a North Korean attending a judo championship in Barcelona, Spain, defected to South Korea. The North receded into deeper isolation during a devastating famine.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the late 1990s, South Korea persuaded the North to resume sports exchanges with the help of economic aid from a private citizen, Chung Ju-yung, the billionaire founder of South Korea\u2019s Hyundai conglomerate. In 1999, the two Koreas played friendly basketball matches in Pyongyang and Seoul after ground was broken for an arena Mr. Chung donated in the North Korean capital.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSports exchanges flourished as the two Koreas achieved a political rapprochement during the early 2000s, when liberal administrations in South Korea pursued a Sunshine Policy of promoting warmer ties backed by generous offers of aid and investment. The two Koreas marched together in the Olympic opening ceremonies in 2000, 2004 and 2006.\n\nBut even during these years, a joint Olympic team remained out of reach. South Korean athletes objected to relinquishing their hard-won spots. Coaches said the two Koreas remained just too far apart in thinking, training and abilities.\n\n\u201cI find it hard to imagine archers from the two Koreas competing on the same team,\u201d Seo Keo-won, an executive at the Korea Archery Association in Seoul, said at the time.\n\nThe sports diplomacy froze in 2008 as a new conservative government in Seoul limited ties with the North, refusing to turn a blind eye to its weapons programs. Talks to field a joint team at the Summer Games that year in Beijing collapsed after the South rejected the North\u2019s condition of equal numbers of athletes.\n\nThis year\u2019s deal came after Mr. Moon, a political liberal who has expressed eagerness to restore inter-Korean exchanges, took office last May. The North also showed flexibility in agreeing to a joint squad in women\u2019s hockey, one of the few winter team sports in which it competes.\n\nThe joint team was created by adding 12 North Koreans to the existing South Korean national team of 23 players. The head coach is a Canadian appointed by South Korea, who must select at least three North Koreans to play in each game.\n\nSouth Korean officials say they did not promise aid for the deal. But they did make one important concession: postponing joint military exercises with the United States.\n\n\u201cSports exchanges can prosper only when political issues are resolved,\u201d said Chang Ung, a North Korean member of the I.O.C., after landing in Seoul this week. \u201cThat is an unbreakable rule on the divided Korean Peninsula.\u201d", "title": "Two Koreas, Split by War, Use Olympics to Make Rare Shows of Unity", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "The United States, she said, is \u201cjust more individual skill; they have four lines that could play on any other team.\u201d\n\nRaty, 28, the first female goaltender to play in Finland\u2019s second-tier men\u2019s pro league, attended college at the University of Minnesota, where she became the winningest women\u2019s goalie in N.C.A.A. history with 114 victories. She now plays for a team in China, which is striving to develop a competitive women\u2019s team ahead of the 2022 Games in Beijing, but continues to make Minnesota her home base.\n\nRaty\u2019s globe-trotting existence has enabled her to see women\u2019s progress from many sides. She supported her friends on the United States team last year when it threatened to boycott the women\u2019s world championships if U.S.A. Hockey, the sport\u2019s national governing body, did not increase salaries and support for the women\u2019s program. The team\u2019s standoff led to a four-year deal that affords the women greater travel and insurance provisions; a guaranteed $2,000 training stipend per month, year-round, from the United States Olympic Committee; and larger performance bonuses for winning medals.\n\nBut Raty is also realistic. She recognized that the same conditions that the American women found untenable would be considered progress among her Finnish teammates. For all of Finland\u2019s international success, Raty said, the country\u2019s system for developing players leaves a lot to be desired.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI feel like all the good coaches go to the boys\u2019 side,\u201d she said.\n\nAnd the lack of support goes deeper than that. \u201cIn Finland, you say you\u2019re a hockey player and they\u2019re like, \u2018Get a real job,\u2019\u201d Raty said, adding, \u201cI feel like in Finland, if you\u2019re not making money in sports you should do something else.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe United States is different, Raty said. Her American friends might not get big paychecks, but they are encouraged to dream big. \u201cPeople think it\u2019s cool you\u2019re willing to put your personal life and finances to the side and go after your dreams,\u201d she said.\n\nWill developing hockey countries like South Korea and China pour enough money and resources into their women\u2019s programs to significantly bridge the gap with Canada and the United States? They have their work cut out for them, since the North American pipeline shows no signs of drying up.\n\nRaty, who works with young players in Minnesota, said, \u201cThere\u2019s a lot more coming.\u201d\n\nOne of the players whom Raty taught a few years ago has arrived. Her name is Maddie Rooney, and on Monday she started in goal for the United States, stopping 14 shots in the semifinal victory. \u201cI take credit for some of the coaching I\u2019ve done with her,\u201d Raty said.\n\nWith tongue in cheek, she added, \u201cI\u2019m really happy she played well today, although she could have let in a few goals.\u201d\n\nMonday\u2019s announcement that the Olympics will let in two more teams was celebrated as a victory for women\u2019s hockey. But if an established program like Finland can\u2019t keep pace with the United States, how will the upstarts?", "title": "Two More Invitations to the U.S.-Canada Party", "authors": ["Karen Crouse"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The 2011 story is clearly the principal one, although not necessarily the most engaging. In it, a second-tier tennis pro, Sandy Allison, falls in love with Alice du Pont, the wealthy owner of Windermere, a Newport estate whose maze, based on the one at Hampton Court in England, provides the novel\u2019s central metaphor. Alice has cerebral palsy, is bipolar and always looks (to Sandy) \u201clike she was being electrocuted.\u201d She wears bowling shirts and pedal pushers as well as rodeo, biker and hippie outfits, and her interest in history helps link 2011 to the novel\u2019s other stories. Indeed, at one point, she leads Sandy on a tour of historical Newport, walking, she tells him, \u201cfrom the 21st century backwards\u201d \u2014 a nudge to nodding readers who may have missed the novel\u2019s pattern.\n\nImage\n\nOf the other stories, most are in the first person and written as notebooks or journals; the best is by Henry James, who did in fact live in Newport as a young man. Smith\u2019s portrait of James is at times excellent, rivaling that of Colm Toibin in \u201cThe Master.\u201d We follow James, a self-described \u201cbudding novelist,\u201d as he strikes up an acquaintance with a young woman, a friendship that goes terribly wrong when she mistakes it for courtship and, to his horror, asks him to marry her. Smith sprinkles James\u2019s distinctively fresh early style with just the lightest pinch of turgid fussiness \u2014 the language is pitch perfect \u2014 and his insights into James\u2019s character and mind are flawless.\n\nSmith\u2019s ability to capture the character of the languages used in each of his historical periods is remarkable. His 18th-century British officer, stationed in Newport during the American Revolution in the 1778 chapters, is a chillingly convincing sexual predator of the spoiled and privileged sort described by Samuel Richardson. Almost a century earlier, Smith\u2019s teenage Quaker girl makes a refreshing contrast. The richness of these 17th- and 18th-century voices makes the 21st-century chapters sound flat in comparison.\n\nThe different strands of the narrative are skillfully braided. Each is interrupted by the next at a salient moment, and each is strong enough that readers can forgive the omnibus ending, whose breathless melodrama feels out of sync with the rest of the novel, and whose struggle to highlight parallels and links between the stories becomes a bit ham-handed. The feeling here is that the writer began with a method that acts like a template and so has to see it through, with the result, for example, that Henry James\u2019s comeuppance is improbably (and not credibly) similar to that of one of Smith\u2019s fortune hunters.\n\nLucy Hughes-Hallett\u2019s \u201cPeculiar Ground\u201d is more modest in its formal ambitions but more ambitious in its plenitude and sweep. Like \u201cThe Maze at Windermere,\u201d \u201cPeculiar Ground\u201d is centered on a great house, in this case Wychwood in Oxfordshire, England, and, as in Smith\u2019s narrative, the historical roots of the story go back to the 17th century, when a five-mile-long wall is being built around Wychwood. In contrast to Smith, however, who in postmodern fashion slices, dices and shuffles his history, Hughes-Hallett takes a more modernist approach by embedding her story inside a frame. The novel begins in 1663, not long after the end of the English Civil War, then jumps to the 20th century for the bulk of the narrative before returning to the 1600s at the end. The 20th century is clearly Hughes-Hallett\u2019s chief focus, and she frames its narrative in turn by beginning in 1961, when the Berlin Wall was built, and ending in 1989, when it fell. Frames and walls, then, are formal devices in this novel as well as thematic obsessions, and are the chief metaphors on either end of a 300-year hiatus. A wall includes and excludes; it encloses and protects privileged inhabitants and means to keep all others out, including religious dissenters and those fleeing the plague; yet it also, as one character notes, creates toxic and stagnant communities for its \u201cprisoners.\u201d\n\nLest all this sound cold and mechanical, a wall\u2019s social straitjacket also induces a certain vital energy, a desire to fling one\u2019s arms apart, and this large and rich kitchen sink of a novel (as in everything but) is full of drama, vivid characters, wit, gorgeous writing and fascinating botanical, religious and social detail. Among its themes \u2014 and perhaps the most engaging one \u2014 is the decline of the great houses of England. We witness the estate of Wychwood being built, watch it survive fire and flood. We both applaud and cringe when it changes hands and becomes first a venue for the \u201970s subculture, with its voluptuaries, dropouts, druggies and rock musicians, its wealthy patrons and hangers-on, and then, at the end, a \u201cpublic show\u201d with a little train that takes tourists on rides through the estate, a wildlife park, a craft center and garden shop and \u2014 the ultimate indignity \u2014 a television series whose measure of success is its sale to an American network.", "title": "Two Novels Trace Parallels Between Past and Present, or Create Them", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Two police officers in a city near Columbus, Ohio, were shot and killed Saturday while responding to a 911 hangup call involving potential domestic abuse, the authorities said.\n\nChief Joe Morbitzer of the Westerville Police Department said the officers, Eric Joering, 39, and Anthony Morelli, 54, had responded at 12:10 p.m., eight minutes after the call, about a \u201cpotential domestic situation.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs they went into the apartment they were immediately met with gunfire, and both officers were shot,\u201d Chief Morbitzer said at a news conference on Saturday afternoon. He paused several times to choke back tears.\n\nOfficer Joering, a 16-year veteran of the department, died at the scene. Officer Morelli, a 29-year veteran, was transported to the Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center in Columbus in critical condition and later died. Officer Joering had a wife and four daughters, and Officer Morelli had a wife and two children.", "title": "Two Ohio Police Officers Killed Responding to 911 Hangup Call, Officials Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "And on Fifth Avenue, Bruce Winston, a son of the jeweler Harry Winston, purchased an apartment, while the Walt Disney Company\u2019s chief executive, Robert A.
