Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "U.S. Bancorp Fined $613 Million for Money-Laundering Violations: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOur culture of ethics and integrity demands that we do better,\u201d he said.\n\nThe action against U.S. Bank was modest compared with cases involving banking giants like HSBC and Standard Chartered that the authorities found had done business with drug gangs and countries like Cuba and Iran that had been barred from the United States financial system under international sanctions. In 2012, for instance, federal prosecutors settled a money-laundering case against HSBC for $1.9 billion.\n\nUnlike the earlier cases, the one involving U.S. Bank focused mainly on warning signs that the bank was ignoring.\n\nFor about five years, senior bank employees tried to balance their security system\u2019s constant alerts about suspicious customer activity against internal staffing limitations, the authorities said. In a late-2009 memo, court documents show, U.S. Bank\u2019s anti-money-laundering officer warned the chief compliance officer that employees responsible for investigating the alerts were \u201cstretched dangerously thin.\u201d\n\nBut senior bank officials knew they should not be curtailing money-laundering inquiries just because they did not have enough employees, so they hid the practice from federal bank examiners, according to prosecutors. One U.S. Bank employee left references to the staffing problem out of the minutes of internal meetings, fearful of what regulators would think, the Justice Department said. Tests of the alert system were halted after they showed that the bank had failed to report suspicious customer activity to regulators.\n\nDana Ripley, a U.S. Bank spokesman, said that most of the senior employees involved in the practices at issue had left by 2014, when the bank overhauled its anti-money laundering program.", "title": "U.S. Bank Cited by Federal Authorities for Lapses on Money Laundering", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Doping by Russian athletes infested biathlon for years. The revelations in 2016 unmasked the larger state-led doping program. Yet the I.B.U. has resisted calls to move events from the country, saying those decisions were made before the World Anti-Doping Agency declared Russia\u2019s antidoping noncompliant.\n\n\u201cThe I.B.U.\u2019s recent decision to move forward with the World Cup Final in Tyumen, Russia, is completely unacceptable,\u201d the U.S. athletes said in a statement.\n\nTheir decision follows a similar stand made by the Canadian team. Czech officials, cited by the French news agency Agence France-Presse, said their athletes would also boycott the event. Sweden\u2019s Sebastian Samuelsson said his team was also poised to boycott events in Russia. Samuelsson won a silver medal in Pyeongchang last week.\n\n\u201cThe outcry from our fellow athletes from around the world has been respectful, strong and definitive. In addition to the dozens who expressed their opinion to the I.B.U. Athletes Committee members ahead of the meeting in January 2018, the I.B.U. received letters representing over 30 athletes, from eight countries, and included three 2018 Olympic Champions,\u201d the American statement added.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee itself has directed winter sports organizations like the I.B.U. to halt their preparations for competitions in Russia and seek alternative venues. For sports officials that have defied that guidance, the threat of boycott by global athletes has prompted them to move major events, including skiing, bobsled and skeleton competitions.\n\nThe World Anti-Doping Agency has declared Russia\u2019s drug testing authority noncompliant, a status it says it will maintain until Russia publicly accepts that there was a state-backed doping program and allows WADA officials full access to data from the main testing laboratory in Moscow.", "title": "U.S. Biathletes Boycott Russia Event", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 United States officials have torpedoed a Chinese state-backed group\u2019s plan to buy an American electronics company, signaling the Trump administration\u2019s continuing skepticism toward Chinese investment deals, particularly those that involve transferring technological know-how.\n\nXcerra, a Massachusetts-based provider of equipment for testing computer chips and circuit boards, said this week that it was withdrawing from its $580 million sale to an investment group backed by a Chinese government-controlled fund.\n\nThe reason, according to Dave Tacelli, Xcerra\u2019s president and chief executive, was that the deal was not likely to be approved by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, a multiagency Washington panel that operates largely out of the public eye. The committee, known as Cfius, plays an advisory role to the president, but it can effectively block foreign acquisitions of American companies over national security concerns.\n\n\u201cDespite our best efforts to secure approval, it has become evident that Cfius will not clear this transaction,\u201d Mr. Tacelli said. The deal would ultimately have been financed by the China Integrated Circuit Industry Investment Fund, a $21 billion fund that counts several Chinese state-run companies as investors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was the latest in a string of Chinese acquisitions scotched by Washington officials. Under President Barack Obama, regulators showed increased skepticism about Chinese deals involving technology companies. That trend has continued under President Trump, who has taken a tough line on China\u2019s trade and investment practices.", "title": "U.S. Blocks a Chinese Deal Amid Rising Tensions Over Technology", "authors": ["Raymond Zhong"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "In December, the White House approved the sale of lethal defensive weapons to the Ukrainian military for its battle against Russian-backed forces in eastern Ukraine. Yet Mr. Trump continues to soft-pedal allegations that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election, even after the nation\u2019s intelligence agencies concluded that it did \u2014 an assessment that intelligence chiefs reiterated in Senate testimony this week.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdministration officials declined to say what steps the United States would take against Russia. But they could include both sanctions against Russian officials involved in the attack and covert measures \u2014 any of which would be likely to fray an already fragile relationship.\n\nThe administration\u2019s public statement echoed one in mid-December when it publicly blamed North Korea for a damaging ransomware attack known as Wannacry. In that case, however, the United States did not follow up with stiff penalties, in part because North Korea was already under heavy sanctions for its nuclear and ballistic missile programs.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump has used just about every lever you can use, short of starving the people of North Korea, to change their behavior,\u201d the homeland security adviser, Thomas P. Bossert, said at the time. \u201cSo we don\u2019t have a lot of room left here to apply pressure.\u201d\n\nPunishing other nations for cyberattacks has proven exceedingly difficult, particularly when the players are as sophisticated as North Korea and Russia. The Russian government flatly denied the allegations that it carried out the attack.\n\n\u201cWe think they have no basis and no foundation, and this is nothing else but the continuation of the Russo-phobic campaign,\u201d the Kremlin\u2019s spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, told reporters.\n\nThe administration had planned to issue the statement a day earlier to coincide with that of the British, according to a senior official, but delayed it after the deadly school shooting in Parkland, Fla.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe White House statement made no mention of an embarrassing related fact: The NotPetya attacks took advantage of vulnerabilities identified by the National Security Agency and then made public by a group calling itself the Shadow Brokers.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Shadow Brokers, which some officials believe to be a front for Russian intelligence, obtained many of the N.S.A.\u2019s most valuable hacking tools, either by breaking into the agency\u2019s computer networks or with the help of an insider. The group has posted much of the stolen malware on the web; North Korea\u2019s hackers probably used the tools in their attack.\n\nIn a ransomware attack, the victim\u2019s files are encrypted, locking them out of their own computer systems, until they pay a ransom. Cybersecurity researchers estimate that criminals made more than $1 billion through these attacks last year, with victims ranging from the chief executives of major companies to small businesses and private individuals.\n\nWhile the motive for many ransomware attacks is financial, Russia\u2019s involvement suggests it was part of a broader strategy to destabilize Ukraine that dates back to Russia\u2019s annexation of Crimea in 2014.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe NotPetya attack originated in Ukraine, according to security researchers, apparently timed to strike a day before a holiday marking the 1996 adoption of Ukraine\u2019s first constitution. It eventually spread to 64 countries, including Poland, Germany, Italy, and Russia itself.\n\nThe administration\u2019s action came as intelligence agencies warned that Russia was already meddling in the American midterm elections, using bots and other fake accounts on social media to spread disinformation.\n\n\u201cWe expect Russia to continue using propaganda, social media, false-flag personas, sympathetic spokespeople and other means of influence to try to exacerbate social and political fissures in the United States,\u201d Dan Coats, the director of national intelligence, told the Senate Intelligence Committee at its annual hearing on worldwide threats.\n\n\u201cThere should be no doubt that Russia perceives its past efforts as successful and views the 2018 U.S. midterm elections as a potential target for Russian influence operations,\u201d Mr. Coats added.", "title": "U.S. Condemns Russia for Cyberattack, Showing Split in Stance on Putin", "authors": ["Mark Landler", "Scott Shane"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "GANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 Four years after he was basically cut from the United States curling program, John Shuster began to celebrate with his teammates before his final rock of the match even came to a rest. The victory was as improbable as it was meaningful.\n\n\u201cThis team,\u201d he said, \u201cis by far the most resilient group of guys.\u201d\n\nThe United States men\u2019s curling team, on the brink of elimination for much of the 2018 Winter Olympics, withstood enormous pressure to defeat Canada, 5-3, on Thursday in a semifinal at Gangneung Curling Centre. Behind Shuster, the Americans advanced to face Sweden, the top-ranked team in the world, for gold in Saturday\u2019s final.\n\n\u201cI think it was heroic,\u201d Shuster\u2019s teammate Tyler George said. \u201cThe guys, one through four, just played the game of their lives when it mattered most. That\u2019s what you dream about doing.\u201d\n\nShuster, George and their two teammates \u2014 John Landsteiner and Matt Hamilton \u2014 had a 2-4 record in pool play less than a week ago before reeling off three straight victories, including one against Canada, to secure a berth in the medal round. The United States had never defeated Canada in Olympic competition. They wound up doing it twice in four days.", "title": "U.S. Curling Team, Once Called \u2018Rejects,\u2019 Beats Canada to Advance to Final", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Randall and Diggins blasted through the semifinals, winning their heat with a time of 16:22.56, more than 10 seconds faster than the Norwegians, who also won their heat. The question was whether the Americans had burned too much energy claiming one of the 10 places in the final, and if they would have enough left to win it.\n\nThey did.\n\n\u201cIn the final stretch I was just thinking, Go, go, go, I\u2019m giving it everything I had and I\u2019ve got someone who I really love and care about waiting for me at the finishing line and I just want to make her proud,\u201d Diggins said.\n\nThe Americans\u2019 winning time \u2014 15:56.47 \u2014 was a 26-second improvement on their semifinal effort. But the gold was not their first milestone.\n\nIn 2013, Randall and Diggins won a world championship gold medal \u2014 the first for the United States \u2014 by taking the women\u2019s team sprint by almost eight seconds. In 2017, they won individual medals at the worlds: Diggins took home the silver in the sprint and Randall the bronze. Diggins also won the bronze in the team sprint at that meet, skiing with Sadie Bjornsen.\n\nThose achievements produced high expectations for the American women in Pyeongchang. A book has been written about them, and the U.S. Ski and Snowboard Association promoted them extensively heading into the Games. But American women have arrived at the Olympics before with a decent shot at a medal, only to be stymied by their rivals from Europe.\n\nThat situation seemed to be repeating itself through the first 11 days of these Games. Diggins finished fifth in the women\u2019s skiathlon, the highest Olympic finish to that point for a United States woman, but out of the medals.\n\nThen she was sixth in the sprint, running out of gas in the finals. Then came the 3.3-second miss in the 10-kilometer race. \u201cI pushed my body so far past its limits I\u2019m actually kind of amazed I didn\u2019t pass out on that final climb,\u201d she wrote on Instagram.", "title": "U.S. Ends Cross-Country Drought With Gold Medal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 A newspaper controlled by the Communist Party of China criticized the United States for its high level of gun violence, calling it hypocritical that a country that condemns others over human rights violations is failing to stem such slaughter at home.\n\nThe opinion column in The Global Times, which is run by the Communist Party\u2019s People\u2019s Daily Group, said that after a gunman killed 17 people last week at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., the United States should look to China, which has strict controls on guns.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s inhumane for the U.S., which boasts about its human rights record, to turn a blind eye to gun violence, snub increasing calls for gun control and risk more innocent lives,\u201d the piece said.\n\nThe column on guns appeared Friday in the English-language edition of the newspaper, but not in the Chinese print version. While The Global Times is controlled by the Communist Party, it is not an authoritative voice, meaning its pugnacious opinion pieces don\u2019t necessarily reflect the views of the Chinese government in the way a commentary in The People\u2019s Daily would.", "title": "U.S. Gun Violence Draws Scorn in China as a Human Rights Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "A system in disarray\n\nFew gymnasts say they will miss Martha and Bela Karolyi\u2019s Texas ranch, where the women\u2019s national team trained for nearly 20 years until U.S.A. Gymnastics cut ties in January. Many were molested there by the former team doctor Lawrence G. Nassar, and the Karolyis are accused of creating an environment that both facilitated his predation and was abusive in its own right. In the past week, both The Associated Press and The Dallas Morning News published major investigations of mistreatment there.\n\nBut many gymnasts do miss the monthly camps where they trained with the national team staff and performed their routines as though they were in competition. Contenders for approaching international events attended a selection camp at Louisiana State University on Sunday, but the regular camps have not been held since November.\n\n\u201cCamps are not just about training,\u201d said Olivia Dunne, 15, who has attended them since she was 10. \u201cAt each camp, we compete and get experience completing routines under pressure.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJade Carey, 17, a double medalist at last year\u2019s world championships, said the hiatus had made it difficult to receive guidance from the national staff. And because few gyms have more than one elite gymnast at a time, many national team members \u2014 far more skilled than anyone around them in daily training \u2014 count on the camps to show them their competition.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt home, Adeline Kenlin, 15, is \u201ca big fish in a little pond,\u201d her coach Mary Wise said. \u201cWe look forward to the training camps as an environment that pushes her.\u201d\n\nValeri Liukin\u2019s resignation as national team coordinator this month, less than two years after he took over from Martha Karolyi, also came as a shock. Liukin said at the time that he had been \u201clooking forward to trying to turn this program around,\u201d but that \u201cthe present climate causes me, and more importantly my family, far too much stress, difficulty and uncertainty.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked whether they were worried that the institutional upheaval would affect their ability to compete internationally, gymnasts said it already had. U.S.A. Gymnastics has withdrawn from two competitions \u2014 the International Gymnix in Canada, held in March, and the City of Jesolo Trophy in Italy, held in April \u2014 that are often the first international experience for new national team members.\n\nAt least eight gymnasts, including Kenlin, have arranged to compete individually in Jesolo at their own expense.\n\nPhoto\n\nAn unwanted spotlight\n\nBeyond the practical difficulties of being a national team member without the accouterments of a national team, gymnasts are struggling to come to terms with a harsh spotlight.\n\nThe current and former athletes speaking out against U.S.A. Gymnastics have made a point to distinguish between the organization and the sport. But to some not involved in gymnastics, the revelations of abuse seem to define it. In one widely shared article last month, a Sports Illustrated columnist declared: \u201cAmerican gymnastics is no longer a sport. It\u2019s a conspiracy of pedophiles and their enablers.\u201d\n\nThe notion that American gymnastics was synonymous with the failures of its governing body has not sat well with American gymnasts, including Simone Biles, the 2016 Olympic all-around champion. Biles, 20, a survivor of Nassar\u2019s abuse who began training again last year, wrote pointedly on Twitter that gymnasts \u201cdon\u2019t stop working hard just because our organization is falling apart.\u201d\n\nAsked what they wanted the public to know, every gymnast interviewed said largely the same thing. None disputed the importance of organizational and cultural change in U.S.A. Gymnastics. But they did not want their work and goals to be ignored.\n\n\u201cThere are still kids working hard,\u201d Kenlin said. \u201cThere are still kids trying to achieve their dreams.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere will always be unexpected ups and downs on the road to success,\u201d Carey added, \u201cbut we will continue to support each other and not let anything or anyone destroy us or our love for gymnastics.\u201d\n\nWise, Kenlin\u2019s coach, said it sometimes felt as if, in the push to make the sport safe for future generations, the current generation had been forgotten.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese kids are working hard, and we are hoping that their dreams don\u2019t get damaged by the ripple effect from what has happened,\u201d she said. \u201cTheir dreams are important. We want to see them have their chance, too.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Gymnasts Worry That Program\u2019s Chaos Will Ruin Their Chances", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI was pleased to see the administration move in this direction, and I think Nikki Haley has led that movement,\u201d said Linda Thomas-Greenfield, who was assistant secretary of state for African affairs during the Obama administration.\n\nThe Obama administration helped midwife the birth of oil-rich South Sudan as an independent nation in 2011. When civil war erupted there in 2013 after President Salva Kiir, an ethnic Dinka, accused his former deputy, Riek Machar, an ethnic Neur, of fomenting a coup, the United States initially sided with Mr. Kiir.\n\nBut as government forces abrogated or ignored a peace agreement and a series of cease-fires, Washington\u2019s frustration with Mr. Kiir grew. In the latest example, the country\u2019s military forces captured the rebel-held town of Lasu in December, creating yet another flow of refugees, despite a unilateral cease-fire that Mr. Kiir had declared in May.\n\nTens of thousands of people have died in the conflict, more than two million have fled to neighboring countries and almost two million more are internally displaced, despite the presence of 17,000 United Nations peacekeepers in the country.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe crisis comes as a drought in nearby Somalia, Ethiopia and Kenya has put millions more at risk of starvation. Some top officials close to Mr. Kiir have been placed under sanctions by the United States, and on Monday the African Union expressed support for imposing sanctions on leaders who are violating cease-fires in South Sudan.\n\nUganda, which sent troops to fight on the side of the government of South Sudan in the early stages of the war, is still feeding the conflict with weapons, said Richard Downie, deputy director of the Africa program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, who visited the region in January. Uganda receives considerable security and development assistance from the United States.\n\n\u201cSo we give Uganda all this aid, and yet it\u2019s been fueling the conflict, so they\u2019ve been playing us,\u201d Mr. Downie said.\n\nNeither Ms. Thomas-Greenfield nor Mr. Downie believed the United Nations would vote to impose an arms embargo, since Russia and China tend to oppose such efforts as meddlesome. And even if one were passed, neither thought it would do much good.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAn arms embargo is not going to change anything, but there are not a lot of good options out there,\u201d Mr. Downie said.\n\nMs. Thomas-Greenfield said there was not much else the United States could do. \u201cI still think we should try for an embargo,\u201d she said.\n\nAlso Friday, the Treasury Department imposed sanctions on six people and seven companies associated with Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed political and military organization that is deeply entwined in Lebanon\u2019s government and backs President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in the civil war in that country.\n\nThe designation is intended not only to punish Hezbollah but also to signal that American efforts against Iran go beyond the Trump administration\u2019s focus on renegotiating the 2015 Iran nuclear pact.", "title": "U.S. Imposes Arms Ban on South Sudan as Civil War Grinds On", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "But his optimistic tone faded as he recalled a meeting with United States Treasury officials this month. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCivilian officials in Pakistan\u2019s government say privately that they are eager to clamp down on insurgent groups, but that the military and its powerful intelligence wing may not comply. The current government was elected in 2013, taking the helm of a country that has bounced between civilian-led governments and military rule.\n\nThe military denies that it supports groups like the Haqqani network, which has been designated a terrorist organization in the United States. It and others are responsible for some of the largest attacks on the United States-led military coalition in Afghanistan, and on the Afghan government.\n\nLast month, the Trump administration suspended roughly $1.3 billion in aid to Islamabad, promising it could be restored if Pakistan clamped down on groups like the Haqqani network.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut with $3 billion in debt coming due, Pakistani officials worry that the United States could put pressure on global institutions like the International Monetary Fund to block future loans. It\u2019s not supposed to be a political forum,\u201d Mr. Ismail said, referring to the Financial Action Task Force. He cited concerns that Washington planned to use the Paris meeting to exert further pressure on Pakistan, after receiving an underwhelming response to the January aid cut.\n\nIslamabad reacted coolly when Washington announced that it would cut assistance, pointing out that American aid had declined for years and was too meager to support Pakistan\u2019s economy. But American officials insist the suspension will hurt Pakistan\u2019s ability to service its mostly American-made military hardware, a major blow to a country that has frequent border skirmishes with India, its main rival, and that is struggling to quell a violent insurgency at home.\n\nPublicly, Pakistan denies supporting insurgent groups in Afghanistan, saying that the United States is trying to blame it for the Pentagon\u2019s failure to achieve victory after 17 years in Afghanistan.\n\n\u201cThere are large swaths of Afghanistan outside the control of the Afghan government, and that\u2019s where the opposition is,\u201d Pakistan\u2019s defense minister, Khurram Dastgir Khan, said in an interview last week in Islamabad. \u201cAny war of words with the U.S. takes our eye off the prize: a peaceful and prosperous Afghanistan.\u201d\n\n\u201cHas Trump\u2019s onslaught of hostile words increased Afghanistan\u2019s prosperity and democracy?\u201d he continued. \u201cHas it seen Kabul take charge of more of Afghanistan\u2019s territory? If the United States lived up to the Obama-era deal, it would mean that President Trump would preside over a reduction of the Guant\u00e1namo detainee population, which would drop from 41 to 40, despite his campaign vow to fill it back up.\n\nBut if the government reneged on the deal, legal experts have warned that it would strongly discourage other detainees from cooperating with military commissions prosecutors by pleading guilty and potentially serving as witnesses \u2014 a key tool that civilian court prosecutors routinely use to win convictions.\n\nLast year, the State Department, under Secretary of State Rex W. As of now, there are no plans to cancel or further delay joint military exercises by the United States and South Korea, scheduled for after the Olympic Games.\n\nStill, the tactical shift by the White House opens the door to an unpredictable new phase in the crisis over North Korea. It also shows how the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, has been able to use the Olympics to pursue a thaw with a receptive counterpart in the South.\n\nPresident Trump himself has oscillated between a get-tough approach and a deal maker\u2019s belief that he can sit down with Mr. Kim and work out an agreement. Some of his advisers, like Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, favor engagement; others, like the national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, have pushed for more pressure, backed by the threat of military action.\n\nReports that Washington and Seoul had reached an understanding on the possibility of dialogue appeared in the news media after the vice president\u2019s departure on Saturday, but South Korean officials would not confirm them until Tuesday.\n\nDialogue with the North has been used by successive American administrations as a carrot \u2014 paired with the stick of sanctions \u2014 in the hopes of getting the isolated nation to end its nuclear weapons program. But the Trump administration has long resisted that approach, saying it would not be drawn into a negotiation like that of the Clinton administration in 1994, which resulted in a deal North Korea later broke.\n\nJust six months ago, Mr. Trump described Mr. Moon\u2019s overtures to the North as \u201cappeasement.\u201d When Mr. Tillerson said in December that the United States was willing to hold a \u201cmeeting without precondition,\u201d the White House dismissed his comments as premature.\n\nBut in an interview with The Washington Post after he left South Korea, Mr. Pence suggested that the United States was open to a meeting, even indicating that it would enter talks without preconditions. \u201cThe maximum pressure campaign is going to continue and intensify,\u201d Mr. Pence said of the punishing sanctions imposed on the North by the United Nations. \u201cBut if you want to talk, we\u2019ll talk.\u201d\n\nAgreeing to talks before the North Koreans have demonstrated a willingness to dismantle their weapons program would be a subtle but potentially significant shift in Washington\u2019s approach \u2014 and a win for Mr. Moon.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Mr. Pence and Mr. Moon met last week, the allies apparently found common ground: They would agree to talks without set rules, but they would continue to use sanctions as leverage.\n\n\u201cPresident Moon and I reflected last night on the need to do something fundamentally different,\u201d Mr. Pence told reporters on Friday after meeting with the South Korean leader.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. She extended an invitation from her brother to Mr. Moon for a summit meeting in North Korea.\n\nMr. Moon, who invited athletes from the North to participate in the Olympics \u2014 where they marched with South Korean athletes under a unified Korean flag during the opening ceremony \u2014 has seen the Games as an important step toward promoting peace on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nDeciphering the Trump administration\u2019s signals on North Korea is tricky, given the president\u2019s unpredictability. Mr. Trump has repeatedly contradicted Mr. Tillerson when he has floated diplomatic openings. But Mr. Pence, officials point out, received his marching orders from Mr. Trump shortly before he left for Asia, and he was unlikely to deviate from them.\n\nThe White House has been relieved by the lull in North Korea\u2019s nuclear and missile tests, even as it has watched the emerging d\u00e9tente warily. North Korea has not conducted any major weapons tests since Nov. 29, when it launched an intercontinental ballistic missile powerful enough to reach the mainland United States.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven if talks start between North Korea and the United States, the gap between the countries remains wide. Analysts predicted that North Korea would use any future talks with Washington to be accepted as a nuclear power and win large economic concessions, in return for agreeing not to advance its nuclear weapons program any further.\n\nNorth Korea has said that it would not bargain away its weapons, and would only discuss mutual arms reduction \u2014 a vow that American intelligence agencies take seriously. The C.I.A. has assessed that no amount of pressure will lead Mr. Kim to give up his arsenal.\n\nIn testimony before the Senate on Tuesday, the director of national intelligence, Dan Coats, said, North Korea \u201chas repeatedly stated that it does not intend to negotiate its nuclear weapons and missiles away because the regime views nuclear weapons are critical to its security.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim, he added, \u201cprobably sees nuclear ICBMs as leverage to achieve his long-term strategic ambition to end Seoul\u2019s alliance with Washington and to eventually dominate the peninsula.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Opens Door to North Korea Talks, a Victory for South\u2019s President", "authors": ["Mark Landler", "Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Federal investigators say they have found huge gaps in the regulation of assisted living facilities, a shortfall that they say has potentially jeopardized the care of hundreds of thousands of people served by the booming industry.\n\nThe federal government lacks even basic information about the quality of assisted living services provided to low-income people on Medicaid, the Government Accountability Office, a nonpartisan investigative arm of Congress, says in a report to be issued on Sunday.\n\nBillions of dollars in government spending is flowing to the industry even as it operates under a patchwork of vague standards and limited supervision by federal and state authorities. States reported spending more than $10 billion a year in federal and state funds for assisted living services for more than 330,000 Medicaid beneficiaries, an average of more than $30,000 a person, the Government Accountability Office found in a survey of states.\n\nStates are supposed to keep track of cases involving the abuse, neglect, exploitation or unexplained death of Medicaid beneficiaries in assisted living facilities. But, the report said, more than half of the states were unable to provide information on the number or nature of such cases.", "title": "U.S. Pays Billions for \u2018Assisted Living,\u2019 but What Does It Get?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "MUNICH \u2014 After years of encouraging European nations to work together to provide more of their own defense, the United States is having second thoughts, driven by concerns about NATO and possible protectionism in defense industries.\n\nThe new American skepticism has been the big surprise of the high-level security conference held this past week in Munich. And it has puzzled and disconcerted NATO officials, who have welcomed the European Union\u2019s new commitment, after the Russian annexation of Crimea, to do more for its own defense.\n\nOnly last November, American and NATO officials embraced the bloc\u2019s plans, under a program called the Permanent Structured Cooperation on Security and Defense, or Pesco, to spend more money on defense and to do it more efficiently, on national programs that would enhance European combat capacity and reduce overlapping national equipment that does not always work together with those of other allies.\n\nThe European Union created a defense research fund to provide 5.5 billion euros ($6.8 billion) a year in financing after 2020, a relatively modest sum, but one that could grow. The State Department sent him a similar letter, which also argued that international law provided a basis for American forces to remain in Syria \u2014 despite the lack of consent from the Syrian government \u2014 to protect Iraq and the United States from terrorists.\n\nAnd both letters said American troops may strike at Syrian government or Iranian forces deemed to threaten Americans or Syrian rebel groups that are assisting the United States in fighting the Islamic State, also known as ISIS.\n\n\u201cThe United States does not seek to fight the government of Syria or Iran or Iranian-supported groups in Iraq or Syria,\u201d wrote Mary K. Waters, the assistant secretary of state for legislative affairs. \u201cHowever, the United States will not hesitate to use necessary and proportionate force to defend U.S., coalition, or partner forces engaged in operations to defeat ISIS and degrade Al Qaeda.\u201d\n\nAmerican troops carried out strikes against forces loyal to President Bashar Assad of Syria several times in 2017 in the name of defending American-supported rebel groups.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEspecially as a matter of international law, the administration\u2019s theory for why the United States will have authority to keep carrying out such operations indefinitely amounts to \u201ca tenuous legal justification atop of another tenuous legal justification,\u201d said Jack Goldsmith, a Harvard Law School professor and former Justice Department lawyer in the Bush administration.\n\nAnd in a statement addressing domestic law, Mr. Kaine said the executive branch was stretching its interpretation of its war authority too far. He called on the administration to seek new authorization for any continued, long-term mission in Syria and Iraq \u2014 especially \u201cto strike pro-Assad forces in areas devoid of ISIS to protect our Syrian partners who seek Assad\u2019s overthrow.\u201d\n\nHe also criticized the basis on which the administration ordered strikes on a Syrian government air base last April as punishment for using chemical weapons. At the time, President Trump claimed powers as commander-in-chief to issue the strikes rather than on any theory of congressional authorization.\n\nThe senator accused Mr. Trump of \u201cacting like a king by unilaterally starting a war.\u201d\n\nThe executive branch\u2019s core legal theory that it is authorized by Congress to fight the Islamic State in both Iraq and Syria was first put forward by the Obama administration in 2014, when ISIS swept out of Syria and began rapidly conquering portions of Iraq. The United States started bombing Islamic State forces to curb their advances.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnder both Mr. Obama and Mr. Trump, the executive branch has argued that the war against the Islamic State is covered by a 2001 law authorizing the use of military force against the perpetrators of the Sept. 11 attacks and a 2002 law authorizing the invasion of Iraq.\n\nThat theory is disputed. While ISIS grew out of an offshoot of Al Qaeda, the two groups by 2014 had split and became warring rivals. Before the rise of ISIS, the Obama administration had deemed the Iraq war over and largely withdrawn American troops.\n\nStill, Congress has continued to appropriate funds for the operations, even as it has failed to enact any new or updated war authorization that specifically addresses ISIS. No court has addressed the question of whether the executive branch has legitimate authority from Congress to battle the Islamic State.", "title": "U.S. Says Troops Can Stay in Syria Without New Authorization", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s kind of funny, but kind of sad,\u201d Chen said. \u201cI wish we all nailed it.\u201d\n\nTheir performance was the worst ever for the United States women\u2019s team in the Olympic short program, which started in 1976. Nagasu finished ninth, Chen 10th and Tennell 11th. Nagasu is nearly 16 points \u2014 a canyon of a gap \u2014 behind the leader, Alina Zagitova of Russia.\n\nAll is not lost: A great free skate and a few breaks could produce a medal. As the saying goes, the ice is slippery. But right now it looks as if the United States will finish off the podium. Again.\n\nThe last time an American woman won an Olympic medal was in 2006, when Sasha Cohen took silver. In the 10 Winter Games before that, the United States always had at least one female medalist. In five of them, the Olympic champion was an American. But that era of success is drifting further and further away.\n\nWhat can be done to stop this medal drought? Is Their System Broken?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The winner of Saturday\u2019s vote also will oversee the process of hiring a new coach for the men\u2019s national team \u2014 a position that has been vacant since Bruce Arena resigned in October after the team failed to qualify for the World Cup \u2014 and also the creation of technical director positions for both the men\u2019s and women\u2019s national team programs.\n\nAnd then there are the lawsuits. U.S. Soccer faces at least five expensive legal challenges at the moment, including at least two lawsuits filed by the backers of one candidate, Eric Wynalda; another challenging its authority to oversee the sport being heard at the Court of Arbitration for Sport; and a separate complaint with the United States Olympic Committee being pressed by another candidate, Hope Solo.\n\nAn unresolved claim of wage discrimination filed by members of the women\u2019s national team with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission looms in the background, too.\n\nEven if the new president has all the right solutions, that does not guarantee they will be able to implement them. The problem, one past president said, is that the new president has little power to resolve any of the biggest issues, or press any of the significant structural changes they are proposing, all by themselves.\n\n\u201cThey can certainly advocate for things and try to get the board to get into a particular direction, but they cannot go and decree something,\u201d said Robert Contiguglia, the U.S. Soccer president from 1998 to 2006 and a member of the board since 1990. \u201cIt\u2019s not going to happen.\u201d\n\nEach president has approached the job differently, making it folly to base expectations for the next president on Gulati\u2019s tenure. Besides, Rothenberg said, while the job might not have much explicit power, it more than makes up for that in soft power.\n\n\u201cThe power to get along with people and work together is not necessarily written into the organic documents,\u201d he said. \u201cThat comes from the ability of the leader to accomplish it.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Soccer Is Set to Pick a President. Then Comes the Hard Part.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "The negotiations in Europe last year were described by American and European intelligence officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a clandestine operation, and the Russian. The United States officials worked through an intermediary \u2014 an American businessman based in Germany \u2014 to preserve deniability. There were meetings in provincial German towns where John le Carr\u00e9 set his early spy novels, and data handoffs in five-star Berlin hotels. American intelligence agencies spent months tracking the Russian\u2019s flights to Berlin, his rendezvous with a mistress in Vienna and his trips home to St. Petersburg, the officials said.\n\nThe N.S.A. even used its official Twitter account to send coded messages to the Russian nearly a dozen times.\n\nThe episode ended this year with American spies chasing the Russian out of Western Europe, warning him not to return if he valued his freedom, the American businessman said. The Trump material was left with the American, who has secured it in Europe.\n\nThe Russian claimed to have access to a staggering collection of secrets that included everything from the computer code for the cyberweapons stolen from the N.S.A. and C.I.A. to what he said was a video of Mr. Trump consorting with prostitutes in a Moscow hotel room in 2013, according to American and European officials and the Russian, who agreed to be interviewed in Germany on the condition of anonymity. There remains no evidence that such a video exists.\n\nThe Russian was known to American and European officials for his ties to Russian intelligence and cybercriminals \u2014 two groups suspected in the theft of the N.S.A. and C.I.A. hacking tools.\n\nBut his apparent eagerness to sell the Trump \u201ckompromat\u201d \u2014 a Russian term for information used to gain leverage over someone \u2014 to American spies raised suspicions among officials that he was part of an operation to feed the information to United States intelligence agencies and pit them against Mr. Trump. Early in the negotiations, for instance, he dropped his asking price from about $10 million to just over $1 million. Then, a few months later, he showed the American businessman a 15-second clip of a video showing a man in a room talking to two women.\n\nNo audio could be heard on the video, and there was no way to verify if the man was Mr. Trump, as the Russian claimed. But the choice of venue for showing the clip heightened American suspicions of a Russian operation: The viewing took place at the Russian Embassy in Berlin, the businessman said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere were other questions about the Russian\u2019s reliability. He had a history of money laundering and a thin legitimate cover business \u2014 a nearly bankrupt company that sold portable grills for streetside sausage salesmen, according to British incorporation papers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe distinction between an organized criminal and a Russian intelligence officer and a Russian who knows some Russian intel guys \u2014 it all blurs together,\u201d said Steven L. Hall, the former chief of Russia operations at the C.I.A. \u201cThis is the difficulty of trying to understand how Russia and Russians operate from the Western viewpoint.\u201d\n\nAmerican intelligence officials were also wary of the purported kompromat the Russian wanted to sell. They saw the information, especially the video, as the stuff of tabloid gossip pages, not intelligence collection, American officials said.\n\nBut the Americans desperately wanted the hacking tools. The cyberweapons had been built to break into the computer networks of Russia, China and other rival powers. Instead, they ended up in the hands of a mysterious group calling itself the Shadow Brokers, which has since provided hackers with tools that infected millions of computers around the world, crippling hospitals, factories and businesses.\n\nNo officials wanted to refuse information they thought might help determine what had happened.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s one of the bedeviling things about counterintelligence and the wilderness that it is \u2014 nobody wants to be caught in a position of saying we wrote that off and then five years later saying, \u2018Holy cow, it was actually a real guy,\u2019\u201d Mr. Hall said.\n\nAmerican intelligence agencies believe that Russia\u2019s spy services see the deep political divisions in the United States as a fresh opportunity to inflame partisan tensions. Russian hackers are targeting American voting databases ahead of the midterm election this year, they said, and using bot armies to promote partisan causes on social media. The Russians are also particularly eager to cast doubt on the federal and congressional investigations into the Russian meddling, American intelligence officials said.\n\nPart of that effort, the officials said, appears to be trying to spread information that hews closely to unsubstantiated reports about Mr. Trump\u2019s dealings in Russia, including the purported video, whose existence Mr. Trump has repeatedly dismissed.\n\nRumors that Russian intelligence possesses the video surfaced more than a year ago in an explosive and unverified dossier compiled by a former British spy and paid for by Democrats. Since then, at least four Russians with espionage and underworld connections have appeared in Central and Eastern Europe, offering to sell kompromat to American political operatives, private investigators and spies that would corroborate the dossier, American and European intelligence officials said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmerican officials suspect that at least some of the sellers are working for Russia\u2019s spy services.\n\nThe Times obtained four of the documents that the Russian in Germany tried to pass to American intelligence (The Times did not pay for the material). All are purported to be Russian intelligence reports, and each focuses on associates of Mr. Trump. Carter Page, the former campaign adviser who has been the focus of F.B.I. investigators, features in one; Robert and Rebekah Mercer, the billionaire Republican donors, in another.\n\nYet all four appear to be drawn almost entirely from news reports, not secret intelligence. They all also contain stylistic and grammatical usages not typically seen in Russian intelligence reports, said Yuri Shvets, a former K.G.B. officer who spent years as a spy in Washington before immigrating to the United States after the end of the Cold War.\n\nAmerican spies are not the only ones who have dealt with Russians claiming to have secrets to sell. Cody Shearer, an American political operative with ties to the Democratic Party, has been crisscrossing Eastern Europe for more than six months to secure the purported kompromat from a different Russian, said people familiar with the efforts, speaking on the condition of anonymity to avoid damaging their relationship with him.\n\nReached by phone late last year, Mr. Shearer would say only that his work was \u201ca big deal \u2014 you know what it is, and you shouldn\u2019t be asking about it.\u201d He then hung up.\n\nGot a confidential news tip? Do you have the next big story? Want to share it with The New York Times? We offer several ways to get in touch with and provide materials to our journalists.\n\nMr. Shearer\u2019s efforts grew out of work he first began during the 2016 campaign, when he compiled a pair of reports that, like the dossier, also included talk of a video and Russian payoffs to Trump associates. It is not clear what, if anything, Mr. Shearer has been able to purchase.\n\nBefore the Americans were negotiating with the Russian, they were dealing with a hacker in Vienna known only to American intelligence officials as Carlo. In early 2017, he offered to provide them with a full set of hacking tools that were in the hands of the Shadow Brokers and the names of other people in his network, American officials said. In exchange, he wanted immunity from prosecution in the United States.\n\nBut the immunity deal fell apart, so intelligence officials decided to do what spies do best: They offered to buy the data. That is when the Russian in Germany emerged, telling the Americans he would handle the sale.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike Carlo, he had previously dealt with American intelligence operatives, American and European officials said. He served as a fixer, of sorts, brokering deals for Russia\u2019s Federal Security Service, or F.S.B., which is the successor to the Soviet K.G.B. American intelligence officials said that he had a direct link to Nikolai Patrushev, a former F.S.B. director, and that they knew of previous work he had done helping move illicit shipments of semiprecious metals for a Russian oligarch.\n\nBy last April it appeared that a deal was imminent. Several C.I.A. officers even traveled from the agency\u2019s headquarters to help the agency\u2019s Berlin station handle the operation.\n\nAt a small bar in the former heart of West Berlin, the Russian handed the American intermediary a thumb drive with a small cache of data that was intended to provide a sample of what was to come, American officials said.\n\nWithin days, though, the deal turned sour. American intelligence agencies determined that the data was genuinely from the Shadow Brokers, but was material the group had already made public. As a result, the C.I.A. said it would not pay for it, American officials said.\n\nThe Russian was furious. But negotiations limped on until September, when the two sides agreed to try again.\n\nLate that month, the American businessman delivered the $100,000 payment. Some officials said it was United States government money but routed through an indirect channel.\n\nA few weeks later, the Russian began handing over data. But in multiple deliveries in October and December, almost all of what he delivered was related to the 2016 election and alleged ties between Mr. Trump\u2019s associates and Russia, not the N.S.A. or C.I.A. hacking tools.\n\nIn December, the Russian said he told the American intermediary that he was providing the Trump material and holding out on the hacking tools at the orders of senior Russian intelligence officials.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEarly this year, the Americans gave him one last chance. The Russian once again showed up with nothing more than excuses.\n\nSo the Americans offered him a choice: Start working for them and provide the names of everyone in his network \u2014 or go back to Russia and do not return.\n\nThe Russian did not give it much thought. He took a sip of the cranberry juice he was nursing, picked up his bag and said, \u201cThank you.\u201d Then he walked out the door.", "title": "U.S. Spies, Seeking to Retrieve Cyberweapons, Paid Russian Peddling Trump Secrets", "authors": ["Matthew Rosenberg"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "GANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 It happens every four years. The United States and Canada play for Olympic gold in women\u2019s hockey, and the game usually goes down to the wire.\n\nThis one did that and more. Jocelyne Lamoureux-Davidson scored the game-winning goal in a shootout on Thursday to give the United States a 3-2 victory against Canada, the four-time defending Olympic champion.\n\nDown a goal with seven minutes to play, the United States got an equalizer from Lamoureux-Davidson\u2019s sister, Monique Lamoureux-Morando, and matched Canada through overtime, even staving off a power play through the last 95 seconds.\n\nThen it was on to a shootout, which also went into overtime, after both teams netted two of their first five chances. In the first extra round, Lamoureux-Davidson scored first against Canada goaltender Shannon Szabados. A minute later, United States goaltender Maddie Rooney stopped a shot by Meghan Agosta of Canada to give the American women their first gold medal since 1998, when women\u2019s hockey made its debut as an Olympic sport.", "title": "U.S. Women Break Canada\u2019s Grip on Hockey Gold", "authors": ["Matthew Futterman"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Losses in Olympic gold medal games can make countries do surprising things, especially when those losses happen twice in a row, to the same team, and that team presents the only real competition in a sport where there is Canada and the United States and then everyone else.\n\nSo after the United States women\u2019s hockey team endured a soul-crushing overtime loss to Canada at the last Olympics in Sochi, Coach Robb Stauber did not chalk up the past shortcomings to a couple of bad bounces as he prepared the team for its next Olympic campaign.\n\nThe Americans had been 55 seconds short of a gold medal in 2014, and only two goals short of one in 2010, and they had beaten Canada to win the past four world championships. Still, Stauber decided to completely rethink the way this team \u2014 and most other teams that have laced up skates and grabbed sticks \u2014 approaches the game.", "title": "U.S. Women\u2019s Hockey Team Is Now Emphasizing Style. But What About Goals?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Like many such games, this one appears to be another wrinkle that has returned from the grave of the Cold War as diplomatic relations have suffered.\n\nIn the 1980s, United States congressional leaders renamed the area in front of the Russian Embassy in Washington \u201cSakharov Plaza,\u201d to protest the detention of Andrei D. Sakharov, the famed Russian dissident, Nobel Peace Prize recipient and nuclear physicist.\n\nSuch moves are not limited to Russia, either.\n\nCongress proposed renaming the street on which the Chinese Embassy sits in honor of Liu Xiaobo, the dissident and Nobel laureate who died last year. Beijing called that effort \u201ca political farce.\u201d In 2014, Chinese commentators retaliated by suggesting renaming the street in front of the American Embassy in Beijing \u201cSnowden Street\u201d for Edward J. Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor who disclosed secret documents detailing the United States\u2019 mass surveillance programs, or \u201cOsama bin Laden Road.\u201d Neither capital acted on the suggestions.\n\nNor is the practice limited to major powers. On Monday, the mayor of Ankara, the Turkish capital, approved renaming a street outside the United States Embassy \u201cOlive Branch,\u201d after Turkey\u2019s continuing military campaign in Syria. The United States and Turkey have found themselves awkwardly on opposite sides of the fighting in Syria, because of the American military\u2019s support for a Kurdish militia. The proposal is expected to be approved just days before Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson is expected in Ankara on Thursday.\n\nPreviously, the Islamic Republic of Iran famously stripped the name of Winston Churchill from the street outside the British Embassy in Tehran and renamed it after Bobby Sands, a member of the Irish Republican Army who died in prison on hunger strike.\n\nLast year, the Iranians also named the street where the Saudi Arabian Embassy sits after Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a clerical leader from the Shiite Muslim minority who was executed in the kingdom.", "title": "U.S. and Russia Revive Cold-War Game of Provocative Street Names", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Kremlin officials said that no Russians had been involved. In a statement, Russia\u2019s Defense Ministry said that the coalition strike had been carried out by helicopters.\n\nThe Russian Defense Ministry also appeared to partly blame the pro-government militia members for the episode, saying they had not coordinated their movements with the Russians ahead of time. But the ministry also said it showed that \u201cthe true aim of the illegal presence of American forces on Syrian territory is not the fight against the Islamic State,\u201d but the \u201ccapture and retention of economic assets.\u201d\n\nAt the United Nations, Ambassador Vassily A. Nebenzia of Russia said he intended to raise the American airstrikes during closed consultations of the Security Council. But there was little or no expectation that the council, long divided over the Syria conflict, would issue a statement on the airstrikes.\n\nSpeaking to reporters, Mr. Nebenzia rejected the American explanation that the airstrikes had been carried out for defensive reasons.\n\n\u201cWe were invited by the government of Syria to fight terrorists since 2015,\u201d he said. \u201cThe U.S. was never invited to Syria. So who is the aggressor, tell me?\u201d\n\nAaron David Miller, a Middle East analyst at the Wilson Center, said the forces backing the Syrian government seemed to be testing the coalition\u2019s resolve. But, he added, it was not clear whether the clash marked a new phase of the war in which the United States and its allies would enter more direct confrontation with forces loyal to Mr. Assad.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re now protecting a territory the size of Indiana and deepening our commitment to the S.D.F., with no sense of where this is going, no sense of strategy, no sense of endgame,\u201d said Mr. Miller, who was a State Department official in Republican and Democratic administrations.", "title": "U.S.-Backed Coalition in Syria Strikes Pro-Assad Forces", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "After rolling out trade actions on washing machines and solar panels that were nominally aimed at China, the administration is considering sweeping action to protect American intellectual property from Chinese incursions. American negotiators are working to rewrite trade pacts with Mexico and South Korea, in large part because these countries run large bilateral trade surpluses with the United States.\n\nSome left-leaning groups that support the president\u2019s promises to end offshoring embraced the view that the administration\u2019s trade policies simply haven\u2019t gone far enough.\n\n\u201cThe same trade policy that Trump attacks ferociously and promised to speedily replace is still in place,\u201d said Lori Wallach, director of Public Citizen\u2019s Global Trade Watch. \u201cIt\u2019s not surprising that the deficit is up because in year one there has been a wide gulf between Trump\u2019s fiery trade rhetoric and action.\u201d\n\nDespite Mr. Trump\u2019s frequent promises to reduce the trade deficit, many economists believe that his trade policies will be largely powerless to reverse the trend. That\u2019s because the overall trade deficit is governed by macroeconomic factors, including the relative growth rates of countries, the value of their currencies, and their saving and investment rates. So while changes in trade policy can shift imports and exports from one country to another, for example, reducing the American trade deficit with China while increasing its trade deficit with Thailand, they are unlikely to reduce the American trade deficit overall.\n\nAnd Mr. Trump\u2019s signature economic policy so far \u2014 the $1.5 trillion tax cut \u2014 is likely to widen the trade deficit in coming years by encouraging more investment in the United States, many economists say.\n\nBryan Riley, director of the Free Trade Initiative at the National Taxpayers Union, said that an increase in the trade deficit from the prior year \u201cshould not be viewed as a problem to be fixed, but as a predictable result of a growing economy that enables people to afford more imports.\u201d\n\nEswar Prasad, a professor of trade policy at Cornell University, cautioned against Mr. Trump\u2019s interpretation of the bilateral trade deficit as a scorecard for an economic relationship.", "title": "U.S.-China Trade Deficit Hits Record, Fueling Trade Fight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Before the trial started, Uber offered to settle with Waymo in exchange for 0.68 percent of the company\u2019s equity, or about $500 million, but its board of directors pulled the offer and allowed Mr. Kalanick to testify, according to two people familiar with Uber\u2019s thinking who were not authorized to speak publicly on the matter.\n\nAfter testimony on Thursday, settlement talks restarted, and Uber offered the lower percentage, these people said. For Waymo, the financial terms were not as important as scoring concessions on not using Waymo\u2019s technology, said a person familiar with Waymo\u2019s deliberations who was not authorized to discuss them.\n\nThe settlement included an agreement that none of Waymo\u2019s confidential information was being incorporated in Uber\u2019s autonomous vehicle technology.\n\nAfter almost a decade of work on self-driving cars, the Uber stake may be the first substantial money that Waymo has made from the technology. Alphabet was already a major investor in Uber through its venture capital arm, GV. It has also made a billion-dollar investment in Uber\u2019s main rival in the United States, Lyft.\n\nAlthough it settled the lawsuit, Waymo\u2019s court fight may have succeeded in embarrassing a rival while delivering a unspoken warning to former and current employees to be cautious about leaving the company with know-how developed there. It also struck a deal before Larry Page, Alphabet\u2019s chief executive, who rarely speaks in public, had to testify in court next week.\n\nWaymo\u2019s lawyers presented evidence that entertained the throngs of technology reporters gathered to cover the trial including texts and emails between Mr. Levandowski and Mr. Kalanick using chest-puffing terms like \u201cburn the village\u201d and \u201csecond place is first\u201d loser. There were also pictures of notes on whiteboards from a brainstorming \u201cjam sesh\u201d led by Mr. Kalanick, declaring, among other things, that \u201claser is the sauce.\u201d\n\nThe settlement helps resolve one of Uber\u2019s many lingering issues from Mr. Kalanick\u2019s tumultuous time as chief executive, which ended in June. His successor, Dara Khosrowshahi, has said he hopes to change the perception that Uber has been too quick to break rules.\n\nThe settlement also clears away a significant legal risk as Uber prepares for an expected initial public offering. It is still dealing with a Department of Justice investigation into its business practices. Although the company insists it did not take any Waymo trade secrets, Mr. Khosrowshahi said in a statement that he regretted the events that led to the litigation.", "title": "Uber and Waymo Settle Trade Secrets Suit Over Driverless Cars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "After a stint with an investment firm in Urumqi, the capital of the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region in China, Mr. Yakup returned to the United States with a plan to share Uighur culture with the world. He started in guerrilla style, selling kebabs on Manhattan street corners at midnight \u201cto test the market,\u201d he said. \u201cThe police told us very nicely to leave, and we did.\u201d Now he has investors, including former Harvard classmates, and a team: his parents and older sister, who recently settled in New York. He calls his father \u201cchief kebab engineer.\u201d\n\nAll meats are presented in broad, shallow wooden bowls that might elsewhere be destined for salad. Each plate, generously priced under $10, is identical in its accessories \u2014 a handful of cucumbers and tomatoes, yogurt and Uighur polo, a dish general to Central Asia. To make polo (akin to pilaf), rice is cooked with carrots, olive oil and bone-in lamb that\u2019s left in the pot until the very end. (In Kashgar, Mr. Yakup said, they would keep the meat to eat, but for people here \u201cit\u2019s not soft enough.\u201d)\n\nThe menu also lists naan (flatbread) as part of each plate, but all I received was a panel of dough blanketing the bottom of each bowl, skinny and stiff as a store-bought tortilla. In Beijing, I once watched a Uighur baker pull rounds of naan from the cavernous mouth of a tonur (akin to a tandoor), the bread thick and half-blackened \u2014 nothing like this.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt wasn\u2019t naan, as it turned out, but in fact a tortilla, meant to be decorative, like a placemat. Two wedges of naan were supposed to go on top, chewy flatbread from an Uzbek bakery in Queens; someone in the kitchen had simply forgotten to put them on my plates, Mr. Yakup explained apologetically. He hopes to bake his own some day. \u201cThere are hundreds of kinds,\u201d he said. \u201cOnes big as the wheels of a car, ones small as fists.\u201d\n\nThe dining room is a minimalist black box, with orders placed and picked up at the counter and tables up for grabs. Sometimes the crowd grows quarrelsome. One night, when I was about to abandon my table, two hovering customers came close to blows over it.\n\nMr. Yakup oversees a Kebab Empire stand in the New World Mall in Flushing, Queens, as well. There, for a brief spell last summer, he offered maruxna (Uighur ice cream), a meld of milk, eggs and brown sugar, hand-churned with a great wooden spoon.\n\nIt proved too labor-intensive. In its stead now is doogh, a simple drink of honeyed yogurt, not too sweet, with a crumble of rose petals on top. Mr. Yakup is focused on kebabs \u2014 and empire.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Uighur Specialties, With Lamb Front and Center, at Kebab Empire", "authors": ["Ligaya Mishan", "Hungry City"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities later said that they found white supremacist material, including Hitler\u2019s \u201cMein Kampf,\u201d at the home of a 28-year-old suspect.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 President Trump\u2019s scorched-earth assault on the F.B.I. and Justice Department, now largely focused on a Republican memo released Friday, is unlike anything the United States has seen in modern times.\n\nHere\u2019s the full memo, annotated by our Washington correspondent.
