About 4,000 costumes have been put up for sale to the public. The costume sales are incredibly popular.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nA century ago on Tuesday, the Austrian painter Gustav Klimt died in Vienna.\n\nKlimt is famous for his heavily ornamented portraits, one of which was confiscated by the Nazis during World War II but later recovered. It sold for $135 million in 2006, and the recovery effort inspired \u201cThe Woman in Gold,\u201d a 2015 film starring Helen Mirren.\n\nAmong the artist\u2019s quirks \u2014 and a source of irritation for his wealthy patrons \u2014 was that he often refused to declare his works complete.\n\nOne Belgian family stopped paying Klimt for a frieze it had commissioned for a palace in Brussels, as a way of motivating him to finish. He eventually did.\n\nBut patrons who tried to collect his artwork were sometimes offered a refund instead of a painting.\n\nKlimt would even tweak pieces after they had won critical acclaim.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis painting \u201cDeath and Life,\u201d for example, won first prize at the International Art Exhibition in Rome in 1911. But Klimt later changed the background from gold to gray, according to the Leopold Museum in Vienna, and gave his representations of death and life \u201cfurther ornaments.\u201d\n\nMike Ives contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Uma Thurman, Jacob Zuma, Super Bowl: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Patrick Boehler"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The discovery of a vintage bottle opener led the historian Richard Rabinowitz on a quest to discover its origins and how it might shed light on his family history. The clues took him to Edlund, a 90-year-old Burlington, Vt., kitchen tool company, and beyond. He\u2019ll talk about it and discuss how audience members can follow his example when it comes to the stuff in the back of Grandma\u2019s kitchen drawer: \u201cThe Great Kitchen Tool Mystery,\u201d Sunday, 2 to 3:30 p.m., $14, $8 for students and those 65 and older, plus fees, Museum at Eldridge Street, 12 Eldridge Street (Division Street), 212-219-0302, eldridgestreet.org.", "title": "Uncover the History of Grandma\u2019s Kitchen Tools", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s easy to see why the city picked this terrain for a park: the ground undulates, and bedrock pokes through at regular intervals. In other words, it\u2019s not the easiest place to build the dense housing required by a growing city.\n\nNeither housing nor open space was much of a concern in 1825, when a black shoeshiner named Andrew Williams bought three lots there; the area was several miles from the center of New York City, then concentrated below 14th Street. Several other black residents soon joined him in buying property, as did the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, whose building likely sat atop the foundation. (Seneca Village eventually boasted three churches, one of which housed Colored School No. 3.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile living conditions in Seneca Village were far better than those of other black areas, like the infamous Five Points, getting the right to vote also served as an enticement to owning land.\n\nFrom 1799 to 1827, New York State gradually eliminated slavery. The transition included an 1821 law that gave suffrage to free black males \u2014 provided they owned at least $250 worth of property. By 1845, more than 10 percent of the city\u2019s black voters lived in Seneca Village.\n\nSeneca Village is usually remembered as a free black community, but by the end of its existence, nearly a third of its population was white \u2014 mostly Irish immigrants who had escaped the potato famine, along with a few Germans.\n\nIn the debate over where to place the great park, however, uptown landowners and newspapers painted the village as a shantytown at risk of becoming the next Five Points, occasionally describing it with racial slurs.\n\nThe initial choice was along the waterfront on the Upper East Side, but those landowners had enough clout to make the city look elsewhere, unlike the residents of Seneca Village.\n\nThe state authorized the city to claim the land through eminent domain, reportedly undervaluing many properties. The community disbanded, failing to form again elsewhere. Researchers have yet to identify any living descendants of Seneca Village\u2019s black residents.", "title": "Uncovering the Ruins of an Early Black Settlement in New York", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The \u201cGirl\u201d is the star attraction of the Mauritshuis, a collection of Dutch 17th-century paintings that draws about 400,000 visitors each year. Removing her from public view for any length of time potentially affects attendance, so museum officials tried to keep the examination period as short as possible, and to keep her in the public eye as much as possible.\n\nInstead of taking her up to the restoration studio, Emilie Gordenker, the Mauritshuis\u2019s director, decided to put the whole research project on display in the museum\u2019s Golden Room, a regal chamber with 18th century d\u00e9cor, where the \u201cGirl\u201d and the research team will be enclosed in glass partitions while video monitors allow visitors to observe what\u2019s happening inside. A high-resolution, three-dimensional reproduction of the \u201cGirl\u201d created by Oc\u00e9, a Netherlands-based Canon company, will sit on an easel outside the glass chamber.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cGetting the \u2018Girl\u2019 out of her frame means that she\u2019s not visible in the way that she normally is for visitors, and that was a big concern for us because people come from far and wide to see this picture,\u201d Ms. Gordenker said. \u201cOccasionally she\u2019ll be lying on a bed with all kinds of cameras hanging around her, so you might not be able to see her as usual, or she might be half covered by a scanner. We wanted to make sure that for people who will come, they get taken along in the process.\u201d\n\nIt has been more than two decades since Vermeer\u2019s so-called \u201cMona Lisa of the North\u201d has been the subject of an examination, and since that time, there has been a great deal of advancement in the tools used to examine artworks. In 1994, researchers employed tools such as X-radiography, UV photography and infrared reflectography, and took tiny paint samples out of the painting.\n\nToday\u2019s imaging tools are noninvasive, which means there\u2019s nary a brush or Q-tip in sight, and there will be no removal of particles. The technologies that have been brought together for this examination will \u201ccull a few terabytes of data,\u201d said Joris Dik, one of the lead researchers, from Delft University of Technology. These can later be used to create high-resolution computer visualizations of the painting that were never possible before.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Sign up to receive an email from The New York Times as soon as important news breaks around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI can imagine at the end we\u2019ll have something like Google Earth where you can click on all different layers and zoom in and out of the painting to see different elements within the layers of paint,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe \u201cGirl\u201d has been on display in the Mauritshuis since 1881. The work wasn\u2019t considered to be a particular highlight of the collection \u2014 which also includes Rembrandt\u2019s \u201cThe Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp\u201d and \u201cThe Goldfinch\u201d by Carel Fabritius \u2014 until a major exhibition in collaboration with the National Gallery of Art in Washington in 1995, followed by the publication of Tracy Chevalier\u2019s best-selling novel of the same name four years later and the subsequent 2003 film, starring Scarlett Johansson.\n\nMs. Chevalier imagined the fictional subject for Vermeer\u2019s painting as a housemaid who is invited into the inner sanctum of the master\u2019s studio, and allowed to wear his wife\u2019s pearl earring for the portrait, creating a certain frisson between the artist and his model.\n\nMs. Gordenker said that in reality, the picture probably wasn\u2019t painted as a portrait of any particular person. Trying to figure out the identity of the real-life \u201cGirl\u201d \u2014 if there even was one \u2014 isn\u2019t a question for research.\n\n\u201cOne of the things that makes this painting so spectacularly appealing is that we don\u2019t know,\u201d Ms. Gordenker said. That\u2019s one mystery that this year\u2019s inquiry will not attempt to solve.", "title": "Uncovering the Secrets of the \u2018Girl With a Pearl Earring\u2019", "authors": ["Nina Siegal"]} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Sheriff Israel said on Sunday that his deputies arrived four minutes after Mr. Cruz had left the freshman building where the massacre took place. But Mr. Tapper noted that the deputies did not know at that point that Mr. Cruz had already left, and should have proceeded as though the shooting were still underway.\n\n\u201cWe will investigate every action of our deputies, of their supervisors,\u201d the sheriff said, adding that Coral Springs police officers will give witness statements to investigators from his office. \u201cIf they did things wrong,\u201d he said of his department\u2019s personnel, \u201cI will take care of business in a disciplinary manner.\u201d\n\nSheriff Israel, who effusively praised his deputies in the immediate aftermath of the shooting, had insisted in a news conference on Wednesday that his deputies had not delayed their entry into the school. He appeared at a town-hall-style event that evening, broadcast on CNN, during which he criticized the National Rifle Association aggressively and urged state lawmakers to give police more power to commit the mentally ill to hospitals involuntarily.\n\nHe did not mention Deputy Peterson\u2019s inaction on that broadcast, even though, as he told Mr. Tapper on Sunday, he had seen video footage earlier that day showing that the deputy had stayed outside.\n\nThe sheriff said on Sunday that his office waited until Thursday, the day after the broadcast, to corroborate that the deputy had not entered the school and to notify families of the victims about the finding.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not on a timeline for TV or any news show,\u201d he said.\n\nSheriff Israel said he has asked the Police Executive Research Forum, based in Washington, to conduct an independent after-action report on how his office responded to the shooting.\n\nHe rejected suggestions that his office had missed repeated signs that Mr. Cruz was a threat to Stoneman Douglas High, even though at least 23 calls involving Mr. Cruz were made to deputies over the past decade. The sheriff\u2019s office is investigating how two of those calls were handled, and has placed the two deputies who responded to them on restricted duty.", "title": "Under Pressure, Florida Sheriff Defends \u2018Amazing Leadership\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The department said in a statement that the checkpoints were \u201cstrategically placed where illegal cross-border smuggling is most likely to converge.\u201d\n\nStephen I. Vladeck, a professor at the University of Texas School of Law, said the department had occasionally pushed the limits of its authority to conduct searches without a warrant far from the border.\n\n\u201cInevitably, one of these cases is going to get to the Supreme Court, which will have to revisit the seemingly limitless government authority the department claims it has,\u201d Mr. Vladeck said. \u201cIt cannot be the case that anyone who lives or travels within 100 miles of the border has no Fourth Amendment rights.\u201d\n\nThe Fourth Amendment protects against \u201cunreasonable searches and seizures.\u201d\n\nCurrent federal immigration law does not require the government to obtain a warrant before searching people and their property at ports of entry. Once away from a land or maritime border, but still within what the Justice Department has defined as a \u201creasonable distance\u201d of 100 miles, officers can search people who are suspected of immigration violations and smuggling drugs.\n\nBut many border residents and travelers say that authority amounts to an invasion of privacy.\n\nAn estimated 200 million Americans live within 100 miles of the border, according to the A.C.L.U. At least 11 states \u2014 mostly in the Northeast and Florida \u2014 are either entirely or almost entirely in the 100-mile radius.\n\nA measure to limit that distance to 25 miles passed the Senate in 2013 but was rejected by the House; it was proposed after Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, was stopped by the Border Patrol at an immigration checkpoint.\n\nThe legal dispute in Texas challenges the Border Patrol\u2019s authority to search private property without permission. By law, officers can go onto private property within 25 miles of the border without permission from the owner.", "title": "Under Trump, Border Patrol Steps Up Searches Far From the Border", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Time Capsule\n\nUnder the Covers\n\nFrom Ovid and Baudelaire to Nabokov, Roth and E. L. James, some of the most seminal texts in literary history are also among the most erotic. Herewith, a selection of 50 book jackets (arranged in order of original publication) that have become as iconic as the risqu\u00e9 work within.", "title": "Under the Covers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIs Loneliness a Health Epidemic?,\u201d by Eric Klinenberg (Gray Matter, Sunday Review, Feb. 11):\n\nAccording to Dr. Klinenberg, \u201cit\u2019s the poor, unemployed, displaced and migrant populations that stand to suffer most from loneliness and isolation.\u201d I disagree.\n\nThese groups are obviously at risk, but many seniors have it worse. And people like me, bedridden with a debilitating, untreatable chronic illness (in my case, chronic fatigue syndrome), are the most imperiled.\n\nNo group in our society is more neglected and forgotten than we millions gone missing in this way. The silence becomes deafening as even our doctors drop out of our lives when they discover that there\u2019s little more they can do.\n\nTo heal ourselves a little, we require a foothold of frequent, friendly human contact. Our spouses and other family caregivers need it equally. Without it, we\u2019re buried alive for years, and sometimes for the rest of our deeply stressed and shortened lives.", "title": "Opinion | Understanding the Different Kinds of Loneliness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFed governors have even more on their plates and minds than just a week ago,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Goodfriend is a professor at Carnegie Mellon University and a former monetary policy adviser to the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va. He is widely regarded as a leading academic proponent of the views that the Fed should focus on controlling inflation and minimize its interference with financial markets, both popular positions among conservative Republicans.\n\nThose views and his stumbling performance at his January confirmation hearing, in which he struggled to explain why his inflation predictions after the economic crisis a decade ago were wrong, have solidified Democratic opposition. Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, said he was voting against Mr. Goodfriend because he questioned his commitment to the Fed\u2019s dual mandate, which requires the central bank to pursue maximum employment in addition to stabilizing inflation.\n\nHe said Mr. Goodfriend, who repeatedly criticized the Fed\u2019s post-crisis economic stimulus campaign, had a record of \u201cprioritizing hypothetical inflation over real people losing jobs.\u201d\n\nSenator Jon Tester, a Montana Democrat who has often voted for the Trump administration\u2019s nominees, said he opposed Mr. Goodfriend because of his comments at the hearing that there was no need for the federal government to guarantee 30-year fixed-rate mortgage loans.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Tester said Mr. Goodfriend was \u201cunqualified for a leadership role at the Fed.\u201d\n\nMr. Paul\u2019s opposition has very different roots. He said Thursday that he was concerned about a paper Mr. Goodfriend wrote in 2000 proposing that the government put magnetic strips on money so it could, under certain circumstances, impose a tax on cash. The proposal was intended to help the government encourage spending during periods of low inflation and low interest rates.\n\n\u201cThat doesn\u2019t sound very exciting to me,\u201d Mr. Paul, a libertarian, said Thursday.\n\nMr. Goodfriend has since abandoned the specific proposal, but in his academic writings he has continued to advocate other forms of \u201cnegative interest rates\u201d \u2014 policies that make it expensive to hold money when the government wants to encourage spending.\n\nRepublicans have a 51-vote Senate majority, and Vice President Mike Pence is available to break ties. If Mr. Paul remains opposed, Mr. Goodfriend\u2019s chances could rest on Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, who is in his home state undergoing treatment for cancer.\n\nThe White House said in a statement that it continued to support Mr. Goodfriend.\n\n\u201cThe president stands behind his nomination of Marvin Goodfriend, who is incredibly qualified for the Federal Reserve board of governors,\u201d it said. \u201cWe hope the Senate confirms Mr. Goodfriend swiftly given the importance of the Federal Reserve to the American economy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Senate Banking Committee approved Mr. Goodfriend\u2019s nomination in a 13-to-12 party-line vote on Thursday. Republicans have not yet scheduled a final vote by the full Senate.\n\nThe political polarization of the Senate has made it increasingly difficult for presidents to secure the confirmation of their Fed nominees. Democrats in 2008 refused to vote on a pair of President George W. Bush\u2019s nominees. Republicans responded two years later by blocking the confirmation of Peter Diamond, who won a Nobel Prize in economics while he was waiting for a Senate vote. Senator Richard Shelby, the Alabama Republican who chaired the Banking Committee at the time, said after the prize was announced that Mr. Diamond was still unqualified.\n\nMr. Trump has not announced nominees for the other three board seats. The White House has focused on its search for a vice chairman, a job that has been vacant since October. Lawrence B. Lindsey, a former Fed governor who was considered a leading candidate, said this week in a note to clients of his economic advisory firm that he was withdrawing from consideration. Mr. Lindsey\u2019s decision was reported earlier by The Wall Street Journal.\n\nOthers who have been considered, according to a person familiar with the search process, include Richard Clarida, a Columbia University economist and a managing director at the investment firm Pimco; Mohamed A. El-Erian, chief economic adviser at the financial conglomerate Allianz; and John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.", "title": "Unexpected Opposition Imperils Federal Reserve Nominee", "authors": ["Binyamin Appelbaum"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere\u2019s something about the creaminess and different flavors you get,\u201d Mr. Crisp said.\n\nSuarez Family Brewery\u2019s sun-soaked taproom, about 12 miles south of Hudson, N.Y., has a tap list that tilts toward unfiltered lagers, like the darkly roasty Bone Shirt and the hop-forward Qualify Pils. \u201cIt\u2019s giving a consumer a beer\u2019s freshest expression,\u201d said Dan Suarez, who founded the brewery in 2016 with his wife, Taylor Cocalis.\n\nWith unfiltered beers, freshness doesn\u2019t mean they always taste best on Day 1. The flavors of Mr. Suarez\u2019s yeast-rich lagers evolve over several months.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a different drinking experience from week to week. At one and a half or two months, they\u2019re gorgeous,\u201d Mr. Suarez said, noting that he favors his own pilsners with one or two weeks of age.\n\nMr. Suarez prefers to describe his lagers as \u201cunfiltered\u201d instead of using the German jargon. \u201cI have this rule that I don\u2019t like to use a foreign word,\u201d he said. \u201cI think the word \u2018unfiltered\u2019 helps convey what the beer is better than the term \u2018zwickel pils.\u2019\u201d\n\nOther breweries proudly wave the keller and zwickel flag. Buoyed by brisk demand, Summit Brewing Company, in St. Paul, Minn., made its Keller Pils a year-round offering in January. Last year, Green Flash, of San Diego, released its Sea to Sea Lager \u2014 the label calls it a \u201czwickel lager\u201d nationwide.\n\n\u201cZwickel is just a fun word to say,\u201d said Erik Jensen, the brewmaster at Green Flash, which specializes in flavorful I.P.A.s. The low-alcohol lager filled a void in the brewery\u2019s portfolio, as well as its brewers\u2019 refrigerators. \u201cWe wanted to make sure we could have something we really wanted to drink,\u201d Mr. Jensen said.\n\nFor American brewers accustomed to lobbing grenades at orthodoxy, producing zwickel and keller beers is especially appealing. Mr. Levine has denied the accusations. The budget office previously projected that the debt limit would need to be raised beyond its current level of $20.5 trillion in late March or early April.\n\nThe reason for the change stems from the tax cuts, which went into effect in January and are expected to translate into less revenue for the federal government.\n\nThe Internal Revenue Service released new withholding tables this month to reflect the new, lower tax rates, which will result in companies withholding less money from worker paychecks. Beginning in February, the government is expected to see $10 billion to $15 billion less tax revenue each month.", "title": "United States Will Hit Debt Limit Sooner Than Expected Because of Tax Cuts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "GANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 It was their first outing as a team together, and it was a rout.\n\nThe unified Korean women\u2019s hockey team, which skated onto the ice bearing the heaviest symbolic weight of the Pyeongchang Games, lost, 8-0, to Switzerland on Saturday night.\n\nAs the only sports team competing here with athletes from both North and South Korea, the women\u2019s ice hockey players had come to represent hopes of a breakthrough in a geopolitical standoff that has stirred fears of nuclear conflict on the divided peninsula.\n\nWith South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, watching from the stands with Kim Yong-nam, the North\u2019s ceremonial head of state, and Kim Yo-jong, the only sister of Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, the diplomatic agenda driving the unified team was never in doubt.\n\nJong Su-hyon, a North Korean player, said at a news conference after the game that playing in front of top leadership of both countries was \u201cthe greatest honor for me.\u201d", "title": "United, They Fall: Korean Hockey Team Loses, 8-0, in Olympic Debut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The study, which concluded that pollution from glider trucks was no worse than from trucks with modern emissions controls, was cited by Mr. Pruitt when he announced in November he would make the regulatory change requested by Ms. Black. Last June, Mr. Oldham had signed a letter endorsing the study.\n\nThe Obama administration had moved to eliminate the exemption for the glider trucks, given the health threat associated with their emissions. The E.P.A., in its own analysis, estimated last year that gliders emitted nitrogen oxide levels during highway operations that were 43 times as high as those from trucks with modern emissions control systems.\n\nThe E.P.A., in a written statement Wednesday, said that Mr. Pruitt\u2019s move to exempt the glider trucks was based on a legal determination that the agency did not have the authority to regulate them, not the findings of the Tennessee Tech study.\n\n\u201cE.P.A. did not rely upon the study or even quote directly from it,\u201d the statement said, adding that the agency \u201conly noted the existence of the study,\u201d and its findings, when Mr. Pruitt moved to exempt the glider trucks.\n\nA lawyer for Fitzgerald did not respond on Wednesday for a request for comment.\n\nThe letter from Mr. Oldham followed a separate letter on Friday from Darrell Hoy, interim dean at Tennessee Tech\u2019s College of Engineering, directed to faculty leaders at the university. A protest was planned for Friday, and earlier this week, the word \u201cWynn\u201d was vandalized with black paint. The university quickly covered it up with plywood, with only the word \u201cCommons\u201d remaining visible.\n\nIn an email to the campus community, the university president, Amy Gutmann, and the chairman of its board of trustees, David L. Cohen, said Penn had made the decision because \u201cthe nature, severity, and extent of these allegations, and the patterns of abusive behavior they describe, involve acts and conduct that are inimical to the core values of our university.\u201d\n\nBut that left the issue of Mr. Cosby. Allegations against Mr. Cosby, who faces criminal charges as well as lawsuits, have included claims that he drugged women to have sex with them, and that he sexually assaulted a woman on Penn\u2019s campus during the Penn Relays track meet, where he was officiating in 2004.\n\nIn 2015, the university rebuffed calls to revoke Mr. Cosby\u2019s honorary degree. At that time, the university said that while the allegations against Mr. Cosby were deeply troubling, \u201cit is not our practice to rescind honorary degrees.\u201d\n\nBefore Thursday, Penn had not rescinded an honorary degree in a century, since it took similar action against Kaiser Wilhelm II and Ambassador Johann Heinrich von Bernstorff of Germany during World War I.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn explaining the university\u2019s decision, which was made by an executive committee of the board of trustees, Dr. Gutmann and Mr. Cohen wrote that once the committee decided that Mr. Wynn\u2019s honorary degree, bestowed in 2006, needed to be revoked, it had to do the same with Mr. Cosby\u2019s 1990 honor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe decision to remove the name Wynn Commons could not be made independently of considering the other ways in which the university had previously recognized Mr. Wynn,\u201d the email said. \u201cIt became necessary, therefore, to consider the appropriateness of Mr. Wynn\u2019s honorary degree and any other honorifics Penn had previously bestowed.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat decision in turn made it also clear that the multiple and highly credible charges involving Bill Cosby warranted the same action.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA spokesman for Mr. Cosby, who faces a retrial on sexual assault charges in Pennsylvania in the spring, did not respond to a message seeking comment. A spokesman for Mr. Wynn said he would have no comment.\n\nWhile Mr. Wynn has denied the allegations, first reported last week by The Wall Street Journal, he resigned his position as finance chairman for the Republican National Committee. His company, Wynn Resorts, has formed a committee to investigate the accusations, and gaming regulators in both Nevada and Massachusetts are also investigating.\n\nThe Republican National Committee said it would not return Mr. Wynn\u2019s contributions unless he were found guilty of the accusations, though the Republican Governors Association and several Republican members of Congress have returned his money or donated the amounts to charity.\n\nThe University of Iowa announced plans this week to remove Mr. Wynn\u2019s name from the school\u2019s Institute for Vision Research, which Mr. Wynn helped fund with a $25 million donation in 2013.\n\nOn campus Thursday, some students took photographs of the newly altered \u201cCommons\u201d sign, with traces of black spray paint still visible around the plywood covering Mr. Wynn\u2019s name.\n\nAmanda Silberling, 21, a senior from Boca Raton, Fla., who has led campus activism on sexual assault issues, said that the school had become more attuned recently to concerns about sexual misconduct.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think there\u2019s definitely been a lot more dialogue on campus in the last few years,\u201d she said, \u201cabout what role institutions like Penn play in setting examples for students and showing what a moral and ethical response to issues like this are.\u201d\n\nAs for Mr. Cosby, she said, revoking his honorary degree was a welcome gesture, even though it was late.\n\nBen Wasman, 19, a freshman, applauded the university for making what he called a \u201cbig statement\u201d recognizing the #MeToo movement.\n\n\u201cNow that there\u2019s somebody directly affiliated with the university, with their name all over the place,\u201d he said, \u201cthey finally realize that change needs to be made, and we should probably go back and revoke Cosby\u2019s too.\u201d", "title": "University of Pennsylvania Takes Away Steve Wynn\u2019s Honors. And Bill Cosby\u2019s, Too.", "authors": ["Stephanie Saul"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Akwasi Frimpong, 32, a once promising track athlete in the Netherlands who immigrated there illegally from Ghana as a child and represents that country, remembers thinking on that first run: \u201cOh, man, I\u2019m going to die. You want to brake, but there are no brakes. If there was a button to press stop, I would have.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut then he got to the bottom nearly a minute later, alive, and recovered his athletic instincts.\n\n\u201cThe competitiveness in you says why not go back up and make less mistakes and go even faster,\u201d he said.\n\nNow, here they are, improbably, proudly, at the Olympics.\n\nThey met in October 2016 at a training camp for what are called emerging countries in the sport. They became fast friends, sharing a quick laugh, skin darker than their competitors\u2019, the bond of representing ancestral countries where they did not live and a determination to get to the Olympics in an unfamiliar sport.\n\nThey have trained together. They have lost together. They have prayed together.\n\nThey share a storage and preparation shed for their sleds here and also the bond of minor celebrity. They also get the same question a lot: What are you doing here?\n\nTo which they say: This is the Olympics. What is everybody else doing here? Dreaming big, testing their limits and, in some cases, sending a message.\n\n\u201cI want to break barriers, to show that people from warmer countries, black people, can do this sport as well,\u201d Frimpong said. \u201cI want to write the history for my country, and hope more kids come out of their comfort zone. And I want to gain experience for the next Olympics in 2022.\u201d\n\nThey finish each other\u2019s sentences and have their own rituals, a handshake and chest bump of solidarity, before and after races, as a way to ground themselves in a sport in which the color of their skin makes them stand out and sometimes invites skepticism.\n\n\u201cBefore every run we dap up, and at the bottom we dap up, and at the end of the day we dap,\u201d Watson said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are nearly 3,000 athletes here from 92 countries. Most of them will go home empty-handed, as Watson and Frimpong surely will. They were at the very bottom of the standings before the final runs on Friday.\n\nYet they demand to be taken seriously as athletes, juggling news media attention while trying to focus and train.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to be just a media guy,\u201d said Frimpong, who, like Watson, competed in the sport\u2019s world championships last year. \u201cI want to show I can slide as well.\u201d\n\nHis journey was particularly circuitous.\n\nHe left Ghana at age 8, carried to the Netherlands by his mother, who had left five years before to work cleaning houses and selling flowers to provide for her 11 children living in a cramped house in Ghana. She had promised to send for him, but he landed in an alien European world where organized sports helped him earn acceptance.\n\nHe excelled at track, gaining notice as a Dutch junior national champion at 17 in 2004, and eventually earning a scholarship to a university in Utah. But his status as an illegal immigrant initially kept him from leaving the Netherlands, until a public campaign helped smooth over the paperwork.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe came close to making the 2012 Olympic track team for the Netherlands, but an injury kept him off and sidelined his track career. He was steered to bobsled and nearly made the 2014 Sochi Games team for the Netherlands.\n\nA coach suggested skeleton. It was 2015, and he was selling vacuum cleaners in Arizona, where he had moved with his wife. He knew not giving it a shot to make the Olympics again would gnaw at him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was like a bucket list thing,\u201d he said.\n\nHe chose Ghana, he said, because he felt he had given to two countries by then, the Netherlands and the United States, where he was engaged in charitable endeavors related to track.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAt the age of 31, you ask, what have you done for your country?\u201d\n\nGhana was more than willing to have him, though he is getting by mostly on sponsorships. His racing helmet, showing a rabbit escaping the jaws of a lion, represents his breaking free from life\u2019s challenges.\n\nLikewise, Watson struggled to make the Olympics in track, and ended up in skeleton as a last-ditch effort. He had scrolled through the qualifications for nearly every sport and found that skeleton offered walk-ons who passed physical tests a path.\n\nHe went to a combine for the sport in Lake Placid, N.Y., and did well enough to earn a spot in an elite camp. Gradually, however, he accepted that it would be highly competitive to make the American team.\n\nPhoto\n\nJamaica, with its \u201cCool Runnings\u201d vibe and history of recruiting promising athletes for bobsled and skeleton, opened the way.\n\nHe had paid the bills by working in the family furniture business and acting, even turning down a temporary spot as a hyena in \u201cThe Lion King\u201d on Broadway so he could train for the Olympics.\n\nThey both know skeptics and doubters remain. They read it on the faces of some athletes, but try to keep focus.\n\n\u201cThis is bigger than ourselves,\u201d Watson said, as Frimpong nodded hard in agreement. \u201cWhich is why we connect so well, because you see a lot of athletes and the reason they are so depressed and on themselves and lashing out at other people is because this is literally all they have. When it\u2019s gone they are not going to have anything.\u201d\n\nBut this skeleton duo insists there is more, the accolades from young fans, the awe and wonder from fans in the countries they represent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe understand,\u201d Watson said, \u201cthere is a bigger audience, and that\u2019s why we have so much fun doing it while we are here.\u201d\n\nOn the last qualifying run Friday, neither advanced to the final, finishing 29th (Watson) and 30th (Frimpong) out of 30.\n\nJust off the track, they dapped.", "title": "Unlikely Skeleton Duo Share an Obscure Sport and a Crazy Dream", "authors": ["Randal C. Archibold"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "It seems these proteins are acting as sensors in these other tissues as well. But rather than sending a message about the strawberry you\u2019re biting into, they are rigged to send messages about invading bacteria, for instance, or to help adjust blood pressure after a meal. They may have been evolution\u2019s version of an especially useful Tinkertoy piece: versatile, easy to assemble in new configurations, already in the tool kit.\n\nIt may have been a similar situation for this protein implicated in both taste and balance.\n\nEmily Liman of the University of Southern California, who led the study, and colleagues were on the hunt for a sour sensor when they made the discovery chronicled in their latest paper. They had made a list of all the genes expressed in sour taste cells and identified those that might make cells sensitive to acids. They had tested about 40 before they came to one called Otop1.\n\n\u201cBecause this gene was already known to be involved in the formation of the vestibular system, we thought it was very unlikely to play a role in taste,\u201d Dr. Liman said. \u201cIt was really just a shot in the dark. We had all but given up, and we thought, \u2018Let\u2019s test this last one.\u2019\u201d\n\nOtop1 worked like a charm. \u201cIt was a huge, huge surprise for us,\u201d she said.\n\nIt isn\u2019t yet clear why Otop1 would be useful in both the ear and the tongue. But the overlap makes a kind of sense. The ability to balance depends on the formation of tiny crystals of calcium carbonate in the inner ear. They rest on top of sensitive hair cells and shift gently as we move, giving feedback that lets us stay upright.\n\nThose crystals will dissolve, however, if they are placed in an acid. Perhaps Otop1\u2019s ability to make cells sensitive to acids is important in the process of creating these crucial structures. Exactly which role the protein plays there remains to be seen, Dr. Liman said. But it\u2019s fascinating to see that in places as distinct as the mouth and the ear, evolution has given the same protein very different, but similarly important, jobs to do.", "title": "Unlocking Secrets of Sour Flavors With Something Found in Your Ears", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Either way, it has been a tough week for Mr. Kelly, to say the least.\n\n\u201cYa think?\u201d said the former defense secretary Leon E. Panetta, a onetime boss to Mr. Kelly, who retired as a four-star Marine general. \u201cI worry about John. Even he has admitted it\u2019s probably the toughest job he\u2019s ever had. And I really do think sometimes, particularly with this president, you\u2019re fighting on so many fronts it\u2019s tough not to have that job wear on you.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Kelly\u2019s long service to his country as a Marine did not necessarily prepare him for the job of White House chief of staff, added Mr. Panetta, who had that post himself under President Bill Clinton. \u201cIt comes to that political judgment,\u201d he said. \u201cYou\u2019ve got to have your antenna up. You\u2019ve got to be able to anticipate where the hot spots are.\u201d\n\nThis week was not the first time that Mr. Kelly did not seem to foresee hot spots. When he took the White House job last summer, he was seen by many as a mature figure who could impose order on a chaotic building. By most accounts, he has indeed created a more organized operation. But he has also generated repeated furors with words and deeds.\n\nHe engaged in a heated back-and-forth with an African-American Democratic congresswoman, distorting statements she had made at a ceremony they both attended. He opined that the Civil War resulted from \u201cthe lack of an ability to compromise.\u201d He said that Mr. Trump had not been \u201cfully informed\u201d about border issues as a candidate and had since \u201cevolved,\u201d drawing a public retort from the president.\n\nMr. Kelly generated further heat this week when he dismissed many of the more than one million immigrants who were brought to the country illegally as children but who did not apply for the protection of an Obama-era program that Mr. Trump ordered ended next month. Some of them \u201cwere the people that some would say were too afraid to sign up, others would say were too lazy to get off their asses, but they didn\u2019t sign up,\u201d he told reporters.\n\nMr. Kelly at first came to the defense of Rob Porter, the White House staff secretary, who resigned in the face of allegations of spousal abuse. \u201cRob Porter is a man of true integrity and honor, and I can\u2019t say enough good things about him,\u201d Mr. Kelly said. \u201cHe is a friend, a confidant and a trusted professional.\u201d\n\nAs outrage grew over a photograph showing an ex-wife of Mr. Porter with a black eye, Mr. Kelly issued a new statement. \u201cI was shocked by the new allegations released today against Rob Porter,\u201d he said. \u201cThere is no place for domestic violence in our society.\u201d But he added: \u201cI stand by my previous comments of the Rob Porter that I have come to know since becoming chief of staff and believe every individual deserves the right to defend their reputation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Porter\u2019s case raised questions about what Mr. Kelly knew and when. The White House was informed as far back as August that Mr. Porter\u2019s security clearance was being held up because of domestic allegations. Mr. Kelly has known about the allegations at least since last fall, according to officials who asked not to be named.\n\nRaj Shah, a White House spokesman, said on Thursday that Mr. Kelly was not \u201cfully aware\u201d of the details until this week. Mr. Shah also insisted that Mr. Trump remained behind Mr. Kelly. \u201cThe president has confidence in his chief of staff,\u201d he said.\n\nOne official insisted that there was minimal knowledge in the White House about Mr. Porter\u2019s troubles. The official said that Mr. Kelly felt misled by Mr. Porter\u2019s account of what had happened. A friend of Mr. Kelly\u2019s said he had learned the details of Mr. Porter\u2019s situation only an hour before suggesting he resign.\n\nBut White House officials said privately that the president was frustrated with both Mr. Kelly and the White House communications director, Hope Hicks, who in recent weeks has been dating Mr. Porter. Ms. Hicks was one of those rallying the White House to Mr. Porter\u2019s defense when the allegations first surfaced in The Daily Mail.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Domestic violence is abhorrent and has no place in our society.\u201d\n\nFriends and associates noted that with Mr. Kelly\u2019s lack of experience in Washington politics, he may not have been attuned at first to how the domestic abuse allegations against Mr. Porter would be perceived.\n\nMr. Porter was also a favorite of Mr. Kelly\u2019s and viewed as one of the most competent members of an often dysfunctional White House team. Some friends expressed concern that Mr. Kelly had changed with his association with Mr. Trump and grown too insulated in the White House bubble.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Kelly has previously played down accusations against someone he believed served a greater goal. He appeared as a character witness in a 2016 court-martial of a Marine colonel accused of sexually harassing two female subordinates. Mr. Kelly praised the colonel as a \u201csuperb Marine officer.\u201d\n\nMr. Kelly has spent much of his six months trying to clear out the White House of staff members he viewed as problematic, and colleagues have credited him with reducing internal feuding as a result. But even those efforts have caused him trouble.\n\nHe pushed out Omarosa Manigault Newman, the former reality show star who had been given a White House post, for what one White House official called misuse of government cars. In an interview on \u201cCelebrity Big Brother\u201d on CBS that aired on Thursday, Ms. Manigault Newman exacted some payback by describing a chilling White House. \u201cI was haunted by tweets every single day, like what is he going to tweet,\u201d she said.\n\nShe added that she tried to intervene but was blocked. Now that she is gone, she said, \u201cI\u2019d like to say it\u2019s not my problem, but I can\u2019t say that because, like, it\u2019s bad.\u201d Will everything be O.K., she was asked. \u201cNo, it\u2019s going to not be O.K.,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s not.\u201d\n\nMr. Shah dismissed her comments. \u201cOmarosa was fired three times on \u2018The Apprentice,\u2019 and this is the fourth time we let her go,\u201d he said.\n\nBut most attention on Thursday focused on Mr. Kelly and his handling of the charges against Mr. Porter.\n\n\u201cI have lost all confidence in him as chief of staff,\u201d Evan Siegfried, a Republican strategist, said on MSNBC. \u201cHe\u2019s becoming a distraction. He says things that are absolutely outrageous, and then he does things in the case of Rob Porter that are morally despicable.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Nydia Velazquez, Democrat of New York, wrote on Twitter that the Porter case was \u201cpart of a culture of misogyny at the #WhiteHouse.\u201d\n\nRepublicans were not so quick to throw Mr. Kelly overboard, even as they questioned his judgment.\n\n\u201cGeneral Kelly has done an extraordinary job as chief of staff to President Trump,\u201d Senator John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana, said on CNN. \u201cI think he\u2019s a good man. It means they\u2019re human.\u201d", "title": "Unwelcome Attention for John Kelly, the Man Enlisted to Bring Calm", "authors": ["Peter Baker", "Maggie Haberman"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Morse declined to speak about construction costs, but his budget for the project has been reported to be roughly $265 million.\n\nWhen it was built, the steel and concrete, gull-wing-shaped structure designed by the Finnish architect Eero Saarinen was so evocative of flight, the mere sight of it was supposed to initiate the journey.\n\n\u201cHe wanted to provide a building in which the human being felt uplifted, important and full of anticipation,\u201d the architect\u2019s wife, Aline B. Saarinen, told George Scullin in his 1968 book, \u201cInternational Airport: The Story of Kennedy Airport and U.S. Commercial Aviation.\u201d\n\nOn that, Saarinen was successful. The T.W.A. Flight Center, as the terminal was called, was bold, imaginative and elegant, according to critics, praise that was matched by what was said about the airline it housed. For many years, T.W.A. was the country\u2019s sole airline with both a vibrant domestic network and international routes, according to New York\u2019s Landmarks Preservation Commission.\n\nWorking out of the T.W.A. Flight Center was \u201can overwhelmingly exciting experience, and everyone around me felt the same,\u201d said Hugh Schoelzel, who went to work for T.W.A. as a flight engineer in 1967 and retired as vice president of corporate safety in 2004.\n\nBy the \u201980s, T.W.A. was experiencing financial trouble. A refresh of the terminal was planned, but not carried out. In 2001, when T.W.A. was acquired by American Airlines, the terminal returned to the care of the landlord, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. It sits empty in front of Terminal 5, home of JetBlue.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough the T.W.A. Flight Center is widely loved, the Port Authority had difficulty finding someone to save it. An effort in 2013 by a noted hotel developer, Andr\u00e9 Balazs, to build a small hotel and conference center there fell through.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLike most people, I believed that the T.W.A. terminal would sit underutilized or empty in perpetuity,\u201d said Nicholas Dagen Bloom, an associate professor who teaches urban planning at the New York Institute of Technology and the author of \u201cThe Metropolitan Airport: JFK International and Modern New York.\u201d\n\nFor preservationists and lovers of aviation history, the lack of progress was frustrating.\n\nBut for Mr. Morse, it was kismet. In 2014, after the Balazs plan faded, the Port Authority issued a third request for proposals, and this time, Mr. Morse said, his company was big enough to take on the task of renovating a drafty, deteriorating monument to aviation\u2019s golden age.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a daunting project,\u201d he said. Asbestos and lead paint had to be removed. Terminal at J.F.K., This Time as a Hotel", "authors": ["Christine Negroni", "Square Feet"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Stonehenge, the prehistoric monument in England that draws hundreds of thousands of visitors each year, is closer to getting a traffic tunnel nearby to \u201cenhance and protect\u201d the tranquil environment of the ancient landscape.\n\nInitial designs for the project at Stonehenge, a World Heritage Site, were unveiled on Thursday. They are part of a project set to cost 1.6 billion pounds, or about $2.2 billion, to upgrade a highway near the monument in the county of Wiltshire, in southwest England.\n\nThe designs address concerns that the tunnel portals and deep cuttings would scar the landscape and cause irreparable damage. Heritage groups had also been concerned that the proposed tunnel exit would be too close to the Normanton Down Barrows, a collection of tombs that is a part of the Stonehenge landscape.\n\nIn the proposal, the latest and most significant one put forward by Highways England, the British government organization overseeing the project, the tunnel would be longer than previously envisaged: 1.8 miles.", "title": "Upgraded Designs Unveiled for Road Tunnel Near Stonehenge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Ever since Nick and Stacey\u2019s father, Gus Bazas, opened Q Florist in 1968, customers, like Ms. Bickwid, have turned into regulars.\n\nSome clients have standing weekly orders. That afternoon, Roberto, a floral designer at Q, was placing tall orchids and oversize green monstera leaves into a large glass vase. \u201cThe family I\u2019m making this for has been ordering these every week from us for at least 30 years,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nGus Bazas emigrated from Nafpaktos, Greece, and he got his start in 1966 by selling flowers from a cart on Central Park West. He bought his flowers from the flower district in Chelsea and stored them in the space that\u2019s now Q.\n\nPeter Jennings, the former anchor of ABC\u2019s \u201cWorld News Tonight\u201d who lived in the neighborhood, became a frequent customer and, according to Nick, encouraged and advised his father when he decided to open a storefront in his storage space.\n\nNick and Stacey got involved in the business in the 1970s, but Gus worked here seven days a week up until he died in 2015 at the age of 93.\n\nToday, the siblings run it together, and Nick\u2019s son, Constantine, also works with them full time. They maintain their father\u2019s traditions: The flowers still come in six days a week, and any child who walks in is given a free carnation in his or her color of choice.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2013, Nick and Stacey placed a 1,000-pound wooden sculpture of a bear at the corner of 82nd Street and Columbus Avenue. Depending on the season, they decorate the bear with flowers and plants. On Valentine\u2019s Day, the bear will be dressed as Cupid and will be surrounded by red roses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSoon after Ms. Bickwid left, a woman walked in clutching a pot with a wilting orchid. \u201cListen, Nick, I didn\u2019t buy this plant here, but it\u2019s so dry and dying, and I don\u2019t know what to do,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cThis is an easy fix,\u201d Nick said. He filled the base with moss to keep the soil moist and told her to place two ice cubes in the soil twice a week. \u201cIn a couple of weeks, the orchid should regrow,\u201d he said.\n\nMary Zingone Vinci, one of the owners of Zingone Brothers, an Italian grocery a block away that\u2019s been around since 1927, was also at Q that afternoon. She has known Nick and Stacey for more than 35 years, and her father, Ralph, was close friends with Gus. Ms. Zingone had come to buy tulips for her mother, Josephine, who has been ailing. \u201cThese yellow tulips, they\u2019re mom\u2019s favorite and are going to brighten her day,\u201d she said. \u201cThey sure brighten mine.\u201d", "title": "Upper West Side Perennials", "authors": ["Shivani Vora", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The videos contain rich and at times startling detail about life in communities roiled by gun violence, poverty and food insecurity. They tell the stories of families where amputations, strokes and other complications of diabetes are the norm. One video, \u201cPerfect Soldiers,\u201d is written and performed by Gabriel Cortez, a young poet who laments seeing his relatives struggle with diabetes, a disease, he says, that \u201cis as common in our family as heartburn.\u201d He talks about his grandfather, a military veteran with a habit of consuming multiple sugary drinks daily despite suffering from diabetes.\n\n\u201cAt 66, we are scared that another stroke could do what no war ever could and cut him to the ground,\u201d Gabriel says in his video poem. \u201cHe drinks, like aunt Maritza didn\u2019t lose both of her legs to diabetes last year, like half of our neighborhood doesn\u2019t look like the emergency ward of a hospital, like he hasn\u2019t seen the pictures: How it is impossible to tell the difference between a roadside bomb victim, and someone who just forgot to take their insulin.\u201d\n\nFrom AIDS to Diabetes\n\nThe program is in part the brainchild of Dr. Dean Schillinger, a co-founder of the U.C.S.F. Center for Vulnerable Populations and a primary care doctor at Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital. Dr. Schillinger began his career at the hospital in the 1990s in the throes of the AIDS crisis, when nearly half of his patients were dying of the disease. Dr. Schillinger witnessed the number of cases plunge as activists, public health experts and the medical and scientific communities came together. But then the obesity crisis began and a new wave of disease flooded San Francisco General.\n\n\u201cThe AIDS ward is now a diabetes ward,\u201d Dr. Schillinger said. \u201cMaybe one in 15 patients had diabetes when I started 25 years ago. Now one in two of my clinic visits are with patients who have diabetes.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBetween 2008 and 2013, Dr. Schillinger served as chief of the Diabetes Prevention and Control Program for the California Department of Public Health. In that role he saw up close the rapid spread of Type 2 diabetes among children, and he was particularly struck by the link between the disease and socioeconomic status.\n\nLooking at maps of San Francisco, he said, he noticed that diabetes hospitalization rates differed tenfold from one neighborhood to the next, driven by factors like income, education levels, segregation and soda consumption rates. While the public discourse around Type 2 diabetes tended to revolve around \u201cshame and blame\u201d \u2014 the idea that people who develop the disease knowingly make bad choices \u2014 Dr. Schillinger looked at these diabetes hot spots and began to think of the crisis as a social and environmental problem.\n\nMany of his diabetes patients live in poor neighborhoods awash in fast food chains, liquor stores and billboards advertising junk foods. With severely limited incomes, his patients are often forced to purchase the cheapest, highest-calorie meals to feed their families, which often means choosing packaged goods and fast foods instead of fresh produce. Many are riddled with chronic stress from poverty and the threat of violence in their neighborhoods.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI have many patients who say they will not let their kids go outside and play after school or after dark because they\u2019re afraid of gangs and shootouts,\u201d he said.\n\nOne day he attended a Youth Speaks event where he saw an overweight 16-year-old girl perform a poem about her body image issues, her addiction to junk food and the diabetes that runs in her family.\n\n\u201cShe was describing how she was eating cupcakes even as she wheeled her aunt who had diabetes and kidney failure into her dialysis appointment,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was basically a food addiction poem in the context of the diabetes epidemic, with the addiction being a consequence of poverty, stress and insecurity. There were so many forces acting on this child that the pathways inevitably led to diabetes.\u201d\n\nA light bulb went off for Dr. Schillinger and for James Kass, then executive director of Youth Speaks. With funding from the National Institutes of Health, the U.C.S.F. Diabetes Family Fund and other sources, they started The Bigger Picture project in San Francisco and spread it to seven other regions across California. The spoken-word poems have been presented to over 10,000 high school students and viewed 1.5 million times on YouTube.\n\nThe Bigger Picture team hopes to conduct a study to see if the campaign has any long-term impact on obesity or diabetes rates among youth. In the meantime, they say their goal is to change the national conversation about Type 2 diabetes. They say the young poets are removing the stigma around the disease and calling attention to the fact that it is often impossible for people to make good choices when their options are limited.\n\n\u201cTo make healthy choices, you\u2019ve got to have healthy choices to make that are accessible and affordable,\u201d said Natasha Huey, a poet and project manager for The Bigger Picture. \u201cI would really challenge folks to take $5 and walk through the neighborhoods that a lot of our young folks are coming from and feed themselves healthfully. It isn\u2019t easy, and that\u2019s why this isn\u2019t a conversation about individual choices; it\u2019s about systems.\u201d", "title": "Using Art to Tackle Diabetes in Youth", "authors": ["Anahad O Connor"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Can I use Microsoft Office on a Chromebook?\n\nA. Chromebooks run Google\u2019s Chrome OS, which was introduced in 2009 as a streamlined operating system for netbooks and other lightweight laptops. While you cannot install the traditional Windows or Mac versions of Microsoft Office on a Chromebook and have the software actually work, Microsoft\u2019s Office apps for Android devices can now run on the newer Chromebook models that have the ability to download, install and run apps from the Google Play store.\n\nThe Office apps are free for devices with screens smaller than 10.1 inches, though a free Microsoft account is required to create and edit files. For Chromebooks and tablets with larger screens, a paid subscription to Microsoft\u2019s Office 365 service is required; the least expensive plan is about $7 a month.", "title": "Using Microsoft Apps on a Chromebook", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "KABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 Taliban insurgents overran three checkpoints in nighttime raids on Tuesday in the western Afghan province of Farah, killing about 20 police officers before melting back into nearby villages, according to Afghan officials.\n\nThe province has been teetering from a wave of attacks by Taliban fighters using night-vision goggles, a technology that once gave the United States an edge in the war. Equipped with the devices, the Taliban quickly overwhelmed the checkpoints, said Dadullah Qani, a provincial council member in Farah, in a telephone interview.\n\nAfghan officials have said that the night-vision goggles the Taliban have been using with such effect typically bear Russian markings, though their origin is unclear. Politicians in Kabul, the capital, have accused Russia of arming the Taliban.\n\nThe authorities in Moscow deny this. They say contacts established over the past several years with Taliban leaders are for discussions on countering a rival Islamist insurgent threat in Afghanistan, from the Islamic State, and on encouraging peace talks with the government.", "title": "Using Night-Vision Goggles, Taliban Stage Lethal Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn the 1950s and \u201960s, when the Southern states remained committed to racial segregation, many of us marched and spoke out against this blight on our democracy. But marching wasn\u2019t enough to end this abuse of African-Americans. Nor were court orders sufficient to overcome this national embarrassment.\n\nAs the Kennedys and Lyndon B. Johnson understood, substantial change would come only with congressional action \u2014 not simply through marches and sermons, however essential they may have been, but by changing the laws of the land.\n\nThe young people who are protesting today are the advanced wave of what must come next: gun control legislation that takes weapons meant for battlefields out of our schools, off the streets and away from disturbed individuals with no respect for human lives. And the way to achieve these legislative advances is through the ballot box.\n\nEvery reasonable voter in this country should make a candidate\u2019s position on gun control a test of his or her ballot.", "title": "Opinion | Using Our Power to Fight for Gun Laws", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "New commissions, from Justin Peck, Lauren Lovette, Michelle Dorrance, Lil Buck, Claudia Schreier, Silas Riener and Rashaun Mitchell, as well as a choreographic debut by the New York City Ballet principal Tiler Peck, are among the highlights of this year\u2019s Vail Dance Festival, which will run from July 28 through Aug. 11. The program, announced Friday, celebrates the festival\u2019s 30th anniversary with an emphasis on collaborative creative relationships.\n\n\u201cBreathing the Rocky Mountain air, we seem to let go of rules,\u201d said Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet principal dancer who has directed the Vail festival since 2007. \u201cBringing together so many distinct voices sets the scene for some highly creative craziness.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a first Vail commission for Justin Peck, New York City Ballet\u2019s resident choreographer, whose work will be set to a new composition by Caroline Shaw, currently the festival\u2019s Leonard Bernstein composer in residence. Ms. Schreier\u2019s piece, created for Ballet Hisp\u00e1nico, will have a commissioned score by Gabriela Lena Frank, and be performed by the string quartet Brooklyn Rider.\n\nBallet Hisp\u00e1nico\u2019s appearance will be its first time at the festival. Kids these days, am I right?\n\nTricky Clues\n\n5A: Every time I see a clue that uses the word \u201ccourses,\u201d I think of school courses. Of course, it could also be food courses, and if you have enough of them, they add up to a MEAL (the answer is MEALS in the puzzle because of the plural clue.)\n\n48A: This was tough for a Tuesday, but the ATLAS mountains \u201cform the backbone of the countries of the Maghreb,\u201d according to Britannica.com. Meta!\n\nThe literary passage is from a book by Alison Frankel, \u201cDouble Eagle,\u201d about the amazing history of the 1933 $20 gold coins that were minted, but never circulated, after President Franklin D. Roosevelt took the United States off the gold standard in an effort to stave off the Depression. There are more twists and turns of fate in the journey of one of these gold coins than in most thrillers. First it gets coin-napped from the U.S. Mint, which was about to melt it down; then it disappears during a world war, turns up in a coup, almost gets destroyed on 9/11, and, in 2002, makes one coin dealer about $3 million at auction (after he was jailed for possessing it and had to fight the American government for joint ownership).\n\nI daresay one of you aspiring cinemateurs could make a go of it. My heart fell for a moment when I looked up \u201cDouble Eagle movie\u201d and saw this, being filmed at this very moment, but apparently it\u2019s about golf. Zzzzz!\n\nAnyhow, I hope your interest is piqued even if you\u2019re not already a numismatist (or an acrostician, there\u2019s always demand for more of those). This passage comprises quite a few dauntingly long words, and the clues are chewy as well. I loved the clue for W \u2014 a \u201cBathroom item that in another form may be cooked and eaten\u201d \u2014 having grown LOOFAH before in the garden, like cucumbers, and attempted some healthy recipe or other, although the result was pretty exfoliating, unfortunately. I also gathered NEW YORK (one of the couple of coin-related clues), AL CAPONE and LUFTHANSA, but the rest was pretty slow going.", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 I am writing this on the seventh day of this Olympics and there is no rest. Conversations in my sleep-deprived, media-saturated household are already sounding like lowbrow Joycean stream of thought involving the rules of curling, incomprehensible snowboarding exclamations, kitchen fires and emotional remembrances of Oksana Baiul and Surya Bonaly (I leave it to you in the comments if you have any favorites of your own). And there\u2019s more than a week to go!\n\nThe passage in this acrostic is tangentially relevant to my ramblings, as it\u2019s one explanation of why some of us can not look away. The author, Christine Brennan, is a journalist, currently writing a column for USA Today, with a long bibliography including several books on sports. This one, \u201cInside Edge,\u201d is on figure skating.\n\nI did not need my \u201cA\u201d game to glide through this particular puzzle; I guessed a couple of vernacular expressions, SIT TIGHT and NOT SO MUCH, and was correct on both. I got a giggle out of \u201cRan out of clothes?\u201d being STREAKED, and also liked the nerdy humor in the clue for RADON.\n\nThe team of Cox Rathvon often slips a few hints in that are relevant to the passage, sometimes subtly; one of the clues I took forever to figure out was \u201cGlowing praise,\u201d which in this case is ENCOMIUM. I resolved to make this word part of my expressions of Olympian admiration this week, and lo and behold, that\u2019s what the original encomiums were, apparently.\n\nFor fans of the sport, here\u2019s a really pretty routine. If you\u2019re unfamiliar with this skater you must watch till the end for the final spin; it\u2019s pretty amazing.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nWe could be persuaded to think, given the last third of this excerpt, that an author sometimes writes with her future acrosticization in mind. We wish it were so! In any case, this passage certainly culminates with a fanfare of the Right Stuff.\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 If you\u2019re dipping your toe in the variety puzzle pool, welcome! There are several flavors throughout the year, and this one has a pretty avid following and a nice back story, as the inventor of \u201cSplit Decisions\u201d passed his art on as a teacher to Fred Piscop, so every time it appears it\u2019s like a little paean to the master (George Bredehorn, who created other word puzzles as well).\n\nYou might find you have a knack for them, but every time they come around I hem and haw my way through. I always find it impossible to believe that there\u2019s really only one answer to every spot, even when I\u2019m finished (in this one, I\u2019d argue that you could have PRIX/TWIX as well as PRIG/TWIG, since the candy bar\u2019s been in the regular puzzle before). There are always a few \u201ccrosswordy\u201d words \u2014 for example, in this puzzle EMCEE, MULLAH and MINICAM make appearances.\n\nMy only advice, really, is to make it a little scrabbly and start with the high value letters, as you\u2019ll probably stumble on a few words where there aren\u2019t many options at all, like \u201cAX/IB\u201d \u2014 a pair that is actually narrowed down more by the IB than the AX (I could think of only a few four-letter words starting with IB: IBEX, IBID and IBIS, which was the only one that worked with AX).\n\nYou may be tempted by the three-letter words where there\u2019s only one left blank, but they\u2019re hardly ever easy. Look at \u201cPU/FI\u201d with one blank at the end; you could use B, G, N or T there, and three out of four of those letters could work fine at the end of a word, as this clue is crossing. Better to keep looking for weird letter pairings. The northeast corner, for example, has _ \u201cKI/TR\u201d_ _ _. You need a vowel at the start of the three blank letters in order to work after TR, but the KI quickly limits you to I, and SKIING/STRING is pretty natural after that.", "title": "Variety: Split Decisions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 With Venezuela suffering one of the most severe economic collapses of modern times, the beleaguered administration of President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro announced on Tuesday that it had begun a presale of virtual currency backed by the nation\u2019s vast petroleum reserves.\n\nThe government, which had announced plans for the new digital currency late last year, said the initiative was a response to a financial crisis marked by a profound devaluation of the national currency, the bol\u00edvar, and quadruple-digit inflation.\n\nThe country is suffering desperate scarcities of food and medicine, soaring crime rates and the collapse of public services and the health system. The crisis has driven hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans to flee the country seeking a better life.\n\nThe Maduro administration hopes that sales of the digital currency, known as the petro, will help its treasury pay off debt and increase imports of vitally needed goods, as well as raw materials for manufacturing.", "title": "Venezuela Launches Virtual Currency, Hoping to Resuscitate Economy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "CARACAS, Venezuela \u2014 Venezuela\u2019s alliance of opposition parties declared on Wednesday that it would boycott the coming presidential election, saying the electoral system was rigged in favor of President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro and his United Socialist Party of Venezuela.\n\nThe decision effectively cleared a path for Mr. Maduro\u2019s re-election to another six-year term and threw the future of the nation\u2019s political opposition, deeply weakened by recent election losses and internal fractures, further into doubt.\n\nThe coalition\u2019s announcement emerged from weeks of debate following the decision in January by the all-powerful Constituent Assembly to put the election on an accelerated timeline, a move denounced by the opposition. The date was cemented this month by the country\u2019s electoral commission.\n\nThe coalition had been divided between those who argued that participating in the April 22 election would end in certain failure at the polls and legitimize Mr. Maduro\u2019s rule, and those who insisted that participation was an opportunity, however remote, for change.", "title": "Venezuela Opposition Will Boycott Election, and Maduro Tightens His Hold", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "In Venice, Italy, it\u2019s that time again.\n\nTime for grand costume balls, fierce mask contests, towering wigs and a parade of preening, strutting revelers as city residents and visitors from around the world take part in its annual carnival.\n\nThe season technically began on Jan. 27 with the Flight of the Angel, a ritual dating to the 1500s, and an opening regatta. Others will follow, and the season it will end on Shrove Tuesday (Fat Tuesday or Marted\u00ec Grasso), the day before Ash Wednesday.\n\nThe theme this year, \u201cCreatum: Civitas Ludens,\u201d evokes the spirit of fun and play during carnival.", "title": "Venice Carnival Brings Out the Masks, Regattas and Revelry", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Vic Damone, the postwar crooner whose intimate, rhapsodic voice captivated bobby soxers, middle-age dreamers and silver-haired romantics in a five-decade medley of America\u2019s love songs and popular standards, died on Sunday in Miami Beach. He was 89.\n\nEd Henry, a family friend, said the cause was complications of respiratory failure.\n\nMr. Damone suffered a mild stroke in 2000 but recovered and retired in 2001 after a farewell tour that included appearances at the Hollywood Bowl and Carnegie Hall. He came out of retirement a decade later to give one last performance in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived.\n\nFor anyone old enough to remember the age of phonograph records, the velvet baritone of Vic Damone was an unforgettable groove in a soundtrack that also included Frank Sinatra, Perry Como and Tony Bennett, singers who arose in the big band era and reached peaks of popularity in the 1950s.\n\nImage Mr. Damone in 1965. After a stormy personal life, he titled his autobiography \u201cSinging Was the Easy Part.\u201d\n\nMr. Damone, a decade younger than Sinatra, never quite became the pop music institution that the others did. Critics said he did not possess Sinatra\u2019s vivid personality or Bennett\u2019s range and sheer energy, although his smooth, unruffled delivery was similar to Como\u2019s.", "title": "Vic Damone, Who Crooned His Way to Postwar Popularity, Dies at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cLet\u2019s get back to the business of why we are here,\u201d she said.\n\nDr. Nassar sat with his head down, listening.\n\nAfter he was removed from the courtroom, Mr. Margraves was placed in detention for possible contempt of court, but the judge later released him without charge, Jerri Nesbitt, the executive assistant of Eaton County Sheriff Thomas Reich, said by telephone.\n\nCalls to several members of Mr. Margraves\u2019s family were not returned on Friday.\n\nThe hearing is based on a guilty plea by Dr. Nassar, the former U.S.A. The plea agreement states the minimum sentencing range would be 25 to 40 years for each of the counts.\n\nLast week, more than 150 young women and teenagers publicly confronted Dr. Nassar during a seven-day hearing in Ingham County Circuit Court, where he had pleaded guilty in November to seven counts of sexual assault.\n\nMany of the young women and teenagers who spoke in the two courtrooms have told stories that have similar elements, including their abuse by a doctor they were referred to or instructed to see by coaches. Some said that nothing was done after they finally did come forward to report multiple incidents of the abuse, which stretches back decades.\n\nThe United States Olympic Committee said on Friday it had hired a law firm, Ropes & Gray, to determine when U.S.A. Gymnastics or the U.S.O.C. officials first became aware of any evidence of Nassar\u2019s abuse, what that evidence was and what they did with it.\n\nOn Friday, Valeri Liukin, the coordinator of the U.S. women\u2019s gymnastics team, said he had resigned, citing the stress of the job. The video shows Syrian militia members abusing the body of a female Kurdish fighter.\n\nThe Free Syrian Army ordered an investigation, saying in a statement that it \u201cwill not hesitate to hold accountable those who prove to be involved in this incident, if it is verified, in accordance with Shariah law and our principles.\u201d The statement went on to say that the group adhered to international human rights principles and Shariah law in dealing with the bodies of victims.\n\nMore than 10,000 Free Syrian Army fighters are part of the Turkish military\u2019s offensive, which began on Jan. 20 to oust the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces from the town of Afrin, which borders Turkey in northwestern Syria.\n\nThe Turkish government, military and official media did not initially comment on the episode.\n\nThe body was identified by Kurdish forces as that of Barin Kobani, a military pseudonym, though a spokesman declined to confirm her real name.
