Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nThe first season of HBO\u2019s sci-fi-western puzzle box, \u201cWestworld,\u201d didn\u2019t exactly end on a peaceful note. With that in mind, there\u2019s something unsettling about the first 30 seconds of the Season 2 trailer, which debuted Sunday during the Super Bowl: It\u2019s all breathtaking panoramas of the titular sprawling, Wild West-themed fantasyland and soothing clich\u00e9s, like \u201cWe built this world together \u2014 a world where dreams come true.\u201d\n\nBut as the preview soon reminds us, Westworld is in the grips of a revolution. Inside its lab, fistfights abound, mechanical bulls turn on their masters and a mysterious, white humanoid figure looms menacingly behind Bernard (Jeffrey Wright). \u201cWe\u2019ve lived by your rules long enough,\u201d says Dolores (Evan Rachel Wood), the park\u2019s rogue robot-girl next door. \u201cWe can save this world. We can burn it down and, from the ashes, build a new one. Our world.\u201d\n\nAt the center of the mayhem is Thandie Newton\u2019s Maeve, a host who became self-aware last season and seems poised to become a messianic figure. Perhaps most intriguing, the music in the trailer is a piano cover of \u201cRunaway,\u201d Kanye West\u2019s self-deprecating ode to tortured genius.\n\n\u2018Westworld\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: HBO\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nSeason 2 of \u201cWestworld\u201d will premiere on Sunday, April 22, at 9 p.m. on HBO.\n\nHBO\n\n0", "title": "Watch the First Trailer for \u2018Westworld\u2019 Season 2", "authors": ["Judy Berman"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "A unique kind of stage-prop dialysis is used to keep the blood hygienic. Following each performance, the tanks of blood are trucked back to J&M, which filters out any newly added particles of foam and dust. The blood is then purified with ultraviolet light to kill bacteria.\n\n\u201cWe can\u2019t use chlorine or anything like that because it would turn the water pink,\u201d said David Feheley, the Met\u2019s technical director. \u201cWhich is, you know, less dramatic.\u201d", "title": "Watch the Met Opera Stage a Sea of Blood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Part of Miami\u2019s shopping appeal is lower prices, without the import tariffs and luxury taxes that Latin Americans would have to pay at home. A Rolex Submariner, for example, costs about 30 percent less in Miami than it would in Brazil, according to Elton Morimitsu, a research analyst who focuses on Brazil\u2019s luxury market for Euromonitor.\n\nIn addition, industry experts say, Miami offers a broader selection of brands and watches than would be found in the typical Latin American city. In the Miami Design District, a large complex of upscale designer boutiques that\u2019s been developed over the last few years (and where Watches & Wonders will be held), Herm\u00e8s has a 13,500-square-foot triplex space and Louis Vuitton\u2019s store sprawls over four floors.\n\n\u201cWe chose Miami because it is a hub between North America and South America,\u201d said Fabienne Lupo, chairwoman and managing director of the Fondation de la Haute Horlogerie, the industry organization that oversees Watches & Wonders and the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie, held last month in Geneva. \u201cNothing had been done in Miami in terms of a fine watchmaking event, and we really wanted to put it on the map.\u201d\n\nDuring the event, the 15 participating brands that have stores in the district \u2014 including Piaget, IWC Schaffhausen and Hublot as well as Herm\u00e8s and Louis Vuitton \u2014 will have in-store displays of new watches and special demonstrators like the Argentine bootmaker at Jaeger-LeCoultre and the master watchmakers at Van Cleef & Arpels. Six other brands, including Romain Jerome and Armin Strom, will open temporary stores; and lectures, workshops and an exhibition will be held in a building in the district.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor several luxury watch brands, Mexico has become a particular focus: Sales there were up 12 percent last year, and 9.2 percent in 2016, according to Euromonitor International. And some brands are outpacing that growth; Parmigiani Fleurier\u2019s Mexico sales increased by 30 percent in 2017. Mexican luxury watch sales from all brands amounted to nearly $500 million last year, more than half of those in Latin America overall.\n\n\u201cIn the region, the market that is really pulling the business is Mexico,\u201d said Michel Cheval, IWC\u2019s regional brand director for Latin America and the Caribbean. \u201cThere are lots of opportunities. Mexico is really the country where now the industry is focusing.\u201d His brand, for example, expanded its footprint in Mexico City a couple of years ago beyond the local retailers Berger Joyeros and Peyrelongue Chronos to include in-store shops in two locations of El Palacio De Hierro, an upscale department store chain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Hublot plans to open three boutiques in Mexico this year, including one next month in the new Artz Pedregal development in Mexico City.\n\n\u201cMexico, for sure, is the star,\u201d said Antonio Seward, chief executive of Audemars Piguet North America and a former managing director of Latin America for the company. \u201cIt has always been, even before the current global efforts of the luxury brands in Mexico. Even in the 1990s, it was very strong. In terms of maturity, in terms of customer base, it is by far No. 1.\u201d\n\nAudemars Piguet has found that, in Mexico, pink gold outsells stainless steel, and that the best-selling sizes of its classic Royal Oak model are on the larger side, with diameters of 41 to 44 millimeters. So it is introducing a 100-piece limited edition pink gold Royal Oak at 41 millimeters that was designed with the Mexican market in mind and will be displayed at Watches & Wonders.\n\nPhoto\n\nSuch limited editions, and the message of exclusivity they convey, tend to resonate in Latin America.\n\nWatch fans there \u201care very interested in something that is unique, with craft,\u201d said Hamdi Chatti, vice president of watches and jewelry at LVMH Mo\u00ebt Hennessy Louis Vuitton. \u201cThey like something distinctive.\u201d Louis Vuitton, for example, monogrammed a watch movement for one client in the region, and recently created customized watches based on its Tambour style so a group of Brazilian collectors could select the metals and the bezel gemstones for their timepieces.\n\nMany styles that will be shown at the fair are particularly well-suited to the Latin American market, which leans toward large-faced watches, often with a decidedly sporty feel (although many Chileans, industry experts said, are the exceptions \u2014 preferring traditional looks). So Panerai, known for its large watches, will showcase its L\u2019Astronomo Luminor 1950 Tourbillon Moonphase GMT, which is 50 millimeters in diameter, and the Luminor Due 3 Days Automatic Acciaio, which comes in three sizes, including a 45-millimeter version.\n\nFor Latin American watch fans, there is one practical aspect to buying and wearing luxury watches in locations like Miami rather than at home: less fear of theft.\n\nIn the region, \u201cyou don\u2019t see a lot of expensive watches on people\u2019s wrists in the street \u2014 it\u2019s potentially dangerous,\u201d Mr. Cheval of IWC said. \u201cPeople buy them to collect, and to wear at private events, private parties, dinners at home and also when they travel.\u201d\n\nAll of which makes Miami that much more appealing to hungry shoppers.\n\n\u201cJust that notion that you don\u2019t have to worry as much is very comforting for the Latin American and Mexican customers when they go to Miami,\u201d Mr. Seward of Audemars Piguet said. \u201cThat is a luxury in itself: to be able to enjoy them, to not just have them in your safe but be able to wear them and not just wear them at home, but be able to have lunch in a restaurant.\u201d", "title": "Watches & Wonders, Now in Miami, Hopes to Lure Latin American Buyers", "authors": ["Rachel Felder"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Stephen Richardson was taking care of his friend\u2019s dog, an 18-month-old pit bull named Onyx, at his apartment in the Bronx, prosecutors said.\n\nOn Dec. 29, according to prosecutors, Onyx and Mr. Richardson were playing in the park. Onyx bit Mr. Richardson, so Mr. Richardson stabbed him, they said.\n\nThen, they said, he stabbed him at least 50 more times, mostly in the face and neck, and also slit his throat.\n\nMr. Richardson, 33, was indicted on a felony animal-cruelty charge, prosecutors said Friday. If convicted, he faces up to two years in prison.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is an incredibly vicious crime,\u201d the Bronx district attorney, Darcel Clark, said in a statement. \u201cCruelty against animals will not be tolerated.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to the district attorney, Onyx\u2019s owner stopped by Mr. Richardson\u2019s apartment on Fulton Avenue in the Claremont Village neighborhood on the day of the killing to check up on Onyx as she often did, and found the 54-pound dog dead in the bathtub.", "title": "Watching Friend\u2019s Dog, He Stabbed It 55 Times, Police Say", "authors": ["Andy Newman"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Atop a 20 foot ladder inside a New York City subway tunnel on a recent weeknight, a worker plunged a drill with a bit as long as a sword deep into a wet wall. Pulverized stone showered onto the third rail below, before the worker plugged the fresh hole with a length of rubber hose. At his signal, workers on the ground squirted gallons of grout through the hose and deep into the wall, until it hit unseen water and the grout burbled out like ectoplasm and slid down toward the track.\n\nOne leak plugged. Untold thousands to go.\n\nMany of the now familiar tribulations of the city\u2019s subway system are self-inflicted: Chronic delays and overcrowding are rooted in a history of mismanagement by officials and elected leaders who have long neglected repairs and updates to a century-old system, where aging cars run on worn-out tracks and are controlled by antiquated signals. Last year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said over $800 million would be invested in a subway emergency plan to turn around the beleaguered system.\n\nWhile a significant portion of that plan is focused on the subway\u2019s brittle infrastructure, money is also being used to help the system fight a force not entirely under its control: water, 13 million gallons of which is pumped out on a regular dry day, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which oversees the subway system.", "title": "Water, Water Everywhere in New York Subway. And With it, Problems", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Decline of Anti-Trumpism\u201d (column, Jan. 9):\n\nWhile I agree with David Brooks that it is not helpful for the anti-Trump movement to become consumed with some of the same misguided standards of many of the president\u2019s apologists, I think that it is important to consider why Republicans are choosing to simply look the other way, or worse, lavish him with the acclaim that he so clearly relishes.\n\nOne of the most lasting memories of those old enough to have lived through Watergate is of patriots like Howard Baker and John Dean who risked their political careers by speaking publicly about unacceptable threats to our democracy by President Richard M. Nixon.\n\nThey chose allegiance to the Constitution and the country over obsequious actions like those of Senator Lindsey Graham and Speaker Paul D. Ryan.\n\nMr. Brooks would do better by focusing on what powerful leaders can do to stand up for and help preserve our democracy rather than lamenting the excesses of those who have adopted the same \u201clowbrowism\u201d that is found both in Trump supporters and opponents.", "title": "Opinion | Watergate Redux?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "KABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 The Taliban staged three attacks in southern Afghanistan on Saturday, killing at least 20 Afghan soldiers as a high-level NATO delegation was visiting the country to discuss the peace process.\n\nThe insurgents have been striking checkpoints and small outposts at night in the turbulent southern provinces of Farah and Helmand.\n\nIn one attack, the insurgents detonated explosives packed into an American-made Humvee that had been captured from the Afghan Army. And in another, they made off with a Humvee, replenishing their supply.\n\nIn the most lethal strike, insurgents overran a checkpoint in Farah Province around 3 a.m. Saturday. An Afghan Army spokesman said that 18 government soldiers were killed and two others wounded, and that a firefight with the attackers had continued even after reinforcements arrived.", "title": "Wave of Taliban Attacks Kills at Least 20 Afghan Soldiers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "The legal drama has gripped Silicon Valley since Waymo filed its lawsuit nearly a year ago. Waymo is considered a leader in autonomous vehicles, and was pouring resources into research and development long before other companies.\n\nBut in the last few years, competitors have been hiring former Google engineers for their own self-driving-car projects. Among them, Uber is considered formidable because it has billions to spend and can test the technology using its vast ride-sharing network.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn an indication of how closely this case is being followed, a line to get into the courtroom at the federal courthouse in San Francisco started forming an hour before the trial was scheduled to begin at 7:30 a.m.\n\nThe witness list includes technology billionaires like Travis Kalanick, Uber\u2019s former chief executive, and Larry Page, chief executive of Alphabet. The judge, William Alsup, even said he had been informed that someone was impersonating him on Twitter.\n\nWaymo argues that Uber has misappropriated eight trade secrets pertaining mainly to lidar \u2014 an abbreviation for \u201clight detecting and ranging\u201d \u2014 sensors that help the cars navigate on their own. The company is asking for an injunction preventing Uber from developing an autonomous vehicle using its lidar technology. In addition, it wants financial compensation for Uber\u2019s use of the technology.\n\nWaymo\u2019s lawyers repeatedly drew a comparison to Ms. Ruiz, one of the most brazen cheaters in sports history. Charles K. Verhoeven, Waymo\u2019s lawyer, said Uber, like the disgraced marathoner, wanted to win no matter what and realized that it couldn\u2019t win playing by the rules.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re bringing this case because Uber is cheating,\u201d said Mr. Verhoeven, who is a partner at the law firm Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan. \u201cThey took our technology to win at all costs.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe highlighted internal communications from Uber executives talking about how winning was an imperative and saying that the company needed to find \u201ccheat codes.\u201d The internal messages also noted that the lidar technology being developed by Mr. Levandowski was essential for Uber\u2019s success in self-driving cars and that there was no substitute.\n\nIn their opening statements, Uber\u2019s lawyers countered that the company had developed its technology on its own and that any similarities were due to the information\u2019s being generally known or easy to figure out for Uber\u2019s engineers. And there is no evidence that any of Google\u2019s technology made its way to Uber, they said.\n\nSo why, then, has Waymo dragged Uber into court? To kill a competitive threat, said Bill Carmody, Uber\u2019s lawyer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThat was quite a story, but I\u2019m going to tell you right upfront: It didn\u2019t happen. Period. End of story,\u201d said Mr. Carmody, who is a partner at the law firm Susman Godfrey. \u201cLike most conspiracy theories, it doesn\u2019t make sense when you hear the whole story.\u201d\n\nIn Mr. Carmody\u2019s version of events, when Uber hired a team of self-driving engineers in 2015 from Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Google\u2019s management became concerned that it would become a footnote in the history of self-driving cars.\n\nTo emphasize that the files downloaded by Mr. Levandowski before leaving Google were never found at Uber, Mr. Carmody reverted to the Ms. Ruiz comparison: Waymo was actually a race official who looked for evidence of cheating but couldn\u2019t find any.\n\nIn a day of sports metaphors, Uber countered with a Bay Area favorite. Mr. Carmody said the hiring of Mr. Levandowski, a pioneer in the field of self-driving vehicles, wasn\u2019t an act of desperation. Instead, it was the act of a strong team trying to land the best available talent \u2014 the way the Golden State Warriors signed the basketball star Kevin Durant in 2016 to an already championship-caliber lineup.\n\nAt the same time, Uber also distanced itself from Mr. Levandowski, who is expected to exercise his Fifth Amendment right to avoid self-incrimination when he is called to testify. Mr. Carmody said Uber regretted hiring him and noted that it had fired him in May \u2014 almost two months after Mr. Levandowski had refused to cooperate with Uber\u2019s case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJohn Krafcik, Waymo\u2019s chief executive and the first witness called by the company, said he and Mr. Levandowski had had disagreements about the direction of Google\u2019s self-driving-car project. He said Mr. Levandowski had wanted faster progress even if it came at the expense of safety features.\n\nBefore his departure from Google, Mr. Levandowski sent an email in January 2016 to Mr. Page, Alphabet\u2019s chief executive, saying the self-driving-car project was \u201cbroken.\u201d He argued for permission to create a rogue team to compete against their co-workers, because the company was moving too slowly.\n\n\u201cHe went from someone I called a friend to someone I considered an enemy,\u201d Mr. Krafcik said.", "title": "Waymo v. Uber Trial Opens With a Battle of Sports Metaphors", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Wayne LaPierre is rarely accused of progressivism. But when Mr. LaPierre, the leader of the National Rifle Association, addressed the Conservative Political Action Conference last week, he invoked the Second Amendment in much the same way that a significant portion of the left has long spoken of the rights it values. According to this conception, rights are zones of personal autonomy where the individual owes no explanation and the community has no jurisdiction. This manner of thinking about rights is a serious barrier to reasonable regulations of firearms. The N.R.A. ritually claims the mantle of the Constitution, but the American founders who framed it had a far richer view in which individual rights were subject to considerations of the common good.\n\nThere may be good reasons not to regulate firearms further, but the individual\u2019s absolute claim that his or her guns are nobody\u2019s business is not one of them. To even make this assertion is an illustration of what the legal scholar and diplomat Mary Ann Glendon calls \u201cthe illusion of absoluteness,\u201d an idea that is hostile to the possibility of political community. All rights have limits. The question is who determines them. For the framers of the Constitution, the answer was that the people do.\n\nOne of the earliest American assertions of rights, the 1641 Massachusetts Body of Liberties, delineated rights against everything from banishment to dismemberment but subjected them to regulation by the legislature. The community could take these actions only according to rules known in advance and equally applicable to all. The essence of rights in this early understanding was the rule of law \u2014 as propounded by the community \u2014 not the isolation of the individual.\n\nThe Declaration of Independence, whose \u201cunalienable rights\u201d individualists are so quick to claim for themselves, dealt with rights similarly. In legal parlance, to \u201calienate\u201d something is to exchange it for an equivalent \u2014 precisely what individuals do with their rights when they form a political community. The Declaration\u2019s rights are coherently \u201cunalienable\u201d only if they are possessed by what the document calls \u201cone people.\u201d This interpretation is backed by the fact that many of the complaints against King George that the document proceeds to enumerate are not that he did something absolutely forbidden but rather that he did so without the legislature\u2019s consent.", "title": "Opinion | Wayne LaPierre\u2019s Unconstitutionalism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you look at where the money is really held, it\u2019s among the top 10 percent,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd if you break it down by age, race and education and parental education, you\u2019ll see the disparities are even larger.\u201d Parents who lack a four-year degree and, later on, their children are much less likely to have a direct stake in the stock market than college graduates; blacks and Hispanics are much less likely than whites.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s too bad such a small percentage of the population has any real or meaningful ownership stake in equities, given their historic and current growth,\u201d Mr. Boshara said.\n\nMost households had less than $5,000 in total holdings in 2016, the most recent year analyzed by Mr. Wolff. Despite the slow recovery in housing prices, the wealth of middle-class Americans is still concentrated in their homes, which remain their single most valuable asset.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor 9 out of 10 households, even a shift in value of 10 percent \u2014 enough to qualify as a \u201cmarket correction\u201d \u2014 would \u201cat most, have a 1 or 2 percent impact on their wealth holdings,\u201d Mr. Wolff said.\n\nIf anything, foreign multinational and other investors would feel more of a pinch, since they own 35 percent of all United States corporate stock, up from 10 percent in 1982. That share of the pie exceeds the single slice owned by taxable American shareholders, defined benefit plans, defined contribution plans, or nonprofit institutions, said Steven M. Rosenthal, a senior fellow at the nonpartisan Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDon\u2019t confuse the Dow with the economy.\n\nThe stock market and the underlying economy are distinct. The two interact, but they do not proceed in lock step or even respond to each other in predictable ways. Certainly, market instability can undermine both consumer and business confidence and restrain spending and investment. And market bubbles, swelled by overextended borrowing, can explode, wreaking losses and stalling growth.\n\nStill, valuations of assets and the country\u2019s economic health \u2014 as determined by productivity, employment, investment, spending, housing values, production capacity, growth and more \u2014 are two different kettles.\n\n\u201cIf all that happens is the stock market decreases or increases in value, but no real fundamentals change,\u201d C. Eugene Steuerle, an economist at the Urban Institute who served in the Reagan administration, said, \u201cthen there are actually a lot of winners, not just losers.\u201d\n\n\u201cOlder people can buy less stock,\u201d and fewer goods and services, because they are living off their investments rather than accumulating them, Mr. Steuerle said. But younger people can better afford to buy stock while it is cheap, which sets them up for bigger gains down the road.\n\n\u201cAttention, discount shoppers,\u201d Michelle Singletary, a personal financial columnist for The Washington Post, advised on Thursday. \u201cThe recent stock market dive is like a holiday weekend sale.\u201d\n\nThe economy still seems solid.\n\nWhen it comes to evaluating the economy\u2019s fundamentals, assessments come in a Revlon rack of shades. Economists warn that mounting debt, as a result of the costly $1.5 trillion tax package, threatens economic stability over the longer run, as private investment is crowded out and interest payments balloon. Productivity growth is anemic and labor participation rates are low by historical standards.\n\nStill, the signs of strength \u2014 at least for the next couple of years \u2014 are impressive.\n\nUnemployment is near record lows, total output is rising at a faster rate, bond yields are up, oil prices have increased, and consumer and business confidence remain high. Every major economy around the world is growing in concert, simultaneously propelling and reinforcing a positive cycle.\n\nAfter all, one of those indicators \u2014 a January jobs report that showed healthy payroll expansion and a jump in yearly wage growth \u2014 is what helped set off the stock market tumult last Friday.", "title": "We All Have a Stake in the Stock Market, Right? Guess Again", "authors": ["Patricia Cohen"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Legally, this should be an easy win for the unions. The Supreme Court upheld fair-share fees four decades ago in a unanimous ruling it has reaffirmed repeatedly, and on which more than 20 states have relied in negotiating thousands of contracts covering millions of public employees, including firefighters, teachers and police officers. The logic is simple: When the government is an employer, it has more control over its employees\u2019 speech than over that of regular citizens. Any burden the fees impose on employees\u2019 First Amendment rights is justified by the need to eliminate free riders \u2014 workers who enjoy union benefits without having to pay for them, which can deplete the unions\u2019 resources in states where they are legally required to represent all workers, members and nonmembers alike. Anti-union advocates dismiss the free-rider concern, but it\u2019s very real: In states that have ended the fees, more than one-third of public-school teachers are free riders.\n\nNone of this seems to register with Justice Samuel Alito Jr., who has made no secret of his dislike for that 1977 opinion, Abood v. Detroit Board of Education, and has been searching for the votes to overturn it for at least six years, writing opinions intended to set up its demise. Justice Alito probably assumed he had victory in hand in 2016, when the court considered the same question in a case brought by California public-school teachers against their union. But when Justice Scalia, whose remarks during oral arguments strongly suggested he would provide the fifth vote against the union, died a few weeks later, the case deadlocked.\n\nAs it turned out, Justice Scalia\u2019s death only briefly slowed the march of corporate interests that have sought for years to protect their huge profits and kill off the last remnants of organized labor in America. They and the right-wing groups that support them quickly regrouped around another plaintiff, a child-support specialist from Illinois named Mark Janus, who makes the same argument the California teachers did: Activities by public-sector unions are inherently political, so it\u2019s impossible to separate the costs of collective bargaining from those of political lobbying. No matter what benefits the unions negotiate on his behalf, he shouldn\u2019t have to pay a dime. Mr. Janus lost decisively in the lower federal courts for the same reason the teachers did: the Supreme Court\u2019s precedent in the Abood case.\n\nThat precedent should guide the justices here, too. Beyond the court\u2019s core principle of stare decisis, which keeps it from overturning its own prior decisions except in extraordinary circumstances, the Abood decision reasonably balanced workers\u2019 First Amendment rights against the government\u2019s interest in labor peace. Two notable conservative scholars go further, arguing in a supporting brief to the court that the First Amendment does not apply at all in this case. The government is allowed to compel subsidies of others\u2019 speech all the time without violating the Constitution, they point out, such as by collecting and spending taxes.\n\nIn Monday\u2019s arguments, several of the conservative justices seemed immune to such reasoning. Justice Alito referred to fair-share fees as \u201ccompelled speech\u201d that infringes on a worker\u2019s \u201cdignity and conscience.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | We All Must Live With Mitch McConnell\u2019s Proudest Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nThe Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.\n\nCalling all young writers: The New York Times wants your help. The Edit, a newsletter created specifically for college students and recent graduates, is looking for five contributors.\n\nThe Times has already received thousands of submissions, but it\u2019s not too late to apply. NBC has responded by learning to make money from viewers who stream its programs \u2014 and now it is learning how to put a number on it. The key is gathering statistics from services like NBC.com, the NBC app, video on demand and Hulu to determine how much money its shows are pulling in from streamers.\n\nTake \u201cThis Is Us.\u201d According to the network\u2019s data crunchers, NBC has earned around 47 percent of the revenue generated by its 2016 pilot episode from advertising through digital views. Over all, 44 percent of the revenue NBC has earned from \u201cThis Is Us\u201d has come through digital viewership.\n\nSimilarly, the critically acclaimed sitcom, \u201cThe Good Place,\u201d starring Kristen Bell and Ted Danson, has earned roughly 36 percent of its revenue from digital advertising, NBC said.\n\nThe new source of revenue is NBC\u2019s attempt to make up for a larger decline in advertising dollars. Television ad sales fell 8 percent in 2017, one of the biggest drops in years, Bloomberg reported. That\u2019s why executives like Mr. Greenblatt need to make the digital business work sooner rather than later.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not insignificant now,\u201d he said, \u201cand I think over time it grows into becoming really significant.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNot every show is making big money from digital views. About three-quarters of the revenue NBC made from the 2015 pilot of \u201cBlindspot,\u201d for instance, has been earned the old fashioned way.\n\nBut NBC was less savvy back then in extracting money from viewers who preferred streaming. By the time of the first \u201cThis Is Us\u201d season, NBC had wised up, striking a deal that allowed it to earn money from Hulu ads shown during episodes of the hit tear-jerker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGenerating revenue from streaming is relatively new for the networks, said Jeff Bader, NBC\u2019s president of program planning, strategy and research.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhen I came to NBC five years ago, we were in this place with: How are we going to manage this business that\u2019s been in decline?\u201d he said. \u201cWe were doing everything we could not to be the record industry and have our stuff pirated and not monetized.\u201d\n\nParticularly depressing was the number of younger viewers who seemed to be changing their viewing habits.\n\n\u201cFor years, we were seeing our average age go up, up up,\u201d Mr. Bader said. \u201cYounger viewers were drifting. \u201d\n\nOnce the network examined the data, however, it saw that younger viewers hadn\u2019t abandoned NBC. They were just watching shows on their own schedules.\n\nNBC has intensified its efforts to measure the nontraditional audience with the Winter Olympics. Its latest ratings reports have combined the number of viewers it reaches through broadcast, cable and streaming platforms under a single figure it calls total audience delivery. This is the network\u2019s attempt to counter the Nielsen measure, which shows a shrinking Olympics audience.\n\nNBC understands the reason for the advertising community\u2019s skepticism concerning the number of people who watch shows via streaming, however.\n\n\u201cThat is the frustrating part of the whole ecosystem,\u201d Mr. Greenblatt said, \u201cbecause we don\u2019t have a third-party objective measuring system that everyone has adopted that we all buy into.\u201d\n\nUntil that third-party system emerges, Mr. Greenblatt said that his sales department has gone all-in on selling advertisers on a statistical portrait that is prettier than the one painted by Nielsen.\n\n\u201cThis started for me purely on looking at viewership numbers, because I wanted to be able to make the argument, \u2018People aren\u2019t just bailing on network TV,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cThen it occurred to us, it\u2019s not just a viewership number we\u2019re defending. It\u2019s part of the business model now and it\u2019s going to be move that way more and more.\u201d", "title": "We Have Streaming Revenue, Too, Says NBC. And We Can Prove It.", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "By Heather Hope\n\nMy husband and I visited one of Sydney\u2019s nude beaches, a particularly gorgeous cove of cream-colored sand and turquoise sea, hidden behind green jungle.\n\nThe beach was patronized mostly by gay men, but lightly sprinkled with a few women.\n\nBefore removing our swimwear we took a reconnaissance walk along the shore. It was then that we noticed a small red boat hurtling toward us. It looked like the Coast Guard.\n\n\u201cUh oh,\u201d we joked, \u201cthey\u2019re coming to tell us that we have to get naked.\u201d\n\nThe skiff came to a stop right in front of us. That\u2019s when we noticed the captain, a wetsuit-wearing Kenny G look-alike.", "title": "We Have to Get Naked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cCan I borrow this?\u201d I asked my mother in September, knowing she would say yes. I was already wearing it: a smart, gray cardigan covered in tiny diamond shapes. I needed something nice to wear over the sleeveless blouse she had already given me and didn\u2019t think my hoodie would cut it for the job interview I had later that day.\n\n\u201cYou can have it,\u201d she said from her bed.\n\nI asked, \u201cAre you sure?\u201d out of politeness, but I knew she was. She wasn\u2019t going to wear the cardigan that day or any day. Chances were she wasn\u2019t going to wear anything in her closet ever again. My mother was in her usual uniform of old vegan-themed T-shirt and hole-in-the-butt sweatpants \u2014 her beloved \u201crags\u201d \u2014 just as she had been almost every day since her Stage IV cancer diagnosis 10 months earlier. It didn\u2019t need to be said, but we both knew her days of wearing smart cardigans were over.\n\nThere had been days in the past several months when she\u2019d gotten dressed to be seen by the outside world \u2014 trips to my sisters\u2019 houses to see her grandsons, a birthday lunch we had for her in April, an excursion to an art exhibition at my nephew\u2019s nursery school that featured finger paintings and creative uses of macaroni. For these, she wore her traditional nice outfit: stylish blouse, long cardigan, crisp jeans, ankle boots and colorful head scarf to cover the bald head she revealed only at home.\n\nOnce back in the privacy of her house, she\u2019d quickly change back into her rags. She liked looking nice, but the worse she got, the more comfortable she wanted to be.", "title": "Opinion | Wearing My Dying Mother\u2019s Clothes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The Weinstein Company\u2019s announcement on Sunday came two weeks after Eric T. Schneiderman, New York\u2019s attorney general, filed a lawsuit against the studio and its fraternal founders alleging that they repeatedly violated state and city laws barring gender discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual abuse and coercion.\n\nImage Maria Contreras-Sweet led an investor group negotiating to buy the Weinstein Company. Credit Earl Wilson/The New York Times\n\nThe lawsuit, based on a continuing investigation into the Weinstein Company\u2019s internal dealings, was accompanied by a public call from Mr. Schneiderman for assurance that a sale to Ms. Contreras-Sweet\u2019s group had three components: adequate compensation for victims, protections for the studio\u2019s remaining employees and no financial reward for those \u201cwho enabled or perpetuated Mr. Weinstein\u2019s misconduct.\u201d\n\nThat brought the sale talks to a sudden halt.\n\nIn the wake of the lawsuit and Mr. Schneiderman\u2019s public statements, the Weinstein Company fired its president, David Glasser, for cause. The lawsuit did not name Mr. Glasser, but it referred to him by his title and said that the sale of the company could result in employees\u2019 reporting to some of the same managers \u201cwho failed to investigate\u201d Mr. Weinstein\u2019s conduct or protect female employees from him. In a statement, a lawyer for Mr. Glasser, Eve Wagner, said that Mr. Glasser planned to sue for wrongful termination.\n\nOn Wednesday, Ms. Contreras-Sweet and Mr. Burkle met with Mr. Schneiderman in New York and made progress toward persuading him that their purchase would satisfy his three stated priorities, according to two people briefed on the matter who asked for anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly.\n\nIn particular, the sale was to include tens of millions of dollars for victims and a mediation process for reaching settlements. The Weinstein brothers, who jointly own about 42 percent of the studio, would have received no cash from the proposed sale, with other equity holders also wiped out.\n\nEric Soufer, the director of communications for Mr. Schneiderman, said in a statement on Monday that the attorney general\u2019s office had \u201cproductive discussions with both parties\u201d during the past two weeks about how to accomplish his priorities.\n\n\u201cWe are disappointed that despite a clear path forward on those issues \u2014 including the buyer\u2019s commitment to dedicate up to $90 million to victim compensation and implement gold-plated H.R. policies \u2014 the parties were unable to resolve their financial differences,\u201d Mr. Soufer said. \u201cWe will continue to pursue justice for victims in the event of the company\u2019s bankruptcy, and our investigation into the pattern of egregious abuse by Harvey Weinstein and his enablers is ongoing.\u201d\n\nMs. Contreras-Sweet\u2019s group had pulled ahead of other bidders like Lionsgate by promising to keep the studio intact and the staff employed. Will File for Bankruptcy After Deal Talks Collapse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "The Weinstein Company\u2019s board of directors announced Friday night that they had unanimously voted to fire the company\u2019s president and chief operating officer, David Glasser, for cause.\n\nThe one-sentence statement did not specify what the cause was. Still, the move represents yet another twist in an ongoing saga that has engulfed the embattled company.\n\nIt comes at an urgent moment for the company, which has been trying to avoid bankruptcy since October, when reports by The New York Times and The New Yorker revealed decades of sexual harassment allegations against one of its founders, Harvey Weinstein.\n\nThe company had been nearing a deal to sell itself to an investor group, but it hit a last-minute snag this week when Eric T. Schneiderman, New York\u2019s attorney general, filed a lawsuit against the studio and its fraternal founders alleging that they repeatedly violated state and city laws barring gender discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual abuse and coercion.\n\nThe lawsuit, filed electronically in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, appeared timed to at least delay a sale, which had been expected to be finalized on Sunday. If financiers get spooked, Mr. Schneiderman\u2019s move could ultimately kill the proposed deal, putting the Weinstein Company on an almost certain path to bankruptcy.\n\n\u201cAny sale of the Weinstein Company must ensure that victims will be compensated, employees will be protected going forward, and that neither perpetrators nor enablers will be unjustly enriched,\u201d Mr. Schneiderman said in a news release.\n\nThe Weinstein Company has been trying to avoid bankruptcy since October, when reports by The New York Times and The New Yorker revealed decades of sexual harassment allegations against one of its founders, Harvey Weinstein. The company was nearing a deal to sell itself to an investor group for roughly $275 million, plus the assumption of $225 million in debt, according to two people briefed on the deal who spoke on condition of anonymity because the negotiations are private.", "title": "Weinstein Company Sale Delayed by N.Y. Attorney General Lawsuit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEverything she was doing was musically mainstream but at the same time idiosyncratic,\u201d he said. \u201cHer music has kind of a luminous quality that strikes me as her own. Our understanding of American modernism of the 1930s and 1940s is not complete without Price\u2019s contribution.\u201d\n\nWriting to a conductor in the \u201940s, Price described \u201can accumulation of hundreds of unpublished and unsubmitted manuscripts.\u201d She continued to compose up to her death; absent her tenacity and advocacy for her own music, her legacy was incompletely preserved and has had to be reconstructed piece by piece. But she was also meticulous, and the manuscripts that were discovered nine years ago, now in the University of Arkansas library with many of her other papers, are mostly complete and easily performed.\n\nThe question is, who will perform them. Even by late last year, when challenged by a group of local musicians to diversify their programming, the Boston Symphony replied that, while it was working on the problem, audiences still wanted to hear \u201cspecifically the universal masterworks composed between 1600 and the mid-1900s.\u201d The orchestra had programmed music by Price some months prior, but only a string quartet in a community concert, not one of the larger symphonic pieces she created as her style matured.\n\nIf American orchestras truly wish to diversify their programming \u2014 the Chicago Symphony and Philadelphia Orchestra, to name just two important examples, recently announced seasons without music by a single female composer, living or dead \u2014 Price is one of the many artists who deserves greater exposure. The Fort Smith Symphony in Arkansas is beginning a project to record her four symphonies for the Naxos label, based on editions prepared by the composer James Greeson, and in May will perform her First Symphony and (in a world premiere) the Fourth, another of the works unearthed in her summer house.\n\n\u201cWhile Price was quite proud of her accomplishments, she always felt like there was a limitation on the reception of her music, because of her race and because of her gender,\u201d Mr. Carter said. When she tried to find a publisher for her song \u201cSympathy,\u201d set to a Dunbar poem that later inspired Maya Angelou, one told her it was just a little bit too chromatic.\n\nMr. Carter speculates that Price identified with the caged bird in the poem. But, as we hear the soprano move into her upper register on the line \u201cBut a plea, that upward to Heaven he flings/I know why the caged bird sings,\u201d we can also hear the full flowering Price has always deserved.", "title": "Welcoming a Black Female Composer Into the Canon. Finally.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "In addition to benefiting investors, these maneuvers will end up boosting the pay of top executives because their compensation packages are often tied to the price of their companies\u2019 stock. Finally, a small sliver of the money will find its way into paychecks of rank-and-file employees, but it won\u2019t be a big boost and will probably come in the form of a temporary bonus, rather than a lasting raise.\n\nMorgan Stanley analysts estimated that 43 percent of corporate tax savings would go to buybacks and dividends and nearly 19 percent would help pay for mergers and acquisitions. Just 17 percent would be used for capital investment, and even a smaller share, 13 percent, would go toward bonuses and raises. Other Wall Street analysts have issued similar reports. If more evidence was needed, Axios reported that just nine pharmaceutical companies have announced $50 billion in buybacks since the tax law was passed.\n\nMr. Trump might argue that it doesn\u2019t much matter that the tax cuts will be a boon for investors because many Americans own stocks. The president has recently touted the rising value of 401(k) accounts as a benefit of the tax law. But roughly half of all families own no stock, and most people have holdings that are worth less than $5,000. Most stock holdings, a whopping 84 percent, are in the hands of people whose incomes put them in the top 10 percent of households.\n\nRepublicans might further argue that none of this matters because the tax law is becoming more popular as people learn more about it. Indeed, a recent poll for The Times found that the law now has more supporters than opponents. But this swing in public sentiment might be less important than it appears. Consider the results of a recent Politico/Morning Consult poll that shows that just 25 percent of registered voters said they had noticed an increase in their paycheck because of lower tax withholding while 51 percent had not. The poll also found that high-income people were more likely to notice that their take-home pay had gone up. That\u2019s because Republicans designed the law to principally benefit wealthy families while offering crumbs to low-income and middle class families.\n\nThose crumbs, by the way, disappear after a few years. Further, many taxpayers in states like California, New Jersey and New York will be hit with higher tax bills when they file their 2018 tax returns and realize that they can now only deduct up to $10,000 in state and local taxes.\n\nThere was a legitimate argument for reforming the tax code in a way that reduced the corporate tax rate, closed loopholes and made the economy fairer and more productive. But Republicans chose a plan that rewards the rich at the expense of workers. They had to lie to make this scheme seem legitimate. Now the true effects are coming to fruition.", "title": "Opinion | Well-Heeled Investors Reap the Republican Tax Cut Bonanza", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "It would be my first time on a bus. I was terrified.\n\nThat\u2019s when my dad sat me down for The Talk. When my brother Stacey, part of the Ruby Bridges generation, went to a desegregated school in seventh grade, my dad gave him The Talk. When my brother Ron was sent to an all-white Catholic school, he got The Talk. Now it was my turn for this milestone.\n\nMy mom was in the kitchen cooking dinner, the sound of the New Orleans holy trinity of onions, peppers and celery sizzling in a hot pan. Dad settled into The Chair.\n\n\u201cCome here, son,\u201d he said.\n\nI went, ready for him to impart his wisdom like an oracle.\n\nInstead, he said, \u201cThey are going to come at you in a group. You are going to get your ass kicked. But whatever you do, grab the biggest one or the leader \u2014 it\u2019s usually the same person \u2014 and you kick his ass.\u201d\n\nMy eyes went wide. I saw what they did to those kids in Boston on TV. Birmingham was still fresh in everyone\u2019s imagination. Not only did my dad tell me to fight, but I was supposed to fight the biggest one? The leader?\n\nNow, my father wasn\u2019t a violent man. But he did fight in Saipan in World War II, so he understood how to defend himself.", "title": "Wendell Pierce: The First Time My Dad Gave Me \u2018The Talk\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Whitfield told those stories with a clear, strong voice that could be languid or sprightly, playful or demure. Among those who praised her singing was Tony Bennett, who called her a \u201cwonderful singer\u201d who \u201cthrills me when I hear her,\u201d The Los Angeles Times reported in 1996.\n\nA 1994 review in Newsday by Gene Seymour compared her to the celebrated swing-era vocalist Lee Wiley: \u201cHer tone has a bracing, enveloping clarity reminiscent of Lee Wiley, who, like Whitfield, could make a song bend or jump in mid-verse without losing control of her timbre.\u201d\n\nMs. Whitfield\u2019s career took hold at West Coast clubs like the Cinegrill in Los Angeles and the Rrazz Room and the Empire Plush Room in San Francisco. In New York, she became a regular performer at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.\n\nBut before that career had really begun, Ms. Whitfield, on a San Francisco street in 1977, had to surmount the kind of life-changing obstacle that few singers ever face.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cTwo little boys came up to me and spoke, \u2018You better come with us,\u2019 \u201d Ms. Whitfield told The Associated Press in 1999. \u201cI turned away, but I saw one little boy open his jacket.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe boy drew a gun and shot her. The bullet struck her spine, leaving her paralyzed from the waist down. But after a period of depression she returned to singing.\n\nMs. Whitfield rarely discussed the shooting or her partial paralysis. Although she used a wheelchair, for many years she performed seated on a chair or stool, usually after being carried onstage by Mr. Greensill; she did not want to distract the audience from her voice, she explained.\n\n\u201cIt has almost nothing to do with my life, and certainly, definitely, nothing to do with my music,\u201d she said in an interview on NPR\u2019s \u201cWeekend Edition\u201d in 1993.\n\nShe met Mr. Greensill in 1981, and he soon became her pianist and arranger. They married in 1986.\n\nMs. Whitfield\u2019s supple voice and Mr. Greensill\u2019s dashes of improvisation reinvigorated familiar songs by Cole Porter, Irving Berlin, Rodgers and Hart, and others, whose work they both considered timeless.\n\n\u201cWe think of the songs we perform as classic, yes,\u201d Ms. Whitfield told The New York Times in 1996. \u201cBut in the same way Schubert\u2019s songs are classic. They\u2019re not nostalgic, even though they\u2019re old. They speak to the human condition today.\u201d\n\nIn their interpretations of songs like \u201cA Kiss to Build a Dream On\u201d and \u201cWhen You Wish Upon a Star,\u201d their different musical backgrounds combined to create a sound that set them apart from similar lounge and cabaret acts.\n\n\u201cAlthough Ms. Whitfield and Mr. Greensill are not the only married cabaret performers who work together, no cabaret couple in recent memory has expressed their devotion through such intense but subtle musical communication,\u201d Stephen Holden wrote in The Times on the occasion of a four-week engagement at the Oak Room in 1993.\n\nThey released \u201cUntil the Real Thing Comes Along\u201d (1987) and other albums on their own label, Myoho Records, before the Grammy-winning producer Orrin Keepnews signed them to his label, Landmark, in the early 1990s. They released some 20 more records together, usually with other musicians, on Landmark and other labels. Their last studio album was \u201cMessage From the Man in the Moon\u201d (2007); they also released a live album, \u201cThe Best Things In Life,\u201d in 2011.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the 1990s, Ms. Whitfield and Mr. Greensill performed at Carnegie Hall and at a White House luncheon for Hillary Clinton, who was then the first lady, and spouses of senators. Their last performance together was at Silo\u2019s in Napa, Calif., in June 2017.\n\nWesla Whitfield was born Weslia Marie Edwards on Sept. 15, 1947, in Santa Maria, Calif., about 60 miles northwest of Santa Barbara. She was the youngest of three daughters of Vernon Edwards, a welder who worked in oil fields, and the former Eleanor Smith, a homemaker.\n\nShe graduated from high school in Santa Maria and attended Pasadena City College before receiving a degree in music from San Francisco State University in 1971. She started singing with the San Francisco Opera that year and stayed with the company for four years, before her preference for nightclubs won out. After leaving the opera, she worked for a time as a singing cocktail waitress.\n\nHer first marriage, to Richard Whitfield, ended in divorce, as did a brief second marriage. She kept the surname Whitfield because she liked the alliteration with Wesla.\n\nThe story of Ms. Whitfield\u2019s first name is more involved. Her mother said she had been named after a friend whose name was spelled \u201cWeslia,\u201d with a silent i. Ms. Whitfield dropped the confusing i from her name after her mother\u2019s death in 1998. She later met the friend, who told her that her name had always been spelled \u201cWesla.\u201d\n\nIn addition to her husband, Ms. Whitfield is survived by a sister, Laurella Pickett.\n\nMs. Whitfield was once asked whether having to sit impeded her singing. \u201cNot at all,\u201d she replied.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always preferred sitting,\u201d she said. \u201cIt brings everything to a stop, and then we just focus on the music.\u201d", "title": "Wesla Whitfield, Singer Who Reinvigorated Standards, Dies at 70", "authors": ["Daniel E. Slotnik"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCHARLESTON, W.Va. \u2014 Public schoolteachers walked out of classrooms across the state on Thursday, protesting pay raises that they called too stingy.\n\nDespite warnings that the walkout was illegal, thousands of teachers and support staff members converged at the Capitol in Charleston, seeking to pressure lawmakers who are still considering other proposals to help them financially. It was their first statewide strike since 1990 in West Virginia, where teacher pay ranks 48th in the nation.\n\nChants of \u201cDo your job so I can do mine\u201d reverberated throughout the Capitol halls, along with other slogans including \u201c55 strong\u201d \u2014 a reference to the state\u2019s 55 counties.\n\nOn Wednesday night Gov. Jim Justice signed a 2 percent raise next year for teachers, followed by 1 percent raises the next two years. But teachers said the increases were not enough. They also criticized projected increases in health insurance costs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou have all these state employees out here who are furious,\u201d said Melanie Pinkerman, a counselor at Huntington High School as she held up a protest sign mocking the governor outside the House of Delegates chambers.", "title": "West Virginia Teachers Walk Out Over Pay", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "A two-day walkout by thousands of West Virginia public schoolteachers and employees to protest low pay will continue on Monday, organizers said on Friday afternoon.\n\nThe American Federation of Teachers-West Virginia, the West Virginia Education Association and the West Virginia School Service Personnel Association organized the statewide action, which left more than a quarter of a million students out of school on Thursday and Friday in the state\u2019s 55 counties.\n\nChristine Campbell, the president of the American Federation of Teachers-West Virginia, said the strike could last beyond Monday if necessary. Teachers across the state, she added, \u201chave made their voice clear.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey believe that not enough has been done,\u201d she said.\n\nOrganizers say teachers are so poorly paid in the state that some must take second jobs to make ends meet. In 2016, the average salary for a teacher in West Virginia was $45,622, ranking it 48th in the country, according to the National Education Association.", "title": "West Virginia Teachers, Protesting Low Pay, Walk Out", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOur teachers are saying to us: We know that we did this,\u201d said Christine Campbell of the West Virginia arm of the American Federation of Teachers.\n\nMr. Justice said the raises would be paid for by revising revenue estimates upward.\n\n\u201cMaybe I was looking at it as, what was the prudent thing to do, and not necessarily looking at education as an investment,\u201d Mr. Justice said at the news conference, which he exited partway through because he had to coach a girls\u2019 basketball game.\n\nBut powerful Republican lawmakers in the state, including the Senate president, Mitch Carmichael, immediately expressed deep reservations about that plan.\n\n\u201cThe governor says there\u2019s more money. We want to see it,\u201d Mr. Carmichael said, adding, \u201cI\u2019m skeptical the money is real.\u201d\n\nAnd it is not yet clear exactly what the state will do to stem the rising cost of insurance. That, more than salary \u2014 which lawmakers had agreed before the strike to raise by 2 percent \u2014 was the tipping point for many of the teachers who joined the walkout. Teachers say they have struggled with rising premiums and other health care costs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Public Employees Insurance Agency, which administers state employees\u2019 health plans, has said it will freeze rates in 2019, but teachers have pushed for a longer-term fix.\n\n\u201cMost people are not completely satisfied,\u201d said Erica Newsome, 32, an English teacher from Madison, W.Va., who was part of a grass-roots group of teachers who first began discussing their frustration with health care costs last fall.\n\n\u201cWe are underpaid and we do need a raise,\u201d Ms. Newsome said, \u201cbut if we aren\u2019t going to fix the insurance, it\u2019s just the same story as before.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnion leaders said Tuesday night that Mr. Justice\u2019s promises were enough to get the teachers back into classrooms, at least for now.\n\n\u201cWe needed evidence \u2014 the teachers needed evidence, the service personnel \u2014 and I think this is a commitment, this is a beginning of better things to happen,\u201d Ms. Campbell said. Pay", "authors": ["Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Members of the terrier group have won Best in Show more than members of any other group \u2014 a whopping 45 times.\n\n\u201cWinston had an idea of what he was going to do and we just followed it,\u201d said his handler, Ernesto Lara.\n\nNext up: Best in Show.\n\nOne of the finalists uses \u2018fairy frost.\u2019 It\u2019s for drool.\n\nFlynn, a 5-year-old bichon fris\u00e9 handled by Bill McFadden, will be representing the nonsporting group in tonight\u2019s big event, the result of years of training and hard work \u2014 and more than a little preshow grooming.\n\n\u201cYou bathe him and dry him and then trim him, then retrim him at the show, then trim him again when he wins,\u201d said Taffe McFadden, Bill\u2019s wife, as her husband carefully combed and clipped the pooch backstage before the show. \u201cAnd then you just keep trimming him.\u201d\n\nThe routine also involved shampoo, conditioner and lots of hair spray.\n\n\u201cYou use a little bit of everything,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s a beauty show.\u201d\n\nThe McFaddens also take time to powder Flynn\u2019s nose \u2014 literally \u2014 with a shimmering white substance kept in a small Tupperware container marked \u201cFairy Frost.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s stuff that dries the drool on their face,\u201d said Taffe McFadden, pausing to brush some on Flynn\u2019s snout (and then brush some off her husband\u2019s blazer). \u201cIt\u2019s like cornstarch.\u201d\n\nNearby, a toy poodle named Cami was coifed with painstaking precision by a canine hairdresser, one of several assistants who swarmed her as she perched on a pillow.\n\nThe spectacle of her tiny body and increasingly voluminous bouffant hairdo drew a crowd of spectators, but none of the humans preparing her for the show felt much like chatting. One woman, when asked if she was the dog\u2019s handler, replied simply, \u201cNo, I\u2019m the help,\u201d before turning back to work.\n\nOf the Moment: Sign up here for the lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use.\n\nWhere the dogs go, when nature calls.\n\nO.K., let\u2019s get real for a second: You\u2019re a dog waiting for your big moment in the ring. Maybe you\u2019ve had a lot to drink today. And you\u2019re in the concrete bowels of Madison Square Garden, far from a yard or dog park.\n\nWhat to do? The Westminster Kennel Club has an answer. And it involves a lot of wood chips.\n\n\u201cThere are little areas with shavings like for horses,\u201d said Kari Smith, who breeds and shows Icelandic sheepdogs. \u201cThink of a giant hamster cage.\u201d", "title": "Westminster Dog Show 2018: Flynn Is Best in Show", "authors": ["Maya Salam", "Liam Stack", "Kelly Whiteside"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "This is all potentially interesting information. How significant is it in context? For starters, what other evidence did the intelligence court rely on in finding probable cause to issue the warrant? The memo doesn\u2019t say. What about the court\u2019s rationale for issuing three separate extensions, each of which required investigators to present new evidence beyond the dossier? The memo doesn\u2019t say. Was any significant piece of information in the dossier found to be inaccurate? The memo doesn\u2019t say. Did the court assume bias on the part of Mr. Steele or the funders of his research, as courts regularly do when considering evidence supporting a request for a warrant? The memo doesn\u2019t say.\n\nYou know what would help to answer questions like these? Even more transparency. It would be useful, for instance, if we could see all of the supporting evidence in the warrant application \u2014 with necessary redactions, of course, to protect sources and methods. Also helpful would be the 10-page response memo prepared by Representative Adam Schiff, the committee\u2019s ranking Democrat, who, unlike Mr. Nunes, has actually seen the intelligence underlying the application. (The response memo reportedly explains, among other things, that investigators did in fact tell the court that the dossier was politically motivated.)\n\nSurely Mr. Nunes, House Speaker Paul Ryan and the other Republicans who, in the days leading up to the memo\u2019s release, expressed a newfound enthusiasm for transparency in government would support releasing this information, wouldn\u2019t they? Transparency in government is the lifeblood of a democracy, after all \u2014 the bulwark against abuses of power by public officials. As Mr. Ryan said on Tuesday in defending the House\u2019s decision to release the memo, \u201cTransparency can reign supreme.\u201d\n\nSince the Republicans are now on board with greater transparency, they will no doubt push President Trump to release his tax returns, as every other major-party presidential nominee has done for the past four decades, won\u2019t they?\n\nHow about the White House visitor logs, which the Trump administration started hiding from the public last year? Or, say, the names of all foreign governments and officials who have stayed \u2014 at their own or at American taxpayers\u2019 expense \u2014 at Mr. Trump\u2019s Washington hotel, at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida or at his golf courses and his other businesses since he became president? Or the names of every foreign business with which the Trump Organization has a financial relationship, especially in countries where America has sensitive foreign policy interests, like China, India, Russia, Turkey or Saudi Arabia?", "title": "Opinion | We\u2019ve Got the Memo. Now What About Trump\u2019s Tax Returns?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Rhode Island\n\nGovernor Raimondo\u2019s move by executive order was the first of its kind. Five other states \u2014 Connecticut, California, Washington, Oregon and Indiana \u2014 have passed similar \u201cextreme risk\u201d laws, sometimes known as \u201cred flag\u201d laws, having done so either in the legislature or by voter referendum. Since the Florida shooting, a dozen others are considering similar measures.\n\nRhode Island has also joined with Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and New York in a coalition to combat gun violence. The group plans to create a multistate database to trace and intercept guns used in crimes or transported across state lines.\n\nFlorida\n\nLawmakers have proposed a package of gun measures that defy the powerful National Rifle Association, but fall well short of the more restrictive measures, like an assault weapons ban, favored by the shooting\u2019s survivors.\n\nGov. Rick Scott, a Republican, proposed raising the minimum age to buy assault rifles to 21 and called for a raft of measures he said could keep mentally ill or violent people from purchasing weapons and keep schools safer. Republicans in the House and Senate, who appear supportive of Mr. Scott\u2019s proposals, also called for a three-day waiting period on the purchase of those weapons, which already exists for those who wish to buy handguns.\n\nMr. Scott proposed $450 million in new funding for school security and $50 million in mental health funding and called for a law enforcement officer to be posted in every public school.\n\nPhoto\n\nVermont\n\nGov. Phil Scott, a Republican, has done an about-face in his rural state, where hunting is a major pastime and which has some of the most lax gun laws in the country. Even after the shooting, he told the Vermont publication Seven Days that he saw no need for changing laws. \u201cI believe our gun laws are balanced,\u201d said Mr. Scott, who has a 93 percent rating from the N.R.A.\n\nBut shortly after, a student at a Vermont high school was accused of planning a mass shooting. Mr. Scott said he was \u201cjolted\u201d by the prospect of such a disaster so close to home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe reality of how close we came to a devastating tragedy underscores the threat of violence that faces the entire country,\u201d he said. \u201cAs a result, I\u2019ve been asking myself, \u2018Are we doing everything we can to protect our kids?\u2019\u201d\n\nNow, he said, \u201cEverything should be on the table at this point.\u201d\n\nThe State Senate is expected to pass two measures this week to tighten gun controls. The Senate Judiciary Committee last week unanimously passed one bill \u2014 to allow law enforcement to remove guns from people considered at extreme risk of harming themselves or others.\n\nThe committee was divided on the second, more controversial bill \u2014 an expansion of background checks \u2014 but in an unusual step, appeared ready to allow it to move to the Senate floor without a committee vote. The State House is likely to take up the two measures later next month.\n\nOregon\n\nThe day after the shooting, Oregon\u2019s House passed a bill making it illegal for people convicted of domestic violence or those with restraining orders against them to possess weapons, even if they are not married to, do not live with, or do not have children with their victims.\n\nOne of the three Republicans who joined Democrats in voting for the bill said pressure from groups like the N.R.A. made him want to \u201ccrawl under my desk in the fetal position,\u201d according to The Oregonian. The State Senate passed the bill late last week; Gov. Kate Brown, a Democrat, is expected to sign it.\n\n\u201cIt took the voices and outrage of youth devastated by gun violence to hold decision makers\u2019 feet to the fire,\u201d she said in a statement.\n\nWashington\n\nA bill filed in Washington State on Friday would raise the minimum age to purchase a semiautomatic rifle or shotgun with \u201ctactical features\u201d to 21, which the bill\u2019s sponsors said would align rules to buy those guns with existing rules for handguns. It would also make the sale of those weapons subject to state and federal background checks.\n\nThe bill would also create a program to allow students to report threats or potentially violent activity anonymously to the attorney general\u2019s office and would require the state to give grants to school districts for emergency response systems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLawmakers in Washington are also working on a ban on bump stocks, which accelerate the rate of fire on semiautomatic firearms. The legislation passed the Senate in January and the House on Friday, with a final Senate vote remaining.\n\nOhio\n\nGov. John Kasich, a Republican, has appointed a committee to propose concrete actions and urged it to make its recommendations quickly.\n\nMeanwhile, several bills, some restricting access to guns and some expanding it, are pending in the Statehouse.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIllinois\n\nMichael J. Madigan, the House speaker, said he would schedule votes this week on two gun-related bills that were filed before the shooting. One would require gun dealers to be licensed, much like car dealerships or beauty salons. The other, similar to the \u201cextreme risk\u201d laws in other states, allows a judge to bar a person from possessing weapons if family members or law enforcement officers ask the court to do so.\n\nMr. Madigan said lawmakers this week would also introduce legislation to raise the minimum age to purchase military-style assault rifles to 21.\n\nIndiana\n\nSome bills loosening gun restrictions have advanced in the state since the Florida shooting, according to The Indianapolis Star. A Senate committee last week advanced a bill that would do away with a $125 fee for a lifetime license to carry a handgun, and would increase from four years to five years a permit that exempts holders from background checks when purchasing a handgun.\n\nIn the House, a committee passed a bill last week allowing people to carry weapons at churches that share property with schools, as long as they are working for or attending the church, and the church does not prohibit weapons. This month, before the shooting, the measure was passed by the full Senate.\n\nKansas\n\nThe state is considering legislation to lower the age at which people can carry hidden, loaded guns in public to 18 from 21, while also requiring anyone under 21 to get a permit, including for carrying their weapons on college campuses. The State House passed the measure earlier this month. It is now before the State Senate.\n\nSouth Dakota\n\nThe House has passed a measure that the N.R.A. calls \u201cself-defense\u201d legislation. It would let people carry guns on the grounds of schools or churches. The Senate is considering a bill to repeal the permitting process to allow law-abiding citizens to carry a weapon without having to get a concealed-carry permit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTexas\n\nAfter the shooting, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, a Republican, sent a letter to Mike Morath, the Texas Education Agency commissioner, ordering safety information to be distributed to all schools, and asking him to take steps to ensure that all schools have completed safety audits and that all have a multihazard emergency plan in place.", "title": "What Are States Doing About Gun Violence After the Florida Shooting?", "authors": ["Katharine Q. Seelye", "Jess Bidgood"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "But a medal is not mandatory for interest. The women\u2019s ice hockey team, which will include a few players from North Korea, will be a hot topic, regardless of its results, Lee said.\n\nGermany\n\nIn Germany, the suite of popular sports includes a number barely registering in the United States.\n\nBiathlon, which Nicolas Reimer of Sport-Informations-Dienst called \u201cthe Formula One of the winter,\u201d was always popular, but it grew even bigger with the success of Laura Dahlmeier, who won five gold medals at the 2017 world championships.\n\nReimer also ticks off \u201cLuge, the women for sure. Ski jumping will be big.\u201d But he worries about Nordic combined. Germans \u201cwon everything last season. This season they are a little bit weak.\u201d\n\nStill, the country will be watching.\n\nSweden\n\nCross-country skiing will be the most popular sport, \u201cno doubt,\u201d said Karl Forssell of Expressen Sweden. \u201cCharlotte Kalla is the most popular athlete by a big margin.\u201d\n\nKalla has parlayed cross-country fame into endorsement deals for electric toothbrushes and vegetarian meat substitutes.\n\nIce hockey is huge in Sweden, and after it was announced that N.H.L. players would not participate this year, \u201cthere was less interest,\u201d he said. \u201cBut when the tournament is on ... it\u2019s Sweden. If they can get into the semifinals, people will watch.\u201d\n\nJapan\n\nThe country\u2019s biggest star, and one of the world\u2019s biggest, is the defending men\u2019s figure skating champion Yuzuru Hanyu.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut it\u2019s not just Hanyu. Figure skating is \u201cfar more popular than the other sports,\u201d said Daisuke Hasegawa of Kyodo News. \u201cThere are enthusiastic fans who go around the world for figure skating events. So many Japanese fans will be here for Hanyu.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week.
