It\u2019s Cross-Country Skiing With Guns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "On the list of snowboarding events for this year\u2019s Winter Olympics, alongside the now familiar halfpipe and slopestyle, is a new competition with a short but evocative name: big air.\n\nThe name is accurate. Everything about the event is big. And the dizzying heights achieved by the snowboarders more than justify the \u201cair.\u201d\n\nIn big air, snowboarders slide down a 49-meter tall ramp (Pyeongchang\u2019s is the biggest in the world) that curls up at the end and shoots them into the sky, seemingly forever, allowing particularly spectacular tricks.\n\nUnlike, say, slopestyle, in which athletes go down a course and have several chances to show off tricks, big air is all about the one jump, the one big, spectacular stunt.", "title": "What Is Big Air? It\u2019s the Olympics\u2019 Newest Snowboard Event", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nGANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 Ever since the International Olympic Committee added curling to its official list of winter sports in time for the 1998 Winter Olympic Games, the sport has been a quadrennial source of curiosity \u2014 and something of an addictive force \u2014 for spectators across the globe.\n\nThe athletes \u2014 yes, they\u2019re athletes and don\u2019t you dare suggest otherwise \u2014 deliver polished granite orbs across a long sheet of ice. They use special brooms and wear special shoes and have their own special language, barking commands like \u201churry hard!\u201d Canadians, in particular, love this stuff.\n\nHere in Pyeongchang, curling will clutter the calendar for 18 full days \u2014 longer than any other sport at the Games. Mixed doubles actually starts Thursday, the day before the opening ceremony. There will be no shortage of hurrying hard this month.\n\nSo as we dive back into the madness, a quick primer might be in order.\n\nWithout getting too technical, how do you play?\n\nLet\u2019s start with the men\u2019s and women\u2019s team events. There are four players on each team, who rotate jobs. But for each throw, one player delivers the rock \u2014 the aforementioned granite stone, which weighs between 38 and 42 pounds \u2014 two teammates sweep and the fourth person sets the target. The target is at the other end of the sheet. Known as the house, it\u2019s a series of concentric circles that forms a sort of bull\u2019s-eye.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo, how do you score?\n\nEach match takes place over 10 ends, which are kind of like innings in baseball. A total of 16 rocks \u2014 eight per team \u2014 are thrown during each end, and the teams alternate shots. One of the quirks of curling is that only one team can score in each end, and that point goes to the team that puts a rock closest to the button once all 16 of them have been thrown. If that team has two rocks closest to the button, they get two points \u2014 and so on. If a team takes three or four points in a single end, that\u2019s a huge score and often amounts to an insurmountable lead.\n\nAlso, it might be worth familiarizing yourself with the term \u201chammer.\u201d The team with the hammer gets to throw the last rock, which is a huge tactical advantage. The hammer for the first end is awarded to the team that puts two rocks closest to the button in a pre-game shootout. (Officials measure the combined distance.) As the match wears on, the hammer goes to the team that did not score in the previous end.", "title": "What Is Curling? Power Plays, Scoring, Rocks and Hammers", "authors": ["Scott Cacciola"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "One of the most appealing things about luge is its name. Luge. It almost sounds onomatopoetic, like a sled whooshing down an icy track. (It\u2019s actually a Swiss term for a small sled.)\n\nLuge feels familiar. It\u2019s like when you leapt onto your Flexible Flyer and steered down the hill with your feet. Only these sleds weigh 50 pounds and can hit speeds of 90 miles per hour.\n\nAnd then there\u2019s doubles luge. Is that one person just lying on top of the other person as they race down the icy track? Yeah, pretty much.", "title": "What Is Luge? It\u2019s Like Sledding at 90 Miles Per Hour", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere are three kinds of skiing events at the Winter Olympics. Alpine skiing consists of the traditional events in which skiers race down a hill: the slalom, the giant slalom, the downhill. Freestyle skiing is the newest discipline, with skiers spinning and flipping in the halfpipe or over moguls.\n\nThat leaves the Nordic events, specifically defined as ones in which athletes\u2019 heels are not affixed to the skis. The two main Nordic events are quite different: cross-country skiing, which requires endurance, and ski jumping, the daredevil event that rewards courage, aerodynamic form and a slight body.\n\nSo why not take these two disparate events and combine them? That\u2019s Nordic combined.\n\nSkiers start by taking two ski jumps, scoring points for distance and style. Next up is a 10-kilometer cross-country race. Competitors start based on their performance in the ski jumping: The best ski jumper takes off first, then the others follow in staggered fashion. The first skier across the line wins.\n\nThree gold medals are awarded in Nordic combined. There is an individual event on the large ski jumping hill and another on the smaller, \u201cnormal\u201d hill. There is also a team event in which four athletes jump, then participate in a cross-country relay. Nordic combined is a men\u2019s only event at the Olympics.\n\nAmong the contenders at the 2018 Winter Olympic Games are several Germans, including the five-time reigning World Cup winner, Eric Frenzel, and the Japanese Akito Watabe. Norway, though, is historically the king of the event.\n\nThe United States had a brief heyday in 2010, winning four medals. But those are the only medals for the country in its history. In Sochi, Russia, in 2014, no American placed higher than 27th.\n\n\u201cNordic combined is such a funky sport,\u201d Alan Ashley, the managing director of sport performance for the United States Olympic Committee, said in 2010. \u201cIt takes a really long time to, first of all, develop the skills and the physical capability in both of these disciplines, and then to figure out how to balance the two.\u201d", "title": "What Is Nordic Combined? Rules Explained", "authors": ["Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBy now, most sports fans are at least a little familiar with the luge: Sledders lying on their backs have been sliding down an icy course at the Olympics since 1964.\n\nSkeleton is like luge. Only the sledders are flipped on their stomachs and careen down the course headfirst. It\u2019s like you remember from your local sledding hill, when school was closed for a snowstorm. But at 80 miles per hour.\n\nAfter cameos at the St. Moritz Olympics in 1928 and 1948, skeleton joined the Games permanently in 2002.\n\nThe unusual name may have arisen because the early sleds reminded some of skeletons, or from a corruption of a Norwegian word for sled, \u201ckjaelke.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough steering accurately around the turns is important \u2014 sliders control the sled with small movements of their heads and shoulders \u2014 a lot of success or failure comes down to the start. How fast can the sledders run 25 or so meters, and how efficiently can they convert that foot speed into speed on the course?", "title": "What Is Skeleton? It\u2019s Like the Luge \u2014 but Headfirst", "authors": ["Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTeachers, please see our related lesson plan, Resources for Talking and Teaching About the School Shooting in Florida.\n\n_________\n\nIt would have been a normal school day, before the gunshots. The Times reports:\n\nEvery morning at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School begins with an affirmation, which is read over the intercom. On Wednesday morning, the affirmation began with the word life. \u201cLife supports me in every way possible\u201d were the first words students heard that day. The announcement went on to speak of Valentine\u2019s Day, and how everyone \u201cdeserves a safe and healthy relationship.\u201d The Astronomy Club announced that it was celebrating Black History Month on Thursday night with a showing of the movie \u201cHidden Figures.\u201d\n\nBut all school events were canceled on Feb. 14, and instead Stoneman Douglas called in grief counselors. Seventeen students and teachers were killed when a 19-year-old barged into his former high school with a semiautomatic AR-15 rifle.\n\nWe\u2019ve asked this question many times before \u2014 after the mass shootings at a Newtown elementary school, an Orlando nightclub, a Las Vegas concert and a rural Texas church. But it still seems as important as ever to make sure you \u2014 students in middle school, high school and college \u2014 have a place to share your emotions, thoughts and questions:\n\nWhat is your reaction to the deadly shooting at a Florida high school?\n\nWe have additional follow-up questions you may want to comment on as well:\n\n\u2014 Has your school ever faced any sort of gun violence or gun incidents?\n\n\u2014 What precautions does your school take to prevent or prepare for a possible school shooting? Do you have active shooter drills? Do you have increased school security? Are there enough counseling resources?\n\n\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Do you feel safe at school?\n\n\u2014 What should be done to prevent more school shootings? In your opinion, is the problem of school shootings mostly a school problem or is it a larger political or cultural problem in the United States?\n\n\u2014 What questions do you have for other students \u2014 or adults \u2014 who might be reading your comment?", "title": "What Is Your Reaction to the Deadly Shooting at a Florida High School?", "authors": ["Michael Gonchar", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The sell-off in stocks has reached a new level in market lingo: a correction. After tumbling in recent weeks, the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index closed on Thursday in that territory.\n\nWhat is a stock market correction?\n\nA correction is a 10 percent drop in stocks from their peak. Since Jan. 26, the S.&P. 500 has fallen 10.16 percent.\n\nIn some ways, 10 percent is an arbitrary threshold. But it often signals that investors have turned more pessimistic about the markets.\n\nDoes this mean stocks are headed down even further?\n\nNot necessarily.\n\nOver the past 20 years, there have been 10 corrections in the S.&P. 500, including the current one, according to Yardeni Research. The previous correction ended in February 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf those corrections, only two have turned into bear markets:\n\nStart date Duration High Low Change 7/17/1998 45 days 1186.75 957.28 \u201019.3% 7/16/1999 91 1418.78 1247.41 \u201012.1% 3/24/2000 929 1527.46 776.76 \u201049.1% 11/27/2002 104 938.87 800.73 \u201014.7% 10/9/2007 517 1565.15 676.53 \u201056.8% 4/23/2010 70 1217.28 1022.58 \u201016.0% 4/29/2011 157 1363.61 1099.23 \u201019.4% 5/21/2015 96 2130.82 1867.61 \u201012.4% 11/3/2015 100 2109.79 1829.08 \u201013.3% 1/26/2018 13 2872.87 2581 -10.2%\n\nWait. What is a bear market?\n\nIt is a more severe and usually more sustained downturn in the market, when stocks drop by at least 20 percent.\n\nThe last one, during the financial crisis, lasted until March 2009. Then, the S.&P. 500 sank nearly 57 percent from peak to trough, according to Yardeni Research.", "title": "What Is a Stock Market Correction?", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSo it\u2019s not about solids,\u201d Shah said. \u201cIt\u2019s about how you put colors together?\u201d\n\n\u201cExactly, and different from what it\u2019s been before,\u201d the woman said. \u201cIt\u2019s almost like a counterculture type of a feeling \u2014 you deliberately use colors that would not ordinarily work together.\u201d\n\n\u201cAccidental colors,\u201d Shah said, coining a phrase.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s a good way of putting it, yes,\u201d the woman agreed.\n\nThe conclave broke for lunch, and Shah walked around the table alone, scratching his chin and muttering to himself while sorting mood boards into piles of similar colors \u2014 \u201cediting,\u201d he said. Occasionally he would wince at having mislaid a board, then pick it up again and set it down someplace else. He worked hurriedly, and by the time the others returned from their meals, he was finished, having arranged the materials into precise groups from which the winning shades could be selected. That afternoon, he and his collaborators finalized the palettes. In six weeks, the forecast would be available to anyone interested enough to part with $795.\n\nColor forecasters like Shah and his team at Pantone have tremendous influence over the visible elements of the global economy \u2014 the parts of it that are designed, manufactured and purchased \u2014 though their profession itself is all but invisible. If you\u2019re familiar with color forecasting at all, it\u2019s most likely thanks to a scene in the 2006 film \u201cThe Devil Wears Prada,\u201d in which the fashion-magazine mandarin Miranda Priestly, played by Meryl Streep, explains to her young, fashion-skeptical assistant why the assistant, played by Anne Hathaway, happens to be wearing a sweater in a very particular shade of blue known as cerulean. Cerulean, Priestly explains, first showed itself a few years earlier in a collection by Oscar de la Renta and was soon adopted by a number of other influential designers before it \u201cfiltered down through the department stores and then trickled on down into some tragic Casual Corner, where you no doubt fished it out of some clearance bin,\u201d she says.\n\n\u201cThat blue represents millions of dollars and countless jobs,\u201d she says. \u201cAnd it\u2019s sort of comical how you think that you\u2019ve made a choice that exempts you from the fashion industry when, in fact, you\u2019re wearing the sweater that was selected for you by the people in this room.\u201d In reality, it was selected by Pantone. Six years before the release of \u201cThe Devil Wears Prada,\u201d Pantone\u2019s forecasters named cerulean the company\u2019s first-ever Color of the Year.\n\nIn the nearly two decades since then, as digital design and social media have expanded the ranks of color obsessives, Pantone has become not just a company but a sensation, its brand bestriding the globe like a behemoth. Its color forecasts, too, have retained their reputation as some of the most influential in the world, even as the field of competitors has grown crowded \u2014 not just with other companies but, thanks to the internet, with people on social-networking sites like Tumblr and Pinterest who have a knack for spotting color trends and enough followers to matter. For the class of fashion and industrial designers who make up Pantone\u2019s customer base, picking the right color \u2014 and exactly the right shade of that color \u2014 can feel like one of the most important decisions they\u2019ll make all year. Companies will pay almost anything to get it right, and the rarefied, vaguely mystical art of doing just that happens to be Pantone\u2019s business.\n\nFor most of history, dyestuffs were derived only from natural materials like plants, minerals and invertebrates, offering people a narrow range of colors from which to choose. Only the rich could afford to clad themselves in more-exotic hues. This changed in the mid-19th century with the rise of the synthetic chemical industry. In London, in the spring of 1856, a college student named William Henry Perkin was experimenting with aniline, an organic compound he extracted from coal tar, in an attempt to synthesize quinine, an antimalarial drug then in great demand among inhabitants of the British Empire\u2019s equatorial possessions. As Regina Lee Blaszczyk recounts in her 2012 book, \u201cThe Color Revolution,\u201d the experiment failed but by accident produced a dark, viscous substance. It happened to stain a rag, and presto! Mauve was born. Two years later, Princess Victoria, the queen\u2019s oldest child, was married in a mauve dress, igniting the world\u2019s first fashion craze for a synthetic color.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore discoveries soon followed: magenta, Hofmann\u2019s violet, Lyons blue, malachite green, Bismarck brown and aniline black. By the 1880s, dye houses in Germany, which was by then the center of the chemical industry, and French textile mills were issuing seasonal color cards and ribbon samples of various synthetic shades. When the outbreak of World War I cut off the supply of German dyestuffs, threatening the color industry with collapse, a consortium of American mills and manufacturers formed the Textile Color Card Association, which developed the first industrywide color library and trend forecast, based solely on dyes that could be manufactured domestically. After the armistice, the group continued to be a hub for the best intelligence on color trends emanating from Europe\u2019s fashion capitals and, in 1955, renamed itself the Color Association of the United States. Similar organizations soon took form in other countries around the world.\n\nThe modern color industry had arrived, if only in a confined sort of way. Born out of the fashion business, it remained rooted there for decades even as it exerted powerful influence on distant parts of the consumer economy, such as the automotive and home-furnishings sectors. But at the turn of the millennium, the color industry\u2019s center of gravity shifted seemingly overnight with a big bang in the field of industrial design: the release, in 1998, of Apple\u2019s iMac G3 desktop computer.\n\nAvailable in 11 translucent shades, from Bondi Blue to Tangerine, the iMac ushered in a new era in which consumers began to value everyday purchases not strictly, or even primarily, for their utility but as a form of self-expression. \u201cThat colorful plastic was everywhere in industrial design for the next several years,\u201d Virginia Postrel, the author of several books on aesthetics, told me. \u201cNot just consumer electronics but all sorts of ordinary objects like irons and trash cans. It was an easy and cheap way to make things look fun and fresh.\u201d Eventually, the enthusiasm faded; Apple itself shifted its palette to neutral whites, blacks and silvers. But the larger idea that the iMac inaugurated \u2014 namely that color choices are serious business and can determine the success or failure of any product in any industry \u2014 continues to ripple through the marketplace.\n\nSteve Jobs\u2019s revolution in commercial aesthetics would have been impossible without another one that occurred 35 years earlier. A nagging problem had troubled the color industry from its inception: how to communicate accurately the subtleties of perception. In his 1963 book, \u201cInteraction of Color,\u201d the Bauhaus artist and Yale professor Josef Albers wrote: \u201cIf one says \u2018Red\u2019 (the name of a color) and there are 50 people listening, it can be expected that there will be 50 reds in their minds. And one can be sure that all these reds will be very different.\u201d There are innumerable colors, he continued, but only about 30 names for them. And even if you could describe all of those colors, wouldn\u2019t your sense of them still differ from someone else\u2019s? As the British journalist Kassia St. Clair writes in \u201cThe Secret Lives of Color,\u201d \u201cYou could no more meaningfully secure a precise universal definition for all the known shades than you could plot the coordinates of a dream.\u201d\n\nThe man who came closest to doing just that was Lawrence Herbert. In 1956, Herbert, who had recently graduated with a degree in biology and chemistry from Hofstra University on Long Island, took a job as a press operator and color matcher at M & J Levine, a New York-based advertising firm and the parent company of a small printing concern called Pantone Press. As the company\u2019s founders turned to other lines of business, Herbert took over the printing division and in a few short years, pioneered a cheaper, more accurate printing method that allowed him to produce a full spectrum of colors from 10 basic pigments. Not long after that, he bought out the company\u2019s printing unit, along with its name, and in 1963 introduced the Pantone Matching System.\n\nHerbert\u2019s system was at once transformative and elegantly simple. It measured precisely the mixture of pigments necessary to produce a specific shade, each of which was assigned a reference number. Pantone then compiled the colors and numbers into books. Rather than provide inks directly, it sold the means by which a printer could faithfully and consistently reproduce any color in Pantone\u2019s library. In doing so, Herbert tamed color\u2019s mysterious nature and turned it into a commodity, in essence quantifying what had until then been unquantifiable.\n\nPantone and its parent company, X-Rite \u2014 a maker of color-management systems and software that acquired Pantone in 2007 \u2014 now have 17 offices and production facilities around the world and offer products used by 10 million designers and manufacturers every day. Pantone\u2019s color library, which continues to grow by the year, contains roughly 10,000 unique shades. The company\u2019s expansion has been helped along by globalization and the offshoring of manufacturing. With designers in Europe, say, marketers in the United States and factories in China, a company can easily communicate color choices up and down the supply chain, so long as everyone involved references the same Pantone chip \u2014 Albers\u2019s 50 reds reduced to one.\n\nThose chips have become the lingua franca of the visual world, and every single one of them is manufactured in a squat, two-story brick building on Commerce Boulevard in a gritty, industrial section of Carlstadt, N.J. The plant employs about 75 people, whose days are spent in the manufacture of Pantone color standards \u2014 the company\u2019s shades applied to materials like cotton, paper and plastic. When I visited one rainy morning last August, I was surprised by how aggressively anti-chromatic the facility was \u2014 gray carpets and walls painted in a shade that a sign identified as Snow White (11-0602). The building\u2019s blandness, I learned, is no accident: Colors are best viewed in a neutral environment in which their essence can be more easily seen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI met Beverly Bell, Pantone\u2019s manager of color and quality standards for textiles, in a dimly lit room adjacent to the factory floor. Nearby, an employee in a white lab coat was standing at a countertop light box, checking a fresh batch of cotton-based color standards for flaws. The box emits D65 light, which, Bell said, simulates the midday sun in Western Europe \u2014 supposedly the purest possible illumination and the industry standard for assessing color.\n\nSuch exacting controls are in place at every stage of production. Cotton swatches, for example, after being dyed, are conditioned overnight in a machine that exposes them to D65 light and a temperature of 70 degrees Fahrenheit at 50 percent humidity. Afterward, they are measured with a spectrophotometer, which compares colors against the Pantone standard with hyperaccuracy. If they pass inspection, the swatches are then hermetically sealed inside plastic, ultraviolet-resistant envelopes, which protect against fading. Colors applied to paper and plastic undergo similar testing.\n\nThe final quality safeguard is the human eye. Every Pantone employee is required to pass an annual exam called the Farnsworth-Munsell 100 Hue Color Vision Test. The test taker has to arrange four rows of samples, 85 in all, into descending order based on their shade. \u201cAnyone who\u2019s actually working with color has to get a \u2018superior\u2019 rating,\u201d Bell said. \u201cSo that means no more than three errors.\u201d That morning, trying my luck on a blue/purple row, I made only one mistake, and might have congratulated myself had Bell not already told me that Pantone\u2019s reigning color-test champion, a woman named Madlin Tadros, who works in the textiles department, has never erred in 21 years.\n\nThe unremarkable appearance of Pantone\u2019s offices belies the excitement the brand engenders around the world. Designers, regardless of their industry, always seem to have Pantone\u2019s color books within reach, like some sacred text of a secret society. \u201cIt\u2019s amazing when you look at it,\u201d an interior designer told me. \u201cI can\u2019t imagine working with anything else.\u201d The company\u2019s color standards are often employed by exacting obsessives for decidedly off-label purposes too. A fish company recently enlisted Pantone to assist with a guide for sushi freshness. And Calvin Klein, according to Lisa Marsh\u2019s 2004 book, \u201cThe House of Klein,\u201d used to keep a Pantone chip taped to the wall next to the office coffee maker \u201cto ensure he\u2019d get just the right mix of coffee and milk every time.\u201d\n\nIn the past decade, Pantone has become a consumer brand in its own right: It now licenses clothes, shoes, cosmetics, kitchenware, furniture, cellphones, jigsaw puzzles, children\u2019s books, skateboards, key chains and thumb drives, in Pantone colors and bearing its logo. Pantone does not report financial information, but Fast Company wrote in 2015 that a full 15 percent of its millions of dollars in annual revenue now derives from commercial licensing.\n\nAnd the cult of Pantone extends far beyond the company\u2019s own merchandise. An online fan club of the Los Angeles Dodgers, for example, has taken to calling itself by the team\u2019s official shade of blue, Pantone 294. An authorized Pantone-themed boutique hotel in Brussels immerses its guests in a kaleidoscopic array of colors, right down to their bedspreads and coffee mugs. Several Instagram users, each with tens of thousands of followers, regularly pair their photographs with the corresponding Pantone chips, and a Brazilian photographer named Ang\u00e9lica Dass has made portraits of more than 3,000 people in 13 countries, all sorted by skin color according to the Pantone Matching System.\n\nThis alchemy of color chips into cultural cachet is largely the work of Laurie Pressman, vice president of the Pantone Color Institute, a small in-house consultancy, founded in 1986. A native New Yorker with shoulder-length brown hair, Pressman arrived at Pantone nearly 20 years ago, shortly after the color industry\u2019s iMac-inaugurated big bang, and since then has worked to make Pantone a household name. Her division produces several seasonal forecasts, as well as a magazine called Viewpoint Colour, which anticipate trends up to three years in advance. It has also helped brands \u2014 from Tiffany and Victoria\u2019s Secret to Barbie, Schweppes and the Royal Mail in Britain \u2014 develop proprietary shades. On the day I visited, Pressman showed me an uncut sheet of soon-to-be-released Pantone chips for Love Symbol No.2, a shade adapted from the purple paint on one of Prince\u2019s favorite pianos and commissioned by his estate after his death.\n\nThat a company engaged in the manufacture of something so intangible \u2014 and, for most consumers, so useless \u2014 as color standards could develop a widespread and devoted following among people far removed from its intended clientele speaks to a larger cultural phenomenon: a growing popular enthusiasm for color in its own right and for its own sake, free of the constraints of form or function. Color\u2019s liberation owes much to the rise of the internet, particularly the explosion of photo sharing on social media. As this digital revolution took shape, Pantone found itself perfectly positioned to exploit it. \u201cPantone did not create desire for color,\u201d said Ellen Sideri, founder and chief executive of ESP TrendLab in the garment district in New York. \u201cIt has, though, facilitated the use of color globally by creating a common digital color language.\u201d A result is that \u201cour culture has become supervisual, and more than ever before. Color has become a definer of many things.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEach December for nearly two decades, the Pantone Color Institute has tried to capture the moment in the form of its Color of the Year, which it has described as \u201ca color snapshot of what we see taking place in our global culture that serves as an expression of a mood and an attitude.\u201d This year\u2019s pick is Ultra Violet (18-3838), a bluish purple that, the company asserts, is associated with the counterculture, nonconformity, mindfulness and visionary thinking, and that \u201csuggests the mysteries of the cosmos, the intrigue of what lies ahead and the discoveries beyond where we are now.\u201d The release of the Color of the Year occasions a media frenzy and, after it, a torrent of bandwagon-hopping service journalism: For months after this year\u2019s selection, Google Alerts continued to crowd my inbox with articles suggesting how I might use Ultra Violet to update my wardrobe, redecorate my living room, create floral bouquets or crochet a scarf. A Swedish art director created a recipe for an Ultra Violet-colored smoothie.\n\nSometimes Pantone\u2019s pick validates an established trend, as Rose Quartz (13-1520) did for the shade popularly known as Millennial Pink in 2016 \u2014 about as risky a choice as the N.B.A.\u2019s picking LeBron James for Most Valuable Player. In other cases, like Ultra Violet, the company has treaded nearer to the leading edge, more a demonstration of power, perhaps, than astuteness. \u201cThe actual tones themselves I\u2019ve not loved,\u201d Jane Monnington Boddy, the London-based color director at WGSN, a tracker of global fashion trends, told me. But over all, she said, she was impressed with \u201cthe philosophy behind them and how they\u2019ve captured what\u2019s happening in life.\u201d\n\nThe Pantone Color Institute is less the elite unit its name implies than a loose network of specialists drawn from Pressman\u2019s contacts. They live in roughly 20 countries and travel the world, she told me, from the established fashion capitals of Europe to other \u201ctrend forward\u201d cities like Shanghai, Buenos Aires, Melbourne and Cape Town, scouring the fashion, technology, houseware, home-furnishing and automotive industries for glimmers of nascent color trends. \u201cI\u2019m very circumspect about who I bring in,\u201d Pressman told me. \u201cThat person has to be of a certain caliber.\u201d\n\nThe person whose judgment Pressman trusts most lives and works in a restored farmhouse painted in the earthy red shade of Rosewood (19-1532). It is set amid towering coniferous trees along a quiet, well-to-do street on Bainbridge Island in Puget Sound, about 35 minutes by ferry from downtown Seattle. The rolling grounds surrounding the house feature carefully tended gardens of hydrangeas in various colors and a rainbow of other flowering plants, each one identified, like shades in a Pantone fan deck, with a label staked into the loam. The owner is the Pantone Color Institute\u2019s always immaculately dressed executive director, Leatrice Eiseman. She began consulting for the company in 1985 at the invitation of the founder, Larry Herbert, and since then has become its public face or, as one of her European associates put it, \u201cMs. Color in America.\u201d\n\nI visited Eiseman in July, when she was teaching her annual class on trend forecasting and color psychology at the Bainbridge Island Museum of Art, and she allowed me to sit in. When I met her at the museum, Eiseman, with her thick-framed glasses, jewelry and bobbed, sandy blond hair, bore more than a passing resemblance to Anna Wintour. Her long-sleeved shirt and patterned pants, precisely coordinated, offered an eye-catching blend of oranges, greens and blues, as if she meant her attire to double as a kind of couture business card.\n\nI sat in the back row of a classroom on the museum\u2019s second floor and watched her students file in. There were two dozen of them, most in their 20s or 30s, all but one of them women. Rami Kim, the founder of a color institute in Seoul who was on her third pilgrimage to Bainbridge, had brought along seven other South Koreans. Sitting to my right was a former nurse from South Africa, now an interior designer, who said she was hoping to learn more about color combinations, and to my left, a young woman who worked for a small family-owned party-supply company, who told me she was interested in the application of color to edible paper. The lone man in the class was a software engineer contemplating a change of careers to something \u201cmore creative.\u201d All the students paid $1,775 for the privilege of being there, and several of them spoke of their instructor with a respect bordering on reverence. \u201cThere\u2019s no one who can talk about color like she can,\u201d one of them told me.\n\nPromptly at 8 a.m., Eiseman switched off the lights and asked a student to close the blinds. \u201cThe colors will be more vibrant if we get more darkness,\u201d she said. For the next six hours, clicking through illustrative photographs from her travels to more than 60 countries, Eiseman delivered a cascade of assertions: Kids everywhere in the world gravitate to red, blue and yellow crayons; people living near the Equator tend to prefer brighter colors; readers have better recall if texts are printed in something other than black and white; gamblers place higher bets under red lights than under blue ones; there was no word for the color \u201corange\u201d in Europe until the fruit arrived sometime in the Middle Ages; blue shutters in the American southwest are meant to ward off evil spirits; many fire departments have begun painting their engines yellow-green because red, the traditional color, too often appears brown in twilight. At one point, when Eiseman paused to take questions, a young woman raised her hand.\n\n\u201cAre there people you can\u2019t teach color to, people who just don\u2019t get it?\u201d she asked.\n\nEiseman thought for a moment, and said, \u201cYou get resistance from people when you\u2019re working, people who think that color is immaterial, not as important as everything else, but you can usually find something to talk about in their background, mostly coming out of their childhood, that will trigger a response.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe idea that colors exert powerful, often subliminal forces on the human mind is at once Eiseman\u2019s ardent belief and her professional stock in trade. As she wrote 18 years ago in \u201cPantone Guide to Communicating With Color,\u201d \u201csome experts believe that humans have an \u2018ancient wisdom,\u2019 that throughout eons of evolutionary history going back to the beginning of time, we have an associative memory concerning space, form, patterns and colors.\u201d Leveraging that wisdom and revealing the unspoken meanings and emotions conveyed by slight, almost imperceptible variations in color has been her life\u2019s work.\n\nEiseman was born and raised in Baltimore. As a teenager, she dabbled in modeling and won a voice scholarship to the Peabody Institute, but turned it down after deciding against pursuing a career in music. A few years later she met Herb Eiseman, her future husband, a Hollywood talent agent who went on to lead the music publishing division at 20th Century Fox. The couple married and moved to the Los Angeles area, where Eiseman finished her bachelor\u2019s degree in psychology at Antioch University and, afterward, earned a counseling certificate from U.C.L.A. She and Herb had two children, and while they were in school, Eiseman began teaching classes part time at an occupational-training center for women in the San Fernando Valley.\n\nIt was there that she began thinking systematically about color. \u201cThe concept that I developed was called the \u2018color clock,\u2019 and it was based on color as it appears in nature,\u201d she told me. \u201cHow Monet painted the haystacks, various things at various times of day, and how the color seemed to change because of the light.\u201d She applied the idea to women\u2019s clothes and cosmetics, \u201cusing my students as guinea pigs to see if it really held weight.\u201d\n\nIn 1983, she published a book called \u201cAlive With Color.\u201d Soon, she was fielding phone calls asking her to weigh in on the color of everything from living rooms to medical equipment. One caller was Pantone\u2019s Larry Herbert, who invited her to meet with him in New York. \u201cI didn\u2019t even know Pantone existed,\u201d she said. It turned out that Herbert, who\u2019d seen her book, was on the hunt for someone with expertise in the psychology of color, in part to help elevate his company\u2019s public profile. Eiseman jumped at the chance, and 33 years later, she\u2019s still Pantone\u2019s ambassador at large.\n\nEiseman believes that our reaction to colors \u201cgoes beyond the psychological into the physiological\u201d and that colors carry inherent messages that all humans innately understand \u2014 the whispers of that \u201cancient wisdom.\u201d She doesn\u2019t deny the important influence of memory and social factors on color perception, but often, she says, \u201cour response is involuntary, and we simply have no control over it.\u201d As evidence, she points to word-association tests she has administered over the years during her work with Pantone. I asked to see a sample test and some results, but Eiseman refused and said they were proprietary. You can get a feel for her methods, though, from a 2015 interview she gave to Nautilus magazine. \u201cYou take a Pantone color chip and you ask, \u2018Give us the first word that pops into your mind when you look at this color,\u2019 and you see whether that corresponds to a positive, negative or indifferent response,\u201d Eiseman said. \u201cIf you show people a chip of Pantone Sky Blue, about 90 percent or more will respond in the same way: It\u2019s the color of the sky, it\u2019s bright, it\u2019s a light color, it reminds you of that openness. It\u2019s a near-universal response that you get.\u201d\n\nLast October, Eiseman published her 10th book, \u201cThe Complete Color Harmony, Pantone Edition,\u201d her boldest statement yet on the psychology of color \u2014 and one that might rightly be displayed in the self-help section. Consider a chapter titled, \u201cPersonal Colors: What Do They Say About You?\u201d which offers a kind of chromatic horoscope that locates truths not in the cosmos but in the spectrum of visible light. Take blue, my favorite color. \u201cBlue people aspire to harmony, serenity, patience, perseverance and peace, and have a calming influence on other people,\u201d she writes. \u201cYou are generally unflappable, even-tempered and reliable, a team player and good co-worker.\u201d\n\nYep, that\u2019s me down to the ground, I thought as I read it. But what about people who don\u2019t like blue? \u201cPerhaps you want to change your job, a relationship or even your life, and long for more excitement,\u201d Eiseman writes. \u201cYou wish that you were wealthy or brilliant (or both), because that would enable you to have all the good things in life without working so hard.\u201d\n\nAll that from a color? And the fortunetelling continues. Do you like green? \u201cYou are the good citizen, concerned parent, involved neighbor, the joiner of clubs and organizations.\u201d Have an aversion to red? You may be \u201cirritable, exhausted or bothered by many problems.\u201d Yellow? \u201cYou are optimistic, hopeful and encourage others to do their best.\u201d Perhaps strangest of all, though, is Eiseman\u2019s observation about those of us who dislike blue-green shades like turquoise or teal: \u201cA little voice inside you (was it your mother, your father or your roommate?) keeps telling you to clean up your room.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe flip tone of these pronouncements, combined with the lack of any grounding in scientific rigor or research apart from Eiseman\u2019s own observations, may tempt you to dismiss color psychology altogether, consigning it to the bin with other junk sciences, like phrenology or cold fusion. But a great many people take it seriously \u2014 so many, in fact, that for all my searching, I found only one person willing to question it. When I put Eiseman\u2019s assertions to David Comberg, a senior lecturer of design at the University of Pennsylvania, he scoffed and said that color preferences are highly subjective, unpredictable and, in his experience, \u201cprimarily influenced by culture and emotion and are not easily quantified.\u201d When we see red, for instance, are we reacting to the color itself or to a personal experience, perhaps buried in the subconscious, that we associate with it? \u201cAnd what about taste, smell and sound? Artificial intelligence and neuroscience may one day answer all this, but I\u2019m not sure,\u201d Comberg said. \u201cIt all seems subjective and irrational.\u201d\n\nBut among people in Eiseman\u2019s profession, as with the hordes of credulous color enthusiasts who populate the internet, her views are not only uncontroversial but well within the mainstream. \u201cWe are born to understand that green equals calming, because it\u2019s found in nature; red equals danger, because it\u2019s the color of blood,\u201d Jenny Ross, a creative- design manager in the footwear department at New Balance, told me. \u201cYellow equals energy, because it\u2019s the color of the sun.\u201d WGSN\u2019s Jane Monnington Boddy agreed, saying, \u201cPeople do have an inbuilt, preprogrammed understanding of colors, as animals do in nature.\u201d What else explains our instinct to recoil from red-and-black snakes, she asked, or from yellow-and-black flying insects?\n\nUltimately, though, whether blue makes you think of the sky or Papa Smurf, by this point, color psychology may matter less to Pantone\u2019s success than something much less mysterious. \u201cHow do you sell color?\u201d David Shah had asked me rhetorically when I met him in London. \u201cYou can be 10 times cleverer than me. You can be much more intelligent, much more creative. But it\u2019s Pantone, with a million Instagram followers. If you\u2019re hidden away, even though your color is better, you don\u2019t win the argument.\u201d\n\nAt a certain point, Pantone\u2019s prognostications began to take on the weight of self-fulfilling prophecies. Much like investors who base financial decisions on the assessments of Moody\u2019s and Standard & Poor\u2019s, Pantone\u2019s clientele seems to understand that, for all the time and effort the company expends in identifying color trends, it\u2019s the judgments themselves, regardless of the research behind them, that matter most. \u201cBecause of our platform, we\u2019re able to promote,\u201d Shah said. \u201cAnd it\u2019s self-perpetuating \u2014 when people believe you\u2019re right, they buy you. You get to be right!\u201d\n\nWhen I brought up the Color of the Year, Shah trod carefully at first \u2014 \u201cI\u2019m not going to say anything about what I think about this, O.K.?\u201d \u2014 then went on: \u201cYou might go: \u2018Oh, my God! That\u2019s the most awful color in the world! Who would choose it?\u2019 And then you\u2019re like, \u2018I better be careful, because it\u2019s the Pantone Color of the Year, and everybody\u2019s looking at it, and if I don\u2019t, I could be left out.\u2019 When you\u2019ve got a platform like that, you can say it\u2019s the color of my toenails! Can I afford not to do it, even if I don\u2019t believe in it? It\u2019s a lot of smoke and mirrors.\u201d\n\nMADE IN THE SHADE Choosing exactly the right color has become a high-stakes decision. Here is a timeline of some hues that made news.\n\nBy KATY KELLEHER\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto", "title": "What Is the Perfect Color Worth?", "authors": ["Bruce Falconer"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "His white supremacist views and staunch segregationism make for a troubling legacy. For example, he vowed to purge the state university system of any employee who supported \u201cNegroes in the same schools with white folks in Georgia,\u201d a stand that helped cost the state\u2019s white colleges their accreditation. He staged an electoral comeback with a pledge to restore all-white primary elections. He used martial law to wage political turf battles, and he was implicated in corruption.\n\nNone of that stopped the state from naming a bridge over the Savannah River for Mr. Talmadge in the 1950s, when his son Herman Talmadge was governor. By the 1980s, that cantilever-truss bridge was posing problems for large new container ships headed for the Port of Savannah. So the state replaced it in 1991 with the cable-stayed bridge that appears in so many postcards and snapshots today \u2014 and kept on using the Talmadge name, perhaps out of no more than habit.\n\nAnd that, Mr. Stephens said, could create the opening for state lawmakers to give the bridge a new name, unburdened by having to formally remove the old one.\n\n\u201cFor whatever reason, there is a huge resistance for us to start doing that, and making those changes at a later time,\u201d said Mr. Stephens, who has sat in the Legislature through years of arguments over the Confederate symbols on the state flag.\n\nIf officials do find proof that the 1991 bridge was formally named, any proposal to change it will be \u201cdead in the water,\u201d he said, but \u201cas long as you\u2019re not talking about a renaming, I\u2019m not running into resistance at all.\u201d (Natalie Dale, a spokeswoman for the Georgia Department of Transportation, whose board had the power to name bridges until 2002, said Friday that formal action to name the new bridge in 1991 had not been necessary.)\n\nGov. Nathan Deal\u2019s office did not respond to a request for comment on the bridge issue, nor did members of the Talmadge family. Over the years, lawmakers said, Mr. Talmadge\u2019s relatives have warned legislators against altering the name of the bridge.\n\nKaleb McMichen, a spokesman for the state House speaker, David Ralston, a Republican, said it would be \u201cpremature to comment\u201d before a bill is formally introduced, but that it \u201cwould be considered through the normal committee process like any other bill.\u201d", "title": "What It May Take to Strike a Segregationist\u2019s Name From a Georgia Bridge: Hundreds of Girl Scouts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "The Supreme Court, in an opinion by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, rejected that reading of the statute. It applied a simple analysis: \u201cCourts are not at liberty to dispense with the condition\u2014tell the S.E.C.\u2014Congress imposed.\u201d By not reporting his suspicions to the S.E.C., he lost the protection afforded whistleblowers.\n\nOne of the complaints expressed by companies when the S.E.C. considered the whistle-blower rules was that they did not require employees to report information to management first. The incentive created by the Digital Realty ruling is straightforward: Don\u2019t just tell your boss about possible violations; make a beeline to the S.E.C.\u2019s front door, at least if you want protection from retaliation.\n\n\u2014 Peter J. Henning\n\nSomething spooked investors on Wednesday.\n\nThe Dow Jones industrial average rose 139 points in the half-hour after the Federal Reserve released the minutes of its most recent policy meeting at 2 p.m. and was up more than 300 points on the day. Then the index sank 455 points in the final 90 minutes to close down 0.67 percent for the day.\n\nWhy?\n\nThere didn\u2019t appear to be anything in the minutes to make investors particularly bearish or bullish.\n\nPerhaps the bond market was to blame for the plunge. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which rises as its price falls, kept climbing after the minutes came out, closing at 2.95 percent. Higher bond yields can make stocks look more expensive, prompting investors to sell. As a result, Wednesday\u2019s mini move indicates that the tug of war between the stock and bond markets is still very much on.\n\nWhile we\u2019re on the Fed minutes, it appears that the central bank\u2019s policymakers did not spend much time discussing an indicator that is flashing a warning sign. The data point in question is the saving rate, which recently sank to a 12-year low. With the rate at 2.4 percent of disposable income, a big drop in the stock market, like the one that occurred earlier this month, could prompt consumers to cut their spending. The Fed\u2019s policymakers did not appear overly worried about the saving rate at their last meeting, which was held before the market\u2019s plunge. The minutes state:\n\nIn connection with solid growth in consumer spending, a couple of participants noted that the household saving rate had declined to its lowest level since 2005, likely driven by buoyant consumer sentiment or expectations that the rise in household wealth would be sustained.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nBroadcom whacks Qualcomm for raising its NXP bid\n\nQualcomm defied Broadcom\u2019s demand not to raise its takeover bid for NXP on Tuesday by increasing that offer by about 16 percent, to $127.50 a share from $110. Now Broadcom has retaliated.\n\nBroadcom shaved $3 per share off its hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm, to $79.\n\nBroadcom\u2019s rationale is that the new NXP offer transfers value away from Qualcomm\u2019s shareholders. From the news release:\n\nBroadcom believes that a responsible Qualcomm board could have preserved value by following ISS\u2019s clear recommendation to work with Broadcom on the NXP transaction and negotiate the sale of Qualcomm to Broadcom. Instead Qualcomm\u2019s board acted against the best interests of its stockholders by unilaterally transferring excessive value to NXP\u2019s activist stockholders.\n\nLet\u2019s take a look at the math\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Broadcom argues that Qualcomm gave up $4.10 a share, or $6.2 billion, in value to NXP shareholders. In response, it cut its price. At $79 a share, Broadcom\u2019s current offer is just under 13 percent higher than its original offer. (Of course, other elements of Broadcom\u2019s last bid \u2014 the $8 billion breakup fee for antitrust reasons, the ticking fee if a deal takes more than 12 months to close \u2014 still stand.)\n\n\u2022 Broadcom also contends privately that had Qualcomm agreed to start deal talks, the two of them could have held firm against NXP shareholders like Elliott Management and Soroban Capital Partners. By giving up less negotiating power to the holdout shareholders, the argument goes, Qualcomm could have recut the NXP deal at a far lower price.\n\n\u2022 Qualcomm argues privately that the $4.10 a share is nonsense, since the NXP deal a) wasn\u2019t going to get done at $110 a share and b) will still add to its earnings per share price starting in the 2019 fiscal year.\n\nThe bet on the shareholder meeting\n\nBroadcom had previously said that it would walk away if the NXP offer went above $110 a share, but now seems content to take its chances at Qualcomm\u2019s annual shareholder meeting.\n\nBroadcom wants six seats on Qualcomm\u2019s board. That campaign gained momentum when the proxy advisers I.S.S. and Glass Lewis recommended that Qualcomm shareholders vote for at least four of its director nominees.\n\nA Qualcomm representative didn\u2019t have an immediate comment.\n\nHow the shares moved today: Qualcomm\u2019s were down 1.5 percent, while Broadcom\u2019s were up slightly. Shares in NXP \u2014 the real winner in this deal saga so far \u2014 were essentially unchanged.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason pressed Xerox to pursue alternatives to its complicated deal with Fujifilm. (Reuters)\n\n\u2022 HNA has borrowed from the private equity firm Pacific Alliance Group, a sign that it may be struggling to raise capital from more traditional sources. (FT)\n\nProductivity Growth Is Weak But might the return to full employment fuel a rebound? Annual growth in output per hour worked, previous five years % 4 3 2 1 0 0.9% 1960 1980 2000 Annual growth in output per hour worked, previous five years % 4 3 2 1 0 0.9% \u201955 \u201960 \u201965 \u201970 \u201975 \u201980 \u201985 \u201990 \u201995 \u201900 \u201905 \u201910 \u201915\n\nUntangling the productivity mystery.\n\nAn economy is doing well when companies each year manage to become more productive, or in other words, get more output from their employees and equipment. But productivity for years has grown far more slowly than it did in the past, effectively restraining economic growth. This decline has prompted economists to hunt for causes \u2013 and the latest big work on the issue comes from the McKinsey Global Institute. The Upshot\u2019s Neil Irwin does a great job of explaining McKinsey\u2019s main finding:\n\nThe latest wrinkle is that the researchers now believe that productivity growth depends not just on the supply side of the economy \u2014 what companies produce and what technologies they use to do it \u2014 but also significantly on the demand side. That is to say, productivity advancements don\u2019t happen in a vacuum just because technology is available. They also happen because companies need to increase production to match demand for their goods, and a shortage, either of workers or of materials, forces them to think creatively about how to do so.\n\nLittle in economics is straightforward, however, and McKinsey\u2019s deep dive prompted a couple of questions. Jaana Remes, one of the authors of the work, was kind enough to respond.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n1) In its report, McKinsey notes that the slow down in productivity growth was noticeable before the financial crisis. What caused that? And to what degree did those causes contribute to the decline in productivity growth after the financial crisis? This is important because these forces could continue to weigh on productivity.\n\nIn the years leading up to 2008, the productivity improvements that started in the 1990s with the introduction of information technology were largely complete, Ms. Remes explains. Important new technologies can often take well over 10 years to have a big impact on productivity, she adds. The optimistic take, though, is that we can in the coming years expect to see big benefits as companies further automate, and introduce artificial intelligence.\n\n2) If a sluggish economy can create the conditions for weak productivity, why did France, Spain and Italy, whose economies were anemic in the period under study, have significantly better productivity performances than faster-growing countries?\n\nFirst, the numbers: From 2010 to 2014, labor productivity grew by 1.4 percent a year in Spain and 1 percent in France, well in excess of the negative 0.2 percent rate for Britain and the United States. Why was that? Because Britain and the United States had made superior productivity gains before 2010. That made it harder for the two countries to notch similarly strong productivity growth in the years after the financial crisis. By contrast, France and Spain, which had made far fewer productivity gains before 2010, were able to eke out at least some afterward. Ms. Remes also points out that a big cause of Spain\u2019s post-2010 gain came from a reduction in hours worked. That might be described as the least desirable way to bolster productivity because it implies a reduction in incomes for workers. The most economically beneficial type of productivity gain occurs when output per employee increases as hours worked grow.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nOr is productivity suffering because certain companies have become too big?\n\nNew research posted by France\u2019s central bank, the Banque de France, shows that the largest companies in the United States now account for a significantly larger share of production. This dominance, the paper asserts, could allow the companies to enjoy \u201cmonopoly rents,\u201d the term economists use to describe the subsidies companies enjoy if their business is protected in ways that are not available to other firms.\n\n\u201cIf these firms hold a dominant position in their market, they enjoy monopoly rents and have little incentive to invest in order to increase their productive capacities. This behavior could explain the weakness of investment in recent years, despite the high rates of return on capital.\u201d\n\nDavid Wessel, writing for Harvard Business Review, also recently took a look at whether dominant companies are holding the economy back.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nJ.P. Morgan to get a new home.\n\nThe largest United States bank by assets announced that it plans to tear down its current headquarters at 270 Park Ave. and build 2.5 million square-foot modern tower in its place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe new headquarters has yet to be designed, but it is expected, according to Bloomberg, to be between 70 and 75 stories and house 15,000 employees. The current headquarters was designed in the late 1950s for about 3,500 employees, JPMorgan said.\n\nDuring construction, employees will be temporarily moved 237, 245 and 277 Park Ave. and 383 and 390 Madison Ave., Bloomberg reported citing a person familiar with the matter.\n\nThe tower would be the first major project under New York City\u2019s Midtown East rezoning plan, designed to encourage office construction in the area.\n\nA new finance chief at Glassdoor\n\nThe job recruiting site said Wednesday that it has hired Jim Cox as its C.F.O., as part of a series of high-level executive appointments.\n\nMr. Cox was most recently at Lithium Technologies, a maker of customer relationship management software.\n\nHere\u2019s what Robert Hohman, Glassdoor\u2019s C.E.O. and co-founder, said: \u201cWe are pleased to welcome Jim to Glassdoor as our new CFO as he brings a proven track record of building and managing financial operations and teams at high-growth technology companies.\u201d\n\nGlassdoor also appointed Christian Sutherland-Wong, most recently its general manager of monetization, as its first chief operating officer, and Samantha Zupan, a longtime executive, as its vice president of global corporate communications.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nSkadden is under the microscope for its Paul Manafort work\n\nThe giant law firm\u2019s work for the former Trump campaign manager \u2014 who has been charged with several criminal acts by Robert Mueller\u2019s inquiry into Russian election interference \u2014 has come into question after a former Skadden associate entered a guilty plea in the investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Kenneth Vogel and Andrew Kramer of the NYT:\n\nThe interest from prosecutors in what Skadden did for the Ukrainian government is one indication of the wide-ranging nature of the inquiries related to Mr. Manafort. It also highlights the risks associated with advising authoritarian governments overseas, a lucrative sideline among Washington lawyers, lobbyists and public relations consultants.\n\nSkadden\u2019s response: It fired the associate in question, Alex van der Zwaan, last year, and is cooperating with Mr. Mueller\u2019s team.\n\nElsewhere in Russian election meddling: Here\u2019s what we still don\u2019t know about Facebook\u2019s role. Chris Hughes, a co-founder, said Facebook must do more to prevent foreign interference. President Trump blamed Barack Obama for not being tougher on Russia. And meet the oligarch who helped fund Russia\u2019s troll agency.\n\nPhoto\n\nAT&T\u2019s case against the Justice Department takes a hit\n\nThe judge overseeing the Justice Department\u2019s lawsuit to block the $85.4 billion takeover of Time Warner denied AT&T\u2019s request to see government communications about the case. He ruled that AT&T had not \u201cmade a credible showing\u201d that the White House had singled it out for retribution.\n\nMore from Cecilia Kang of the NYT:\n\nThe decision puts a crimp in AT&T\u2019s defense for its $85 billion proposed merger with Time Warner. And it is a big win for the Justice Department, which would like to avoid attention on the role of politics in its decision to stop the deal.\n\nAT&T had already agreed to take the Justice Department\u2019s antitrust chief, Makan Delrahim, off the witness list \u2014 but could call him during the trial if needed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "What It Takes to Be a Whistle-Blower: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Britain\u2019s National Health Service turns 70 this year, amid warnings of an existential crisis. At the end of last year, we interviewed several staff members to ask them what they hoped and feared for the system\u2019s future. Now, readers tell us about their and their families\u2019 experiences with the N.H.S.\n\nHere are their stories, edited for length and clarity.\n\nI believe they did all they could\n\nIn 2015 my husband died from cancer at 35. It was a short time between realizing something was wrong and him dying, most of which we spent in the hospital. The staff were all caring and professional. I believe they did all they could, and when it became clear that he would die, they were very supportive. I was 20 weeks pregnant at the time, and they went above and beyond to look after us both. One example: We had decided not to know the sex of the baby, but when we realized he wasn\u2019t going to make it to the birth, the midwives in the hospital brought a mobile scanner up to the ward so that my husband could have a last look at the baby, and we could learn the sex together. That meant so much to us. And after he died I had extra appointments and scans (at no extra cost) to reassure me that the stress and emotions hadn\u2019t affected the baby. Again, not everything was perfect, but I just can\u2019t imagine going through all of that, and having to deal with insurance companies and money worries as well. \u2014 Kate Trouw, United Kingdom\n\nI would not wish the U.S. medical system on anyone\n\nI am an American living in Britain. I would not wish the U.S. medical system on anyone. When I had a baby in Britain, all was paid for. Suspected meningitis in my baby? Hospital stay and all tests paid for. Sexual health screenings? Free. Dermatologist check-up on my Southern Californian skin? Free. Possible cancerous mole removal? Free. Father-in-law treatment for cancer? Free. End-of-life care for my mother-in-law? Free. Lengthy hospital stay plus live-in rehab unit for an elderly grandparent? Free. If Britain reverts to a U.S.-style system, this country will truly lose what it means to be British: care and compassion for everyone. \u2014 Jennie Vian, United Kingdom\n\nThere\u2019s been no help\n\nWe\u2019re meant to lionize the N.H.S., here in the U.K. But it\u2019s not always that great.\n\nMy youngest son has been on waiting lists for the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services for four years. The process is so slow, I had to get my member of Parliament to intervene just to get an initial assessment. We wanted him to get some help for anxiety and autism-related problems before he moved on to senior school. There\u2019s been no help, and he had to start senior school. It went very badly for him. We\u2019ve since had to withdraw him from the school system.", "title": "Opinion | What It\u2019s Like to Be a Patient With the N.H.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Imagine that this is your daily life: While on your way to work or on an errand, every 100 meters you pass a police blockhouse. Video cameras on street corners and lamp posts recognize your face and track your movements. At multiple checkpoints, police officers scan your ID card, your irises and the contents of your phone. At the supermarket or the bank, you are scanned again, your bags are X-rayed and an officer runs a wand over your body \u2014 at least if you are from the wrong ethnic group. Members of the main group are usually waved through.\n\nYou have had to complete a survey about your ethnicity, your religious practices and your \u201ccultural level\u201d; about whether you have a passport, relatives or acquaintances abroad, and whether you know anyone who has ever been arrested or is a member of what the state calls a \u201cspecial population.\u201d\n\nThis personal information, along with your biometric data, resides in a database tied to your ID number. The system crunches all of this into a composite score that ranks you as \u201csafe,\u201d \u201cnormal\u201d or \u201cunsafe.\u201dBased on those categories, you may or may not be allowed to visit a museum, pass through certain neighborhoods, go to the mall, check into a hotel, rent an apartment, apply for a job or buy a train ticket. Or you may be detained to undergo re-education, like many thousands of other people.\n\nA science-fiction dystopia? No. This is life in northwestern China today if you are Uighur.\n\nChina may no longer be the bleak land of Mao suits, self-criticism sessions and loudspeakers blaring communist slogans. It boasts gleaming bullet trains, luxury malls and cellphone-facilitated consumer life. But when it comes to indigenous Uighurs in the vast western region of Xinjiang, the Chinese Communist Party (C.C.P.) has updated its old totalitarian methods with cutting-edge technology.", "title": "Opinion | What It\u2019s Like to Live in a Surveillance State", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "The basketball player Joel Embiid of the Philadelphia 76ers is almost as famous for his playful grandstanding as his considerable skills on the court. The 23-year-old, who grew up in Cameroon, has become synonymous with the concept of \u201cThe Process,\u201d a strategy for long-term talent building that originated with the former 76ers general manager Sam Hinkie \u2014 Mr. Embiid famously punctuates his feisty tweets with the phrase. Currently in his second season with Philadelphia, Mr. Embiid will play in the N.B.A. All-Star game in Los Angeles on Feb. 18.\n\nMr. Embiid spends much of the year on the road, traveling for games. \u201cGenerally, commercial flights aren\u2019t designed to accommodate someone my size \u2014 and I get it, there aren\u2019t many people that are 7-foot 2,\u201d he said. \u201cI just don\u2019t feel comfortable since I don\u2019t exactly fit.\u201d Fortunately the team usually travels by charter, which has more room to spread out.\n\nWhen Mr. Embiid travels, he usually spends his free time on his PlayStation, not partying. \u201cA lot of my teammates party in L.A. and I have a lot of friends in L.A., but L.A. is like the only city. Maybe New York but that\u2019s about it. Other than that, I just want to chill and play video games.\u201d\n\nHe said he doesn\u2019t get sick of the travel. \u201cWe travel a lot, but that\u2019s what I signed up for, so I never complain about it. We get paid a lot of money to do so, so I\u2019m going to live with it, and I don\u2019t think I would ever get tired of it. Sometimes, you miss the food at home, you miss the people around you, but other than that, you should never get tired of traveling.\u201d", "title": "What Joel Embiid Can\u2019t Travel Without", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Jupiter\u2019s scientists will have to grapple with a number of technical challenges. While current climate models can provide broad statistical projections of how average temperatures and rainfall patterns are likely to shift across large regions over the coming century, it remains difficult to predict such shifts precisely over shorter time scales \u2014 which is what companies are often most concerned about.\n\n\u201cForecasting at 10-20 year time periods is perhaps the most difficult period to forecast,\u201d Simon Mason, a climate scientist at Columbia University\u2019s International Research Institute for Climate and Society who is not involved with Jupiter, wrote in an email. \u201cIf that is not enough, trying to predict severe weather events rather than long-term averages is even harder still!\u201d\n\nPast efforts to provide what are known as \u201cclimate services\u201d have struggled with this issue. In 2009, the German government established the Climate Service Center to provide information about global warming risks to cities and businesses. But Guy P. Brasseur, a climate scientist who helped start the center, said potential clients were often disappointed with the uncertainty in the resulting forecasts.\n\n\u201cOne airline wanted to know how often the airport in Frankfurt would be closed because of snowstorms next year,\u201d Dr. Brasseur said. \u201cWe were unable to answer a question like that.\u201d\n\nJupiter, which acknowledges the uncertainties in climate forecasting, will have to prove that a market exists. But at least one firm in the insurance industry sees potential value in the company\u2019s approach, particularly after flooding and other disasters caused $306 billion in damages last year in the United States and record losses by insurers.\n\n\u201cThat certainly raised the stakes in terms of trying to get the best possible science on your side when you\u2019re pricing risk,\u201d said John Drzik, president of global risk at Marsh, one of the world\u2019s largest commercial insurance brokers, which is currently in talks with Jupiter to explore what types of data and risk analyses might be most useful to its clients.\n\nMr. Drzik noted that many of the traditional catastrophic risk models used by the insurance industry are rooted largely in historical data and don\u2019t always grapple fully with how climate change could shift those risks in the future. While his company is still evaluating whether Jupiter\u2019s climate-oriented models are useful enough to be worth paying for, \u201cit grabbed us as something that had a lot of promise.\u201d", "title": "What Land Will Be Underwater in 20 Years? Figuring It Out Could Be Lucrative", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The comedian Lewis Black, known for his abrasive, expletive-laden style of stand-up, appears regularly on late night talk shows and has released 12 comedy albums. His latest, \u201cLewis Black \u2014 Black to the Future,\u201d was released last fall.\n\nMr. Black travels the country doing as many as 200 shows a year, so he has become obsessed with finding direct flights \u2014 \u201cAll I care about are direct flights. My life is devoted to direct flights\u201d \u2014 and even arranges his travel so that he\u2019s leaving his New York apartment to get to Newark airport at low-traffic times. \u201cBetween 11 and 12 in the afternoon, that\u2019s the window. Plus, usually, traffic in the airport, too, has gone down at that point.\u201d\n\nWhen on the road, he also spends considerable time on the tour bus. \u201cIf I have two weeks back-to-back out west, or you know, in the middle of the country, then it makes sense that I don\u2019t get off the bus. So I\u2019ll spend two or three days on the bus traveling to the next set of shows.\u201d He\u2019s written most of his three books on buses in between shows and recommends it for anyone trying to write. \u201cYeah, but on a tour bus. A Greyhound, it\u2019s not going to happen. You\u2019re going to kill yourself after 12 hours.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what he takes on every trip.", "title": "What Lewis Black Can\u2019t Travel Without", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Many of them had spent their weeks looking for jobs or permanent housing, or walked over to a nearby church that had opened up its kitchen for them to cook in. The children went to school. But this was a Friday night, and as they splayed out on beds watching TV, listened to music or played video games, it felt like they were just killing time, one day passing like so many others before it.\n\nThey had air-conditioning. They were not waiting for hours in lines for food, water and fuel. They had cable television. Still, the aimlessness that plagued them seemed like an extension of the storm\u2019s trauma.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not easy for anybody to live like this,\u201d Janette Febres told me in the room where she, her husband and 12-year-old son had shared a bed for months.\n\nI have never traveled to Puerto Rico, before or after Maria. My impressions of how so much had been upended were formed by the stories told by Puerto Ricans, the photographs they showed me, the distress I saw in their lives. On the other hand, my partner on the story, Luis Ferr\u00e9-Sadurn\u00ed, who visited a hotel in Queens, was a native of Puerto Rico. He had spent nearly 40 days there reporting after Hurricanes Irma and Maria and had experienced, as he put it, the dire conditions that \u201cdisrupted their lives and led thousands to take that leap of faith\u201d to leave behind their homes for the mainland.\n\nMy reporting was certainly informed by my own experience with storms. I grew up on the Gulf Coast of Texas. I\u2019ve spent hours packed into a minivan with family and the dog, trying to get a couple of hundred miles away, and spent weeks staying with relatives wondering what I would return to. But the scope of the turmoil and uncertainty these families from Puerto Rico faced was well beyond what I knew.\n\nLuis and I were taken by similar observations of the dilemma these families faced: \u201cTry to make it on the mainland, where many have struggled to find jobs and housing,\u201d Luis said, \u201cor return to Puerto Rico, where stability is still elusive.\u201d\n\nMost of the families he interviewed, he said, \u201chad not yet found what they ultimately left their homeland looking for: a sense of stability.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf all the people we met, a young family that Luis found in Queens stuck with me the most. Yanitza Cruz was nearly eight months pregnant; her due date and the expiration date for her family\u2019s FEMA-provided hotel were worryingly close. The family traveled from a remote mountain town to New York using almost all of their savings. Her husband, Joel Garc\u00eda, even panhandled.\n\nBut they maintained an incredible level of optimism. They talked about getting an apartment in New York, and him finding work as a barber. As most of us in New York groan over subway delays, he was astonished at how he could journey across a metropolis for the swipe of his MetroCard. And the family marveled at the generosity they have been shown.\n\nOn a visit to the Puerto Rican Family Institute, they met a maintenance worker who took Mr. Garc\u00eda to a department store and bought every member of the family a jacket. He did not even look at the price tags. His name was Nate. \u201cI\u2019m never going to forget you,\u201d Mr. Garc\u00eda said he told Nate.\n\nOf all that remained uncertain, he and his wife had settled one thing: When she gives birth next month, they plan to name their son Nate.", "title": "What Life Is Like in a Hurricane Hotel", "authors": ["Rick Rojas"]}
